reviews.review: Beautiful spot to visit. This place was beautiful to take photos. Our driver took us to a part of this Rice Terrace where it was nestled inside a village away from the main strip so we are able to take some awesome photos. Good thing was we did not have to pay as it was about a 2min drive from the main strip and it was quiet with a few people. Downfall was the locals are very pushy for you to buy their stuff. Trying to take a video and I had one of the locals tapping me and asking me to buy her stuff. Besides that this place was awesome. Nice place to fly a drone if you have one! :)

Don't waste your time. . If you've not been to a rice paddy before I can imagine it's good. But I don't really understand why you've got to pay to see this one? Because you get to walk around it? While trying to fight off the ladies selling warm drinks and the children trying to cling on to get 'tour' fees. Real touristy. Wouldn't recommend it.

Great site to see. We visited the rice terrace as part of a trip around various highlights in and around Ubud. It is a spectacular sight. We did not do the terrace walk but would plan to do this next time with lots of water, insect repellant and suncream.
Holiday. The Rice Terrace is very beautiful. Arrive early and take small amount of money in note form. We gave 10000 rupees twice when passing through farmers properties.
Beautiful scenery. Amazing scenery and a wonderful trek. Make sure you take plenty of water and be prepared to give a few donations.
Great view. A fantastic place to walk through since rice plays a huge role within the bali culture. Lush green and stunning

Only a quick visit while on a tour but looked amazing. We stopped here on our way to a Jegeg Cycling tour. It was super pretty. We had planned to visit here but after stopping in we decided not to go back. Worth the trip though.
Beautiful view. One of the stops of our Bali Sun Tour. Was a hot day, though great spot to stop and look at the view. Also took some photos at the 'LoveBali' sign :)

Breathtaking!. This is breathtaking!! The walk is a must do! You might want to have sneakers on ( I walked in teva sandals with no problems) as you are climbing up narrow paths. There are locals along the way with huts charging you as you go. Some have water or coconuts, others want you to take a picture with their props! We gave them each a small donation, after all everyone's just trying to make a living!! I also got a bamboo stick from them to help with the climb! Very useful for my knees!! It took us about 1 hour and then we ate lunch at a cafe overlooking the terrace's! By far one of the prettiest places I've seen!!

Hidden Charges. This rice terraces are quite impressive and worth a short visit. However, there are so many hidden "donations" that it feels like a scam. First off, when you drive along the road in front, you get stopped to pay 10,000 each. Not sure where that money goes. We figured it was a ticket. Then you walk into the rice terrace and someone asks for a donation. However, it's a minimum price so not a donation at all. It's 10,000 again. Then you get a bit further and you're asked again. It's mad. I'm all for helping the Indonesian community but just charge for a ticket price and ensure the money is going to the right cause, this just felt like begging.
Awesome Paddy Field. Love the scenery of the paddy field. It was beautiful and the lovey arrangement of the fields. Nice view.

Beautiful but Crowded!. We stopped here on our way to our hotel outside of Ubud. It is lovely but so crowded and very touristy. What we didn't know but quickly found in Bali is that all of the "must do's" are also very touristy and somewhat overhyped. We were there mid-afternoon and it was too hot to really get out and walk, I would recommend going in the morning so that you can enjoy the walk more.

Beautiful landscape. We traveled to Tegalalang as part of an Ubud day trip with Mano Bali Tour Guide. We had a long, scenic drive up to the rice paddies, and stopped at the main Tegalalang view for lunch. We had lunch at a BEAUTIFUL cafe called Alon Alon Cafe. They had small tables along the side of the hill, giving a complete view of the ride paddies. The view is completely breathtaking and it is great to stop here for lunch with a view. However, you would not need to stop her for very long, as there is not much else to see apart from this view. It is a great stop for a few pictures.
Beautiful view. Came here through a tour and I must admitt it had an amazing view. There was even the possibility to walk on the terraces.

Amazing views but quite touristy. This spot offers a perfect Bali photo opportunity with its dramatic views of the rice terraces – we did take a lot of photos. Yet, I’d say it looks quite touristy and not a ‘must-do’ item (maybe it’s because we had visited some rice terraces with a much larger scale in China and other Asian places with less shops nearby). You would need to walk down quite a bit to get into the rice terraces – please do expect your shoes will be all in mud! There are also a few stations / ‘check-points’ with farmers and children who seem pushy to ask visitors to buy postcards, take photos with the farmers or donate – we did buy/donate as there were no way to resist and it was around US$3-5 each. Suggestion is it’s not a must for you to go down to the rice terraces, you can spend more time in the cafes/restaurants nearby to enjoy the wonderful panoramic view instead.

Beautiful place, worth visiting . My family (2 young girls and a baby) and I visited the site last week.Spent 30 min at the area and walked through the terraces. V nice landscape, although it was extremely hot, therefore left after 30 min
Amazing place to visit. If you're visiting Bali, make sure you see a rice terrace. It's the real Bali! Amazing scenary and a great walk to do early in the morning

Afternoon visit. Our guide took as to this place which is really beautiful to see although you do need to be reasonably fit and there are a lot of steps to go up and down. But it's well worth the effort!
Lovely view. - lots of cafes to choose from in the area, we had a few snacks and coffee at Alon Alon- great for a few photos and walking along the rice paddies, 1hr is lots of time to enjoy the place

Unique!. The rice field terraces are pretty cool if it's your first time looking at them. We were there when the rice plants were not yet flowering, so they were fields of gorgeous green. Else at other times they'ed be a field of yellow (flowering, harvest time) or just reflective brown (just planted). The road parallel to the fields are congested with traffic and lined with souvenir shops. Very very touristy and crowded, as with most Bali attractions. Have to trek down dirt/muddy steps sometimes, so wear good shoes if you can. It was in the afternoon that we visited, so it was VERY hot! There will be locals carrying baskets of grass, hoping to take a photo with you with payment of course. This place is near the central Ubud, so visit if you're in the vicinity. Else if you have more time to travel out to the mountains, visit the Jatiluwih Rice fields which are much bigger, more expansive and more breathtaking.
Meh!. I liked the scooter ride from Ubud to here but to tell the truth there are much better rice terraces on the way from Candidasa to Tulamben!!!!
Nice views. Great views of rice terraces. Quintessential Bali. Was not able to do the hike because of weather, but very beautiful to see.

Too crowded!. There are so many better rice terraces to visit. We went on a Monday afternoon and it was packed with tourists. It was pretty, but nothing compared to Jatiluwih. There were many shops along the road with vendors and nowhere to park. Cool to visit, but definitely not relaxing. Visit Jatiluwih instead! It's very large, remote, and there's tons of parking!
Something you have to see. If you are in Ubud, you don't want to miss this place. Most amazing view and most amazing pictures to catch.

Like watching NatGeo TV! Amazing!. This place was one of the most interseting place that I have seen in my life. I am living in Ankara, Turkey. I have visited most of the Europe. But this kind of places are not available near to us. You are in an interesting kind of green. Terraces and walley is very interesting. As all the travellers recomend, the season is very important. We went at the beginning of April and it was wonderful. Try to hire a Taxi for full-day for visit. Combine the rice terrace visit with Volcano and Temple Ulandanu. It takes around 30-40$. On the return way, try to reserve time for visiting wooden furniture stores. They are also very exciting.
Nice place . Really nice view of the rice terrace, but to crowded by noon. You can enjoy a coffe at the local restaurants,prices are a little high for bali.

Memorable. The view of the rice terrace was breathtaking. We went for the rice terrace hike without knowing what to expect. It turned out to be a 1 hour+ hike for us along wet muddy paths. Not the easiest but we were so glad that we did it!

Beautiful Rice Terrace. We checked out the rice terrace as we had heard so much about it. No regrets despite the hot sun. Absolutely gorgeous view but be careful with your steps as we chance upon a snake during the trail. Btw, it will be nice to donate a little to the local farmers whom had managed a good job for the rice terrace. Apart from a very obvious pavilion at the top of the terrace that you are requested to donate a small amount, please also donate to the old farmer at the foot of the terrace, he does not have a tin for collection but this old friendly farmer is located at the bottom of the terrace. Do be a little generous for him.
Beautiful rice terrace . Pretty green color, nice walk on the terraces. Quite busy during the afternoon. Could do with better steps since so many people are paying to go there.

Really Beautiful . Best thing I did in Bali. Have driver take you through the back roads to get there. So worth the drive. Walk the terraces. Stop and have some street food outside the restaurant. The ladies ther are very nice. Stunning views.

Magnificent view w stunning landscape. Beautiful place which you could walk down to rice terrace follow different walking track, unlike Tegalalang which you only allow to stand & take picture from top ... just ensure you bring hat , water, sunblock & comfortable walking shoe .
Worth for the drive

Really cool, best rice terraces I've seen. Really great 30/40 walk around the rice terraces of Bali.
Having seen them in Malaysia and Vietnam they were definitely our favourite.
The walk can be pretty muddy and slippery so take your time.
Amazing view , a absolutely must do tour best by Ebike. Fantastic view, breath taking , have a juice at the restaurant and enjoy this umbeliavabke nature. Bet morning or late afternoon

Stunning landscape. Great place to stop by for some pictures, souvenir shopping and decent local food. There was a cost for us to park which I felt was a bit steep, but they do have to make money somehow...

Definitely worth the visit. . Definitely worth the visit. Never seen rice fields like these. They are very beautiful. However, Very touristy and hot.
You have to pay donations as you walk through the fields to access more and see more of the rice fields. Also beware that you don't actually have to pay 10000 rupiah like I did.

Super view- if you go off the path be prepared for a muddy foot. This is a busy attraction. Shops line the main road. If costs nothing to have a walk down to the river and up the other side, though at one point we were asked to donate to charity. The paths are not well marked. If you do not find a proper path and choose your own route down you are at danger of putting your foot and ankle into thick mud. We saw a number of people do this ( me included). There is plenty of running water to wash off the mud. The slopes on the road side have restaurants. It is a good place to sit and have a coconut and drink. I would advice a walk- we have seen plenty of paddy fields in travelling, rarely getting the opportunity to walk on a terraced slope. You can appreciate the work that goes into constructing, keeping, and using the fields.

Raining but great.. Even to it was raining by the time we were halfway through the fields we had a great time, tho there were people asking us for money when we passed them, sometimes it was like they wouldnt let us pass. They got a bit irritated when we only gave them little (we didnt have much to give on us).
Wonderful viewpoint overlooking the rice paddies. Great view over the rice paddies. About 10km north of Ubud. No need to book a tour, just go there by motorbike.
a must go ! . great walk through rice plantation ! get your camera ready because the view it's breathtaking! green everywhere :)

A nice view, but that's it, just a view.. Our driver stopped by to show us the rice terraces. They are lovely, but it is not a stop that is worth going out of your way. There are some shops there on the other side of the street, but they are nothing special.If you go, be prepared to have kids trying to sell you postcards the entire time.

Beautiful views . Well worth a look. Has lots of steps, we counted 207 down to the bottom then a harsh climb up to the other side in order to get a better view of the rice terraces. Great photo opportunities.

This is rice terraces at it's best. If you want to see good rice terraces then this is a good option. Pay a donation to get further into the terraces and you will get better photos and further away from the tourists.

Beautiful!. Worth the hiking around the little paths and acting like a mountain goat to see these - really beautiful. Even if it's hot go as far into the fields as you can it's worth it!Lots of shops trying to sell tourists stuff as is everywhere and lots of pleading children.You do need to pay entrance ticket then pay donations more, the further you walk through the fields. I went through 2 donation shacks although I saw 2 more. Good place to get rid of a few 2000 or 5000 notes :) There was also an old lady with baskets of grass who seemed to be working but actually was just taking photos with all the tourists and taking between 5000-10,000 approx per person. Got some cool photos with her so I didn't mind and I gave her 5000. You just give what you feel my guide said otherwise she will take much more!I wore jandals which was hard to mountain goat in, so I took them off and went bare feet, it's just smooth dirt and was quite nice going barefoot especially as some parts were muddy and I just washed my feet in their little waterfalls. Fab for photos, lots of people there but not too many so you could get a photo without people in the background.
Amazing view. Amazing view on the rice terrasses, we had not to much chance because it was a bit foggy. Very touristic.
Rice Field. This is the place to take some nice photos. But traffic there can be horrendous at certain time of the day.

What a nice and peaceful place!. My morning resolution was to walk the 11km from Ubud center to the rice terraces! It is feasible if you want to feel the sun, smell the humid ground and frangipane fragrance and listen to the song of the birds. Once you arrive at the terrace your reward is waiting for you: a panoramic view with various tones of green that moves with the wind and the course of the sun. Go down the terrace but watch out for slippery and wet tiny path then climb all the way to the other side of the hill. You will be asked for a provision that is used to maintain the path and the bridge. Try to go inside the woods and sit still and listen to the wind... you will not want to make it back!

Nice view. It is a must stop. We went with thekids and only went down a few terraces vut you get the beautiful view and photos. Some people get to go further but it was difficult for us with a 2 year old. You can have lunch in one of the restaurant there with spectacular view.

Nice but not awesome. Got there a little late after scootering thru the local roads around the area. View is nice, but I was expecting more !Would be nice to chillout at the cafes overlooking the terrace if we were there earlier. We arrived about 20mins before sunset, so still managed to catch a little of the evening glow.

Tourist trap . This rice terrace near ubud is included in all the day tours. The terrace itself is amazing, if you are short of time visit it for sure, the views are great and you can walk around and take a couple of good pictures. The problem is that it is way too crowded, packed with tourists and shops and bars and locals that won't leave you alone trying to sell you postcards and all sort of souvenirs. So if you are looking for a quite place to get away from ubud's fuzz, well, this is not it. As i said, if you are time restricted, do not miss it, but we visited jatiluwih the next day and we enjoyed it so much more.
Beautiful must see in Ubud . Been a couple of times. Such a lovely view. Great little shops around as well selling local crafts. Rained when we were there which made it extra fun!

Beauty just outside Ubud. Went here by e-bike and was totally worth the travel. Even though we already saw several ricefields in Java, it was still stunnig. When we were there, there were hardly any tourists and great weather, which made our experience even better.
So if you have a good bike or a scooter, go for sure!

Walk Walk Walk . This place is nice, there is so many places where you can make nice photos, enter is around 20.000IDR for person but on the way is many ppl who want money because you walk on their Terrace... Take a water away, there is just one or two places with drinks

A must see in vali. Spectacular. Amazing view and beautiful. There will be a lot of tourists, there's nothing to do about that, but you should try walking further in and up. If you go there with an organized driver or trip make sure they don't take you to one of these over prices lunch buffet. If you are going to stop for lunch, find a place your self Otherwise, not much to say about rice field except of the obvious beauty if it. Definitely worth the trip!
Popular Rice terraces near Ubud. Absolutely excellent to do sport and camera shoot here. To get passed you must to give a donation to the owner.
Very special . Amazing place. Good to stroll through or just sit and watch and enjoy the greenery. Easy to get to from Ubud. Early morning is best I think.

Pretty to Look at. The Rice Terraces were gorgeous but mostly for some pictures and to move on. A lot of people cycled or walked through them and seemed to enjoy that. We were more interested in seeing the temples and other wonders of Bali.

Overrated and crowded, only worth seeing around wet season. We have seen this place years ago, during the wet season and we liked it. The last time we visited, is was very dry and didn’t look anything like before or the mainstream pictures. It is also much too crowded now. Still, it is worth a short stop on the way between Ubud and any of the northern tourist attractions (e.g. Lake Batur, Kintamani). However, I would not go here just for the Rice Terraces, but rather stop on the way while visiting other places in the area. You can find Rice Terraces much closer to Ubud (e.g. Penestanan or Campuhan), although a bit less spectacular, but far less crowded and accessible directly by foot from your Ubud accommodation. We skipped it entirely this time.

Needs Good Cardio, Money money money!. You must have a good cardio to walk this terraceIts much more vertical then others and in the middle of some valley so you need to go down first and go up for otherside.Which needs good cardio. Or you can just watch terraces from top.You should wear sandals not slippers because ground is very muddy and slippery. I have been inside mud till my knee few times and need to clean up some water ( most probably polluted ) few times. So watch your step. In this places locals love money. You pass a bridge to other side and they ask for money for the "maintenance" of bridge which is made of scrap metal and wood stuff probably collected around and sticked together :) On the top side they placed some rice baskets and when you take photo owner of plantation comes and ask for money. When you go up on other side there is some kind of "cafe" and they ask for money. When you are in top some people try to sell you coconut in middle of rice terrace and asks for money.So its all about money here. And they say its some kind of "donation". Most probably the only word they know in EnglishBut need to be cautious about insects because this places is crowded with them. Some bite my wife and we have been to BIMC hospital in same night :)We had good time anyway, a must see place but dont forget to bring some small Rupiah like 1000-5000-10.000 because you will need them till otherside :D + For scenery and beauty of place - For payment in every corner and tricky locals
Soak in natural beauty. Yes, it allows you to enjoy a beautiful natural Bali landscape . Before coming here I had no idea that even paddy feilds can be so picturesque!!

Wonderful. Don't stay arround the road but go into the rice field and discover the other terrace by walking on the trekking road that goes to the other side.You'll feel like you have the landscape only for you and the time will stop for a while.Magical moments, I recommand!For the tolls, you don't have to pay 10 000 or 20 000roupiah every 100meters, you can just forced or pay 2000 even for 2 people.

Spectacular view- definitely something to see. We made a stop here on our tour. As mentioned in another review- a guy in a jacket walked over pretty quickly to ask about parking money- as far as I saw- my guide did not pay. We went to a lookout and I took some pictures- I did not want to go down into the fields- although many tourists did. There was an older gentleman with baskets - tourists asked for pictures with him and the baskets- my tour guide reminded them that he was there for photos and relied on donations- which I thought was good. I love the glass bowls draped over wood- so I bought a small one here at one of the shops for 200 000. Probably way over price- but I saw it as helping the community ;-)

Pretty scenery great for pictures!. Great landscape to take pictures and very unique experience that you can't find anywhere else. However, it is super touristy (but who cares? We're tourists!) and gets very crowded during the day. For this, I highly recommend coming here in the morning before beating the rush that may drive in from outside areas like Kuta and Seminyak.

Do not excite. The terracing and the natural irrigation of water to achieve the maximum usage of the land to grow rice is a feat in itself. The beautiful land scape it creates, with the vivid green colour combine to give a good sight.

Rice paddy day out. What a lovely place. The only negative is locals hitting you up for money to either maintain their bridge, which won't need any maintenance for years to come! Or just pay money because they want you to. Great visit but the locals can make it a little negative.

Amazing scenery. A must see!Spectacular scenery! Beautiful landscape.A feast for the senses!We loved this place. I think it was only approx $AU1:00 fee to get in.Lots of steep steps down and up but well worth the effort.Totally loved this place.
beautiful!. really nice, unfortunately they had just harvest the crops and it was empty, but still really worthwile!

Family hols. Fantastic views. Breathtaking. A must if you visit bali. Some areas were difficult to walk cause it had rained and some areas was quite muddy. Sensible footwear was needed. Only negative that payment to visit there went up in October 3 folds. But nevertheless a beautiful place to visit.
Overrated I think.... I think they are not as grand as they make out to be. I saw some larger terrraces at Samaya, Ubud. Anyone it is ticked off
Totally useless place with charge to see the fields. Paddy fields are visible everywhere but still here people charge to see the fields. It is just a generic coffee shop area with a paid ticket.

Breathtaking views . A very nice morning out, not far from Ubud. We rented a scooter and drove one very easy straight road to get there. Be warned: this can either be a very cheap day out if you know the following... As we parked a man in a fluorescent jacket came up to us and some others asking for parking money. We said we were just going to look round before we stayed, but the other couple paid straight away. We then just walked off to the paddies. This fee isn't legitimate and you do not have to pay to park on the street. Just avoid the man and continue your day. Also on our way in, some girls told us they were annoyed that around the paddies there are many huts that ask for donations for you to continue and they used a lot of their money just to pass through. Knowing this, we didn't follow the sign that said 'trek starts here ->' and instead went the other direction, exploring the paddies freely. We only ran into one hut where we were happy to donate. Although they ask for a large amount, you can just pay what you have just don't show them you have anymore!

True agricultural art. If you wanna avoid the big crowds you have to go in the morning, but the terraces are amazing when the sun falls on them. The viewing platform gives you a good look, I'm hand in hand with nature so didn't wanna walk on the actual terraces but it is an option for a cheeky pic.
Beautiful. A must see in Bali. I had no idea how rice was grown and this was an extremely interesting site. Beautiful vistas make for great photographs!

Have to see this ! Beautiful . Absolutely fantastic and amazing
Have to do it !
The rice terrasse is above the center and quite close
20 to 30 min to go you can walk into it and lots of shops like tourist gift shops

A nice stop with pretty look-out. We were taken on a tour up to a volcano look-out, a coffee farm etc. and just before dusk we stopped at this very pretty spot. There were people slip sliding in locals' backyards, but we opted to take photos from near the road.

Visit early!. Got to the terrace around 9.00a and was not crowded at ALL! Did not make the short trek around the paddies, but took some wonderful pictures from the look out at the start of the trek!! Great for some wonderful photos!
Wow. Great afternoon - climbing the terraces was amazing !! Very tiring but worth it !! Lots of little cafes to grab a snack 😁

Beautiful landscape. By far the best rice terrace around, came here twice. All proceeds for the village entry,& parking go to the local community , more money inside for a bridge and people selling stuff, i did 'buy' a couple of photos with the woman with the baskets on her shoulder, she let my son have a go, worth the 10k. The tracks get slippy so take your time.

Hikers walk through the fields is a must!. After seeing several rice terraces the view here will not be very special, but taking a walk through the fields will be! After the rain it was quite slippery but that made it even more fun. The hike is took us about an hour through a fairytale like landscape. Def worth the visit!

Beautiful but over developed. These rice terraces are gorgeous for sure and easily accessible from Ubud if your time is limited. But there are many other less touristy ones not much further away that make for a better experience. If you go, go in the late afternoon - that way the sun will be behind you for photos.

Go early avoid the crowds. Visited via Ubud with a taxi guide. We arrived early to avoid the crowds and the heat. There is no cost to go in but there are areas where its expected to give a donation to pass.You need to take water and be prepared for a lot of climbing around. Best not to wear flip flops as the ground can be muddy and you need grip! Views are stunning and this is probably the best rice terrace in bali. Probably need about a hour to get round the main areas.
Nice, especially when sunny. Today, the weather was sunny and we drove through Tagalalang without planning it. It was very nice, but a clearly preferred the Jatiluwih Rise Terrasse.

Out of this world. Even more prettier than in the pictures, rice fields are the must see thing in Bali. Be shure to take hiking boots or good shoes because there is lot's of mud, and it is not short hike. Very important - there is no entrance fee, but they expecting for you to give "donations" at almost every step, and at the exit there was a man who will not let you get out if you do not give him some money, so be careful not to spend all of your planned "donation" at the very beggining.

Amazing views, amazing photos. Be prepared for a lot of walking up stairs, down stairs and through some rough terrain (muddy uneven paths). Suggest wearing appropriate footwear if doing the entire walk. Lovely view from top.
Amazing views. We visited the rice terraces early morning and were quite amused by the lush green views of the rice fields. A must visit spot in Ubud.

Hard to find. We struggled a lot to find it, no signs pointing to the exact spot where to enter. After whioe somebody finally told us to go to Loji cafe. When you are under the cafe, turn right, around the buildings leads the path. Not the easiest and can be slippery when wet. Unfortunatelly we had bad weather, raining, had to wait it out in the (expensive) cafe. Terraces are beautiful but be sure u have nice weather, I would go for sunset and bring umbrella when it is sunny. Can be really hot and there is not much shade on the terraces.

Very busy. The view from the road is excellent but as mentioned there are tourists and hawkers everywhere.Probably remains on the must do list but there are better options to spend your time and money in the area
Good Photo Opportunity/ No need to walk it. As the title says, this is a good photo stop on your Ubud trip, but there’s no need to walk the fields. We took our best photos from the top of the fields.

A scenic beauty... These fields shouldn't be missed when in ubud. Being from a country where we see paddy fields in almost all the country side, thought this would be another such field, still gave a shot and what awaited us was this criss cross trekking paddy fields which we don't get to see in my country..A trek through this field with 5000IDR, would let you take some of the best photo shoot and admire what man made nature looks like..Once done with the trekking, you can end up with a bite of snacks/coffee from one the restaurants overlooking these paddy fields.. And it rained after we finished our trekking which was even more amazing!!!

Nice terrace. This place looks really nice. The walk isn't very easy but not too difficult either. It's more difficult to do it when it's very hot and sunny so maybe early in the morning would be better. It's a bit annoying how you cannot get past of certain places without offering a donation. I do understand these people live in difficult conditions but applying an entrance fee would be a more elegant way to receive some more money. You have to pay the parking, although I am sure there are ways to avoid this but we weren't aware of this at the time we arrived there.

A nice place to stop by for a walk. The rice terraces were nice, but also a bit commercialized, which was somewhat disappointing. However, it is nonetheless worth a quick visit to walk around and take in the lush, green surrounding in the middle of a busy area.

Stunning. Stunning rice terraces in Ubud.
You'll see the typical landscapes that you expect to see when visiting Bali

Beautiful scenery . Rented a scooter and drove to the terrace from the centre of Ubud! Took about 15 to 20 minutes so was a lot better than paying for a taxi or tour! The terrace themselves are beautiful and a great way to spend a few hours!

Nice village - with taking time to stop and even enjoy a drink or walk. It is definitely a tourists village.
But the view is really nice..
You'll find view, drinks and local crafts in the same place.
Note that you can get much cheaper prices than Ubud for same objects.

Nice tourist trap. Very nice scenery - definitely try to go early morning to avoid crowds.It's a shame it's such a tourist trap though, everyone there seems to rattle a 'donations' box at you and there are even small children selling postcards - tainted the experience slightly for me.Worth going for a good photo or two but not a highlight of Ubud, in my opinion

Wedding proposal. I have done my wedding proposal the 10th of September there, one girl have seen me doing it then she took us in picture.I gave you my email adress maybe you lost the sheet.Anyway if you see that post please contact me, it would be awesome for us...Thank you so much though.
Amazing.. So green and lush. Great thing to do early in morning and then stop at the little hotel/resort/spa on way back to downtown Ubud.
Beautiful . This place is one of the most breathtakingly beautiful places I have seen.Worth a stop. It's what they use for tourist brochures of Bali.

Nice spot. Hawkers were a pain. . This is a great spot. Great for those who love photography and I guess hydro engineering. The hawkers selling there wares (postcards, fridge magnets and sarongs) were a pain and although they meant well really made the experience a 3 and not a 5. I completely understand that there is a local economy but I ended up just buying a sarong as a gift to have them finally leave me alone so I can take a photo or two. Not a fan of being badgered. Anyway, a very very busy spot so if you can go either very early in the morning if if not then then late in the afternoon however it's more likely to be raining then. If you book with Mr. Bedu's Tours he can take you to some terraces that are hardly occupied and you can actually get some photos that are almost tourist free. Certainly a great attraction but in my opinion don't be too disappointed if you miss out on it.

Amazing. . My wife and I were taken to Tegalalang on a private tour from Alaya hotel. The private part of it was we were driven in a taxi and then shown where to walk down and where not to go when in the terrace. We were told at certain points within the terrace you need to contribute a few IDR's to the farmers. They have these little enter and exit points. The farmers were cool, they didn't ask for a specific amount or pressured you into giving more. The walk within the terrace is not for the unfitty within you. It does take it out of you especially if it's a hot or a humid day. Our visit was a humid day and Wow did we sweat. My wife is fairly fit but she refused to walk certain paths because she felt it was unsafe. Unfortunately we didn't explore the entire terrace but from what we did see it was inspiring. My Advice:Take waterPut on mosquito repellentWear a hatTake some IDR'sWear trainers that you don't mind getting a little muddyBe prepared to sweat
Beautiful but touristy. We know there are many tourists in Bali but I swear they unleashed half of them in this area. It is truly amazing but so are many other rice paddies in Bali.

Fascinating look at terraced rice fields!. We had a great time walking through the rice fields on that hot and sunny day. There were tickets to be bought at IDR10k. Worth it as the feeling and the place is amazing!
Stay a while and browse through the fields, with the sun rising and just going through the multi tiers. Worth the travel and the climb.
Beautiful site. We stopped here briefly and took photos. Must stop to at least see when traveling in Ubud! Breathtaking.

Spot of marriage photography . It requires some hiking while you will be enjoyed the scenery of the rice field, is best time to visit while the sun is rising, the air were so fresh !
Have a cup of local Balinese coffee after !

AMAZING VIEW... A MUST VISIT.. but follow this view tips to make it better... Tegalalang rice terrace is perfect view for visit, pictures and walked down over the paid field... very beautiful and very nice.if you are in bali, this one of a must since it gives you the experience of "real indonesia"when entrance the village, each car will charge 10000 Rupiah (around 1$) per person and you get ticket. make sure you pay with quite big print, so you can exchanges a lot of small money since there is some spot in this area that you have to put "Donation" another 2k, 5k or 10k Rupiah/ person depends on what you have or you cannot keep going, so better save some small prints.picture with the woman/man is not free. they will offer you to take picture with them in paddy field, or with their props such as the paid basket etc, its quite recommended and quite a good souvenir for you! but to avoiding awkwardness when they ask you money, keep in mind its not free, at least you can give them about 10k/person who takes picture and they usually tell you after... (one woman ask for 20k but you can always bargain).i love take this picture, specially with the one old man that very kind. some of them also sell the coconut leaf hat, its PURELY HANDMADE and i am support their local creation. they sell it for 50k/hat, since i am indonesian, i am bargain to 30k-35k/hat (i got to bargain because i buy 2 hats :)) but PLEASE don't bargain for less than that! its a purely handmade and consider that this 3 dollars might help them. this is very good hat and it last long, even when its dry and become brown, its still can be use! and its cute too!i suggest you take some coconut water during hot day! the coconut water can replace your body ion (body liquid) faster than water...! Try the young coconuts water from real coconut, and do not only drink the water! do you know that you can scoop and eat the coconut inside with spoon... (you might know or might not, my fiancé did not know, and i am happy to inform him)use comfortable Shoes and Clothes, the path needs some climb and hike. Use Mosquito repellent since there is a LOT in Indonesia, and if you don't get use to tropical sun use SUN BLOCK at least Spf 50! its very HOT!

Postcard delight. Terraces drowned in water and lonely paths from tourists hiding away from the heavy rain made the perfect scenery for us. Take your time and walk all around it. There is a postcard picture around every corner. Impressed.
Holiday. Over all , worth visiting if not very busy. Bring an umbrella as it can rain a lot. Every one has to pay a fee to enter the area so bring small denominations of the local currency.

Nice to look at, money asked for everywhere!. I've wanted to see these rice fields for a while now, but had no idea what I was in for. Sure, the view is beautiful, bit first we paid to park the car, then some donation for a bridge being built, then another guy asking for money both going up the fields and coming back which really ruined the experience. Just get the photo from near the road side and carry on.

Nothing special. Compering to endless rice terraces of Northern Vietnam this is nothing special. It would make for a nice evening walk if not for the owners of the land asking for donations every turn you take. The land is split among four owners and everyone is collecting donations if you want to pass through. It would be best if they agreed on one fee and colected once at the start. After we encountered the third gate we turned around and went home , it was not worth it. If you pay twice you can turn towards the spring which is free, but since it is free there is a lot of trash around.
Unorganized . Fields are not too big. Place very unorganized. Every few steps someone asking for money. Should be only entry fees so people can truly enjoy the walk.

Must visit but beware of mosquitos!. This is a must see if you visit Bali. Bring comfortable shoes and bug repellant!I got bit 20 times during my 2 hour stay here - no joke. I'm just a mosquito magnet and I'm allergic as well.The view was amazing and definitely worth visiting! I'd be very careful walking around here if it rains or immediately after.

nice but seen nicer. the place is amazing. unfortunately when we were there, it was raining that day so we had to hike in the mud. although the area and view is amazing, however it is somehow crowded at some times as it is famous. you will enjoy it but don't over expect something other than the view. it is a hiking activity and a nice time to spend in the outdoors

Excellent attraction while in Ubud area!. Excellent attraction while in Ubud area! Beautiful scenry, got some drinks at the cafe close by there to enjoy the view. Very reasonable prices. Great place to take photos. Must go to this place if you are in the Ubud area! :)

Amazing view of Bali's most beautiful rice terraces. When you make a trip from Ubud to Kintamani, you'll possibly pass Tengalalang, but take a break overhere and enjoy the beautiful view. Also lots of places for drinks and food in het neighborhood for very reasonable prices.

Worth a visit but take mosquito repellent. Good view and a great place to enjoy a panoramic view of a true rice terrace.Yes, it's very touristy, but what holiday destinations are not touristy.*Wear shoes/ trainers, I saw many people lose their flip-flops going up and down the terrace.

only a rice terrace nothing special for local tourist from indonesia. only a rice terrace nothing special for local tourist from indonesia. just go anywhere else rather than to this place. or maybe just rent a bike and drive surrounding ubud area

Stunning must see. This rice terrace is one of my favourite places in Bali, its so beautiful and unusual. I have been three times now as i love it so much. I prefer to go morning-midday, it's nicer when it's less busy. Wear appropriate shoes, it's a bit of a climb, food and drinks are expensive so bring some water, you will get very hot during the walk!

Beautiful scenery but cruel to animals. If you care for animal welfare you may want to look in to the treatment of civet cats before visiting as the coffee they sell there is made by these animals in a pretty awful way. Can get nice views of rice paddies elsewhere without supporting that particular coffee trade

beautiful views but too touristy and spoiled the experience. Ok first up the rice fields are picturesque but it is so crowded with tourists and in such a confined space it was an average experience at best and spoilt by harrassment by hawkers selling all manner of associated gifts etc. The rice paddys can be seen all over Bali and there are other ways to see these in more relaxed, enjoyable and natural surroundings.

Into the green . My dream came true! After years that I was dreaming to come to Bali and get into the natural environment of the country, finally I got the opportunity. The rice fields are something that must to be seen . Going around with my scooter I "had the pleasures " to get lost. A pleasure because I saw small villages out of the typical tourist paths and I have experienced the beauty of the country, the beauty of the culture and the beauty of the Balinese.

Simply stunning!. This place looks amazing in person! Try to go late in the day, because sunrise not only makes it look even more beautiful, but you also don't get bothered by locals, trying to constantly sell you stuff.

Stunning view!. We arrived at the rice terrace around 9:30am, it was already quite busy but not too much. It is very very hot here with little shade so be prepared for that. It had rained the night before so quite muddy, bring reasonable shoes that you don't mind getting dirty. We saw lots of people getting flip flops stuck in the mud! Oooops. The view is like nothing we have ever seen before, very beautiful! We didn't get stopped once or asked for a donation by anyone. We passed a farmer who had lots of rice in his baskets who we had a photo with and he asked for some money which we think is reasonable. We weren't forced for a photo. We stayed for around a hour or so, walking down and looking around taking lots of photos. It's rather difficult getting back up to the top if it has been raining but you can get great pictures staying at the top! Shops at the top selling food and drink. Well worth a visit! We stopped at a coffee plantation on the way back which I would highly recommend!
Nice Views. A nice thing to see near ubud. Great photo ops. Cute bunnies along the way! But leave extra time as we got lost trying to get out! Can be like a maze!
Overrated . Gah. So many tourists. Really tacky and not nearly as beautiful as many of the rice fields you drive past on the back roads north of Ubud. Couldn't wait to leave.

If you want to see amazing rice terraces go to Jatiluwih Village. The rice terraces are lovely but really crowded, hard to find parking, and the area is small. Great if you are combining with other places on a day trip out of Ubud. Lots of opportunity for shopping along the roadside.
Great view of Rice Fields. We stopped off on a tour for a quick lunch at a restaurant overlooking the rice fields and had a very nice meal with great views of the rice paddy's.

Rice Terraces. Amazing place to visit. Best to go and explore by walking down and up the other side to get the real perspective of the terraces. Early morning best before ti gets too hot.Be prepared for the farmers along the way to ask for money for the maintenance of their bridges. You need to be active and mobile to walk the terraces.

It's ok. There's so many awesome rice fields in the area making this place ok for me. There's not that much to see, but it's a very cool place to have have lunch at least. We did not walk into the terraces. I think that would probably be more exciting.
Crowded but pretty from afar. We tried to go, but it was very crowded and difficult to find parking, so ultimately, we only passed by and saw it from afar.
Nothing much to see . There is nothing much to see hereMaybe nice photo in front of the cave if you have a phobia of closed places i advise you not to go Specially with they have there smoke inside

Great one. To all my friend who come to Bali you have to visit this place tegalalang.Tegalalang is one of the best place to enjoy the great panorama with the rice terass and you can enjoy lunch there with the view was awesome.I do little tour with my client from all people around the world so lets join me

Not as touristy as I'd dreaded. We stopped here as part of a cycling tour so we didn't walk down into the terraces, rather we just observed from up top. A bride and groom were having their photo taken in the terraces which was a nice touch. The view was great and the rice fields themselves were quite amazing. I had read several reviews saying how tacky these terraces were with tack tourist shops lining the road from where view the terraces.......but the shops had been lining the road constantly since we'd left Ubud. I saw it more as "suburbia" having reached Tegalalang.
Very picturesque . Great views of the rice paddies. We booked a private driver for the day and visited with him- he took us to a much quieter place with no tourists. Worth the visit

Great scenery. These rice paddies are laid out in beautiful cascading concentric beds. A great view with good photo opportunities. It was unfortunate that guides are not obvious and so we only got to look and not learn
Stunning place. I loved it!!!!! The view is simply stunning, a must place to see in Ubud. You can have a drink in one of the cafés overlooking the field.
Hyped up. The place was very green and there were rice terraces but I expected it to be huge, covering a vast area which it wasn't. Not worth the long drive there in my opinion.
Stunning terraces. The rice terraces of tegalalang are gorgeous! Great photo opps all around. It was amazing to see such beauty

The View. Amazing view! You can walk the terraces if you'd like too. Make sure to rent a scooter and drive around Ubud freely and discover other rice terraces that aren't as touristic but are as beautiful as this one!
Gorgeous. A beautiful rice terrace, definitely a must see. It was quite a climb, though, and very hot and humid, so go early if you can! The path can be a bit tricky, so wear some good shoes.
Worth a visit on your scooter. It's a great picture from the cage there but the more we explored Central Bali, the more we saw that there were quite a few places that had terraced rice fields

Small rice fields and a tourist trap. Very disappointing. Find some other rice field location.. Of all the tourist hotspots in Bali we really wanted to visit a beautiful rice terrace area to take some photos and soak in the beauty. We were expecting it to be the highlight of our trip. What a massive let down. It was very touristy and very small. It was hard to take a photo without getting a tourists head in the photo. We were gutted. I had to confirm with the driver that we were actually at the right rice field because it was so disappointing. Perhaps he did take us too the wrong spot!There were a lot of children begging you to buy postcards etc and there was hardly any room to move to take photos. The rice field view is only in one direction. As our driver pointed out, if you walk down into the rice fields or walk to the other side of the rice fields and look back, you will have a view of the street and not a perfect rice field view. Our driver told us to take photos of the rice fields with the shops and road behind us. It took us quite some time to drive there and we felt our time would have been spent better elsewhere. Next time we will try the Jatliluwih Rice fields instead. I think they would be worth the extra effort.Overall, if you have other places to visit in Bali, don't bother having the Tegalalang Rice fields high on your to do list.

Pretty and a nice walk. Nice little walk across the rice terrace valley and some nice views and photo opportunities. You can walk it yourself if you want but probably easier to just pay one of the local guides to take you around. Super cheap and nice to give back to the locals.Some dining restaurants around overlooking the terraces. Not the highest quality of food but good enough if hungry.

Stunning, concentrated and little-touristy. Visiting rice field is usually more rural and hectic experience than visiting Tegalalang rice terrace which is situated right besides a Main road near Ubud (No hike or even a stroll to see view). The cafe's inside shops have sprung which offer decent coffee with a view. The overall panorama is stunning and concentrated. The setting while not very rural and authentic, it certainly is worth a visit and enjoyable.
Great view. Beautiful panoramic rice terrace. No booking or anything required. To go on to the terrace a small donation is required.

Shame it rained. Got here in the pouring rain so we did get to see the rice fields from the terrace but could not walk around them due to slippery mud and rather wet conditions. Can see how on a warm day this would be a good activity. Lots of restaurants round here offering local food
Best terrace rice in Bali. This terrace is so ammazing,..one of the top human creation.must see when you are arround ubud, a beautifull scenery..thanks

Awesome!. Concentrated on one place :) You can take a short (30-60min) walk and enjoy beautiful views over rice terraces. Be aware that people are not just asking you for donation because they are lazy but because there is no entrance fee and they are actually letting you step on their property. We did not know it and after 5th guy asked for donation we were quite angry at that moment.
Rice terrace. Stunning vie of rice terrace its located near the central of ubud , its take a few munite from ubud, the road quite well !!

Breathtaking. Our tour guide took us here and it was totally breathtaking. We could't believe our eyes! It was so big and full of Indonesian culture. Just a tip, Put on some tough shoes because the pathways in these rice fields are horrible. But it was a unforgettable experience.

Nice, but a tourist trap. Took a 1/2 day excursion and this was one of the stops along the way. Dominated by hawkers, some of whom are a bit pushy, contrary to the very polite culture. You can walk among the terraces, but with so many people visiting at the same time, kind of difficult totaled nice photos. I preferred the self-directed terrace walk that begins at the Starbucks in Ubud.

Spectacular views. We had a driver for a day and asked to take us to see some interesting things, we aren't that sort of tourist that has to see all these sort of things, but we were really impressed with the beauty of a traditional rice terrace.

Manzara olağanüstü & extraordinary views. Fotoğraf çekmek için çok güzel bir yer. Spor ayakkabınız olmalı. Büyük bir alan. Biraz yoruluyorsunuz.
&
a very nice place to take pictures. Sports should be your shoes. A large area. Are you a little tired.

Over rated touristy site. Not a bad place if this is going to be your first time at a rice terrace. Otherwise, this is just one those many touristy and highly commercialized places in Bali. If you are genuinely interested in learning more about rice field, there honestly isn't information about the subject here unless you have a guide with you. While we were on our way to the terrace, we actually happened to pass by some farmers and their rice fields. One of them was kind enough to show me how he diverted water into the field. This experience, to me, was a much more enriching one than this over hyped rice terrace!
Simply Beautiful. A must see place to stop and take in the picturesque beauty of the rice terraces and to appreciate the Balinese culture of ricefarming.

Fantastic place for sunrise. as most of the time in Bali the secret is getting up early. It´s just about 25 minutes from Ubud by scooter. Take your time and walk down and in between the terraces. We were only 3 couples for sunrise. The moment, when the first rays are lightning the terraces was just amazing. We haven´t been asked to pay any "fees" or donations.Of course, don´t forget to bring your camera :)
What a charming place. Really beautiful place.Trekking activity, requires a couple of hours.Is free, but you are invited to give a donation.A must in Bali

Very nice view . Don't take a tour, way to expensive. Just rent a scooter and drive yourself, it's only 50000 / day. The view is breath taking, but not suitable for sunset atmosphere, because it is in a valley and because if that will just not look as good as in full daylight.

Beautiful!. Stunning, can't not visit! It was one of the only things I really wanted to see in Bali and my wish was well and truly granted with this. You could spend hours walking up and down the hillsides winding your way through the terraces, there are viewing platforms each side and plenty of small warungs and cafes to stop and have something to eat or drink. So glad we visited this place. The Bali Purina coffee plantation just up the road was excellent too and well worth a visit!

Stunning!. We had a driver drop us near the cafes and show us the walk across to the terraces. It was absolutely wonderful to see how these terraces work with them being farmed by the locals. Do make sure you have some small notes for the bridge crossings and to give to the farmers if you take photos. Definitely worth a visit!

Rice Terrace. We hired a scooter and found our way there. It was well worth the trip as it is absolutely beautiful, you might see a lot of people at times however this does not ruin the experience. Beware the locals at different points asking for donations, after giving one we refused to give any further. You just need to be firm with them, also they should not demand a certain amount as it is purely a donation and most of the time they are taking a chance.

Beautiful sight. Fantastic views, go there! But again, it is Bali, so please be aware of that there are a lot of stairs/steps everywhere. And also be prepared for small kids who begging you to buy different things.

scenic view. well...its 40 mins ride from ubud if u rent a bike ....to tegalalang rice terrace,along the way you see local shops of different kind of architecture and design stuff .the road is quite good to ride byAbout rice terrace its a good adventure trip ...its good for trekking so better wear your sport shoes,cause i was in my flip flopits a diffrent kind of rice field...cause its grown on the mountain so its a great view to see after the walk you can go to cafe and relax with best view .

Tourist haven. Visited the rice terrace on my way from another attraction and had a quick stopover. Lots of tourists. Didn't really have the time to explore the fields so took some pics from the top. WiFi is available in most shops and restaurants. Cooled off with a drink from a giant coconut. It seemed that a sweetner was added to the coconut milk though. Shops selling gifts and souvenirs. Bargain tip: if you are told an item is worth say 100R, then it should be between 20 and 40R. Use the formula x (price)/4☺☺☺☺

Crowded but beautiful,. A very busy stop to look,at the terraces and marvel at the beauty. There are many Cafes to relax at and this is an easy place to spend an hour or two,soaking in the scenery. Only downside the number of street stalls and hawkers

Vitamin for my eyes. Maybe this is one of stunning view that i ever seen. Tegalalang rice terrace located in ubud bali. I drove motorcycle for 4 hours from my hotel in nusa dua bali. Such a long ride but when i saw the view is very worth it. Maybe my picture will give you clear discribe the beauty of this place. If you want to go here i suggest you not in rainy seasons. The activity that you can try at this place are. Eat with the view from cafe around tegalalang, or spa . If you like to walk in rice field you can a track in rice field. In tegalalang also had art market. The price is cheeper than in kuta or seminyak.
Loved the rice fields!. I loved the place, very nice view for photos and interesting way to see how rice is grown there. Definitely would go back again!

GOD's creature.... Very beautifull places. Rice terrace view. Only green colour that you see in this area with a lot of cafe before you go to the entrance. The best time to visit this place before 12pm. Because start 12pm the sun too bright. It's not good for your photo. Nice place, very good decorated terrace.

Great trek and stunning rice terrace views . Stunning views of the rice terraces. A bit touristy so if you are looking to trek through some of the rice fields without the crowds you may want to arrange with a local or tour guide for the area. It is definitely worth seeing though even if you don't want to trek down you can see the views without walking through the terraces. We ate lunch at a nice little restaurant at the top before we started the trek down so we had some time to sit and enjoy the view. There are a few restaurant choices at the top along with some local vendors selling which is typical for any of the tourist areas. Great experience to see the infamous Tegallalang terraces!

Rice terrace. The view in tegalalang rice terrace is overrated and we are quite disappointed as the place is not as big as we expected..the place is also very commercial and crowded with tons of tourists..

Amazed again!. Went there again after 2 years and again I was mesmerized by the beautiful rice terraces!!!This place is very relaxing and peaceful... You just need to avoid the kids asking for money against postcards. They actually say that it is to pay their school fees... Not sure if true or not but they can be quite insisting and aggressive. Just keep cool and enjoy the view!!!!

Beautiful. As touristy as the place can be, it is a must do in Ubud. no other rice fields are as beautiful as Tegalalang. Make sure you have comfy shoes on to climb stairs and not so easy steps (if you decide you want to walk all the way), also carry change as locals ask you to pay contribution fees at least twice and a bottle of water when its humid.
Rice fields. Very nice,but there is alot of stairs to get up and down. Gets very slippery up the top so can be a bit scary. Worth the effort but if not fit i would take photo from the top.

A visit to the past. We went to this very pleasant area. It was very nice to see, but quite crowded. The terraced rice fields were amazing. We didn't walk down them to explore, but they looked beautiful and definitely an example of how life used to be.

Money money money. The rice terraces are nice to look out on especially if you stop for food. But you have to pay every so often if you want to walk through them. Firstly 10,000rp for a ticket which 50% goes to the farmer and the other 50 to the conservation effort which seems fair enough. But once you walk through you will be stopped and asked to pay donations which are not optional. Its a very frustrating thing and certainly put me off walking through as id already paid for a ticket but yet still had to pay. Made more annoying by the fact our guide for the day made no mention of this. So just be warned.

Not worth it. The entire place seems to be hyped unnecessarily. Even after paying an entrance fee, you will be stopped at multiple places by locals there who will ask you for donations. And donations are not by choice, they are by force. We actually saw the local there physically stop a visitor by pushing him when he denied giving a donation the second time. If you take a picture there with a local, again you need to pay up, or be prepared to be pushed around. I've seen a few rice terraces earlier, this one wasn't really worth our time.
Just fantastic. visited this amazing rice terrace on the way from volcano. since it is located at road side and easy to access. you also can taste some coffees or teas at warung
Beautiful but to many tourists . Very beautiful view, but mostly for the tourists. Try to be there early in the morning before the tourists hordes arrive.

wow. We hired a driver for 5 hours from Ubud and included this on our trip. It has the wow factor and the view is just amazing! It was extremely hot so recommend getting there early. Fairly busy but would definitely add this to your list of things to see in Bali!

Fantastic view. Hired motor bikes and rode to kintamani, on route stopped at the rice paddies, incredible views of the rice fields, and lovely lunch stop on the way home.We didn't walk through the fields just took in the sights
A work of Art. Amazing landscaping by very hard working people! Great walks with quite a few steep hills but the views are incredible!!!

Very touristy but pretty views! . Very touristy but pretty views! So try to go early in the morning so its less busy! Quiet close to the risefields you'll find the Kopi Luwak coffee plantation this had spectaculare views and is less busy

Beautiful but also a touch of sadness . This is indeed such an exquisite area of agri tourism however I felt somewhat saddened to see the area being engulfed by pop up cafes and tourist shops. Such a shame that more land around the area is not preserved to keep the rural aspect alive.
Beautiful place. Amazing view, luscious green surroundings! Lovely cafes around overlooking the terrace - definitely highly recommend to visit

Picture post card, classic rice terrace view.. This was the nearest "classic" rice terrace to where we were staying (Ubud). We had a rental car so easy to sort a drive straight up from the hotel.When you first get near the terraces, which are at the far/northern end of Tegalalang), you'll know you're there as a car park attendant stands in the middle of the main road diverting traffic.From the car park, it's a 100 metre or so walk up to the first terraces, with a number of cafe's providing good views across the valley. However, these terraces are very much about the tourist buck. When we were there, the terraces were teeming with tourists, and the only "farmer" we saw was an enterprising guy who was hanging round with a yolk getting tourists to pay him for photo's.If you want to see a more authentic view, just walk another 200 metres up the road and you'll see natural terraces being farmed. There's a very nice café off the main road where you can get some brilliant views.Worth going, just pick your spot.
Amazing view must see. This place has amazing view that you must stop by when visiting baliSpecially during sunset To see the layers of the rice fields

Spectacular views over terraced rice paddies . The Tegalalang Rice Terrace is a great spot to visit about 20 minutes from Ubud. The road come into the town at the top of a steep valley. Parking is difficult, but worth the effort. There are numerous little restaurants overlooking the valley, where you can stop for lunch or a drink, before embarking on a walk along the little paths that wind down between the rice fields. While I haven't braved the walk due to time constraints, it would be well worth it if you're up to the challenge. Be careful that your driver doesn't take you to the newer restaurants on the other side of the road. These maybe lovely, and have a nice view, but they are not the same.
Nice view once you get passed all the souvenir shops. Not much else to say. It was full of tourist taking photos and walking the terraces. It's a quick stop on an all day adventure.

Disappointingly touristy. We actually just stopped at the rice terraces on our way to Gunung Kawi and Tirta Empul because we thought it might be nice. Unfortunately it was croweded with tourists and the fields I didn't find too impressive. There are others which are much nicer and natural not made for tourists to see. If you pass by, stop and see it but don't go out of your way for this.

Must photo opportunity. If you are in the Ubud area, the rice terraces of Tegallalang is a must see. This is one of the best attractions in the whole of Bali.Make sure to bring along your camera as there are plenty of photo opportunities.
photos place. very good amazing place to visit with friends and family to get amazing photos with , but it took 15 minutes to visit which is considered short time

Difficult access Rice Terrace. It is far from Kuta, Legian and Denpasar that the many popular hotels are located. To see that well-recognized terrace scenery is not so easy, I mean there may be heavy traffic jam or the sudden heavy rain. Hence, it's better for you to take those risks into consideration to visit this terrace. (As for me, I couldn't enjoy it due to the sudden shower)When it comes to the scenery, it was beautiful but smaller than I expected, and there was not so much difference between this and my hometown one. (My country also has such a Rice Terrace)

Heavily Commercialised. The terrace itself is beautiful but it's surrounded by hundreds and hundreds of shops and the street is very narrow and congested due to traffic, all this kills the beauty and charm of Tegalalang Rice Terrace.We sat at a restaurant facing the terrace and had coconut water, probably the biggest coconut we ever saw in our life.The path to terrace has narrow steep stairs and is not safe for children and elderly.Heavily Commercialised.

NICE Tourist Trap. Well, it is touristy as you can get, and a veritable traffic snarl much of the day. But if you are in Ubud, or passing nearby on a daytrip, how can you not come. It is still pretty nonetheless.You can walk down amongst the rice terraces if you wish, usualy with a few locals sitting down there seeking donations on the premise that the terraces do need to be maintained. As a tourist be respectful and cough up some Rupiah, the financial cost to most of us is nominal and the impact on locals is far more substantial. You can do the uber touristy thing and grab a beverage or snack in an overlooking cafe or restaurant if you choose. Been here year after year and it is still nice.Favourite visit was renting a bicycle in Ubud and peddling up, parking, then going walking in the terraces when it was still quiet. And then losing my balance...left over the edge or right into a wet muddy rice paddy. Rice paddy.Touristy but hey, why not!

Stunning views. We went on a rainy day and this beautiful place was still heaving with tourists. You look down on to the rice terraces from the roadside and have stunning views. You can walk down in to the paddy fields but we chose not to as the rain was torrential during our visit. I imagined it to be a bigger place from the description and photos, but it is no less disappointing for that. Sadly the business of the place detracts from it, which is maybe the tragedy of successful tourism. Well worth a visit all the same
Iconic rice fields of Bali, must see. Beautiful to see the green fields all though there are tourist who can block your shot sometimes. I think it's worthy to go there

Not interesting to us!. When we came to the terrace, we could not find entrance. Made some photos and drove to the next place. After few days we went to the Jatiluwih Rice Terraces and it was amazing. We found the entrance and walked on terraces. It was a good trip.
Beautiful . Amazing view, wear good shoes if you would like to walk about through the rice fields- it often rains ans gets a bit muddy.
amazing. Beautiful rice terraces below your feet - what an amazing view! You can walk along the terraces and see people working on the fields... Great experience!

Must see when in Bali!. Although there a more beautiful rice terraces on Bali, the Tegalalang fields are a must see! The view from above is really beautiful. They are easy to visit by scooter when your in Ubud, it takes just about 20 minutes.

Very busy but beautiful scenery. A must see in Ubud because it is one of the UNESCO's World Heritage sites. A very beautiful scenery but it is crowded with tourist in and around the rice terraces. There are viewing decks to enjoy the view but one can also venture down and be closer to the rice terraces itself. It is very challenging to go in and out of the rice terraces as there are no proper stairway but it is surely an adventure to go and explore.
Must see!. Of course there are lots of tourists here but still very enjoyable and a must see! The place is absolutely magical!
rice terrace. its got that wow factor if you have not seen anything like it before, its a lot of walking if you want to get right down to the terraces but the photos are very special

Awesome view. The rice fields are pretty awesome. But a bit dangerous to walk through (wear good shoes, no sneakers or flip-flops). The view is awesome from the side of the road, unfortunately from the other side it's not so spectacular because of all the buildings (I've called them favellas). There is also a problem that every 100-200m they collect a toll on the main path (for a bridge, for the path etc) so get some rupiah for the visit. There is a small beer shack at the top of the hill with a nice view. The view is totally worth the little price.
Tranquility and purity in one view. You come here to have lunch (aka pitstop) and absorb the view. It's worth it. Hollywood could not recreate the archipelago of rice paddy fields and Mountains!

Good experience, worth the cisit. You pay a 10k entry fee to the area by the locals which is fair enough. The rice fields are well maintained and very scenic. We had lunch looking over them which was a nice experience too.
Spectacular Scenery. The scenery is so spectacular, everything is so lush and green and just so amazing to look at. This is a must see day trip.
Beautiful scenes. It's a tourists spot ie with many tourists.And yet, worth a visit to witness the beauty of the terraced rice field scenery.

Wow!!. A must see while in Ubud, although there are a lot of tourist around this is an amazing place to see! There are other rice patty fields close by that are just as good! Take small change as every little shack you pass you need to donate.
Very touristy . If you've been to other rice terraces, give this one a miss.It feels like it's just there for tourists.

nice place to see. It takes around 25-30 mins by car from the center of Ubud. You pay fee (IDR 10.000 per person) when you enter to the village. It could be tiresome to go down & up in the terace but it worths to see it. Some peaole ask for donation when you are in the terrace and do not allow you to go unless you do not pay.
Nice but crowded. This place is very nice but also very crowded. We just make a few pictures and move on. But if you go by stop is definitely worth of it.

Over rated. This is purely for tourist only. It is much better to spend time on somewhere else around Bali.
However if you insist to see rice terrace, there are other rice terrace around Bali.

Nice Place to visit. - We went to this place to watch the traditional way of planting rice in Bali, and to enjoy the beautiful view from there.- My shoes got stuck in one of the irrigated beds, so bring a good closed shoes so you can hike up and down the steps.- If you are going with your car, you will face some problems with parking.- bring some money for donations, you will spend there 30 Min maximum.
Beautifull. If you're travelling to Indonesia you NEED to visit this place. The rice fields are breath taking and you will soend aorund an hour here.
Magnificent place. It feels like you are in heaven. The place is very quiet and peaceful and very very green. Simply amazing, must see.

Beautiful - but crowded. The views are breath-taking, it just needs to remain tolerant that so many other travellers also want to see this place. Luckily the big tourist-busses are slowly being replaced with smaller ones, causing less traffic congestions, together with a new parking lot.

One of the most beautiful things I have seen - ever. I feel like pictures do not do this place justice. You have to experience the beauty and the patterns and see how ingenious their water system is. Peaceful.

Great! . This is great. But if you wanna come here, make sure to wear shoes that's comfy for long walk. Also to have small amount of money (like 10.000/ 20.000) because you will be asked for donation at some spots. They view is amazing and it's better to finish the trekking.

Magnificent. Very beautiful place to visit. The view is amazing, 50 shades of green :) There are a lot of rice terrace in Ubud but this one is the touristic one.You can't go to Ubud and not see the rice terrace.

Beautiful . This the place when you want see Balinese rice terrace with traditionally irrigation "subak" in Balinese ,you can just see from the top of the view or go down to the rice field,but remember because this rice farm is private so you must prepare for small money to give some people in that area,,but if u not want give money u can still see from the top on the cafe or view points,have cafe handy craft ,parking etc,,this place is nice for walk and sunset
Stunning! A must do. A must do. Just bring good closed shoes so you can hike down the terraced fields. Try get there early to avoid too many tourists in all your pics as well.

Stunning, But Busy. The views are spectacular, so understandably this is a tourist hotspot. The biggest problem we had here was parking, as there simply isn't a car park, only street parking. Our driver dropped us off at the entrance and we had to walk a fair distance to locate him after we were done. Lots of steps to contend with here, so don't bother going in if they'll be a problem for you (instead just have lunch or drinks in one of the cafes down the street, as they have great views).

Nice place for photographs.. Not much to see. While coming back from mount batur sunrise hike, we decided to stop by the rice terrace .. It's an ok place, lots of greenery and nice view to take photographs . Visited this place only because it was on d way.. Nothing much to see. just take some Gud photographs and spend around 20-30 minutes max.
Green carpet Steps!. A wonderful place with lots of photo opportunities. Surrounded by restaurants and cafes and lots of small and slimy commodore lizards.
Okay... Not as autenchic as expected. . It looked good and authentic but for every piece terrain you want to go to the locals want "donations". But worth an hour or two.
Magic atmosphere . Do it and you will not regret it...One advice though, avoid flip flop if you wish to do the trek which I highly recommend.
Nice but too touristic. The rice terrace is nice but there are a lot of steps and you have to pay to the different locals every time you walk a new piece of land
OK!!!. If you are passing by Ubud, you can opt for this place (instead of Jatiluwih which is quite far away). However, for me, i think Jatiluwih has much better view and nice paddy field in Bali.

Getting Lost in Beauty. I understand some may think it is over hyped but it is beautiful and unique to see such a large steep terraced landscaped. It's beautiful, and there are paths all over so you can wonder around for hours. Yes some donations are required, it may equate to a toal of 5 to 10 USD maybe, but well worth it. Bali is pretty cheap, and i think giving $10 to help support the grounds and the people who operate around the area is nothing for the view and experience you get. It is very hot so stay hydrated and bring water, a fan, a hat or umbrella to provide shade when needed.
Very commercial touristic. Nice view but.....very commercial touristic atmosphere . There are better place s to experience the rice fields

Mwah . To be honest: we visited the rice terraces in China so it is perhaps not Faire to compare the rice terraces. It was alright, a lot of tourists. And too many souvenir shops. It felt more like a tourist attraction than an actual rice terrace. Views are beautiful, but if you have seen other rice terrace I would skip it.

Tourist trap. Seeing the rice terraces was one of our to dos when visiting Bali. We hired a diver and car for the day from Legian. We're glad that we did rather than take an organised tour as when we arrived at the terraces it was very clear to see that it was just a tourist trap. After being harassed by kids trying to sell overpriced items for "my school" we made out way down to the terraces, we decided after the first level not to bother going any further as it was way too busy. We spent about 10 minutes before going off to find our driver who had to park further up. However, that gave us a different view and we managed to get some photos with nobody in them. Yes go and see but don't bother walking down.

Typically green and beautiful . Beautiful.However there are many around that are just as nice. You don't need a guide. Tips:-Rent a motorbike and go find some more with less people!- there is an entrance fee

Nice but a lot of donation required. the rice terrace are amazing located nearby to Ubud. well worth to walk through terraces. once you cross bamboo bridge a lady stop and asking for donation of the bridge. next we got the higher step then a man stop for the donation minimum 10,000IDR/person. on the way back we went through another side and again donation required. totall 60,000IDR for both of us. be ready for that if you want to walk through!

Over hyped. Hearing a lot about the terraced rice fields we went to see it only to find that it was teeming with tourist and I was not sure what they were looking for.The place was full of teenage hawkers whose catch phrase was that they have not eaten anything for the day or they have no money to pay their school dues.The articles on offer were exhorbitant and would not be of any use when one goes back home.For Asian these rice fields are no novelty.

Rode our bicycles to this beautiful spot.. This is our second time visiting this "Postcard" place in Ubud, Bali. This time we were on Bicycles, best way to see the sights. We stopped for a drink at Celek (?) which is just before the main area where everyone stops. Much better here. You can still see the amazing rice terraces.
