Street here is wider so not push and shove in the traffic. Take the time to walk around and see the shops.

Beautiful Terraces, so-so experience.. First of all, the terraces are absolutely breathtaking. It's a stunningly beautiful place to look at. We came for lunch and ate at the restaurant. The restaurant was pricey (as expected for the location/view); food was decent, but we had a lot better at our local warung. As the reviews below me also mentioned, there's a lot of children begging for donations ("for my schooooool"...you'll hear it over and over), and they're quite aggressive and don't take no for an answer. One child nearly tripped me while begging, and I could've gotten seriously hurt as we were trekking back up the terrace. This sort of begging should be made illegal. It was a bit of a tourist trap, as well. So many people that it was hard to even take a picture without someone else in your shot. It's hard to make room for other people passing, as the little paths are quite small. People were just pushing through without regard.The area would be nice if it had a sign to explain how to get to one end from the other...we figured we'd have to walk down to the bottom, but a sign would've been nice, too. We were also charged $5 AUD to enter and walk around the terrace...apparently if you go before 7am no one is there to charge you.All in all, the terraces are beautiful, but the experience wasn't great. We probably wouldn't go again. At least we got a few pictures.
Nice view . This is a good placa for you to see both natural beauty and balinese rice fields. However, careful when walking on the field because it is obviously swampy.
Amazing views. Great views, great experience! Muse see attraction for anyone who is visiting Bali and in the Ubud area.

Nice view. It was a nice view of the rice plantation, but to be true I thought the regular rice plantations even more spectacular! There are a lot of rice everywhere around Ubud and this one was too much for tourist.Kids were asking for money insistently! And they charge if you want a picture from some part of the views.

Amazing views - watch out donations people. Definitely go and do the trek around. It's fine in flip flops. You will be a little tired if it's hot and sweaty. There is a legit donation guy at one point asking for a donation to go a certain way and you just give whatever you want but I also noticed some that I don't think are legit trying to stop you going certain routes unless you give them money. Just say no and walk past whatever they say. One thing I've realised in Indonesia is that they try and cheat you quite a lot.
stunning views . Loved walking through the terraces even in the rain. Mornings or closer to sunset would be best to avoid beating sun as it is very exposed.

Tourist trap: waste of time. This is a place were busloads of tourists from Kuta are dropped off to see rice paddies. Well, the influx of mass tourism has really destroyed this place. It probably was beatiful once, but now it is much too commercial, there are too many touts selling tacky and irrelevant souvenirs and there are too many people with selfie sticks. Looking for 'authentic' Bali? You won't find it here.
Beautiful . The rice fields are lovely and so green. The trip from Ubud was a experience in its self. It was great seeing the local farmers planting and picking the rice

INTERESTING TO VIEW. To enter this area, there is a IDR10000 per person charge, but not for the driver. Interesting topography and buildings as well. Usual hustle and bustle that is tourists attractions in Bali. Stalls, shops, beggars, traffic and tourists and actual people who live and work there. We did not venture into the rice fields on this occasion but could see many who did. We did learn however the Bali must import rice to feed its people and obviously us tourists...They just cannot produce enough. Certainly something that should be experienced by travellers because you get another glimpse of how others must work to live, to survive with not a lot of creature comforts.
A long walk. Had to pay a small fee and then walked a distance to the rice fields. Some people walked the rice terrace we didn't. Was good to have a look at

Worth a look !. Interesting drive and there is food and shops once you get there. Good idea to go on same day as an Ubud trip. Lots of locally made crochet items in shops. Paid 750,000 Rp. for large crochet bed throw. A few kids selling postcards too.

Impressive . This place is huge!!! Really huge! The sheer scale of it hits you from the approach and people appear tiny as they try to traverse the fields. You could treat it as a day's hike and get a great workout!As with everything else in Bali, folk are friendly and helpful and you can take amazing pics. Great part of a day out if not the whole day out.

Spent 45 min to get there and took 2 pics. Stunning view! Lots of traffic so not sure if it was worth it to take 2 pics. Kids will try to sell you (multiple) postcards to help them pay for school. You can climb down into the rice fields if you want but wear runners. I stepped into mud and had to yank my muddy flip flop out. No washrooms around to clean it off...
Rice Terraces. Am amazing site to see these rice fields, unchanged for decades. You are free to stroll around, and between the fields, as long as you stay to the paths.
Beautiful spot. Luscious green rice terraces. We viewed from the top as we weren't very keen on climbing all the way down and back up. But it was very picturesque and worth seeing.

Completely trashed. Visited 25 years ago,now its a dreadful tourist strip full of hawkers who insist on charging you an entrance fee when its actually free to walk through.Very overcrowded street.Some pretty crochet work for sale but far from hassle free vendors.

Worth The Long Journey. I went to this place during afternoon. It took us few hours to reach this place from Gianyar. The road to this place is quite challenging, cause it's small and it's curvy. And it is quite hard to find a space to park your car, cause it's so crowded with tourists. But the view from here is definitely amazing. It is so greenish and relaxing for our eyes. But it is so hot and if you want to go down to take a good shot, the road was not friendly. So prepare a proper shoes if you want to walk down.
Nice and close to Ubud. These are nice to visit if you've never seen a Rice Terrace before and you are tight with time. If you have more time the Jatiluwih ones are probably better.
amazinggggg place. love nature love greenhad amazinggggg pics maybe some times crowded with tourists but its ok you will love it

View of the Tegalalang Rice Terraces. I viewed the terraces from the main street look out point and the landscape was breathtaking. Very green and lush. Worth travelling to see. With more time, next time I will walk through the field and give the farming of rice a try. Beautiful scenery

Unique!. It's a gorgeous area to visit. There are several shops on that street, in case you would like to buy sarongs and take pictures that look more authentic than touristy. The people are extremely friendly and welcoming. I find it very peaceful and fascinating. It's a great experience in the heart of indonesia. The scenery is unique and I enjoyed sitting by the terraces and staying quiet, taking a break there. I'd advise to stay in an area that is not too high during hot days, it can be a strenuous walk uphill, be sure to hydrate!
Overrated. A little Bit Crowded and not as Spectacular as on many pictures. If you come by here anyhow you should do a quick stop
Fantastic. A must see. Take a walk around and have small money (5000rp) ready for "donations". Great and free to see.

Good introduction to the rice fields . A rice field that provides a lovely introduction to the Bali rice fields close to Ubud. We took a trek through the field and had a coconut drinking rest stop at the back corner. The views are especially beautiful early in the morning when the first light hits the area. Also it's a possibility to enjoy the walk in solitude as most tourists have not arrived yet.Certainly worth a visit. And bring your camera.
Rice terraces. Beautifull. Just like all the pictures. Many tourist so go early and love the breathtaking looks of the rice terraces

Interesting place. It is an interesting place for picture taking. The place is easily accessible by taxi. There are quite a lot of small stalls selling local souvenirs around the area. I find that the price is quite reasonable.

Walk 100 metres for a tourist-free view. The main terraces are a tourist trap, with restaurants sarong and tat sellers lining the road. Write or walk a hundred yards further uphill to find equally pretty terraces without tourists tramping all over them. The small cafe with the 'I love Bali sign' and old cycle rickshaw in the garden isn't cheap but has a good views and a clean toilet
So greenish. The view was excellent.Fully greenish upto the site.u can go down n see the entire field.itz jst like mini trekking.lot of shops were there but u hve to bargain much.

Nice views. This is good to see, somewhere you will not stay to long once you have taken in the vast and beautiful views. We did not go further in and explore.Theoretically you are meant to pay (which we did) its not much. However most people just walked in and enjoyed it.
Nice rice fields. We visited these rice terraces last week.This not the best time of the year as the rice was just planted, about a month later it must be very colourful.

So Busy.... We stopped here to have lunch at a nice little place (I forget which one) and the views were nice, but it was crowded. The restaurants and shops block most of the view of the rice terrace and there are tourists EVERYWHERE walking all over it - which totally ruins any photos. We came here a 6 years ago during rainy season and it was much nicer - uncrowded and less shops/restaurants.

Must see. This site has to be a must-see! The beautiful greens and still water and layered views are stunning. Beware of the 'donations' expected to pass into various areas though. Didn't mind paying once but after we were asked a fourth time it got a bit annoying considering you've already purchased a ticket outside. Other than that, the locals there are friendly, and the walkways allow you to explore all over.
Beautiful views.. There are some lovely restaurants overlooking the rice terraces. Excellent food.........we should have walked on the rice terraces but didn't .

AMAZING, MUST DO. This place is beyond beautiful!!! There are so many angles from which to take excellent photos. It is lush and green, and so interesting to look at. As an American, it is a completely different landscape from anything I have ever seen. You can actually hike down into the rice terrace and walk all around, which I highly recommend doing. It is a magical place to explore and there was even a man playing a flute, which really added to the atmosphere. It is best to get here in the morning when it is uncrowded and not too hot. We arrived around 8:15 - 8:30 am and for a while we were the only ones there for a while! It was a comfortable temperature, and so peaceful. By 10 am the sun was beating down and very intense and we were glad to be finishing. There were also lots of people by that point.

Must see. A bit touristy and hardly in use by local farmers, but still worthwile to pay a visit. Spectacular 'agricultural art' with rice paddies on steep slopes. Sure you have to pass local vendors, 'cafe's with a view' - but hey - why not ?

Tourists are welcomed. There was a top less lady maybe 60 yo almost out of teeth, 1$ photograph)). Crossing the small bridge will cost you some "donation". And finally what is really disappointing that all the rice pads are fake. Locals don't grow the rice they just use it as an entertainment.

Beautiful view. To get there they charge about $1 per person in a car. You cannot park as it is crowded, let a driver drop you and pick you up later. The view is amazing, we did not feel like walking on the terrace ( not my thing). But everyone with what they want. I love seeing this from above, had a coffee and left.
Beautiful . One of the best places to see the rice terraces in Bali. We went at the right time before the rice was being harvested. Worth a visit for the amazing views.
Nothing much. Nothing much to see actually. But the food is good and if you took the e-bike tour, it'll be more worth it.

Full of tourist traps. No entrance fee, but the locals try to rip you off on every step of the way – charging parking fees, little girls leading you the way or offering to take a picture, some kind of tolls every once in a while, claiming they are collecting donations for maintenance of the rice fields (not sure what happens if you don’t pay). Best footwear would probably be sneakers, I had flip flops and I slipped into of the muddy fields, so I continued barefoot, which also wasn’t that bad.I expected the fields to be prettier, since we have been driving around Ubud for a couple of days and been seeing a lot of amazing greenery, including small rice terraces, which were prettier than this one and completely empty.

Nothing gr8 about the place... Good to see the rice terraces, though its common everywhere. one thing good was the restaurants located on the edge of the road, gives awesome view of the terraces as well as fresh air.. The place is usually crowded, but doesn't affects much...Good place to have lunch or evening snack...

A beautiful way to get some exercise. I really enjoy following the path up and down these rice terraces. Beautiful, lush view, especially in early morning or late afternoon. The steps are quite steep. I suggest wearing securely strapped sandals as flip-flops are not the best footwear for walking along the narrow ridges that can be pretty slippery after the rain. Please give donations at the entrance to support the locals in maintaining this beautiful site. I know that it's a common practice in Bali that a donations are pooled for the village for this purpose.

Beautiful landscape. We spent a few days in Bali and did many local walks through beautiful rice fields and rice terraces. Just step out of any town or village centre!! Tegalalang is on the Bali tourist itinerary and lots of cars and coaches stop here (very briefly) for the outstanding view. But I would still recommend going here. It is a beautiful narrow valley with steep terraced sides, surrounded by palm trees and lush vegetation.
Nice views and wonderful service. The views are incredible and the food is reasonable for Bali. Even if you just go have a drink and take in the scenery it is worth it.

Best views of the region. It is normally crowded of tourists but that does not affect the view (rice fields are in front of you most of them with a valley in the middle) So you can enjoy the landscape and take nice pics even with many people around you.If you go by motorbike there will be a not so nice guy asking you for 10.000 rupias for parking.

Good but nothing special. Very cool to see the rice terraces in the flesh, but nothing too special about them. Hard to access, with a very little entrance off a busy road and very step stairs. I didn't think walking all the terraces was necessary, as there wasn't much information about the terraces let alone the rice plantations, Very tourist based I felt (to get money rather than for educational use).

Interesting but too overcrowded.. Nice view, interesting to see such big rice field, loads of then in fact. Too many kids trying to take your money by offering you some postcards pretending they collect money for their schools. Way too many people pushing and being annoying. Apart from that the fields themselves are very weel looked after and nice.
Amazing view. Amazing view and appreciation for individuals who plant and harvest in the rice fields. Wear comfortable shoes and take plenty of water.

Go for it - worth it. Fantastic terraces. But of a hard slog for unfit me, but worth it.Plenty of good spots to refuel ( food and drinks). I'm extremely allergic to nuts so make sure they understand that.

Not a must - very crowded around noon time. Most of the year these Tegalalang terraces are not used and dried out. Don't go there around noon time as it is normaly very crowded at this time (havy raffic!) If you want to go there, try the mornings or later afternoon. A much better, authentic impression of the rice fields you get when driving around by motorbike (especially in the north and east of Ubud).

A day I won't forget! 💍 . Tegalalang rice terrace is a must see during anyone's stay in Bali! During my trek with my boyfriend he popped the long awaited question of "will you marry me" of course I said "yes" a beautiful/romantic spot to pop the question! Breathtaking views from the top and the opportunity to trek amongst the rice terraces and cross a bridge to the other side of the terrace. A perfect spot for photos with beautiful scenery. I recommend wearing trainers/walking shoes as I saw many people struggle in flip flops. When we return to Bali we will certainly visit the rice terrace again.

Come when the light is good. This is one of those places that's good fun to scramble around. Don't come in silly shoes or tight clothes, because you really want to clamber about to make the most of it. In case you're wondering, you don't have to get your feet wet. You can get around on the edges of the wet fields; you just need sensible shoes because steps are generally etched out of the earth and you want a good foot grip to hoist yourself up and down. And if you're here for the photos, then aim for a good time of day when you get good light.

Nice view. The view is beautiful.. And you can walk through the rice field. But there are local people (farmers) around who will asking you to give a donation when you are walking in. I saw so many tourists fighting with the farmers because they didn't want to pay double. We already paid a donation at the first entrance and then the other farmers upstairs asking for another donation. If you don't want to pay, they will not let you to pass.. They call it a donation but they will ask you to pay for minimun 10.000 rupiah.

First time visit. It was an easy way for us to view the terrace - we had a car tour and were able to overlook it from the footpath. Apparently there wasn't as much growth to see as usual - which explains why we weren't as awe-struck as we thought that we might have been.

Take A Ride Out To Tegalalang . Rented a motorbike to go and see the famed rice terraces. Takes approx 20-30 minutes from Ubud center. Entrance is free, be prepared to give 1 or 2 donations to farmers at various stages to ensure free passage around the terrace though. Enjoyed walking through the terrace and watching the farmers till the land. Wonderful scenery and it makes for great photos. Must do when in Ubud.
Gorgeous green terraced rice fields. Right off the main road, this vista is amazing. Get out and go walk among all the levels. Unique and vast network.

Very scenic. This is a very beautiful and scenic place. Unlike other rice fields, they have made small puddles and steps of paddy fields. You can go on a nice walk down the steps into the mini valley or just stand on the very top and click pictures.
Apt for some selfies.

Too many tourist. We got there about 9:00am, it was too late. We could barely get a picture without any one else in the background. Just make sure you get to the place by 7:00am if you want a good picture

Beaufitul like... many other rice terraces on Bali. The terrace looks wonderful, but during our trip around the island we found several other rice terraces which are equally (or even more) beautiful. For some reason this one was chosen as the one to let the tourists in, but it doesn't mean it's the unique place on Bali.

Amazing views. What a sight seeing the rice fields like this. Long drive from ubud about 45 minutes but this was part of our day tour with a driver and we were quite tired by the end of the day but it was nice to come and see this

great place for all the family. our entire family loved hiking amongst the Tegalalang Rice Terraces. Our 6 year old wanted to be the 'leader' decided which route to take and had fun crossing over little bridges and picking which path to take. I thought it would be totally overcrowded, because parking was a bit of a nightmare, but once we entered the rice terraces we found it to be quite relaxing, sure we crossed paths with lots of people but over all it was quite & really beautiful. It was one place we wished we spent more time at or even returned to.

Fun free & beautiful . We came upon the Rice terraces during a random scooter ride around surrounding ubud. There was no charge to hike down up & around the terraces, however a donation is expected. Perfect place to adventure and sit to obsorb the stunning scenery.

Rice fields but no tranquility . I made a special trip to see the rice terrace, hoping to find what I discovered nearly 30 years ago. It doesn't exist anymore. This rice terrace is lovely, but you would need to get away from the one crowded lookout and go walking in them to get any real sense of them. And it's such a small valley. Nothing like the huge expanses that used to be. Plus you get hassled by the hawkers, and the police charge a 10,000rupiah fee to see a public view!! Good to stop if you're up that way, but otherwise Not really worth it.

Breathtaking in more ways than one. Be prepared for the trek up and down the rice paddy by wearing sturdy trainers and bring a water (or two) to hydrate yourself when taking in the view from the top. Make sure to have small notes with you as the workers ask for donations periodically at different 'stations' so that they can repair the paths.

Beautiful views, beware of the forced payments. Really beautiful views, worth the heavy trecking, although make sure you wear sensible comfy shoes. Mine blistered and I had to go it bare foot.Although I'm more than happy to make donations, and most are friendly, there was a station where the man took our payment, told us it wasn't enough and we ended up leaving with him keeping the initial payment which was stressful as he was demanding more cash from another couple and being quite aggressive in not letting them past. Maybe make the rice fields a one payment entry to let visitors walk round as they please, instead of being hit with constant harassment for payments at every turn.

Too commercial. Green padi but not too green.
Crowded at times.
Plenty of cafes there.
Parking is painful.
Kids asking for money in the area.
Free entrance so...
Wear good shoes cos it can get slippery.
Dusty when dry.

Beautiful Rice Terraces. Really enjoyed our time at the Tegalalang Rice Terraces. Beautiful and loads of tracks to explore. There were places to stop, take in the views and get a drink, which was great after our 1hr30min walk from our accommodation. The only issue was a bit of hassle on the way round from people wanting a 'donation' for entering various sections of the rice terraces - however it is free to get in. Didn't think much of the spring water area/trek but to be fair we only walked down to the concrete structure where the water was coming out from...
A walk on the wild side.. This was a religious experience for me because I saw how my beloved rice is made in person. However, I was mostly impressed with the irrigation system.
Lovely morning visit. We visited these today beautiful place full of picture perfect oppurtunities. Has many touristy shops similar style to ubud market. Definately worth a visit.

Beautiful Bali. A lot a little restaurant near the tegalalang , would very great enjoy if you have a meal with see the Beautiful Rice Terrace. Such beautiful nature. And there was A lot little Sovenir shop around too, That's worth visiting.

Tegalalang Rice Terrace was Terrific!. An amazing place to take beautifully dramatic photos no matter when the rice terraces are planted or harvested. Would recommend visiting before the crowds and heat or after dinner when life settles down for the evening.It is most serene with a history that started in the 8th century. Learn how the subak (traditional community irrigation) was developed and maintained through the generations. Find Garuda (a mythical Balinese figure) or just enjoy the moment.

Beautiful. Excellent to visit the rice field in terrace during the sunset with the motorbike , on the way we can find a lot of artcraft shop and the locals are so kind and so friendly.Of course you have to bargain but it's the game.The locals are very nice , and they are curious as well.A MUST DO IN BALI

Beautiful . These rice terraces are quite a site and beautiful to see. We didn't trek around the terraces as we had already done a lot of walking and it was super hot, but we found a local restaurant that overlooked them and admired the view. It was lovely and well worth a visit. It's 10000 IDR to gain entry, and you could spend hours there if you are mobile and love a hike, very affordable. The area is along a stretch of road filled with shops selling local crafts, souvenirs and places to eat and drink. Watch out for the rogue chickens wandering along the pavement, clucking at you. Lovely site to see, just not very accessible for those with mobility problems.

Beautiful views, great for photos. This is a lovely rice terrace, there are little bars and coffee shops where you can sit and enjoy the view, if visiting for the rice field early 8am or later after 4 for less crowds, market stalls seem to open around 9

Great experience and lovely views. Lovely views and very cool picture opportunity. Make sure you wear trainers / appropriate footwear as you can climb down to the fields. It is not easy to do it in slippers as it is rocky and entails balance and sturdy footwear.

Beautiful rice terraces - shame it's so touristy. The rice terraces are absolutely stunning, and I can imagine when this place wasn't a tourist trap it would have been really serene. It was lovely to walk through the terraces although the view is slightly marred on one side by all the shops along the Main Street. We gave a (mandatory) donation to enter the fields (we gave 11,000rp for two of us - they didn't check or suggest a price). However we were also charged again near leaving as we entered a different farmers fields and gave 2,000rp for the two of us. It is a lovely place and worth seeing but be prepared for hawkers and donations. We visited in the afternoon when it was fairly busy, but it's probably best to visit earlier or later when it's quiet.

Nice viewpoint and walk through the rice fields. We have visited this place before lunch with our own driver. You pay 10k IDR entrance per person. They drop you off at a nice viewpoint where you can also have a drink are something to eat. Here you can also go down by stairs to walk through the rice fields. It's a nice walk. But I advice to do it before noon because of the heat and less tourists. When we went back there was already a huge traffic jam.

Absolutely beautiful rice terrace!. We went there around 7 am and it was very beautiful! No heat and no other tourists! The place was very serene and it was an amazing experience to walk around with great green views. The entrance to the hike is not very prominently marked, but it's close the rice terrace cafes. The hike itself takes about 1-2 hours depending on your pace and how far you want to walk.

One of man’s wonders and ingenuities. From the farmer’s temple with the pink sign to the single person well-worn dirt path the stair step rice paddies are one of man’s wonders and ingenuities that must be seen to appreciate. Our shore excursion of cruise ship passengers with “Wayan Tours” quickly realize these are not the modern marvels that will be easily appreciated by those that seek instant gratification. These paddies took time to build and are appreciated best by those willing to see that point first.

Fantastic but tourist central. I visited the terraces as part of a tour, the view was incredible and I am glad I went... However, it was very very touristy and on the tour I was on we visited many different, and deserted, rice terraces on the way to Tegallalang from Ubud which were just as good to see and better for photos as there were only us and the occasional rice farmer in sight

Great place to get a feel for a Bali rice padi. This place is very touristy but its still well worth a visit if you're near Ubud. Once you're in the valley, you can forget the touristy bits and just enjoy the stunning surroundings. Go there either at the begnning or end of the day to avoid the crowds and get the best lighting
Stunning view. Visited as part of a tour didn't really know what to expect but was blown away by the view it was magnificent. We paid 10kIDR (60p) to have our photo holding the rice picking baskets.

BORING. Great for taking about one picture then you can move on. Nothing much to see just a lot of the same thing every time you cross a bridge to move on the higher level they ask for a donation. This excursion can be done in 10 min.

Stunning. This place is picture perfect postcard stuff. I would advise to go early as it gets hot and crowded .When we finished and walked back to the street it was gridlocked with cars and tour buses. It's virtually impossible to take a bad shot of these beautiful fields which are an engineering masterpiece. Of course there are the usual donation boxes which might annoy some people but personally to give a $ or two for maintenance or wherever it goes is not a problem for me. I'd highly recommend a visit

Beautiful views . We went in the afternoon in September and it was HOT. I think this would be better as a morning activity as it is definitely a hike to the top and to go around. There were a lot of 'stops' along the way that asked for payment or donation to pass through. We had some small IDR notes and complied, but I don't know if it is required. I would bring water for the hike, and there were a few places to stop and buy some refreshments. We went with our 4 year old and 7 month old. It is NOT stroller friendly, so I wore our baby in a carrier. There are a lot of great shops and vendors up on the street to buy souvenir, and you can bargain shop when they give you a price also.
Beautiful. Beautiful place!! We hiked through the paddies & loved it. Be prepared with cash as they collect a small amount along the path for bridge repairs. We can't wait to go back!

Overrated. The place is not as amazing as expected. It is sorrounded by concrete houses/establishments. Too crowded.
If you really want to see a bigger and better rice terraces, you should go to jatiluwih!

Stunning . I don't know what else to say, but the rice terrace was Stunning!!
If your happy to get a bit dusty and muddy make sure you walk all the way down to the bottom! The views are incredible, don't skip this in your tour!

Beautiful scenery . We had lunch over looking these rice fields.
Was very peaceful and amazing scenery
I have been to bali 4 time and this was my first time here. Can't believe I had never been there before. Would definitely go again

Worth the visit. I hear there are many rice terraces of course all over Indonesia. From Ubud with the right driver it is a lovely ride through local villages and the mountains to this rice terrace. When we were there it was not too busy w tourists like us but clearly a spot to be. Also note local leaders are collecting a fee to visit $R10000 per person. It is not a choice. Just pay it. He's wearing a police neon vest you or your driver can't miss him. We were there on a clear blue sky day. Amazing views. These terraces take up hectares and feed a large community to work the land for each other. I had never seen this before and understand it is the way rice is grown in communities throughout Asia. In addition you could see another rice terrace being built. I would put this on a must see on a trip to Bali. A good driver can get you there. You can ignore the tourists w selfie sticks and just hope they don't step backward off a terrace. Enjoy.
Worth to go there. You should put it on your must see list but make sure you are in the morning there before all the tourists come

OK. This was just OK but great if you have never seen one before, great for pics and if you wish can spend a bit going down and up exploring. I think there are better options but this is good if your time is limited in Ubud.

Such a beautiful visit. We loved the rice terrace! Everything was so green and lush and it was nice to explore these on our own! We hired a driver for the day and he dropped us off and we went in to explore. We were not in there long probably not even an hour but the place is very beautiful and make for some wonderful pictures! There are a lot of stairs though so may not be the best for those with mobility issues. There were a few stops you could get cold beer, drinks or snacks which was nice! The cost was minimal and I would totally recommend it!
Worth the visit. Amazing place, just don't stay on the view point, walk through the fields. It is absolutely breathtaking.
Real not like photos. nice place but when we go there we didn't find it like photos we already so over the internet finally nice landscape
amazing view . it was amazing to look at the expirans of looking at the nature the green aroud you walking in between the rice growing was amazing
Nice view. Nice to take beautiful pictures with the beautiful landscape. The terrace is popular, but actually you can also see some of the same at other parts of Ubud.
Fantastic viewd. Went early morning when cooler and quieter. Had a guide. Fantastic views definitely worth a visit in my opinion

Looks Good. The rice terraces look great , it is a hard walk down for some, there are nice stalls and eateries all round , a very busy place, you can hire a driver and do a few different places , we did the Volcano , the Rice terrace and finished at the Monkey Forest in Ubud then returned to South Kuta , that was a long day , but very enjoyable .

Good Laid Back Experience . The view is gorgeous & the people friendly. It's an pretty laid back experience. The key is to wear shoes your comfortable getting soiled, take a hat, and of course a water bottle.The paintings available here are incredible and reasonably priced

Beautiful!. This was one of my favorite places! So gorgeous!! We loved walking through the rice fields. We paid to go across to the other side, once we got to the top and to another check point we said we didn't want to pay and we would go back. Then the lowered the cost and eventually said we could go for free, but we were ready to go back anyway. FYI you can get through some places by bartering. Highly recommend seeing this beautiful location.
Stunning!. An absolute MUST visit location. I lived in a villa nearby so I got to visit at different times of day to catch some amazing views. Don't visit Ubud without checking out these rice fields.

Flat tire. Well the terraces are nice but frankly we found the ordinary rice terraces which are omnipresent around Ubud much nicer. Tourism really got a grip on this place. We parked out motorbike as close as possible and were immediately harassed by a women demanding we should buy postcards or just give her money. We opposed to both and she did not like it. When we got back we had a flat tire. Might be coincidence of course, and we certainly hope it was, but it left a bitter taste to our visit. If you go here, park a bit further away and walk the last couple of metres. Just to be sure.

MUST SEE !. amazing and so beautiful !!! we climbed right to the top where we were given coconut refreshments for 25,000 r and sat to drink with the most picturesque view. But please be careful, if you act carelessly you can fall and seriously hurt yourself
Not the time. It wasn't a good view during our travel time. This is due to the rice terrace is no longer hreen or yellow as they have already harvest the rice.

This was the highlight of my trip. Beautiful place. My first time in Asia so this was really amazing! You can do a hike around the rice patties which takes about 1 hour. Totally worth the visit even if you are not staying in Ubud.

Dirty rice fields, touristic trap. During the walk inside the "rice fields" of Tegalalang you will be asked money for crossing a wood bridge, charged money to make a selfie with a "love" panel, a old woman will ask you money to picture her with fake tool. I doubt that any rice is finally grown in this place! Strongly advise to look at the rice field before Tegalalang (free of charge and with real people cultivating the places).
Day tour. We visited the rice terraces as part of a day tour. Beautiful scenery. We found a little spot to enjoy fresh watermelon juice and watch the world go by.

spectacular view. I didn't spend much time here, you don't need to. The agricultural engineering is astonishing. There are a few terraces where you can take some photos. I found it easy to traverse, but if you're not spry, I don't recommend, if you fell it would be quite bad, and fairly far down.
Beautiful.... Very cool but of course as with all of these sights, its tourist central... Early mornings are best and do the hike!

Nothing special. Visited the rice terraces in August, the rice has just been harvested so the view was nothing special. There were a lot of tourists, buses, cars and bikes which kind of spoil the peace and calm that you should experience visiting the terraces.

Very nice and different environment. The place is really nice but we recommend to go early, before the stores opens and the place gets really busy and with a lot of people asking for donations. We went there before 8am, a driver took us there. At this time all the stores and coffee shops are closed but the place will be exclusive for you. We didn't pay entrance because no one was there, the donations stops were empty. We were able to take photos with no worries and without anyone standing in the background, you can go up to the terrace just walking and taking the stairs.

So beautiful and free!. Really worth a visit to the rice terraces they are so beautiful and you can walk all the way around them (Took us around 45 minutes) there are locals there who will ask you for donations but you don't have to give anything. Thankfully my boyfriend read a review before we left recommending you wear trainers (I didn't even think about it) but definitely do. It would have been difficult in flip flops! After your walk around, there are loads of cafes and restaurants you can go to which overlook the rice terraces! Would highly recommend spending an afternoon here.
Amaxing. Go early morning or late afternoon mid day is really warm out there on the fieldThe view is beautiful

So beautiful . Really loved my visit here. So picturesque and inspiring. I scootered up from central Ubud and found parking easily. In terms of the people asking you at various times for donations - I did donate some change a few times but eventually said I had already donated and no longer had any cash. I understand that the rice fields need to be maintained for so many visitors - but I wasn't willing to keep donating. Some of the collectors got quite unhappy with me - but there was nothing I could do if I had already given my cash away!Highly recommend this attraction though.

my Bali. Ignore the shops, ignore the people selling their souvenirs..ignore the cafes...just walk past and SMILE and then walk around these beautiful rice paddies. Maybe we were lucky...not many people around on our walk, I just love the colours...the use of every scrap of land..the terracing is stunning and it is just glorious...blue blue skies and the green of the rice is a perfect picture and memory to take home....a must do when you visit Bali

It looked a bit sad. The spots were all tourists and tours go are overcrouwded an really not that nice. Venders bothering you and people who want money to take their picture. Ricefields are trampled and look rather sad. We heard that sometimes they let people pay 30k to go trough the street (there are two viewpoints in tegallalang)If you want the real thing, just hire a bike and ride around the area . You will find far nicer and greener sceneries. We hired a bike (25k) in Ubud and had a ride up the hill to tegallalang (1,5h with a couple of breaks). Not along the main road, but the sideways. It was not always easy to go uphill all the time, but the ricefields were incredible. The way down was easy, just let the bike go down en enjoy!
Postcard Paddy fields. This is most probably the view you will see on all of the postcards. Our guide said the terrace was formed naturally.
Still picturesqe. Terraces still picturesque. Have to pay 10.000rp to stop and take photos. Numer of restaurants with goodviews
Beautiful . Most beautiful view in ubud. Go see it. May be charged to go through certain areas but is just a donation, up to you how much you contribute. Money goes to farmers who own the land.
Beautiful and peaceful. Great scenery, both beatiful and peaceful. Seeing the real Bali, enjoying the views and super friendly people
Great view. amazing place , Great view ,The most beautiful place in ubud , the best rice terrace in all bali and You can see the rice farmers there
Pretty to see but not much else. Get a nice couple camera shots but not much else to see otherwise. Lots of tourist traps and pushy folk at this site

Over comercialised. You have to pay a fee as you drive past Tegalalang Rice Terrace, and then find a view point at a café to see it. Guess it makes a good photograph, and you can see why it has become popular, but its popularity has taken away its appeal.

Worth the $-- gorgeous views!. Though these fields are somewhat commercialized, they do offer a lot of fantastic views. There are many steep steps so some visitors may want to enjoy the view only from the top. We loved the challenge of exploring all around. If you wander long enough, you will encounter several temples, a woodwind musician and a charming home with chickens. Look for other surprises along the paths.

More tourists than paddies. We stayed for 5 minutes after the long trip there. So much traffic, souvenir shops a plenty.
If you are looking for an authentic paddy experience, this is not it.
its an awesome experience. saw locals sow rice for rice fields its peaceful and breath taking view, you can actually walk among the rice fields I will go back again

Be picky. If you go on a tour with a driver he will take you to all the places (coffeeplant, restaurants) where he will get a commission. That's ok because he has to make a living as well, but it doesn't mean he will take you to the best places... We had lunch here and the view was the best ever, but the food was not good at all. The toilets were awful. I will not go back.
Amazing sight. A bit crowded with tourists (it was August after all), but what a sight! The trek is a bit hard, but worth it.

Fantastic - don't miss!. A great couple of hours - stroll through the rice terracces and soak in the nature. Fantastic views. Bring change as several of the farmers offer drinks and refreshments or ask for donations.

Great Views But bit boring to climb. Yes they look okay after seeing so many buildings around these days in Bali. Cool to see, if you have never seen rice fields. But nothing special, Everything is tourist prices in this area for souvenirs and clothes, very expensive and the food ..Better off going in a local warung anywhere you see many locals visiting better food and better prices. These restaurants charge you 100% more than a local restaurant and does not taste so good,

Very nice experience. Tegalalang rice terrace it is located 15 minutes from center of ubud with scooter that it is advisible to reach The place. There is at The entrance a very long stairs to reach ricefield. I suggest to walk around random in a very peacefull area.

Unique irrigation up close. Nice experience to be able to visit this site frequented by many tourists. You'll need to provide a donation to enter and walk up the terraces, but it will provide an up close look at the traditional practices with gravity irrigation from top to bottom of this steep terrace.
Beautiful. Must visit! Really beautiful rice terraces, can walk around the levels as well, real picture worthy. Beware of the hidden snake in the watery area, they're apparently harmless but still!

Beautiful, tranquil morning walk!. We had a guided tour of the rice fields and found the beauty and tranquility exceptional. Our guide was knowledgeable and respectful, explaining the cultural do's and don'ts. A lovely morning constitutional before breakfast!
Must see. If you visit Bali, you must see this unique place, located in beautiful Ubud. Photographers like me, prepare your cameras, to capture breathtaking photos

Serene in the early moening. I did not go cycling along the rice terraces--just trekking early in the morning and I liked the slow pace to appreciate the space around me. It is nice in the morning shortly after dawn when you have the trails all to yourself and the few local farmers. If you are one for taking pictures, there will surely be a few you take here that will be one of your favorites from your Bali trip.

Rice Plantation . This is a very pretty and interesting place to see while in bali. They grow three types of rice here and you can get a local guide to teach you about the growing process of all three types of rice. This was a very interesting place to visit.

Very nice view and walk . We took a guide from our hotel to the rice field, you have the option to enjoy the view from the top or you can walk down and across the fields, the view from the other side looking back to the town is also nice. It is also possible to walk alone each time you cross a checkpoint the locals are persistent you give a voluntary donation which is a little annoying but is very cheap for the experience.

Beautiful but can't see a lot for free!. As I had read in some comments, you have to pay every 5 minutes going further....so it's nice to go and see, take a few pictures, but don't pay the 1st entry if you are not willing to pay the next ones! You won't see a lot more.

See the rice fields but you pay donations. The rice fields are nice but I think you can find better in Bali without all the hassle. You arrive at a parking spot where you need to pay 10.000 idr for entrance. But this ticket you never have to show at entrance. In the rice fields you need to pay donations (we could choose) or they will not let you pass. I don't mind giving donations but here they will force you (with agression). That's the only downside. If they want us to pay, they should ask it at entrance and not when you're halfway in the fields. M

Tegalalang rice terrace . I was in absolute awe of this wonderful sight. I'm so glad that we made it here on this visit to Bali because to have missed it would have been so unfortunate. If you want to get away from the faster louder pace of Kuta or Seminyak for example, Ubud is the place to do just that. While you're there make sure to check out this amazing place which is truly breathtaking!

Really Rice Place to Go!. Loved the rice fields. Confusing as to how to enter (it's a small opening on the right hand side near the start!) amazing to see and walk around. Hard work and you'll work a sweat up - which is perfect to cool down and have a well deserved lunch overlooking the rice fields at the many cool located spots

We did a tick-mark visit. We were traveling with our 6yr old who didn't seem to appreciate the rice paddies as much as other tourists. So we reached the place, trekked down a bit through the cafes/restaurants until we got a clear view of the paddies all around, clicked a few pics & then got back up. None of us had the motivation to trek all the way through the paddies (though they looked lovely in layers) and get on the other side. However, if you like rice paddy fields & trekking, perhaps you could spend a couple hours here. Even if you don't like trekking, you could just hang out in one of the cafes here sipping your drink admiring the lovely views.
Must see. Definitely a must see place in Bali, amazing and unique vue, better wear trekking shoes and not sandals cause there are so many steps to climb.

Beautiful Rice field. We stopped by this field in our tour and took pic and went down the field and fall in mud but it was unforgettable experience as i was trying with my 4 years son to go up the muddy steps and fall down on near by rice greens.

beautiful terraces. Time to enjoy Bali in a mountainous area with a beautiful view of the rice fields. the air is fresh and clean area. Ubud has a lot of foreign tourists visit because the place is fun. Ubud is one of my favorite places in bali.

Day trip. Beautiful view and setting.
Stopped in on our Ebike tour with our guides.
Definitely worth the visit and lively to see the countryside.
Highly recommend taking the time to visit and enjoy lunch at the top.

Hot and steep. We enjoyed an afternoon trekking around the Terraces.
Unesco world Heritage site and a great nature walk.
The periodic "tolls" from locals were a bit odd but all in I think it was less than $10 cad so I can't really complain.
Definitely should have chosen early morning like 8am. Mid day was too hot.

Beatufiul place to be!. The Tegalalabg Rice Terrace is a great place to be!
We did a bike tour, but i think you can also visit the place in an other way.

Not sure what the fuss was about. This was just one stop on our whole day tour and we saw much more beautiful and interesting rice paddies just travelling around. You have to pay to visit this area which our driver told is not really a working rice field but just a tourist site. It was boring to be quite frank. We stayed just 10 minutes couldn't see any reason to stay longer.

Stunning!!. Beautiful landscape..exactly how we imagine the rice terrace from postcards before going to Bali!The lovely village of Tegalalang is worth seing! We loved the place and the atmosphere.Mandatory stop in your holidays in Bali!

Beautiful. We drove by and took a picture on the lookout point. It was beautiful. There can be quite a bit of traffic around this area but pull over on a acooter or requeat your driver to stop its worth it.

Nice to look at. A must do stop and even better with a Bintang at one of the local eateries - the weather was so hot we didn't go for a walk but you could pretty much see everything from the cafe - quite busy with the tourists
Breathtaking. Breathtaking views. Restaurants and coffee shots allow you to sit and admire for however long you please. You can view from above or walk down to the bottom. Phenomenal from every view.

Beautiful rice fields. These fields are well worth a visit. There is an entrance fee (50k IDR). They have several pay-points on the track but you're only supposed to pay once. Be aware of a creepy guy who asks to hug you if you tell him that you've already paid. The walking path could have been marked better.

Excellent views. Certainly worth visiting as the views are truly stunning - many people were actively working on the fields when we visited which means it's nice to know it's a genuine place and not just a tourist thing
Fascinating palce.. Good photo opportunity but beware of locals selling goods or posing for pictures. They are very persistent! Also a bottleneck getting through the village.

Excellent view but careful. The rice terrace is spectacular. I love the view. Take some time to stop here and enjoy the view on your way to Kintamani. You can also have a breakfast by the terrace: they are a few mini restaurants you can choose.If you wear right attire, you can go down the rice terrace and climb the other side. The view is much better on the other side. However, you need to be careful as some of the path is quite slippery.

Come earlier before it's get too hot. We came here yesterday. It is beautiful scenery and we pretty much enjoy our trip to get to the location, using our rented bike. But please note, Bali is hot, and we arrived at 12pm. It is extremely hot. Maybe will be better if you come earlier. Just don't forget to pack your sunblock and water.

Ok to visit but nothing special if you've seen other ricefields elsewhere. If you happen to be in the Ubud area then by all means take the effort and go to Tegalong but if you've seen ricefields in places like Taiwan, Thailand or Japan before then maybe this is nothing special. This one is probably the most famous one in Bali but there are actually 3 or 4 others in the area which are larger and maybe equally picturesque but less "touristy". Once you're here you can walk down to the ricefields and walk around there, but it's pretty steep. If you don't want to walk down, then spend 15-20 minutes here. Or you could stay here much longer if you're doing the "hike". Not a place to visit if it is a rainy day. And we were also a bit unlucky in that they just harvested the rice before we arrived, so the fields were not as pretty. My nephew went here only a few days before me and his pictures are nicer because of that.

Rude local thugs demanding donations ruined beautiful UNESCO site. Just a heads up: you pay 10,000 IDR to enter the fields and then at multiple times will be hassled by locals to make a 'donation' otherwise they won't let you pass. One of them jumped in front of me and started yelling that the additional 10,000 I gave him was not enough. Best just be prepared for this kind of behaviour and come with a few 10k notes because the terrace is definitely worth seeing, even if just from the viewing platform at the top.

Beautiful but has been ruined by tourism. It is pretty amazing to see even if there is no actual no rice paddies at the moment...When you arrive there is a checkpoint that when you are about to exit the Tegalalang area have to pay, but if you leave through a backroad, you will be fine and not have to pay just because you are a tourist. Also I would recommend not parking right in front of the terraces because some local people there or even the police will ask you to pay. This is just another way that government and some people take advantage of tourists. From the moment when you arrive in the area, children will be coming from left and right to ask you to buy something or support their school and pushy sales ladies trying to lure you into their shops without taking no for an answer. Also had an encounter with an aggressive dog, almost bit my ankles for no reason, just came running up to me from the other side of the road to give me a scare.Overall beautiful rice terrace but it has been ruined by locals taking advantage of tourism. Trying to enjoy beauty and having pushy people around creates not such a grand experience.

Pretty and worth a visit. We went there just to see the rice terrace and managed to get the obligatory <3 Bali picture overlooking the fields. We didn't stay too long maybe 20-30 mins but we saw lots of people walking around the terraces. Pretty place but busy with tourists. We had a driver but parking was a bit of problem even if you were on a scooter so busy.

Top Attraction with Beautiful Views ; but Bring Suitable Footwear!. The Tegalalang Rice Terrace is one of the top attractions in Ubud offering spectacular views of the rice terraces. However, it is imperative to bring suitable footwear as the paths are often quite slippers and steep and during our trip we saw several tourists fall by not bringing suitable footwear. If you want to walk through the rice terraces it would undoubtedly be a great experience, though perhaps strenuous! However be sure to bring some small notes as farmers may ask for a small donation for you to walk through their fields. I would definitely recommend this attraction to all tourists.

Beautiful sight. Lovely place to visit and when we were there it rained and it looked even more beautiful, its one of the best sites to visit for sure. very crowded at times but worth it and a must visit site.

Stunning views. Amazing views if you visit the terrace. It is very touristy so expect there to be a lot of street sellers and other people around. But if you appreciate the view for what it is I found none of the mattered. I was on a tour so couldn't stay very long but you can walk all around the terraces and see the fields up close.
Very nice!. Really at the Main Road but still the view is incredible! You can also walk through the rice terraces and have a close look !

Amazing view . We visited rice fields in the end of august. I never saw such rich green color in my life. You can have nice walk true fields, but I fully recommend you to buy banana hat from local sellers. First you will protect your head from sun, second its veery stylish anf last you will support local, mostly poor, people. Enjoy balinese coffee with fried bananas in local caffeterie and amazing view

Fascinating and pretty. We had lunch overlooking the terraces - a beautiful and peaceful place. The terraces themselves were very interesting to see and our guide gave us a lot of information about the techniques used. Well worth a visit!
Beautiful. Lovely rice terrasses which one can climb up and down. It is very popular with tourists, so it is not the most serene place in Bali. However, it is very beautiful and easy to access

Mixed feelings. We appreciated the visit and the view was really beautiful but we have to admit that we were disappointed by the local people asking for money every step we took.After the entrance ticket if you want to reach the top of the terraces you have to pay sort of "donation" to every guy/girl has a hut on the ground.One for the bridge, one for the path.. and we really felt like they treat tourists as ATM.Beautiful place but on my opinion the atmosphere is not the right one.

Beautiful. We came here on a scooter from Ubud and glad we did as the parking situation was horrendous around the area. The rice terrace is absolutely beautiful, halfway through visiting a torrential rain caught us out, it was still beautiful, but we had to cut the actual walk through the terraces short. Tried to wait out the rain in one of the restaurant with direct view over the rice terrace, it was lovely.

Not as bad as I was expecting. Having read reviews suggesting a tourist trap, I cycled up here from Ubud expecting a dump. In reality, it does have an abundance of gift shops at the roadside and eateries clinging to the other side, but it's not too intimidating. I ate lunch at Teras Cafe, which wasn't cheap, but also was pretty good. I sat and admired the terraces while I ate, then, after seeing all the locals interacting with tourists inside the terraces, decided against a walk. I'd avoided any harassment until that point, so I jumped on my bike and rolled back down the hill to Ubud. Nice day out.

Definitely worth a look!. Depending what growing stage the rice paddies are at, sometimes it can be prettier than others. If the growth is established, the rice paddies are a lush verdant green. Perch yourself in one of the many cafe options and order a banana pancake and enjoy the gorgeous view and ponder the centuries of farming it took to create this spectical. Incredible!!

A little touristic. If you have never seen rice terraces before, have limited time in Bali, or are passing through on the way into Ubud, by all means visit. However, if you drive around Bali you will see many more beautiful rice fields, with the waft of incense from the offerings wafted over you.....
Just amazing!. Everything that has to be said is in the title, if you are in Bali, you have to visit it. You can also stop in a Shop where you could try their local luwak Coffee ;-)

Scenic view. Nice experience seeing the rice terraces. Although would recommend being in rubber shoes and to be extra cautious when walking around the terraces. Very difficult to explore the vast area.
Great place for tourists. This is a nice rice field located 20 mins from Ubud. It is filled with tourists walking all around. In my opinion the rice fields you find around Ubud are much prettier.

It's beautiful!. Parking is a nightmare. Fortunately our driver dropped us off and we wandered around the rice paddies and ,of course, the shopping. Some serious bargaining is required here as they are used to the tourist market but it was great fun with great views and the amazingly friendly Balinese people.
Good but not as good as.... Jetaling rice terrace. Busy and lots of shops make it a tourist trap so I suggest getting there early. Oh and watch your step!

Incredible outlook. Awesome spot. It's so beautiful. Lovely to see these terraces and the workers in them. However extremely crowded with tourists. Worth going for a walk around down the bottom and other sides to get away from them all. Being bug repellent as there are a few mosquitos getting around.
Amazing Terraces. Stopped of for a short visit to the rice terraces. There were amazing. Very busy with with people. Walked a little way down, no real paths, just grass and mud to walk down.

A must do for anyone staying in Bali. Learn the realities of growing rice & scratching out a living using traditional rice growing & production methods. Incredibly labour intensive. Gives a great insight into a product we take for granted.

Stunning scenic views . My girlfriend and I visited Tegalalang Rice Terrace on our way to the Holy Spring Water Temple. It was beautiful, lush green rice paddies and a pretty backdrop. My only criticism is every 100m there is a bamboo shack where the locals won't let you pass until you make a donation, so keep a few IDR2000 free...

A must. This is the must of Ubud area. A spectacular view over the rice terraces. I would like to suggest you the best timing to be there to avoid traffic and minibuses...but I don't think exist. Anyhow go and have a look and a walk in the fields.
Beautiful but crowded. The terraces are beautiful, but it's full of tourists. I preferred Jatiluwih personally, but you should still have a look.

Morning sights. Make sure you wear appropriate foot wear. We did it in thongs but joggers would have been better. A great leg workout. And a heap of fun negotiating which path to take. The tolls are not too bad... we paid 2. At $1 AUD for 3 of us not to shabby.

Average photo opportunity. Worth only a short stop, too touristy and full of tourist traps. Beware of old men posing for photos. Will demand money and before you realise, they would have put hands in your pocket. Handicrafts are grossly overpriced, will give for 100-150 percent less price. At least. With a display of total disinterest, you can bring down the price even more. If there, go for a small trek into the fields on your own. Good photo opportunity

Authentic Balinese Farm. We firstly didn’t have planning to walk up the terrace but when I arrived there I was eager to go up the terrace. Most of visitors just see from the side road. It will be nicer to walk through rice field
Nice view... Rice terace tegalalang is very nice view, and so nice atmosfir.. we can do walking a round the teracesFeel like walk at the pictureSo nice

More tourists than rice terraces. Our visit in early August was quite a disappointment. The 30 min drive from Ubud along a street of souvenir shops made me sense what to expect: loads of tourists, more shops, and then the rice terraces. Unfortunately it was just after harvest, so there was no rice plants but terraces of brown ponds or soil. We were told by a local friend that instead it's recommended to visit the UNESCO protected Rice Fields around Ubud.

Simply Beautiful !. Visiting the Rice Terrace is a must activity should you ever visit Bali. You can see the locals at work while making a tour across the greenary. The shops on the main road are quite expensive but you can always bargain and purchase for a decent price. We were accompanied by our local tourguide called Comang throughout our holiday stay in Bali and can be recommended for cheap yet comfortable day tours via +62 877 6004 4646. You can whatsapp him for more details.

Nice views, great photos and exercise too!!. It was 2nd in our list after the river rafting, it was not so far. our ride dropped us and paid for our entrance which was not much. You have to be careful if you are in slipper like us. What we didn't like is after we start walking inside the field; we were stopped by an old aggressive lady who imposed a fees of 20,000 per person to pass!!!!
beautiful place. beautiful place just like you see in the pictures.Nothing much to do here though just a place to come and click the pictures

Beautiful location, good prices for meals at the cafe, clean toilets, Steep stairs. This whole area is so pretty and so much cooler (temperature) than Kuta. Looking out over the rice fields is naturally calming, we loved it. Wehad a really nice meal, spring rolls were delicious, chicken satay, mie goreng - everything was good. The drinks were icy cold and staff friendly. The toilets are nice and clean, so use them before heading back to Ubud or travelling on from here. The steps are uneven and quite steep, if you have bad knees or mobility problems be careful - you might get down but have trouble getting up. The crochet goods line the streets and you can get some real bargains here - cheaper than Kuta. The mosaic plates are stunning - I could've gone crazy but getting it home is another thing. Enjoy this place, it's beautiful.
Simply Beautiful. Come at 8am to skip the crowd and enjoy hovering sunrays. A must do when in Bali but some quieter valleys might exist around providing you got time to explore.

Too much toerists. I would not go here. If you really want to see rice fields, this is not the place to be. The place is so toeristy, they ask you an entrance fee to enter the village and everywhere you see man standing to take a picture with you. We could not even enjoy the rice fields because of the crowded place.

Admire the hard words!. This place is entrance free to visitors but you might be required to give donation when you're trekking along the terraces. They said the donation was for preservation or whatever. Recommend to trek in dry days only as the road is quite narrow and no safety tools are arranged here, you're responsible for your own steps :)As an Asian, rice terrace is something not so " WOW" to us, however what made us feel it worths to travel a long way to be here was a very fresh feeling with amazing panoramic view once you get to the top of this hill. Such a wonderful touch to the serene nature and felt appreciate to hard works of all people here to keep this terrace in good condition. A good camera will help you to have stunning captures :)

Nice spor. Come in early to avoid the crowd. Descent spot allowing you to walk into the rice terrasse. Entrance fee is not too expensive but be prepared to make donations at different check points to be able to walk forward..

One of the most beautiful places in Bali. I definitely recommend to visit. It was great to have a coconut enjoying the panaramic views and realising how rice paddies are deeply integrated into the cultural life of balinese people. The place is authentic and on the other hand is very welcoming for tourists. You can walk around easily or just enjoying overviewing from the top.

Loved it !. If your curious about this place but you still haven't made up your mind yet, I say GO for it! We had a great time in the fields. Walking around taking photos we didn't relised how time passed so quick. Surrounded by lot of souvenir shops and cafe/resturants. When you get there make sure you take small change locals will ask for donations. Also i have to mention, to get a good view there is little hut at the top of the terrace. Local young girl selling cocconuts. It has a seating area, a swing and a priceless Beatiful view..You won't be disappointed. Enjoy :)
Nice walk and great pictures . Cheap entrance, a bit of a difficult walk perhaps for elderly and kids ("stairs" can be far apart), beautiful scenery, visit while in Ubud!

Beautiful rice fields close to Ubud. Just 15 kilometres north of Ubud with wonderful rice fields. I prefer these to the Unesco ones up north, though obviously these are smaller. If you are driving yourself it is easy to find - straight north of the Arjung statue. Cars passing through have to pay a fee to the Banjar. Scooters mostly don't. The many cafes and restaurants has steep prices, but the view makes it worth it.

Gorgeous place with stunning views. We went from Ubud on a rented motorbike and had no issues finding it. We thoroughly enjoyed walking on the narrow paths and taking in the stunning views. We were asked for donations 4 times along the way, so keep in mind to not donate all your money at the initial stop.

looks nice but they will milk you. Beautiful place but it can get very expensive. 10k for parking or some unofficial entry fee and on the way in the rice terraces are multiple "donation" stations where you are forced to pay enough to let you by. 2k may be enough but in the donation basket they only keep >= 10k notes. many kids offensively try to sell postcards as their "school project". So it's a beautiful but not really maintained place with lots of annoying locals.

Tick the box. Best to go early here as around lunch time to afternnon it can get a little crazy and crowded.This is a fantastic place for photos of the beautiful rice terraces , you can walk up and down if youre feeling energetic too.Plenty of small warungs to get food and drinks also....at least see it once.

Worth a visit from Ubud. 25 minutes drive north of Ubud, with loads of great little craft shops, super cheap, on the road in. Wife bought a set of 3 giraffes, few other bits cost less than 180,000 inr. The rice terrace was good, you don't need long there unless you plan to walk around it all, which we couldn't as travelling with our baby. Good some great photos, loads of cafes to grab a Bintang! ,

Beautiful!. These rice terraces are very beautiful and you will have a better experience if you walk around rather than just staying at the top. If you are happy scootering it is only a short ride from Ubud. The traffic here can get rather bad late in the day! So always good to visit early in the morning!
not really good if after harvest time. we visited this area a few month ago , we arrive here in the day time, so hot for us and the view is not so green because after harvest time
Beautiful. Even just catching a glimpse of this beautiful attraction will stick in your mind. Wonderful greenery,

Unesco rice terraces that have to be seen. These are not only very picturesque but also make you stop and think about the work that can go into producing one grain of rice! You can also start to understand what back breaking work it must be, working in the mountain terraces. You need to get out of the car to explore the terraces to appreciate the water flowing through the region. You also pass through some of the original jungle which does help you to form a picture of what Bali was like before development. Not too expensive to see this site, just a toll on the road.
Worth a visit. We stopped here as part of a day tour. Would have liked more time to walk through but still worth a stop!

Don't be lazy go down there . Don't just go there to look from the top go down its so worth it and very beautiful inmates what stage of growth the rice is at! Also go down on the other side because lazy tourist stay on the entry side mostly so much nicer away from the crowds!! Great restaurants surrounding. Be prepared to pay donations inside also only about 5000r pp per check point amounting to about $1.50 for a decent view or the rice terraces. Must do in Ubud!!
Beautiful rice paddies!. Authentic rice fields with local people showing you how to collect rice or plant peanuts. Good trek of 2 hours!

Scenic terraces. This is a scenic place and it gets even better when you walk down the terraces. There are a couple of photo-op spots (I don't know who made them), but they are well made with a lot of caption plates. In order to get to the other side, you have to cross a bridge by paying a "forced" donation of as much as you want :)

It’s a bit of a drive, but well worth it. Miles upon miles of beautifully carved rice terraces lining the hillsides…they cascade down from the hill top like a waterfall. With unobstructed views – no buildings, busses, and very few tourist – they are beautiful. No mystery why this is a World Heritage site. Worth every bit of time and money to enjoy such a spectacular site and location.

Absolutely stunning.. Get there early- around 8 and it will still be nice and quiet. The place is absolutely beautiful. There are several locals collecting money along the terraces and are a bit aggressive- so onlyGive small bills as you'll Likely pay 2,3, or even 4 times!
Rice paddies, that's it.. Terrible to park, crowded with tourists so difficult to take good photos. You need to be quite fit, the paddies are steep.

Beautiful Green. You can't easily find in other countries around the world, view of rice field like this. This has been million years the farmers maintain. That was why lots of foreigners very much interested in this beauty. Greenish, refresh our eyes.

Over run with tourists. The influx of tourists has made this once serene place crowded and the many cars often cause traffic jam on the narrow stretch here. Is best to come early before the tour buses arrived, and is less hot too.Take a walk into the rice field but prepare to pay some donation for them to 'built bridge', not once but 2-3 times as you walk into the terrace.

Beautiful views, lots of toursts. Tough this place is full of tourists taking lots of pictures, you can enjoy a beautiful view of the rice fields. It is a charming place, you can walk around and find more peaceful spots without that many people to enjoy fully.
Beautiful . Beautifully kept, picturesque place. A bit of hike if u want to go to the top. Although you can spot rice plantation all through ubud.
Amazing agricultural feat. Delighted with views, such a lush and beautiful scene to survey for the 4 of us and not far from the cultural town of a Ubud .

Beautiful views. We saw this area as part of a day tour and it was beautiful. It was also cooler in the breeze and a nice place to sit and relax. You could walk through the paddy fields for nice photos and wander amongst the market stalls. Iced drinks and snacks readily available but the area is pretty busy. As we had rice field views from our hotel we would probably not choose it as a single destination but it was a pleasant change as part of a tour.

The best feature of Ubud. We had great fun walking down and then up the rice paddies. It is a good exercise for us but a fun game for my kids as they race along the tiny paths between the fields. Some locals would offer to bring you around as a guide. You probably would not need it but for first timers it helps.

Tourist Trap. Beautiful place but there are other rice paddies that are far better. Place could be a bit busy from tourists since it's accessible, just along the road, and cheap entrance fee. If you dont have much time to visit rice paddies, this is a great way for you to see one and have your photos taken.If you're staying longer in Bali, read and visit other paddies.
Green. Enjoying the great view at this fantastic rice field. Great to explore the nearby area and took a little walk around the rice field. There are some cafe around it to enjoying the view.
Beautiful but rather spoiled by touristy restaurants . The rice terraces are lovely and the view is amazing but there are several over priced and unexciting restaurants that have crowded the area.

Mass tourism at its best. If you arrive at the Tegalalang Rice Terrace you got an impressive view but when you try to take some pictures you always get asked by some annoying locals to buy some useless souvenirs. Also many young children try to sell useless postcards in 2016 and they don't really accept your friendly "no, thank you". As the terrace is part of many guided tours you also have many western tourists all around the firlds that make it hard to take authentic pictures.

One of the things to do when you are in Ubud. Tegalalang rice terrace address is located at Tegalalang village, north part of Ubud, Gianyar regency and 600 meters above sea level. The place is hot and humid, but the view is superb. You will need about 25 minutes driving from Ubud market with a scooter.To see the rice terrace view is quite easy and free. It gives you a good idea on the complexity of terrace rice farming.

A Rice Terrace. Thats All. Okay i know that the rice terrace was shaped beautifully. but for me as a local person, its just a rice terrace. i admit that the view was amazing. but its not such a hype for me. maybe if i go abroad and see wheat farm then i will be amazed. hahaha. the parking fee is free for motor. there are a lot of shops and restaurant in this place. you can easily reach this place from ubud.

A must do. Yes it is full of tourists, yes you will have to donate a few times but do not miss these rice fields. It is one of the best in Bali. It is better to arrive around 09:30 for a better light , will take at least 2 hours if you take pictures.

Breathtaking views of rice fields . We arrived quite early at Tegalalang with our scooters, to avoid traffic and massive groups of tourist. That was quite a good idea as the access to the rice fields is through tiny narrow paths.These are not flat and large rice fields as you may see around in the region, but rather terraces and one plantation above the other.I went with slippers but ended up more comfortable barefoot, as the ground was sometimes wet and muddy, almost felt into the wet rice field. Take some sandals or sport shoes, it's safer. Upon arrival you will see many cafés, you do NOT have to drink and stay, just go through them to access the rice fields at their stairways. You should manage to make it down the valley and up again towards the opposite side of your arrival side.There is no entrance fee and no need for guides, BUT be prepared to spend some "donation" as the different land owners ask you money to maintain the paths and won't let you past their barrier. I paid three times 10.000 IDR (I saw some tourist paying 20.000 and 50.000! way too much), but it is worth if you want to make it up to a hidden valley which I accessed walking passed an upper lake with a yellow umbrella.There you will find a charming old and smiley farmer, musician and proud to show and play some of his instruments. He also sells you young coconut, by far my best in Ubud area although the price was ridiculously high, 30.000 IDR but which I bargained a bit and got lots of nice pictures of him in return. Avoid buying the postcards the kids arriving in swarms try insistently to sell. It is always "for their school", really don't know in who's pocket that money will end but sounds like local family-mafia to me, same scam as in other countries. Overall the visit shouldn't take more than 45-60 minutes. Nice place, beautiful scenery, worth the visit.
Bali at Its Best. Away from the hustle and bustle of busy Ubud the rice fields offer an incredible landscape to enjoy. A photographers delight. Artists shops along the way.

Very beautiful. You can take a walk in the rice fields! Its nice to see new things! Although its not a very big place but there lot of tourists and u can enjoy learning how rice is planted and its steps
