Beautiful but full of tourists :-). It's a big attraction so it's full of tourists. And I mean, really full :-) Still nice to see and worth going.

Beautiful views. The rice terraces are lovely and nice to walk around and explore.
Be aware there will be lots of stops to pay a donation for 'maintenance.' One man we met was very rude and pushy, I would suggest bringing small notes so that you can pay them to pass and not let it ruin your experience.

Bring small money. The view is great and it is nice to walk around. This is just one of the many rice fields on Bali though. Make sure you have some 5k rupee bills, as some locals have built some guard posts on the trail and only let you through when you make a "donation".
WOW!. The terraces are spectacular. Get there early in the morning before the crowds for some great photo op's. Try to include a side trip to the Pilani Coffee Plantation. You won't be disappointed.
Rice Terrace and Crowds. The rice terraces are ok, but this is super crowded place full of vendors and hustlers. There are better rice terraces at up the road a few kms at Pulina Agro

Going to seed....?. Once a beautiful place, very regrettably now overrun with commercialism and floods of tourists and traffic.
Still, its worth a visit and a sip of coffee or local brew at one of the fringe cafes along the bank.
Cheap, crowded, disappointing. Title says it all. Go to the Ritz instead (meal/ afternoon tea) for great views on unspoiled jungle and an experience to remember. Did not take pictures as I hated it.

Stunning . Definitely worth a trip. Be aware that you should wear trainers if you are planning on walking round the terraces as the paths are uneven and slippy. Also take plenty of water - it gets hot! The views are beautiful and it's really nice to get out into the countryside of Bali a bit. Definitely go if you have the time!

Wonderful Wiev. Some kind of wiew that you may only see in your dreams or in tegalalang. That was the best wiev i have ever seen. Very close from Ubud Centre. If you want to see the all wiev you should visit with motorcycle.

Tegallalang - nice 3 hour morning excursion off Ubud. Some tips : 1. Its easy to organize a taxi with a 60-90 minute wait at Tegallalang. You need to pay about 250-300k IndRup for that. On either side of Monkey forest road or any other busy street you have owners of vehicles calling out to you 2. Its really hot and humid out there and so an early morning trip really helps. We left at around 8:00 am - may have been better to leave earlier. 3. Takes about 30 minutes to get to Tegellelang. Your taxi driver will need to park at the designated area - go quickly to the side that oversees the terraces and figure out the public steps that take you to the rice fields. You go down the constructed steps and after crossing a small brook start climbing up the terraces where you see farmers working ( some will smile and wave at you )4. You will have to pay small amounts as donation at points during the walk. Keep some smaller value local currency handy Its a nice walk through greenery, interesting to watch the terraces and local farming, also a great place for pictures

Breathe taking views. Very nice views at the rice terrace but it needs an effort as the hiking itself might take up to two hours, so get urself ready and do not dress great, recommended to be on slippers or an old shoe, you might face some mud areas

Go first thing in the morning . We went first thing in the morning around 7:50. We were the only ones there which was quite the surprise after reading all the reviews. It rained a lot the night before so I got the water shots I was hoping for. Very happy we went there early. Afterwards we went to water temple and then mount Kawi. We were also close to the only ones there too.

Must visit touristey stopover!. This place was extremely crowded. I was not expecting it to be as crowded as it was. I enjoyed visiting it though but I had to leave after some time due to the crowds. Do go early in the day out here to avoid the crowds & to take photos in a more diffused lighting situation.

Very nice but could have been cleaner. Nice place to see the famous Balinese rice field terrace. Many good photo shoots and you can actually do trekking on the rice fields. Just look for a gate with statues of two women carrying rice containers to enter the trekking zone. Beware that the pathway is quite steep and can be tiring during the climb up.The whole place could have been cleaner thought. Saw several trashes laying on the rice field. Shame!Overall a nicr experience. Do check when the crops are near harvest. That would be the best time to visit.

Beautiful view over the riceterrace. Worth a visit if you like nature.The view from the viewpoint is very pretty.We didnt walk around because we were tired from the whole day, but we sat down, bought a juice and just looked at the pretty terrace.

Great place, worth the hike!. This place gives you a really adventurous feeling; climb and walk wherever you want. It has many nice view points. About halfway down the trail there is a pot for donations. You may decide the amount of the donation yourself of course.
Worth including. We visited the rice terrace on a day out in Ubud, well worth a visit although there can be a lot of people
Really beautiful don't miss this. Really really stunning view here. Does get quite busy but a little patience and you can get great pictures. Great little area for shopping too

Good view. But it's a "take a photo and go" place. Nice and beautiful view at this place. But it isn't a place to spend to much time. As like every place in Ubud you have to pay an entrance fee. If you have to choose one rice terrace I would suggest Jatihluwi.

A sight for sore eyes!. Fantastic view, made better by sipping young coconuts from the Teras cafe. Definitely a kodak moment! You can choose to climb up and down the terraces if you're feeling energetic, or you can opt for the lazy way out like we did and just soak it all in from the cafe.

Unforgetable views of the rice fields and ubud jubgle. A must see place in ubud. Large amounts of tice fields at your footstep. Here you will get the chance to take amazing pictures and walk through the rice fields. Make sure you get your walking shoes on as flip flops are not recomended for this type of activity

Beautiful but really overrun. These rice terraces are stunning. We went in the afternoon to catch the pre-sunset light ... along with a ton of other tourists, many posing and hamming it up with selfie sticks. The terraces are just off a street lined with tourist shops too. Just thought it would be helpful to know the whole vibe and context before you go. If you want a similar view but quieter experience, seek out the lesser known terraces sprinkled around the island.

One of the best. This Rice terrace is really something to see in Bali. You can walk through and discover closely.Avoid stopping at the first part of the terace when you are coming from ubud center, the amount of people there will just spoil the visit.You can stop at the 3rd one, quiet, calm, less tourists and you can take amazing pictures.At some point, i think you 'll have to pay to continue walking through the rice fields ( don't know why but , you know, tourism ).Quick tip : it's real life there, not a garden in Paris, so watch out for snakes and/ or spiders and what may live there.Enjoy the trip !Cheers
Nice Paddy Field but too many extra charge when you go up!. Its a nice paddy field but there are too many extra charge like tol station when you go up! Kinda disappointed but everything worth it!
Beautiful!!!. The view is stunning but in high season there is a lot of people and a lot of traffic to go there !!
Excellent views..... This is very nice green lush place. One can enjoy with eye relax. Also walking around rice farm is best experience. Photo perfect place.

Classic rice terraces of Bali. If you want to see the rice terraces that you see in all Bali photos, then this is the place. However, it's really very touristy now. We spent only 30mins to take in the view and some photos before leaving.

Nice terraces, close to Ubud.... It was really nice experience at sunset...not a lot of turists then, so I guess we were lucky :) It's nice to have a beer in one of the bars there and admire the view...
Beautiful view. We liked the view but that's the only thing that is taking you breath away. For the rest you not much do at this place. But it's a Nice view that u must see

Busy super touristy. Major attraction with lots of tourists, crowded, not a relaxing place to be. Typical tourist trap!
On the way there we saw many shops selling all kinds of arts, crafts & souvenirs

Bring some small change for donations. The rice terrace is interesting to walk through but make sure you bring some small notes for donations. We had to pay for a ticket to go into the terrace and then as you walk along on the different tracks there will be a hut with a person there asking for a donation to keep on going. If you don't have any money you can't go through, be aware that they will also stop you when you come back through asking for a donation again, just say 'No I gave you money when I came in'. The donation doesn't need to be much but if you are unaware you will not be able to go through. I think there are 3 different places that they ask for money on the trail. Can be very hot while walking so make sure you take some water and get there early or later in the day.

Rice Terrace - a experince. Its an very intereting experince visit the Rice Terrace, it allows you to experince the way of life in the Asian continent which is very unquie compared to other place like India where rice field are very different.

A nature walk trekking through the rice fields.. Pure oxygen out in the openfields,coconuts trees yonder and within the rice fields.The convenience stalls beside the road....the power to bargain is very essential.Do not trust their opening prices.An advice:- D norm....I told them I feel very ashame to bargain ( as I will knock @ least 60% off their opening prices ).I told them...its better they open their discounted prices.
Very tourist focused. Other surrounding areas of Ubud with rice fields are just as nice and the drinks and food isn't overpriced like here.

Amazing . Quite an amazing view to take in. Past all the traffic and tourist it's such a beautiful site to see. You have to pay 10k (IDR) to view the terraces and can stay there as long as you please. Awesome experience, u must!!!
worth the trip!. this attraction was a bit far from our location. we stayed in Ubud... this place is worth the trip! it is rice field as far as the eyes can see!

Beautiful. This rice terrace is only small compared to Jatiluwih, but still very pretty.From the restuarants behind the shops you have a nice view on the rice terrace, you can also enter the fields there and go for a stroll. Please be respectful to the farmers though and give them a tip (10.000/20.000 RP), as you are walking on their land.
Nice. I guess this was one of the nicer views in the Ubud area. However, if you have traveled in Southeast Asia, the view isn't anything you haven't seen before.

Terraced paddy fields amidst lush greenery . For folks who haven't seen paddy cultivation, this is an interesting visit. Lush greenery, helpful locals and pleasant rural environment. Not for the old, very young or infirm since the trek through the terraces involve steep muddy steps.
Nice relaxing plce. I always spent some here for tea.. Even tough a bit pricey its very reccomended.. 2 hours is a minimal when u wan a relaxing mood
So fallin in love with this place. I cant write much about this place..., as i know i really love this place. The view really looks like a painting, so fantastic...

Nice, but watch for "donations". We stopped on our way further north, and enjoyed the view. The terraces weren't green, but still looked pretty. The views from the roadside of the terraces are great. Going down to the bottom and to the other side, you run into a person asking for donations for the upkeep of the terraces. We said ok, gave 10k, and went on. After about 100m, there was another man asking for donations at another shack. We said we already donated, he said this was a "different" one, and when we stated we already gave a donation, he told us we couldn't pass, and told us to go away.He was a terribly rude man, and it was good to see people who came up after us did not give him anything and turned back (as we did). Even people who came from the other side, he barred their way along the path and told them to donate.Clearly a racket, so advice is to enjoy the terraces from the road-side of the terrace. Views from the other side are ok, but you get pretty much the same as from the front. Don't pay more than 1 donation, especially if they're rude like the man we ran into.
Beautiful . It was beautiful seeing the rice terrace and learning all about how it works and how the process is.

Nice family trip. We combined the Tegalalang rice terraces with Ubud and the Tegenungan falls. It was a splendid day out from Seminyak with our 5 month old daughter. We took her with us in a carrier and hiked the terraces. We enjoyed our time with the stunning views. On the way to the terraces you can already enjoy more production oriented rice fields, these however are a true attraction.

Great with a cycling or walking tour guide. We cycled through the rice terrace with Greenbike tours and learned about the irrigation system and rice harvesting. This was a great experience and very interesting. The afternoon is a great time for this activity because the sun isn't so harsh and the sunset is very pretty reflecting on the terrace.

Just okay. I had wanted to see this attraction as it was recommended by locals. But when we got there I was a bit disappointed.Maybe because I come from the Philippines that has the Banawe rice terraces which is more grandiose.Also the traffic, people and the stalls along the road make it harder to enjoy the view, which is also happening to the Banawe Rice terraces. There a lot of souvenir shops, convenience outlets and restaurants around.
Great view. You have to climb there. It's just amazing. The work of people, the scenery... It's an amazing place. There are many restaurants with very good food and very small prices

gorgeous views!. Breathtaking views 20minutes from Ubud centre. We took the four hour tour that stopped at - Tegalalang Rice Terrace, plantations (with view of the rice fields) and the holy water temple. Highly recommend it. We loved it!

Worth the drive . This is a breathtaking spot to view the classic Bali terraced rice fields. We hired a scooter and rode from Ubud in about 20 minutes, returning in a loop via Keliki and Sanggingan road. If you have independent transport, check out a map and you will see it's easy to take a circuit back to Ubud, adding to the interest and scenery. The shops and cafes where you view the rice terraces from are a bit of a tourist trap, but a nice place to have a drink and enjoy the vista.

Gorgeous tourist trap :) worth a visit. Gorgeous view and many perfect Kodak moments. Nothing in this world is free so be prepared to pay to be able to walk in the rice fields, abt 10 000IDR per person. This particular rice terrace itself is completely meant for tourists and the actual rice fields aren't with such a scenery. Still worth a visit if you have time and strength to walk down the very narrow paths.

Nothing much to see. Ricefield were none existence. And even if there is, its a rather small area and in its beginning stage. And 1 more thing that me and my group of friends were frustrated was the number of "gantry donations" by the locals. We paid for the entrance fee therefore it is ridiculous to be paying for "gantry donations" in the ricefield area. We came across at least "gantry" areas by the locals. And dont have a choice but to "donate" some money. And the locals were aggresive too as they insist to be paid before allowing us to go through their make-shift gantries.

Great scenery, worth a visit if in the area. We visited these rice fields as some friends of ours stayed at a place close to them. Very nice scenery and great picture opportunity. A nice place to see close to Ubus
Wonderful panorama on rice terrace. The view is breathtaking and so peaceful. If you expect to see typical rice terraces, you should go to Tagallalang! Amazing spot!

Overrun. On an island with hundreds or thousands of sumptuous rice terraces, this is the one that draws Disney-like crowds... totally killing the vibe. Maybe at sunrise or during a heavy rain it'd be more manageable ... otherwise it made me depressed and sad to see a hundred tourists trampling on this area.

Magnificent views!. Absolutely beautiful to see, a must go place for when in Ubud. It really is a wonderful sight. Just a shame that the surrounding areas have become crowded. Filled with souvenir shops and plastic things. It takes away the peaceful and beauty of this area. But this is what is happening all over the world. Just beware of overpricing. Nevertheless the view is worth the journey up here!
Rice terraces. Nice scenery. Definitely worth a visit. Make sure to go down from the road and walk the terraces. Be careful it gets a bit slippery.

How long will this last. The rice terraces are still extremely beautifull, but already the area is reducing too much and I wonder how long it will take untill the first tourist accomodation reaches these terraces.

Amazing scenary. We went their in thr evening around 5pm probably the best time . Clear blue sky with lush green rice terraces makes it a perfect spot for photographers. Indulge yourself at the cafe overlooking the terraces. No steps to go down and coming back so make sure you are ready to go through the muddy footpath

Must see. My boyfriend made me walk with my eyes closed till we got to the spot with the best view so on first impact, it really took my breath away. It is beautiful. Read about the rice fields before you go. The irrigation system is really quite impressive. And have lunch at one of the restaurants overseeing the fields. Best part of this visit to Ubud.

Not special but must see. The ricefields were not very different from other ricefields, but surely worth to visit one of all the ricefields. This one was not free to walk around, maybe you can walk around at some other fields for free.

Cool place to take a look!. Stopped here for a few photos. Lots of people but cool spot to take a few photos and enjoy the views. Again it does get crowded but fun to see. We didn't spend a lot of time here nor did we walk in the fields.

Beautiful Ubud rice fields . Ubud rice fields are simple breathtaking and tranquil .We rented a scooter while we stayed in Ubud which allowed us to ride to rice fields quite easily to enjoy the serenity . There are plenty of local restaurants around rice fields and their food is quite good and safe to eat , you can also walk around the rice fields but mind that step as it can be slippery .

Nice enough, but very touristy. While it's nice to see the rice terraces on the hill sides, I think you can see more authentic ones in the surrounding areas of Ubud with real people tending them and you can see them much better. The main street is jammed with tourists and souvenir shops.

Beware of scammers . So disappointed! I was really looking forward to seeing the rice fields but there are none! The terraces are just full of mud and the whole place is a tourist trap - you can see more rice fields driving around Bali.Also, there is a fake admission office set up that demands you pay 10,000 idr each to go to the rice fields - yes it's not much according to western standards but it's the principle. The office looks very legit with the workers all wearing uniforms but it's not - no one ever checks your ticket and you are never told where the money goes. Furthermore, when you get to the top there are locals demanding you make a 'voluntary' donation before you are allowed entrance. Not worth the trip - just get your driver to stop at the many rice fields around Bali instead.

Takes you away from the busy streets but close to town. This walk begins just up from the tressel bridge and cuttting in Ubud and finishes near the palace right in the town centre. This makes this walk an easy and convenient stoll through the rice paddies away from the busy ness.

Make sure you check the weather forecast before you go!. Spent several hours here in the early afternoon and unfortunately got caught in the rain! We rented a scooter to get there from our hotel (right in the main touristy area) as it's much too far to walk. There's not really any obvious parking, we just ended up pulling over and parking where a few other scooters were parked. There's also no really obvious start and end points, you just go down into the terraces at some point and walk along the edges going up, down, or whichever way you please. The initial areas are quite full of tourists, local children trying to sell you postcards or act as your guide, and locals offering you a chance to take a picture holding their baskets (for a cost of course). You can go as off-the-beaten-path as you want, but be aware there won't be an obvious way out unless you go back the way you came (which is how we ended up stuck out in the rain!). If you do get stuck in the rain be careful as things will be very soggy and slippery very fast! It would be advisable to wear proper shoes (either hiking shoes or sneakers) as opposed to flip flops as even when it's not raining there are some descents without a good path/steps down. Overall it's a must-see but choose your time with the weather in mind!

Looking tired but maybe worth a visit to Pakadui. All a bit packed with cars scooters and taxis and the padi fields look as though they have been over-trekked. Doesn't seem to be many of the fields actually active with rice - more that the structures of the fields are an attraction in themselves - which they could be because they are amazing. All looks and feels a bit tired now which is a shame because they would have been spectacular in their best days. If you do come up to here then might be worth walking for 10 minutes up the road (turn right on road just after the terraces) to little village (string of houses) of Pakadui where a number of homes specialise in carving Garudas - you will see single carvers or family of carvers at work and they will be delighted to show you some of their work with no pressure to buy - the carving is amazing.

Amazing. I really enjoyed walking in the rice terrace. It is an experience highly recomended! Just for that worth It the visit to ubud in My opinion. The trekking was not Hard. We are not sportive People and we did It very relaxed.

Beautiful. A must see beauty if you are in UBUD. If you have a bike, just jump on it and go for a ride to see this amazing place. Rain or Shine the green you see here is something to remember. the well designed terrace is another art to wonder about the structure of this place.

Breathtaking. Don't miss the 90min walk through this UNESO world heritage site. Have shoes with a good profile or go bare-food. Have a young fresh coconut at one of the farmers huts. You never had a better one!

Tourist trap. This place is no more than a tourist trap. I've first visited in 2010 when it was still nice and there was actually rice growing on the fields. When I went again this year, I was really disappointed. There was no rice, the terraces were either dry or just muddy. All the tourists are taken to this spot on their tours, so there are souvenir shops all over the place. It just felt like a massive tourist trap. There are so many nicer rice terraces in Bali, don't bother visiting this place. Just ask your driver to take you to other terraces, where you can actually see the rice and people working on their fields.

Very nice but make sure to visit other rice terraces in Ubud!. It's definitely worth stopping by the Tegalalang rice terraces but I found it to be a bit crowded and not as pleasant to walk through. Definitely find other areas of Ubud with nice rice terraces where they actually grow rice!

Beautiful . A beautiful spot in Ubud to escape the intense humidity! We had a late lunch here overlooking the terraces and it was so peaceful. The view is stunning as you eat your lunch and watch people tending to the crops.You get locals hounding you to buy things off the street but stand your ground and they back off!
Amazing view . Visited this place as a part of day excursion trip . Quite impressed and loved it . Although did not hike as it was too hot to walk in the bare sun .

A little disappointing, and not the UNESCO world heritage sites. I booked a tour to pick up my family in Seminyak, tour some of the top sites, and then deliver us to our hotel in Ubud. Since I asked for rice terraces, this was the most convenient. At the time we visited the terraces were being smoked for bugs, which left even less to see. If you've never seen rice terraces and you have limited options, this is worth a stop, but if you've been poring over Nat Geo photographs of the gorgeous Balinese rice terraces, be prepared that this may not match up. Also, depending on the time of the year, the terraces may be filled with rice, and the prettier photographs of the sun reflected in the terraces come later when the terraces are flooded for harvesting. Rice is typically harvested twice a year - all guides should be able to help you time this.
Beautiful view - great for photos!. A stunning spot to stop and have a bite to eat at one of the many warungs/cafes that over look the rice terraces before heading down the main road for some bargins
Rice terraces . Beautiful but rice plants was still young and not as luscious as on all the postcards photos. Will definitely recommend visiting this fields with the eBikes tour.
Stunning landscape but very touristy . The rice terraces are something to do when stopping at Ubud. Unfortunately the place is full of tourists, so it is hard to enjoy the landscape :/

Incredible. Amazing!! I have no words for describe this view :) Everyone has to see it :) better is go there before lunch, because lots of people are there and sometimes could be "traffic" in the terrace :)

Incredible. Amazing!! I have no words for describe this view :) Everyone has to see it :) better is go there before lunch, because lots of people are there and sometimes could be "traffic" in the terrace :)

Very beautiful but far too hectic. The breathtaking view is partly spoiled by vendors in swarms and too many cars -either you get out asap or take a seat for a far too expensive soda and soak in the view.
Chill out. Nice rice terrace & great place to take pictures. Lots of souvenir stalls & need to bargain. Love the coconut water & enjoy a great view.

Stunning!. This is just a MUST see! we had so much fun there and it was really impressive! Unfortunately we heard some other tourist complaining that they had to "pay" the locals to pass some ways. C'mon, it was not even $1 what they wanted, and if tourists are not willing to support the locals even a little bit, just do not visit those places! We just loved it!
Beautiful . Beautiful views from lovely hillside restaurants. No matter what season the rice is in, this is a lovely picture postcard setting.
beauty of nature. green, green, green and beautiful...walk along the terrace and breath fresh early day time air.sit in a cafe, drink a cup of tea and let the positive energy embrace you

Beautiful views. Visited on a sunny day and viewed the rice terraces from above. The views are unbelievable. Wear comfy shoes that you don't mind getting muddy if you plan on climbing down the terrace.

Nice view, worth a short stop. This is a nice view, good to see things that is often showed on photos, in real life. a god example of how it is possible to harvest on hillsides. Our guide from GreenBike, told us a lot about how the community works, in regards to field sizes, access to water etc.Not too crowded when we were there, all in all, a good experience.

Funny cute children. Amazing place and quite busy with tourists. The children are so cute and funny they try to sell you postcards and helping you climb the rice fields terrace. Definitly a must go! The view is amazing and should be experienced in your trip.

Expected more. At the time that we visited Tegalalang Rice Terrace there was way too many people. Crowds everywhere, no free space ar the restaurant. No normal area for walking, always have to climb somewhere unsafe.Terrace has beautiful panorama, but it is only interesting for 10 minutes. Heard a good rumours about it, so I expected more.Still, worth visiting.
Only for first timers. Well, you would like the view if you are looking at rice terrace for the first time. But doesn't seem to attract those who are from India, Thailand and china.

Over rated. The steps of paddy plantation is created to attract tourists and farmers are given free seeds to keep growing paddy here. It's not how paddy is naturally grown here and also not as scenic as photos. Be aware of people trying to help you around (as eventually they will ask you to buy stuff )
Beautiful. Arrived here in the morning about 8.30am in the rain and we were the only people there! It was fantastic to see. We didn't climb down into it as it was very slippery and pouring with rain.
Idyllic and beautiful. One of the highpoints of Ubud. It's idyllic and very beautiful. Take a trek. You won't regret. Most resorts organize for a trek and there are independent guides as well

nice to view but stopped constantly by people asking for money for photos. You can view this from the top and take photos without having to pay but we went down for the walk which we thought would be free. Silly us. You were constantly stopped by people asking to have a photo, ie a lady with rice buckets, or someone selling post cards or just simply gate tolls. You can ignore them but I felt rude doing that. I did learn to by the end of Bali though. You didnt actually get to see how a rice field is managed but there were magnificent photo opportunities

Good. This is good for a quick look and a couple of pictures. I feel it is a bit over hyped. I have travelled across Bali through rice fields which look more beautiful and picturesque.... Tegalalang is crowded at most times and the area is heavily commercialised too.. take away a bit of the charm i feel.

Very busy. I felt that the rice fields we drove past on the way to this place was much more beautiful and authentic. I wouldn't bother with this place. Children begging and crazy traffic + a million tourists... not so peaceful.

Nice terraces. Depends on the season, if you see wonderful green rice terraces or brown fields that have been harvested. In July, we had a mixture of brown and green fields. Definitely worth visiting, although it is popular with many tourists.

Scenic terraced rice fields. Tegalalang Rice terraces are about a twenty minute drive up from Ubud. Allow around four hours to walk the terraces and stop for lunch at one of the many Warungs that dot the hillside looking down onto the terraces. This is one of the iconic spots to visit whole in Ubud and there is plenty of shopping to be had from the many shops along the road up to and at Tegalalang.
very happy atmosphäre. lovely people and a wonderfull nature. amazing view and a little great sportive act. the system how the ricefields grow is impossant and unique! i had a happy time there!

Worth driving past, but not really visiting. We drove past the Tegalalang rice terraces on our way to Klungkung and stopped for a bit to enjoy the view. The rice terraces are beautiful, but look a little manicured and are crowded with tourists.Would recommend hiring a bike and driving north of Ubud into the countryside to see far more spectacular rice terraces that are actual farmlands. That's what we did!

Amazing! Worth a Visit.. It was a great place to visit. To see working now rice fields and watch how it's done. It's worth paying to walk along the track. One tip is to wear sensible shoes. I wore flip flops and almost fell over and they landed up in the bin due to a huge amount of mud. The view is amazing!
This is worth a look . The rice fields are interesting once you get away from the hawkers i sugest going further around the rice fields than trying to stop in town

Too busy!!. Compared to seven years ago, this thin winding stretch of road is seriously busy with traffic. As it looked like the harvest was done recently, the terraces were quite bare, my husband got out of the car to take some pictures but I didn't have the inclination to join him and stayed in the car with my half asleep daughter. I think the rice fields just outside Ubud where we stopped for a few minutes just to have a stretch after a traffic jam, had a better feel to it. I'm sure the scene is superb if you get there when it's all green or before harvest...
Great for one picture. What's left of the rice fields of tegalalang exactly fits one photo. Beautiful but a real change compared to 20 years ago

Too busy. Overcrowded, excessively popular, lined with stalls. Moved on after ten minutes, on reflection would not have bothered. Saw many more rice terraces across the island that were not so busy.Quite a long walk to get decent photos, did not bother.

worth the photo stop. appreciate that the balinese people have preserved it. It was worth the 1 hour trip from Kuta, going to Kintamani. Lots of souvenir shops lining up the road from left to right and some restos. One could go down and experience walking in between rice paddies but one should get ready to sweat and get on some sort of sticky mud. Bring extra shirts and hats, protection form the sun.

Beautiful panorama. Although you have many beautiful areas in Bali where you can see the ricefields fields this is surely one of the top spots. You have to pay an entrance fee to get the best view bit it was worth it. The have several walking trails through them, definitely worth a go.
Still worth a stop for a few minutes.. Tegalalang is beautiful, but I do not see any other difference with other rice fields elsewhere in Bali. It's just a place swarmed with tourists.
Very good but not the best in Bali. These are great, until you see the Jatiluwih or Belimbing rice terrasses. If you can find the time, go for the other options.

Lovely views. Went up to the rice terrace with my daughter by scooter. Very good journey which took only about 20 minutes from the centre of Ubud. Drivers were making our it was far away and charging quite a lot of money but really it was very easy to get there and to park (10,000 Rp). Great views of the rice terraces and excellent souvenirs en route ( don't buy when you get there as the prices are a lot higher). Lots of the shops en route are wholesale businesses but you are able to find some good bargains on wood and metal products. If you're travelling by scooter it is so easy to stop on the side of the road.Scooters can be hired for 50,000 per day (at current time about 3 pounds which is an absolute bargain!)Went onto see lemak coffee being produced - about 2km up the road. Fascinating if not a little bit bizarre.

Great rice fields and big area to explore. We went there just by ourselves (instead of with a guide). Great rice fields to see with still lots of locals actually working there to grow rice. You can just go there on a scooter, stop near the rice fields, and walk downwards yourself. At some point you have to give a donation to enter the big part (5000 is enough), which gives you access to the whole mountain to explore by yourself. Great pictures and terrific to see how the fields are connected and actually work.
Must see. This is a must see when in Bali. Spend a couple hours hiking around the rice terraces and meet lots of local farmers. Get there early as it gets hot and crowded.
Climb it or simply have a coconut and enjoy the view - stunning. Picture perfect. If yo climb it, be careful not to slip. Amazing photos and good light. The wow rice terrace experience!
Famous rice terrace. It was amazing to go and see the tegalalang rice terrace. It's just like the postcards. Fantastic to see and worth the drive to get there and see them.
Tourist Ants Climb The Terraces. While the farmers get on with their work, tourists swarm the terraces. Get there early. They are ok, seen better elsewhere in SE Asia
Relaxing and beautiful view. It is a must to visit this place in Ubud. The picture can talk themselves. Different kind of green color...

Nice but a bit commercial.. Visited terraces today. $1 aud entrance fee. Pretty and worth a look. Good fun climbing around and exploring the area. Reasonable/average level of fitness required to walk all the way around terraces. Only thing we didn't like was the commercial side of things. A few local people along the way wanting donations to let you pass, but the way it is I guess. Still worth a look though...
Beautiful View. The green and structured rice field makes my mind calm. The temperature is also nice with fresh air. Be careful in the peak season you will hardly park your car here. Traffic jam.
Just amazing!. You can hike around the terrace all day long. We spent only 1,5 hours but we wished we had more time. Bring enough small money for mandatory donation. Loved it

Romantic, divine..... My partner and I rode up here, I was unaware it had anything to with a movie. We sat in a bale on cushions. We had a light lunch and some juices which were all absolutely beautiful.
The scenery was so tranquil. Service was excellent at this place.
I loved it and would love to come back again.

Excellent actuvity. We went to the rice terraces as part of our day long tour and were very impressed by the magnitude of the structure. Definitely worth a visit and good location to get some great photos.

Beautiful but there everywhere around Ubud.. Pretty and of course full of tourists traipsing all over them.
We certainly know how to reckon things.
Just looking from the top is nice enough.
I think the flat ones you see everywhere in Ubud are just as impressive.
Picturesque. Go early - we arrived at about 9.30 and were able to appreciate the beauty of the terraced rice fields without crowds of other tourists.

Rice is nice...quoting. We were hesitant to go, as we were put off by some reviews that you get harassed by locals. Let's just say, we are thankful that we decided to go ahead. The scenery was dreamlike. We enjoyed our ice creams sitting in a very nice cafe watching the terraces.I guess we were luck as we went in the quite time, late afternoon. You need to have daylight tough. A must see.
Beautiful!. Very scenic! Famous location because of the movie Eat, Love, Pray. Worth visiting. Pictures turn out great.

Not in the good time. When we visited there, there is no rice field around. It was not a good time to visit tegalalang and we have to pay all the time every 100m to the local people to past the next entrance.

for an Indian this was nothing special. we thought we should see this much touted location. it was nothing great as in india we see this type of field in many places. i think tea gardens are much prettier and surreal. the drive was nice through narrow roads and very green. skip this if you are short on time.

Go really early. We went really early in the morning and it was the best option as we didn't have to bother with tourists in the photo nor locals requesting donations or wanting money for photos. We arrived there 7:40 and stayed for one hour. The difficulty, though, is finding your way through, discovering which are the best paths to go up and see the best view. Some parts seem abandones and not cultivated any more, but still is very beautiful to see the techniques. Tourists: please stop taking rubbish and dirtying the place!! Be respectful with the people who cultivate there and with nature!
Wrong time of year when we visited. The terraces weren't flooded when we went which means view isn't so good. We had a cup of coffee at a place with a view. The hawkers are really aggressive though.

Definitely worth the visit . The rice terraces are really quite amazing! You won't regret spending time here at all. It's best to go earlier as there is a lot of traffic. You pay $20,000 entry fee and there are lots of restaurants /Cafes around the terraces also. It can be muddy so sneakers are best although I wore thongs and was fine but it can be tricky walking down the steps etc.

Would be beautiful, is beautiful but a bit overrun.. This is a beautiful place but I didn't really enjoy seeing hordes tourists tramping all over what is working farmland. It's not an expansive area but very pretty and there are a rash of warungs and tourist tat shops clinging from the roadside to the side of the valley overlooking the rice terraces opposite. We had a meal and enjoyed the view but I couldn't help but think that marauding tourists felt somewhat disrespectful. Maybe the Village could make a marked path with some interpretation boards that would lead to good vantage points as I would have liked to go walking. We would have appreciated the opportunity to understand more about the village, it's cultural heritage and the farming not just avoid hawkers selling Bintang singlets.

Disney on Rice!. It's a short trip from Ubud to the rice terraces which were completely dry and rice free when we got there. That is possibly because the farmers were busy posing for (paid) pictures and charging tourists to cross bridges to view the terraces. The scenery is beautiful and we stopped afterwards for a beer in one of the hillside stalls just looking over the peaceful valley which was great. But you couldn't help feeling it was as if Disney had put together a rice farm ride with so many tourists, hawkers and the farmers clearly making more money out of modeling - Kate Moss move over - than they ever will from planting rice.

A MUST. it is a beautiful view -- look out for the "photo opportunity" places that cost a few bucks ... i mean support the local entrepreneurs but don't be shocked... it was the only time we came upon it

Rice is nice. Rice terrace is beautiful. Well worth the stop. Our tour guide recommend it and I very happy he did. Beautiful views. Only this is watch out for the kids selling the post cards. They will not back down if u show a little interest in buying. Just say no. We had one that wouldn't leave us alone and kept walking beside us asking us to buy.

Beautiful Scenery . Loved the Rice Fields, a 30 min ride from Ubud it is a little far but worth it, not sure its worth a drive from South Bali though (only if you spend the day in Ubud, Kuta is an approximately 1:30 away and expensive cab ride) but I really love green and nature so I think it is ...
Rice Terrace. We took a private tour and stop by the rice terrace. Very nice view, good stop for pictures. You can walk all the way down, but we were in a hurry so we only took pictures and left.

Nice to see. We visited here but only stayed for a half hour. It's nice to see it but it definitely not an all day experience as there's not much to do or see! You can walk down onto the rice fields but it's quite difficult and a lot of people fell in getting very dirty! Apparently there's is also a lot of poisonous snakes that live in them?!

So so!. There are others nicer on the island. It's nice but a bit disappointed. Locals will try to charge for photos, try to sell anything and everything, there are even "gates" where you are asked (read required) to give a donation to walk further. This is our seventh time in Bali and have seen many changes, good and bad.

Lovely Trek Among The Rice Terraces. Easily accessible even without a guide. We trekked across the rice terraces by ourselves, with some help from the local kids selling postcards. They would also offer assistance to tourists trying to walk across the terraces, in hope of some tips. I didn't find them too pushy though. They would usually walk away if you indicate "no" or "its okay". No fees for visiting. There are people collecting bridge maintenance donations. You can give as much as you wish. Trekking at your own risk.

Amazing View!. The Tegalalang Rice Terrace is one of the pictures that you see on Google and say "wow!"
That wow factor is definitely something that is evident when you are walking through the terraces.

Scenic rice terraces . Well worth a visit and hike around. Very scenic, beautiful, quite a hot humid day when we were there, a little fitness makes it more pleasant, nice finishing off with a coconut drink. Defines Ubud being surrounded with rice paddies and these rice terraces should be on the must see list

Breath taking. Really e joyed this trip. Went on scooters so can take them right through the fields and take in the whole beauty. Stopped for coconut at the lovely stall and enjoyed a bit if banter with the vendor. Lovely morning. No need for guides but no one speaking much English if your curious about the process you may be lost
Dr Amru . It was a pleasant time ... but need fitness ... not recommended for heart problem pts.. unless just watchi. ..
Beautiful Place. Perfect place for a good pictures, Lush Green, and beautifully maintained, will see farmers working on feilds, lots of places like coffee shops etc to hand around and enjoy view

Nice stop on the way out of Ubud. Not as impressive as the rice terraces in China but if you are there it's worth stopping.We were staying in Candidasa and I wouldn't go all the way to Ubud just for that. Instead we took a day trip and did some shopping, visited a few galleries, had a nice lunch and on the way out saw the Tegalalang rice terrace.

Beautiful spot in ubud and friendly local people. Tegalalang Rice Terrace is located in ubud. The views from the top is stunning, i could feel the natural beauty. There are restaurants nearby. The local people are very friendly, as when i accidentally step into a tank of muddy water, the local children very nicely approached me and helped me wash. I was very impressed. I did not go down the terrace because i didnt find the correct way. I will definitely visit again for my next trip in December.
amazing place. i like this place , zou can walk arround... or zou can just stiiting in some restorant arround and hava a great look on this rice..really nice
Beautiful Rice Terrace. Must visit place for natural lovers. All green rice plants with beautifully organize farming. Visit during Rain or after Rain period.

Rice Terraces easily seen from a car. Perhaps it's because I am growing so much older, but increasingly as I travel I think about accessibility issues. What could be better than treking through rice terraces while on a vacation is Bali? For those who can no longer trek, I recommend Tegalalang because one can follow the ridge in the comfort of a car and still have a good view.

Like a fairytale. It is hot, and the cafe's overlooking the rice fields are a nice place to be seated. We wondered if we should walk the rice field around! But we do not regret! If you are normally fit you should, and give some extra to the people you meet along the road! Then they will all hjelp you! Like wandering in a fairytale!

Beautiful spot. Its a 30 min drive out of Ubud to the rice terraces, you can get a taxi scooter or driver or self drive. We didnt walk the terraces as it was a hot day, had limited time and a young one in tow but we had lunch in a cafe overlooking the terrace which was really good food (teres padi cafe). It is pretty busy on the street, lots of shops selling the normal touristy things and trying to drag you in and kids trying to get your to buy postcards so expect a little pestering but just ignore it as usual
Rice fields. Very pretty site overlooking amazing landscape and nature. Some little shops are around the area with some nice souvenirs.

Amazing place a must . Went to the rice terraces wow what can I say eclectic place to go great time just walking through the terrace short narrow path ways can be slippery in places but great fun so great photo opportunities available it's a must in Bali

Nice to walk around. This is quite a touristy destination but it's worth it to see the tiers of rice all stacked together. You can walk down, up, and around the terraces. There are also a lot of cafes with balconies overlooking the terraces as well. Our driver took us to some similar terraces nearby as well~ they were less maintained and lacking in an abundance of cafes but still just as nice to look at.

So cool. The view is just amazing. You can walk around, up and down the terrace. It's pretty hot and tiring but you earn the view. It is just amazing to think that people made this by hand once upon a time to create more land to cultivate. I am glad I went to see this. My parents who were not fit to walk the long stairs waited at the cafe.

Terrace on high ground... That's all . If you spend a day or two in Ubud, you will see many rice plantation... Terrace or flat land. Tegalalang is only special becoz of the steep slope. And it's full of people. Even if I didn't visit here... I won't miss it

Beautiful View. Nice location for a quick stop and look as some unique man made landscapes.Very interesting to see how the local make the most of every spacePhotographers dream location with morning fog

Best Rice Terrace I saw in Bali. The Rice Terraces here are so beautiful. My friends and I went while the sun was coming up and it was so beautifully lit. We walked around the terraces instead of just looking out over them. There were not a lot of people at that time of day so it was very peaceful and we stopped along the way where a man was selling coconut water and shared some coconut water while looking over the terraces. Truly beautiful.
Excellent view. Great view over the rice fields. Beautiful terrace. You can take great pictures, enjoy the view and absolutely worth driving after.

Beautiful but not that special. The views are quiet nice. For me, as a domestic (Javanese), the paddy field isn't that special as I could get a better rice field views in my hometown. But you'll have your own trekking experience here since the place is specially designed for the tourist. And sure you'll have plenty nice shots for your camera.

Amazing views. If you are looking to experience the rural aspect of living in Bali, I recommend going to this attraction. The views are spectacular and seeing how rice is grown provides a new appreciation to this humble staple food type.

Beautiful work of art by nature. The rice terraces make a wonderful photo and are great as a view while u grab a bite or a drink. Or you could just stop there on your way up to the volcanos. I wouldn't go here just to see the terraces, though they were very pretty indeed.
A little touristy but worth it. There are plenty of rice paddy's around Ubud but this one is organised for the tourist. Its easy to get to with plenty of photo opportunities
Beautiful but very touristic. The ricefields are very nice but the place was quite touristic. There are other ricefields which are much more impressive such as Jatiluwih.

Pretty but overcrowded. Beautiful rice terraces, however it's hard to appreciate their beauty fighting all other tourist for a nice spot. Strongly recommend going to ancient Karangasem village and trek with a local guide to bigger and more secluded rice terraces

Nice view. One of the places that Bali is known for. The view is a very traditional Balinese one, showing a great image of the rice terraces. The access road is very congested and you may get stuck in the traffic jam even on motorbike(like me). But it worth the time in traffic. You may have access to the terraces but the best view is from the street.

Go early. This is a tourist set up so go early before the hoards of people arrive. It is steep and on the day we went slippery. It is not for people who are not fit and agile. Take some small notes as there are 'voluntary' donation stops at a few different points. We didn't have a guide and it probably isn't necessary although they would be informative about some aspects of the culture. You don't need long here. We spent an hour an hour at about 10am. Wear insect spray as quite a few bugs. Very picturesque and great for some nice photos.

Nice landscape. Even if there was no rice when me and my wife got to Tegalalang Rice Terrace, the view was beautiful. Be careful, because sometimes, after the rain, the place can be a little slippery.There are a lot of shops nearby and cafes.

Early morning pre-crowds is a must. We got to the Rice fields at 630am. THey were quiet, calm, peaceful, and sunlight had just started breaking through the trees. What a treat!We didn't have a guide but our taxi driver said go... Just walk and get lost. Closed shoes are a must as it has rained the night before and there are a few steep areas that we were thankful we had sneakers on for. We meandered through sections, crossed bridges, paid some local ladies to get onto "their land", and just admired the views. Best part... We saw 3 tourists in the distance but NO other people were in or way or blocking our view.
Stunning. Absolutely beautiful!!! Amazes me the systems that they use and the entire process. Markets nearby, so can do a touch of shopping, have a drink or something to eat

Such a beautiful sight.. I did not get to walk amoungst these rice terraces, but what I saw of them was such a gorgeous sight. I was pretty keen to venture into one of the many shops to check out all the crochet stuff.

Nice View & Amazing Paddy Terrance. First time saw the paddy field like this!!
Different from Malaysia!!
You won't regret to come!
Please bring along your cap, is kinda hot~~

All for the tourists. Not sure if they grow rice there anymore it's more than anything a tourist trap, with lots of shops and restaurants overlooking some very nice, but very empty rice terasses, and if you go down to the terasses the wil be plenty asking you for a "donation" to use their bridge or walk on their path, it really looks at the main income today is not farming rice but, charging tourists to walk on the terasses, I would recommend to go for somewhere else

Fun !. Went with a friend to check it out! Was great day to be a bit adventurous and see some cool sights! Make sure you wear closed toed shoes or else u will get a bit muddy! Bug spray is a must so make sure u bring that with u! Other than that enjoy the views!
Nice scenery close to Ubud.. Nice place to escape from the very crowded Ubud center. Sill very touristy, but great place to take pictures. Will go there again on my next visit.

Nice view. Commercialized.. Good view. Crowded and unfortunately commercialized. Guess it's a must do in ubud and you'll get nice pictures. There's this guy selling a hat made of leaves and you can take a picture with him as well. There are cafes around the rice terraces which you can sit and enjoy the view which is nice.

Relaxing during sunset hours . A quite relaxing sitting by the rice terrace with a cup of coffee enjoying the breeze of the place... Such a memorable place where the rice terrace is huge and u can go around from one side to another side. Remember to put some mosquito repellent and sun protection during the noon time.

View from heaven. The view is wonderful and very relaxing. It's like a piece of heaven. Location is amazing and there are many small shops for souvenirs and other stuff. If you go to Ubud you must see this rice fields as it is the most famous and most beautiful
Starting to be spoiled by tourism. If you have the chance, visit Jatiluwih instead before it gets spoiled too - none of those gaudy cafes, touting farmers and jostling crowds.

Absolutely Breathtaking!. We spent three hours here, although some may stay for shorter or others for even longer. A truly wonderful experience, the whole place was simply spectacular, so much greenery, vegetation, nature, peace and tranquility. You can spend hours independently trekking around, but take note you won't get far if you have difficulty walking. Can also get very hot so bring a hat if you visit midday, there are several small stalls that sell refreshments, and you are obliged to make a few "donations" along the way in order to continue up the path. All in all, a great afternoon and most certainly our favourite day out in Ubud, a trip not to be missed!

One of Ubud's Must-see. Tegalalang Rice Terrace is one of Ubud's quintessential landmarks. As such, it's a must-see. There's path that allows you to go right into the field although it can get very slippery so I avoided the experience. Instead, I just find the best perch and appreciate it from there. There are several restaurants and cafe that you can also sit/relax/drink/eat while taking in the view. If you don't trek into the rice field, I can't see spending more than 30 minutes here. TIP: One of the best time to see is September when the rice is ready to be harvested...that's when you will get to see Tegalalang Rice Terrace in all its glory.

Very Commercial, OK view . The restaurants and cafes lining the top of the rice terrace know they are at prime location and charges a high premium for their food. Taste is about average. Parking can be a bit of a problem if you are driving by yourself on peak weekends. The rice fields are well kept and do make for some nice photos if you can get a spot where not tens of other tourists show up in your photo as well. There are other terrace rice fields around Bali that make for lovely photos without all the crowds and the high priced cafes and souvenir shops lining it.

Nice experience. We have been to rice terrace before and were in a way aware of what the expect. We went to a restaurant where the view of the rice terrace valley was nice. We reached there and it was raining a lot. So we had the lunch and enjoyed the view. The rain stopped in a bit and we went to take pictures. The pictures came out to be really nice. We walked around and liked it.
Just okay. It's nice- but it pales in comparison with what we have in the Philippines, the scale of which is so much grander than this one.

Nice views, Don't get lost! :). The area is touristy as there are small shops selling souvenirs and lots of cafes and restaurant. But the rice terrace itself was nice and quiet. There are few "checkpoints" were you have to pay small fees to get forward, remember to get small money with you. You can choose the amount yourself, Maybe 2-10k at stop per person.The area is beautiful but almost a maze, when we wanted to leave here we weren't quite sure which is the way out but we just followed other hikers :)This is not the best place if you aren't ready for little hike :) It maybe takes about an hour to go it all the way

Very cool!. Great place to go when visiting Ubud. Have been here twice and have not been disappointed either time. Some words of advice though- don't be silly with the bananas if you purchase them to feed to the monkeys (use your brain- don't tease the monkeys or play games with the monkeys). Keep all but one hidden from the monkeys (they will jump on you to grab whatever bananas are visible and can be aggressive). Just be respectful to the animals and you will have a great experience with them.
it'd be wonderful if..... it'd be wonderful if the weather were good with clear sky. you can come early in the morning (7-9am) to avoid fees for taking photos.

Get out quickly. This place is maybe worth the 5 minutes we spend taking pictures - not more. Stay longer and you will have kids and other trying to make you buy post cards and other stuff you dont want ;-)

Rice Terrace Walk. Located in Tegalalang approximately 15-20 minutes north of central Ubud, this is one of the more popular rice terraces in Bali. Entrance fee is usually about Rp 10,000 per person or so. This usually includes even just stopping to take photos vice walking up and down the terraces. Bring small bills as there are numerous stops along the way as the owners/workers of their respective paddies will expect a small donation (Rp 5,000 per stop/toll is fine). Same goes for taking pictures of workers in action. The terraces themselves are essentially family plots and none is exported from here. It's associated with the village of Tegalalang located just behind the paddies, so not a bad idea to stay in a villa or homestay in the area if this will be one of your primary stops. There are eateries/warungs overlooking the paddies, so not a bad spot for those not wishing to hike the paddies can lounge.If it's rained the night before or morning of, expect the trail to be muddy and slippery. Wear good shoes. Not a very safe excursion for small kids, probably better for those at least 8 years and above with the reason being there are steep sections on the pathways where even adults can easily take a bad fall. Just be careful either way.It gets hot as well as the paddies are exposed to the sun, bring water, wear a hat, and use sunscreen. Also, check ahead before visiting as if it's harvesting time the views aren't as good unless you don't looking at fields of brown/yellow stalks instead of green or freshly replanted paddies. Found a good guide for the hike though who also showed us his family's plot as he lives in the village (Rena - 085-338160441). There are many guides/drivers in the area, but we found him to be especially helpful and polite.
Nice terraces but better to be found. Jatiluwih rice terraces are much more impressive, more spectacular views, and less of a tourist trap.
Expansive....slippery. quite expansive and picturesque, be wary of the slippery ground when attempting to trek, worth a good picture if you do not intend to walk down and through it

Peaceful place . We stopped at this place to grab a drink ,it was really nice place and very charming view ,very simple shops there serve drinks but its not expensive ,for me I could sit there all the day .

Not an attraction , kindly skip this place. I felt it was a not a worth visit , kindly take this place out of the schedule it is in your day plan
I just saw barren land and nothing else , don't go just to take a pic

Beautiful place. Great for a short walk, you have coffee shops and restaurants along the terraces overlooking them.
Try to plan more things to do besides the rice terraces

Nice terraces but make sure that you go there in the right season . We went there roght after harvest so the terraces were empty, we saw much nicer rice fields just cruising around with our motorbike.
Banu Bali Transport. Banu Bali Transport provide cheap price private and sharing transport. Our transport service is ideal solution for you if you want save money
Walk trough rice terrace. If you ignore the crowd of tourist, in between "toll" stations which collect donations, you can say a nice get away from busy streets of Ubud.

Early morning views are best. There are several places to stop along this stretch of road that overlook the terraces and paths. Pick a spot with the best view and have a coconut or coffee and just stop and appreciate the greenery. For the energetic take a stroll down and up the rice fields. This is a 30mins stop at most perhaps an hour if you walk around.And* make this part of your earlier morning tour with a local Ubud taxi guide on your way north to other interesting tourist spots. 25mins north of Ubud.

Nice experience. Nice way to spend some relax time to enjoy this spectacular view. Sitting down at the opp, with a cold drink in hands, watching out to the padi fields during noontime. It was bearable hot so do wear light clothings and comfy shoes to walk.

Nice view. Easy scooter ride from Ubud (7kms) and great shopping opportunities on aether side of the road the whole way there and back - cheaper prices as straight from suppliers. The terraces are nice to see and explore but as with tourist attractions can get quite busy at times. A few nice eating options around with fantastic views.
It's a must see. For all of you that have eaten Balinese rice this is the place to see where it comes from. Although you see rice fields everywhere this one is the most typical and easy accessible.

Could have been a nice view if they didn't burn trash. There are much better views of rice terraces but if you're in the neighbourhood you might as well visit this highly commercialised location. At the time we passed by there was a huge fog ruining the view because villagers were burning their trash. Nice timing but not,tens of tourists were wondering where to go to avoid the bad smell and were disappointed in the spoiled view. Me included. Hint: trash is burned every day so hopefully you are there at the right moment
beautiful place. Very beautiful rice terrace near Ubud. You can also walk through the fields (extra fees applies) or have a sit at of one of the many restaurant there and enjoy the view.
Ubud Area. Just need 30 minutes drive from central of Ubud.nice view and good atmosphere.You can reach if on foot or biking from Ubud.

The Quiet Growth of Rice. Well worth getting away from the noise of the town to get renewed. Best to go in the morning or the end of the day to avoid the heat of the day. Paths are raised. The labor in the fields is intense and long. I got a real appreciation for how easy my life is.

Nice, but not overwhelming. Try to go after noon. We went in the early morning,on our way to another trip and we couldn't take nice pictures because of the sun. I expected it to be much bigger. It's nice,but I've seen rice fields that were more beautiful than this one.

Great experience. Visited on Decemeber. We spent around 1 hour walking through the rice fields, I recommend you take light and natural fiber clothes because its hot as hell and you will sweat a lot but its worth it. A local kid was our personal guide and she took us to a place where you can sit a bit a have natural coconut water.

Incredible . Saw a few of the big rice terraces in Bali, and this was the winner.Spectacular views, less people than Jatiluwah, and seemed slightly more authentic. Incredibly green, lush, and a few little cafes to have a drink and look out. Your photos will be incredible.The bonus - not more than a half hour drive out of Ubud.

Very touristy but still nice. Went in July when rice had just been harvested so the terraces are not as spectacular as in pictures but still nice views. Only complaint is that it is super touristy, with restaurants, souvenir shops and even photo "booths" along the terraces.

Awesome view, but extremly busy. If you are looking for a peaceful walk, forget it. It is busy, busy, very touristy, lots of stalls, everyone trying to sell you something, inviting you to their cafe etc. but, nonetheless, the view of the terraces is beautiful and not to be missed if you are visiting Ubud.

Must-see!. We are very glad we made this our last stop, actually on the way to the airport to leave Bali. This is a must-see while on the island. We didn't feel like a trek, so we just took in the views, took photos and bought a few souvenirs before heading south. Much cheaper than Ubud, btw!

Big tourists trap. -the place is small and packed of tourists.-the rice field area is quite small.-there are 3 or 4 checkpoint along the pathways down to the mountain. We ask you for donation for the bridge, the pathways, the gods, honor, etc... They set the price for you. It's not donation then, it's multiple entrance fees set by different locals. After the second one, we decided to go back as we felt cheated. Not sure if those checkpoints are legal either. Many people were disappointed and getting angry with locals because they did not understand.

Worth a look. We came here as part of a private tour, it was great to be able to walk around the rice terrace and learn the different stages of rice production.I especially liked seeing the buffalo working the fields with the old machinery that you don't see used much anymore.The way down was a bit difficult as it had been raining and it was lots of steps that had come away from the ground so you had to be careful not to slip. The way up was much better with a big slope but no old steps.
Worth a visit. Definitely worth a visit. Our guide prewarned ys ti be careful of the farmers though as they encourage you to take pictures with them and then force you to pay for the privilege.
Beautiful . I recommend you to take the trekking, and please remember to sneakers. It's pretty muddy on the trail.

Ok !!. Ok to have a short visit just to look at the rice terraces. Did not wander down to them as it was very muddy and you could see it all from the viewing points off the road. Toll for the road was charged.
Beautiful scenery . I went to the rice terrace as part of a day tour. Magnificent views and a good place for a walk and to relax.

It's a long walk down!. This was my second visit to the rice terraces and I really wanted to walk to the bottom. It wasn't to be though. Too far and way too hot. But nevertheless it offers wonderful viewing and photo taking is great. Be wary of the locals asking if they can take a photo of you on your camera, they expect to be paid for it. All good if you have spare change. At the top there are many stalls that sell food, clothing, souvenirs and the prices are a little more than you would pay at the markets. Overall, another "must see" on your trip in my opinion.

A photographers dream. Lovely rolling hills and meandering terraces make this place a worthwhile place to visit. It is only a few minutes outside of Ubud so for anyone staying there, this is a must visit. Ideally you go when its good whether because the photos will be breathtaking. Take a guide and don't get too bothered by the regular sales pitches by locals young and old.

Way better paddy fields nerby. When I visited, the rice was either being harvested or the fields were empty of any seedlings. So that's probably where majority of my disappointment comes from. Another factor is that huge amounts of tourists come to visit these particular rice fields and main road is either packed with vehicles or vendors trying to make a living from selling tourists merchandise. I suggest getting a moto and discovering nearby area for more pristine and authentic paddy fields instead.

Lovely view for a short stop.. We stopped here as a family of 5 with ages ranging from 6-60. Access to the terraces is through a toll road, which our taxi driver paid. Once parked (it is very very busy) it is a short walk to the steps which access the rice paddies.If you can overlook the amount of tourists there, it is easy to appreciate the beautiful scenery and the time it must have taken to carve the rice terraces into the side of the hill.You can go for a walk all around the terraces, and up the other side of the valley, however due to having older members of family with us, we chose not to as it had been raining, and no proper paths. (would advise minimum of trainers to walk in, flip flops not really practical).There are a few nice restaurant's available to eat in, overlooking the amazing view, if your looking for something to eat and quite a few tourist shops, with various items for sale.Overall a nice place to stop for a while or go for a walk if your feeling fit. Be sure to take your camera as the scenes are lovely.
Amazing. it s definitely worth to see.very relaxing and amazing view you can also take very nice picture on the way to tegalalang rice terrace u can see very small and traditional villages

Worth the drive . I've noticed some people say it's not worth it, or its overrated, and I think they are nuts. It's a beautiful rice field that is huge and majestic. Tons of great photo ops and natural scenery that can't be made up.Beware of the crowds, it gets very busy and if there are any buses trying to get through the very narrow street...be prepared to hangout for a long time.

Beautiful Location. The rice terraces are amazing and you can get some great photo's, especially if you walk down through the pathways and do some exploring. It wasn't too crowded when we were there but you did get hassled by the young kids asking you to buy post cards etc. It costs IDR 10,000 which is about AUD 1 so a small price tag for the view and experience. If you are walking through the pathways you can sometimes get asked for more money but we didn't experience it on this trip.

Beautiful green rice terraces. A short drive away from Ubud on a straight road, these rice terraces are worth visiting. Although it does get crowded. Scooter would be the best, since finding parking would not be a hassle.

Beautiful but..... This place is stunning there's no doubt about it! BUT you're going to get bothered constantly for cash. I ended up paying 40,000 rupiah for a photo to be taken and for a "trek". The trek lasted 3 minutes because there was no way I was going to risk falling. After being assured id be fine in flip flops it was quickly apparent I was either going to end up covered in mud or with a broken neck so I opted out and was guilt tripped into paying "what I felt was enough". I'd say, stop by, take a picture but don't bother with much else.

Overrated, but still a good place for photos. The place has nice views for picture moment, but the scale is relatively smaller compare to other places. In my opinion, it is overrated, but if you are visiting Ubud for the first time, might as well make a quick stop here.An option to get a quick glance of this place is if you are visiting Lake Batur and Kintamani, include this spot on your way back to Ubud, it is up to you if you want to stay for few moments (pay the entrance fee) or get a quick glance in your car while passing it.

8/10 | Beautiful but go early.. - We went at 9am. Just as we were leaving it was getting very busy. Go there earlier. - The pictures of the rice fields don't really show that it's right next to a busy road with lots of shops. it's not in the middle of nowhere which photos often depict it to be. It's still beautiful, but just be aware of that.- Good opportunity to walk around/ drone/ get some good footage.- You need a driver to get you there from Ubud.- Would recommend people to visit, but there are other more exciting rice fields around Ubud/ north of Ubud.

Amazing views. Amazing culture . The rice terrace was like a maize. Unfortunately we arrived after the harvest (not sure if it's the right word) of the rice but walking through the maize of rice terraces was amazing.My partner managed to get a picture with one of the people that live in the terrace and wore his hat. He looked at home.The walk down is good and then walking up on is a great challenge on its ownBeautiful place.

Worth a one time visit . Lovely scenery but it is very full of tourists which is to be expected but does detract somewhat from what would otherwise be a beautifully scenic and peaceful place. You need good walking shoes to properly access the terraces. Paths can be steep, slippery and uneven.

Shimmering green. Although a very popular tourist destination the tiered rice paddy valleys of Tegalalang [hard to pronounce] are a must see. There are many places to view , not just the crowded ones and many walks into the rice paddies to experience.

Memorable views. Amazing and really memorable views, for sure one of the important places to visit during your stay in Bali! Don't miss to visit also Bali Pulina Agro Tourism, which is very close and is a wonderful place to try the Luwak coffee and to see the coffee making process, there is also a great view :)
very busy. Just a few, 100mt of road with eateries and hawkers, you have to pay to park then walk. You can hire a driver and see equally good sights out in the country.

Ok but not worth a special trip. If you happen to be in the area, go for a look and perhaps a walk through but I wouldn't take a special trip. This area is cooler than the beach areas and it is worth considering for a stay and there are several restaurants overlooking the rice terraces including Boni which is relaxing and has good food for cheap prices. Be prepared to be hassled by aggressive shop owners and others 'selling' the right to walk through the terraces.

Beautiful to see but inaccessible. A lovely sight of local life and rice cultivation. Good for a quick photo stop. It was not possible to access the paddies. I would not go unless I was on my way elsewhere.
Beautiful views . Great day trip out. Lovely views and a must see when visiting Bali. We had our own driver from the hotel, so we could come and go as we pleased.
Worth a one time visit. Beautiful greenery and lush rice fields.. But the walk can get very tiring on a hot day.. Try to avoid visiting at noon

Beautiful walk through the rice field. It is so peaceful walking through the rice field. I saw people in thongs and ladies in dresses?!? I would recommend good walking shoes and comfortable clothes. It can be slippery and there are lots of stairs and uneven ground.There is bamboo walking sticks available. Entrance fees were a donation. But when you follow the track you end up at an old lady who doesn't speak English. She wants money to allow you to exit. We offered money but it wasn't enough for her liking so we had to do the walk in reverse and exit back where we started. There is a little bar up top for refreshments of you wish.Some of the farmers allow photos for money.

Wonderfull view. We went there by scooter (cheapest and most easy way). You can see the amazing view from the road allready. We parked the scooter and walked down. You can walk down and walk all around the terrasses. I thought it was beautifull and made some wonderfull foto's. A must see when you visit ubud!

Good but not great. Smaller scale than expected and doesn't really match up to similar rice terraces across asia, but it maybe have been because at this time of the year they have already harvested the crops so it was kinda dry and yellow. Need to wear sensible shoes as it can be quite muddy at places and not the easiest path to navigate down. Still worth a visit though if you have never see a rice terrace before!

Beautiful but super annoying. The place is stunning - green, tropical, with the terrace looking as pretty as a pic. We went there in the morning which I would strongly recommend doing because we weren't annoyed by the tourists ! we saw them just when we were leaving and I can imagine the place being absolutely crowded during the day... One super annoying thing though - you have to pay to enter the terrace (which is ok). BUT THEN they constantly ask for "donations" which are clearly not because they have a minimum amount of money they accept and they refuse to let you go past it if you don't want to "donate" because you've paid your entrance. It's more like a toll rather than a donation gate. Every toll allows you to go further in the terrace.

Great photo opportunity. The rice terraces are beautiful and you can get some great pictures. I was a little disappointed with the amount of shops/restaurants blocking the view of a lot of the terraces. You do find a lot of children trying to guilt you into buying their postcards all along the road. We didn't get chance to go actually go into the terraces as it started raining but we did manage to get some nice photos
Beautiful Terraces. This place was very beautiful.I enjoyed walking around the terraces although a little scary as there are areas that are a little steep.
Simply Amazing. If you come to Bali and don't go to the Tegalalang Rice Terrace you're a fool! One of the most stunning places I've ever seen.
