Very touristy. If you want to see a rice terrace but dont have time to drive around its ok, but there are plenty more authentic and more serene places around Ubud.

Nice hike and great view from the restaurant . I have always wanted to climb rice terraces, and we did it! It wasn't too hard at all, and the view is spectacular. The only thing is halfway up to the top there was a woman demanding that we make a "donation" of some sort... It was pretty much, don't go up if you're not donating...

Beautiful Undulating Rice Terraces. While not the largest rice terrace attraction in Bali (Buleleng has more rice terraces over much greater expanses of land, and I believe Jatiluwih Rice Terraces are much bigger), Tegalalang is certainly stunning in its own right. Make your way down steep, shonky steps to view the lush paddies set upon different tiers - and if you're taking a photo, tread carefully as the pathways are narrow. Enjoy the sun setting over Tegalalang in one of the little cafes dotted around - we drank from fresh coconuts across the road and soaked up the view.

Nice but dishonest. The terrace itself are breathtaking and really peaceful but we were annoyed with locals who asked for "donation" every 10 meters - to cross the bridge, to get higher and etc. It is dishonest considering we payed for the enterance here and I mean it is not a voluntery donation. They asked for not less than 5k rupees and do not take coins.
Beautiful...!. A refreshing view.. When travel in March/June/Dec, better check with the local guide if the planting season has started.

Nice for a photo and a short stop. Nice place to visit for a photo or a short stop and drink (entrance fee 10.000 RP per person). Many little shops and people trying to sell things (just like any touristic attraction in Bali). If you're not keen of mass toerism, I'd recommend visiting the outskirts of Ubud (try the Campuhan Ridge Walk or a visit to Sari Organic Caffee in the rice fields).
Check it out!. I'm from Bangladesh where we have a lot of rice paddy fields. But this place is different with all the landscape and is definitely worth a visit.

Not to be missed .... Extremely picturesque and a lovely one hour stroll can be had walking up and down the terraces. Perhaps not suitable for the elderly or those with knee problems as getting up and down on the terraces involves steep steps often carved out of mud. Only 30 minutes or so from Ubud. Not to be missed .

What a sight to see. We visited the rice terrace on our way to another destination as we we had heard how lovely this place is!. Unfortunately for us it had been heavily raining the morning of our visit and the terrace was fairly slippy underfoot however we were able to visit and see its beauty. I am disappointed we didn't get to stay longer and wander the terrace but we are so glad that we got to see it in person! - Would recommend a visit here!
Nice photo opportunity. Only stopped to admire the view. It was pretty dry at the time but looks great nonetheless. Some cute cafe's perched on the hillside offer a nice spot for a quick refresher.

great day out, but be ready to walk. We took a hotel car to Tegalalang, took some photographs from the main central street and had a walk along to see what stalls were selling etc. We then found an incredibly steep staircase down into the valley which turned out to be one of the two entrances down into the rice terraces. we walked along and through for about 20 minutes before reaching a 'checkpoint' where they ask for a donation - I had read about this, but seeing as there wasn't anyone at the entrance I decided we would give the 10k rupiah here and resist elsewhere as its not mandatory though we did hear some stories that the locals get aggressive and threatening if you don't donate... it then isn't a donation in my mind if you 'have to' give... anyway. we walked on for quite a while and felt that after about 45 we'd seen most of what there was to see and so turned back so s to avoid any confrontations, we had plenty of picture opportunities along the way and didn't feel doing the extra hour or so (although we were close to half way) was really worth it for us. we had done what we wanted and see what we wanted to see. very beautiful and amazingly well kept. point to note is that its difficult to find a taxi back to ubud so you will need to look for local drivers, we asked a shop owner who also works as a driver and cut a deal with him!

Sensational!. We decided to visit Tegalalang rice terrace following great reviews from other people who have travelled to Bali. This was definitely one of our favourite experiences purely down to the sensational, breath-taking views. I would advise wearing trainers to climb up the terrace because there are some steepish steps and muddy stepping stones.

Pretty spot but too many tourists and hawkers. We loved the view but we went at the end of the day and found there were many tourists from Japan and found them to be quite rude, barging past and causing my wife to fall in the mud. I've met many lovely Japanese tourists in the past but this is a spot which doesn't have much room and a slender pathway and they just crowded on and barged past us. If you went early then I think it would be stunning.

Not worth it!. So overcrowded with cars, you have to pay to get up the road and the footing is treacherous! I would never advise anyone to go. Ask a driver to take you out in the country and see the fields and village life too. A much better experience without all the tourists.
Great views nice local food great friendly staff. loved the vies the food was nice and fresh home cooking at its best, staff so nice and friendly always laughing and smiling another good feel factor.

Lovely view. Really lovely view, and nothing we had seen before. Fun to see how the made their little irrigation systems in the fields and there is just lovely naturen surrounding the fields. Must see on Bali.

overrated, overcrowded. honestly, just go to Jatilwuy Greenland terraces, you won't be disappointed. unlike here, where the fields are crawling with tourists who are constantly hounded by vendors and sellers of all the same junk you see everywhere in Bali. Such a shame, because it may have been beautiful at one time ten years ago.
Iconic Ubud location. Exactly as it looks in the photos! Beautiful area of Ubud to visit, just be prepared for the crowds (tourists like us!). Well worth a visit

Very nice. This are one of the most popular rice terrace in Bali, due to its easy access from Ubud, it is a very nice place to take some nice pictures, just 20 minutes away from Ubud center, here you will be able to have a nice lunch in one of the many restaurants with an AMAZING view, be aware that there will be a lot of kids begging in the area, it is very sad to see, and they are very insisting, telling you for their school, in 30 an hour you could easily get up to 30 of them coming to you, it is very heartbreaking. If you want to walk through the terrace don't go in a rainy day, because it will be hard. No entrance fee.

Amazing views!! . We went there from kuta which took us forever to get there! But really worth the trip. Amazing rice fields, many locals were there still working and also selling souvenirs. If you catch a sunny day i can guarantee you gonna have amazing pictures!!
Beautiful landscape. Nice landscape with cafes in the area whereby you can sip a cup of Bali coffee and enjoy the scenery. Eye opener for a city dweller like me.

feel the peacefull. when you look rice terrace you can feel so peacefull and enjoying the beautiful scenery. i can walk in the middle of rice terrace. you don't need to pay to look this rice terrace , just pay to carpark. Worthy to visit
Wrong time to visit. To visit a ricefield u must assure that the rice is there. By the time we were there they already harvesting the rice so not much to see really.

Bali at it's worst!. Total money grabbing tourist trap. They want your money to park (per person), money to go in, money to take a photo and money to leave the place too!!! Full of loads of other tourists.Ask your driver to take you to see rice fields somewhere else. There are loads of views in Bali which are much more authentic than here. Absolutely awful!

Pretty. Ticked off our Bali list, very pretty as others have said. A few things I should of read up on, get you cash sorted before you get there! Fee to get in to the parking area, then donation after donation to the individual farmers paddy, kids selling postcards or photo opportunities. If your prepared you will have a beautiful experience walking through the rice paddies, as the scenery is stunning.

Beautiful place. A great green view, a mandatory stop in ubud... Climb the ricefields and see the other perspective.
In some places they will ask for money "donation" to continue the path ..

Commercialised tourist trap. Whilst we were staying in Ubud we chose a hotel out amongst the rice paddies and had a far more natural experience seeing the traditional farm hands working the land from our walk into town. The tegalalang paddies are nicely set in a compact valley but the tourist shops and the additional charges to walk certain paths are overwhelming - I felt this detracted from the experience. There are many more rice paddies and a tour of these may have been more enjoyable.

Lots of tourists. Worth a visit although we went past on a trip up to the volcano country. Lots of tourists. I think you could spend the day at a cafe and just people watch. Rice fields were average to look at as rice had just been planted.

Decent photo Op. A bit of a tourist trap. You'll most likely pay to get access. If you go down into the terrace and cross the bridge, a lady will ask for a donation. There are kids trying to sell you postcards so that 'they can go to school'. Don't come here just for the terrace. Go to several other places around to make the trip worth it

beautifull view. We were there on a nice and sunny midday on Bali. We just bought ourselves two bottles of bintang and enjoyed the view for a good while. Then you also have the posibillity to walk through the rice fields. Get there early in the morning then there are not so many tourist and it is nice and quite.

Amazing view!. Such a beautiful view of the rice fields in Tegalalang. Easy to get there, and plenty of parking for scooters; costs 10,000 IDR. Be careful with the shops there, selling items like sarongs etc., they're overpriced. There's also a--new to us--kind of 'selling' stuff. Small kids trying to sell you postcards, extremely insisting (gives you the feeling of begging).. Not very pleasant. Also lots of people all day through.

Something you want to behold with your own eyes. Paddy fields built like this might become something rare in the future. If you visit Ubud, don't miss the chance to behold it with your own eyes and maybe make a memory of it. There is a place, free of charge, to gaze and marvel at this magnificent scenery.
Beautiful. A little tricky to find, but once on the path, it is well worth it, we went counter clockwise and missed the exit and took a more pariless route than needed, so be careful!

A great stop-off. We had a quick stop here on our way to a temple. From the road you get a great view out over the rice terrace. We didn't get to go down and walk around - but if we had more time it looked like that would've been nice.

Best part of Ubud!. After hearing and reading so much about the rice terraces we couldn't wait to go and it lived up to the expectations!! The scenery is simply beautiful, excellent photo opportunities, and is interesting to see a functioning rice paddy. We spent a few hours just wandering around and taking in the beautiful landscapes. The entry itself is free but you are expected to make a small donation - 10,000RP or so - but I would have definitely paid more as it is simply the best part of Ubud. It's a short taxi journey away and perfect to combine with a trip to the Holy Spring Water Temple. Only warning is look where you are standing - almost lost a flip flop in the paddy!!
Very pretty!. Reminded me of the rice fields in Kerala! So scenic. Recommend making the trek out of Ubud to check it out.
Nice view. Had a quick stop over on the way. ..the scenic beauty was good. .it's just the picture taking spot and the landscape
Nice rice terraces. We were only watching the terraces from the viewpoints on the road. Nice scenery with jungle around. Very close to Ubud. Often part of private tours from Ubud.

Peaceful Rice terrace. It is a peaceful, green and scenic place. We stopped by a restaurant that was on the sides of the rice terrace and which had a great view.
It was a soothing and relaxing experience to have a break midst fully packed tour day.
Tegallalang riceterraces ubud bali. Tegallalang riceterrace is located at north ubud village about 7km.the riceterraces green view surrround with coconut parm.

Green Bliss. Visiting the rice terraces isn't a must do but it is a beautiful view, just make sure you time your trip correctly. It's well wroth the short journey if you find yourself in or around Ubud. My friend and I visited just before the rain fell during rainy season so the terraces were not flooded and were a beautiful green all over. There are some complaints that the trip is over-priced and touristy however, we planned our visit as part of a day tour, thus significantly reducing the cost. The attraction itself is actually free, you're just looking at rice fields though you can go on a little tour which will cost, how much I do not know. Additionally, visiting in November, the very beginning of rainy season, we were able to avoid the tourist crowds that flock here in dry season and December (Christmas break).

Nice view but very touristy. Went today to see this. The main part of the field had been harvested so we only stopped to see one end. Still a beautiful view. It was very busy with tourists though. Only stopped long enough to snap a few pictures and then moved on. Worth a view.
Very impressive and beautiful.. We went on cycling tour through the rice terraces. What an experience and very worthwhile. To see balinese women working so hard is amazing.

Tourist-trap. It would have been worthwhile if the place wasn't bustling with tourist and people trying to sell them souvenirs. This shouldn't be sold as an original countryside sightseeing excursion. Be wre of the farmers who do nothing but stand their posing for photos (not what I would expect from a real farmer).
Lovely Places. Awesome terrace rice field in ceking ubung.best view around ubud.we can trekking also in here.lovely place to take rest
Rice Terrace. Absolutely stunning and definitely a must see if visiting the Ubud area. Grab a beer and sit at one of the kiosks and take it all in.

Busy and overpriced . The rice terrace area is impressive, but the numbers of tourists is very off-putting.
There's only one busy road, lots of annoying touts, and a few overpriced, underwhelming eating spots overlooking the terraces.
Avoid altogether, or take a quick look and move on.
The surrounding area is simply stunning.

Green & beautiful landscape. Rice Terrace will be a good choice for you if you want to find the other beauty of Bali nature. When visiting Ubud, Tegalalang Rice Terrace will offer you a green and beautiful landscape.

Nice. I liked the rice fields, my boyfriend was a bit unimpressed. I think in real life the views are great but can be hard to capture on camera. It was actually less touristy than I expected after reading all the reviews. I would recommend going but an hour is the most you would probably want to spend there.

A one time trip. Overall a good experience however just a one time, quick visit is fine. 2 points to take note - certain places are quite slippery hence be careful when you are walking around. The place charges entrance fee however we noticed many people entering the terrace without tickets. Be cautious you have certain people who claim to be owners of the field and ask for money to open certain access gate....as the currency valve is not high and the overall experience is worth it we did not mind offering the money.

Lovely. Great place to visit and very beautiful a lot of the café etc are over priced due to location. You will get bugged by children selling stuff and there is a vertually forced donation when walking up the rice paddy's.
Part of day trip. Marvellous site but very crowded when we visited. May have been the time of day (after lunch) but that takes nothing away from the sight
Terrace rice !! . Went there during lunch time and not so crowded .. As per my tour guide I am lucky manage to get into this place less than 1 hour .. Normally is very jam

Interesting but not must do. Went there in way to kintamani/Batur. Nice plantations and you can go through the field; its quite beautiful. You need to pay first on the road...its like a man standing on the road who charges you toll. Once inside the field you need to pay at multiple times to cross mini bridges within the field....nominal sum; not a lot. Beautiful but not worth a specific trip only to the Rice fields.

Top-5 things to do in Bali!!. My wife and I took a bike tour through the Tegalalang area lasting about 7 hours including a stop for lunch and were simply overwhelmed with the scenery. We encountered just a few other cyclists/tourists - all in all, a great low-budget adventure!Even if you can't devote a day, spend an hour or two and just take in the views as they are truly gorgeous!!Bottom line: This is a Top-5 "things to do" in Bali!

For the ultimate ricefield picture. A small stretch of terraced ricefield, especially made for tourism and for those who don't want to go far away to see the real thing. Still impressive to see and perfect if you want to have that last minute picture of the terraces. Traffic is a nightmare and vendors all over the place.

A little touristy. It's pretty but they have these silly Love and i❤️Bali signs that show up like watermarks in all your pictures. It's a check off the box but if you don't have time, buy the postcard and do something else.
Nice but crowded. The rice terraces are worth a visit but get there early to avoid the busy crowds. A much smaller area than we were expecting but none the less very spectacular.

Although a little touristy, still breath taking. The views as you come up onto the road looking over are what really make it. Although a busy tourist area you can walk down and around and take in some real balaneise culture. Be careful if your coming up on your bikes, police checks everywhere.
Beautiful!!. A must see if you come to Bali!! Even if you can't hike in the rice paddie because of the heat definitely go and take pics!!!

Walk and breathe in the fresh air. Love it! though you have to walk to appreciate it even more. There are restaurants in the starting point with live Indonesian music. Lots of vendors offering souvenirs, just be polite whether you're interested or not. Better bring water as you walk through the rice terraces so you can take your time walking, resting and appreciating God's creation. And don't forget to apply sunblock lotion if you'll visit around noontime
Endless green. Lovely to walk down into the terraces via the lovely vendors selling their local handicraft. Very picturesque and worth a visit to

Worth a visit!. Best visit early or late because it will be too hot in the noon. Look out for the red ants who bit us! Bring same water and a hat. You need to donate sometimes. Restaurants in the area very cheap.
Touristy but Extremely Prettt . Definitely a tourist attraction, but the terraces are beautiful. Locals a long the way asking for money or else they wont let you continue onward.

Beautiful few. No entrance. You can give a donation if you want to go nearer to the fields. We walked downstairs and walked the trekking way to see the fields and the workers. I counted 201 Steps :DIt activated my muscles but it was nice. If you do not want to walk down you cannot see the amazing few from above. It is a must see. You can do that for a little break or lunch
It was a wow. We have never seen anything like this before (except in the movies) A good place to visit and take photographs

More beautiful than I could have imagined . The rice terraces of tegalalang were absolutely stunning. There are many places you can take photos to ensure you can capture the beauty. The steps are pretty steep so take care when walking down towards to fields.

Definitely worth the visit, but be sure to walk the terraces. This turned into a highlight of our visit when we were caught in the middle of a huge downpour of rain about a third of our way into the terraces. We found shelter with some locals but eventually had to give in and work our way out of the terraces in the pouring rain. To be honest, the family thought it was a terrific adventure trying to find out way out of the maze like terraces. There are a lot of stairs down/up to the terraces, and the terraces themselves are often thin walkways and steep ascents/descents. But if you are up for it, it was a great walk – in rain or shine. Stunning views in every direction and a chance to see up close just how well rice terraces are created.

Good rice view but need more interesting activities. We came here to see the rice terrace. Yes it was beautiful, but we hope we could do more there. We drove long trip to reach this site, and we wanted to spend more time here. Perhaps more interesting cafes or activities can be done here.

Very touristy, better options available. We drive asking here and stopped to walk around as part of a day-tour. The terraces are very touristy, and feel more like an attraction than actual farmland.To walk across them you're also asked to keep tipping to cross people's lands. Fair enough I guess, but was a bit awkward as we didn't have any small notes on us!A better way to see the beautiful Balinese countryside would be to take a trip with Bali Quad Discovery (or similar) where you drive around more remote countryside of a quad bike.

Beautiful . I would suggest you visit here early in the morning, before 10 am should you wish to avoid paying viewing fees, crowds of people and beggars.This is a very beautiful view point for viewing rice terraces but also a total tourist trap should you allow it. Go early enough to avoid crowds of people as to enjoy the tranquility of this majestic place.Remember tours are coming into Ubud from the coastal areas for a one day tour to see everything in one day. Everyone is in a hurry, hot and bothered, hunting for the best shots and dashing off again. So if you are like me who stays in Ubud for two weeks at a time for peace and quiet, the last thing you will need is a ton of frustrated tourists. Well worth the visit, it only takes 15 minutes from the main area of Ubud, up Tagalalang Road and you are there. If you are staying a while in Ubud a walk to the terraces are very possible , l do that myself but take cover with you for your head like a hat or umbrella, it gets very hot at midday. Enjoy!

Outstanding. I truly loved this area, peaceful, powerful, majestic! Just let the mind imagine the years of work creating these rice paddies. Funny how some places are really worth visiting. The locals are delightful, the little cafes are really geared to help you. The local kids selling their postcards for 'school'? All in all a great trek if you feel up to it or just sit and look

Huge. I went on a tour from Ubud that takes you to a variety of sites as after 20 years of visiting Bali I'd done very few! This padi is huge and just goes on and on. Although if you're looking for the screensaver shot I think you'll need a helicopter as its beautiful but, there are trees obstructing the full padi view
Nice View. I do a short visit to see the rice terrace, the view are nice but the access and facility can be improved. There ade lots of small cafe & shops along the way but I didnt try them.

Great view. Not a Disney attraction but very impressive looking down into the valley and its terraces of rice. Beware the vendors above and surprisingly only Ubud area we encountered pan handlers/kids asking. Still great to do.
Beautiful . Worth the 30min drive from ubud. Can be combined with a walk of campuhan Ridge (the walk from the top of campuhan to here is maybe 10km so get a taxi from the top to tegallalang)

Worth a visit. Beautiful rice terraces which you can walk in and explore. Picturesque. Good for 1-2 hour visit. Avoid during afternoon, ideally do it when sun is low.Locals will ask you for a "tip" without which they won't let you enter. Only pay that at one point a bit after you enter the fields. The standard rate is low at 5000 rupiah based on what I heard from guides and I paid that and walked across. However they ask for 10-20x that from unsuspecting tourists.

If you haven't seen padi terraces - GO!. We loved it. Having never seen terraces like this in anything but pictures it was really great. You can wander around or stay at the outlook points for good photo ops. I suspect of you have seen anything like this before it is small but charming.

Soak it all in with this view. If going to Ubud, I feel like the Tegalalang Rice Terrace is on most people's list. It is beautiful with the cascading terraces and the green reaching all levels. It was more of a view point for me, but definitely worth seeing! There were many people in front of the rice terrace begging for money so be forewarned. Once you get on the rice plantation, there are men who let you take pictures of the rice baskets and the hat to go with the scenery, but they expect payment afterwards so be forewarned of that too. A little tip: instead of stopping at the main gate, if you stop a little beforehand, there is another side of the Tegalalang Rice Terrace with less tourist, which means less people and more enjoyment!

Nice but bit of a climb. We visited but found it to be difficult steps for bad knees. The view was beautiful but we were able to see many other rice paddies with easier access while riding around the area with our driver, Jack Yadnya. Hawkers were also pushy at this location.

a little disappointing, just average. The pictures looked amazing before I went to see it myself in person. I was a little disappointed in seeing the real thing as it was so built up with restaurants and shops above and the rice paddies were mostly empty and dried up. It looked like this was just for tourists now and not for actual rice farming. I went to a coffee plantation nearby (Bali Pulina- really a coffee shop on a hill) which had a much more picturesque view of a rice terrace below.

Beautiful walk. Be prepared to get hot though!. Amazing views. We were quite hot at the end but luckily there are a number of cafes (we stopped at Karsa cafe) which provided affordable drinks/food and transportation back to central Ubud. Really nice way to spend a morning.
Nice Place to visit. It just a Padi Field on hills and nothing great to share about this place since it does not Amaze me much :-)But for those who likes Padi fields. You will enjoy it.

Nice view . The rice terrace looks nice and you just have to be careful as while you get down it's a bit slippery and steep. The locals were very helpful when we tried to climb down. Several good spots for photo taking as well!

Must See!!. We visited this on our day trip and when we got there we were so glad we stopped because it was amazing,Little cafe on the top that overlooks the fields and if your up to it do take the walk through them ,And do not forget your cameras as it is moments you will keep forever,The photos do it no justice so get there and check it all out
Stunningly beautiful. Lovely and lush, a place of great beauty. Don't forget your camera as you will get great photos! There are places where you can eat and drink here.

Another place for enjoyable walk. The place is basically a terrace of rice field and you walk along the paddy dykes. While walking your eye will also be spoiled by the fantastic scenery. There are restaurant where you could also enjoy local delicacy and the scenery at the same time. If you decide to come and di the walk, pleaseve aware that you will be sweating and bit tire after that.

Great view but overcrowded. We visited after harvest so the view of the rice terraces was not as impressive as you see in some photos The terraces are about 30 minutes from Ubud and the countryside en route was interesting. The town with the terraces is incredibly crowded and "touristy" so we spent a short time only at site, keen to leave.
small rice terrance. a short drive from Ubud. lots of cafes and restaurants facting the terrace. better to go for sunset. facing direct sun in the moring.
close to ubud. it is relatively small but very close to ubud center. if yo u dont have enough time in ubud and bali. should visit here

Very interesting, part of our day trip.. We visited the hand made rice terraces as part of our day trip with our private driver. Our driver too the back roads from Tirta Empul Tampaksin. We found the trip there very enjoyable as well.The rice terraces are just beautiful, you can walk downs the steep dirt paths into thr bottom of the terraces. Across from the terraces there are all the standard shops.
Lovely view of the rice terrace. Nice place to take photo and enjoy nature. Theres many cafe that you can sit around and have coffee or tea.. Great place to go shopping as well!
With a look. . The rice terrace is picturesque and there are plenty of markets and cafes to visit. Not s must see, but we enjoyed our time there.

Nice rice terraces. Bali has a rich rice terrace farming all around the ubud area and its worth a visitIts generally very crowded as its once of the must go places if in Ubud but I would suggest you not to spend any money as most of these places have a small fare to visit. You can always experience the place from outside, but again if you have never been to one or dont have one back in your country then please do walk around and get close to nature!
Not worth the trip. This rice paddy is not the most spectacular that we saw. It was a long drive from our resort and the terrain was steep and slippery. It was more of a tourist trap than anything.

Nothing special here. This is like most rice plantations all over the world...nothing really special about this place though!! but I do recommend visiting as there is not a heavy entrance fee...you can enjoy a coffee besides the plantations views in a cafe near by!

Great View. I went there before sunset,it was a bit crowded but it was nice,I prefer jatiluwih rice fields but they are different than each other and you have to visit both,lots of shops there to buy souvenirs.I recommend a day trip: go first to Tegenungan waterfall,then up north to Kintamani mountain to have lunch there,then back to Tegalalang rice terrace,and u can ask the driver to pass by any luwak coffee farm on the way,this cost me 400k for the car,avoid normal taxi and get car from any tourism booth and keep bargaining.
HUGE!!!. Fabulous view not to be missed! Plenty of shopping and quaint cafes at the top to enjoy the view. Take the time to explore in depth if you desire by walking around the area

just rice field. Simply just paddy field with rice, you can walk down and up the field. but along the route you have "checkpoints" where you need to pay a "donation" to the person. one checkpoint is 1USD, every 5min walk up the field, u encounter a checkpoint.. Its kinda ridiculous. we only walk till almost the 2nd checkpoint, took some photos and trek back down for lunch near the field.

No crowd, great view. I notice many reviewers say the rice terraces are touristic but when I went in May there was no crowd whatsoever. We were sold some fake tickets by what seemed like a traffic police only to find out later that we didnt need the ticket. It was a sunny pleasant day without any crowd, we walked without a guide for about 2,3 hours, took some pictures with the farmers, cows and view before we made our way out, which is quite tricky because it is like a maze but a lady showed us the way and we paid her some $'s. Few $'s goes a long way in Bali. I recommend insect repellent & sneakers for the walk. Once done we walked to Kampung Cafe, 10 minutes down the road, got a great view and delicious indonesian food.

Get lost, find locals, drink coconut water with them. Packed with tourists so we got as far back and lost as we could and came upon a Balinese woman serving up coconuts. Played her cats and played her musical instrument and hung out with her for an hour. Really nice. Lots of hawkers make it annoying but unavoidable so buy a packet of postcards from a kid and get on with it. There are 2 spots where you will need to give a donation. I thought donation meant "your choice" but it's compulsory or do not pass go. Anyway, it's like a total of 8000rupiah- $0.75usd. But really beautiful. Though I will say, if you rent a scooter, take a drive a short while out of Ubud, you will find many rice fields and marigold farms- epic.
Must see place. Too many hawkers, best when rice is green, but beautiful none the less. If you are fit enough this is a great place to walk into the terraces.

NIce Landscape. Nice landscape, its a little difficult going with a young child, the footpaths aern't exactly designed for tourists and I wouldn't expect them to be. It's a nice place not too far from Ubud to visit and take some photos.

Bucket list. Loved it here. We didn't walk around the terraces as things are not good walking shoes for that. We found a warung directly opposite and had a long leisurely lunch while taking in the views. The rice had been harvested so it was golden brown rather than green but still stunning.

Will get the best photo shoots for Rice Field. If you are not planning to hike the paddy field but want to get a nice shoot on the paddy field, Tegalalang Rice Terrace will be the best choice.We'd been Tagalalang Rice Terrace two times, Jatiluwih Rice Fields and overview point of Sidemen Rice Field. I'd recommend to hike both Jatiluwih Rice Field and Sidemen Rice Field to get a closer look on them and understand the life of the farmers. For Tegalang Rice Terrace, you even just find a lookout point along the road, you can easily get a very nice picture of paddy field.If you want to understand more, please plan for a hiking trip.
A Must Go Place!. The view is beautiful. We love climbing up and through the terraces. A great experience and a must go place.
Crap!. Not worth the trip, there are so many other beautiful rice fields around Bali without the crazy crowds.

Disappointed to see this gem is now a tourist location.. This place has turned into a tourist attraction and it looks like the rice fields are only maintained for the tourist but not for the real use of farming.

Growing Rice. Although we had seen rice fields before- thesis rice terraces were very interesting!
You can actually walk along the path and see close up the rice plants that were almost ready for harvest. Parking was available along the road.

Tegalalang beautiful stopping point and amazing views. Tegelalang has fantastic views but is steep to descend into the valley. Only the sure footed and fit should attempt this. However the Warung nearest the top is lovely and the street sellers have amazing crochet blankets, wish I'd bought one.
Nice view. It was very nice view place ,yo can take photo or take a break for relaxing and drink some tea in the one of the many restaurant there w

Beautiful landscape seen in movies. Very beautiful landscape, place to walk and take a beautiful photos. Definitely take some drinks in the some cafe to enjoy this amazing view. Also there are a lot of interesting handicraft shops along the whole way from Ubud. Take time and explore them, we did not do that (were thinking that we will manage some other day, but unfortunately did not) and regretted it after all. The one thing you should notice that there are some locals on the way demanding (!!! That's right, not asking of begging) for money in order to pass through. Our local guide told us that couple thousands of rupias is enough, but they demand more. So be careful, have some small cash with you and do not give too much!

Breathtaking but busy. This place is beautiful offering some real nice opportunities for taking amazing photos of the pretty view. The place however is very busy with lots of tourists and with that a lot of locals selling mass produced souveniers, which is somewhat stealing the focus of the beautiful place. We did not go down all the way as we did not have the right footwear.

Nice scenery but overcrowded . The scenery is very beautiful, but there's too much business around. Locals are pushing it too far when trying to have a "donation" of 50k just to walk on fields, it immediately kills the mood.
Good view. Excellent view from the top of the rice terraces! Try out the restaurant Boni Bali! Great food with a good view.

Nice View but not a Day Trip. We were luck enough to be staying half way between Ubud and the rice terraces so we cycled here. Which you could do from Ubud also but there are lots of hills so it takes some time. As per all the reviews this is an area that is especially touristy, having said that we were not asked to pay or hassled by any sellers but it was June so not quite the busy season. We stopped and had a drink in one of the warungs looking over the view - Orange juice was about £1 a glass which was very cheap for this location. We had the bikes so couldn't walk down through the terraces but if you want to spend more time here that is what you should do.

Perfect view . Perfect ricefields to pamper ur mind... The lunch we had, seing this beautiful ricefields was amazing . I would reccomend not to go with a Driver go by yourself take a bintang take a lot pictures and watch the green fields it Will be better ✌️

Nice stop on a tour. If your doing a full day tour of Ubud I would make this one of your stops. We went at midday so it was VERY hot, but worth it to see the fields. There are a few places to grab a drink or food but we did not stop at any. Overall it was not the best stop on the tour, but definitely worth going to and nice to see if you have never experienced a rice field.
Rice fields very nice. Loved walking around them. Flat shoes only ladies. We had a lovely 30 mins there and highly recommend

Too touristy . Very touristy and better local rice paddies you can see for free. Tourist trap with overpriced, bad food. A lot of pushy vendors around also, and you pay to drive on the terrace road- skip this!
More demanding walk. A beautiful view,but serious walk if you want to reach the opposite side(wear snickers)F&B is really nothing much,so I suggest go someplace else for lunch

rice visit. beautiful scenery and interesting to see; we visited the rice terrace as part of a day tour. I wouldn't recommended solely going here but would suggest visiting this location as part of a visit to multiple places.

Beautiful. Beautiful views; however, it was quite crowded. Street parking is difficult to find. It was helpful to have a driver drop us off whike he finds parking. There are lots of shops for souvenirs and a variety of restaurants.
Nice terrace. Nice view of the terraces and good places to eat something with a nice view. One of the best places for a nice picture.

Too touristy. Needs a one way system. Nice scenery but far to touristy and we spent most of our time waiting for people to pass.Far too much rubbish in places.Worth a visit if you cannot get to Jatiluwih as long as you move away from the main site. Pathways are narrow (its rice paddies) so expect to be part of a very slow moving procession. Don't wear you best shoes as you are likely to get them muddy.Once you get away from the main crowds it gets a lot better.

Beautiful views. The views are beautiful. Take a walk up and down and across the terraces, it was a lot of fun with the views and not exerting. Beware of "locals" demanding "donations" from you to cross bridges or take photos though. I paid a small amount once and ignored the rest.

Overrated. This rice terrace is for masstourists, nice though. If you are in Bali for a short time this is fine to see an example of ricefields. However to rent a scooter for a day and explore the island you will see prettier ones.

Picture Postcard. The rice had been mostly harvested when we arrived, so the view was not as spectacular as shown in the travel guides. Saying that this place is still worth a visit. If you do not want to walk through the Paddy fields, you can enjoy a drink at many of the cafes.

Over rated. . I think it is too commercial. Too bad that The beautiful view of the terrace paddy rice field is blocked by so many stalls and restaurants, so it is not natural anymore. The local government should step in to clear it up.
Views of rice fields. I have been to this restaurant a few times and love it every time I come. Food is fresh and the views are breathtaking. At must if visiting Ubud.

a beautiful scene. 青翠美麗的梯田景致
green, beautiful terraced fields
沿途有幾個收費處, 一個人會收10000RP
On the way to the bottom, there are a couple of tolls asking for donation, which is 10000RP per person.
有一些景觀餐廳蓋在入口高處, 可以一邊悠閒地喝茶, 一邊觀賞梯田風光
There are some restaurant at the entrance on the top. You may have some drinks while you admire the terraced fields

Hot, take water, but beautiful views. We went around 1pm, it was extreamly hot and there was no shade. The views were beautiful however the experience would have been 100x better if we had a tour guide. We didn't take water in with us but ended up buying some as we walked through. There are 3 donation points along the way were you have to pay to proceed any further. We paid 10,000 ird but were told we could have given much less. The place was beautiful but would have been more pleasant with a tour guide so we could have learnt a bit more about this place, with water and perhaps earlier in the day when it is not so hot.
Worth the trip. The views are amazing and you can walk through the paddies if you wish. Lots of places to eat as well

Disappointed . Pretty but notes good as I thought it'd be. Had just come from the monkey sacred forest so had high expectations. My hubby and I ate at the restaurant overlooking the rice patties. Have been unwell since with stomach issues. From Australia and find montville and melany sunshine Coast in Queensland more beautiful. As always though, the locals were beautiful.
Beautiful. This place is beautiful!! :) Such a peaceful place. The foot overlooking the rice terrace was amazing food! Road was narrow and hard to find parking, but overall was amazing!!
Nice attraction. While in Ubud this place is a nice place you should not miss. The view of the rice field on the side of the mountain is amazing.

Disappointed . Cycled from ubud to the rice terraces and I was more impressed with what I saw on the way. Rice fields being farmed and no touristy crowds. Iv seen amazing rice terraces in China so these were very disappointing

Nice view but way too crowded. We came here yesterday at the tail end of our program. The place was really busy with tourists walking all over the rice terrace. I wasn't wearing the right type of shoes so I didn't make it very far. With so many tourists all over the rice terraces and the walk ways weren't wide, it was easy to fall into one of the many puddles. I saw a teenager taking a picture and he fell down the next level because the ground wasn't very sturdy. I recommend wearing water shoes, if you fall into one of the many muddy puddles in tennis shoes, it can be quite unpleasant. It is a fantastic place for pictures if you can find a spot without many tourists. Great place to see from afar but maybe next time I will try trekking further in.

A great view and education on rice. This is well worth a visit if your in the Ubud area. The place does heave with tourists but if you go far enough up past all that it's a really nice and serene place. Try Dewi Cafe for a great view, reasonable food and good prices.

Beautiful terraces!! . It was so nice to ride here from town by motorbike. Just go straight up north, very easy! The rice fields are stunning, lush & bright green. There are many stalls of souvenirs and trinkets surrounding the area. Always fun to shop and negotiate! There are a few cafes overlooking the fields. You can Walk through the rice terraces. Definitely worth a short visit. Best by motorbike!!

Gorgeous place. Couldn't take enough photos of this place... just awe inspiring! Only things to note - bathrooms difficult to find (had to go to a restaurant to use theirs) and had to keep paying locals more and more money to go to other parts of the rice terraces.
Early in the morning.... Best time! . Before 12.00 a clock is Best time. The Most tourism is after 12.00.You dont need a guide. Dive by yourflex own with a scooter.
A nice walk. Great to explore this rice field and perfect for photo shoots. There are a lot of huts asking for donations for the upkeep of paddies - so just be wary

The I'm amazing views. This place was very close to Ubud. It was almost a one stop shop from Kuta as a day trip.nwe went to the monkey forest then to the Tegalalang Rice terrace and also stopped a few feet away to try the koi Lusaka coffee experience. This is free to do. If u are not great with heights or edges it may be difficult. I couldn't go all the way down as the stairs were very steep. They had hand rails but for normal people you would be fine. Stupid anxiety got me. My husband went down took some amazing pictures

Beautiful views . We got a return taxi here from Ubud for 200k rather than doing a day tour. Stayed for about an hour just wondering around the paddies it's a really beautiful area and great for taking photos of authentic Balinese culture. Could easily stay longer, a tour would probably be interesting but not necessary if you're low on time. There are lots of cafes overlooking the paddies if you're there around lunch time and want a gorgeous view.
Nice spot. Good place to stop for a Bintang overlooking the terraces, immaculately looked after and a big contrast to Kuta.

Lovely area so peaceful. I love seeing the rice terraces even though it can be a busy area with lots of tourists doing the same thing. But I stayed in a resort that looked over the terraces many years ago and there was a man playing a pan flute and it echoed all through the valley. just magical,

Beautiful in person, but crowded.. I was looking forward to this view. It was stunning, but I think we chose to go at the wrong time. It was soooo crowded. Surrounded by tons of tourist shops too. After the obligatory photo, we ventured down a bit, but decided it was just too crowded. I did learn that it may be best to access it from the other side, but you have to hike to get to the view. Maybe next time.

can avoid the Tegalalang tice terrace. this place seems to be over hyped as there are lot of other places where one can enjoy rice paddy fileds,one should always check on the harvest season before visiting there as the day we visited the harvest has just taken place and no go view could be seen,however the only saving grace is the good overviewing resturants which hace good food and real competitive price !!!!!
A very interesting place to visit. The first place in this world where I have seen rice being cultivated in terrace. On the way we saw paddy fields much above the road we were traveling.

Beautiful landscape. Was there in June so there wasn't a lot of tourist. There are hidden cost like paying to take pictures with items but it doesn't cost much , they don't earn much so don't haggle. It's just a few cents. A few kids were selling postcards ,just tell them politely that you don't need it. There's a few warongs too if you wish to have lunch as well. The terrace are narrow so do be careful esp if you have young kids or elderly. Some are rather steep and slippery. Best to wear sports shoes. The view is stunning and depends on when you go . Certain months the padi will look lush and green . During the period I went , the padi was slightly turning golden brown but still beautiful.There's also shops selling souvenir and clothing along the stretch.Worth the visit.

Beautiful but too touristy. Famous thanks to the movie Eat Pray Love. Indeed the padi field terraces are amazingly lush and beautiful.However, it wasn't too appealing (at least to me) to see so many souvenir shops cramming both sides of the road and equally many people touting their wares relentlessly. There also seemed to be more tourists than farmers walking in the fields!We attempted to take a walk down too but were prohibited as we were not customers of the cafe lining the pathway down :(Unfortunately due to it being so crowded and restrictive, we left within 10min..Recommended only if u MUST see the land made famous by the movie and do not mind the touristyness while soaking in the picturesque views.
Lunch. We had lunch here beautiful views of the rice fields. Staff lovely but the food lacked any flavour, presentation was good but that's as far as it got

Good photo opportunity . Not as gigantic as I thought. Touristic. Yet you could get quite a bit of good photo opportunity. Be ready to do some trekking down the rice Terraces. Wear a hat to protect yourself from strong sun and sturdy shoes as the ground was a bit uneven. A lot of children selling overpriced post cards, and even fee for bridge maintenance. Before you reach the rice terraces, you would also need to pay rp 20,000 just to pass the road. The rice terraces was not bad. But too many other hidden charges which kind of put tourists off.

The dramatic rice terraaces of Tegalalang. One of the most picturesque rice terraces in Bali can be found in Tegalalang about 30 minutes from Ubud. The landscape is really beautiful because the terraces are carved along the river valleys on both sides. You can take a walk along the fields boundaries from one side to other side of the river or make a photo with a local farmer carrying his grass basket for his cows.This is definitely worth a visit during your holiday in Bali.

Nice views . Nice views but a bit of walking. Use insect repellant as lots of pesky mozzies. Need to pay small fees with walking into e terraces.. Just pay no more than 5k each....beware of e scam ladies in e terraces whom offer free pic taking with carrying baskets n farmer hats.... After e pics she will ask for money. We refused n finally settle it with 6k for 4 of us. Only 40cents

relaxe your day here !. should you visit ubud centre , its nice if you are able to spend an hour here .. facing the rice terrace next to central of ubud.. afternoon at 4-5 is the best time to visit here.. and make an appointment with hot coffee and slice of tiramisu cake :)life is so beautiful ...
Rice Terrace. A highlight. We have seen a lot of rice terraces, but this is by far the best. Walk down into the paddies if you desire.

Beware of traps. Local people offering to be your guide for 50k rupiah  Avoid and say no you can go and visit rice terrace on your ownRemember it! Then some people ask for a donation. It is free so up to you you don't have to give money for their "association" if you don't want to.We probably arrived at the bad period cuz the rice was not really grown.Kind of nice photos to take

nothing spectacular. if you are anticipating a view of vast terrace paddies fields then best you give this place a wide detour. nothing much to see - just snap a few pictures and move on. too commercialize.

Beautiful. I was very tired and hot by the time I arrived to the rice fields, after spending the whole day sight seeing. But it is a must to visit the rice terraces and explore the fields. There are crafty farmers who set up pit-stops where they ask for a donation for maintenance and won't let you pass until you do, I would recommend to going back and taking another route. It is breath taking and such an experience.

Beautiful view but hassled the whole time we were there.. Was beautiful to look out but we just felt hassled from the moment we got there. They have set up these tacky I LOVE BALI in the prime photo locations and then have kids pushing postcards in your face saying they need money for school. then when you walk through the paddies you can't pass certain sections until you pay the "repair the bridge" fee and also the "best photo spot" fee. Very underwhelming. Also harvesters asking you if you want them to take your photo but expect $$ in return. Also area are quite slippery and saw a few people stumble. True some very wearing very inappropriate footwear but not at all safe.

Stunning views. The rice terrace is a must see in Ubud. Its stunning and makes for awesome photos. There are a few resturants on the way down which is good. My sister and i didnt stop but they looked nice. The terraces can be slighlty difficult to navigate and we only stayed there for 30 minutes or so but i love the photos. Most drivers will incorportate it in a day trip with other destinations like the waterfalls and coffee plantation which is a good way to go
Wonderful . Wonderful experience which is unique to south east Asia , you will love the view and the great welcoming of the people there

Wrong time . We visited when the rice harvest is in progress. Not much water in the paid fields and look nothing like the tourist pictures Overcrowded, no place to park. Avoid at all cost We ended up just driving past it. Very difficult when we last visited about 15 years ago. Best to during planting season
Nice, to be done quickly. Nice rice fields, you can take one hour to visit it. It is quite touristic and not so wild and huge. Ok with kids (we had from 3months baby to 7years).

Pleasant sight of rice-terrace. I visited this place two times, the first one was back in 2014. Since they were in the same month, there was no difference in general. I was wondering when to visit to see the rice-terraces all green.No entrance-ticket needed but they charge for parking.Small cafes are around offering views for visitors.You can walk down to the terraces, I think the steps might be slippery when it's raining.Anyway, great place to relax while enjoying authentic's rice-terrace view.
Average. I didnt find this rice terrace that attractive as it sounded at first, because we have many bigger one is India. So i'd say its average for me.

Scenic view. Nice scenic experience. Good to know that these areas are still existing and there are farmers working on them altough there is a slow erosion of them moving to the city centres for "greener pastures".

A bit disappointing. While it was on my list to see one of the rice paddies on a hillside, this is so commercialized that it wasn't to my taste. Others might like all the souvenir stalls along the road. However, there's a "heavy sell" and you'll have to work your way around at least one of them to get a good view of the rice terrace. You can also walk through the terrace, however, I didn't have time. The good thing was that I saw several wonderful rice paddies on the way; albeit flat.

Beautiful!. There is stretch where the tourist flock just after the toll area. Very pretty and lot of shopping. But we chose to avoid those and get a little future away where you could see the serene nature truly representative of the beautiful place
Scenic padi fields' view. We followed an electric bicycle tour and this was one of the pit stops. Beautiful and unique rice terrace. Lovely place for photography.
Beautiful view of rice terrace. We have seen similar scenery in Japan, however the rice terrace here are more developed and unified.
Very nice. Great place to visit but can be very busy and hot. I personally recommend wearing runners/trainers/converse as it can be slippery and if you want to do a lot of walking

Beautiful view. We had a quick walk around before we went to the coffee plantation. Spectacular views! Had a banana smoothie in a small resteraunt near by. They have a little spot for you to take a "love bali" picture which is free but they do have a small donation box which we gave 2000 rupiah (around 20p) cute little spot!
Stunning rice paddy fields - go before the crowds. Beautiful place to visit. Go in the early morning and you can really appreciate its beauty and peacefulness. Definitely a must see

Nice rice fields, however commercial.. Don't expect a quiet place when you go there.. it is sooo commercial.. all around are shops and you are very likely to be stopped by the locals to buy their goods.. the rice fields are nice.. lots of tourists.. further up, there are more fields with less tourists, which was nice. Parking around is crazy. If you drive, park away from the guards, as when you come back, you will be asked to pay for parking (on the road). It's nice to visit overall.
A w e s o m e. A mussst!!! It s a gorgeous view, everything is so green, it feels your heart with joy!Don t miss this!

Worth seeing . The rice terraces are something you have to see, bit like the Eiffel Tower if you Tavel to France. The drive out from Ubud is not to far at all so a taxi wouldn't be to expensive or you can pay for a driver for the round trip like we did. It cost us about $30 Aus or IDR 300,000rp to take us from Ubud to the terraces he also took us to the coffee plantation not far from there (also worth checking out, coffee plantation is free and staff are very friendly!) and also to a near by waterfall and back to our hotel. The rice fields are thumbs up all round, great views nice work bit of an exercise is you want to walk all the way around and makes for great photos. The only downside is they have "donation booths" scattered around the terraces, basically you have to pay them a small amount of money to keep walking. But it is what it is, try not to pay more than 50c or IDR 5,000rp for each one and enjoy

very scenic. its very good place to visit in ubud and its about 11 kms from ubud palaceyou would need a good shoes because lots of ups and downs there some entry fee there but i didnt because i didnt know about it and nobody asked.

Beautiful . This place was very beautiful. It was a great stop along the way to see rice terraces and farmers doing their daily work. There are many places to eat with nice views as well. Wear nice shoes such as tennis shoes because you can walk along the rice fields and sometimes the rocks are steep and slippery. You don't have to walk along the fields, even just for a quick photo opportunity this place is beautiful.

Steep hike through beautiful rice fields, but go early and be prepared to keep paying as you go. The Tegelalang rice fields provide the visitor to Bali with the chance to get up close to rice production. The hike down into the valley and back up the other side is steep. So wear good hiking footwear. Also, in addition to the Rp10.000 entrance fee, you will be asked to pay another "donation" of Rp5000 at two other locations along the way. And be aware that if anyone offers for you to take their photo, they are expecting to be paid. If you go with all that in mind, you can enjoy yourself instead of feeling a bit annoyed. Keep in mind that you are walking along their paths and across their rice dikes. So, it is fair that you pay them for that privilege.

Lunch. Excellent food, and good service. Awesome views of rice fields and watching people climb the tracks to the top. Three tiers of eating, bottom ones don't have chairs and very steep, so not good if that would be difficult, but plenty of tables and chairs at the top. Really enjoyable.

One day tour. I went to tegalalang by a scooter, 1 hour 30 minutes from Seminyak, place are beautiful, i was get some beers at the restaurant called gang nam style rest, we had wonderfull experience, the staff asking for taken you some picture
Unreal. This is a must visit if your in Ubud. The views are unreal. I would suggest wearing trainers or suitable shoes as there is a lot of walking. Amazing!

Stunning. Absolute highlight of the stay in Ubud. The rice fields provided a stunning view, walking experience and insight into how indonesian families harvest their rice.
Be prepared for steps! To enter different areas of land you are asked for a donation, be mindful of this. Theres lots of walking and we got a bit lost which added to the fun.

Trap for tourists. The landscape is beautiful but we paid a ticket to access the area and then we've been asked for a "donation" for the maintenance of some bridge in the terraces...when we gave the money they said it was not enough and they told us how much they wanted for 2 people...we then left. This place is full of traps for tourists which is a real pity because it would be really nice and peaceful.
Great views. Amazing short trek around the rice terraces. The steps can be a bit slippery if it rained the day before, but it cam be done, even in flip-flops

Must see tourist spot. The rice terraces are beautiful and totally catered to the tourist. Beware of the "tolls" along the way (never pay more than 10,000 rupiah to pass, make sure you have change for when you go) up and down the terraces. It is gorgeous with all the green and palms. It is free to get in but once you are there you do have to pay the tolls - we walked through most of it and spent about 20,000 rupiah. You can probably spend more the longer you explore. It is an iconic scene and would recommend it. I think it is a lot cheaper to higher your own driver/taxi than take an actual tour.
Awesome . Great views..Will recommend going early in the morning to avoid the crowds and have the best view/experience. Walk along the fields a must!

Ideal outdoor activity in beautiful scenery . It's a short trek but tramping around these lush green rice terraces will get your heart pumping a bit. The site is only marred by the numerous "donation points" set up along the route - some by shakedown artists who clearly aren't rice farmers.

Rice terraces. After half an hour's drive north of Ubud you reach Tegallalangs beautiful rice terraces. There is also the opportunity to get something to eat or drink. You should be aware that it is quite steep and slippery if you want to get through the rice terraces down in the valley.

Mother and daughter . On our recent tripto Bali we were taken to the Tegalalang Rice fields by our tour guide from Bali traditional tours. It was an awesome day beautiful I would recommend this tour to anyone who visits the Ubud region

Lunch with a Great View!!. Tegalalang Rice Terrace was a place worth seeing. This was one of our stop on a multi stop tour. The rice terrace was not that big, but it was beautiful. There were shopping, restaurants that can keep you occupy for hours. I wished we would have stopped longer here, I would have loved to dine at one of the hillside restaurant. Imagine eating Balinese food in a 2-4 person booth on a hillside with the view of the rice terrace. Unfortunate, we didn't have enough time to dine, will definitely do it When I go again.

The Rice terrace is huge. Be prepared that they will ask you for a donation, I think they make more money from tourists than the actual rice. The fact that you can walk up and down the valley amongst the rice is pretty special. Definitely worth the experience.

Cool to see but overpopulated by tourists . First of all, make sure to put on comfortable shoes and no flipflops and bring around 60k p.p. in small denominations for various charges by rice field owners. They call it a donation, but not a voluntary one if you like to move around freely.Really really populated by tourists and the corresponding amount of vendors. Better to arrange your ride prior as it is off the beaten track and there are no normal taxis to be found

Amazing rice field views. Stopped by before we went to mount batur area for a coffee break. Where else in the world where you can enjoy a cuppa overlooking the ricefields..this place is amaaaazing! Thanks to our tour guide for taking us here

Must go if you are in Ubud!. It would not make sense to take a trip to Bali and not visit rice terraces. If you are in Ubud, you are certainly crazy if you don't take the quick drive to Tegalalang! This place is beautiful. I hiked around the rice terrraces in about 30-45 minutes. A nice quick visit. Go early in the morning to beat the heat!There are shops along the way, but from my own personal experience, I didn't feel these sellers were extremely aggressive in their selling tactics at all. They were very kind and welcoming. I stopped at one and had a nice refreshing coconut while he played us the flute! Very sweet experience.Other reviews state lots of trash. I did not see one piece of trash on the rice terraces. Not sure where this is coming from. Maybe on the street they were talking about? But certainly not on the trail. And besides, have you honestly been anywhere in Ubud where there was a village/shops and not seen trash everywhere?Some people state that the "tourist-trap" road with shops takes away from the beauty of this place. I also disagree. This place is stunning, with or without the backdrop. You are visiting a poor country, people. Keep in mind these people have to make money somehow. It sucks for you, yes, but what person in a third world country wouldn't take advantage of selling items where thousands of people visit? Besides, from the road you are able to take pictures without the backdrop of the shops. It is a simple solution to a minute problem.Visit here for sure! and please make sure to wear sturdy shoes! I can't stress this enough. The trail is decently maintained but there are some spots where it was difficult. My hiking sandals broke the day before so I had to go in flip flops and definitely struggled. Where the water drains from irrigation there were slippery spots and muddy puddles. Be careful and walk with caution. Some of the steps are just dirt and have very high heights to step up. Shoes with good traction are preferred. I went with people who wore Toms and they were slipping in some spots as well!
Nice. Overrated tourist spot..farmers charged for photos without advance notice and they asked for a lot. Nice place overall

Each time I go back there are more and more buildings blocking the view.. Don't get me wrong the place is unique. However, each time I come over there are more and more restaurants built right on the edge of the road. You can't see a thing anymore from the street.

Beautiful Paddy Fields. Picturesque as in the postcards you see. We saw visitors climbing down into the paddy fields for a walk but our legs were sore from the climb at Mount Batur so we skipped that. Instead, we went to a nearby cafe overlooking the paddies. We spent only half an hour or so there, which is enough. We should have stopped over during our return trip from Mount Batur to Ubud instead of spending another S$30 and about 40 mins to and fro from our accommodation in the heart of Ubud. Might also have been more beautiful near late afternoon. Plenty of shops selling woodcraft on the way.

Beautiful! . After traveling through SE Asia for a few months and having missed out on the rice terraces in Sapa due to the weather earlier in the year, we were eager visit Tegalalang - we were not disappointed! The terraces are in a beautiful setting and was a great experience walking through them. It is as green and lush as it looks in the pictures. You don't need a guide or anything and can just walk around yourself, the paths around the terrace are clearly marked and is difficult to get lost in. Just a tip, to my knowledge there are three families that own the terrace and each have their own "station" along the path. At each of these the families require a "donation" (5 000Rp or 10 000Rp does the trick) to allow you to walk through. We had no problem paying and would highly recommend it to others. Other tips:- get there in the morning to avoid crowds, we got there around 9:30am and walked around with very few people on the rice terrace.- there are great cafes and restaurants on the hill looking over the terrace and is a lovely spot to enjoy a cold drink or meal after walking around.
nice view. Lovely rice terrace in Tegallalang, Gianyar, BaliVery easy to find beside the main road of Tegallalang.From Ubud only 20 to 25 minutes by scooter

Nice but .... The beauty is there for sure and it was quite a maze to walk through the terrace. On some occasions we had to backtrack as we were worried of getting too deep but it was generally fun to walk through.What pissed us off are the 'donation' booths that were scattered throughout the terrace. Obviously donation is not what they want but rather tolls. You are not given a choice. If you refuse they will act aggressive and start using their hands to block you or pull u back. They will also try to act blur when u run out of small change and had only larger notes. You have to be forceful with them. I had visited several tourist sites during this bali trip but there were no other places like this. My advice to all: if you really want to visit the terrace, don't bother walking through them. Just get sit down in one of the cafes overlooking the terrace to relax and admire the view
Stunning view. It's an amazing piece of art, i really liked how they are making beautiful things out of necessity. I'd recommend it.

A balinese treasure. A must to see for a Balinese trip, the culture of Rice is so important here, I hope is not gonna desapear for resorts buildings....It is a true knowledge and Balinese treasure to protect.

Lots of trash, lots of tourists, lots of souvenirs . The rice terraces were kinda impressive - but not what you would expect after seeing pics online that have been photoshopped beyond belief. Lots of tourists, and we were there on a quiet day. What turned us off the most were the copious amounts of trash in the terraces. Probably due to disrespectful tourists, but still: It's there. Every local age 6-85 is trying to sell you sth, like on many tourists Hotspots. Okay for a 30-60min visit, no must see unless you're really into agriculture or similar.

Great view. The view is amazing and walking through the field was hard specially with my young daughter 3 years old we had to carry here many times but it totally worth the effort we enjoyed the view drink coconut from very nice lady who has place to rest at the middle of the field and we got great photos. We also get the chance to meet a very nice boy who offered to guide us through our walk. I was so proud of him he was so polite speaking good english he was a boy but acting like a man so he got our respect.

Nice scenery but challenging to walk . Nice place to spend a bit of time in Ubud. Good view to take picture but it is quite challenging to cross to the other side of the rice terrence. There are some cafe and restaurant where people can enjoy the meal and view at the same time
Best rice paddy views. I suggest enjoying the views from a cafe here in Tegalalang.. Many to choose from...order a bite to eat..sit back and take in the breathtaking views!

Stunning scenery. The scenery here truly is breathtaking! You will be absolutely blown away by the beauty of it -- particularly the vibrancy of the green. However at the same time to us it wasn't very appealing due to it's touristy nature. It just didn't feel authentic. You are also requested to donate money on several occasions if you choose to walk through the rice terraces. You'd be better off using a motorbike or private driver to just adventure through the gorgeous scenic routes outside of Ubud.

Tegalalang Rice Field @ Bali Trip.. Good scenery in this hillside paddy field's visit, first time see such setting of paddy plantation. Rainy when we reach there, but the rain stop shortly and sun come-out shinning afterward. A good place to visit, but the con's side is the entrance fee.

Beautiful -Worth the stop. . Beautiful area, small shops- and Lewak Coffee. Stop! I tell you! You won't regret it. It was raining when I was there - but still worth the stop- would have loved to walk the rice fields had it been better weather.

Differen experience. This is the only place in bali where you can see that kind of rice terrace. I recommend to everyone who will go there to be with comfortable shoes and get an umbrella. During my stay there was a rainstorm and it was very slippery despite that very beautiful and unforgettable place.
Amazing place. An Amazing Place to visit, you can't miss it! I really Would like To Come back, especialy with My fantastic Guide Wirta Pande:)
spectacular. spectacular views, lots of tourists and eating places but if you overlook that the scenery is magnificent.
One of main things to do. About 25 minutes away with motorbike from Ubud .. good place to take some photos and great place to relax and enjoy watching green fileds

Notre première visite . It was amazing wonderful !!
Just an information if you would like to lunch in front of the Rice Terrace, choice this restaurant (picture enclosed) it's less expensive

Beaut View of the Rice Terraces. We took our tour group there on a scooter ride. It was a very easy ride from Ubud and the view was excellent. We had lunch over looking the terraces and it was delicious. Only problem is that was very busy there and it was hard to find parking and crossing the road was a challenge.Our group enjoyed the experience.

Beautiful site. Visit here for a unique experience! Nature at its best! Wear shoes for walking as the floor is uneven and a bit damp and muddy in places! There are steps down to the bottom of the terrace but remember you have to come back up and it's quite a workout!

Unreal beauty . Once you reach this area , you think you stepped into heaven , the vast huge rice terrace is unbelievable , and u can walk in and go down to see the details and the watering system, the strange plants, its like an adventure , it's amazing and safe , we went on a rainy day , it made it much more beautiful specially when he ate lunch on the nearby restaurant terrace . It's a must see
Beautiful view. We dropped by to have a look. It's not as extensive as other terraced rice fields are but the view is refreshing and worth visiting if in the area

Scenery that fuels the soul. A breathtaking spot to take in some lunch at one of the many cafes, and some fun bartering with the salesmen, just don't believe them when they try to convince you that their poor old mother had crocheted the throws. Lol. I chose to sip a fresh pineapple juice and look out at the stunning view while the rest of my family went tromping around the rice field tracks. I did not regret my decision when a heavy bout of rain came down. My family may have, after doing the dash up the muddy goat tracks, sometimes the lazy way is the wise way. Hahaha
You must go there, but...... It is a must see in Ubud, Bali. However, try to go inside roads and explore more. The rice terrace just besides the highway is crowded and not very nice.

Great Views. The rice terrace isn't far from the city of Ubud. We got a taxi from the street that took us around for 5 hours for 400K. Probably could've gotten a cheaper price to go straight to the rice terrace. The rice terrace had a lot of good views. There are some people with hut set up throughout the path asking for donations. The first one there's a guy with a gate and he won't open the gate to the path without a donation. Don't give too much 1K or 2K. Further along the path around the rice fields there are more aggressive people trying to block the path with their arm for a donation. Just say no and walk past them sternly. They targeted me and my friend because we were 2 girls, but a guy ahead of me signaled to me not to pay.

Nice view, but too many 'donation'. In total, we really enjoy our exercise in Tegalalang Rice Field. We enjoyed beautiful scenery while hopping from one square field to another square field. Path ways are already prepared for easy walking. Despite no significant mark on which direction, but we can follow the path ways.Paid Rp 10k as entrance fee to the village (Tegalalang stated in this one village, run by the locals) by using car. While we were walking we found 2 major stopping points, where you "should" donate for rice field maintenance. Don't get me wrong. I don't mind pay any cost or donate for the maintenance. Hence I would recommend to put all cost before people start wandering in the rice field. Let's say Rp 30k - 50k to include village's entrance fee and "donation". It wasn't very pleasant when you're struggling to climb the path ways or just want to enjoy scenery, but you can only pass it through the stopping point after pay certain amount of "donation". Less practical, I must say.Road leading to Tegalalang (to be fair, all area in Bali) is rather small, thus have to be carefull.

Beautiful terraces. Such beautiful scenery so close to central Ubud with amazing photo opportunities. Various options to experience the terraces from sitting and experiencing quietly or a leisurely walk through.
Simply beautiful . Beautiful Bali...Gorgeous Ubud.One can trek around tbe fields or like us enjoy the scenery from the road. They are beautiful and a must see.
Fantastic view! . We just stopped and view the rice terraces fromthe road, and wow what an incredible view. Other people were walking through which I think would've been amazing too.

Big and beatiful. This rice terrace is pretty big. I suggest going early morning, as it gets really hot. We were sweating like crazy walking around the terrace but it was worth it. We also had some drinks afterwards at the cafe, with such a beautiful view.
beautiful. beautiful view, only few kilometres away from central ubud. theres plenty cafe there also you can sip a coffe while viewing at the rice terrace
Bike ride starting point. Beautiful spot only 15 mins out of Ubud. We saw it as part of a bike ride which i recommend also.On the bike ride we saw lots of ducks and workers in the field

photogenic. This is very cool place to take photos, it's very photogenic. You have to pay like 1 usd per person to enter the area. If you like shopping, you have to be a good bargainer. They are adding like %50-70 to normal price. Actually this is like a rool in Bali :)

Beautiful view and lots of verdure. Nice place to visit in sunny day.You can pick a lot of fantastic photos. Sit in a restaurant or bar on the slope and just relax with a cup of local balinese coffee - kopi luwak or cool Bintang.

A Must See - Tourist 101. IF you are in the Ubud, you will definitely stop here. You can walk all through the Terraces and it is quite fun. Don't worry about the ladies that stand at the bridges, only give them money if you want to, as it is not required, but a good way to get money from tourists.

Great photo opportunity but very busy. We stopped here briefly but didn't venture far into the rice fields as we had already had a long day of driving, but you don't need to walk far to get a beautiful view and some good photos. It is very busy with tourists and limited parking for the drivers.

A must see for every visiter of Bali. A lot of tourists, but should be visited. Unique rice fields and jungle around it. Drank coconut . It's wet rice cultivation and I expected mosquitoes. None seen.

Scenic terraces but very touristy. We visited this attraction as part of a private tour with Amansuka Tour. The terraces can be viewed from the side of the road which overlooks a valley and onto the slopes on the opposite side. The whole road side was full of vehicles when we arrived around lunch time, and choked with the usual shops/cafes catering to the tourists.
