It's not an easy climb down the side of the slope, there are no defined steps or handholds, made worse by the high human traffic all using the same few passages. If you wanted to see padi fields, there are many in Bali which do no require you to exert yourself so hard. It is very scenic, so you can choose to just soak it all in by enjoying a cool drink at one of the many cafes overlooking the terraces. My two boys loved the challenge of the climb and racing to the top of the opposite slope, and declared it the highlight of their day.

Amazing views of Indonesian Culture. The rice terrace is a unique first hand view of agriculture as it has been done for hundreds of years.Although surrounded by shops, hawkers and parking attendants it still stands out as a must see location while in Ubud and Bali for that matter.Rice is still part of a staple diet of most Indonesians and its interesting to see it still be grown here and producing good crops.I liked the views and the terraces.The hawkers and alike didn't impress me to much but left you alone if you said no to be buying anything.Good places everywhere to grab a cool drink or something small to snack on.I found parking my scooter not to much of a issue at the time i visited.Overall a location to view and appreciate the hard work that goes into tending these rice areas.

Bring good walking shoes!. The way to go down to the rice terrace is a bit hard to find once in Tegalalang, as the road is lined with shops selling souvenirs and cold drinks (do buy one!), and asking for money in exchange for the right to take pictures. There are toilets in the restaurants that you can use for 2,000Rp (15 Euro cents).The tour of the terraces took us a bit more than one hour, but there were more trails to walk longer. It is a bit confusing and there are no signs indicating where the exit is. There are also local people set up in strategic places who ask for a 'donation'. Just tell them no, they are not official (except the one at the top with a barrier, you must pay otherwise you're stuck).Even with all these drawbacks, the terrace is an amazing place. It is beautiful and it makes for a nice walk. Bring good walking shoes as the trails are a bit long, there can be mud, and tricky places.

An experience!. It was really an experience to see the rice terrace as this is the first time we have seen this. However, the steps are quite difficult to climb and it can be very muddy too. But is worth the climb. Be careful and have good walking shoes.

Must do. This rice terrace is a must do. If you can get it as a part of a day trip with a driver (we paid 550 for 9 1/2 hours from Seminyak to Ubud) it is a great addition to any Bali trip. Have a tea at a cafe and enjoy what is a great tradition in Bali. You can avoid the entry fee of 10,000rph by getting dropped at another point other than the main car park. We didn't walk up the hill but there were plenty of keen sweaty tourists who were exploring the terraces them selves and even posing with a farmer or 2!! All in all an awesome stop!!

Stunning. This place was incredible. We decided to trek it, and although it was slippery and perilous at some points it was amazing to reach the other side of the embankment. The only negative was the horrid little Balinese woman on the one bridge leading to the other side, demanding money from people and preventing them if they didn't make a donation. A forced donation of 10000 is not a donation! So many people got into a yelling match with her, I am surprised she hasn't been knocked down!
Great views. I have visited the rice terrace a number of times and it's breathtaking. A great way to see the beautiful countryside around Ubud
Too commercial. The rice paddies are beautiful, but there are too many tourists an commercial activities.We liked the rice fields of Jatiluwih much more.
woahhh. this is my very first time to see view of rice terrace. and this is just woahh great view who love natural and go green for our life time.

Too many people. Overall the rice terraces are pretty, but there were so many people that the peacefulness was ruined. I am sure there are other areas we could have gone to, but when we requested our driver take us to the rice terraces, this is where we ended up. It seemed like a tourist trap and I was disappointed.

Coffee break. On the way to Kintamani we stoped by to have some coffee break in the side of rice terraces, good to visit in the morning, in mid day the road are full with car parked in the side of the road.

Wow!!!. The rice fields are incredible. It's the first time my partner and I have ever seen rice fields. The place is incredible. Walk the hiking track which is quite short but offers incredible views at the top. The only thing that put us off slightly was every turn has a donation entry bay and the occupants are forceful. Rent a motorbike for 40000 idr and its about 25 minutes from central ubud. Worth the trip.
Fun. Be ready to walk and enjoy the scenery . I enjoyed it although a bit hot. Come prepared with sunscreen and a hat. Take pics

Good experience. It's a beautiful place. There is entry ticket for it. U can park car and go down to see. Can walk and take photos of good view. Not so great if u r from India and visited south india. It's same .

nice view. If you are in Ubud, take a chance to visit this site. As I walk to the rice terrace you need to be very careful or balance to your body. Just take a view pictures with this background and you are officially been in Ubud. =)

No need to pay for a beautiful view. You can get a great view of this iconic rice terrace from the cafes across the street. There is a little walkway that's free where you can snap the photos for your scrapbook. The further into the terrace you walk, the more frequently you will be charged.
Lovely view. Only pull over on the road and see rice paddies. Easy to access and doesn't take too long. Basically beside the roaf
Great views. Great views not far away from Ubud. If you are early it's more quiet. We went by scooter and had a drink there which gives you some privacy.

Rice terrace hike. Tegalalang Rice Terrace menjadikan inspirasi yg sangat menakjubkan & semua bisa nikmatin alam dg 30 minute hike in this area ..best combination trip ...'
Great place ...

Beautiful views. Gorgeous views of winding, sloped rice terraces. There are various coffee plantations nearby from which you can watch the view and have a drink, some serving coffee luwak. Their presentations and flights of different coffee types are quite intriguing, but the numerous civet cats kept in small cages is disturbing. Stay away from these venues or refuse to buy their coffee luwak at least. There are other places to be found where the civets run wild.

Rice rice rice!. Pretty neat to see all the rice. We tried to not follow the main path everyone takes and it allowed us to explore a little more of the hillside and we didn't get in trouble so it is ok to do? Hot and lots of hiking up and down so be ready for that!

A great visit - go earlier . We hired scooters for the day and took in all the sites around Ubud- a really fun day. I wished we'd got to the rice terrace earlier as the light was fading - they are gorgeous though and you could spend hours wondering the little paths.

A beautiful place but ... Maybe a tourist like me from Egypt would think that this view is amazing and the nature is beautiful in this place and yes to be honest I was amazed but what I see. The way the field made by architect however those views you can see places similar in Europe , so I don't think that Europeans might think it's something not normal. Maybe helping an old man there buy paying around 10000-15000 rupiah which is nothing there to hold his equipments and take a photo with it as a farmer there. Over all the experience is new and nice but if you decided to walk around there then you should wear light comfortable cloths with sports shoes because you will climb the place.

Worth seeing. Definitely worth a visit for 15-45 minutes. You can see the fields from the road when driving past but without doubt worth getting out and taking a picture. You can also walk around the rice fields a little bit. We met a great old local man who let us take a picture with him and the rice crops he was carrying for free. The usual shops selling clothes drinks etc are all there.

Beautiful rice fields. Make sure you have good non slip shoes. Lots of stairs! You will be asked for a "donation" to walk thru the fields... It's inly a suggestion and not mandatory. Beautiful and again, many stairs.

Unexpected walk. We did not want to go to this field, but we were stopped by some guy that looked like policeman and he told us we have to turn to the parking. Some time after we had realized, that this their way how to avoid traffic jam on their main street, which leads around the fields.The entrance is pretty cheap, 10k rph per person. The parking is free, which is fine.The fields itself are very steep, so I would not recommend to go there during noon. Fields are very nice to see, but it depends on the season. If it is after harvest, you wouldn't see much. At the top of field is something, that will be shop in the future. There you have to pay another fee to get further. But 5k for two two is OK, so don't worry about be scammed.I would not recommend to go to the spring , because the walk does not worth it. The view is the same as from the walk to the field, and the way at the end seems to be collapsed, so it is very hard to get to spring itself.If you compare it with Jatiluwih, there are nicer pictures in Jatiluwih, if you get lucky. The trip is easier for walking, but you won't get as close as there. But the road to Tegalang is far more better.

Amazing experience!. MUST SEE in Bali! If you are staying in Ubud I highly recommend renting a scooter. Its a 30min ride and very easy to get there. After the main rice terraces we got lost around the many other plantation in the area. Great roads and views to see.Wear comfortable shoes! You can go into the plantation and walk around, but most paths are basic or even muddy

Beautiful....Definitely Worth Seeing. This is a great way to see first-hand how rice grows. The terraces are beautiful to see and if you are inclined, you can hike around on the hillside where the rice is growing. You can a few minutes viewing the terrace or an hour or more trekking the paddies.

Nice Rice terrace view. We have just spend half an hour when visit the rice terrace. The road to this rice terrace are narrow and very busy. The view are very nice and nature. There have some store to sell some local souvenir.

Beautiful Rice Terraces. These are probably the most beautiful rice terraces you would see anywhere in the world. They are spread as far and wide as you eyes can see. A very picturesque location. You can go trekking here but be careful of the path. Its easy to slip and the muddy path gives way too easily sometimes. Good spot to click some nice pictures. There are a few warungs here where you can sit and enjoy the view while you sip your favourite brew.

Really beautiful. This huge rice terrace is only 20min bike ride from the centre of Ubud... Really easy to find, and a lovely drive.It's kind of exhausting, lots of stairs, so make sure you wear good shoes, hat, sunscreen and keep on with the water!! You can basically spend the whole day walking around there...Also always take small notes as some of the locals ask for donation in some parts of the field, and they are usually grumpy ladies that wont let you go to the other side haha :)Sunset time is the best to go!!

Too good to be true . Looked fake! So beautiful, lush and green. Definitely worth a visit but don't need a ton of time there. Maybe an hour to walk around a bit. Careful on the slippery mud, easier if you stay on trails rather than go along the edges of the paddies. If you walk a little further away from the main touristy part, you might get lucky and get a private 'tour' from a local (for a small fee).

Small area. It's actually a small area where you can take a walk in the rice paddy fields or opt to just take photos at strategic points. There were kids selling postcards. I don't find it worth paying the ticket if it's only for photo taking session. A tip, if u join the Eco cycling tour, they do bring you to this place for a quick photo-shoot during the early mornings without having to pay for the ticket!

Breathtaking! . Saved the best place til last on our first Bali trip. Absolutely amazing - breathtaking views over the rice fields. So much fun and a must see when in Bali. Do not miss going here - it is incredible. Can't recommend it more :)

Good trekking experience. I thought we were only allowed to take photographs but we are allowed to hike and trek through the terraces! Came unprepared and came in flip flops which wasn't adequate but managed to complete whole course! The routes are Abit dangerous and you might slip and fall so be careful. Not recommended for beginners as terraces are quite steep. We had lunch at cafe dewi food range from 40.000 IDR to 100.000 IDR but was very tasty. They had kittens running all around I wasn't a fan of kittens so hurriedly finished the meal.
Quick View of the Rixe fields.. A drive to see the rice fields. pretty view but touristy and busy....a slow drive past would have been just as good.

Wonderful walk. The walk through rice terraces was such a wonderful experience. We walked that day around 28 km. I and my husband were amazed about the views. So peaceful and beautiful nature. The great thing was to see the local people and not many tourists.

Disappointing. Had read about this & was looking forward to visiting. After buying a ticket it is hit n miss if someone takes your ticket. It was not sign posted & although you can see the rice fields you cannot work out how to get to them. There is no information verbal or written to explain the fields. It is a bit of a hazard to walk down/up. A shame as it is pretty & could be a tourist attraction raising money.
Amazing place. Amazing place, beautiful nature, palmtrees and everything green. "You haven't seen Bali, until you have seen Ubud"

Beautiful in every sense of the word . The rice paddies are so green and lush and you can wander down into them and explore. There are restaurants along the side if you want to stop for a drink or some food but the view alone is worth going to see

Unique!. Really beautiful, very unique. But the throngs of tourists - and hawkers and children in your face and space- can be a little much. Go early in the day and really explore. It's genuinely a Beautiful place.

Beautiful but overcrowded . Beautiful rice terraces but i couldn't help feel on edge everywhere we trekked for fear of being asked for a donation.. it is a small amount of money but i felt i could not fully relax and enjoy the scenery. Definitely nice to see though :)

Stunning! . A must visit place in Bali!
Pick a cafe to have a cold drink and just take your time admiring the view.

Great view . Sun was out lots of people enjoying it. The Balinese have to work hard for their food and it is great to see how it's done.
In the west it is so easy to forget where our food comes from

Worth checking out. We were surprised to learn this was not the rice terrace we had seen in photographs of Bali. There is actually a more extensive rice terrace and unfortunately I cant remember its name. I´d say Tegalalang is still worth checking out, just note you have to pay 10K IDR when you enter the viewing area (which supposedly goes to a community fund). And if you decide to walk/climb the terraces, there will be 'donation' collection points asking you to fund the families who own the terraces.

Not for the faint of heart. At a glance, it's was beautiful but until you are 1 hour into the trek and you realize it seems to be never ending. There are also several "toll ways" which locals will coerce you to give. Keep some small change and make sure you follow someone who can get you out of the maze!

beautiful but make sure you have plenty of small cash. beautiful rice terraces definitely worth going even if just to stop and have lunch by and take in the views. If you are going to do the trek around make sure you have plenty of small cash on you. One lot for the donation box at the beginning and some more tucked away too as there are some unscrupulous individuals whom have planted themselves at different parts of the path and will not let you pass until you have paid them, one of which physically restrained me and separated myself and one half of our group from the other who he decided to let pass without paying!

Too touristy. . There are so many rice paddies in Bali I found this a bit of a tourist trap. You pay for you parking then a donation to enter and at the top if you wanted to go further they asked for another donation. It wasn't much and we are only talking a few dollars but just to view and walk in a terraced rice paddy? It was beautiful all the same. Take good walking shoes as the walkways are slippery and steep at times.
Lovely views. Option of walking down to the valley if desired between the rice terraces. The view can still be seen if no walking desired.
Nice view of the paddy fields. Beautiful views and cool air of the mountain. 15min drive from Ubud market. Worth to see if you have not seen a rice paddy field before.

Hard to enjoy the view. Found it hard to enjoy the view of the terraces as the only places we could find to stand were outside people's shops and we just wanted to be left alone without shopping. It was too hot for us to walk on the terraces, don't know how people could manage that! Probably over half an hour out of Ubud centre and sort of a long way to go when there's nothing else to do out there.
I really enjoyed this. Awesome place. Great scenery in the sun. Take your camera, you are gonna get some good ones here. Make sure you have cash on you.
Overrated. I was expecting more but it was a bit of a let down particularly if you compare the view to that of the Banaue Rice Terraces of the Philippines

Beautiful view. We weren't able to go into the rice field and thank goodness we didn't. Just as we left there was a lot of heavy rain causing the roads to flood. If you plan on visiting make sure to go when the sky's are clear

Too touristy. It's just a small patch of rice terraces made totally touristy with hawkers and cafes. You can skip this place and will miss nothing. There's great handicraft shopping all along the way if you're driving to this place from Ubud.
Awesome. One of the things I was looking forward to see when I was in Bali, if you love nature, then go here when you're in Ubud.

Beautiful scenery! . Definitely a highlight of our trip! The pictures don't do it justice, the fields are beautiful. We visited around midday and stopped for some lunch. Our driver Wayan took us to quieter entrance so we felt like we had the fields to ourself.

One of my favorite places to visit. The rice terraces are amazing to view and to view as you are eating at one of the restaurants along the road overlooking them. I walked down with my daughter an we took some spectacular photos. A word of caution, the path ways are hard mud and can be slippery and quite narrow at some points but it is fun. There are a fair number of individuals trying to make money by selling you things like post cards or photo scenes they have staged but they are all very polite. Lots of shops at the top and crafts shops of every kind along to road leading to the rice terraces.

WOW! MUST SEE. I've previously seen photos of this amazing sight but to actually visit is breathtakingly beautiful. Visitors can actually walk around and experience close up the amazing terraces of these ricefields. Set in one on the most beautiful parts of UBUD area and a MUST visit to see for ones self. Whether young or old, everyone will enjoy this attraction
Impressive. If you are touring around Ubud, I would definitely stop at this rice terrace. It is picturesque and grand in scale.

Walk right as you're facing the terraces to find the free concrete stairs down. Really beautiful and worthwhile. Top Tips: There are free viewing platforms for photos and free stairs to the right of the shops as you're facing the rice fields. Ignore all the signs that say "come down / beautiful view, etc" as you'll find yourself inside a restaurant or unintentionally browsing souvenirs and have to climb all the way back up those steps!! The free stairs doesn't have a sign, but you'll recognise it straight away. It's just a whole lot of concrete steps. Wear good shoes as there are about 200 steps down, and then you have to walk up slippery mud steps on the other side (some "paving" with tree stumps, but be careful stepping on these). I saw some elderly Chinese women struggle even with the concrete steps. Would not recommend this activity with wheelchairs / prams. A walking stick might be useful if you have bad knees.Remember to talk sunscreen, mosquito repellent, a hat, and a towel (for the inevitable sweat). Don't rest your bags on railings or tables unless you want ants over them.

Nice rice terraces, but commercialized and too crowded. Go to Jatiluwah instead.. Nice rice terraces, but there's a lot of hawkers and people in the terraces asking you to pay to take picture with them. There were so many tourists there. Recommend going to Jatiluwah rice terraces further north instead, Tegalalang pales in comparison.

A great view of the rice fields. This is one of the huge rice fields and one can visit to catch up the view and walk around the rice fields , click photographs , and eat out while having a great view of the fields. It was pretty hot when we visited the place. Also there is a small fee to enter the fields .

Stunning, but locals harrass you.. The scenary is very beautiful, and you must come here to look around. There are two sets of rice fields here, the first which is the main area close to the road, and the second set over the hill which is less popular and therefore fewer tourists for a nicer more private experience. You can wander through the various levels of the fields, but they have fences up so like many people, you think you are following a path, then cant get back onto the main path because they have put a fence up to stop you. Its not logical at all!When I say locals harrass you, its because they are dotted throughout the fields trying to get people to make donations ALL THE TIME! One isnt even a donation, they actually forced us, blocking our path so we couldnt get past till we put 10K each into their pot! These guys really spoil the place! They don't even realise, or they just dont care!Overall the scenary is spectacular.
Beautiful !. It was the first time I saw rice field like this which absolutely I will not be able to find in my country.Highly recommend this place if you visit Ubud !

Stunning views. This place is about 20 -30 minutes from Ubud depending on the traffic. There is not much space for parking and it gets extremely busy with tourists. The local sellers can be a bit pushy however over the years I have purchased some beautiful quilts and crocheted blankets here. It gets very hot and steamy by mid morning so make sure you have cold drinks, hats and sunscreen. There are a few cafe/restaurants there but again they know how to play the tourists and will even tell you you cant take photos from certain vantage points unless you are a customer.

Use the stairs!. We didn't realise there were stairs so we scaled the muddy banks to get down and across the other side, only to realise there were stairs. They're at the start of the markets as you come in from Ubud on the right. Spectacular views and so green. Definitely worth a visit and once you've climbed back out, treat yourself to a drink with a view.

Breathtaking. The view is breathtaking. For youngster and have a good stamina, do take the opportunity to hike to the other side.You will see few shops selling embroidery. Buy it here instead of in Kuta which is quite expensive. Sometimes they dont have the same design as in here. Even in Sukawati its quite pricey as well.

Great trip, Highly recommend. Green terrace like other terraces in SE Asia, nice to take a photo of a greeny rice.We pay 450,000 IDR per day for a car with driver and entrance fee is applied but we don't know how much it is (no proper ticket booth or sale ticket station, just the Local with one chair sit beside a road and a driver stop-by him pay for a fee to visit this Rice terrace), here was the first place of the day we visit, it was pretty hot (early May), crowded, but nice view, Be careful of wearing high heel or platform, better flip-flop or sneaker, I found girl her shoes and half leg dipped into a pond between a level paved.

Beautiful Terraces. A must do if you are anywhere near Ubud. Pull up and take time to either walk through or view from a cafe the rice terraces of Tegalalang. Every time we come to Bali we always go back.

Nice view outside, better view inside the valley. Good short hike.. If you like a short hike then this is one for you. If you like the history and intricacies of agriculture this is impressive. Being in the rice field and the view inside the valley is awesome. The fields are owned by several farmers and they ask a donation at each entrance to their part. There seems to be at least twp owners that you must enter to complete the hike. Some quibble about paying 10000 Rupi donation for entry to each area but that is less than a US Dollar. Surely a small price to trample thru their field. Or you could pay once but you must see the valley. Well worth the view.

Beautiful place! A shame that moped are autorised to come over. As I already explained,indonesia is a very noisy country with a very high level of smog and so, getting away from the noisy traffic is a privilege! We decided to spend few hours in those beautiful fields!All you can hear is the water, along the small road, edging the rice fields, the ducks and some rice farmers until a wrong wrong from a moped comes to interrupt this magical moment!Very nice and peaceful place for a relaxing walk.Again, my big disappointment has been to find an average amount of trashes, plastic bottles in the lovely river, on the floor and the fields!

Look for the free viewing platform. That free platform is almost hidden among and behind the souvenir shops, but descend and admire the justly famous curved terraces Balinese rice farmers have carved. Calm is restored while you turn your back to traffic.

Nice terrace - too touristy.... This is a great place to see nice rice terraces. If it wasnt for all the sellers trying to pawn off cheap goods to you everywhere... If you want to see real peaceful rice terraces without being panhandled then you should check out other locations which are much more surreal!

Nice view but physically demanding. Was with kids 10 and 8. Very good view but quite demanding physically. Needs proper shoes and careful walk. Any offer of picture with a worker there is not free but very much worth it. Also crossing the bridge means parting with some donations.
Photos. Not what I expected...you get hassled to buy postcards, & other stuff so all we wanted to do was take a few quick photos & get out of there...
Too many toursts. A beautiful place but unfortunately also a tourist attraction with many souvenir stalls and people crawling amongst the rice terraces

Amazing Views, but Be Prepared to Pay for Them. My husband and I rented a scooter for the day and drove the short drive the terraces just north of Ubud. We had a free place to park and easy access down to the fields but every local working within the terraces want you to pay them for all sorts of reasons. You had to pay to take a photo, cross over their bridge, or to walk up to the next level. Be prepared with small bills if you wish to continue your climb or you will not be allowed to pass. The views were beautiful and I recommend making your trip in the morning before it gets too hot and all of the other visitors make it out for the day.

Walking through the rice. When you get to the Tegalalang Rice Terraces you can take pictures just off the road and can find a stairway down into the rice terraces pretty easily. Once you go into the area there will be someone asking for donations and since the terraces are used by different families and farmers this is something you will see a few times as you walk around. When they are growing rice the terraces will be flooded and you will have to watch your step. The paths can sometimes be hard to figure out but that is part of the charm. The views were wonderful even if when I went it was a rainy day. It was great because me and my friend were the only ones walking around as all the other tourists had left because of the rain.It felt like for those 2 hours it was our place to explore because everyone else stayed by the road to take pictures as we went in and explored the farms and watched the locals do the their work.

It's cool to see but not a required stop. It's pretty amazing. Definitely a tourist trap. Good to stop, grab a beer and keep moving on. Lots of stalls selling the same stuff. It was reccomended we don't walk around down there. Way too many insects and parasites in the mud. A morning rice patty walk with good shoes might be a better way to experience the countryside.
Almost as beautiful as Jataluwih. Gorgeous rice terraces, and a few nice cafes with terraces from which to enjoy the view. 30 minutes from Ubud

Nice to see! . Happy to visit Tegalalang, it's possible to take the scooter from Ubud and park it in front of the view for a small payment around 5000 - 10 000 rupiah. Be sure to take a walk on the terrace but have some small money ready to pay for "entrance fee" (locals have built stairs and railings and charge for it, around 5000-10 000) It's amazing to walk along the side of the terrace so be sure to do it! If you walk to far into the terraces (locals don't care if you trespasses their property) but they will ask for "donation" to them but it's up to you if you want to support begging.

Good Experience at Tegallalang. Tegallalang rice terrace famous with it terrace scenery. A must visit place when visit to North Bali. We arrived on a raining day and cool weather made a good experience with after rain atmosphere and beautiful view. A narrow road plus tourist mpv stop along the road side made this area a bit jam. There are many wood craft arts and souvenir shops along this area. You can walk around, dine awhile and shop your favourite items. Worth visit if you never been to rice terrace in Bali.

Stunning View. If you love rice paddies and the green forest, you shall not miss this stop. Be ready to walk and hike some stairs to immerse yourself in this oasis of tranquillity. We enjoyed very much the visit, especially the courtesy and genuine welcome of Wayan, a old peasant that offered us fresh coconut and a nice performance with a traditional instrument. We were happy to pay the 20k rupees he asked for the coconut.Unfortunately, the others families owning land in the valley (yes the rice paddies are divided in many families) just stopped us, blocking the way while walking asking the payment of a "tax" to go further. We refused to accept this approach and rudeness and walked away.Go early in the morning before it gets too hot and bring a lot of water with you. A ticket to access the rice fields shall be paid to access the area, something equivalent to few euros per person.

Nice to see for a first time. If you've not been to Jatiluwih before or visited vietnam, then you'll surely like it.There are some restaurants overviewing the terrasse rice fields, nice places to contemplate the surounding.So why not stopping by and enjoy the view.

Breathtaking views but.... Tarnished with the poor steps / access and also the litter (more from the locals than tourists). We were travelling as a family of 4 but our youngest fell asleep enroute so hubby stayed in our car with her. Myself and our eldest (6yr old) ventured down. Views were beautiful but very very busy so hard to stop and take 'a moment' as people needed to pass all the time.Glad we've been but not suitable for young kids and I would recommend wearing runners as some of the drops / slopes are a bit dodgy when wearing thongs.

Beautiful . This was the first stop of the day for me. The views were beautiful. Be aware that if you are going to walk around, there is an element of steep paths. I often had to go slow since I was wearing flip flops. About half way through there is a bridge that you cross to get to the other side. A woman will stop you and ask for a bridge donation. This really isn't a donation, you should look at it as part of the admission price. The only downfall was all of the little girls following you around putting the hard sell on for post cards. All in all, I highly recommend.
Stunning!. We spend an afternoon at a little coffee shop overlooking the paddies. What a beautiful setting - probably one of the best places to photograph the paddies as well.
Beautiful serene place. Never did i ever expect to see such beauty in a rice field, but it does exist. I definitely recommend stopping and seeing this.
Beautiful. Wonderful rice fields not far from Ubud. It is highly recommended to arrive early in the morning when it is not too hot and too crowded.

Stunning! Must go!. Don't miss out this Rice Terrace, it is incredible how people cultive rice in this way and walk between the field, it is really beautiful and a good contact with the local culture.

Beautiful!. The rice field was pretty big and beautiful!! I didn't do a tour but my driver was pretty knowledgeable. I would highly recommend coming here as there is also a small restaurant near by. The staff was sweet but we didn't have time to stay and eat. Also, you are allowed to walk all across the field which was pretty nice.

Good Photo Op's. Great spot for some photo's, you can walk through the terrace as little or as far as you like. Along the way there was a man with his stick with the baskets on the end (sorry not sure of the correct name) he will take photos for you holding this but he will expect to be paid approx $1 (AUD). Worth a short visit.

Too Touristy. The rice terraces in Tegalalang are only a small sample and I only recommend to go if you are in the Ubud area, as part of a tour or on the way to some place like Mount Batur. Like everywhere, tourists have to pay a kind of toll to pass the road. There are a lot of shops on the area and a lot of tourists also. It is a nice view and it is possible to take very nice photos, but to see rice terraces it is better to go to Jatiluwih.

Beautiful Rice Terrace - Cafe Dewi is OK but has great view. We had a nice lunch at Cafe Dewi overlooking the rice terraces, the food was good not great and the prices ran about RP 50,000/dish. The view however, was beautiful. This is such an amazing place and if you have a driver, he should drive you all around this area to see the rice terraces and how amazing they all are.

Lovely Rice Fields. Dropped off by our driver. Spent about 40 mins walking the track, some areas can be a little slippery and difficult. A couple of sections are blocked off unless you pay a small fee to access. We saw enough without adventuring further.
Beautuful. Amazing & breath taking views!! It's pretty amazing this type of irrigation farming has never been succesfully duplicated in the entire world!

Great Vista of Rice Terrace. It was a rice terrace which is so popular to see in Bali.Well, it was not the only one in Bali but the most popular one I guess.Due to its popularity, it was super crowded.Everybody want to take a picture with a rice terrace as the background.The problem was there's not enough space for everybody to stand still and have a picture in one place because the path available for the tourists to walk basically was just some pile of soil which was used by the farmer as the barrier of the swaths.It was like just 50 centimeters wide.To go down there you need to travel down through steep, slippery, and muddy steps.Well, it was a great place to visit but maybe do it in the morning when it is less crowded.

Nice rice terrace in unud. I have been visiting this rice terrace was amazing view with palm trees inside. There is use traditional irigation sistem. This place need 30 minutes from ubud center and its arraund 1,5 from kuta. I paid donation for traditional brigde make with wood and bamboo. I need 20 minute walked down and walking up. Note there is very crodit lot of tourist come visiting this place.

Lunch on the hill. Had a very nice lunch at the rice terrace. We walked a little away from the crowded are and got to spend some quiet alone time. It is such a beautiful place and quite an amazing view.

Arrozal Ubud, Bali. The rice terrace is worth a visit. It is a beautiful place to see and walk. The sights are amazing. Some of the sellers ask donations in order to let people pass on the paths, wich is not a good thing.If you want to buy a coconut or another drink, the best place is with the girl in the photo. She is lovely and has a fair price. She has two baskets which you can use to take a foto for free (they are in the second foto).

Don't miss. What a wonderful place this is. The tenacity of the farmers who originally carved out these rice terraces is amazing. You can enjoy drinks and snacks in numerous cafes which feel like they are suspended over the valley and take in the glorious view

Earlier the better for the view. We went around noon time but still the scenery is very much appealing. A lot many people advises that one must go early - in fact go for sunrise!Carry enough fluids if you are going later during the day as it would be hot. Need a good pair of shoe if you wish to go down and explore the place.

Amazing views . Went to the rice fields on my own. I hired a driver for half day through my hotel that charged me around 600.000 rupiah for 6 hours which I only used 3 cause I only wanted to see the places closer to the hotel. It was quite hard to find the way to go down to start the walk. I got asked twice for donations to cross one bridge and go to the highest point. Paid only for one.Have to be careful if it was raining the day before as it gets quite slippery and a few people, including myself slipped and fell over.Definitely a must. Worth the view

Nice walk at sunset. Beautiful green landscape.We went for a walk at sunset because during day is too sunny, too hot and can get crowded. We have a baby so sunshade (or lack of it) was an important issue. If you have time, cross the bridge (just a donation) and walk around. Wear apropiate shoes, sneakers is a good choice. Flip flops is not.Don't forget sunscreen and mosquito repellent.
Stunning. Stunning views of the rice terrace! We came here as part of a day trip around Bali and this was definitely one of the highlights for us!

Awesome scenery, get there early. Our driver managed to get us to the Tegalalung terraces very early - around 7.30am. In fact we were so early, the booths to pay hadn't opened yet and we were free to roam around. As a landscape photographer it was greatly appreciated that there were no other tourists roaming around the fields. Is it worth it? Definitely - it's a very spectacular site and if you have the opportunity I would say go.

Go for sunrise! . beautiful however can get very touristy and crowded during the day, best and most beautiful time is at sunrise. if you take a car you have to pay 5000 per person for parking. which equals about .50 cents.
beautifull. A great view for the rice fields, mainly in february it is the green season in Bali! Just enjoy the scenery and the wonderfull and patient work of farmers

Better in the social media photos. This place did not live up to the expectations one has after seeing all the pretty photos of the rice fields. The town this place is located is remote and run down. Unless you're a seasoned hiker or bush walker, I strongly suggest NOT walking down and through the rice fields. I made the mistake of thinking that you needed to walk in the fields to get good photos. There's a Cafe along the main strip where you will get the best views/photos of the fields.
Definitely a good place for kids!!!. Kid definitely love this place, especially city kids!... This rice terrace is incredibly beautiful..

Spectacular scenery. The greenery is so vibrant and perfect for photo backdrops, like a postcard.There are many paths to follow once you step down from the street and the little resting cafe areas.Take a water bottle and just follow your nose around the narrow rice field tracks. Some areas are very very steep. But it just depends on how deep you want to go.Once youre down in the fields its a very peaceful place.

Nice, but overcrowded. It is a pretty view but it can get overcrowded and difficult to take a pic for that reason. If you have a guide you can tell him/her to take you to other rice teraces just as nice
Beautiful Rice Field Visit in Ubud. One of the best and most well-maintained rice fields in Ubud. A rich and vibrant green landscape will miles to walk through.
Beautiful. A little touristy, but still can't beat the views. Good place to stop for a coffee or lunch if out in the area sightseeing.

Beautiful. I was really looking forward to visiting the rice terrace but was left disappointed after my visit. The rice terrace is stunning but as we drove in and realised that it was just another tourist trap with vendors everywhere we left after just a few minutes. I expected to visit a natural place. It is beautiful to see once you walk through all the vendors set up alongside it, but for me it was ruined.

O.k. if you desperately want to photo a paddy.. I really wanted to see a terraced rice field so it was worth the trip. It was crawling with tourists though. There are some shops selling lovely hand crocheted bed spreads and clothes. I was watching a lady make a top and selling it sooooo cheap. It didn't fit and she kept lowering the price. I should have bought it anyway and given it to someone back home. I felt sorry for her such a lot of work.

BEAUTIFUL!!!. What a sight! The rice terraces are incredibly beautiful and the pictures don't do them justice. The area has a lovely 'peaceful' feel to it. Even walking around the market stalls behind the rice terraces is a fun experience. And that view!!! You would never get sick of it!

Beauty in the crowd of tourists. It is a stunning terraces but it has becoming so commercial and always be packed with traffic and vendors. But if you smart enough to get here early in the morning like 8 am or 9 am would be the best time to enjoy its beauty on your own.

Nice from above . Great to see the rice fields from
Above! It's a bit crowded with
(Other) tourist.
Be carful when you like to see the fields from below! The "steps" are slippery.
If you go u bit more up north, you will find other rice fields as well

A walk in the beautiful rice terrance. The road leading to the rice terrance is very crowded with shops and restaurants. You can either just take a few steps down and get a nice view of the terrance or take a 45 minutes trek all the way to the other side of the terrance and get many good views in the process.We did the latter and enjoyed this trek. There is a small shop selling juices, water etc. at the terrance.The views of the terraced rice fields is great.

Sunrise walks here are life-changing. I felt like I was in a movie. My husband and I came here at like 7 in the morning and had the whole place to ourselves. Apparently some people paid to do a tour? We went in for free, without speaking to anyone. In and out in about an hour...WEAR SNEAKERS. Enjoy :)
Rice Terrace. I enjoyed walking the rice terrace and seeing the locals work the fields. I learned a lot during my walking tour

Beautiful . Really beautiful. That's all I can say really Definitely worth a trip. The terraces were lovely & green & you could walk around taking photos & cross the bridge to the other side for a donation. You don't even have to donate if you just stay on the side nearest the road. The little shops that are on the road are pretty cute selling standard tourist tat but some of the things are pretty nice.

A good stop over after Kintamani tour. This place is often visited on way to Kintamani volcano mountain or on your way back from there. Rice fields and more rice paddies is what this place is all about, quite scenic for a few selfies to add to your photo journal. Heaven for painters and photographersApparently they have a traditional balinese irrigation system called Subak for these rice paddies and quite interesting stories about the guy who invented it in early 8th century. There are a lot of food joints available and a few local shops if you wish to shop as well.All in all a place to visit if you have taken the Kintamani tour or the Ubud local village tour.
Long way to go. Its a long way to go in lots of traffic to see rice fields with tourists walking all over the tracks. Could have lived without it.

Tourist trap!. Visually stunning if you can look past all the tourist shops and restaurants. How to spoil what should be a natural place to visit!! I felt let down and our visit was brief. There has to be other less touristy rice paddies in Bali!!

Very photogenic place. A very beautiful place to visit. The whole area is so exotic and so green. Nevertheless the area has become somewhat commercialised. Since the terrace belongs to private owners they usually ask you for donation when you trespass their property. If you try to trek a decent distance you will realise you have to walk across a couple of different properties. Some farmers will pose for you then ask for donation. Also the rice field is slippery so thongs are not so good but then you don't want to ruin your runners with mud either.

Breath taking . This is a definite must in Bali, it's hard to believe how amazing this is until you see it with your own eyes. The only disappointment for me was not exploring out in the fields as it was so hot

offer so much more than ricefields. come here to explore, not to take pictures. if u come here just to snap up some pictures, it will take u 10 mins max. but please, go for a walk, hire a local guide and explore. it was possily the best part of my trip. walking around terraces, climbing, seeing local lives. it was so amazing. try to walk around to the next villages as well. literally there was no other tourists, except me and the local guide. awesome

Picture perfect. Great spot to stop for photos and take in the beautiful rice terraces! Even if you don't want to walk down in to the terraces themselves you can enjoy the view from the top! I would highly recommend!
Good view! . I like it because you can go every where and can look over all the riecfiels as far as you can. There are a alot restaurants and the entry fee is quite cheap (2000 IDR). :)

A Good Place to Start.... If you want a quick visit to a rice terrace then this is the place to start. This terrace is beautiful (and the entrance fee is cheap) but it is crowded and the path down is rustic. There are much better rice terraces to see on Bali Island but this is a good start, or if you have little time etc.

Postcard view, perfect for taking pictures. A "must visit" place for taking pictures, very green, a bit overcrowded, but still worth it. If you have knowledgeable guide he would show you excellent café with the view of only terraces, not people.

Nice nice nice. We booked a trip with a private driver he drove us as well to the rise terrace the view is so beautiful tipical balinesian rise fields you can sit there on a nice restaurant eat local good food and enjoy the view

Beautiful, but a shakedown!. Lovely to see. but be aware when walking around the whole rice terrace you will be expected to pay people to pass. On a skinny little track we had our path blocked by a man and told to walk all the way back around if we didn't pay. I understand they have no money and live poorly but there must be a better way instead of intimidation of tourists. My recommendation would be to stand at top and look around. It is beautiful but plenty of beautiful rice terraces Bali.
Small. It's small and to many tourist. I have seen much better rice terraces at other places. If you are short of time; no worries about skipping

Too touristic. On the way back from the volcano we crossed plenty of pretty, wide, authentic rice fields with actual farmers. Unfortunately our driver insisted not to stop and go to Tegalalang. It worth going few kilometers more North to have an real view.

Not worth the trip. This so called attraction is a commercial and tourist exercise. I notice most tourists are there on route to other destinations. To enter the area, each visitor is imposed 10,000 rupiah. The area is really crowded with tourist rental cars and coaches. The road is lined with stores that sell cheap and tacky souvenirs. The attraction which is the terraced rice fields is only a small area. The paths going down to the rice fields is crowded and there is a risk of falling down if one is not careful. We didn't bother to go down to the rice fields because of this risk. Moreover to get to each patch of rice field, one has to pay an additional fee to the owner of the respective rice field. Its a waste of your time going there. You are better off going to the vast terraced rice fields in Vietnam or Myanmar.

What a view!!!!. Visited Nov 2014.We hired a driver to take us here after reading so much about the terraces before we arrived and it really did not disappoint!! Actually if anything the pictures don't do it justice, it's an amazing sight!We visited at lunchtime as we were stuck for time but I would recommend visiting either early morning or late afternoon as firstly because it's obviously so open it's incredibly hot! And secondly it was soooo busy the day we visited, it was impossible to even find a gap to take a picture at one point. The only reason I gave this a 4 out of 5 is if I'm honest I hated the area and road looking over the terraces, in the end I was glad we only had about an hour spare. Like with many parts of Bali, Ubud in particular it just felt unsafe. I know it's normal in Bali for locals to 'claim' ownership of the tourist attractions and charge people to visit them (which I did without complaint every time) but for me it ruins the experience slightly. If they weren't so aggressive and forceful towards people who are there to appreciate the beauty of their island they would stay longer and spend more. whereas following people for 10 minutes because they didn't 'donate' 1,000,000 rupiah like the person before you (which is lies btw as we spoke to the elderly couple in front of us and they terrified after being followed too!) at the THIRD donation checkpoint is ruining it for themselves and everyone else.
So Beautiful!. One of the most beautiful places in Bali. However, I visited there after a rainy night. It was all so slippery! I almost fell a few times. But clicked some nice pictures.
Beautiful. A must see. This rice field view is better than others i visit . I am not saying is the best , only the best I saw .
Stunning Scenery. Absolutely worth going. The rice field terrace is just stunningly beautiful and don't forget to go down to the bottom of the forest. Give it more time.

Cool! . Must visit! Do it on your own and rent on motorcycle (easy with google maps) Very Nice to walk around. Pay Attention to the people who are asking "free" donations... There's nothing wrong with paying a few IDR for this but not over and over again. So don't do this. Walk futher on... Don't let this interrupt your visit. Good luck!
Breathtaking Views. Wounderful sight. Great to have had the privilege to view this beautiful scenery. The walk to the rice field was an exciting experience. First time for me and will do it again.

Interesting!. The best way to visit Tegalalang Rice Terrace is by a short deviation from the main road that goes from Ubud to Kintamani. If you don't intend to walk through the rice terrace there is no need to stop and pay the tolls just to take a photo. You can take the same photos from your car while passing through. Remember Bali is full of rice terraces that are as beautiful and less touristic!

Con Artists have Successfully Ruined this Beautiful Place. This rice terrace is a very pretty view, but do not be fooled by the innocent vibe it portrays. You will need to pay 10 000 IDR to enter the grounds (not bad at all) however when you begin to walk down into the terrace, this is where the ugly truth is shown. You will enjoy the small huts along the trail with people asking for donations. Sorry let me rephrase that, there will be locals who block your path and demand a mandatory donation. This money is meant to sponsor the "bridges" that they have built for you to walk. Well let me tell you now that laying down a 2 ft 2x4 plank is not worth money. I only had a 10000 note in my wallet so I gave it to the lady expecting to pass. She then replied "not enough. More" in disgust I showed her my empty wallet. She then moved out of the way as she yelled at me in what I presume were derogatory words. Towards the top of the terrace was yet another hut. I explained to the man that I had donated all my money down below. "Different family different donation" he replied. He refused to let me pass as I showed him my empty wallet. This guy was the turning point for most visitors. Even those with money were displeased and left. I would not be offended to donate to people who have done some work or if the cause had merit, but this was obviously a scam for tourists. Further more it is not a donation when you are forced to pay. I have spoken to many people since and they are appalled by this behavior. If you want to see rice terraces without the scams. There are plenty more in Vietnam and other parts of SE Asia.
it was amazing. the view was spectacular but you need to wear sneakers not flipflops like we did :D would definitely recommend paying it a visit.
Beautiful view. Beautiful view, you can walk on it, take a nice pictures, easy accessibility, there are souvenirs stores and restaurants.
lovely!. you have to visit this place. beautiful scenery! take photos, go through the rice field (careful with your step, as the ground can be slippery). it's good, really

Very crowded. This is a small area of terraced rice fields that has been over run by touts and tourists. If you visit early enough you may enjoy it but we stayed about 10 minutes and got the hell out of there.
Beautiful site to see . The irrigation systems they've made by hand there are extraordinary. They also have nice a nice platform to take pictures hat says love Bali and has an old rusted bike.

Beautiful view. Get here early, weather is cooler and only a few tourists. We got here by scooter at 8am, not many tourist at that time, we walked around the rice paddy field, this place is picturistic. It is about 30mins on scooter from Ubud. Lots of cafes in the area, but they only open at 10am. We left this place around 9:30, quite a few tourist buses were arriving. Get here early is my tip! Enjoy.

Beautiful place. Very beautiful place. You can go walking into the fields. Little bit hard "road" to walk and little bit muddy. Dont go with young children. You hhave to pay if you want to go all the way. And i thinks the women made up the prices. Note said that it is donation and there were two girls and the women said to them that it is like 30 000 rupiah. There was lot of garbages in the fields which was really sad. Also there were kids selling post cards and asking money which wasn't so nice...But if you are staying in ubud go there. Parking places were packed up.

Beautiful typical rice terraces!. Visit these as early in the morning as possible. ANytime after 10.30am they become overrun with tourists. If you are early the restaurants will not be open but it's worth it to be able to walk down into the terrances almost alone and with no one hassling you to visit their shop along the road!
Nice view. Nice view, just next to the main street. Try to come early so you can enjoy the view with less people around you. Try to walk at the terrace and have drinks facing the terrace at the cafe
Monkey Forest Ubud. Good time had by all at the Monkey Forest in Ubud. The forest is really nice to walk round and the monkeys are plentiful. If you have a banana you'll make lots of friends quickly.

Another rice terrace - and stunning!. The rice farmers work so hard but for the view we get as tourists it is well worth it. A slightly smaller version than the UNESCO heritage site but wander down to the paddies and see them up close. A must see in Bali and add it to your itinerary

Picturesque!!!!. Visited this place on our way back from Kintamani & its really Picturesque!!!!Nothing spectacular but well worth a visit.Its a small area & you will find lots of shops selling different products.

Eat, Play, Love. Visited the filming site of "Eat, Play, Love", the famous Tegalalang Rice Terrace. Sat and dine at one of the restaurants with perfect view of the terrace. Food was acceptable but a great viewing gallery. Some tables do not have the view.Restaurant has WIFI but very slow. Meals are inexpensive. Waitress and waiters were polite. Truly Indonesian hospitality. Lots of Caucasian, Japanese, Korean tourists.

Breathtaking landscape. The views of the rice terrace is absolutely breathtaking. You can see it from the road. Wear shoes as there is a fair bit of off road hiking to do to get to the other side. Some climbs are rather steep so be ready. Can be really hot towards noon so water is essential too. There are also 2 bridges with donation booths that you may feel compelled to donate by the locals there. We did, but it's up to you.
Beautiful!. Beautiful sight to see! And great photo opportunities, would definitely recommend . We stayed nearby, and walked past this a few times during out stay, and it never got boring.
Beautiful view and very accessible. These functioning and very picturesque rice terraces are very accessible as the main road passes right by them. You can stop for pictures and lovely fresh coconut.

Well worth a visit. One of the places you want to visit when in Bali. Beautiful as long as your expectations are reasonable. Loved the colourful display of people and wares on my way down to the rice terrace. Talk to the locals and ask them if you may take a picture, they were friendly and very engaging

expecting more. I was expecting a bit more from this heavily marketed tourist area, and for the cost to get here by auto. The view is really nice, smaller than the rice terraces to the west of Ubud, but I found the presence of trinket sellers right there to be annoying. Kind of spoils the experience. Walking along the terraces is pretty easy although it was also annoying to pay to cross a bridge because a local woman said I had too. She wasn't an official anything and when I initially paid her, she said it wasn't enough, typical. I decided not to pay her and went around the terrace a different way. Kind of unbecoming to demand payment for crossing a ten step bridge. It's not a money issue, it's just spoils nature to be handing out money, left and right, to take a simple hike. Every culture has their village idiot, I suppose. I would recommend going to see the bigger rice terraces to the west, less touristy, or even just going on the rice treks around Ubud, which in my opinion, were a lot better views and not many other tourists.

Brief view of a terraced rice paddy. Quite a pretty little micro shot of a terraced rice paddy. The pathway was pretty decent, with lots of stairs. Due to an ongoing ankle injury, I stopped at the midway and enjoyed the opportunity to shoot macro exposures on tiny orchids and yellow butterflies as well as the lizards and other plants.

Disappointing. My visit to Tegalalang Rice Terrace was disappointing not because it was not beautiful but because a great part of the terraces was pretty much destroyed both by locals and tourists. On the one side, the locals have built up cafes and photo place structures on the terraces. On the other side, the tourists are walking all around the rice paddies which destroys them. Also, be aware that it is full of locals standing on "checkpoints" and not letting you go until you pay a "donation"... For me, it was unpleasant.

Could have been better.. Was disappointed about this one. Firstly you payed once entering the rice terrace, then when walking down in the valley we had to "donate" 3 times when walking down there. The whole thing felt like a money grab operation.Would have liked to see that you perhaps payed a larger entrance fee that the farmers could share. Then you would not need to get you wallet out every 10 min, and instead enjoy the scenery.Other then that it was a nice walk down the valley, hopefully they will improve the path walking down. I had good shoes on, but saw a lot of people in "flipp flops" struggling.
Don't miss Tegalalang Rice Terrace. Absolutely amazing! Couldn't stop taking pictures. Have a walk around, up and down the terraces and end up with an ice-cream or a cool beer enjoying this paradise.

The rice terraces to see near Ubud. Seeing the rice terraces was no.1 on our list before coming to Bali :) these are closest to Ubud and definitely super beautiful. There were also nice places to eat offering the view (looked delicious, but we didn't have time). If you don't get the chance to go to Jatiluwih rice terraces (larger), do not miss Tegalalang ones.

Worth a few hours. Stunning views, although much smaller than I expected after having visited Sapa in Vietnam. On a positive note, provides much greater access to explore/walk the fields than Sapa. One of the most memorable days of our Bali visit.
Good to see. Nice to see and take a few pictures. Nothing else is around there. All taxis and tours stop around there for tourists. Best to go in the morning.
Trade mark of Bali. New experience to walk on the margin of rice terrace. Very nice nature, very exotic. Take your time, stop and breath.

A must see when in Bali. me and my wife had a very nice experience we couldn't bother to walk down to the rice fields and opted to sit in one of the Cafe's on the cliff and look down on the fields whihc are amazing.
Rice Walk. Stunning view there and everything was so calming. The fields are just beautiful and leave you speecheless

Must visit!!!. We visited the rice terraces in December at the time of the monsoon but it was simply unreal. You need to be in good condition physically if you want to walk through the fields in such humidity. I truly loved the place. You're close to the nature and it was like fifty shades of green :) take your time and relax there because it's such a peaceful place. I can't wait to go back!!!
Must visit when in Ubud. Absolutely amazng and picturesque. Made a lot of nice photos - there are views to die for. Do go with comfortable shoes (not slippers). :)

spot you must visit. beautiful spot you should visit if you are going to Ubud . one of the famous place in bali. make sure you take photos as many as you can because it is amazing memory. and don't forget to apply sunblock if it is sunny day because if not you will get burn :D
Great views. This is a good place to stop off at on a day trip, but not if this is all yo do... combine it with other local attractions

Overrated. Our experience involved being ferried to a coffee shop from where we admired the rice fields, but at the end of the day it was not worth the hour+ detour whereas we could have seen another temple which seemed prettier.

Amazing , no tour needed. I went there few years ago with a tour and again this time by myself.Easy access from ubud town , 15mins by car , just get some taxi , will cost you 20000rp max ( Aud $20) for the car not by person and just couples of hours if you having a drink there.Or just rent a bike , pretty nice ride from the town.Nice walk , you also can choose to buy a ticket ( 10000rp from memory , Aud $1 ) to go everywhere on a field but don't really need it for a quick view.Or if not book a day trip with a driver from Kuta it will cost you 300/400k rp ( around $30/40) with stop at some shopping area and restaurant with a stunning view , I can't remember the name unfortunately but sure every tourists informations will help you out.

Sad farming activity. These rice terraces are found in abundance in Indonesia. But in Ubud sadly it is a dying farming activity. Glad to have met a former farmer who now has a restaurant. Her friendly chat with us explaining the current state of affairs in the area. Youngsters moving to big cities to work. Totally uninterested in farming as souvenir shops have a thriving business. Tourists are attracted by the rice terraces and mainly visit for this reason. The rice terraces is supported by tourism. A brilliant idea!

Great natur spot in a village. Hey thereEventho it is very close to the village, it has ita own charm. the restaurants on the one side on the hill are fantastic to watch the fields. the walk into the fields are also really nice, yet the locals try to male their money with several photo booths. its their living so might as well wanna stop every now and them for a funny picture and move on.

Needs effort to go down the rice terrace. It was a great experience in tegalalang rice terrace. I was there with my 4 years son. It needed more effort to go down with natural stairs but it worth with the very nice view.

Don't miss this if you visit Ubud. Visited one afternoon while staying near to Ubud. A spectacular view, and our first real experience of rice terraces. You can walk right down in to and through the terraces, quite hard work in places as it's quite steep and slippery. A few of the farmers have set up some 'gates' where they take some money from you to walk through their fields (which is fair enough). They get you on the way back as well, so make sure you take plenty of small notes with you.

absolutely beautiful. The rice terraces were really beautiful, very picturesque and scenic. I only have an issue with the people who constantly accost you to buy stuff the moment you stop to take pictures.
Magnificent.. Most beautiful views in Bali (not taking into account the underwater world). It is stunningly beautiful and a must-see location.

Perfect for short easy hike.. Beautiful place, Green galore! Restaurants right outside the terrace, fun alone or with the family. I was surprised how quickly i was able to hike the terraces, If your nice to the locals they will show you different paths. You can take pictures with some of the workers, although small donations are expected in certain areas so bring change. No entrance fee.

Too crowded!. Yes, the rice terraces are beautiful. However, this place is too touristy and too crowded. The area is not very big and you cannot do much of a walk around. Go see some rice fields in a more rural area instead!

DEWI CAFE: come for the views and eat light. The food was marginal, but the views of the rice paddies was incredible. I came for breakfast after hiking up Mount Batur and ordered an omelet with coffee. The coffee was watery and the omelet slightly over cooked. Overall, come for the views and order light.

Just stunning. We organised a driver from our hotel & this was well worth it as he took us on a path we had previously not walked, well worth the effort but not for the unfit. Lots of stunning photo opportunities
Nice to for a photo stop. Nice for a photo stop on a nice day, a little bit annoyed about having to pay to park on the road but only a minor thing.
beautiful place!. went as part of a day tour of sights! beautiful terraces and wonderful to get walk around them but very touristy and rather busy! still worth a visit.

Wonderful rice fields. We visited the rice fields for 2 hours. The views are wonderful and the place has a certain serenity.
However take a few bucks with you for "donations"
Rice field. Beautiful scenery but too crowded.. Better come early .. You can have breakfast at cafe2 with rice field view.. The field not as wide as I expected..

Beautiful scenery but a bit too commercialized. This place looks as beautiful in real (or even more) than it does on pictures. We went there on a hot sunny day and walked down and up the hills to the other side of the terrace and enjoyed the beautiful scenery of this lush place. While hiking up the steps of the terrace, you will come across a few booths set up by locals who ask for “donations”. Oh well, as per my understanding, donations should be voluntary and not enforced payments, right?! They don’t ask for much. Around IDR 1,000 (less than $1 USD) is required to be donated in order to continue your hike up the terrace. One visitor behind us did not have any change with him, so these “enforcement officers” did not let him pass and he had to end his hike at that point, which was not nice of them (the locals…). After all, pretty much every visitor who passes that point donated, so they should have just let one slip through without paying, since they already made a lot of money that day – box of money was full (around noon when we arrived). A few steps further up during our hike, there was a local lady, “dressed up” as a rice field farmer to pose for pictures with tourists. To do so, another donation was required.I don’t mind donating money to locals, especially since we were visiting the grounds that they had been keeping so beautifully for visitors to enjoy, but to demand donations to enjoy the beauty of a country/location is too commercialized in my opinion. However, we still enjoyed visiting the Tegalalang Rice Terraces very much and would still recommend a visit.
Simple beautiful!. Spectacular views, a must do while in Ubud!!Photo op at every turn, nature, history and a peek into local ways!Great spot to explore.Must bring a camera!

Stunning. A must see :-)Word to the wise- our driver told us there was a 2000 per person entry fee here, we quickly discovered we were paying for his parking while we went in.Absolutley beautiful, lots of very steep inclines which can be quite slippery, numerous locals requesting donations along the way, we have a small amount to each ( about 10,000I think) some were quite persistent and wanted 100,000 in one case I had to yell no at top of my voice and shove our money at him as he was becoming abit too intimidating so best be prepared for this.Definitely worth a visit, stunning scenery, you can get stuck just staring out into the terraces. We went mid afternoon & there weren't too many tourists. Numerous cafes lining the tops of the terrace to sit for a refreshing drink as you exit with very reasonable prices.Sensible shoes water & small notes are my recommendations. Definately not for the elderly or anyone with bad knees/ hips etc.

Breathtakingly beautiful. I put this destination on our tour list think meh it's just a rice terrace, a quick pic and we will leave. But it was awesome!! It was beautiful. Stunning even. Unfortunately it was raining lightly but it was really spectacular to see. There is a tiny little shop to the right as well and the lady in there is selling things soooooooooooooo much cheaper than in kuta or seminyak. Highly recommended.

Beautiful rice terrace. It was amazing to see how the Indonesian people have managed the mountain and hill slopes to their advantage. They have converted these into multi level mini farms growing rice, herbs and vegetables on these. Amazing and beautiful art of agriculture for micro farming. Lovely scenery of rice fields with palm, banana trees in the background. A bit slippery slopes if you visit the narrow borders of these farms.

Beautiful place, but with persistent locals. Beautiful place, definitely worth visiting to see their local agricultural practices. Locals can be a little persistent with donations which we gladly donated, except for one whom was rude (probably due to the couple earlier who didn't donate), and pestered us for a donation. Even grabbed the wife's hands and only let go when I grabbed him back. Very rude and uncivilised.Nevertheless, the rest were very friendly. Overall, a good trip.

Very Nice Rice terrace!. It's a very nice rice terrace with lots of green steep terrace and reminds you a bit of Lord of the Rings Hobbitown.Anyway, there will be a few places where they ask for "Donations" and this is fine by me sence i already hide all my big money and only had 2.000 or 5.000 bills in my wallet.Most places you are allowed to donate whatever you want, but a few places demand like 10.000 per person. When you encounter them just but in a 2.000 and walk past them, if they start to insist, just speak some hibbo pibbo languish and pretend you don't understand.For me donations should be voluntarily, and not like "You have to donate 10.000!"But it's really a large nice terrace, a bit touristy but good! On the way down and up there are lots of places that offers food and drinks.
BEAUTIFUL RICE TERRACE. Gorgeous looking rice field terrace nestled in the middle of various tourist businesses. Good place to take scenic pictures.

Touristy but beautiful. We stopped to view and wander...was beautiful to take it in but really touristy. We did enjoy a meal in the shade overlooking the rice terraces,,,but had many vendors to deflect.

Good view. Overall good view, but nothing much compared to nice places in india.There are plenty of shopping and food options available, but relatively expensive. Try your luck, bargain to get a good deal.

Splendid view! Fresh air!. Very nice view. There are many restaurants that can exceptionally satisfy your vision and taste buds. Regretted that I miss out the walk along the padi trek due to shortage of time.
A bit overrated. It's a nice view, but to be honest there are much nicer places in Bali. Also, it was raining when I visited so the path was very slippery that I decided not to continue my descend.

a long walk. these rice terrace is very nice but also muddy along the way you have to give a donation for al there hard work that they have put in to making the rice terrace you can also buy a card or take a photo

Beautiful but covered in garbage . This spot may once have been beautiful (and still is in many ways) but really is covered in garbage. Combined with the hassling from vendors and frequent demands for payment as you walk through definitely detracted from the experience. Not a bad stop as part of a tour, but there are more beautiful fields elsewhere in Bali.

Incredible views all around. This was one of the best experiences I have had on holidays throughout the world. You feel like you are in the heart of Bali and the views are amazing. I chose to walk in the fields and spent about an hour walking (with million of other tourists) but it was a great experience and even though it was busy the atmosphere was still calm and relaxed. The paths down and up are narrow and you need to be careful with your footing and where you are walking. A lot of the time it is single file only. The photos you get to take home are breath taking. I am so glad I took the time and walked. It can be hot walking so go early morning if you can. You are asked for a donation but it is minimal. This is a one of those bucket list places :) No regrets making the trip out there. Would tell everyone to give themselves this experience.

Great Experience. What a beautiful sight! The rice terraces are definitely worth the visit. I didn't expect to actually be able to walk along the terraces so I suggest you wear shoes that you can climb and jump in (some areas require a small leap) and that have a little traction since the dry areas can have loose dirt that can cause you to slide. The place wasn't overrun with tourists, though there were quite a few. I don't know if it's the time of day that we got there, which was around 11 am. We walked quite a ways across the terraces - we were wearing flip flops so we had to find our footing well and I ended up with a muddy foot and muddy, slippery slipper when I made a jump and landed in some mud. Also, don't carry a tonne of luggage with you - who wants to miss out on an opportunity because they have too much stuff with them? I took off 1 star because of the man who refused to let us pass after we almost got to the top of the other side. There was a sign asking for donations to help maintain the bridge and to me a donation is not mandatory but he literally blocked our way and wouldn't let us pass. He wasn't verbally aggressive or anything but you can't physically move an old man out of your way. A couple happened to be there at the same time and they had already paid and gone to the other side but wanted to turn around and go up again and the man was insisting that they had to pay again to pass. I didn't like the pressure tactics so I remove 1 star. Be prepared to pay (I don't know how much, I didn't ask) if you want to make it all the way to the other side. Even so, this was a beautiful experience because the rice terraces are simply beautiful to behold!

Fantastic views. Went here on part of our tour around Bali wow the views are amazing and to actually see the rice fields and how they were built into the mountains looks fantastic what a beautiful place definitely worth a visit

Beautiful. We spent ages trying to find these fields. We kept bumping into the same man who was pointing us in the right direction and eventually when we reached them he was there again. He offered to give us a tour for a good price snd at first i was a little put off by the fact that he had followed us but he took us to places we wouldnt have gone on our own and told us lots of information. I definitely reccommend getting a guide to take you round because you see more and they know the best ways to go around all the fields.

Famous Ubud rice terrace. Scenic place.... Ubud has another beautiful scenic place for nature lovers... the famous rice terrace of Ubud.It is exceptionally glamorous and beautiful in the mornings at about 8am~9am where the sun rays cut through the surrounding trees into the rice terrace. An awesome sight and a memorable view to take away from Bali.
Not very special. In Bali there are much nicer rice terraces than this one. Take a drive to the north or walk through the rice terraces around Ubud.

Clearly worth a visit!. Take a motorbike and cross it from North of Ubud towards Tirta Empul & Gunung Kawi sites! Get away from busy Ubud and enjoy the rice terraces parading around you! We did not see any tourists on the way the day we drove around, it was absolutely awesome! I strongly recommend the trip!

Wonderful and post card like scenery. . It's nice to take pictures and over all it's free. Doesn't need any entry tickets. It's on the way to mount Batur. So you can stop on your way back and spend some time there.
Beautiful place!. Ubud is so busy that this terrace is music for the ears. To have a walk there is nice, just ignore the salesmen. Best is to visit in the evening before the sunset!

Beautiful place!. Ubud is so busy that this terrace is music for the ears. To have a walk there is nice, just ignore the salesmen.
Best is to visit in the evening before the sunset!

Off the Beaten Track and beautiful scenery.. We visited this beautiful area with a guided tour from Bali Traditional Tours.Our private tour for two persons included a professional guide and a very nice vehicle. The driver picked us up at our hotel in Ubud at 9 a.m. and we did not return until about 5:30 p.m. The total cost was about 70 US dollars. Was well worth it.
