The guide was proficient in English and very knowledgeable and was a very good driver. Do not try to drive to this place. It is fairly isolated and far into a rural area. The rice fields are incredibly scenic... quintessential Bali. Several good restaurants have popped up right along the road overlooking the rice fields. We ate very well for a very reasonable cost. Our "Bedugul" tour included other stops per our request and notably also included a trip to a beautiful lakefront temple and park in northern Bali.

Not ideal for small kids. We took our five and two year old. While it was beautiful, going into the actual terraces proved to be a challenge with our two year old. It's quite a hike and we ended up carrying him most of the way. Several families that own the terraces charge a "donation" to continue. If you decide to go and don't want to hike, I suggest just stopping, taking a picture and doing something else.

Picturesque. This is well worth the visit. It can be a bit strenuous, if you are wanting to go all the way to the floor of the valley.The walkways are quite steep and narrow. There are some interesting market stalls for the avid shopper ,the prices are very reasonable. Great opportunities for the amateur photographer.
Beautiful. Nice place for a quick rest, beautiful and relaxing. Can even take a walk around the terraces and take pictures. Worth at stop by if you happened to be in ubud.

Good if you want a sneak peek, but there are better in Bali!. This is a very hustle and bustle area. The rice terrace is quite pretty, just make sure when you are organising a trip that you check with the tour operator/driver that the rice hasn't just been planted otherwise it's pretty bland; not lush and green as you see in the photos.If you're looking for something to do, this is not a bad 1/2 day trip or so, however in this area the Rice Terrace is far spread and many other plants such as Palm Trees etc, interrupt the view. If you really want to see the beauty of the Rice Terrace, I highly suggest Jatiluwih Green Land, it's about a 2.5 hr drive north of Seminyak. Well and truly worth the drive.
Unbelievable . Better than the photos. A bit of hiking though. Go during the morning that it is cool. Have small notes with you because many people ask for donation in the middle of the fields tolls
Beautiful. Did not have the time to go down the trek, but it was worth the trip. Just a short drive from Ubud, about 30 mins. Beautiful :)

Beautiful. This is my second time going here and it's still beautiful defiantly not something you can see back home. Only down side is the horrible stairs to get down from the road not good for someone with a bad back or unsteady on the feet. But can still see the fabulous view from the road side etc
Incredible Beauty!. This place is stunning. You can take a short or a long walk through the ricefields to soak up the beauty of this stunning place

Beautufuk. This is a must see in Ubud. You can go as part of a day trip but we just paid a driver to take us there and back from Ubud central. Beautiful views. Can walk through the rice fields as well which is awesome. Take some money for the markets surrounding. The people here are really lovely.
Nice view. A good place to take a walk around the padi field with kids. Carry cash, because almost all of the businesses there won't take card.

Its rice. I'm an Indonesian, and I've seen rice fields all my live. So when a bunch of my Dutch friends visits bali and told me (to be exact, forced me with near colonial Dutch brutality) to come with them and see the rice fields, I already know its gonna be a GOOODD trip.And so i went, half drunk and half effected by not so legal substances. Now I'm going to review based on two different views:The dutch truly enjoyed the view, they go up and down the rice fields, took photos with the local, hang out and have a nice coffee in some of the cafe located on the edge of the rice fields, as if they reminisce the good ol' VOC colonial days. To them its just good nature, good landscape, something new apart from all the tulips and windmills that they used to see.The Indonesians, we expect more from all the hype. But it only brings what is promised by them, rice fields. And more rice fields. Albeit, the new found popularity of this place had become a new source of income for the locals, as now they can sell many arts and craft to the Bule in higher price. We went back, the Dutch still mesmerized by the view and the Indonesian nearly sober.All in all a very nice scenic place to visit, especially if you're not from Asia or you've been living in the city all your life.

Beautiful rice terrace. It was a beautiful rice terrace, but a pity it was raining on the day we were there.Many tourists stop to take photos just slightly below the roads and not head down. However, if you are the adventurous kind, you can take a walk but be prepared to be approached by young locals who would ask to be your guide (they will say they need the money for their school fees and sell you post cards as well). Be in comfortable shoes and not slippers as the slopes may get slippery, especially on rainy days. We saw a couple of people with abrasions on their knees while trying to clear the "obstacles".There are a number of cafes as well overlooking the rice terrace. We chose the easier option of getting a drink (around 30-40k) and banana crepe (around 25k rupiah) in Teras Padi Cafe. You can get a good view of the entire terrace. Not too expensive for such a view.We heard from the waiter there are stairs by the side of the rice terrace which may be easier to access the lower levels.. Didnt get a chance to try it though. You may want to check it out if you visit.

A must see!. One of the most beautiful things I have had the privilege to see in my life. The view is awe-inspiring. There is a lovely little restaurant located at the side of the terraces that offers a halal buffet and a lovely views of the terraces.
Amazing rice terrace!. It will take your breath away! Too bad we couldn't trek with our young girl, we shall be back in future!
Breathtaking Terraces. Lovely sights however trekking down from the top is quite dangerous as there's no actual pathway, just rocks - it's worth it though, you really do get a nice view.

Beautiful views. Amazing views! Definitely worth going to. It cost us 10,000 rupi but you have women & children trying to get more of your money the whole way. I would also suggest you wear athletic shoes and pants. Mosquitos are bad. I would recommend that they remove the women & children begging.
Great experience. If you are in Bali. You should see here. You can hire motorbike and get there easily. People are nice, you can spend 30 min but definitely worth do it.
Bloody nice view. Enjoy the view and in your way back buy some handcarts directly from locals in best prices. It worths to visit.Tip: try it on early morning and enjoy the walk.
Spectacular. What an amazing view of the rice fields. It was very hot the day we visited so would recommend going early in the morning if you want to trek the rice fields.

Not bad for 1st timer. I've been to Bali many times but it was my first time visiting the Tegalalang Rice Terrace. The view is beautiful and the paddy field is well maintained. As you have read in other reviews, there is an entrance fee to this place and if you would like to go to the other side of the paddy field hill, you may require to donate some money for the upkeep. In my opinion, there are other places that has more nicer paddy field view.
Just to say you've been there. It's fine, quintessential Bali, but it's no better than what you can see driving around. I wouldn't bother getting out
Amazing to just stroll across. These rice fields are along a road and are really lovely to take a walk through. However each section has a toll fee which needs to be paid.

Rice fields with terrace cultivation. You may not need to walk it down and up in the sun as its viewable from all angles. Unless you need to sweat t out. Drive past and stop from main road to view and take some pictures. Many cafes on the ridge to rest ad catch green air.

Totally Worth The Trek and Small Donation To The Locals. The meandering paths can be accessed from the street just above the fields. You'll be asked for a very small 10K (about $1) donation per person, and it's well worth it. If you take a few pictures with the hard working locals in the fields, expect to pay a few thousand more. The pics you take here will be the ones your friends most ooh and ahh over on your social media accounts. If you go during the wet season, it may not be raining, but you'll be soaked with sweat anyway. Bring a bottle of water or even better Pokari Sweat (it's like Gatorade, but without all the colors and chemicals). Enjoy!
Beautiful but a drive past is enough. Unless you are not going anywhere near a rice field, it is interesting to see the terrace but doesn't hold much apart from a walk around it.
Tegalalang Rice Terrace.. Tegalalang rice terrace is second best view of rice terrace in Bali, and then interesting walk down to the smal river for up the other step rice terrace to see amazing view.
Beautiful. What a way to experience the colour green. A beautiful walk through the rice terrace. Be prepared to walk and for a little bit of mud, however the sights are incredible.

Amazing sights of very intricate rice terraces. You have the option of going down and traversing across the lower rice terraces but at the top the view is spectacular and there is no real need.My tip is try and go at a quieter time. There are so many tourists here.

Nice view but nothing much to explore. It has nice beautiful view and quite a number of shops targeted at the tourist. but apart from the nice view. there is nothing much to explore. can give this a skip if you have other plans in mind.

Beautiful views. Real picturesque view ... Careful when walking after rain because ground may be slippery! You will be requested for donation when you enter different farms.. 5000 IDR is ok . About 70 cents (US)! Well worth the beautiful pictures!
Not bad, worth the visit . Need to be able to climb. Beware for the compulsory 'free' donations you have to give at the bridge and at the end.
Nothing new . This place is overrated place, if you want to look for best paddy field in Bali then go to jati luih, too much crowd here in tagalalang
Must visit place . We don't need to buy tickets here expect if want to go down in the field which I think most people won't like to go you get to see good scene from top
Nice view . Very beautiful place to visit... Worth to visit not recommend much for shop. Take few pictures will do.
Nice views but touristy. These are lovely rice terraces but they are becoming a little touristy. You can see plenty of terraces around Ubud if you're prepared to do a little exploring.
LUSH!. Definitely a must see if you've never seen rice terraces before. Be aware! the lush green might hurt your eyes :)
Family holiday. These field were quite an experience, I was unable to track all over the fields but my daughter did and was amazed by the experience. I was able to watch her from a viewing area.
Nice place. Loved the rice terrace here, just be careful as it is slippery somehow but a walk in there is always nice.

Beautiful views. Gorgeous view of the real Bali and its quintessential rice terraces. Stop by at one of the terrace restaurants for delicious Indonesian food. One downside is that in some places, the views are somewhat obscured by trinket shops targeted at tourists.
Beautiful!. What a site to see! Green rolling rice patties everywhere. As you look down over the patties it feels as if you are on top of the world.

iconic place in Bali. did you have receive any post card from Bali before? if it yes maybe you will find same thing here. it is picturesque, it is tranquil. However many of the restaurant near it have a very bad building, so it is make the view worse.
amazing. I really like this place, is a beautiful view, all green and nice place to visit, you must go there I recommend your visit

Picturesque. Went here as part of a day tour organised by our hotel. Very beautiful.It had been raining the day before so it was a bit muddy and slippery. But our guide showed us a safer way to go back once we'd traversed through the rice fields.Bit of a challenging walk as you have to mind your step, can get quite high up in parts.
Lovely Scenery. Nice view of the rice terraces. Managed to take in the uniqueness of the area and had a number of photos taken too!

Beautiful. The Terrace is small but beautiful. A spectacular green when it is illuminated in the morning sun. Great photos. Best time to visit in the morning 8:00 - 10:00 before it is clogged with busses.

Best rice fields in bali. Amazing rice field due to the location being hilly.. The rice patties are staggered upon a slop which gives it an amazing view. There is a cafe you can eat at too which overlooks the rice fields, not a place to be missed if exploring the ubud area

Nothing much to see. There is not much to see here. You can just view this from your vehicle itself. If you are up for it and agile then you can get down and walk around the fields. It's astonishing to see how efficiently they make use of the space here. Every small patch of flat land has rice grown on them. Nice view though if you like green colour.

That's Bali . The rice terraces are really nice and appear in a bright shiny green as soon as the sun comes out. That's what Bali is special for and at Tegallalang it's one of the most beautiful of it. The only negative is the crowded and noisy main street full of tourists and shops.

Beautiful and absolutely worth a visit. The atmosphere around the rice terrace is really something special. I arrived in scooters with my friends after an easy drive from Ubud. We parked and crossed the road where we were meet by this beautiful view of the terrace. Underneath us there were many lovely restaurants and bars you can chill on whirl enjoying the view and they played soothing traditional music. You follow the road and walk down to start your walk/climb through the rice terrace and after stops and picture time, you end the walk with a cold cold beer of coconut in one of the nice bars with the beautiful view. Really nice experience and recommend it to everyone :)
Nice. A nice place but it's quite small. It,s quite hard to walk with children. Jatiluwih is much better and access are very easy.
Great place to visit. Great landscape, what a beautiful place it is. I recommend everyone to visit this. The steps are bit tough, going down is easy as usual but coming up is very hard.

Nothing spectacular, rather commercialised. Visited Tegalalang due to the hype over the rice terraces. I found it over commercialized and the rice terraces aren't really that spectacular. I have seem better ones in China.

Beautiful in the morning!. Make sure you go in the morning, and try to get there before the harvest. There are 3 donation points, its nice to put a donation for the community, even $2. Well worth the visit.

Rice Terrace. Beautiful rice terrace, markets and restaurants. Would be good to enjoy lunch overlooking the terrace but I would recommend getting there early to beat the crowd. We got there around 9:30 and the crowds were coming by about 10am
Picturesque . The most beautiful serene place i have ever seen.. a must to see in Bali!Grab a drink or enjoy a meal.. a selfie stick too
stunning places. It is nice to see the rice terraces on busy area such as Tegalalang.Not only taking picture, go for a short walk to it. Highly recommend! Please, help farmers to keep they best work.

Green Magic. The rice paddies are lovely throughout Bali, but those at Tegalalang are really outstanding. The rice terraces are situated in a valley/ravine and step down from road level into the valley and continues on the other side against the hillside. At road level, perched on the hill, there are a variety of souvenir outlets as well as restaurants, from where one has a wonderful view over the rice paddies. More fit and adventurous tourists are able to walk down into the paddies and up the hill on the other side.The main road goes through Tegalalang and the road can get rather congested. This section of the road is also very commercialized. There are many other shopping opportunities just further along the road where local artists and craft workers create and sell there goods from their homes.Great photo opportunities. Definitely worth seeing!
Nice!. We arrived here by motorbike and it was cool to take pictures to the Rice terrace.Avoid visit this place at midday because of the sun.

Disappointing. Slightly dissapointed with this recommendation given by local driver. Had to pay an entrance fee (on the main road mind you) just to continue down the road to be dropped off by driver then hounded by stall holders and small school children to buy from them. Beautiful scenery of the rice field with opportunities to take some good pictures but thats about it.
Get away from the tourists. Surprised to find these rice terraces busier than Orchard Rd during the Great Singapore Sale. Drive a few miles further on, the scenery gets better.

Beautiful landscap. We was unlucky as we arrive there in May which is the month they just finish harvesting. But the view still nice. You can interact with the farmest and you can also try to harvest the way they do. Should try the coconut water as well. Go around there as they are many nice photo spot you can take.

Ubud's top. Amazingly beautiful rice terrace which draws huge crowds. You can walk through the field. There are many small cafes where you can seat, drink and enjoy the scenery. Whole street is full of shops and best place to have some bargains.
Must See.. With so many exciting places throughout Bali, the rice fields are really what took my breath away. Go early in the day though to avoid lots of people and before heat gets super unbearable.

Great for pictures. A nice area & worth a visit , not much parking , you would only spend 20 minuets here , just for pictures , there is the usual shops & too many children with postcards in hand with the same sad face asking you to buy their cards for their school , a bit of a pain , but still with a visit .

Beautiful sawa's, great pictures. Ever since 2 or 3 years the Rice paddies of Tegalalang or part of the Kintamani tour and almost all bicycle tours go to Tegalalang. So expect cues for taking that great shot, but your patience will be rewarded with this mind blowing view.

Enjoy the rice field. The place is a little bit crowded in the afternoon so better to be here before 11. At that time many cafes have not start their business and not many traveller.But you surely can enjoy the view while you are having lunch here.

Great view but a little crowded.. We went there by ourselfs. Spectacular views. But too many tourist...after taking pictures you can rest in one of the small cafes with a glass of cocktail or fresh juice... we enjoyed it.

Gorgeous, do not skip this!!. The rice fields are a cheap entry (maybe 2$) and have lovely cafes overlooking the rice fields, absolutely stunning views, you can climb the fields to the top (there will be locals asking for donations along the way) wear shoes that you won't slip out of, I ended up going barefoot and it can get quite muddy if there was rain recently. Don't leave the camera at home for this one
beautiful rice terrace. Very beautiful place but little crowded .there is a lot of cafes and restaurant to sit and enjoy this gorgeous view.
Nice greenery. Love the lush greenery! Our guide brought us there and explained how the rice were harvested. Good to wear proper shoes as you are required to walk on uneven steps. Worth a visit!
Beautiful place. Very nice views, about 30 min trekking around the fields, you can make really nice pictures, would definitely recommend it!!

Beautiful view. If you to Bali, you have to visit also the rice terraces from Tegalalang. Very nice view from the street, but if you want to catch the perfect pic, you have to pass through the terrace on the other side of the hill, where you can stop for a cold drink or fresh coconut juice from the locals while taking pictures.
Beautiful scene. it is good idea for quick stop on the way to Kintamani. Lush green terrace and a lot of coconut trees. Perfect place to take pictures or do selfie.
Must do. Go for late lunch overlooking the terraces, then a little shop for some beautiful lace...my favourite place to visit each time we are in Bali...

Beautiful, but.... Of course the terraced rice fields are beautiful, but hire a driver and go explore other rice terraces. You won't be subjected to the mass tourism of Tagalalang or be hit with the never ending souvenir stands precariously perched on the side of the cliff.
Nice one. Niceee..but dont spend alot of time there at the end it is only a lovely view for picture and eye amusement but it was a nice errand

Stop and Enjoy the Vista. Excellent views of the sawah or ricefield terraces from the roadside. Quite a few stalls and vendors, and tourists here. My last visit was while cycling down the road from Kintamani.

Wonderful landscape... If you don't follow the signs. The landscape you can admire from the road from Ubud to Tegalalang is beautiful... But it's nothing compare to what you can see once you start walking between the terraces. It's very hard to describe the place so it's better you go and visit it yourself.But I suggest you don't follow the signs and you just find a side entrance and start walking from there, avoiding the touristic entrance/exit point. It's like a show there: the locals you can see are no real farmers... Or maybe they are but they're just there for the picture and they'll make you pay for that.Plus, this point is very crowded while the rest of the terraces are very quiet and peaceful.Note: don't walk in on a rainy day...

Nice view. There is no place for cars to stop at the rice terrace itself, as parking is tight. We went a little ahead to the Bali pulina (my review can be checked under the Bali Pulina heading) and sat there peacefully and saw the terraces while enjoying the coffee tasting
Simply breathtaking!. Imagine terraces of green paddy fields extending in front of you... A must-go if you are around Ubud! Many villas in Ubud boast a view of the rice terraces.
One of the highlights of our holiday. The rice terraces are a site to behold, but are even better if you trek down the hill side and view the paddies at ground level. Expect to get muddy.

Beautiful Views. Tegalalang is a beautiful rice terrace and definitely worth the visit. Its also the most popular rice terrace in Ubud so its pretty busy with tourists. It's on the smaller side when you compare it to the biggest rice terrace in Bali, Jatiluwih, but I highly recommend a visit if you're in the Ubud area

Beautufl. Like a canvas painted by nature with a little help from man. Amazing rice fields terraced gorgeously up and down two sides of a valley. Only negative is the hawkers asking you to buy their goods. But we all have to survive so it comes with the territory. I think a must if you want to see what Ubud used to look like.
Stunning. Stunning rice terrace...can get a bit touristy with lots of taxi's. A must see in Bali. One of the best one's we saw.
Overrated. Not the nicest terrace in my opinion. The terraces you will see when you are heading for mount kawi are a lot more prettier! And there where less vendors and tourists when we went.

A lovely place to sit back & enjoy the view. We came here as part of day trip Ubud. Great rice paddies & you're even able to walk amongst it all. I highly recommend having lunch then leisurely wander through the terraces.
Nice views ! . Some breath taking views and scenery ...other than that just rice paddy fields on hills ....good hike up and down and you get to capture nice views

Nice view, but bad villagers.. The view and restaurant there is incredible. However, after we paid the entrance fee before entering the rice terrace, we went around the half way in the rice terrace and there are a family of village stop us to pass through except paying them for the dontation. It's fine for us to pay the donation, so we try to give them 2,000 Rp., but they denied us and 5,000 Rp. per person. AND THAT'S JUST NOT RIGHT FOR US. We denied to pay and go back to the car. It's not because we can't afford, but I won't support any illegal activity here. Hope local authority officers do something about this.

Fantastic green view. we did small hike into rice terrace exploring the beauty of this terrace. The unique thing when we saw farmer cultivated the land manually. We wonder how they can contribute and share the water in sufficient way.

A Must in Ubud. I am not the biggest nature-lover out there, but once we were brought to this place by our tour guide, I was in awe. Though rice terraces, in general, are created by man, the view is spectacular and makes you really appreciate all that mother nature has created. These rice terraces are significantly smaller from the one in Jatiluwih and there are more shops and hawkers around the area. There are also a few more cafes/warungs in Tegalalang than in Jailuwih.It is best to get a tour guide or go with a tour to this area, absolutely breathtaking.

Great view, wear proper walking shoes. Went as part of a day tour, beautiful views but I chickened out and couldn't go any further in thongs as the steps got far too steep and slippery! The family on our tour didn't seem to make it too much further in normal runners either. The view is spectacular and it was so green everywhere I looked but very slippery, not sure if it's always like that or just this time of year. Must see though!

amazing meandering rice terraces. We visited these rice terraces while we were heading back to ubud from Besakih Temple. Before you reach the rice terraces, there is a patch of road that is lined with many shops selling furniture and other home decor things. some of this is exquisite - we couldn't help but stop, browse and buy! Once we reached the rice terraces, we made our way through the walking tour up to one of the cafes. a word of caution, keep some small denomination notes with you, a lot of people ask you for money for walking through the trail. once we reached the cafe, we enjoyed watching the sun go down while we sipped our ice tea and hogged on pastas. these cafes are cute. the one we went to was constructed on various level and provided great view of the rice terraces

Hidden from View. Located about 15mins North of Ubud, the rice terraces are a bit of a site to see. Seen from the road and the surrounding cafes there is plenty of opportunity for a decent photo.For the more adventurous you can trek down into the fields but not for the faint hearted as watch your step.  You could probably add this to a trip somewhere else as a stop off for a quick break.

Beautiful epitome of rice terraces. Sure, it's a little touristy, but there's a reason. It's a stunning prime example of rice terraces at their best. Bring a bit of money for the old ladies maintaining the trails because they'll hound you for donations. Follow the trails throughout all of it because it's all beautiful and provides different angles and photo ops. We went before 8am to beat the heat and the crowds which worked well. The sun was kind of in our eyes and hence photos directly looking at the main terraces were washed out. Late afternoon with the sun behind you would probably be ideal, however not sure about the crowds. Early in the morning, we were the only ones there practically, which was awesome. Loved it.
Unexpected Charges. The views of the rice terraces and the hidden trails are worth the visit. The only thing that I could go without is the hagglers wanting a "donation" for you to walk thru.

Crowded and really touristy . If you have a romantic idea of quiet rice terraces forget about this place. There are so many cafes and shops around it that is hard to appreciate the beauty of the terraces. Don't get me wrong, the terraces are beautiful but they are not at all what I was expecting. I asked my hosts if they could recommend other terraces that were less crowded and touristy and they recommended something further away. I also saw some nice ones on the way to Amed beach.

Very cool and so beautiful. We visited the terrace while on a tour and they're absolutely beautiful. It's just picture perfect walking around but everywhere you go people are chancing you down to sell you stuff. Definitely worth a visit!
Nice landscape!. If you haven't been to any other rice fields in SEA, Tegalalang Rice Terrace is a good place to have an idea of how the rice fields work, the landscape is very beautiful.
A must-see in Ubud. If you are in Ubud you should really check it out. It is just really a spectacular view. It is a little out of Ubud but easy to get to. It makes for some great pictures.

Good fun. We enjoyed the beautiful view and walk around the rice terrace. There are people who stop you along the way for a required to donation to go any further. It's a minimal fee but is somewhat frustrating after we paid an entrance fee when tickets were give to our driver (if you just walk up to the site, I think it would be free). Still, nice morning and worth the visit.

Rice Terrace. These are the highlight of my trip. It was very interesting to climb the terrace, there are local guides too. Looking at a whole field of green was very relaxing to my eyes/mind. I went there around 3-4pm when the sun is not so hot, the pictures turned out superb too.
Go early in the morning. Impressive to see and good photo opportunity. Go further into the countryside for even more spectacular views. Visit earlier in the day to avoid the crowds

Nice walk in Rice Terraces. If you are staying in Ubud, this will be on your way to Mt Batur. If you have time, a walk on a nice day would be nice. Else, there are cafes where you can relax and watch the lush green terraces!

Pretty views but a bit of a tourist stopping point. Great rice terrace views and a nice photo opp spot. Didn't quite live up to expectations as this is in a busy area where people stop at the side of the street, snap some pics and move on. Like it was placed there for the day-trippers from south Bali. I thought it would be more rural and we could enjoy a nice walk but it's really just a photo stopping point.

Great spot actually. Just try to avoid crowds . Well it's free entrance but not really. Different families ask donations if you want to get further in... "donations" accepted usually around 5k to 10k rupiah. But then again here's the most important - if you go try to go early or then hour or two before sunset to avoid crowds. And if you walk in go straight up and around the corner where will you find some really amazing views. Moat of the tourist never go there... Weird

Rice Terrace. Whenever I come to Bali, I always love to spend my one of my days to visit this place. It's so peaceful and you can enjoy the beautiful rice field while eating some food at the small warung or restaurant on the side of the field. The weather is so fresh. I LOVE it so much. By the way this place is one of the scenes used for Eat,Love and Pray's film that stared by Angelina Jolie

Tegalalang Rice Terrace, Ubud. I love to visit cultural places whilst exploring wonderful countries and Tegalalang Rice Terrace is fabulous and not to be missed. We visited in the late afternoon and the sky was dull. I would have preferred to go in the morning as I love taking photos but imagine the heat would be quite unbearable any earlier in the day.Lots of steps to climb and steep rice terraces but worth the effort when you get to the top and look back.Definitely worth a trip and there are lots of little market stalls near the entrance should you want to visit them before/after.

Stunning. Stunning scenery, well worth a visit. Just be aware to go down the hill and up the other side you are walking on narrow muddy ledges so make sure you have good footwear, if is raining your going to be sliding down and crawling back up!

Beautiful. This place is stunning. I remember my first view of it, I wasn't expecting it to be so 'wow'. You have to pay a small amount to get in (we bought a ticket at the car park opposite) but then half way up the terraces there was a woman asking for donations. A bit cheeky I thought. So be prepared with some small notes! Absolutely beautiful though

Stunning. We had an unexpected heavy downpour when we arrived at this rice terrace. It didn't deter us, we simply waited for it to clear and still had an amazing view and took some great photos. We sat in the restaurant for a better view and ordered a drink. Great views, lovely hardworking people.
Beautiful!. We stopped there and really appreciated the nice view of these terraces! Unfortunately it was raining hard, but this didn't remove the beauty of the site.

Nice View. The rice terrace was one of our destinations on our latest Bali trip. The greenery of the view was as impressive as in our previous trips. The road where we have had a look on this beautiful view also had some vendors selling souvenirs for you to bring back home. Worth a visit.
So much green. It is one of the must to see place in Bali, the photos don't get you whole picture of this beautiful.
Nice but very touristic. Cekin village offers a very view of rice terrace, however this place has become very touristic and not so typical.Sebatu village offer wilder places, only a few km further.

Pretty cool... but don't pay a driver!. Worth the drive out. Many drivers will offer to bring you out here, as a part of a day tour. I highly recommend renting a scooter (available for 40k IRS a day) and riding out on your own. You'll meet lots of locals actually working on the terraces and there are a ton of small little shops to buy fuel, food and other goods at.

nice view from the main street. need to ride for like more than an hour to reach this place from the main street Ubud, but worth it.. there are also some nice cafe with nice view in this area, there are also some handicraft seller in this area...
Beautiful. Stunning views and amazing location just so pretty, it is just so great to see the fields in operation and how beautiful they can loook

One of the most spectacular views in the world. If was worth the drive to see these rice paddy terraces. It was amazing seeing this from top of the mountain looking down in the fields. The shades of green are so beautiful and not as the shade of the Irish Mountains. It was fascinating seeing how these fields have surpassed the test of time and still are working rice fields. A classic Balinese photo op

Pretty views. Great lunch spot. Lots of tourists.. Astonishingly beautiful. It was raining but that added to the atmosphere. Nice to stop and have lunch overlooking the terraces (as you can see pictured with the beam in the foreground of the picture). You can also walk along some of them (unsure on cost) but we didn't do this as it was so rainy. I'd highly recommend visiting here, especially if you've got a driver or someone who can give you information about the terraces. For example, our driver told us that white rice takes 3 months from planting to harvest, and that usually they plant different things at different times of the year but due to tourism they are growing only rice all year round now.

Stunning Terraced Rice Fields Near Ubud. We ride a motorbike when we are in Bali (Asia) and always go up the ride past these rice fields at least once each visit. Sure it may be touristy, but if you time it right you might be the only one there. But this doesn't really matter since it's just a photo op of something beautiful in nature that has been enhanced by man. That's a novelty isn't it!

Very very overrun. Hard to enjoy terraces as the amount of noise, smoke pollution and hawking was just overwhelming. They looked pretty enough (though not particularly better than some others) but close up, there was quite a bit of litter in them. Would not recommend a trip here.
great view. went there and great view to look at a beautiful nature of rice terrace make heals our eyes for free.

Enjoy the ambience of natural paddies field. Just to pay for entrance 10k rupiahs per person you could already enjoy this beautiful view.I was lucky the paddies was just started to grow so it looks green everywhere.When i visited there,our driver dropped us to Doji cafe then we started to walked down the rice fields to enjoy the amazing ambience.Need to have a fit body to walk and climb a long the fields.And the soils might be little slippery so we have to be careful.But dont worry you still can have beautiful views from the cafe/restaurant on the hill side without going down to the fields.So when you visit Ubud,you should come to this place,see and enjoy the views by yourself,believe me you'll not dissapointed.

One of few good attractions in Ubud. We visited the rice terraces in a hot mid day and found it is not bearable when you are with a child less than a year old. The spot have heaps of shops selling souvenirs and on the other side are restaurants. Not much to do but take photo unless you are game to walk in the field. Something to visit when you are in Ubud.
Avg. Nice scenery . Little difficult to walk around as there are only man made path along through the rice fields.
Find a good spot for pictures. Definitely on our what to see in Bali list, cca 20 minutes drive from Ubud, close to coffee plantations as wellworth at least stop for taking pictures

Really Beautiful place to sit and contemplate the world.. The weather had taken a turn for the worst when visiting the rice terrace, therefore we decided to stop off and have drinks while the rain stopped. Sitting looking out over the rice paddy just helped your minds just wander into a peaceful place. Extremely well priced, delicious milkshakes.Pleasant staff
It is what it says!. Nice to look at, but i didn't find it the most interesting thing to do around Ubud. Visit if you have time, if on a short timeframe i probably wouldn't.

Gorgeous! . This could be a bit of a challenge for older crowds of people with any type of mobility issues, but it's absolutely stunning, even from a distance! There is a 10K fee to get in, and along the path there are places to make "donations" although the locals won't let you pass without "donating" 10K pp. the money goes to the upkeep of the paths and bridges. The views are amazing and it's worth a look!

Nice to look at, otherwise nothing special. Went there and took a couple of pictures. Although the view is stunning, there isn't much else to do (and little, very persisent kids will try to force sell you overpriced postcards so watch out).

fascinating!!!. beautiful nature, wonderful rice terraces in the middle of tropical forests or by small dirt roads . just by looking at them heals your eyes and calms you down.Local vendors are sometimes a bit too much, offering you everything for ridiculous and sometimes for reasonable prices. If you need or want something, always negotiate.

Beautiful . This place is lovely. But don't get ripped off with all the little stalls and shops around. They have very inflated pricesJust enjoy the view for free and you can walk down into the terraces is you have time

Stunning!. Some of the most stunning scenery I have seen! Make sure you wear solid shoes as there are some narrow paths and we arrived after it rained and it was extremely slippery at times, but 100% worth it!!

Beautiful terraces. We took mopeds to see the rice terraces. We hired bikes at 70,000 IDP and a guide for 200,000IDP for the day so we didn't get lost on roads. The guide also knew the less busier roads to take. The rice terraces are free to see and are stunning.
Stunning . Wow! This place is stunning! Do yourself a favour and go see the rice terrace. The whole scenary looks like a post card. Enough said!

Beautiful, but too crowded. The unfortunate thing about this place is that it's covered with shops and hawkers. It could have been a nice serene escape, but it being a tourist destination, you're shoulder to shoulder with people. It is still amazing to look at.

Beautiful photo op. Great example of terrace culture, and opportunities for great pictures abound. Mic you are a big fan, then the ones I have seen in China are more dramatic. There are extremely well maintained, very beautiful.

Gorgeous view of rice terraces. I've never thought rice paddy fields can look so gorgeous until I got here.. What more.. you could take a short walk down the terraces to have a close look. when we were down the rice paddies must been only 2 months old and i can imagine it will look prettier when it gets to 4 months old.

wonderful view, good pictures, opportunity for a good walk. Rice fields are a must see in Bali and they have made it convenient and fun. small fee to get in, good views, good places to have a drink, and a wonderfull opportunity for a fun walk

Must see in Bali. It is one of the main tourist attractions in Bali. Despite being overcrowded I like the spectacular views down the hill. Try to avoid rush hours and holiday periods. Parking can be a challenge as everyone goes there and the street becomes chaotic.
Just Looking. Decided to go and have a look , very interesting, it was was good very different to what I expected, take a look.
Must see!. Nice to cycle from Ubud...uphill but very rewarding. A must see when you're in Bali. The terraces are absolutely stunning.

Bali's postcard fodder!. The rice fields are as pretty as they look in the postcards. Make sure to visit early morning or late evening as the scorching Bali sun can put a dampner on things.
P.S. Be sure to avoid the creepy old man in the fields who insists on kissing every woman who passes through his hut.

beautiful view. Tegalalang rice field terrace is good place to lose away our stress as it has very beautiful view and good atmosphere. for those who want to try to prove that the view can make you peaceful, please climb and look back the view from the rice field and give yourselves time a minute to sit down there and enjoy the view so you will get it.
Simply Stunning. Wonderful souvenir shops and breathtaking views over these rice terraces. Lovely cafe built into the hillside - great place for lunch.
One of the must visit in Ubud . Lovely place especially if you have a local guide to tell you more about it.Try going in the morning when it's less crowded.
Unesco world heritage site with reason. Simply stunning! A must see. We did not appreciate the scale of this place until we saw a local working his field... Enormous and awe inspiring.

Rice paddy! Breathtaking view!!. Great day out! The view was unbelievable. Very steep and you really need to go down very carefully. However all worth it when you get down and to the other side, take in the view and marvel!
Beautiful. This is a gorgeous landscape of greenery that takes your breath away. I highly recommend this for any first time visitors to Bali.

Really very nice place to visit. To enjoy, go far from the first terraces, where everybody is.
You will see more beautiful places and you will enjoy being alone or almost alone. At least for pictures, you do not have anybody else... :)

Worth the clamber in humid weather . We went early and beat the rush and high humidity.Take plenty of water as none available in the fields and it will leach out of you. We added hydrolyte tablets in all our water to keep our electrolytes up and had no headaches which we are prone to.The pathway closest to where you just arrive has the least people and not next to shops or Cafes so no hassling with touts. You do have a few people in the fields who look after the pathways and keep it clean so they expect a donation....you don't have to pay this but as it was the first place I saw in Bali that had no rubbish I am happy to encourage the cleanliness of this spectacular area.We had three on our walk and paid 10k at each point.If you go when it's raining it will be very slippery.Not suitable for anyone mobility impaired.
Tourist trap. The rice terraces are undoubtedly beautiful but the area is crowded and busy these days. You can see the unspoilt rice paddies in other parts of the island.
Nice view . Really nice although you have to pay for the view. If you don't have a driver and a bit tight, I recommend going around ubud rice paddies.
Pretty rice terrace close to Ubud. It's worth to see, not far from Ubud, you can take a walk there or jest stay in a nice restaurant terraces in front of it. A bit crowdy on the street.

a must. If you think that rice terraces are boring, just go there and see it for yourself. It was an amazing experience, I've never seen something like that before. The views are extraordinary and it's worth exploring the whole area what can be really exhausting especially given the heat and humidity (try going there in the morning or afternoon) but you won't regret it!!
Its nice.. The view is amazing, and you can chil at these nice cozy coffee shops. And enjoy the view. You can also walk around the rice fields.

Very nice rice terraces, but views blocked by too many shops.. Ubud is surrounded by very nice paddy fields. Since tourism had discovered the Tegalalang rice terraces, many shops have been built, blocking the view on this beautiful landscape. So if you want to see rice terraces on steep slope and stay close to Ubud, go to Tegalalang. If you want more unspoiled view on rice terraces, Jatiluwih or Blimbing are better choices. These locations are about 1.5 hours driving from Ubud.

Great rice terrace view! Beware of (very) slippery road. Climbed down the rice terrace and up to the top of the other side and then back again. Requires a bit of energy buut you could enjoy the great view from the top (and bottom) of rice terrace. Prepare some small money as local ask for 'donation' for maintaining the road (we 'donated' 10k Rp for 2 people).

Fantastic view and cultual site. Seeing the terraced rice paddies where everything is palnted and harvested by hand gives one an appreciation of each grain of rice you consume. If youarefit there is a great 2-3 km. walk in the valley and up theterraces. It's a great view from the road if you don't hike. The usual souvenir shops line the road.
Beautiful!. Awesome, lush green terraces and plenty of people taking great pics! You must stop here for a few selfies!

easy to find them. There are better rice terrance near Ubud, this ones are just famous. If you don´t have much time to spend in Ubud, I suggest to go to this place. Otherwise go north, the rice fields there are much much better
Beautiful place . The rice terrace cultivation is so beautiful and soothing to the eyes. Lots of greenery around. You can walk around the paddy field too. A must visit in Bali.

A Must see!. We visited the rice terraces during a day trip. They are too far to walk from or go by bike from Ubud so you do need a car. but the few is well worth it. With the blue sky and the sun you will be stunned by the nicest green view, very enjoyable!

Fun place for an hour or so. A little touristy, but a great place to sit and have a beer and look at the view. There are about 10 restaurants along the road that look down over the terraces. Clean bathrooms are a little rare.
Beautiful view. Beautiful view from the rice terrace, you will take a lot of pictures for sure :) most see on Ubud :)
Nice view. Nice view of traditional rice terraces in a slopey little valley. Gets a bit crowded and parking can be tricky

Beautiful rice terraces. I was really looking forward to seeing the rice terraces with on my first trip to Bali, and they were really beautiful. I will say, I was disappointed with all the tourist huts on the top rim of the terraces, which took away some of the beauty of it all. We did not stay very long as there were alot of people and not much room to walk around

Nice and tranquill. We went with our 2 young boys and they enjoyed the view too. It's a nice place to have lunch/dinner and take a few photos but not much more.The restaurant prices are slightly inflated but overall not too bad. I wouldn't drive any longer than 30 mins to see them but if you're visiting the monkey forest then why not.
Stunning location.. If you have driver taking you back to Kuta etc get him to go here also. Great photo stop and if you have time go for a walk.

Beautiful! . It was picturesque here. We paid 5,000 rupiah per person to get higher up the rice terraces after walking down from the road on the other side. There were more places where you had to pay a 'donation' to get higher up but we didn't go up that high. Definitely a great place to go, and it's worth the small amount of money to go higher up for something very different and beautiful

Perfect example of Rice Terrace system. During our 5 days in Bali we saw many rice fields, we stopped in the middle of the road for pictures. But this place in Tagalalang it has a very steep incline and you can appreciate how the system really works. You can walk down almost to the bottom of the cayon.Expect many tourists, shops selling local souvenirs and unfortunately trash around the shops. All is worth it !
Worth the trip!. Authentic rice terraces, worth the walk to the other side from all the touristy shops. Find a shaded area and enjoy the amazing views.

Great view!. Lot of restaurant with great view around to fulfill your hunger. Walk through the rice field path is a great choice to spend time in Ubud. Nice and fresh weather! Don't forget to:1. Bring bottle of water while walking.2. Bring handy towel.3. Wear proper shoes or sandals, sometimes it could be slippery.4. Take a pee before you walk, you can't find any toilet in the middle of rice field.5. Cover your head with hat or something.6. Have fun!
A place to visit while stopping over for 10 mins. Its a place which you will pass while going to batur volcano. Not a wow place but you can just stop over and be there for ten minutes.

Over hyped. We may have simply got a bad guide who didn't show us a better view, but I was definitely expecting a lot more than what I saw of the rice fields. Yes, i saw terraced rice fields but they did not stretch to any great distance. It was certainly not worth a special visit. If it is enroute to any other site you plan to visit, stop by one of the café's that dot the hill side for you to soak in the view
A breathtaking vista. We passed by without stopping the first time, but the glimpse was so good that we went there for the full experience. I've never seen something like this!
Rice terraces . Place is nice with great view of rice terraces. Though those asking for donations in some corners before you can pass are turn offs.

Amazing views. Very nice views, several places to eat overlooking this valley. We had lunch while looking at the valley. When we arrived it was raining, so the air was fresh , you may want to bring a scarf if you're easily cold.
A Must!. It is sooooo pretty and a must see! You can also do coffee tasting here... Luwak coffee is a must taste... We took the most beautiful photos here.
Fifty shades of green. The beauty of these fields very much depends on the light; on sunny day they make a picturesque combination with blue sky and white clouds.

Brilliant lunch in lovely setting. We stopped here whilst on a day trip in Bali with Putu Supartana and had a lovely lunch overlooking rice paddies. The food served was delicious and the drinks well looked forward to seeing it was a very hot and humid day.This meal was one of the best we had in all the eccursions we had on our 21 day South East Asian cruise on the Sapphire Princess.
Not really good view, better view in other rice fields. Not really good view, better view in other rice fields. We stop before to Kintamani, and only see for a while. Not much to see

Amazing Sight. It is truly a wow moment when you enter and see this! The cafe is along the ridge. I sat in a private cabana and had a refreshing drink while talking to the very friendly waiter and soaking in the view.

Photo worthy but not much else. Pros.1. Great place for photography.Cons1. An hours drive from Ubud2. Nothing to explore or experience (If you are from a country where rice cultivation & terrace farming is already being practiced, not worth more than a 1 min photo halt)3. Local vendors start pestering

My favorite Rice Terrace. For me, this place was amazing! The landscape was incredible and the rice terrace looked even better than on the picture (I think it will depend on when you are visiting). Also be aware that some kidz could go and lead you around and be nice to you and in the end beg for money even if they didnt do anything and you didint ask for ant guidens.

OK but leaves something to be desired. If this is your first time to rice terraces then it's worth going to Tegallalang, 10km (30min) North of Ubud centre. Slightly commercial & has a "for display" rather than actually for farming feel. There's another area at Jatiluwih which could be better. Certainly Longjing rice terraces in Guilin China is larger, more natural & breathtaking. Anyways, here goes:1. Entrance fee Rs.10000pp, payable at the entrance roadThereafter, there are 3 other "huts" set up to collect "donations" to go to the higher levels of the terraces. This leaves a bad taste though it's not expensive Rs5000-10000pp (fixed, not "donation"). 2. Go in the morning - less people & less hot!3. Explore the back ways (not facing the houses); there are some good photo vistas & small huts offering refreshing whole coconut juice (~Rs20000ea), a chance to meet the local family/s who actually live onsite4. No toilets inside - use the ones belonging to the cafes before/after entering the terraces5. Low to medium physical fitness required. Shoes/ sandals preferable to flipflops.
Beautiful scenery. Definitely a place to see. Picture perfect scenery without any commercial bothering stores. Go there you will not regret it.

hot. Beautiful place to take picture. Not much to see, just beautiful nature for sightseeing lover. Very hot because we went there around 11 pm. Ready your sport shoes or any suitable shoes because need to climb small hill and a bit slippery.

Beautiful view!. Tegalalang Rice Terraces is almost a must when you go to Ubud. The views over the terraces don't make you disappointed. Incredibly beautiful and you can walk down through the terraces. This is free! Near the edge of the road lies the small restaurants, viewpoints and shops with cheap art, sarongs and other knick-knacks/krimskrams. What pulls down this visit some are all beggars who either want to sell postcards, charge money to let you pass, "guide" or let you be photographed with them.

Incredible. Stunning rice terraces. We drove out on a motorcycle (~25 minutes outside Ubud) and found it very easily. We spent about two hours climbing down and then up the other side and exploring the area. You'll have to pay the locals - we paid twice (Rp 5.000/person). They are so friendly and will let you take pictures with their hats and tools. Once you get to the top on the other side turn right and go into the back terraces... no one is there and it's really stunning... Don't miss this if you go to Ubud..

Beautiful View. The view of the rice terrace is beautiful, and it's very interesting to see how the irrigation works. We didn't spend long there, but enough time to walk around and check out the terrace and take a couple great pictures. It is a very peaceful area, away from the craziness of kuta etc. Though lots of tourists stop by on day trips to take pictures.

Not as good without the sun. I saw some pictures of the rice terrace and was very impressed and decided to visit. But the day I arrived it was overcast and the view seemed pretty mediocre. It was nice to take a walk around but not as amazing for sightseeing.
A amazing to see.. An Amazing place seeing the way they have built the rice paddys to allow the water to flow down supplying all the different Terraces...

Great view of the rice fields. The views of tegalalang rice fields were mesmerising. It is really amazing house the farmers grow rice crop on the slopes. We arrived there around 2 PM, as we walking around found a nice restaurant overlooking the rice fields. There food was delicious and the sight of the fields was fabulous.

Ignore negative reviews. Timeless testimony to Balinese rice farming . Tegallalang Rice Terraces in Ubud is renowned for its spectacular scenes of rice paddies involving the ancient subak (traditional Balinese cooperative irrigation system). This is exactly what you will witness here; a wonderful display of traditional agriculture. Tegallalang forms the three most splendid terraced landscapes in Ubud's shared region, with the others being in the villages of Pejeng and Campuhan.Of course, it's similar with countless other destinations on the island, Tegallalang’s rice terraces have a distinctly “found out” feel, but the view is especially hard to beat. We found this a superb morning activity (could easily fill an afternoon too) and we didn't get charged to enter. We grabbed a bowl of fruit from one of the stalls, sat back and appreciated what was in front of our eyes. Admittedly, it is rather touristic but where isn't these days? Considering Bali is still revelling at finally being recognised on the UNESCO World Heritage List for its rice-growing traditions, it's definitely worth coming to see why.
Nice to see. This is one of the best rice terraces to see. Really taking care off. Take the time to walk in the wally. Really worth it. Avoid, all the people trying to sell things to you all the time

Relaxing escape from Ubud. If you want to take a fresh breath out of Ubud after city run. Just take scooter/taxi and come over for a relaxing walk. Be prepared for 'donations'. I had there really good time closing my active day.
Beautiful place. Beautiful place with so much greenery around. It just takes around 30 min to reach from the town on bike.

Great Views - though become a tourist trap. I would recommend to visit the rice Terraces at Tegalalang for the amazing views. Though it now become a huge tourist trap with micro coffee houses perched on the opposite side of the terraces with every one selling T shirts to ornament.. Worth the trip but over crowed with tourist

Go in when the rice plants have grown. A nice view of terraces of rice plantation. Since the plants are small it didn't look so beautiful. Honestly since I am from a rice growing state in India I didn't find much attraction here.For first timers you can see how the water is used for plantation at different levels.
Beautiful. A very beautiful place but of course also very touristic. We visited it on our way from Ubud to Lovina.

Beautiful but money hungry . We did this last minute and turned out to be one of the highlights of our trip, it doesn't take long and it is very beautiful. The only thing we didn't like was being asked to pay an entrance fee (10,000 Rupiah) per person and then being asked for a 'donation' which wasn't really a donation but rather a payment. They demanded a min of 5000 Rupiah, not bad but constantly being asked for money puts a downer on the whole experience.

Nice Views. Prepare for a long uphill trek. It took about 45 minutes of steady climbing along a stone path. Not always a two way path. The view from the top is worth it. The steady stream of souvenir shops are never ending....

Don't bother. Tourist trap. You get dropped off on the other side of the proper rice fields where there are lots of restaurants and people constantly throwing things in your face to buy. Had to pay to get in which was fine but then was asked for a compulsory "donation" to get to the actual rice fields. I was very disappointed and we left within 20 minutes. I felt completely ripped off. I would try a different rice terrace or just drive past one.

another world. beautiful, breathtaking you feel whole I'm not goddly at all but you get this feeling. the locals have a toll booth to enter this helps with the upkeep. you have to see it for yourself it cool up there and the people are every friendly. so green and quite.

Beautifull views. It is very easy to access and they dont charge entrance... Dont get tramped from guides trying to sell you the tour if you are motorized, there is no tour, just a big rice field to walk around very easy, its beautifull.

Only worth for instagram photos. We came here after seeing great instagram photos of these terraces. The place is actually bleaker than on photos. There's a lot of shop selling different junk, and tiny street cafe's around it. The place crowded with tourists and very littered.  There are two places you can come in to the terraces. and in each you have to pay about 5000rp per person. If we understand correctly, because these terraces belong to two different families, and each tries to get money from tourists. But the road here from Changgu was quite picturesqe. On the way we snapped great views of rice fields, river canyons and tiny bridge across one of them

Walk and understand how hard harvesting rice is. From one side this is nice view and fine walk but you also have an opportunity to learn by yourself how rise is harvested... if you want to see more - prepare to get dirty
Very Intriguing. Extremely stunning view. Not sure about payment for tourist as control wasn't properly checked. Nice place to spend the day if you bring your own lunch
Touristy. Very. . Too much tourist. But very beautiful paddy fields. Very commercialized too with lots of shops and cafes. Its an old province made commercial by the demand of the tourism....

Different kind of scenenary. Living in big cities would need a place to release all those stressful lifestyle.
A few minutes stopover at this place to see the green paddy field would be great. Specially when you come with children, this place provides a great alternative to introduce nature to kids.
Errm Rice Fields..... Well being Asian familiar with neighboring rice terraces...didnt do much for me...but still its respect to those who slog in that sun...

Lovely, but those poor women's backs. The viewing terrace at this UN Heritage Site makes it easy to see the tiny terraces used to grow rice in an apparently unending vista. The terracing is so spectacular because it manages to make use of so much space. However the terraces, our guide told us, are too small for any machinery so the planting and cultivating and picking [and subsequent hauling of the 85lb [40kilo] bags of rice is all manual labor. Done almost exclusively by women. Imagine the compression of neck and spine....

Very nice view rice terrace. Before to go there i saw some people say it's a small rice terrace. So i was hesitating for a while. But finally we went and we enjoyed it. Its not so small. You can have a walk down to the field. Nice view! Good thing is some cafe just right there to enjoy the view. So worth a visit.

Picture perfect. I visited this wonderful sight when i was last in Ubud .I have often seen pictures of the terraces in many brochures .it doesn't dissapoint .Make sure you have enough time to walk around the terraces ..I will return as I didn't have enough time .it definitely mustn't be rushed

Gorgeous views. We enjoyed the views of the rice field from the comfort of a local cafe and opted not to make the trek down and back up again.The view was beautiful and the mood was relaxing.There is an entry fee and there are plenty of people selling you things along the way so just ignore them if you don't want to buy anything.
Photo OP. Great for a walk in the rice fields and for taking lots of photos, but the locals treat the tourists as atms and will get money anyway they can.

World Heritage listed Wonder. The Tegalalang rice terrace (sawah) is part of the extensive irrigation system (subak) that feeds the thousands of rice padi in Bali. This system is over 1200 years old and is a testament to the ingenuity and amazing skills of the Balinese people. The rice terraces are under threat from the combined impacts of climate change and reduced or erratic rainfall and pressure from the tourist industry to take land and water resources away from agriculture. See this place while you can !!
Awesome Place. Worth a visit, however we were asked multiple times for 'donations for the terraces' in rude ways. Best way to get there is by scooter.
One of the best rice paddy views in Bali. Gorgeous views just like a postcard! Worth the drive! This place never fails to take my breath away so very different to Australia.

Tourists everywhere . Beautiful site especially with some rain. Tourists are everywhere which makes it less special add to that the local villagers charge to stop and look. Lots of hawkers and cafes. Overall the experience is overrated as you can go for a drive throughout countryside and see similar sites anywhere in hilly areas.
Lovely view!. Very nice paddy field view. The food in some of the cafes was just ok, though. But recommended to go there for the experience.
Worth 20 minutes to walk around. The rice fields near Ubud were just as nice and in some ways nicer as there was mor.e happening each day... these were just fields of rice
Ubud visit . Incredible! A must see. Took a private tour from our hotel in Ubud, Plataran Hotel and Spa, it was a 6 hr drive and this was just one of our great stops.
Picturesque. Had to be visited. Was exactly as expected and well worth a visit. Don't forget to buy you Balinean hats here.

Great Views!. Amazing place to visit, breath-taking views! We didn't walk along the entire path but definitely worth the trip, even if it's to sit in the cafe nearby looking out at the amazing rice terraces whilst grabbing a bite to eat or a fresh juice/milkshake!

touristy!. This place would be gorgeous if it wasn't commodified to this absurd level. Not the quiet rice terraces you see on the postcard of your imagination. It's crowded and noisy and filled with terrace view cafes. Am sure it's not the rice farm workers who are benefitting!
Nice and Very Hot. Something different from what we have in Malaysia. The weather is really hot. We brought along our umbrella and hats for the kids.
Beautiful view. This is amazing to see the different levels being farmed. View is stunning only downside is markets everywhere. Sitting looking out was very relaxing

Just beautiful!. This is one of Bali's famous rice terraces but what makes it unique is that there are restaurants in the area where one can soak in the beautiful view while dining. Ask your tour guide (I highly suggest Made from Mayor Bali Tours) if it's the best time of year to see it. It certainly is not as pretty just after the rice has been harvested, which is done on a rotational basis.

So so. Very touristy when there are more beautiful rice fields around Ubud to see. The street is over run with people trying to sell you everything. There are even tacky photo booths set up for tourists to get photo's in frames and things that belong at parties not rice terraces!

Green green green. I don't believe that green is that much beautiful color.Green rice fields make me comfortable and calm.On my way to Ubud from Legian I just drop by Rice Terrace to have lunch.The view was so nice!!!There are few restaurant but all of them are pretty expensive and un tasty and not good service.

Great for taking photos - be aware of the toll!. We took really great photos and the view is nice. There are some locals on the rice terraces who do not let you go through unless you pay a "donation" (about 5-10000 rupiah per person) also if you take pictures with the workers they will ask for money afterwards.
Always worth the view. When the sun is peaking through the thunderstorms, the light and green rice terraces can be excellent. Tour buses detract but that's the way with popular destinations.

Magic rice. Oh my god... I've never seen anything like tegalalang terrace... The place is just stunning.The level of perfection of the terraces is unbelievable and the watering system is brilliant. When you think of how the whole place is done and not a single brick is used you will appreciate how the Balinese put their heart into things.Go to the Terrace, walk down, cross to the other side and sit for a while to just breath the beauty.

Beautiful!. We only stayed for about 10-15 minutes or so, but it was worth it! What a beautiful view! I think you could go down in "the valley", but we only made a quick stop som we stayed on the top.

Beautiful rice terraces!. Not that far out of Ubud and you can ride a scooter there. Go later in the afternoon for better photo lighting. We went around 8:30am and the sun was against our camera. Also most all the cafe opens after 10am. A beautiful ride along the way. Can go to Titra Empul ( an amazing experience) from here - not too far.

Tour of rice terraces was worth it. Good to visit as part of a day tour, excellent lunchtime stop with local guide, good local food, very very busy and crowded in places. Our guide took us to a great spot for lunch that was fairly quite and had a good view of the terraces. Well worth the time.

Great Photo Stop. A must stop outside Ubud...fantastic photo opportunity of the traditional rice terraces in Bali. Just a 15 min scooter ride from downtown Ubud. Only issue is the typical street vendors roadside...not pushy just a distraction from the beautiful location.
Beautiful place. It is really beautiful place. Everything is so green. You need to be able to clime a bit but it is worth it.

stunning!. Well worth the effort to get here. Prepare yourself for some fairly strenuous walking/trekking but it is absolutely worth it. What a stunning place.
Had lunch there too which was good.
beautiful. beautiful place must visit ....... adding a picture which was taken from the top viewing level of the place.... loved it
green green green. rice fields are very relaxing, green terrace are so calm, good athmosfere, must see, walk into the fields

Great thing to see while visiting Ubud. I really enjoyed visiting these rice paddies. It really is very beautiful and there's lots of trails so you can walk all around in the valley. The only downside is it is very touristy. Of course I was expecting this, but still crowded places are not my favorite. Just expect lots of people and little children following you around trying to sell postcards etc... There's nice places to sit and have a cold drink or a meal if you want along the top of the valley. To see the terrace it takes 1, possibly 2, maaaaybe 3 hours if you really hung out and relaxed. Not counting getting there and back. I biked here 10k from Ubud which I would recommend, so long as you don't mind biking in traffic and aren't afraid of a little ( ok a lot) of sweat. The place I rented my bike from was about half way between the palace and the monkey forest, they've got a lot of bikes next to their shop it's hard to miss. The bike ride is simple, you follow the same road for most of it. It's uphill pretty much all the way there so get an early start! Way back is downhill and much easier!!!

Nice to see. The rice terraces are nice to see, but I don't think I would make a special trip, although there are a few things to do in conjunction with the terraces to have nice day trip.There are many rice terraces through Bali, these are bigger than most.
Family. 1st time here. Average I would say..Nothing much except rice fields. An experience. Would not come again
Eat here and remember. One of those memorable experiences of great food in a setting that just fits.You wont regret it. The food was great, with bintang beer. Mie Goreng, satay and coconuts.

Overrated. I have to say that although the view is lovely, the whole experience was overrated. If you wanna enjoy the view in peace (without anyone trying to sell you something) you have to sit in one of the restaurants/coffee shops. If the food in the restaurant (forgot it's name) was good that will be ok, but it wasn't. And the service wasn't good either. Honestly, the rice paddies we saw durring the cycling tour around the villages were much more beautiful.

Stunning rice terraces. Wow! Absolutely beautiful! Unfortunately, the cafes and shops are very touristy, expensive and you are pushed to purchase various items everywhere you walk... However, definitely worth a trip as the scenery is stunning.

A Theme of Green and Brown. Are you fit to walk down multitudinous steps and up the other side and back again in the 90% humidity with temperatures in the 30Cs. If so do the walk and recover in a cafe on the roadside when you get back. If not stay in the cafe and take pictures and marvel at the creativity of man and the sculpture of nature before you. Wonder at the people who work it to make a poor living. Watch the ploughing of the brown sludge or the back bending planting.The small fee to enter the village raised on each tourist who passes (not locals or guides) goes to the community. The tourist shops can be browsed or the street seller might just have the item you suddenly need to get rid of the pest. Psychological warfare is launched at you with the little girls selling cards. Beware.

Amazing views, fantastic walks. Nearly only experienced from afar, as 'tour' driver did not want to stop! We insisted on stopping and decided to follow the trial. Glad we did, amazing! Some gentle climbing, but good exercise, especially if on a tour.
a short tour to Tegalalang Rice Terrace. You may pay a visit here if you are a green lover and natural lover. Free entrance and this is not a easy job for the farmers. We shall respect them!

Love the greenery . Saw amazing pictures of this place from Instagram and wanted to visit! It is really nice view but we got too tired as we just arrived in Bali, therefore we never walk down the terrace. But worth a visit if you want to snap good photos here :)

So beautiful it makes you dizzy . We travelled with "hire Bali driver" and he took us here. It was just gorgeous the views from the road where breath taking! There's a lot of little shops along the road that you could buy market things. But the locals hound u a little. Especially little girls selling post cards :/ A few people where walking the rice fields. I would not recommend it for the unfit or older folks. Looks like hard work haha But It's a beautiful view to take in!

It's become a tourist trap. I will start by saying, if you are in the area, please go ahead and stop. That being said, I would not go out of my way to see these. There are beautiful rice fields all over Bali and and this area is crowded with vendors that detract from the beauty of the place.

Stunning site. Nice for a small relaxing day trip. We went for a trek through and although not quite relaxing it wasn't to strenuous and worked up my appetite for the baby coconut I had at the end. Some interesting local characters too :-)

Well worth the heat 😅. It was stinking hot but it was just amazing. The views were breath taking and you stop when you like and in the shade too, they offer drinks and coconuts along the way but be careful as we paid $5 for a coconut!

Could be a messy walk. If you plan to walk around the terraces, bring along some sandals or shoes you don't care getting dirty because you are walking in muddy terraces afterall. One can't help but think about all the hard, manual labor through the centuries planting rice in these terraces. Amazing view from the top but an entirely different experience walking down in the terraces. Please be respectful as these terraces are primarily for tourist but for the livelihood of those who work the fields. Went in the afternoon and it was crowded with tourists. The guide tells me it's like that all the time.

Good place for relax. The view was awesome, so fresh and clean. You can enjoy the view while walking around the terrace or just lunch with rice terrace view behind.
It's good place for family trip.
Must do. Great place to come see, there are many cafes and restaurants all along the strip with great views of the rice terraces. Recommend go somewhere for lunch and take in the veiws
Disappointing. The place is full of garbage and not well maintained, so it was almost unpossible, after heavy rain, to visit the fields. And we were almost forced to buy postcards ..

Not the Same Anymore. I was first visit Tegallalang Rice Terrace in 2002, and sometimes revisit about once a year. It was far more prettier than 14 years ago. now, to crowded, too many cafes by the street blocking the view from the street. too many vehicles parking. People are racing to take advantage of the place.
stunning place. great little spot with beautiful terraces. not very crowded very relaxed atmosphere and a few places to to enjoy the spot with a cup of coffee.

Stunning in the rain. We stopped here for lunch and were blown away by how beautiful this place was. So green! The only downside is the volume of tourists trying to squeeze into this tiny location. We really enjoyed the visit and took some great pictures. I think it's a must see at least once during your trip to Bali.
Impressive views. Beautiful views across the small valley. Not bad for a free activity. We didn't partake in the guided tour though. Worth popping into if you're in the area.
Not impressed . It is definitely beautiful, but we were staying on ricefields where the hotel was, so it wasn't worth the trip in my opinion.
Wide reaching views. The pictures do not do justice to the rice terraces. They extend over such a large area. We went on a rainy day but they were still a amazing site. Do not miss this
picture-perfect. Beautiful rice terraces, picture perfect, easy day trip from ubud or kuta. We stopped for an hour, had coconut and relaxed, just watching that wonderful view.

Nice view from the top of mountain Road.. Nice view from the top of mountain Road.
You have walk down through the steps , it is more tiring . It is worth visit for the view only.
Very beautiful terraces!. Place must to see! It is so beautiful!!! Nice green terraces and great view! We liked to be there. Come at the morning or evening because it is very sunny and hot there!
Worth seeing unique. My 21 year old son Trekker up the hill to the far side in the distance. It is a beautiful spot and this was my first experience at a rice paddy/field. No cost!

Quite scenic.. We recently went here on a day trip to Ubud. We stopped along the way and had to pay a man to continue on to where the lookout was. Its quite scenic here and great place for some holiday pics. Just a note to tourists - if other people have waited while you take pics it would be considerate to allow them an opportunity to also have a picture taken. There will be many kids trying to sell you their wares with the same spiel I've heard many times in Bali....

Definitely worth a visit . We checked out the rice terraces in Ubud on our way to seminyak. Amazing how they grow the rice and the process that is involved. Try to go with a guide so you get some background knowledge, as opposed to just visiting yourself.

Definitely worth a visit - even if it's just in passing!. Unfortunately, due to a mistake by our tour company, we did not have sufficient time to visit the rice terraces on our way back to Ubud. However, we were able to stop and observe these from the road, and even this was beautiful! Having seen this, I would definitely try and make time for a proper visit in the future! Also, make time to stop if you're passing, even if it's only for half an hour!
