You will see this must see destination in Bali if you want or not.. You will see this must see destination in Bali if you want or not. Every driver in Ubud stops there if you go around Ubud. The views are realy great, but far from authetic. This are paddy fields arranged for tourists. And you can make some great photos there, for sure. Enjoy the scenery. Avoid the restaurats.

Surprisingly cool trip. I wasn't convinced this needed to be at the top of our list, but it ended up being a very cool experience. The view itself is worth allocating a morning or afternoon to wandering through the rice terraces. It's a unique experience that you won't find many other places. Finish it off with a coffee or iced tea overlooking the terraces and you have yourself a nice day trip!

Beautiful place to visit. Upside1. We booked a tour- so everything was organized and convenient2. Stunning view 3. Lots of photo opportunities 4. Clean and green Downside 1. Quite a far place to go to (so bring drinks and snacks) 2. Several restaurants located along the road - but food isn't served hot (buffet style).
Great viewing. Beautiful rice terraces, but you get hounded by people to buy their wares as its in a market area, very annoying
A must see !. That's very nice to see and a good walk you can spend few hours walking in and take pictures. I would recommend to visit it if spending some time in Ubud area.

A heavenly scenery. A must see destination in Bali. The view and the restaurants are great. Although i don't recommend eating there as food quality wasn't the best. You can go for a drink and enjoy the scenery

Quick stop to view! . We stopped by here for about 20mins just to admire the view and take a couple of snaps for our holiday. Worth a see but not for long as there are many rice terraces in the surrounding areas.. Got harassed by kids to buy things of them, which we did just because the girl was so polite in her way! Worth a visit but don't be disappointed if you can't come to this one as there a re many to view all over the island!
Rode scooter to Tegalalang and had a beer at a cafe.. Great views of rice terraces from a range of cafes but road is narrow and parking difficult if on scooter as it is popular.

Always stunning to look at any time of the day. These rice terraces are so lovely. I have viewed them many times and am never disappointed. Such a short trip on a motor scooter from UBUD and so peaceful (if you try to miss the busy toursit bus times of day)

Tourist List Check-Off. The rice terraces are beautiful, and interesting. It is not someplace where you would spend hours, a quick stop so you can get the background information and take some stunning photos will do. That way when your friends back home ask if you saw them, you can answer "yes". We had a private tour guide, and did not run into swarms of tourist, or souvenir hawkers, so an extra thank you to Gusti, for taking us there at a time when we were able to avoided them. I believe if you have never seen the terraces you will always wonder what you missed, so take the time it takes to drive by if nothing else.

Beautiful yes - but everyone thinks so. There are beautiful rice terraces all over this island and at the rate of spoiling a beautiful and pristine location and turning it into exactly what I don't like about Tegalalang - the views at Jatiluwi are worth the trip. Tegalalang are an easy reach from Ubud, so if that's all you have time for I get it. Ubud is surrounded by rice fields, so just venture out a little and you'll see for yourself. Get up early and meander - a much better use of your time.
Beautiful. Not much to say... Must do, beautiful, but once you took your pictures, go somewhere else (disappointed by restaurants near)
Rice Terraces. Beautiful view...Minimal charge...Difficult to appease street sellers here...particularly children...Great avocado juice for sale at little cafe near steps to viewing platform...

Lovely but very touristy. Obviously the terraces are pretty amazing to look at, but there are many tourists and many people trying to force you to buy postcards. Not really my thing :)The best thing about it was the drive up there .. I rode the scooter, accidentally took a back road and saw many other amazing terraces and unreal scenery - we were the only ones on the road. Don't be afraid to depart the main road and explore, there are many more terraces and paddies other than Tegalalang!

Beautiful sights and Delightful Sounds . Right in the midst of busy Ubud town there is a little path that, if followed, leads you into into a beautiful and natural oasis. Follow the path to view the terraced rice fields, farmers at work, cows, simple homes and sacred temples. We even came upon a nest of baby ducks! This is a lovely way to spend a few hours and get some exercise.

Worth the walk. We were lucky to see a couple to take their wedding photos.The green with the white long gaun makes the scenery sunning and touched your heart.Walk between the terrace and see the morning dews shining under the sunlight.
Stunning but not as stunning as Jatiluweh. This is a beautiful and special place but teeming with tourists. Also not as stunning as Jatiluweh but it's closer to the tourist circuit...recommend.
Beautiful view. We went to a coffee shop at the top and had an amazing view of the terrace. It is a beautiful sight to take in.

Beautiful views- a nice stop for a busy day of touring. If you're touring the countryside of Bali for the day, the Tegalalang Rice Terrace area is perfect for a quick stop to enjoy a snack or lunch in one of the many hillside cafes facing the terraces. Enjoy!
You're not alone. The Tegalalang Rice Terreaces are nice to look at but are only visible from a street lined with tourist shops which kinda spoil the ambiance .

Beautiful views. I have been living in Indonesia for 6 months, so rice terraces are nothing new to me, but I was still very glad we visited the Tegalalang Rice Terrace. Beautiful views and gives visitors an idea of what a rice field is like.

Nice to see but you can pretty much drive past and get the view. One of the sights in Ubud that is worth a look and is close to the coffee Luwak plantation so ties in well but literally you'll be in and out of the car in 5 mins. Not something to plan your day around necessarily and a bit of a tourist trap, they make you pay $10k to park the car and have a look.

Stunning views, but very touristy!. Along with the Monkey Forest Tegalalang Rice Terrace is maybe the most known attraction in Ubud, so it gets quite touristy. But I still think it's worth checking out, because it's really as beautiful as you see in the photos. It gets super hot and humid down at the bottom, so prepare to sweat. Have something cold to drink in one of the warungs and enjoy the view.I would recommend renting your own bike, so you have a bit more freedom. The 20 min drive from Ubud centre is mostly straight forward on good roads. Plenty of fun places to stop along the way. Most people stop right when they see the first parking so it gets super crowded. Try driving a little further to find a spot away from the masses. Also I would try to visit as early in the day as possible, before it gets to crowded and hot.

Amazing views. The views are incredible from the road that hugs the ridge. Recommend driving a but further north of the paid parking area to the couple of cafes looking over the northern terraces. There you csn get pictures that don't show tourists crawling all over the fields

Amazing landscape. The rice terraces are simply amazing, what let me down were the young girls selling postcards. They would not give up. The whole street could use a major clean up too, quite dirty and shops that were rundown/empty.
However, take that away you are left with stunning terraced rice fields, with the odd person working in the paddies.

Very picturesque. This wasn't on my to-do list whilst in Bali. With my husband who is a keen photographer & my kids who are 19 & 16, there were so many other things which appealed to us more.Our driver took us here on the way back to Ubud from Ulun Danu temple. It was lovely & green & the grey clouds were rolling over thick & fast which was a nice cool relief. My daughter was hungry so we stayed up at a place which had a buffet lunch for $10 each but I have to say, the only thing that looked edible for us was the rice, so it ended up an expensive meal for what we had. My husband & son went for the walk through the rice fields and they came back with some very nice photos. Glad we stopped though, was nice to see another side of Bali.Oh and the road leading into this place is shocking - the money they make on entrance fees, they should get this fixed.
Beautiful views . It a bit of a drive from Ubud but a beautiful one, we went to the temples same day so made a full day of it. We had buffet at Jimmys and sat by the window and it is stunning.

Nice place for a short visit .. 25 mins bike ride from ubud. Nice place.. But morning tends to be hot n humid. Diff to climb up d to d top.. Wear proper shoes.. Diff to climb or walk with beach slippers . Sells cold coconut water just at d exit which is a life saver in d heat. Must visit in ubud

Beautiful and Breathtaking Exp. This visit is truly a mesmerizing one with the a view of beautiful and breathtaking location infront of your eyes.This gives immense life to our eyes.Call me back ..Rice Terrances ;)
Beautiful. This was so cool, an absolutely stunning practice that has been a part of the culture for so long. Definitely worth the stop.
20 minutes ride from Ubud Centre. We rent a motorbike from ubud centre to here. Use GPS to reach the location, Nice view, sitting at the cafe nearby to enjoy the view and taking pictures.

An iconic view of the rice terraces. Whilst in Bali there rice terraces are a sight i felt i wanted to see as its one of those iconic sights associated with Bali. Ubud and the surrounding area has many attractions so we combined the terraces in with other places of interest. You have to pay to drive into the area, though this is minimal...20 IDR(about £1GBR) Your drive takes you into the village....this is not a quaint rustic village of palm leaf huts, but modern buildings and aimed at the tourist, with all the tacky souvenirs. From the street you get a stunning view across the valley and rice terraces...from here, though stunning you really only get the one view. It was pouring with rain when we arrived so we didn't get any closer, but if the weather is nice and you have the time make the effort to go down to the terraces, i think you'll appreciate making the effort.You could say you'd done this sight in 15 minutes but equally if you go down to the terraces you could spend much longer.
Breathtaking. If you're in Bali, you must see the Tegalalang Rice Fields. I was told they're more brown because the rice was just picked, but it was still like stepping into a beautiful painting.
Wonderful sight. A visit to the rice paddies has to be on your list when in Bali. It is a sight to be seen. It is a absolutely stunningly beautiful sight.

Underwhelming . Not what I was expecting to be honest. Pay to get in... Stand on a road around 50 meters from the rice terraces and take some pictures and then get on your way. We were there for 5 minutes.

Walk on the wild side!. If you step away off hte main street and cross over the fields you can explore the back community of the rice terraces. I dont recommend it if its been raining as the paths are very small and often muddy. We met a lovely old man with no teeth and exchanged lots of laughs. The small restaurants offer a good place for coffee, but food in most isnt that great.

Relaxing view over the rice fields. We stopped for a cold drink and something to eat at Rice Terrace Cafe after some shopping. The view was lovely and the coconut drink nice and cold. If you are feeling energetic you can go down some stairs and wander amongst the rice fields, plenty of photo worthy opportunities!

M u s t . S e e !. The rice terraces had been on my list of things to see for a long time. The end result was perfect as the rice terraces are breathtaking. I highly recommend anyone to go see them. You end up arriving along this strip of shops and cafes, you are able to walk through any of them to gain access to the rice terraces. I would recommend wearing runners or sandals with grip to walk along them. I didn't have suitable shoes so I ended up going in front of a cafe and taking photos. It was still perfect to just see them. When I visit there again, I will be walking along them.
Bring your grippy thongs. Well worth the walk down and up the rice terraces. Wear shoes/thongs with grip, and bring a few 10,000Rp notes as you will have to pay a few times along the way.

Always a nice visit. We try and stop at the rice paddy a once a year. Several places to have food or drinks overlooking the rice fields. Several markets nearby and many shops on the way up. Would recommend.

Worth seeing but not in the league of Jatiluwih. These rice terraces are interesting and located quite a short distance from Ubud, which naturally means they are a little less picturesque than Jatiluwih Rice Terraces. Nonetheless, they are interesting to see and if you do not have time to visit Jatiluwih Rice Terrace, they are absolutely worth seeing.
Great Adventure. This was a beautiful experience but the trick is to wear good walking shoes/sandals- a lot of walking up and down, and can be muddy in spots- but well worth it!
Breath taking views ☺. Today i visited these rice fields and it was totally stunning .Wow the views from the top...yes a little steep narrow path but no rush..take it slow so worth it.
stunning scenery. Our 3rd trip to Ubud and our fist visit to the Rice terrace - we were blown away. the scnery is truly stsunning

Beautiful surroundings!. We stayed in Ubud during our stay in Bali for a couple of days and we took a bike tour that took us to the Tegalalang rice terrace. The rice fields are very beautiful and I enjoyed that biking tour very much. We had a very passionate enthusiastic guide who took us to the starting point of your trip where you could see the three biggest volcanos of Bali through a small local village where we visited an elementary school, through beautiful nature and lots of rice terraces and down hill roads until we reached the Tegalalang rice terrace. If you are in Ubud and you have the time and the chance to take such a bike tour, go for it! It is absolutely worth your time (and money). Ellen and Eva, Eindhoven, the Netherlands
Disappointing. The day I went is when they just planted the new saplings. I was unable to see the actual beauty of greenery
Disappointed there are better rice fields to see elsewhere. I have seen greater, more vast rice terraces in Bali, this is overrated and you have to pay to drive down the road rediculous

Beautiful . It's a lovely view but if your planning on trekking, be aware that they will make you pay (donations) along the way. At one place we said no and turned around to walk back and then he changed his mind and let us go through without paying.Just annoying behaviour while trying to enjoy the views.
Not so interesting to Chinese tourists. China has far more splendid and spectacular rices terraces! Can make it stop-to-take-some-photos spot when you visit other more exciting places.

Worth a bisit. Even though this site is now a major tourist attraction with many street stalls it's still worth a visit just to see it. It's beautiful to see all the terraces and if you're short on time on the way to other places you can swing by and just take a photo and have a look from the main road. Otherwise take the time to walk down and see farmers at work in the terraces. Go early to avoid the hot sun beating down which starts around 10am onwards.
Touristy and Over rated. Tegalalang Rice Terrace is exceptionally touristy. One should rather visit the rice terraces on the outskirts of the city.

Another beautiful view. Do stop here if you are on the way from or to Ubud. But not for the trip. The view is so beautiful. Must be crowded on a normal day but we went there on rainy season (it was raining a bit) so it wasn't too crowded as people told. We didn't walk along the rice fields because we were just stopped there for lunch. It was nice lunch too with the view of the rice fields.
WOWOWO. So beautiful!! Incredible how human intervention has created such a gem! The views are unique! Rent a scooter and go look for them yourself!

Beautiful Place. I came here because i read that this is the best rice terrace in ubud, which was it is...Need a little exercise to go down and get up but it was worth. So many shops around which is OK..

What a shame. Came here a few years ago and was lovely, revisited yesterday wow it how commercialised poor rice paddys have been trodden to death by tourist what a tragedy really dissapointed to see what has happened to this once picturesqe view.
Lush. The rice terraces are a must see if you are in the area, simply stunning - like functional works of art carved out of the landscape , definitely recommend.

Wonderfull. The biggest rice terrace! Balinese people are very proud of these rice terrace, the only one certified by Unesco. You can have history lessons listening about the way they work. The view is also wonderfull, and walk trought the aisle of the plantation will be a unique experience.

Beautiful . Walking through the rice fields was a beautiful experience. My friend and I were there in the middle of the afternoon so it was quite busy, you had to pay a small fee to cross a bridge which was strange. Yes there are young local children who try to sell things, we kindly said no and moved along. The views are breathtaking, you can stop at a cafe and have a bite and drink, and just enjoy the views.

Crowded and a bit dry. Impressive by their size, a bit crowded but still lovely place to visit and view rice terraces. The biggest drawback is the locals trying to maximize their profits from tourists and you will be repeatedly strongly encouraged to donate to various sections on the terrace (not sure that several wooden planks deserve 10000 rupiah). They can get verbally aggressive if you do not provide the requested cash

Lovely view. We visited when it was raining quite heavily. We didn't walk around the rice terrace but instead say in a restaurant overlooking it. We had delicious banana crepes and tea which more than made up for the rain. Very picturesque.

Lovely view, pity about the touts. Brought here as part of a day tour. The view itself is lovely. The shops on the road can be ignored as can the cafes.There are young children attempting to flog you postcards; not unlike Angkor In this regard but admittedly less persistent.My biggest gripe is the "donations" for maintenance. What was the IDR fee of 10000 for then? The unavoidable one is just past the bridge at the very bottom. From just before the next hut the views will probably be sufficient to soothe your selfie-needs and social media exploits!

Arrive early in the morning to beat the crowds. These terraces are stunning and if you get the chance to visit then you should take a few hours to really get out and explore. I timed my visit for dawn and had a peaceful couple of hours wandering around the nearly deserted rice fields. There are gatekeepers and donation points scattered around but it's not hard to hand over a few notes and help out the locals. Many work long hours to survive, often sleeping on site to ensure they are available at all hours. In fact, I arrived so early that I disturbed one of the gatekeepers still sleeping in her tiny shelter and I had to wait for her to get dressed so that I could pass : )Make sure you wear good walking shoes or boots and try not to damage the fields when you are clambering around. Respect the local farmers, but feel free to ask them about their work, most of them will be happy to talk and pose for pictures, especially if you have taken the time to learn a little Balinese.
Eh. It was ok. Bali's rice terraces generally pale in comparison to other Asian countries'. Good for a stop, don't make a trip.

Simply Incredible. Do not leave Bali with out seeing these rice fields and having lunch in the local restaurant. We visited here half way through our 10 day trip and found it to be the most beautiful scenery in Bali hands down. You can walk through the rice terraces for $10 Australian per person which was absolutely worth it. The view from the top is amasing. You'll want to taste the regions red rice pudding for dessert.

Be friendly and pay. Overall the terrace has a very nice view and if you have not seen it in real, definitely give it a shot. There are a lot of stations where you have to pay an"donation"... They get really unfriendly if you don't pay. The view on top is gorgeous. Be prepared to walk and step with no sign and being clueless about the way. It's normal. Plan 1h

A typical rice paddy scene. How beautiful and tranquil this small range of rice paddies on the mountain top in Ubud.Fascinating to wander through and get a good insight. I had lunch against the mountain side and it was a great stop to recover from a long trip and a very busy day.A local farmer cam to say Hello and was quite happy for me to take a photo. Life is definitely at a slower pace here! A beautiful spot to reflect.

nice little trek in nature. you can find rice paddies everywhere in Ubud. this is one of the terraced rice paddies that is popular with visitors. we went in the rainy season so it was muddy. it ended up being a solo hike for me! it was a nice experience. some climbing up and down to be done. keep some rupiahs ready for unofficial 'roadblocks' (forced donations)...

Killing the goose!. What a pity this beautiful place has been overwhelmed by the many commercial enterprises that hinder the views. The traffic is crowded. The best vantage points are now accessed via the many shops, cafes and outlets. Ask your driver to take you a couple of km further to the organic coffee farm where you can access unhindered views on the other side of the hill!

Nice view, not as big as you might think. We drive past on our way back from Mount Batur. The driver didn't stop as they charge for parking there. Sounds like a bit of a tourist trap. But he did slow down for us to enjoy the view. It does look lovely but isn't a grand view of rice terraces like the famous ones in China. Still worth checking out if you're renting a bike or something anyway

Still beautiful post-harvest. The rice was mostly gone when I was there but this area is magnificent. The terraces are spectacular in most every direction you look. Be prepared for some walking and tread steadily as some areas can be steep and slippery. Take some small change as there are huts along the way as you pass to a new families area. At these huts they'll ask for a donation. I wouldn't pay more than 5,000IDR if I were you as you'll have around 8 of these points. Also be aware that the lovely old people carrying the rice on their shoulders that offer photographs also want money. One lady asked me for 50,000IDR so I deleted the photo. They don't make you aware of a charge before hand so be prepared. It is not offensive though, just letting you know to take small change. Well worth a visit to see such an iconic view.

Beautiful Rice Fields of Bali. The rice fields in Bali are an epic view and part of the island. Tegalalang is great, and I would advise climbing it and checking it out. We went here as part of a day tour, and they rushed us here, and tried to get us out of there as quick as possible. we go some great photos, and saw some people hiking and climbing it. This is not he best place to see rice fields, but they were wonderful.

Amazing rice terraces. best rice terraces just few minute northern path of Ubud, amazing trekking route also available , it spend around an hour from the beginning and return to the start point.surrounding are so green and will feel like in the forest with pretty temperature

Amazing experience. This is something one MUST see when in Ubud. If you can, get a local guide to explain you the technique behind the paddy fields, how the villages divide the rice and how things changed in the last years.

An attraction goes down. I have been to the Tegalalang rice terraces many times over the past ten years and observed the process of commercialism and tourism of this once beautiful setting. One could somehow life with the fact that there is no empty spot left on the observation side of the valley. Every meter is occupied with coffee shops and restaurants selling the spectacular views. Both yesterday I was shocked seeing tourists walking through the rice terraces. Herds of tourists walking on this delicate soil, will definitely destroy the whole construction which will be the end of this Bali attraction.
Culture experience.. This is a must for travelers to Bali, to be able to see the country side in all its glory is a privilege it is truly breath taking.

Gorgerous setting with bus loads of crowds. What was once a working tea farm, it is now run mostly for the tourists who come by the bus loads each day. While the crowds are a distraction, it is still a worthwhile destination for the views. Easy to get to from Ubud.

A must see!. We could not be happier with our trip to the rice fields! Everything was so green and beautiful. The walk was pleasant but was a bit slippery at some points so wear proper shoes. They ask for donations along the way to help keep maintenance up - we didn't know before and didn't have small change. This is a must do!

Too much ado about nothing. Bali is plenty of rice terraces as beautiful or better than Tegalalang, I think nowadays is a tourist trap, with shops and more shops selling the same thing. Outside Ubud no one will sell you more sarongs and there are plenty of rice paddies to walk
There are several ricefields but this place is different.. There are several rice fields around Ubud but this place is different and a must see even though its crammed with tourists you will love it.

vendors and sellers have taken over..... i have been there before years ago and there was one lady selling sarongs at the time - now the traffic is so bad that everything is sop and go - no parking and the tourists descend on this view and destroy it. the previous empty road from where you could overlook the rice fields is now filled with cafes and souvenir shops that block the view and everybody is pushing a special offer. even the rice farmer is fake and just poses for pictures with the bamboo tray with with grass for a fee. tourism frenzy at its worst.
Breathtaking. I always return here. The view of the rice fields are incredible. Highly recommend eating something in one of the restaurants while looking at these fields.

Not as pretty but closer than the others. This is pretty close to Ubud. There are much prettier terraces further away on way to Besakih. This is kind of a tourist trap. Lots of stores selling stuff. I did like the Luwak coffe place that is here.

Nice terraces for a quick picture. Nice view of the terraces. Not as spectacular as I was expected, as too close to the road. Very busy and popular. Lots of shops and restaurants around. Entrance $10 K/pp. You can walk down to observe them from close proximity.

Close to nature. If you are in Ubud, definitely go to this place. The step farming is beautifully done and shapes the rice fields in terrace like pattern. The surrounding is lush green and quite usually. I won't recommend climbing it down too much below the road level, let it is in its natural form. Just go, sit for a while, take pics and come back. If you are going back to Ubud from here, try it in the evening before sunset. If you are lucky, you can see huge flocks of herons returning to their homes in Petulu village. It's a lovely sight.

Not unique. It was the cultivation period when we visited, the terrace wasn't really majestic. its much better to see it during summer I guess. I wasn't so impressed, maybe cause I saw much better terraces in other places in Asia. good to visit if you're passing by or if you're in Ubud

Beautiful greenery, sit at a cafe and enjoy the views. I think to visit this place, you have to pay twice, once upon entering and another upon trekking the rice terrace. it is called a rice terrace but there are no rice that i can see. we opted for sitting by a cafe looking over the entire terrace and had a chilled afternoon coconut water. stalls on the side sells some nice painting that can be bargained way down than what you'd be ask to pay at a proper gallery.

Serene Lunch Stop. A beautiful rice terrace with plenty of places to sit and eat, you can walk down to the fields but be respectful its peoples livelihoods. I recommend it as a stop on your way to Kintamani.

Stunning greenery of Ubud . This is a must see in Ubud.We motor biked from JL Bisma to this sight and it was great! It suddenly poured with rain when we arrived so we ducked into a little restaurant overlooking the terraces for a ginger tea. The route to and from here is dotted with artisans and temples so it's an experience not to be missed.
Rice Cultivation in Hilly Region. Beautiful view, good for walking/trekking around. There are a few Cafe's to relax and enjoy the natural beauty.
The real Bali. The Bali farmers working hard in their rice paddies, the paddies in Florese are bit more intresting done like a spider web but these are still fantastic
Beautiful terrace view. was a rain day so cant do much but the view is like real bali. Was so peaceful moment but locals push for money every moments. really disappoint for that

Day trip from Ubud. It's very close to Ubud. Rent a bike (which is so cheap) and head out for the rice terrace. You can park the bike at the car parking. If you continue on the same road you can reach Bali Pulina Agro Tourism which is a coffee plantation. A good recommendation for coffee tasting and sitting on their terrace. The coffee tasting is not expensive, but they will try to sell their coffee which is pricey. I bought their Bali coffee which was good in order to bring home.

Beautiful and nice. A nice and beautiful view. We can spend time with family while having a cup of coffee and banana fritter. There is many outlets selling local products along the way/by the road side.

Picturesque rice terrace views. Around the town of Tegallalang, which is strung out along the main road, are several places to stop for a scenic view of rice terraces.It's a pleasant short stop as part of a day or half-day tour (combines well with a visit to a coffee farm, and Tampaksiring's temple attractions).Unless you love hiking, and have plenty of time to spare, probably no need to descend to the bottom. One of my pics is facing east off the main road; the other is looking west from the coffee farm terrace.
Amazing. Wonderful place for visiting. Amazing view of the rice terrace. Must see when in Bali. Short drive from Ubud.

Menu is simple.. The view is splended.
Yakimeshi nashi-golen is so good.
Yakisoba mea-gplen is also good.
Soup is so so.

A beautiful view awaits you!. While it was raining when we visited here the view from the top of the village is stunning. The green panorama of the terraced rice fields makes for an amazing scene and a view worth seeing in my opinion. Yes there are many little shops at the top and some along the way however I did not find any of them pushy. Yes there are some school aged children trying to sell post cards with the message--I need to sell these to go to school. Don't let this keep you from seeing this attraction.

Get in!!. we have visited rice terrace around 10 am but it was already way too hot!! so unless it is rainy be prepared for the heath. we were asked a small entrance fee, like everywhere in the entire Bali... the view is amazing from the top but I strongly recommend going all the way down and then top. It was very strange though... we were stopped by a woman who did not let us cross the bridge unless we pay a "donation!!!!) so get ready to donate something if you want to climb all the way up.

Just a view but could be so much more. Unfortunately rain made this a photo stop for us and not more. But I can see the potential of this stunning location. Without two tired toddlers in tow, we would have sat in any one of the cafes overlooking the terraces and chilled the day away.

It would of been better with a full rice field . It was incredible to see how far the rice field goes in this area. Advise it's best to go early morning due to the heat from the sun. Was a little disappointed it had only just had fresh rice planted so didn't get to see it in full bloom.

Beautiful Terraces. I took a guided tour through the rice terraces, Bali Nature walks I believe it was called. Although the fields themselves were gorgeous I think the tour was helpful as he was able to explain a lot about the nature, the working of the rice fields and some other interesting tidbits to me. Its a lovely walk and a beautiful way to submerge yourself in nature for a couple of hours. It gets hot though so dress for the sun if you need to.
Beautiful views!. We visited here when it was pouring with rain and it didn't spoil the view, it was very beautiful and interesting. Beware of children trying to sell you postcards though!
too much. Beautiful view ruined by the sellers and the fact that tourists can now go and walk around the rice fields which somehow spoils the vista.

Prepare to give money along way. Beautiful. Go in morning before it gets too hot. They have locals at various points along the trail asking for donations and can be very demanding. Lady at end will offer photos with her and then ask for money, was not happy with the amount and got very angry.

Beautiful Place. Beautiful views but Lots and Lots of tourists... May other rice paddys to see that are away from the crowds.
But good to add to your monkey forest trip..

Majestic view!. Yes, i have seen google images of this place but i felt sooo humble when i saw it with my own eyes. Total beaut! You'll have to go down loads of steps to get to the beginning of the terrace. I stopped there because unfortunately I'm not great with balance.I'm sure it would have been a great experience to explore the whole rice terrace, meeting the farmers along the way :)

Nothing New or Different. I have visited many tea and coffee plantations and didn't find anything different or new here at all, the others I have visited were really awesome, hence I was not impressed with this much. The view is good but the concept of rice terrace is made keeping in mind the tourist and doesn't come across as natural and real. There are many stairs down and then one needs to come back up (around 250 to 300 stairs), hence I don't suggest one visits with elders or young children as reaching the terrace is difficult but just views the same from the viewing galleries which are a plenty there, there are many coffee shops around with the view and one can spend sometime there as well.
One of the must visit in Bali. Aside from the beautiful Rice Terrace, you can also enjoy the local delicacy around the area with awesome view, shopping and nice local people to take picture with

Incredible. I cant begin to describe how incredible this view is. It is like looking at picture it is so pretty. The market stalls beside the Rice Terrace are fabulous if you like the traditional patchwork quilts its the prefect place to buy one or like me more than one.

A great sight. We didn't walk through the terraces, however we did stop at a restaurant and admire the view. It's a shame the top road gets so busy, but that's tourism. If you can get down off the road, even a small way, you can appreciate the terraces for the calmness and quiet they bring. Even with people dotted along the landscape (those who were out walking on them), it didn't detract from the sight. It's worth a trip up there if you're staying in Ubud.

Awesome View, Maximum an hour visit. We passed by the rice terrance on our way to Ubud the view is awesome and breath taking. you can stay there for a coffee and enjoy the view nothing more than that.The flavor of coffee is really good but the prices of the coffee there is really overpriced. don't plan a day for it, its just a location with a nice view and that it.

Nice sights. The Rice Terraces in Tegalalang are a great place to venture for stunning views and green scenery. It's set next to a little town full of souvenier shops. As you make your way to the terraces you will quickly notice the many children trying to sell postcards or give you a tour in hopes of raising money for their "school". Also, you have to pay the locals about 4 or 5 times to continue on the path for upkeep. I understand their needs, but it is a little excessive and they aren't very nice about it.
Beautiful!. Best part of our tour, the terraces are fantastic. So peaceful, calming. Take your time to see the different shades of green!

Memorable Views. We arrived here by private driver late afternoon. There weren't so many tourists and it was just breathtaking the views of the terraces.You are able to get great views of the terraces along the road or you can venture down a little to see more uninterrupted views. We ventured down a little and I spoke to a lovely local cafe owner who had various cattleya and phalaenopsis orchids on display around his cafe, his knowledge and hospitality was just as memorable as the views. We weren't pressured to eat there or buy anything but I gave him a donation for using his toilet.

Lovely but begging is off putting. Lovely rice terraces but the constant insistence of locals to "donate" an entry and exit fee (we were asked 4 times) is off putting. If you don't donate, the locals don't give you passage. Sad and annoying.

Majestic beauty. Amazing beauty the rice fields are a terraced vivid green a sculpture in nature.The best way to really experience the rice fields is to hike the path to the top ofThe hillside. You will pass through several huts where you will be asked to pay a small fee to continue on path it's well worth it when you reach the top.There are also photo ops to don a hat and rice buckets and have one of the riceHarvesters take your photo fun of course there is a fee but it's small. A must see
Sightseeing. Bring your walking shoes. Views are amazing. Never knew there are so many varieties of rice. Well worth a visit.
Amazing view. Nice place to visit and the view of the rice fields is breath taking. Its vast and looks really amazing on the mountain slopes.
Amazing sight. There is unbelievable beauty in looking out over these rice fields. Bring water and an umbrella in the event of showers. We had rain but it did not distract from the beauty.
Nice views. But I don't get why you have to pay to see natural scenery?The restaurants with the views are nice to sit and overlook everything.
AWESOME!!. Its so peacefull! You sit in cafe and take a pics or you can go around and take a tour to rice field terrace to explore and take a selfie.

A must see place. We rented a scooter from our Ubud resort and went there in 10 mins. It has a beautiful view and very relaxing to walk in the rice terrace. There are lots of cafes and restaurants overlooking the terrace where you may rest and enjoy the view. Also loads of souvenir shops are around.

Refreshing Scenery!. At this famous rice terrace, the landscape was green, and great to capture footage and photos. Keep in mind walking down the pathway can be slippery and steep! Not suitable for unfit individuals. Luckily we had amazing weather to top it off.

Kind of OK. If you have never seen rice terraces so far, it is definitely worth to see the agricultural architecture.If you have seen or will see the much more sophisticated and impressive terraces in north Vietnam or Longshen, China, you can skip it.Anyway, you will most likely pass by on your way to the volcano or a Luvak coffee tasting.
Spend 5 minutes to take some pictures here. The road is pretty narrow there, so it's better to just take some pictures here. Of course you may enjoy some coffee and snack as well.
Beautiful landscape. Beautiful landscape and views. Nice to see the workers climbing a palm, the common dresses to work, like a centuty ago

Great for photo Ops. Terraces paddy field with all the greenery will give you a very scenic selfie/wefie background.
Walk down will give you a good exercise.
Great View, worth the visit. If you happen to go, try to climb down and up to the rice terraces, there is a wooden bridge and the view up there is magnificent.
Beautiful place with plenty of cafes and shops. One of the most enjoyable places around Ubud. Tegalalang offers plenty of rice terraces. You can find great shops and cafes on both sides of the road.
Good 1/4 day trip. My boyfriend and I really enjoyed our stop here. We left our driver on the main street and then walked over into the Rice Terrace. Take some change to pay the bridge lady.
Beautiful views!!. Was pouring with rain on our visit, but wow the views are amazing! If your going on a day tour definitely stop to check out the view of the rice terraces!
just beautiful. I had the opportunity to eat lunch and just stare out into this landscape. Just so beautiful. I would go back.

Nice place to take pictures of rice paddies. Beautiful views but crowded with tourists waiting to take a shoot or a selfie. They are other areas around very nice and without coaches of tourists queuing for a snap!

Bring your camera!. When you get to Tegalalang Rice Terrace you will be looking at the rice terraces from the other side, this makes a perfect location to get a good shot of this Balinese agricultural traditions. Unless you want to walk on the terraces I don't recommend to pay for a tour to just see this place, it is better if you organise a day tour and visit several locations and then include Tegalalang Rice Terrace as a pit stop.
Spectacular views.. Must see in the Ubud area. At the time of the visit........no rice though. One word of warning. Beware of the cute young girls selling postcards 'to finance a school project'.

Very beautiful. Absolutely beautiful. A must see location. Great photo opportunity! Would highly recommend!
We went down to a market stall to take photos- stall owner offered to take photos of us. We tipped on this occasion.

Rice and than some.... Nice experience walking through the rice terraces. Be prepared to get your footwear dirty if you want to explore some shortcuts... Lovely view of the terraces from the village bars but nothing spectacular though once you are in the rice fields. Otherwise worth a visit if you are in Ubud area...
Picturesque. Definitely worth checking out to see the real Bali! Arranged a driver to take us to Ubud market, temples and rice terrace. Was a great way to fit in lots in the one morning!

Breathtaking in every respect. Challenging drive to get to these fields, but well worth the drive (we took taxi...Agunk Torres of Ubud Area Tours). This is a very popular place and it is understandable after seeing it. The terracing is nothing short of amazing.

Quick stop by. This was a quick stop for us to get a drink and enjoy the view, stayed about 20-30 minutes and it was amazing view, wish I had more time to eat/stay as it was the last thing on our tour!

Great view!. Stunning place to take panoramic photos of the landscape. If you take the tour take good walking shoes and a bottle of water. Great opportunity to learn and appreciate something as simple as a grain of rice.

Looked Pretty From Afar. Well everyone says if you visit Ubud you must see their rice paddies and so here I was on a hired motorbike to get a glimpse of the sight. No doubt it's beautiful and looked awesome from the top but that's it, there's not much else to do there. Although there are a few cafes around there's not much to do once you've seen the beauty from afar . the paddies looked spectacular from the top as you see in the pictures.

Stunning . It's about a 30 minute scooter ride from Ubud, the drive offers lovely sights. My boyfriend and I drove up a bit further and got a private tour, he walked us around for about 2 hours, the way we went was very strenuous, especially down the bottom when the humidity sets in so definitely bring water, a hat and wear good shoes.
great place to visit. this place is picturesque lots of shops selling cheaper wares and food just ok- You have to pay for privilege to drive in $1.00 pax. good photo opp

A great view but not what I expected. It is a nice place but I expected something more immersed in the nature instead of only restaurants and shops around. However it is a unique plafr that csn be only found in Ubud

Beautiful scenery, but little else. The rice terrace itself was great to look across from the road. There were the usual shops and stalls, and restaurants. People trying to sell things to tourists, and some children selling postcards. The road was busy and noisy. We only escaped this by visiting a nice restaurant near the top of the hill to look out over the terrace in peace. Although we had no problems, we were told by the driver to beware of beggars and pickpockets, which is why we didn't venture too far into the place itself. Overall, nice to see, but couldn't stay too long.

Awesome terrace and views. Definitely a must do when in Ubud. Make sure you bring enough small notes as there are a few stops where you need to make a donation to pass through. I wore runners which made the walk around easier. A great restaurant to have lunch at after your walk. I am definitely coming back to do this again.

Beautiful views. I believe there's an entrance fee for going in. I just stood outside to snap photos. There's actually many beautiful rice terraces just north of Ubud, similar to the ones seen here. Even at the top of the entrance going to the elephant cave there's gorgeous views of rice terraces.
Okay. Postcards show a better view than today, which is cluttered with small shops and agressive sales people.
Stunning beauty. We saw it as we drove by, but if we had the time we would have spent it there to get to see more of it.

Very crowded. There are a lot of rice fields in Bali, this place is a bit of a tourist trap. You pay to enter 5,200 IDR pp (about $0.35 USD) and your driver or guide has a difficult time trying to find a parking spot. The narrow road is littered with vendors and food stalls. We opted to not hike down as it was hot and we already walked among the rice fields at Pura Gunung Kawi. It was nice to see, if you went early or late for the sunset I'm sure it would be beautiful.
Nice but not that nice. They're really nice to get a few pictures of, and maybe it was just us but we weren't allowed to go walking anywhere near the terraces. It's a good time filler

Unique ! . We went to Tegalalang Rice Terrace on 30 Jan. The entrance fees is 10.000 IDR per person. The weather was really hot but we definitely prefer this rather than raining ! We choose to walk on the top but scenery was spectacular enough to be framed. We even had our lunch there while enjoying the unreal scenery of this famous Bali's rice terrace spot.
Beautiful. Very beautiful view of terraced rice fields. We didn't hike through them but did see a few people doing it.
Awesome views. Great spot to just relax and admire the view, the landscape layout is unreal great to take some photos and so green and lush.
Not that nice. We visited there after the monkey forest ,not really nice .far from the road actually and we like most of the visitor are just standing there and took few pictures

Beautiful. There is a nice view of the rice terrace very green though the Weather is hot so be prepared. This is a must see while visiting Bali. You can shop around as well and eat at the cafe/restaurants surrounding the place. They have a photo spot where you can see the view and take nice photos
Amazing view. go to this place and walk through the terraces. views is amazing for need green views for your eyes. amazing

Amazing view. Very beautiful view. fresh air. really a heaven on earth. if you have plan to escape for a while from all of your problems, this is the right place. 1 thing that make me give score 4 is because a lot of people throwing garbage (local people I guess). Too bad.

Beautiful rice paddy trek. Definitely do this! It's a short but steep trek through working rice paddies. Great photo opps. Be ready to give a small donation when you arrive (we gave 7,000IDR for two so a little less than $1USD). Beware local workers who wave at you to take pictures and then want money. Lesson learned.

Interesting. Interesting and amazing views from the top, can go for a walk through the terraces which was quite good. Couple locals asking to take their photo then ask for money. Very beautiful scenery , good for photo opportunities .

Pretty view for lunch- part of stock standard day trip in Ubud. The view of the rice terrace is beautiful. We came here to eat lunch on our "day in Ubud". I've been to Bali before and been here before but my friends hadn't and I thought it was worthy for them to see, so i'd say it's worthy for you to see too! Whether there are better ones around, I don't know. But this one is obviously well known, and offers quite a beautiful view. There's nothing really to do there, other than have lunch while enjoying the view. We did a mountain hike in the morning so we didn't walk through the fields. Summary: We did the Mount Batur hike in the morning. 2am pick up at our hotel. 4am start for the walk and finished about 11am finish. We hired a driver for the rest of the day. We picked our itinerary which included a coffee plantation, Tegalalang Rice Terrace for lunch, 2 temples and the Monkey Forest. This is pretty much the stock standard day trip to Ubud. (Well aside from the mountain hike)
A must see. An amazing site the beautiful rice terraces, can't believe all man made without machinery.Set in beautiful surroundings, also can enjoy lunch at one of the nearby cafes.

Excellent to stop by or go from Ubud. If you never seen a ladder Rice field, Tegalalang is a good place to go from Ubud, Of course you still need a car or bike. this rice field shows a typical Bali style rice ladder terrace and you can feel this is a interested tourist point. However, if you really want to see a spectacular magnificent rice terrace. It is not here.

a very nice Location. slightly Overrated and very Touristy...it changed a lot in btwn the last years and the flying traders are sometimes very penetrant...restopricing over there is quiet expensive for the Value u get...good for an photo or two or talking an overpriced horseride....but surely not for lunch and dinner

Beauty Revisited. Such stunning rice terraces! Love the fact you are able to take photos as you wish and not be pestered to pay for the pleasure.
Had planned to walk amongst the terraces but due to rainy season everything underfoot was a bit stoggy so decided that can be a 'next visit' thing.
Natural beauty that's just stunning!

Terrace Padi Panorama. Bali offers the best views of rice terraces. It's a nice location near Ubud to spend a day enjoying the sights and sounds of the nature in sprawling green villages . Like in China or Vietnam rice terraces and the traditional irrigation methods are distinct. Lots of tourists visit these locations to experience the spectacular views of landscape and paddy columns. You can also enjoy the Balinese traditional hospitality from the nearby terrace restaurants . A peaceful experience to be enjoyed !
Absolutely awesome place to see on person. Spectacular views!! The small cafes and eateries have vantage points to see across to the terraces, or you can walk through the terraces also!!

Do a bike tour. I would suggest to do a bicycle tour in the area as you get to see a lot of smaller rice fields and authentic villages along the way. Travelling from this area back to Ubud is mostly downhill so an enjoyable tour to do.
Soothing scenery. This place is frequently visited by foreigner. Once i steped out of the car, i just wanna stay and look at the green and terasering that gave me a soothing feeling

Touristic views to which there are better. It is nice to have a view over the terraces yet along the road when making a little effort much nicer terraces can be found, not lines up with all the stalls with the same tourist crap.

Underwhelmed!!!. Start with the fact you pay on way into town and agian to park. Then you are part of a mob scene all trying to take the perfect photo of a terraced hillside that is obviously now just a tourist attraction rather than a real set of working rice paddies. Would much rather have gone farther afield and seen the real thing unencumbered with souvenir shops and refreshment stands!!!
Not the right time of year!. Nice to see in person, however wrong season so it looked nothing like the photos. Very popular with tourists. Would definitely go back.
A bit disappointing. Nice to see but nothing special, we thought it would be water filled field,but no activity. Do not go here this time of year, it's a long detour.

Image the undertaking with only hand tools.. I'm not at all sure when the terraces were hued from the hillside. I can only imagine that it happened well before modern equipment would have been available to the rice farmers here. Terracing with hand tools would be very difficult and the hillsides here are quite steep. It really is an engineering marvel on the part of the people and a model of perseverance for today's young people. Certainly worth the stop to check it out.

beautiful. we weren't lucky enough to see the rice fields in full glory but still nice to have seen the terraces anyway. I imagine its fun to do a bicycle tour but we didn't because the heat was to much that day!

Breathtaking Scenery in the Rice Paddies. Absolutely loved doing this trek and seeing the stunning views of the rice paddies. I recommend wearing runners as there are lots of steep steps and slippery slopes throughout the walking path. Despite this, it's a great group activity that lets you see just how picturesque Bali can be.
Serene peaceful. Breath nature, fresh air. Inhale - exhale. Scenic beautiful, they look like painted landscapes. The place is amazing.

More to Bali than you think. Have been coming to Bali for some years now and can't believe I have never visited this spot. If you are staying in Seminyak or Legian you will need a driver which will take you about 90 minutes to get there. The trip out there gives you a chance to see some of the local villages and more traditional way of living. Well worth a trip.

Breathtaking views. The view into a steep valley with partly very small rice fields is awesome, really fantastic. Newly there is a parking lot provided but nevertheless the traffic jam, often caused by large busses, is less enjoyable. But it is caused by us, the tourists... Despite this and the sometimes too diligent vendors it is worth seeing
Nice to see.. Its a nice to see, but I wont recommend driving all the way to Ubud just to see. Make it a stop on the way from or to something. Looks much better on the photos.
Gorgeous!. The rice terraces are stunning. We took a cycling tour and were just in awe. You don't find this natural beauty just anywhere. Love love love!

Better rice fields at Gunung Kawi. We went there, its full of people walking around, so many people that some of the terraces were collapsed and dry. Its been transformed into a tourist trap with market stalls and beggars and frankly you can see more breath taking rice field views at the Gunung Kawi temple.
Beautiful scenery. Visited the rice fields but the farmers had already plough the wheat. Then again, the acenery there is very beautiful. So many cafes nearby and shops.
Very Beautiful to see. Tegalalang is a very beautiful area. Worth stopping here and taking in all the beauty of the site. Found this to be a very beautiful area to take pictures and enjoy lunch at.

Must go. Very Famous and so touristic,..., but awesome rice terrace.
To do at least once if you visit Bali Island.

Spectacular scenery . Stopped here briefly before start of cycling tour to take a few photos. The scenery is spectacular, so green and beautiful, would love to go back and explore the terraces properly.

Just love it... Been here twice, and I love to drink coffee from the cafe that has a terrace outlook.. Locals ask donation about 10000 rupiah/person and I was given like small ticket. it doesn't matter though, since the view is really gorgeous.
Rain stop. Do not spent your money entering the sppt. There are couple of spots near the main road with best view and cafe service hot dishes and beverages... espessialy when it rains :)
Great cultural experience.... Was wonderful to be able to wonder around an actual rice field and experience the culture first hand.....Lot's of steps but work the exercise...

Beautiful views !. Great views from the terrace. We did not do the walk down to the rice fields rather just took the touristy photos from the terrace as it was really hot that day. The views are beautiful and definitely worth a visit if you are in Ubud

Beautiful rice terraces, make sure you take a little money with you!. Stunning spot to walk among the rice terraces and watch the locals at work. Be aware that your driver will have to pay to park while you go for a walk, and that the locals will also ask for donations to cross bridges or to stop and have photos with them. We didn't realise this and had to return to the car for some Rp when one lady guarding a bamboo bridge got VERY cranky with us for not making a donation! Fair enough I guess! There are numerous warung and clothes shops up the top where you can sit and take photos or recover from your walk. A tip - wear sturdy walking shoes! I had rubber thongs (flip-flops) on and they really didn't cut the mustard on the steep slopes.
Awesome trip. Just amazing place. But little bit traffic. But still fine. I was enjoy my trip in bali and ubud. Will be back

Worth flying round the world to see. Do not be put off by tourist shops on road. There are good viewing points on road but best way to experience the terraces is on the marked walking trail where you can have the terraces much more to yourself. About an hours trek in the heat but so worth it. In there way as iconic as other world ranking places to see.
Beautiful like a painting. Beautiful view just like a painting. You have to take some photos there and post them on your social media. hahaha
Beauty of Ceking Terraces. Do you know that there is a road through rice fields that will lead you to the opposite side of rice terraces directly. Not necessary to climb terraces..

Not bad. Before go to Kintamani from Ubud. You have to pass this place and you will be amazed by the rice terrace on your right side. You can stop, go to the terrace and take photos or enjoy the scenery from the restaurant while you enjoying your lunch or just drink hot coffee or hot tea.
Beautiful views great lunch. Very nice place to sit ,relax and enjoy the view. Restaurants are great and reasonably priced. A great spot to stop for lunch when exploring Ubud

A nice stopover on our tour. It was one of the stops on our day long tour we booked with "Bali Incredible Tours". When we arrived it started drizzling but we grabbed an umbrella and went down for a quick walk... Most of the rice paddies were clear cut as it was past the harvest, or just being seeded. But given the periodic rains, the whole village was beautifully lush and green. Really nice views!!!Now, the whole village is set up to cater to tourists so there wasn't anything authentic about it, lots of coffee shops, restaurants, trinkets and souvenirs everywhere, a kind of a "tourist trap". We spent there all-in-all about half an hour and it was plenty.
Spectacular view. This place is stunning. Definitely worth the trip. Not too far north of Ubud. Plenty of cafes to sit and eat or have a drink while enjoying the view.

One of many impressive rice terraces in Indonesia. Our private guide took us there on the way back from some other attractions. The overlook was impressive and crowded with vendors trying to sell us something. The views were good and the sun was out but it is not worth a long drive unless it is on the way from somewhere else. You only need a few minutes to take it all in.

This is magnificent. It;s a really lovely experience and I recommend to everyone going there. The only disadvantage the "toll stations" the locals have made all around the walk area where they are asking for money several times, even though the amount is not big.

Worth the trip!. Such incredible views here, so glad I decided to come here. Unfortunately it was pouring rain during my visit, but still managed to get some great photos and soak in everything this place has to offer. Also made some friends with the local children selling postcards, very cute!

A glance of traditional rice field. Definite touristic spot. Its better to have covered footwear, it can get quite muddy especially during rainy season and there are some walking to do if u want to get a good spot for photographs.
Beautiful views. We had lunch at the restaurant overlooking the rice fields and the view was amazing - finished off with some brief shopping across the road
Stunning Views. Stunning views! Make sure to sit and have a drink or a meal while here. It's a great location to take a break or do some shopping too!

BEAUTIFUL FARMLAND. Wow! What a site to see!
This is a must do to take some wonderful pictures and to see what the Balinese culture does on a daily basis as a means of agriculture.
Awesome views!. Super busy road, but the views, they are just wonderful! Stop by and admire them! You will not be sorry!

Great views. It was nice to walk along and see how the rice field looks. Do more than just stand at the top and take pictures. Go though the fields and explore them. The only annoying part was having to pay these rice field workers money to get through certain parts of the field. We were fine with giving money to the local people of the fields but by the 4th one we were out of money and annoyed. Not sure if it's really required, more like a nice gesture to do....but we did have one guy who made it seem required and wouldn't let us by. Other than that it was a nice experience. I mean after all we are walking all over their farm land.

Visit to rice terraces . Worth a visit! Hard work walking , narrow and exhausting for those who are not physically fit! You have to pay a several check points but worth it if you enjoy nature. For those who just enjoy a view, stay at the restaurant and have lunch
Rice Terrace. We just stopped by this place to view the rice terrace. Could not enjoy when the sun was hot, but spent a bit of time there when it started drizzling and the place cooled down.

Breath taking view.. A worthy place and a must visit tourist attraction. However, our hired driver only took as at the road side to take pics of the paddy field. We couldnt go round the paddy field because he doesnt know the access to it so we try to go down thru one of the restaurant by the roadside however, the narrow walkway is very steep and dangerous. Therefore, we could only manage to take pics for the roadside.
Beautiful!. We hired a car and driver and visited after the monkey temple. the terraces are beautiful and well maintained. The township is pretty.

Beautiful scenery - fascinating for the kids! . Never seen rice grown in the wild before, so definitely an education experience for the kids. Easy to get to, a short drive from the hustle and bustle of Kuta.

Good but not great!. The views are great - I would recommend just hanging around at the start for the best views --> click a few good pics --> sip a coconut and head out to the next destination. I have been to Tegalalang twice and haven't experienced the need to take the walk all the way around. It might differ from person to person though.

Beautiful... walk around. We stopped and took some pictures then walked down to the cafes but I dont recommend drinking tea there (Bali Belly for sure!). Just sit and order something bottled. It is beautiful and close to the woodcarvers workshops and the famous Garudas (Balinese giant eagle).

Great view. On the way to Ubud from Kuta we visited here. In the right front of it there is 2 level restaurant where you can see that rice paddy while enjoying your food and drink. It is near the coffee plantation which you must visit as well.

Not worth the effort... Yes they are good to look at but you must have the stamina to take the long, long, long trip down and the hike it all the way up. There is a restaurant if you want to eat but we saw some disgusting habits by the kitchen staff and did not stay. Our driver took us to some local rice fields as we were very interested in the process which was much better and flatter.

Wow!! . Beautiful view! Walked through the rice fields, and got a good taste of this Balinese culture. I wish it wasn't so hot, and I would have walked around much longer... Instead I sat and have an iced coffee at the cafe over looking the rice field.
Beautiful. These rice fields were beautiful and very green! We enjoyed the view while sipping ice coffee with our amazing tour guide!

Travelling with family. It really was nice view, but we only can take a picture without any activity. Maybe if you want to explore more you can ask travel guide but not recommended if you with infant.

Amazing views. We hired a driver for the day and this was our last stop. It is very commercialized but the views are fantastic. We were feeling a bit tired at the end of the day and the rain was threatening so we decided not to walk down the terraces but opted for a cold drink at one of the several cafes overlooking the terraces.

Disappointed due to bad timing. Apparently our visit was 2 weeks after they had picked the rice, so it wasn't as spectacular as others' pics suggest. Of course, that's part of the cycle so not anyone's fault. Just would be best to check ahead before making the trek. We recommend checking out the rice fields just off the main road of Ubud.

The beauty of the terraces overshadowed by the beggars and commercialism . The terraces themselves are very beautiful. It looked fun to climb and would be great for pictures. Every few meters there were locals blocking the paths and demanding money to pass. The beggars were so distracting that my wife fell off the terrace and was injured. They and approached us on narrow dirt walking paths and would say 20000 rupiah to pass and go further. Kids ran the paths and tried to sell packs of old post cards for 150000 Rupiah. There were shops and crafts in stores near the terraces and the shop owners were very aggressive. Good buys were to be had here with a little negotiation.

beautifulll. it is a beautiful view, if you are sporty it is a nice walk . otherwise you can still admire it from the coffee shop terrasses. but is is very touristic and crowded. we went on off season and was nice .
Amazing Views!. Well worth the trip if you want to see the Terraced Rice Fields, best time to go is early afternoon so the sun is not directly in your camera. Great photo opportunity!

Great photo ops.. Very pretty views and a great short hike up and down the rice terraces. It will test out any knee issues you have though, and only part of the walk is suitable for kids under 10. But if you can't do the hike, just look at the view from the village cafes and shops on the opposite hill side. And we hardly noticed the touts and hawkers when we were there. Our taxi guy stopped and showed us rice being harvested and also the huge yoga retreat / resort on the way. Well worth a half day trip, then back to the pool...

Breathtakingly beautiful scenery. A photographers dream which was why I was here at sunrise. The mist in the valleys and the every shade of green imaginable...what more could you need. I had a little trouble getting into the fields as I am disabled but managed to still get some spectacular shots.
Nice. Nice to view, fresh green look of rice terrace. Like the small cafes made along side the roaf for having some coffee and enjoy the view

Impressive views but go early. Lots of exposed paths through the paddies, so will be brutally hot by mid-morning. Great views and quite a bit of climbing, so a good workout. The only bit that was annoying was the woman who literally blocked my path and insisted on a "donation" to help preserve the paddies?! Pretty sure that is a scam.
Calm place. I think this place is slightly overrated especially for a person from the southern part of India. You can see such fields everywhere.

In touch with flora & fauna. The best way to get in touch with nature...see the rice terrace up close & personal. Nothing can beats that...the views were breathtaking & you can feel the peacefulness of Ubud, Bali.

Scenic Views. Visited here quite briefly.The terrace is vast with beautiful, scenic views. Visitors are freely able to walk down into the terrace as they wish.Small market stalls surround the terrace, with some scenic cafes.Good for a quick visit.
Beautiful. This is one of the most breath taking sites i have ever laid eyes on simply amazing i had never seen anything so well kept and beautiful !!! A must see

Jan is post-harvest season, not the best time to go. Rice terraces are always beautiful because they are attractions not built with violence (like the castles of europe or china's great walls). They are functioning food sources and they are attractions co-created by man and nature.I would warn you though that it's a bit diffucult to experience this site deeply given the many tourists going for that 'jump-off-the-cliff' selfie shots and whatnots...Be ready for some walking. If not, ask your driver (do get a driver if you plan to visit bali. Message me to get a reco) to drop you off at one of the scenic spots to just enjoy an overview of the terraces.For shoppers, you can haggle for better prices at the shops on top. Tip: name your price, walk away...and you'll get your item at the price you want.

NICE VIEW. We had to get there early & it was a long walk. It was refreshing view cos we dont get to see this back home. It was a good experience though a little tiring with the walking & blazing sun.
Scenic lookout. Just went there late in the evening.Dint walk much , just took a new pics.This was on the way to Kintamani (volcano area) and got done for a view.

Rice field visit. This is a must do in Bali. However, the road is very busy. Make sure you allow time to view the fields and get great photos. Our driver drove slowly alongside us as we took photos and walked the length of the road, ultimately making us feel the pressure to rush and jump back into the car. There are some market style stores around- haggle to get best prices, lots of pesty locals shoving goods to buy into your hands and the pathway can be crowded and very busy.I have visited in May and the fields were lush and green. This trip (end Dec/early Jan) the friends were brine and it was harvest time. Still beautiful just not as green and lush as my May visit.

Rice Terrace with no water. Nice view but unfortunately the rice terraces were dry due to lack of rain for a long period of time. When you are there, there will be some friendly kids trying to sell you postcards and want to guide you through the rice terrace, but as long as you don't mind that, it's worth a visit.

Scenic. Just took photos here as we didn't fancy walking around as we had been to another rice terrace the day before. Very scenic but very little parking - we had a driver so he dropped us off and then came back for us after about 10 mins. Worth seeing though especially if it's the only rice paddy you visit.

Get there EARLY!. By early I mean before the tourists come heaving in. And that would be 7am at the latest. Not a single tourist in sight except farmers, sunrise, gorgeous vast view of the terrace, fresh air and sounds of roosters waking the city up. It's free admission but walking back after a solid 1hr trek, a local farmer insisted I donate and aggressively blocked my way from heading back. She let me through but word of warning - be prepared to get harassed. Otherwise bring your camera smile to the early risers and hard at work farmers/villagers - leave before 8:30am!

A quick view and a few photos wss enough for us. Véry interesting place to see. Very crowded up at the village however and it proved quite a challenge to get decent photos. I got better photos of rice terraces on our way down the hill to one of the temples.
A MUST GO. This experience will leave you breathless, I mean it will literally take your breathe away .. be careful while going down though, coz it's slippery.

Very Relaxing for the eyes. It is a very relaxing scenery specially of you come from a country full of skyscrapers only a concrete jungle you live in it for your whole life. it is good to visit in your way to other monuments or in a tour. A lot of art crafts stores in the way to it. so you can do shopping too.

So good. . We just used bicycles to get ther
Maybe 45mins? Really awesome ride and when you get there its really cool. Really different from most of the paddys around ubud. Definitely check out

Breathtaking view, challenging climb. Really nice view of the rice terrace in the afternoon. To see the entire thing, you have to walk along the ridges of the terraces, climbing down and up again. It was pretty easy for me but my family struggled a little. You have to pay a small toll (donation) to continue past certain points, we reached the second toll gate and decided we saw enough. Good for taking pictures and seeing why and how they flood the rice!
Wrong Time. Came at the wrong time. The fields are dry and overgrown with weeds. I think they have just harvest the rice.
Surrounding rice padi fields were more beautiful!. I was underwhelmed by these rice terraces - the rice padi fields surrounding it were much more beautiful & incredibly friendly farmers!

Amazing cultural adventure wandering through rice paddies. This was a truly amazing experience. Highly recommend walking around the back of the rice paddies for even better views and more unique experience. Along the path you will need to pay 10,000 rupiah per person to go further along the trail. This is worth the small cost. To experience the little homes where locals live amongst the rice paddies was so interesting and I'm so pleased my 9 year old daughter was able to witness this. Make sure you wear good walking shoes as some of the paths can be slippery and unstable. Wouldn't recommend this for the elderly or families with children who need to be carried. Enjoy this amazing experience.

Scenic- just what you expect to see at Bali. Most people just stop to take a photo but if you can get parking, take a walk down into the fields a bit. We ended up talking to some of the workers and learned a lot about the rice growing and got good photos. There are also plenty of shops where you can buy souvenirs, but I was most impressed by the quilts. Did not see quilts anywhere but here during our stay.
Awang Awang Showed me a better place to view the terraces . Awang Awang showed me a cute little cafe which provided a lovely relaxed view of the Terraces without the mad crowds THANKS Awang Awang!!

Nice view but.... It is a beautiful scenic view of rice terrace however most of the best spot is from the cafe. Difficult to get parking spot. Good view but not supported by good facility such as parking area

Simply breathtaking!. One of the main reasons I came to Bali! This view did not disappoint at all... absolutely beautiful to sit and take in. We decided to have a late lunch part way down the terraces and sat looking out over them in amazement, making out rice farmers walking through. Absolutely worth the trip! We hired a driver for 600,000 rupiah to take us on a tour of Ubud for the day and it was worth every penny, this being one of the destinations. His local knowledge was really useful and insightful too!

Great place to go as a tourist. It's great to go. I enjoyed the experience (and got some great photos), but it was quite touristy. Our driver told us we had to get a ticket (which you don't need), then there are gates throughout the whole thing where they ask you for a donation or they don't let you through. It's a bit of a rip and cost a lot more than I was expecting.I think you can walk through other rice fields for the same experience, without being forced to pay every time you pass a gate. It's worth going to see the enormity of it, but maybe just grab a bite to eat at the cafe's for the view rather than walk through...
Very beautiful and interesting!. Really enjoyed visiting the Tegalalang Rice Terrace. It is so large it almost doesn't seem real. Very beautiful and picturesque. Highly recommend it.

Plan ahead to be at the rice field for beautiful view. Unfortunately I visited the rice field at the wrong time so I did not get the most beautiful view. I believe we should try to be there before the harvest time for best view

Refreshing indeed!. Imagine yourself watching the morning fog rise over the rice fields. You can hear birds chirping among the trees near you. Your lover takes you by the hand, while you breathe in the fresh mountain air. Sounds refreshing indeed! The island of Bali provides so many stunning rice fields, and one of them located in Tegallalang, Ubud. Being the most famous photo session spot, Tegallalang rice fields still manage to keep its beauty and becoming the right place to say “I do”. Take your bride-to-be for a short walk as walking amongst the rice terraces is a feast for the senses.
Saw from the road. We did not have time to go to the terraces, but the view from the road is breathtaking. The trek is suitable for teenagers and above and should not take kids along.

Beautiful but very touristy . Really nice view over the Rice fields. Just don't expect to be alone there... Tourist buses stop here all the time and there are several souvenir shops. Still, the view is really nice!

Impressive. I've been here a number of times and always impresses. An improvement recently is the car park so the whole place isn't clogged up with vehicles. Looks like you can take tours round the terrace now as well. The wholesale shopping in Gianyar which is on the way if travelling from Ubud is worth a look too

Lovely and quite nice for pictures. It's worth a quick stop if you're around Ubud to snap some pictures. We didn't walk down into the field - we stayed up top. There are little shops lining the top and plenty of spots for good pictures. Just watch your wallet - there were lots of local kids walking around trying to sell post cards and the like.

Review. Beautiful sight to see and many life lessons. The beauty of being at these places and villages are not just a view but a means to appreciate life's wonders. Many people today are not happy with what they have even though they have much already. However, there are those who have fewer than a few, and would be grateful for what they have. The rating is more for the view but the people and the journey (even though it is long) deserves more. And the restaurants there are about average - service is not so great.

Tourist tat. Second visit to ubud, first visit to the terrace's.Lasted about 20 mins or walking past tourist and souvenir tat.Most views are obscured by the numerous cafes and warungs.You can walk into the terrace's but on our visit there was. No water held in the terrace's so not as photogenic as often seen.
