Padi plantations. Is favorite tourist destination..famous with the beautiful rice terrace ..the local paddiea are planted in this place look typically on the high relative size plant
Amazing views.. Truly awesome. Great views, quiet, calm and peaceful, but get off the main road and head into the main restaurant. Go downstairs to sit in a Balinese hut- breathtaking.
Beautiful Outlook. . We looked at the views from afar, actually while we had lunch in one of the restaurants. It was a Living and working Panorama.
Definitely worth a visit. Got there at around 5pm, had tea and a local snack at one of the café's and enjoyed the views over the rice fields. Well worth visiting.

Pretty but nothing special . It's pretty but it takes a bit of driving to get too. Like all tourist attractions in Bali, there's rows of markets and coffee shops to cash in on it. I just arrived, took a few photos and left. Not interested in walking through mud.
Too touristy. This place is nice for take a quick photo and run away. Very touristy place. There are nicer terraces just around the corner. Peaceful and beautiful

Stunningly lush. Well worth a visit. I was guided around by two tiny local girls. You will find every few feet, locals asking you for money to pass to the next level. So what? It's no cost to see and you give a small amount which is supporting an impoverished local community who have prepared and sustained this beauty for you. Still up to you what you donate and there is no pressure.

Late afternoon walk . Great spot for late afternoon walk , much cooler , very touristy and lots of children trying to sell postcards . Today rice has been harvested and without the rain , new planting a have not been started , Still good to see - suggest coffee plantation up the road -

Worth a visit!. Worth a visit BUT there are way nicer rice fields in Bali with way less/no tourists. If you are driving thru Bali by motorcycle I would just explore the other fields you see when driving along in Bali

Do the tour your self. We hired scooters in Ubud and took a day to ride out to Batur. You can stop at these and many more beautiful rice fields. Although these 9 ned had the hilarious side benefit of tour cars stopping, unloading for pictures and then zooming off! Riding is easy, take your time.

Rice Paddy. Rice paddy was amazing with small track for walking. Paddy was on top of the hill. Better plan before visit to tegalalang, because when we went its harvest season so cannot view the gold scenery of the paddy

rice terrace. Make sure when you are going there . if there is no paddy then it looks very barren only grass left so make sure it has not been cut already when you went visiting. it could be disappointing. I went to see it and it was very barren and hot did not like it. take care of your children they might slip as happened during my visit. there. I personal suggestion will be to go to Bali pulina the coffee testing place where you can test famous "cat-poocino" coffee of Bali and also enjoy the rice terrace from there . they have a spectacular view from there.

Picture Perfect. Don't miss Tegalalang Rice Terrace. Rent a vespa and drive from Ubud (about 15min) and get lost in the rice fields. Bring some small change to get access to the entirety of the fields. The local restaurant got great mangoes!

Beautiful nature in peaceful surroundings . As beautiful as the many pictures. Had a relaxing lunch with my friend listening to the melodies from the scarecrow mills. Just beautiful and such an authentic Balinese experience.

Get ready for the hard sell. The rice terraces themselves were beautiful. Unfortunately, we were accosted every 20 steps or so by someone wanting a "donation" and getting upset if we didn't donate. We did donate at the first couple of these roadblocks. Immediately after one of them, a woman asked if we wanted to take her picture. We did, and then she got upset and told us we needed to pay. Kids tried to divert us into different paths where there were more donation roadblocks. The whole thing was pretty awful.
Subak tegalalang view. Great view of "subak" rice terrace view. Great for morning treking and relaxing around tegalalang rice terrace.
Simply amazing. A definite must see in Bali. The intricate location and design of the terraces really makes you appreciate the culture and the necessity of the rice in Asia.

The most beautiful riceterraces in Ubud.. Long time ago Ubud was a sleeping village of artists. Now it is crowded with tourists. But the area around Ubud is still worth visiting. The rice terraces in Tegalalang, only a short distance from Ubud, are the most beautiful one. There is also a small nice restaurant, but I forgot the name.
Worth a visit. Beautiful! But you'll be charged for different areas you go to. We didn't know this and didn't bring any money so we only got to see a small part of the fields.Definetly worth a visit!

Amazing scenary for photos. Visiting Bali and not going here, is the same that going to Rome and not see the Pope or Vatican. The vues are really astonishing, with the rice fields in front of us, seem to be like a sculpture in the hills, with geometrical design really amazing...

A convenient opportunity to get your iconic rice terrace photos. It's pretty widely accepted that Jatiluwih is a better set of rice terraces to visit, but also much more out of the way, depending on where you are. If you're coming from Ubud, Tegalalang, along with Gunung Kawi, is a conveniently located stop that will satisfy your itch to see the spectacle of Bali rice terraces. You'll probably only spend 20 minutes here, but it's still worth it.

First time seeing rice terrace. During august 2015 we went to visit bali and we get to see alot of attractions and this is definitely one of the most beautiful sights to see. Bali is so magical and the locals are very nice too.

Beautiful. We went to these rice fields for free and no donation was asked from us, not even one vendor tried to sell us any thing. We went around 10 AM in the morning, and it was just beautiful! Not many tourists are there at this time, so the experience was even better. Bali is so beautiful, I cant wait to come back and my trip isn't even over yet! Thank you to the beautiful people of Bali, your smiling faces are so welcoming!

Terrific VS Traffic. Beautiful rice terrace. The location bit further approx 30 minutes from Ubud Centre. Best for tea time as the scenery are perfect and not so hot compared at the lunch time but the traffic was the only problem, long que to park especially for car. But again, the view worth the effort.

Gorgeous to see. Fab fab pictures and stunning views! It's free to walk through the rice fields but I advice not to do it in flip flops-it was a last minute visit for us! Didn't stop us from enjoying it though. You can contribute to the workers whilst you're there if you like for a fab photo with them and the wooden rice carrier, a great memory! Lots of little cafes near by and your usual tourist shops where they all sell exactly the same things!

Tegallalang rice terrace. It is one of most nice landscape have to see during your holiday in Bali. You may do short walking down and up around of rice field area. And also you can have a drink or light lunch here while enjoying of the panorama. Its located 20 minutes from ubud centre or 1,5 hour from denpasar area

TEGALALANG RICE TERRACE. Tegalalang Rice Terrace in Ubud Region of Bali Island.You can spend few Hours on the Way to Kintamani Volcano.Beautiful Natural landscape of Paddy Filed by step Farming with Tropical weather , rice fields and coconut Trees and Other vegetation.You can walk around Rice field with Local Guide.Have some local eateries and Local handicrafts shops close by.Must visit for any Visitor to Bali Island
Good view. Walk along the street at tegalalang rice terrace, good view and many shop and cafe here also. Time to see is good at the early morning 7-10 AM or at evening 4-6 PM.

Beautiful view. This attraction was on my top list to visit in Bali. We went there late morning and it was crowded by a lot of tourists. I still enjoyed it, the only downside is the path going down to the rice field wasn't very nice. There was a shop nearby that dump their rubbish near the walkway. There was a little water way that had a lot of rubbish and unwanted smell. .

Worth the mission to get up there.... I think it took us longer to drive up to the entrance than it did for us to walk the track...It wasn't a difficult track at all, in fact we did it in thongs...although I would recommend trainers if you have them with you as it can be a bit slippery and the paths can be a little narrow with a bit of a steep drop. It was pretty difficult to find the entrance as it was remarkably busy on the street. Beware of the locals demanding donations and make sure to have cash on you if you want to take photo's with the farmers or locals as they will ask for about $1 per photo...we only realised they charge to have photo's after the fact. The view is spectacular, if you can visit during low season it might be a little better as it was busy when we visited in December which is expected.

Must see!!!. The rice terrace was a great experience. It's so green and well manicured fields with great view. It made me really appreciate how hard the locals work to keep this fields this way.It's steep and it was hot so we didn't go to the fields but on the side of the hill there's food/drinks kiosks whereby one can just chill and enjoy the view. It's just beautiful! !
Rice plantation . Very interesting to anyone who has ever eaten rice, a in very hot very green and exceptionally interesting landscape with agricultural workers wearing wide hats in view

beauty. We took the trip in the rain but luckily the rain stopped. The terraces are so beautiful. Then there was this friendly old man who allowed us to take photos with him. It's lovely to walk around. Don't miss this!

Good to visit and meander for a short while as a break in a bigger trip. We hired a driver and asked to see a few attractions, her recommended we go via this rice terrace... a great view, not too many people when we visited and easy to wander around.. we had small kids with us and it was still relatively accessible although we are outdoors people so sort of fit..
Lush and Green. Very scenic, it was lovely to see Rice Paddies farmed in an age old tradition. Lots of craft shops alongside. Worth a visit if you are in the area.

Gotta go, but be ready for the donations. It's great and still do it. Just accept that you will be stopped three times for "donations". Just pop the 10/20k rupee in and move on and don't let it affect your experience. Too many tourist get upset by it but it's just a dollar or two and their family definately needs it more that yours.

Nice place. Tegalalang Rice Terrace actually offers you a nice view, wil be better if you could come when it's not too crowded. You can just sit back and relax, sipping some coffee or tea, and enjoy the view. taking one or two picture. Too bad some cafe is close early, at 5.

Work a visit to Tegalalang Rice Terrace Into Lunch or Shopping. We stopped at Tegalalang on our way back from a sunrise trek up mount batur. Our driver took us to a great lunch spot right on Tegalalang, a little apart from where all of the other restaurants were. We really enjoyed the classic Bali scene of a verdant rice terrace, and I also really liked the sensory experience of hearing the wind blow through the rice, the contraptions the farmers have rigged to make a noise when the wind blows, the smell of the rice, etc. There is a great market nearby, good restaurants and shopping nearby, so I would recommend working a visit to Tegalalang with another activity.

Too busy and harassed for money the whole time!. You pay to get in, you pay along the trail like three times, children chase you to purchase things. One man at a paystop actually grabbed my arm and would not let me pass until I gave more money!
Cool. Really beautiful setting. Lovely people and a fun place to explore.Maybe stop off for some lunch and a few drinks

Ricefield terraces with lousy parking. Way too many cars parking on the road side and causes traffic slowdown. The view to the rice field terrace is nice but not really amazing, especially when the rice has been harvested. This place has gotten way too many tourists that it has lost it's charm.

Save your time and go to Jatiluwih instead. Handy to visit from Ubud but so many touristy shops and only one real view. Doesn't even seem like a working area but more set up for the tourists now than a real farm. Go to the UNESCO World Heritage Jatiluwih rice fields instead. You can walk among them and chat to farmers and do lots of exploring.

The Green of the Rice Terraces is Amazing.... One of my picture taking goals was to see the rice fields in Bali. The driver we had took us here and it is obviously made for tourists but we loved the friendly vendors and the ease of getting around the fields...

A real slice of Balinese life. We cycled up to the teraces in the early morning with a young guide - Dwi Obama,. He took us off the main road and through the terraces.We also visited the luwak coffee plantation - which was a real highlight.
Nice rice terrace in Ubud. Tegalalang Rice Terrace is a very nice place to view. However, there are not so much rices when I visited there.
GREAT Stop over for GREAT Views. We stopped here on our way to Mount Batur, it was a quick stop, just to admire the terraced rice fields, very lush and picturesque, not much other than the view here

Interesting half day excursion. We had half a day free and went on one of local excursions and went to see this. Although it was interesting to see, I am not sure if I would recommend it as there are other activities that you could do for the same price and time requirements.

Beautiful vistas!. Made a quick stop here on a day trip. The views are great through the valleys and over the terraces. Make sure to take some cash for "donations" to access the walks (it is private property after all). IDR 5000 for each collection point (expect 2 or 3).

Recommend to walk here for sure . Went early about 8am. Not any tourists. Read some reviews no need to go in and take pic from road. I totally disagree I went in with my driver walked a circuit. Really good views and scenery. Farmer was very polite no money given but if they do ask I don't see any issues with this as it's their land you are walking on. Well worth it.
A must see in Ubud. I highly recommend seeing this wonder. Beautiful to take some photos here - it is so lush and green.

Wonderful curling images !.. Any rice terraces are worth the time to look and take in the amount of time and work involved in producing such images and the fact that they produce such a basic food item is incredible. Keep eating rice !!The time you spend viewing is up to you , different weather conditions give you many images, time is up to you.

This is what UBUD used to look like 30+ years ago!. I was shocked to see this tiny area of rice paddies that was packed with tourists jostling to see the "special" rice paddies. It's more of a commercial sales place for paintings and souvenirs with a backdrop of green below.But I guess as Bali develops, this will be the tiny viewing point for its days of yore.I preferred exploring the countryside on a scooter and seeing the real agriculture and scenery. If you don't have time, then perhaps join the tour buses and visit.

Beautiful View. Being able to see this scenery is just amazing. Another place where it's a postcard picture but you are there seeing it with your own eyes! If you are in Ubud this is definitely a place to visit!! It's about a 20 minutes motor bike ride from the city.

See it once. Tagalalang Rice terrace is on the agenda for most day trips. So visit it once. You can see the paddies rolled out to distance and maybe sip a coffee while you take in the view. There are a lot of people and vendors.If you really want to experience the rice paddies, I would suggest just rent a bike and go. You'll be amazed by the scenery.
impressive. You have to find a guide for visit the terrace... You can lost between rice terrace. Local little children are helping you.

Yes, it's good. In end Dec, on a hot afternoon it was not best place to visit. It could be excellent during monsoons, when those terraces would be totally green. Still for tourists, it offers a range of shops offering variety of souvenirs at the price suited to your bargaining skills.

Nice for me but disappointing for my friend. I was born a northern Chinese city girl and have never seen such a view before so I thought it was nice while my friend who's been brought up in the south found it boring... I guess it's all depended on whether you've seen such a view before.

Nice stop to take pictures and move on. We drove through quickly as the whole place is full of tourists. There is a small fee of 10,000 idr but it is worth it to take a quick picture and move along. There are lots of coffee shops and restaurants where you can sit and relax as well but we felt it was too crowded.
Very pretty. Make sure you go and walk through the terrace rather than stay up top and take pictures. And remember to wear average sneakers as it can be quite muddy.

Do it by bike. We went on a cycle tour with Bali on bike and got to see a lot of beautiful rice fields. Would recommend this option as you get to see a lot of the real Ubud, and the breeze while cycling cools you down!

Don't expect much. We only saw a small area of rice terrace at the hillside. Tourists could walk along the terrace but had to be very careful to avoid ending in muddy shoes. The place was full of tourists and we ended up in a coffee shop after walking for 10 minutes. Worth visiting only if you stay nearby.

Beautiful landscape absolutely ruined by shambolic tourist development.. The rice terraces are an absolute disgrace to their World Heritage listing. Unesco's original listing in 2012 should be instantly revoked for this area.Whilst the landscape is amazing the terraced fields cannot be viewed without obstruction due to the uncontrolled building of horrendous concrete block and corrugated asbestos stalls selling overpriced crap to the hordes of tourists coming through this area. Photos of the landscape have to be carefully composed and artfully cropped in order to not show any of these buildings.The local government charges $10,000 Rupiah to enter the area. Visitors can walk down the hill and along paths through the ricefields but each field owner will demand payment for crossing into their land.
Good. Good but we visited a better one in Ubud areas a few years ago. More on the road side to stop area.natural look.This was definitely more a tourists planned area.
Stop for 5 mins and take pictures.. I did not find this place as a must-see. We just stopped for 5 mins on our way to other temples and took pictures.

Enchanting views at rice terrace. The Tegalalang rice terrace were an awesome experience for my wife and I. It really was the first time we saw rice paddies and got to walk around. There are some nice restaurants with overhanging views of the rice terrace to enjoy a quick lunch.

Hmm. Disappointing.. Well. The rice terrace looks overcrowded and it does not give you an authentic Bali feeling. The place is more like a tourist trap where you will have a lot of people asking you for money, so it would be difficult to have a quite time. The terrace itself doesn't look like it has been looked after much. There are more beautiful rice fields around Ubud which allow you to have better time and to relax. If you want to have a walk in Tegalalang terrace you will be asked for COMPULSORY DONATION. Though it is made ridiculously funny. First you will be asked a COMPULSORY donation to cross a bridge. But then, when you crossed the bridge, in 50 meters you will be asked another COMPULSORY DONATION. And the woman which collects them will not give you to go further if you do not pay. We somehow avoided the bridge donation (maybe the collector run to the toilet). However, we couldn't pass by the women, so we turned back. Somehow i just didn't feel like paying to the rude person. I think the better way would be to place a ticket booth somewhere at the beginning so that you pay for entrance instead of having dodgy compulsory donations :)

Nice coffee stop. Its quite nice to stop by here for a cup of coffee. There are many shops and they are pretty much the same. I would not recommend any food as we had a peak in one shop's kitchen as it was quite filthy. If you have good knees, its a nice walk around the terrace.

Gone is the view.. We used to go here to look at the view. Now it has traffic jams, too many shops built in front of the view and many people trying to sell you "stuff". If you want a view go to the Jati Luwih which is a World Heritage site.
Beautiful Scenery. Beautiful Scenery. Well worth stopping off at. Nice places to sit & have a drink on the valley overlooking the rice plantation.
Nice ridfe walk with great views. Did a short walk on this path. It was a great way to see some rice terraces. Saw some folks take bikes along parts of it, but there are some steep steps.
Nice views..... Nice place to visitGood climbing and good pictures takenAll good just don't like money requested at every break spotNot recommended if you don't like climbing muddy uneven stairs

Great Terraces, Manic Tourism. Try and get there as early in the morning as you can. The air will be cooler and the crowd thinner. We got there about 1 or 2pm and it was just a bit much. The scenery is beautiful and I enjoyed walking amongst the terraces and saying hello to the friendly workers. But I was one of many tourists scouring the hills. Felt like agritourism at its worst. No real exchange of knowledge. If u can get someone who speaks English well to help you communicate with a local about their rice cultivation that'd be cool. Heaps of stalls with pretty nice knit work, blankets etc. The road out to the south has some great places where you see the wood carvings and other art being made.

Overrun and overrated but if your trip doesn't permit anything else, do it!. I was here twice, the first time 20 years ago and then again in October 2015. I was shocked by how overbuilt and commercialized this place (and frankly everything in the Ubud area) has become. If you possibly can get to other parts of Bali (east, west), do it because those places are far less commercialized and far less touristic with much better scenery and authentic local culture. On the other hand, if your travel schedule or budget doesn't permit a trip to a far-flung part of Bali, then definitely you should come here and check it out. This is like a miniature preserved rice patty, scenically positioned on a steep slope. Very photogenic. From the Ubud area this is a short trip. From the resort area Nusa Dua this is at least a one-hour trip, maybe more, but if this is the only place you can see outside of the resort area, you should make the trip.
Nice and comfy place for coffee . Enjoyed the moment looking at rice terrace view with an ice coffee. Feeling relaxing and we met a very friendly and passionate Tegalalang people

Amazing views. Very beautiful place. Definitely a must-go when in Bali. You best go here with a private driver or by rental car/motorcycle. You can wander around the terraces.m and enjoy the beautiful rice fields.

Disappointing. I had looked forward to seeing the rice terraces, but just took a peak from the car window as we had stopped at some smaller terraces early on. This area was a disappointment as it had become just one more tourist trap where the hawkers just won't leave you alone. It may have been "authentic" years ago and perhaps it looks fantastic in season but it was very disappointing to me.

An over-rated Tegalalang Rice terrace..... We'd read lots of reviews to visit the Tegalalang Rice Terraces in Ubud and we made the trip there when we stayed in Ubud in Dec 2015.It turned out to be a rather small rice terrace. You stop by the side of the road and there is a small view terrace. That's it. Nearly impossible to walk down to the rice terraces itself. I reckon Jatiluwih, another rice terrace and Unesco site in Bali, would offer a better trip option. Overall Tegalalang was a disappointment for us.
Beautiful view . You can hike around the rice fields quickly. 10000 IDR to enter. Lots of shops and cafes. Definitely a place for a photo stop while exploring Bali.

Great veiws but only worth if on the way. We stopped over at the Tegalalang Rice Terrace on way to a bike tour. Great views and something different to experience. However not worth the trip especially for this. There were quite a few shops around that area though.

Worth a look. Nice views, but as most of the rice had been harvested, the terraces were dry. I expect it looks more stunning when they are filled with water. The terrace cafes opposite are quite nice but the shops along the street are a bit run down.
Beautiful. No need to pay to go in just view it from the road. Watch out for all the souvenir sellers and negotiate strongly.

Beautiful scenery. Took a day trip to Ubud and the rice terraces were abit brown as the rice has been harvested. But the view was still lovely and we had a wonderful time looking at the beautiful scenery and taking in the tranquil setting over lunch. It was cooler in Ubud and quite windy I must say. Must visit place!

So so. Sorry but Philippines have better rice terraces. This one is so small and has an obstructed view of trees. It is not that tall also... it also has a fee of 10,000 IDR... unlike in banaue Philippines just drive by and you can see tons of rice terraces for free.
you can go so you can see and compare.

Too touristy!. Stunning valley and rice paddies views but too many tacky shops and tourists and traffics for me! Narrow steep Paths down behind shops were not safe, needed good shoes. Rubbish strewn. Had to wait every few steps to pass another tourist. Looked like would be OK if you kept walking another km to the valley, or visited when not so busy.
stunning views. We hired scooters and drove through villages to the rice terraces and it was nice to see this place.
Beautiful landscape and greenery . Nice for phototaking but was small compared to the Jetiluwih rice terrace. And I also prefer the cooling breeze at Jetiluwih and its huge padi fields and quiteness.

Splendid landscape. This rice terraces was beautiful, stress reliever, cool and breezy. perfect destination for very hot season. you have to give some donations to the native group in the field so they'll let you pass and take pictures around the rice terraces. Souvenir shopping abound along the roadsides especially the magnificent wood carvings, paintings and a lot more.

Spectacular Views!. The view onto the rice fields was spectacular and the street behind us was lined with colorful shops and residences.It was difficult to find the entrance down onto the rice fields and it took a fair bit of negotiating past the locals and children asking for donations, to enable your way down to the rice fields.The view from atop the rice fields was just as spectacular, however again, we had to negotiate our way to the top past many locals asking for donations. So therefore, I'm not sure if all the negotiations and hassles was worth the effort of making a long trip to the site.

1st Bali visit. Well as I'd never seen a rice field before I visited this place I've got to say its so awe inspiring absolutely loved my visit there, great restaurant and food the sceanery is absolutely breath taking. Will defiantly be recommending to my friends when they visit Bali. I've never seen a place so beautiful and amazing have enjoy my trip

Stunning!!. The rice terraces were absolutely gorgeous!! I have never seen such a scenery in my life before so for me it was stunning and beautiful. The most memorable part of the rice terrace experience were the kids who sell the post cards. I befriended some of them and they helped me climb the rice terraces as some places were slippery and some steep. LOved the workout!
Breathtaking. . The most stunning view and landscape of our Balinese adventure! Absolutely beautiful and impossible to capture with photos. This is one you have to see for yourself!!

Glad I'm not a rice farmer. The best view from up top but if able good to walk through fields it was very hot & lots of steps hence glad not rice farmer you have to pay plus donation to farmer, restaraunts hillside to enjoy the view & of course markets well worth the visit

Nothing exceptional. Nothing exceptional about this place. The views are good, but you will find better rice terraces when you drive through Bali. Moreover we were charged IDR 10,000 pp just to stop by and click pictures.
Beautiful scenery. Absolutely stunning, as with nearly everywhere in Bali the market people will hassle you but it was worth it to see these beautiful rice terraces

Nice view with cup of tea. Tegalalag rice terrace is just beautiful! And there are many nice cafes which is able to relax with beautiful view. Small kids are bit bother of selling products and asking tips.
Really nice view!. The rice terrace has a cool view and you can hike between the different rice fields. You should definitely bring good shoes, if you want to hike a little.

Beautiful but too many toll gates . The view is stunning but if you decide to walk around the rice fields you will have to pay a donation to each family that is present along the way (and a minimum is required) on top of the road entrance fee.
I preferred other rice fields that were more quiet and free walking distance from Ubud center!

nice to see . we had had a full day and I stopped at the coffee place about half a km back up road which I found to be amazing and had seen the big rice fiels from there. we stopped at the fields it was good ,chose not to walk through. would be a great experience if wanting hands in and walk through for the experience.

My favorite green!. Never dull to visit Tegalallang rice paddies! This is all about the place that I love! Very photogenic and just simply relaxing! I go there at least three times a month and still want more.
Nice view. Superb view, UNESCO protected. 12 kms from UBUD, go there with a driver for 100'000 IDR and enjoy one drink in the small warung around.

Beautiful Scenery. About 20 to 30 minutes' drive from central Ubud, we parked by the roadside and walked down the steps to have a birds' eye view of the rice terraces. The view itself is spectacular and worth the trip. There are girls selling postcards, with shops lining the streets selling the usual touristy items and cafes. I recommend going early in the morning (I was there at 9.30am) as our driver said that the tourists usually arrive midday so that they have lunch there as well and it is very crowded. So I had a lovely view of the terraces without having to battle with other people and it wasn't too hot either. We didn't do any trekking or walking around the area due to my mobility issues but if I could, I would have, it was lovely. Note: we had to pay a token fee to view the terraces.
Beautiful and informative. Kids had a wonderful experience. Trekked for about 1 hr. Clean air and beautiful fields. Sight to behold.

Bali Nature Walk. We sign up for Bali Nature Walk Ubud Sunrise Tourist Agency. Our guide Dewa was helpful and engaging. We started trekking down the rice field and he explains all the different kind of plants around the rice field. We even chit chat with the local farmers. Its a totally different side of Bali. Being back to the nature brought us more awareness in the world we are living in. The farmers only had natural lighting which is the sun and the kitchen uses charcoal or wood. The house itself is made from mud. After the trekking, Dewa brought us to Tegenungan Waterfall. We saw rainbow along the waterfall. And we hike to the peak to take pictures. We relax at the waterfall for about 45minutes. Overall the whole experience to the nature of Bali is worthwhile. We were glad we did this. And our guide was very patient and simply the best.

Lovely. Really lovely but when you walk down to take a closer look there are people hassling you to buy stuff every few steps, also once you get to a bridge you have to pay a donation to cross which I thought was ridiculous considering you've already paid to view the rice fields. There is a litter problem too. There are just as attractive rice fields all around Ubud that are just as beautiful that you can see without being hassled. Having said all that I do still think it should be on your must see list.

Ubud countryside, rice field. Rice field in tegalalang-Ubud-Bali is most different from other rice field,terraces is unique, green and a lot terraces, it was not complete holiday in Bali without visit this place.
incredible. what a beautiful place...something you have to do in Bali....looking around the rice fields is something also so relaxing...nice to discover the way of life and activity of the locals

Nice photography spot. Location: next to a main road. Take a taxi there. Not far from Ubud. We booked a car for US$15/h. Things to do: you can get down to the rice field. However, the path down is quite steep, thus can be quite tiring going down n up. There are little girls selling postcards along the way down. Nice photography spots can be found near the road. After that, can head for a restaurant facing the rice fields for drink or a meal. Our driver recommended Alon Alon which served Balinese food. Nice view from the restaurant's little hut where we had our lunch.
Gorgeous views. There isn't really anything to do there but they make for gorgeous photos. We just pulled up on the side of the road, took a few snaps, then continued onto our next destination.

Interesting. When we arrived it was pouring rain and there was garbage everywhere. I was surprised at how busy the road up top was. I think all the surrounding tourist shops have taken away from the tranquil nature. I have visited other rice fields and prefer them.
Absolutely stunning. This would have to be one of the most picturesque places in Bali. Stunning views of the rice terraces. So worth the drive away from the hustle and bustle. This is the real Bali!

Stunning landscape. Such a beautiful place, I could have stayed there all day.Great photo ops! We had morning tea at one of the hillside cafes, was a really cool experience. There were two guys sitting in a hut jamming some balinese music which added to the good vibes. Would recommend wearing running shoes/trainers tho.

Very calm area. Ubud is the best place for adventure tours, Markets and temples! We went to the rice field which has an entry fee of 10,000idr per person. Alot of the small restaurants are overlooking the rice field which is very architectural but quite small, You can walk down to climb up to the rice field to take pictures also markets all over early morning is better as it is not so busy.
Such a nice view !. This is the most famous rice field in the region. Nicely shaped. If you have time, you can go down and explore more.

Not really that impressive.... This rice terrace, although pretty but it is over rated in my opinion. Travelling around Bali, I found that there are many other rice terrace that are far more impressive especially in the northern areas amidst the mountains. However they are not as accessible and thus not as popular.Personally, if I want to see a rice terrace with a spectacular view, I wouldn't mind travelling a little further. It's akin to travelling to Nepal for Everest which would be further away, instead of going for a local hill which is closer and more accessible. Personal preference I guess.There are shops around the rice terrace here. However quite touristy. All quote price can be bargained in this place.
Amazing Views. A must see part of any trip to Bali. Amazing views and especially tranquil in the rain. A window into life on this island

Wonderful rice terraces . I have been to Jatiluwih rice terraces but I still enjoy visiting Tegalalang. The two rice terraces are quite different, Jatiluwih is much bigger in size and its rice terraces are flatter compared to to the more narrow and levelled rice terraces of Tegalalang.We were fortunate to have a driver who took us to a less well known parking spot, where there were less annoying and aggressive vendors then at the main srop off site. A short 10 minutes track gives you an amazing view of the terraces. We ran out of time, otherwise would have tracked further. Will definitely come back again.

Iconic view of rice fields. If you want to see rice fields as they have been for many years this is the plce to go. It's about 8kms north of Ubud but is worth the drive. The only downside is because it is very picturesque many tourists go there and also you may get hassled by the shop and stall owners, but still worth the trip. It's a terrific view of really terraced rice fields and is a lovely place for photographs.

Okay I guess. The rice paddies are beautiful there is no denying that but there are many people there asking for money. I understand that it isn't a super rich country and people aren't as well off as other but there was these kind of checkpoints every couple of metres. Someone would be stationed there and ask for a donation for the upkeep of the terraces - the first time this isn't too bad but the 3rd 4th and 5th time it gets a bit much.

Stunning Scenery. If you are in the Ubud area or even heading towards Kintamani , take this route. These rice terraces are stunning, You are able to take a hike through the terraces which will be an everlasting memory.Street Hawkers are everywhere, they can be aggressive but that is their way of getting an income. Just be polite even if they annoy you. I always try to remember this is their Island.. A few warangs overlooking the terraces where you can enjoy the view if you don't want to do the hike.

Nice View. This place offer a very nice view but very crowded with tourists and sellers at the road side as well. We went there during paddy harvesting season and most of the paddy has been harvested. No proper road to go down and up into the hill.

Fun and pretty. Beautiful scenery and great hike but very touristy. On the hike you will be greeted by a "farmer" who will tell you he will guide you..... He was sweet and took lots of pics but preferred to be alone. Did enjoy the "Bintang" half way through the hike! The vendors were aggressive at the road. This makes me sad. School kids selling postcards for their "school". Not sure why they weren't "in school". But a must see.

Touristy but Beautiful. This seems to be a place that taxi drivers take all the tourists. The terraces are beautiful but its a congested area with many vendors at the entrance. I've visited more scenic and spectacular rice terraces in Bali but it is a longer drive to get to them. For a quick stop, this is very lovely.

Nice view but not much else to do. The view is very nice but the place is by the roadside where it's not easy to find parking. Besides the view, there's some places to shop and have lunch while enjoying the scenery.
Rice paddies... the view is absolutely stunning, the beautiful green paddies, the fresh smell of the rice, the calmness and the area is a must see

AMAZING views and a good happy vibe here. Few good shops up here, a few hagglers but otherwise had an amazing vibe, and views OMG! My favourite view in Bali, stunning. There are a few shops, not too many, seemed to have a bit more variety I found, prices were able to be haggled to reasonable. A few eateries, although we did not eat here, it looked nice. Kids selling postcards but hey whats a dollar to make a kid happy?!

Amazing eye candy!. We stopped off briefly at the rice terrace on the way to Mt batter for Bali Eco Cycling tour. Jaw dropping scenery... Your camera cannot even come close to capturing the beauty of this place!

Majestic view. Paddies, paddies, paddies everywhere you go.As with all rice field related attractions, the beauty really depends on the timing of your visit, whether it is after or before harvesting.I guess the management realizes this, so they never plant all the rice at the same time, otherwise it will loose its attraction when all are harvested. Expect to see some brown patches amidst the green rice field.

Welcome sight . We visited the rice paddies a few times. The vivid greens of the rice fields are a welcome change from the urban roads of Ubud city. There is a cafe facing the fields and as you might expect with a captive market they charge a premium on their food. On the roadside there are many little shops all plying their wares. We found people to be friendly and mostly willing to negotiate on prices for clothes and carved wooden items. The children selling postcards are experts at pulling the heart strings. We did not want any postcards but they were happy to receive a silver coin. If you want good photos catch the eye of the 90yr old woman carrying her rice baskets on the terraces, she will let you lighten her load for a while and pose for photos. If you go via your own transport be sure to travel further along the road uphill from Tegalalang to really experience the genuine Bali.

Traditional Rice Terrace. if you kind of city people, it is very nice for your brain refresher. enjoy the color of green scenery. you can take a selfie picture here or if you to excited you can go down and enjoy the air too.
Lunch. Have to say how lovely the views are as you relax over lunch and a bintang. The meals are just average and a bit disappointing.

Beautiful but not the one and only. Spectacular vista but there are other rice terraces that are not so touristy. The paths can become very slippery especially when it rains so take care if you plan to walk around.

Great view but too many people! . Been here long time ago when it was less people, it was a great experience. But now there's so many people! A lot of sellers selling stuff, I guess they want to make a living but it was too much and quite aggressive. There's other places in Bali that offer more beautiful rice terrace.

Find Another Paddy!. While only a short drive from Ubud to Tegalalang, it is crowded with tourists, accessed (for a fee) via a congested road, and lined with vendor stalls all hawking similar goods.As you scramble for an angle to take a pic of the terraced rice paddies, you are hard pressed to take a shot that doesn't have a tourist in it.There are prettier venues for terraced rice paddies in the area...take a moment and find them (we found some lovely stepped paddies as we trekked down to see the temples carved into the cliff face at Gunung Kawi).

Very pretty, lots of tourists.. The rice terrace itself is gorgeous. The location is convenient because its literally right off the side of the road. However, lots of tourists, traffic and merchants. Take some time to get pictures, walk down if you want (not a requirement especially if you have littles) but you aren't too much if you don't. Lots of shops & cafes overlooking the terrace so a nice spot to grab a drink & relax. If you're interested in shopping, plenty of options. The sellers here seemed a little less pushy than some other places, maybe because there were so many tourists. I say its definitely a place to see while you're here but only if you haven't made arrangements for some other rice field experience.

Paddy (rice) Fields are always a pretty site . With their lush green colors paddy fields with palm trees as a backdrop always make for a pretty pleasing picture for the eyes and when they are carved into terraces on a hillside you get an added dimension not seen as frequently in Asia. One can pay to walk through the fields which is a nice hike
Rice terrace, excellent vieuw!. If you are for the first time in Bali go to Tegalalang. Nice vieuw of riceterracea. But at this moment it is becoming very commercial. They even made tracks in it!
Brilliant views..... Beautiful views, field looks good when the rice plants are not harvested, month of November is best time to be there...

Worth the visit. Passed by while driving from Mount Batur to hotel in city centre so decided to take a short walk here. 30-45 min is more than enough for you to walk through the main terraces and snap some scenic photos. It's a beautiful place! Be sure to prepare some money for donation and to tip the locals if they lend you a hat or something for your photos.

Great place for tracking. I went there with my friends and we took about An hour to experience the beauty of the ricefieldThe view is just amazing that no other place has.However, as we go through the track, there were few huts asking for donation which i guess it was for their own benefit.

Gorgeous Rice Terraces. We put this as our second rice terrace on our 6 days tour of Bali. Our privately hired driver took us there early before the herds of tourists got there. That was a good plan.We loved this location because here once you leave the car, the terraces are right there for the taking. You walk along the road and can stop anywhere you want to take photos and more photos! At the other famous rice terrace we stopped at a few days before, you have to pay to enter into the village and the terraces were not as attractive there as in the Tegalalang location.There are vendors, but they were not aggressive. We stopped at a "cafe" store and bought a fresh coconut to drink. The owners are so charming and showed us their baby. We took a photo this lovely family.Yes, it is definitely on the to do list if you visit Bali. Don't miss it.

Nice. I thought this would be pretty dull, well was I wrong. Well worth the visit. Very interesting to look at, and if you are energetic enough you can walk down the hundred odd steps to the bottom. Be warned, it's a lot harder coming back up, and steep too.There is plenty of cafes overlooking the rice paddies.

Breath taking. A tourist place, but nonetheless it is breathtaking. Did not walk into the terraces, only along the trinket shops on top of hill. You simply do not pay attention to the hawkers and breath the peace.
Enroute attraction. Can see enroute to other sites. Good to stop and see - spend 30 minutes. less exciting if you have seen terraced rice fields elsewhere.

All You Need is Go Out of the Car and Stroll Around.. It's a bit ironic when you're driving back and forth to find the spot, while you only need to stop by and stroll around. The rice terraces are adorable, something that big-city travellers are longing to see. A must-visit, definitely!
Stunning! . This wasn't far from where I was living and I can't believe I only visited once. It's stunning! You must go and bring a camera with extra batteries and memory cards!
pretty. very nice to look at from the street restaurants and the shops have some good cheap buys. the terrace is easy to walk around and the walk isn't strenuous
Ubud my favourite place. In ubud you can visit the Tagalalang rice terrace with a wonderfull view and know how the locals works the plantations!
Astoning View. breath taking view from roadways, time for visit in the morning, so you can see the farmer do their daily activities

Beautiful, peaceful setting for a bite to eat. Lovely, calming and green. The food is okay and reasonably priced, but the view is worth it; you can even walk through it. Highly recommend even if just to have a drink overlooking the rice terraces.

Awesome view. Great place to stop for a cool drink - fantastic views of the rice padddies - little bit of market shopping - but mainly stop for the view - if you have time go for a wander through the paddies - awesome experience
Stunning views. Only stayed a short time but well worth the look. This is a very popular spot to take photos. Just beautiful. Many tour companies will stop here on the way to other destination.

Perfect scenery. Lush greenery all around,rice terraces that take your breath away.it was our first experience hence we liked it.The ticket price was 10000 IDR the area is quite touristy with craft shops and restaurants filled up to one side.But that gives you ample choices to experience the view.there are a few restaurants,we had lunch from one of them facing the rice terraces and it was awesome.Felt close to nature.You can even walk along the rice terraces,remember to wear shoes as its quite slippery.
Spectacular view of the rice fields. We had one of the best meals we had in Bali at this cafe/restaurant overlooking the rice terraces... about $5 AUD and ever so delicious.... and the view!
Average yet beautiful. This is pretty average and only requires a very short stop where you can also refresh and re energize at the local cafe. There are better terraces to view.

Tired But Worth It. If u love walking trip and hike, this is the place that u should visit.. beautiful view of ricefield. not a good place if u bring babies..maybe u can stay at the restaurant.and sadly there's some bridge that we must give our money for charity build that facilities of bridge.. sometimes the local people angry if u don't give money or less than their expected.
Beautiful spot for photos. A great spot for landscape photography for nature lovers. There are also shops and restaurants on the main road facing the rice terrace.
Nice . It was nice but I had better expectationsBe careful! We feel, it can get slippery. Try getting a beer or coconut water in one of the terraces with view. So nice

One of the best tourist attractions in Bali. I live in Ubud and still try to visit the rice fields every month or so. I love it up there. The village is really nice and the fields always look beautiful. It is only about 20 minutes out of Ubud and worth the hike

So So. May I will say this place is gorgeous if I havent seen Jatiluwih which is terrific! Much more better than this place. It is just a small area and completely full with all the sellers. Besides that I can't really feel how it is so refreshing when you walk through the path in the rice fields because it just like you just watch it from the other side of the rice fields.Tips : better if you go to the north of ubud, take your bicycle and enjoy what is around you. Or you may go to a place named pomegranate rest which is located in the mid of rice fields, it can only acces by walking or bicycle. Not really recommended the restaurant but the environment is pretty good, especially on this month when it looks so green
Gorgeous. We visited the rice terraces a couple of times through various tours and they're definitely worth a look. Learning how they work and why they look how they do is really interesting.
Amazing walk. Was a great walk with amazing views . Our guide was very knowledgable about local history and customs.

Beautiful. The whole thing is really beautiful.. especially if you are coming from a city. The neat terraces, the green colour.. it a feast to the eyes.
Walk around the fields or find a coffee shop with direct views of the terrace.
It's a bliss!

Absolutely gorgeous . We paid someone $5 USD to take us on a hike of the terraces. It was well worth it. Wear comfortable walking shoes. It can be very slippery and while it is not necessary to have a guide, I think it's worth the few bucks and it helps the locals

Must-see but very touristic. It's beautiful, one of the most beautiful ricefields of Bali. But it's also very touristic. The road is blocked by all the tourist vans and busses. When walking through the ricefields there are several points where you are asked to make a donation. There are also enough good restaurants to eat. Eventhough it is very touristic I still recommend you visit because it's still very beautiful
Very Cool. Amazing rice terrace structure. Worth a tour, we bought some sugar cane and were able to pick snakefruit from its host plant. Good visit.

Nice place to visit. A nice stop, to see the beauty of the ricefields. Having a tour guide with with you will help in understanding how rice is grown. Plenty of places to stop for coffee or a snack, and the locals are very friendly.
Beautiful setting. stopped here on round trip, we only stayed 10 minutes or so to take pictures but it was nice to see people working on the terraces.
Great expierence. Wonderful rice terraces and a nice view. Green and healthy nature. I really recommend this place. You can go by a driver or scooter
Beautiful but way too commercialised. Tegalalang rice terraces are beautiful but we were very disappointed in how commercialised it is. I would have preferred to see a working rice field.

Breathtaking view with exhilarating hike. It was special as the paddy was planted on terrace whilst trekking up the terrace will give you better view of the entire hill of paddy. The surrounding is simply breathtaking and you will get good photos from all angles.
Beautiful scenery. Beautiful scenery, a Must see in Bali and especially in UBUD.Witness the gorgeous plantation and lifestyle in Bali.
Loved it!. Myself and my partner absolutely loved going to these fields! It was amazing and so beautiful! It's certainly a must see!

Look beautiful . We went to Tegalalang rice last month was beautiful green field. When I looked down seem is not that big but when I walked down yeah is big. Love to walked around and took pictures there.

Go Green All Green. This is a spatiality of Bali...All green Rice Fields. You have to pay little amount at the entrance of the Village..far from actual fields. Its almost drive through.. The view is great.. very cool for your eyes.. the cool baize from field makes you fresh.. you have little walk in the green field...for some photos.. the snaps surely very beautiful.... the fields are in steps which makes it beautiful. Just slimier to Tea gardens of India. You can have cup of coffee at some restro while enjoying views of rice field. Also at some place some local seller sales the local rice.. try it out..

Unesco site not to be missed on your tour of Bali. This was the first stop on our day tour toward northwest Bali. We arrived at the base of 2,276m Mt. Batukau at 9 am, after a one hour uphill drive from Ubud. After paying the 30K entry fee, we noted the mountain's powerful streams supplying the intricate Subak canal system over the miles of rice terraces below. We were dropped off at the trail head where a map detailed the 1 km or the 2 km trail along one of the canals. As we walked, our attention was riveted to the one mile views of long curving terraces with occasional cow sheds, small temples, and distant farming villages before the green forested mountain. The morning light was perfect for pictures and we appreciated being nearly the sole strollers along the nice trail. Near the end of this marked walk, we came upon a lone farmer plowing a small terrace with his single water buffalo. He stopped to toss buckets of water over her back and head as the morning sun began to warm this wide valley. From here we walked up to the Unesco Viewpoint Memorial where we met our waiting driver. This one hour walk produced the best of our long rice terrace views in the three day trips we took around this beautiful island.

Beautiful view. These rice fields can take quite some time to walk through them. The view is amazing from anywhere you go. At the beginning you pay entrance fee but while walking the field there are huts and people there demand from you to pay a "donation" otherwise they don't want to let you pass them and there is no way around it. I don't really understand this obligatory "donation" even though you pay entrance fee. Otherwise it is very beautiful. walking around in flip flops is not really the best idea so think about wearing sneakers or trekking shoes.

Beautiful!. Hire a driver and view the terraces; amazing and great for photos. Our driver took us to watch the harvest and explain the process. I won't complain about work again after watching the harvest.

Beautiful view but totally over exploited. Beautiful but totally over exploited..you are charged as you drive into the village, village entrance fee, parking fee, then you have to pay gratuity to people on rice terrace to let you cross at varying levels of the terraces,,they won't let you pass until you pay, there's some cozy cafe and restaurant in the area but not much to do or see other than take a few photos.

Ready... set... TREK!!! 🇮🇩. Tegalalang is known for its rice terraces! My day tour included this amazing and scenic attraction! I explored and trekked on my own but you can definitely get a guide here if you must!First thing you'll notice is the endless choices of vendors along the street selling awesome Balinese souvenirs! There are also some food places near the stairs so you can grab some much needed refreshments before or after your trek! Anyway, make sure to make time for this! The views are very nice and worth every step and sweat, lol! There are locals in small huts in some areas and a small donation is greatly appreciated by them! TIP: it would probably be best to visit the terraces early morning! I was here mid afternoon and I was sweating bullets just walking down the stairs!!! Regardless it was an amazing experience and it was not crowded so it was very easy to climb up and down and take pictures!
Island sightseeing. Stayed in Nusa Dua so took a 1 hour drive by moped. This place was stunning, amazing colors and went on for ages. Amazing countryside

Nice view to relax. Have great time with family here, need to claim up to the rice terrace, thus not suitable for old age. You are force to give some donation in order to proceed claim to higher terrace.

Great outlook - pity about the hawkers. I've taken visitors to Bali here on a number of occasions and the view is always spectacular, however, the number of hawkers harrying you for "buy, buy, buy" is getting beyond a joke.
Beautiful sight. Worth going if you have the time. It's beautiful. We were there at the right time when the padi are yellowish gold in colour.

Visit. The place gets more popular each time,definitely worth a visit,scenery fantastic. Eating places provide a top view,stop for lunch and enjoy. If your fir enough do the walk through the rice fields.

pleasant morning walk. As a part of our day trip in Ubud we had been to this rice fields. with slippery side paths the walk was a pleasant relief from the usual city's hustle bustle . The wind chime at the top of the hillock can be heard right till the roads . The journey way up is almost a 45 mins to 1 hr trek , the locals have created intermediate toll shacks were they might ask for donations and also serve fresh coconut water if you are puffing and panting due to the walk up hill . i would not recommend the trip during the noon as the heat is too much and the walk is not suggested for kids or aged folks
Nice drive. Lovely tour and so much to look at. We had a good guide that explained the rice harvesting and process excellently.
Beautiful Sight to see. What a beautiful, photogenic sight to see! We stopped by here on our Bali Eco Tour cycling tour. Make sure to not miss it in Ubud!

Great place to stop. This was one of the places we wanted to stop on our tour of several places so our driver dropped us off and we went to explore.The amount of stairs to get from the road to get to the bottom of the rice fields was a bit daunting but well worth it. The place was absolutely beautiful to visit and the views were spectacular from the top of the rice terrace. Didn't stay long but glad we stopped to check it out.

Early morning is beathtaking. We decided to visit the rice temples at about 6am, why? Well, first we were still a little tipsy from the night before and also because we wanted to catch the sunrise hitting the rice. Result? STUNNING.We also got in and out before the crowds, and the heat. I recommend visiting before lunch time to avoid lots of people. That being said, it is such a large place that other people don't tend to get in the way except for photo ops.
Nice view. Nice view, but the shopping next to it was a bit too much to handle. It is the same stuff you can buy elsewhere, but it was easier to batter down to lower prices with the locals here.

beautiful terraced fields.. lovely place to see traditional rice fields. Not good if you have limited or poor mobility as it is quite steep in places. there are also steps leading down into the fields which are also quite steep if you have limited mobility. However it is possible to view them from the road or from one of the cafes/restaurants that overlook the rice fields. only "downside" was the number of children selling postcards and asking for donations to pay for their school fees. Bit pesky after a while. several shops along the road where you can buy the "usual" Bali things-sarongs, t shirts, bags etc.We sat at a restaurant and had drinks, as it was quite a hot day.

Great views. I'll up a chair in one of the cafes overlooking the Rice Terraces- have a cold drink or a snack. Nice place where you can sample teas and coffees. Stunning views. Can even trek thru the terraces and get first hand experience.

Enchanting. It is pleasure to see such terraced rice fields spread over large ares. The hills are terraced and paddy grown therein. We noticed in between other crops were also cultivated like cabbage, tomatoes etc to supplement the income of Bali farmers.

Wonderful . If you're in Ubud for the first time, you must visit the rice terrace & tick it off the list. Great photos, good little walking tracks, plenty of shops & cafes to sit in to relax, chill & take in the views. Simply wonderful.

A bit of a money making scheme. Paid 150k for a taxi here and back which was decent. I think we paid 20k to pass into the rice terrace village. Not really sure why it was just a man on the side of the road requesting money... So we started to walk down, the track is quite difficult in flip-flops I'd recommend trainers as its quite muddy and dusty. You get up to where the good views are and there is a lady asking for a "donation" for the bridge, basically there's one path and she stands in front of it until you pay. Oh and it's a minimum of 10k, I didn't realise there would be a minimum for a donation..Then you get to the next bit and there's a man holding the baskets that hold the crops and asks if you want a photo. You take it and then he says MONEY. Then there's a little girl asking if you want to have a picture. The views were nice but I got fed up of being pestered for money. She probably had more money than I did in that tub of donations.

An amazing view!. We came to see the rice terraces after seeing photos - but the photos just don't capture the beauty. It was only about $3 each to enter, we walked around the top and found a little cafe to sit at and look out at the terraces. Unfortunately we were unprepared so did not take suitable shoes, however if we had of, we would have definitely done a trek through the fields. Amazing place!
Amazing view. Stopped here as part of an Eco-Tour where we were allowed to enjoy the scenery. The view of the terrace is truly breathtaking and such terrace is a must see when you're in Bali.

Indeed, very picturesque. Go early in the morning if you want to catch photos with no other tourists. There will be people asking for "donations" to cross the paths, reason is that they maintain a certain stretch but just give them what you want/can. It was a friend and I, we only had change as we left everything with our driver. This is a place with lots of photo ops.
Unique Sights in Bali. Beautiful rice terrace in Bali, with many huts on top the mountain so you can enjoy coffee or meal while enjoying the view

Good but not great. This is very simple scene for a sightseeing, not breathtaking. I have visit in few times. The best is in raining season, which the rice is the most vivid green. There are many shops sale paintings and also few coffee shops and restaurants. There is a dirt track to walk through the rice terrace. But if you are in a hurry, 15 mins is enough for photography. Please take note that on the sunny day, it is really hot over there.

Reminded me of Sting singing "Fields of Bali". I really loved doing this walk one morning. Looking out at the fields while walking around and around the different paths were breathtaking! Only word of caution, bring some small change with you to pass through some of the rice terraces... Glad that we found some change and were allowed to "pass". Overall I could do this probably every morning.. Also wear tennis shoes because it will be slippery in parts and you don't want to fall and break your neck..
Tegalalang Rice Terrance a great experience. Amazing experience to be enjoyed with the family as whole. Had the opportunity to take some pictures of the scenery and it was a time well worth it.
Lovely and peaceful. Spend some time here... It's a great experience, and it produces wonderful pictures for your memories.

Another tourist trap. Interesting to look at from a distance if you like a "staged" ricefield - I suggest you wind down the car window, take a pic and drive on! Stopping means paying for parking, dealing with the constant stress of aggressive hawkers, having to "donate" a fixed amount for entry once across the bridge and having to say "no" to buying postcards from beautiful Balinese children who beg for you to give them money to feed their sisters, brothers, parents, grandparents etc etc (it was gut wrenching). The place is tourist trap and far too commercial - nothing authentic about it. Plenty of authentic rice fields can be seen on the drive from Ubud to Kintamani Volcano.
Nice view from the restaurant. We visited Tegalalang rice tellace by rent-motorbike and had lunch by the restaurant named Cafe Dewi . Having nice time to be relaxed !

It's now my Facebook profile picture!. If you have the time, go see this terraced rice field. It's something out of a picture. It is lush and green and worth seeing if you are in the area. Go later in the day to avoid crowds.

Picturesque. Make sure you take your camera as the rice terraces here are incredibly photogenic! Also, take a hat & water as it gets very hot and there is little shade as you are walking. If it has rained recently then take care as it will be slippery. You descend into the valley, then climb up again and can continue as far as you like it would seem, we were out for about 45 minutes which was long enough given the heat. Passed two toll points manned by locals along the way, paying 5k at each, which I was happy to pay given the stunning views. Also had option to take a photo holding some rice harvesting equipment which I declined.

View from the heaven. forgot Vietnamese paddy fields, Balinese would pride themselves at mere mention of Tegalalang paddy views. in our last trip to Bali, we enjoyed these mountains and rice fields of Tegalalang.best view is offered when you travel from Ubud to Lovina or simply Ubud to Tegalalang.
Stunning. Beautiful. Took my breath away. We did a short stop. I wish we would have had more time to hike down into the terraces. Do not miss!

Go here for excellent photo op of the rice terraces. Located reasonably centrally if you're staying in Ubud. It's a tourist magnet however the views of the lush rice terraces justify a quick stop for a few pictures. If you'd like a more immersive experience, you could walk down and wander amongst the rice terraces. There are a couple of restaurants and local shops around as well.

Rice fields on the hill sides. Experience the view of rice fields growing in contoured furrows on hillsides.Meet the locals selling reproduced postcards Local markets line the road opposite the viewing area of the fieldsTake a walk down the hill into the fields.

Amazing views. The views in this area are just amazing! well worth the drive. There are some nice places to eat but pick them out as some are not so good, we did have a lovely lunch and there are some shops as well, found some bargains but you have to look hard. The drive there is truly wonderful

Stunning view of the rice terrace!!!. We stopped here along our way to see other places. The view was amazing! Took several pictures, I hope they turn out. We did not walk the terrace as we didn't have the time. I wish we had more time to enjoy a closer look.

good exercise. by walking a little bit down stairs and see the panorama, forget the hawkers if they are aggressive, and keep focusing to where you put steps to save your tracking down to paddy fields, would be a great fun, be careful, the river is narrow and deep enough if someone fall that will be a bad thing for your body. sleepery also, just be careful especially when wet. hv a good time

Beautiful view . Must visit if you are on bali. I only went to this place to ubud for a daytrip by my own with a private uber driver. I payed 300k for the way from semynak to ubud and back. I could spent there the whole day with a coconut and watching the nice view.

beautiful paddy terrace scenary. its worth to spend at least 30 minutes and wandering around to find a good spot for photos. but trust me, most of the spots are picturesque! only the crowd will be the downside as you will be struggling to find empty spot for good photos. this place is just nearby to the most of Ubud best resorts, you may pay a second visit if you stay nearby.

Very picturesque, but too busy!. This is certainly a lovely spot! The terraces are impressive and really suck you in. A lovely walk (early in the morning to avoid the masses of tourists and stunt models, who will suck you in for an expensive photo!) and coffee in the coffee shop with a priceless view! Definitely worth it!
Amazing!!!. What a beautiful place to visit and take a walk around the rice fields. You will enjoy this. Afterwards stop at a restaurant for some thing to eat and look at the views.

Sums up to expectations!. We have rice terraces in the Philippines but this one sums up to my expectations. Plus it's free so why not pass by it. Since the area is close to the road it's best to use either have a van tour so you can go down and take a closer look at the terraces. There are also stores around the area so you can eat when your stomach starts to grumble. Must see if you havent seen any terraces before!

Just Beautiful . That place is a nice view point. The green from the rice is very calming and the atmosphere there is good.To go to that place is good in the morning before all the masses of people arrive. It is a must once in Udud to see that beautiful place.The possibility to go into the fields without a guide makes the access friendly and the locals are very friendly.
Fay Labiris . A visit to the rice terraces is a must while you holiday in Bali. Very beautiful. We were also lucky to see the locals harvesting the rice

Defenetly worth a look if your in Ubud very green and peaceful so different to our pastures. So quite and peaceful my husband and I hired a moter bike and was not hectic very nice ride up to this beatufull place we passed so many little markets so much cheaper than Ubud same quality .
Amazing views. The views were breath taking. We stayed in Ubud and it only took us 20 minutes on the scooter definitely worth the ride

Its free so why not if you never see this before. Actually the view is not bad especially for those never see the rice field before. However its just ok to me because i saw something better than this but seen we pass by this area so why not? This natural scenery is located at the roadside but it is not really attracted me because I have saw something even better than this in Boh Tea Plantation in Cameron. The only difference was this is paddies plantation that one was tea plantation. Well, the weather here is quite good, windy and refresh, you can walk down to the field but must be careful of every step you walked. I saw a lot of tourist walked down to the fields too. There are a few souvenirs shops along the road, you can enjoy a cup of beverage at the mini café if you want to.

Good photo opportunity. Not much to do or see other than take a few photos. Pestered but small kids for money for tat.but to be expected and not expensive.had a drink overlooking the rice tiers at the end of our long sightseeing day.worth an hour of your day.
Simply amazing !!!. Amazing, beautiful, peaceful, so green !!!!You can pay to enter inside the actual rice terrace and it's 1$ or you can stay on top and watch the beautiful view
Take the time and enjoy the amazing view.. Absolutely beautiful natural landscape near Ubud.A must visit if you are in Bali.Some cozy cafe and restaurant in the area.Simply stunning

Its good scenery . The scenery of green paddy fields is mesmerizing. But if u are the tired kind, lazy to go and walk through the field, then that is it. Its just paddy field and taking picturesBut for someone who have seen paddy field, i'd still say its nice to come and visit if you have plenty of time to spare
Worth a visit. Great place to visit, explore the rice fields and have a delicious lunch amongst the rice patties. Go in the morning and find hidden places - it's worth it.

Must visit!. Terraces of rice fields, quite a nice walk and you will be perspiring after that.There are also voluntary donations along the trek for the local rice farmers so do bring along some small change

Overrated. We travelled so far out of Seminyak and when we finally reach this place, it was not as good as we thought it would be. Going down the rice terrace might be quite dangerous as there is a risk of falling down since there are no properly steps and gonna walk on dirt path.

Eat, pray and love.. We loved our time at tegalalang rice terrace. it was simply amazing, we rented a bike and went there by ourselves, took our time to walk all over it, after just stayed a bit siting at one of the cafes with this amazing view, it was pretty full of tourists and hard to walk slowly and take pics at the rice field but it was amazing anyways.
Breathtaking. Just don't use flip flops, as we have to walk up and down on a damp land. View was fascinating, it's hard to find place like this in the city nowadays.
Lots of photo opps here!. This is a gorgeous place to walk and enjoy Bali. There are multiple trails and it's lovely to walk beside the river, or along other trails that lead to villages or temples.

amazing view. it is in Ubud so don't miss it !,, Ubud is a historical place but rice terrace is outside it so beware of traffic ,, also beware of stairs there as they r dangerous ,, you have to pay gratuity to people on rice terrace to let you cross it as they r collecting that money to fix stairs and bridge ,,take a hat with u and wear a good shoes
Looking down to the terrace rice fields. The splendor of the country side . The people were friendly food was tasty . If it was raining which it didn't would have made the experience interesting .
Tegalalange Rice Terrace. very nice view. You can sit in some nice restaurants at rice terrace or walk around to the rice fields. Only 25 min by motorbike to get there

Very peaceful . This is one of the most beautiful places I visited in Ubud.... The place is wide , very peaceful and have beautiful scenery. You can reach the top and sit quietly on the cliff just listening to the air, birds and the music of the place.

Great. We visited here recently and had a great time walking the track to the rice terrace. Views were great and well worth the trip. Beware of the STAIRS! lots of them so if you can't handle stairs or lots of walking this is not for you.

Beautiful green and steamy!. Loved our visit to the rice terraces, we climbed our way down into the terrace, make sure to wear good shoes to walk in!Such a hot day but worth the hike through, take some small notes as there are couple of spots that some people try to get some small money from you. It's optional I think but hey what's a few $ here and there I'm not sure if they do much though?Good photo opportunity so bring a camera if rice terrace are your thing.We came early as we had a scooter which was great, as we were leaving the tourist buses were coming in so come early if possible, the cafes opposite the terraces was a nice place to sit and take in the ambience.

Beautiful view. It's a marvelous sight to behold, really shows how agrarians were able to change a landscape, turning a mountainside into even steps of green.No charge needed but donations accepted at varying levels of entry. Really wish this was developed into an educational experience where they'd tell you about how rice is harvested and processed.
Stunning. A beautiful landscape set on the side of a small hill. You can walk through the rows of the field and see the locals hard at work. Definitely worth a visit to see the stunning landscape.
Worth seeing but have seen nicer. Beautiful but totally over exploited (in the tourist sense) rice terraces. You are charged as you drive into the village to ensure they get their fee.

Nice Location but beware...... . This is one of the well known and heavily visited rice terraces by tourists exploring just beyond Ubud. The difficulty with visiting is getting your timing right to beat the traffic jam and also to see the terraces while they are at their best and beautifully green. As with all crops the latter is much more difficult to determine, however, even if the greenery is lacking the ingenuity of the subak is worth the trip. The chaotic traffic is due to tourism and small roads that cannot cope with parked vehicles. Patience is your friend. Sadly though, making cash is the main theme here.......make sure you bring plenty just to cover costs, then extra if you want to risk shopping and bartering for highly priced items. Arrive in your own vehicle or on a scooter and expect to get slugged left, right and centre. First of all you will be required to pay an "entrance fee" upon entering the area from either end. If you ask what the entrance fee includes e.g parking, walking the terrace etc. you will be told "entry only" and it's not cheap. Balk at the price and you will be told "if you don't like it, leave"!! (Seriously?!). You will also find that you get slugged a parking fee when you're leaving too. If you decide to walk the terraces be prepared to pay another fee that is supposedly a "donation"......this donation had a starting price of 10,000Rp/person but drops to 5,000Rp if you are prepared to argue the point. When you think you've got over that annoyance you'll soon discover that you'll be up for another donation in three more locations. Some of these collection "agents" are pretty aggressive and will not let you pass until you pay. Again if you argue that you have already paid you will get the "if you don't like it, leave" attitude. We saw people getting turned away because they refused to pay again. It's a very disturbing trend in Bali at the moment to grab as much money as possible from tourists and tell them where to go if they don't want to pay. Very poor for tourism. Also, be careful if taking photos. You might find that the farmer, old lady, kitten owner etc etc will want a "fee" for your shutter button going off. They will ask a crazy amount too and get pretty narky if you disagree.  Then there are the restaurants, if you're lucky to choose an OK one you're set.......but good luck with the toilets (that you'll pay for "maintenance" and wonder where the money goes). The restaurants make a killing on over-priced food for the most part but generally the few I've tried have served pretty good meals. I go to some of these places more than once in a year as they're not far from Ubud and a nice change from eating locally.
