Tegalalangs Ceking Terrace is a nice view but it's very touristy and overall it's expensive. Sadly, I've seen many people leave feeling very disgruntled and unimpressed with the locals. I have to wonder how long it will be before tourism will dwindle as it has in Kintamani due to the aggressive nature and money grabbing of the community?Wake up leaders of the Banjar, you're milking the cash cow dry.

Reminder of Growing Years. WE stayed at Abing Terrace Resort and the rice terrace is not too far away and in fact there is a track that one can take to the site while enjoying the sounds of birds,cricket,frogs and the whole lot...and I decided to go for the walk because I was brought up in the padifiels when I was young while my mother toiled to harvest the padi or assisted in digging the plot of land in order to get the field ready for the transplanting of the padi seedlings.We only returned home very late in the evenings and I often got a ride, for part of the way anyway, on the piggyback of my elder brother.Those were the years before I was old enough to enter school....

Melbourne Traveller. Not too bad a placeI was driven here as part of my day tourReminded me of my hometown Sri LankaI feel the area would be better if there werent as many markets along the way of where the rice terraces are

Pretty view but limited viewing area. We stopped here enroute to another activity and wished we had brought our own drone as someone else did as the view would have probably been a bit better.Word of warning - based on its location and where all the viewing platforms are located, it is better to visit in the afternoon when the sun is behind you if you want to get great pictures.

Just spectacular. I absolutely loved this place. So picturesque and beautiful. One of the locals gave us his baskets so we could take pictures and put his hat on our head. It was a wonderful experience. There was some lovely cafes and places to eat along the road overlooking and set into the terraces. We sat and had a drink and something to eat and admired the views.

Beautifull ricefields. I stop by at tegalalang rice fields on my way to ride horse at Ubud Horse Stables that located not far from the rice fields. The rice fields was good and beautifull. But only the warung by the road was not a good idea as it make it look dirty. The parking on the road looks crowded and makes traffic.
nice place. . it's a nice place, the view is great. have a meal in the restraunts enjoying the view of the rice terraces.

You must feast your eyes on this if ever you get the chance.. Oh my oh my, came across this piece of heavenly paradise by complete chance. It was a particularly cloudy day so we jumped on our scooters and headed straight on the main road where our spa bungalow is located, Lokasari on the Raya Andong. I have never in my life seen such beauty, the views across the basin are utterly breathtaking. We took a coffee over looking the rice fields and it really did leave me speechless, and that doesn't happen too often, I urge you to make the pilgrimage.

The green paradise!. We (a couple) visited rice terrace located in Ubud one day in August. The temperature was hot and the place required hiking skills. Because we had very limited time, we needed to run up and down the hills that was quite tiring. Besides that, the place itself was spectacular as it had unique view to terraced landscape full of rice crops. In addition, there were tall palms and other trees around, that made land and sky to be green.It is definately a must for those, who want to be dazzled by the green color!

Amazing views. It's definately worth taking a drive past Ubud to see these awesome rice terraces. You can access them directly from the road although it's extremely steep and quite dangerous if youre not fit and nimble. We did attempt to climb down the valley on the road side, and others crossed the valley to climb up the other side, but I wouldn't recommend it unless you are very good at climbing as its wet, slippery, muddy natural paths. There are the usual roadside stalls selling all the same same but different stuff, which detracts from the beauty of the place, but you get that everywhere nowadays.

Got to be done!. When you're in Bali you can't not visit a rice terrace. This one is great, and is free although if you're walking through there are points where you will be asked to make a donation of your choice for the up keeping of bridges etc. Also one of the ladies that worked there asked us if we wanted a photo so we said yes but little did we know after we had the photo she wanted some money so be aware of that. Make sure you wear decent shoes, we rocked up in flip flops not knowing how muddy and slippy it would be! Great activity to include into your day but you don't need to spend very long there if you don't want too!

Lovely views. I know there are many rice terraces in the area and I viewed the ones on Jl Raya Ceking from the balcony of Cafe Dewi. It was wonderful to sit down and enjoy the view without crowds and folk trying to sell you something. The light was particularly good and I got some great photos.

Scenic View near Ubud. You come here for the scenic views. This was one of my highlights for my stay in Ubud but I admittedly am a nature lover and a hiker. The terrain isn't easy and those who are more immobile may want to steer clear of this one. It is lush green space with a nice little village nearby with shops and restaurants. There were some "tolls" set up by locals who try not to let you pass unless you donate to them. I found these to be a little annoying. The cost to enter the fields is nominal (~2 USD) but these people try and take more money although I found myself donating small amounts as I wanted to continue on the path. I recommend this to travelers who like to hike and who love nature.

Beautiful scenery . A short trip from Ubud will see you here.Some fantastic views of the rice terraces.There is also fresh mountain spring water running by that you can use to cool off with.There are a few restaurants around this area and also souvenir shops.Well worth a visit for some romantic photos but you can finish seeing everything in a short time.

A great walk through will numeous Toll. When you see these rice fields from the road they look wonderful with people walking through. However as my guide pointed out, that in case you want to walk freely you need to pay a token at various points. A walk through these fields could easily set you back around 50,000 - 80,000 IDR.

Stunning view. Went here with my family of 3 adults and 4 kids (ages 2, 6, 8 and 10). We all had fun! The hike is quite easy even for my 2 year old. A good way to burn some fat. Went here on a bright sunny hot day.Tourist are asked to give some sort of tip on several point of the hike, which is understandable to me since these are the farmers who manages the land and a little token of appreciation (gratuity) would mean a lot to them. We've met a farmer along the way and he showed us how they work in the field. He then brought us in some kind of gazebo where we requested for some refreshing coconuts (very cheap!) and the kids chatted and played with him while the adults admire the beauty of the surrounding. I gave him a tip for accompanying us and he was very grateful for that. Lots of souvenir shops along the road overlooking the rice terraces, I think they're kind of pricey though for Indonesia standard.I would come back here if we'll visit Bali again.

Nice view, but that's it.. If you are passing by, Tegalalang rice terrace is definitely worth a stop. Bice views, especially when the sky is böue and the fields are green. But honestly, there are tons of rice terraces in central Bali, so travelling there just for this one location wouldn't be worth it.

If you come to Bali, you will want to see it. Went here on my trip to ubud. Wanted to see the classic rice Terrance. There were some cafes set on the side of the cliff to enjoy the view. I just went to take some photos and the headed to a coffee plantation which over looked a small rice terrace. I'm glad I saw it and snapped a few rad photos.
just scenic. The terraces are very nice for a walking the evening or first thing in the morning for beautiful sunrises.

Unique experience . It's certainly a beautiful spot, and to be able to walk amongst the terraces is indeed a unique experience. The curves of the landscape are mesmerising and utterly photogenic.However as with most of Indonesia, us tourists are exploited to the full, and you're expected to pay wherever an opportunity exists, such as to cross a rusted unsafe bridge from one terrace to another. The 'donation' is intended for upkeep, however corruption means the money never goes where it should, leaving places untidy and left to rust in ruin. Eventually this will come at a cost to the country....This aside, you will enjoy the views!
Stunnng. Very beautiful scenery but can be a bit crowded. We walked around a little for about 15 mins and took some great pictures. I think this is one of these tick box placed if you have the time.
Amazing sight to see. I'd highly recommend visiting here. Really interesting to see how rice is made and how large the fields are. Makes for a good half day trip and the sights are beautiful.

Just beautiful..don't miss this... The Rice Terrace was just beautiful and you can walk it, breathtaking..also there is a very good restaurant which I can't remember the name which afterwards as a reward make sure you go to..lots of fresh made juices and good food..just a beautiful site.

Absolutely beautiful.!. A place not to be missed.! Though we were charged at a minimum fee for passing through via car. Amazing view from the above, but very daunting as we get into the rice terrace as they isn't any proper paths. We had to walk by the edges and literally slide down to get to the lower level of the terrace. Highly recommend to visit this place with proper shoes. They have very nice cafes overlooking the terrace as well.!

terraced rice paddies. A must see if you happen to be in Ubud, Bali. I was there in the "dry" season but it was still very green and lush. Coconut trees, banana trees and lots of rice paddies. Very pretty at sunset. Find a little roadside place, buy a coconut water and enjoy the view. You are able to walk through the terraces of rice paddies and take in all the views.

Just like in the pictures. It's really amazing and beautiful the rice field views. Just like in the pictures. You can go up and down the rice field, some people will ask you for money but you are not obliged to it. You'll have some places to shop and eat if you please.
Beatiful to see. Go early to catch the best light and try to beat the crowds. Several restaurants overlook the terraces so you can linger and view.

I wasn't expecting this. I found this by accident, on my way to Bali Purina coffee plantation, so stopped to have a look. a bit strenuous but absolutely stunning. to see the whole thing you need some pennies as a donation for the upkeep of the footbridge, but wow!

Wonderful view of terraced rice fields!. We arrived late morning! As we were gazing the rice fields, we heard the melodic sounds of Balinese music. We concluded to eat at one of the restaurants with views of the rice fields! Absolutely beautiful natural landscape and a treat for the soul!

Try to go beyond the terrace they drop you in. These terraces seem cozy and small but they are actually huge. It was really great to go a bit beyond and explore parts where there were less tourists. Be aware of locals asking donations, sometimes in the sense they block your free passage... that's the only annoyibg thing. For the rest it's a peaceful place ro go for a walk.

The Green Cove. Tegallalang Rice fields enchanted me as a reader and so was a definite must go when I planned my Bali trip. The cab driver dropped us at a point which was higher in terrain amidst rows of shops showcasing very colorful and attractive curios. Whilst I must admit that it did distract me a bit, we soon found our way to a point, the beginning of about a 100 steps down through the greens to the greens back up to the top. An innocent sense of guilt caught me for having been proud of being a Keralaite, the southernmost state of Kerala in India, the God’s own country as fondly called .The chirping of birds and screeching of insects ,beautiful orchids and wild flowers on the way, it was freshness,rejuvenation,bliss and a feeling of oneness with nature which left me in total awe of the creator, which even made me question if the life we live back in the concrete jungle is even worth it? The green sandwiched between bright sky blue and rich browns of the soil below. Though the 100 step climb was pretty much a pulmonary function test, it really was worth every breath that I lost
Great view. The view over the ricefields are awesome and within 15 minutes by scooter from Ubud easy reachable. It's worthwile to have a coffee there and to enjoy the pretty landscape.
Beautiful spot! . What a gorgeous place to visit! Def worth stopping to have a look, you can stroll through, however we were over the heat by then!

Lovely . Visited the rice terraces last week as part or a day trip and we enjoyed it even though it was so hot we didn't walk through the whole terrace (it was midday and there is no shade when you are on the terrace). It was busy but not as busy as we expected, and people asking for donations to walk past their bridge/hut on the terrace were friendly and it's so cheap for us there is no point arguing (10,000 for the 3 of us). The terrace is big and beautiful just like on the postcards and we saw different types of rice and learnt the principles of rice farming thanks to our great guide. Had lunch in one of the warungs overlooking the terrace which was really lovely too, and not too busy.

Should see but very touristy and contrived. This place should be seen because we've all seen photos of Bali with it, but it is a tourist trap. There's really no rice produced here, the fields are kept green for the tourist and there are even locals charging you to "pass" as you are climbing the terraces. You can just bypass and avoid them. Not impressed, although, this once was a marvel of useful engineering.
A beautiful green valley. The terraced slopes are a work of art and were an oasis in the unnaturally very dry surrounding countryside.
Just wooow . Beautiful, peaceful. Also very interesting to discover this specific technic to irrigate and grow rice. We went in november and there were almost no others tourists in the area :)
Nice view for lunch. Went here as part of our day tour. Had lunch in one of the over priced restaurants overlooking the terraces. Nice place to stop by.

Green and Traditional Taste!. a nice green view you could see. The best part of Tegalalang Rice Field is the terrace of rice field. But it's better to manage it well between the farmer there, so they also could serve the guest warmly. And also, the merchant and shops could be designed very well, because it rather looked untidy. But the most important information if you wanna go to Tegalalang, you'd better go early in the morning (before 10 a.m), because it would be shinny.

nice view. Beautiful green rice terrace on the cliff bank and understanding how does the local farmer work on it hardly to make rice. It is a beautiful site that you must go and visit directly and you will be in real Balinese ambiance.

Beautiful. Worth a quick stop to take pictures. I didn't take the hike as I'd been sightseeing all day and it was grossly hot outside. Just beware that you will get harassed and hounded for your business by shop owners perched along the side of the road. I also had to pay 10,000RPH for parking?

Nice but touristic. Close to Ubud, all tours go there. I recommand you to rent your motorbike and go around 5.30pm when everybody 's gone. The rice terasses are just after the city and are well indicated. Just go straight !
Some drink and good view in the cafe. There are some cafe builds beside the Rice Terrace, it is good for have a sit ad get some drink there with a good rice terrace view.

Nice view. It is a nice view from up the road, and something you should have seen when visiting Bali. However there are lots of souvenir shops. Which means you have to say no about every 20 seconds...

A must visit !!!. The only place that you could experience walk up and down in the paddy fields that easy access. And you will get a beautiful picture form every angle. Don't forget to wear something flowy if you want to have a beautiful picture as beautiful as stars, since Kate Hudson had been picture taking in this area.

A worthwhile experience. The rice fields north of Ubud are worth the drive. We hired a scooter and drove up there ourselves and it took about 20 minutes. It is lovely to walk around the rice fields, however they are getting a bit over run with tourists so go early in the morning before the buses arrive.

Must Visit!!. As this is the face of Ubud, so everyone must visit Tegalalang Rice Terrace.A lot of cafe/shops facing the rice fields, so we can seat and relax while enjoying a fresh coconut with a jaw-dropping view of Tegalalang Rice Terrace.

Good time, Good Friends, Good experience. it was very nice view from upstair.. you can go downstair if u want to... they have so many restaurnt at the clif so you can eat with a brautifull panorama to see and there's one place that can serve and tell you about luwak coffee.. so for you guys that like to drink a coffee, you should tried that

Relaxing at Terraces padi place. Follow the trip at Tegalalang st. on 15 minutes by car or motor bike from Ubud central to northern this area you will arrived in Ceking Village.Which one this area famous about some Terrace padi view.They call Tegalalang Ceking Terrace.Not to big area as like Jatiluwih rice terraces but this is so pretty terraces for you do some small tracking or picknic with your friends or family is available and relax.Need spend time just for 30 minutes do arounding up and down this terraces.And you can see the farmer on street paddys area waiting for you take photo or they sell some original young coconut picking by them self.Some tourist i see they pay just Rp20.000/1 coconut and they will prepare ready drink for you.Totally time for 1 hour relaxing, taked photo and enjoy some food or lunch there is enough.Cause this people there also manage some small cafe for you with Indonesian food and chinesse food also weatern food and drinks.For the price is still cheap than kuta area.Normally the beauty of view there is when the Paddys still younger look like green grass in 1 month yers old after beginning time on processing grawth. They have 3 times harvest every years.Please try to visiting this area with relaxing and some art shop also waiting you there with bargain price.Remmember, you must bargain or negoitation every interest need buy some souvenir or gift every where in Bali.Esapecially in supermarket they have fix price already.Good luck.Hope you find me for Bali Driver anytime.Thank you.Best Regards,*Wayan.*Mobile: +87860708052.*Email: iwayantinggalseputra@rocketmail.com
Nice view. Really nice view and nice to see how rice is grown pretty annoying with two locals following us trying to sell us stuff they were relentless.

Donation or Tax. Beautifull place to visit.A funny thing: we went trough the bridge and a lady asked for a DONATION FOR THE BRIDGE 10000 Rhp ($1).It seems more a tax than donation. Anyway I was very happy to pay.The place is very nice.

Well worth a visit. The rice terraces were beautiful and unlike anything I've ever seen before. They are an easy trip from Ubud (about half an hour) and as soon as you arrive you'll be glad you came. The scenery is stunning, and the photos you'll get are even better!

Watch for "donation" viewpoints. Beautiful place, even in dry season. We only spent about 15 minutes here wandering around because we had other plans and still wanted to see the rice terraces. Great views, but look out for hidden signs for "donation" if you go down any steps. We went down a little path to take photos, only to be accosted by a woman pointing to a sign hidden in vines that said $100,000 donation (IDR).

The essence of Bali . A must to visit Ubud and this area. Truly spectacular such a beautiful contrast to the coast .Nobody haselling you lovely region for art and craft works much cooler than the coastal areas nice to see old traditions being held onto .
Stunning rice trraces. Worth a trip, even if you just relax at the cafes and enjoy the view of the rice terraces. If you have the energy do the walk.

One of the most beautiful scenery you will ever see. Enjoy the perfect cooperation between nature and people ! It is simply breathtaking!!!!Go there early in the morning , before lots of tourists show up.
Beautiful!. Highly recommend visiting the rice terrace if you have time while in Ubud. Absolutely breathtaking views!

Well worth visiting. Beautiful lush green terraces, brilliant photo opportunities. Recommend going early morning though as the bus loads from the beach areas arrive late morning/lunchtime and its packed. You have to fight off the street hawkers then too.
Beautiful rice plantations!. Excellent to appreciate while drinking something in one of many balconies. Also great to walk through the plantations. Very calm place.

The earlier the better. We got there at about 9:30 and it was the best time to be there. Very few other tourists had arrived so we didn't get asked for 'donations' as we walked round it is also much cooler at this time of the day to be walking up and down dusty dirt paths. Don't go down if you are unstable on your legs, but sit a look a while from one of the many restaurants and bars at the top. Had to pay Rp.10,000 each on the way up the road, but other than that it is free.
Greenny Scenery. The Tegalalang Rice Terrance representing the Kampung Style. On the other hand, the place is peaceful.

Rice Terrace. Small rice terraces, it is a nice view, but if you have seen the terraces in China, this is a bit disappointing. To much cultivating and organised around tourism. For those who have never seen a rice terrace, a nice first impression.

Highlight of Bali!. visiting the rice terrace was a highlight of my trip. The depth of colour can't be described. The terraces are an engineering marvel with water flowing everywhere to water the rice. This was classic Bali.
Nice but too crowded. Driver brought me here as a stop to take pictures. Too many cafes crowded with tourists for view of rice terraces. Great view。

Not as nice in the dry season and flooded with tourists. I went to Tegalalang today. It was dry and therefore I didn't get the verdant pictures/experience I had hoped for. Plus, about every 10 feet on my way down there, I was asked for money---sometimes as a purchase of postcards or some kind of grass hat, sometimes in return for taking a local's photo, sometimes for a blanket among the tourist stalls at the top of the road. Then, you cross a little bridge and you are stopped to give a mandatory donation to folks. I decided not to do this and just walked back, as I really didn't need to hike the terraces anyway given I had already done so after being lured into another tourist trap (a guy offering to show me nearby rice paddies). Bottom line: It's okay but not awe-inspiring. Disclaimer: I may be jaded from traveling for 3 1/2 months.

So much Bali.... In a way, this special landscape captures the essence of Bali with its tranquility, vibrant green colors and almost sculptural beauty. Like being in the middle of a postcard.Walk (carefully) along the narrow paths between the individual small terraces and perhaps you will see the farmer with the characteristic pointy hat working bent-over picking up the weed.Try to be there in the afternoon when the shadows from the vegetation seems to float down over the terraces.

Best time is early in the day. We took the advice of our driver and made the rice fields our first stop. There was a Rp.10,000 fee on the way up the road to the area and we were given an official ticket. There was hardly anyone else there and our driver parked right where he wanted to. We walked down the rough paths some with hand holds that would not have stopped a fly weight, most with nothing. The paths are loose dirt so if you are not so nimble on your feet best stay on the steps at the top that still offer great photo shots. Didn't get asked for a single donation that visitors later in the day get plagued with. The rice terraces are most picturesque even in the dry season and worth the stop off if you are in the area.

something different to look at rice fields. Was pretty fun, nice view of rice fields nice to have a walk around and spend time at markets. Half way up the rice fields they ask for a donation but then they ask for 500000RP $5AUD so you can walk up the top of the fields probably not worth it as you can walk all around everywhere else just aware of the people trying to sell you postcards etc in every direction you walk, the usual Bali, but just ignore them and wander around at your leisure. some nice cafes on the terrace.

Come early in the morning before 9am. Very nice when it's still empty and cool!. Shops will not be open by then but You can go down and walk around the paddy field with less people to charge you money and fees from every step. Near to lunch time it will be crowded and traffic jammed, kids shoved you postcards to buy with pleading looks asking money for school and other things.. it's fairly uncomfortable.
Nice, bit touristic terraces, but easy accesible. Nice rice terraces just outside Tegallalang. Easy accesible, but a bit touristic. Be aware of locals asking 'toll' to pass their lands.

Beautiful panorama. I went to Tegalalang with my mom by motorcycle from our hostel. It took about 30 minutes. By the time we got there, there are several cafes offering tourists the beautiful scenery of rice fields. Some local people will offer you to wear farmer's hat to strike a pose and pay them for sure.

It was just average. I was expecting a breathtaking view but whn i got there it was all there is to see. I mean its beautiful but its only a scene that conjour up everything. You just admire the terrace n contour of greens and thn after that everything is just a piece of green. I had a stop at a cafe with no fan and aircon. It was quite breezy and i was with my baby. The fd was just ordinary bcos the rice terrace is the ultimate attraction.

Beautiful to see, bad administration. It was beautiful to see however, as everything in Bali, nasty people always try to take advantage of foreigner and the block different places and they force you to give tips just to cross. Disgraceful

Nice place, but busy!. The main tourist stop to view the rice terraces. Great place to take pictures as you can access many different levels. You do have to pay to get it, but once you are in you are free to explore as you wish. There is a bridge you can cross if you venture down the hill, but they do ask for a donation when you cross. You will want to wear good shoes or sandals not flip flops or heels.Like most places in Bali, you will have to pay to use the bathroom. Worth a visit, but they can be crowded.

Glorious Bali. This is how i imagined Bali before coming for the first time. All shades of green in a single place. Peaceful local farm activity may be taking place there. Enjoy!There is also a restaurant where you get a nice view, but it isn't cheap... Worth it though.

Scenic but A LOT of tourists . The terraces were very beautiful, and the palm trees added interest to the scene. It is possible to walk down along the terraces on the dirt paths, but I didn't do this as there were SO many tourists wandering through the terraces already. Difficult to get good photos due to this (and yes, I'm aware I was one of them!)The road at the top is lined with souvenir shops like anywhere else in Ubud and surrounds, which spoils the 'natural' scenery a little. Some reviews mentioned payment at some point, but I did not come across any need for payment anywhere. However, perhaps I would have if I had walked down amongst the terraces? A grizzled old farmer with shoulder baskets was offering selfies with the tourists, and he happily smiled for many photos with people, which was nice. An old lady farmer took my hand to (unnecessarily) help me down a steep portion of the track, and was smiley and helpful, and did not expect payment. Overall, worth seeing, but perhaps try very early morning and there may be fewer people around?
Nice place :). Nice place to see rice terraces, people very friendly and food was great. You have to pay a fee to enter the are and then a fee when you walk around the rice terraces.
Very touristy. The rice terraces were not what I was expecting - while beautiful this is a tourist spot with lots of shops! Does look great in photos though.

Pleasing Sight...Tegalalang Rice Terraces. It was a bright day when we visited Tegalalang Rice Terraces. Beautiful Greenery all over. We had lunch at the Dewi Restaurant and had a very good view of the Terraces. We also walked along the fields and enjoyed the walk. Good place for photography!!
ricefields. rice fields are lovely to visit ware strong shoes as a lot of walking and climbing many stairs up and down stick to the steps as the fields and tracks are very slippery

Nice view . The views here are amazing. ...every time of year it looks different. ...my favorite is when the rice is ripe and ready to pick..... but that's as far as it goes. ...food is poor quality and over priced because of the view and service is terrible. ....I always try and arrive away from meal time and just have a quick photo session or a meander thru the rice than stop along the road back to ubud for bargains straight from the families making the many goods for sale. ..
Stunning views. Fantastic place to visit, you could easily wander for hours. Close to Ubud, you simply must visit. Grab a coffee from the myriad cafés with a view and relax the day away

Beautiful place. Amazing view, worth visiting when in Ubud. Lots of local shops on the way, many restaurants (cheap) and cafes. You can take a walk on the rice terraces. Very nice. Stunning in early morning when there is less people.
Amazing. Such an amazing site, loads of great stalls and restaurants around. Definitely recommend to anyone visiting Ubud / Bali

Stunning views. This is the best rice field terrace in Bali.View is amazing and it's a beautiful place.We were here with our 2 year old daughter it was ok but be aware where you step so you don't slip up or fall.Don't bring a stroller with you.Also there are these locals who are on different "stations" on the way up who demand a donation and they want 10 k or person and there are at least 4 of them we didn't go all the way and our driver said only pay 5 and not 10 well I am not sure what is right to do but bring small change with you so you have for the donation.
Great view. We had lunch here, but it was average, the meat was rather tough, so the vegetarian option might be better.

Awesome but beware. One of the most unique experiences in Bali that I had was at the rice terrace. It was beautiful and made me feel an intense feeling of awe because the canyon was massive and I felt like I was dropped in a travel brochure. This place had working rice farmers and the only note from me is to not get suckered to take a picture with one of these farmers. They are tricky and will ask for money after you've taken a picture with them or of any of their tools.
Every tourist's must see!. Place is a bit crowded, but soooo beautiful! wear comfy shoes tho, as some of the paths are quite slippery! Great experience.

Rice fields Bali. The location was breathtaking.Parking was difficult and busy as the main road was narrow and traffic was busy.However once you saw the scenery it was all worth it.The rice fields and surrounding countryside was an absolutely stunning. We spent about two hours walking the foot paths through the fields and taking lots of photographs.You will need to wear sneakers as the paths are very narrow and thongs (Flipflops) are not a good choice.There are nice cafes in the area to get refreshments.

The best thing in ubud. Very niceee, absolute tranquility .. traditional and original lifestyle of bali farmers .. with alot of pictures to take and and to climb ... u better have great fitness, cause u have to go in .... and out :)

Beautiful and worthwhile, despite the persistent requests for "donations". We (family of 4) spent an hour walking and photographing the rice terraces, and were glad we went. It's lovely! One caveat -- when we entered the area, we were solicited for a donation of 5,000 rupiah per person and happily gave our 20,000 (under 2 USD). A few minutes further on, another request. Then another, and another. We gave further donations at some, but were a bit put off by the persistence, and in some cases, the aggressiveness. One man actually even grabbed my wife's arm and pulled on it! I do get that different families are probably soliciting for themselves, but it is awkward. People, you need to get together and POOL YOUR "DONATIONS". And by the way, if you call it a "donation", that means it's supposed to be voluntary. No grabbing people!

Serene. Enjoyed going to this lush experience. It is a drive about hour depending on that Bali traffic and of course not much parking but we hired a car to take us out for the day and this was one of the stops. You have stalls mainly on one side selling all the Balinese stuff and of course even some on the rice field side. So you got out and ventured down by the rice fields we did not walk into the rice fields or really explore into the rice fields we stayed on the out skirts and had a snack at one of the restaurants that had a gorgeous view. The green layering of the rice fields is just mesmerising and I just loved it. I wished I could have walked out into the fields but with kiddos it didn't work out that way but it was lovely to see and of course the rice is delicious.

A must see!. Beautiful rice fields. Definately worth going. Cost 200 IR from ubed in a taxi (return).Free to get in.Best advice, go early ! We got there for 7:45am. No one else was there, its cooler and the sun comes up over the hills which is beautiful. I wish we'd gone earlier. You have to climb over the gate to get in though. Would have been a different experience if we had gone later. Few tourists starting to gather when we left at 9am. Our photos were free of randoms in the background. Bonus!

Must visit!. The rice terrace views here are phenomenonal! And lot of small cafes a nd restaurants to sit and enjoy the view. We were there around 2 pm, and were lucky enough to be able to see the terraces without hordes of tourist walking the terraces. When we left, that was the case, and does take some of the serenity of the place and view away. Nevertheless a must see destination if you are visiting Ubud area!
Small Rice Terrace. Very small rice terrace surrounded by cafes and novelty shops, nice place to stop for a drink and something to eat while passing through the area.
Peaceful and beautiful. The terraces are definitely a must in Ubud, the slow pace and sound of windmills is more then relaxing. Only downside is that is crowded with tourist, and are quite small.
very nice. Very nice drive , and very nice to see. There are nice places to eat there , and some shopping near by. the views are nice .

Nice rice terrace near Ubud. It's a nice place to get some beautiful photos,walk around the fields to close up yourself with this beautiful nature,once you feel tired get some refreshment on the local restaurant with the view facing the paddies

Wooww!. We stayed at Kampung Resort and decided to walk to the rice terrace about 10 minutes to the entrance where the steep stairs are.. We missed the sunrise, but we didn't regret it.. It was beautiful..!! Taken some nice pictures together.. But afterward we need to climb back up 200+ steep stairs.. Quite a morning exercise.. :)
Meh.. Stop for 5 minutes to take pictures and that's about it.If you are pressed for time, you can skip this attraction altogether.
Wonderful view!. Magnificient view. Good idea is if you don't want to walk around is just to visit any of the many restaurants providing good terrace view directy from the table.

Follow the street and get lost. Simply don't follow travel guides or gps system.
Take one road inside the terraces and get lost, you will be impressed from what your eyes will see.
And if you are lucky you will admire incredible wonderful hidden resorts.

Great view, can easily get there with scooter. Short drive in the North of Ubud, this place is easy accessible and a perfect picture motive. More a touristic spot, you have quieter rice fields but it's still nice to see, especially if you only have a day or two in Ubud. It's free, of course you have lots of shops etc around it.

Beautiful paddy terraces. About 30 minutes drive from Ubud downtown. Awesome view, fresh air, and I can't stop taking photos! There's 2 way to walk at paddy fields, one with nice cement road and the other is sloppy-rocky road. You can ask peoples there which way to go. A-must-go!

For city folks who have never seen rice paddy, for the rest just a photo opportunity. Yes its a close look at the terraced rice paddy, however excessive commercial interests around the place (line of tea shops and restaurants on the hill side from the road) just took the pleasure and beauty away. A recurring sight of unplanned development to capitalize on tourism.

Come early in the morning, worth your time!. Just north of Ubud, a short drive, dramatic rice terraces, some of the most spectacular in Bali. Make sure to arrive early, 8 AM best, definitely before 9 AM, before many tourists (and local vendors) arrive. Take your time to walk down between terraces, along irrigation canal, a magical place.

Dramatic view, picture-perfect. You can visit these rice Terrace just by simply asking a taxi driver to give u a tour for 3-4 hours. The view is dramatic, picture-perfect. Travel magazines post these photos routinely when they mention Bali, and with good reason. Can stop and sip out of a young coconut, while you take in the view

Rice fields. Amazing place to visit and spend a few hours it crowded but still worth the visit you
should go with a guide sit by one of the terrace restaurants and enjoy a meal
Gorgeous. These terraced rice paddies present a beautiful picture of traditional rice farming in Bali. A great place to take pictures.

Beautiful but overrun by tourists. We had great expectations to the Tegalalang Rice Terraces and myself in particular for some nice shots with my camera. Surprised completely when we arrived to see an unexpected circus of tourists all over the area mostly occupied by taking selfies more than enjoying the spectacular views. In spite of everything it's nice but overrated.
Interesting. Beautifully maintained rice fields that can be viewed from the roadside. I think our driver paid a kind of entrance fee so beware if you are visiting by yourself.

Great To Visit. This is a great experience to see how hard the farmers have it. If you have children it's worth sharing it with them so they understand how lucky we are. When we were driving there we saw the rice drying on tarps on the side of the road.

Was just OK. It was over 2 hours to get this place from Ubud. I was hoping to see 'green' rice terrace just like in the pics. However, when we got there.. they were mostly brown! So disappointed.
O well...
Do it for your zen. A gorgeous way to spend a few hours, so serene and peaceful. Your mind will thank you for the respite after the hustle of the main streets.

Nice to see. If you have nothing to do just grab a motorbike and drive up the Jl. Raya Tegallalang Road to the rice fields. It is very easy to find and for free :)
It is very impressive to see the water system in action.

Must visit. The rice fields are amazing, you must experience the nice views.
But beware of the tourist traps (woman and men trying to sell you expensive stuff)
As most nice places in Bali, I recommend to visit them with a rented guide from the hotel.

Very photogenic. The Tegalalang Rice Terraces were, by far, the most photogenic rice terraces I saw in Bali, and the most accessible. One can see it from the road and there are view decks for taking pictures. One can also walk along the terraces. There are plenty of shops beside the road if one is inclined to buy souvenirs or knick knacks after viewing the rice terraces.

Stunning, but full of tourists. This place is catered to the tourism market. We were overwhelmed with how many tourists and foreign visitors. No rice field workers to be found at the terraces, only foreigners taking photos. It was great to hike around and get some exercise after a full day in the car, but not my first destination choice of our trip in Bali.

Beautiful tourist trap but worth the visit.. This is a very unique example of the terraced rice fields. Cascading down both walls of the valley, they appear as sculpted green stairs, Amazing work on the part of the farmers, and very photogenic. You can take it all in with a short stop or If so inclined you can walk amongst the terraces. Rice terrace agriculture is not limited to Bali, but this site truely exemplifies it. The area attracts many tourists, there are many restaurants with great view of the terraces and many souvenir shops. Admission is IDR 10,000 per person paid on the road in. The entire area as you drive in and out is quite interesting to see.
Catch it in the afternoon light.. Quite impressive - one side of the steep valley beautifully terraced, the other side cluttered with shops and restaurants, with touts galore.

Beautiful. Very beautiful landscape. A must see if staying in Ubud. Can be a bit step at times and make sure you do wear closed in shoes. There are farmers stationed throughout asking for donations to keep the paths maintained. But definitely worth it.
Great scenery . The rice fields are an amazing piece of scenery. Going to bali seeing rice fields are a must. You would be impressed
Really pretty, close to Ubud. Rent a Motorbike and go there when it is not to hot. Going midday is really hot, so do bring water or buy at the shops at the entrance.
Pretty!. We didn't get out of the car and only took pictures from the top. We were too tired to do more walking, but it was beautiful!

Close up with nature.. On our way down from thr Kintamani Highland we drove through the the winding mountain road with the rice terraces reaching down to the valley .... A sea of emerald green dotted with tall coconut trees. There are pathways to walk amongst the rice fields to be up close with nature and smell the green green fields. Irrigation is no problem with the mountain streams providing water to the fields. Simple farming community and we met a farmer who was having his smoke sitting on the hillside with a huge smile n his wrinkled up face. Highly recommended for urbanites to glimpse the
Great views. Try travelling further north and visit some of the carving shops, they also have amazing views with fewer tourists
Wonderful!a must see. Spent 1h30 and this was magic, fabulous sightseeing and you realise how hard is to work in a rice field!  This was my highlight in Ubud so go!

Beautiful. The Green the calm the cool dry winds across the paddy stemsThe sound of gurgling waterSuch a serene reality that soothes the heartI walked around the early morning before the crowds turned up and it was surreal Definite must do
Awesome view / landscape.... Very nice view of the rice paddy / landscape. The green terraces are so nice for us to take pictures. Must visit when you are in Bali!
Stunning views. On the doorstep throughout Ubud are views of the Rice Fields ... such a beautiful part of Bali. Watching the hard working souls is inspiring. Countryside is just amazing

A small rice terrace worth visiting. It is not far from Ubud, or the Monkey Forrest. The admission is 10,000 IDR each. The rice terrace is relatively small comparing to the one in Dachai, China. However, the coconut tress among the rice terrace gives it a rather unique and more pleasant view. As you walk up and thru the rice terrace, there are places where they ask for a donation, about 5,000 IDR will do. There are quite a few gift shops and restaurants at the top of the hill. Some restaurants have tables and floor mats in a traditional setting facing the terrace providing a very pleasant way to relax and enjoy the view. Prices are a bit higher but not exorbitant.
Tegalalang Rice Terrace. Very nice view, relaxing place, you really need to spend some time walking down the field, nice place for photo shoot, have a drink by the terrace, best to visit for sunset.

An awesome quick-stop landscape photo opportunity. Bali's most well-known and photographed rice terrace fields have become famous for a reason. I've been to a few fields and I am still quite fascinated by the intensity of the green, and this is the winner. The big minus is that it is fairly developed with souvenir shops and cafés and full of other tourists, but I didn't find it crowded at all. And the entrance fee, that our driver warned us for, was something like 10,000 or 20,000 IDR per person, so quite negligible. I think a 30min stop is enough, but if you are looking for a steep walk, why not take do it here.
Love the views. Always like spending time here. So Bali. The rice terraces are always stunning. I never tire of these lush green terraces

B-E-A-U-T-I-F-U-L. Simply stunning! I don't know why this isn't more advertised but this place was pretty incredible. We rented a motorbike (50k rental) and it's a simple 5 mile-ish drive north of Ubud. We also went early enough (maybe 11am) where there weren't parking attendants charging for parking your bike which was nice (it's probably saving $1 but there's no reason to pay for parking).You can walk in the fields, though if you plan on doing this WEAR GOOD SHOES. There were so many people in flip flops and sandals and the paths aren't meant for flip flops. The workers are actually barefoot. The fields are owned by many families so when you walk through the rice fields you'll go through gates where they ask for donations. I didn't know this so i gave a "hefty" donation (20k) but then had only 8k to give when I reached the next gate. I think 10k is standard practice.Definitely a beautiful place! I would go back!
Great walk up and down the paddy fields. It is a lovely walk along the paddy fields and down, up then down and up again! A great way to see how the rice grows before getting to our plates!

Beautiful but path hiking path not clear. The view is very beautiful. We were left at the beginning of the hiking trail where a map shows two routes, we wanted to take the longer one but after following the signs we were dissappointed when we finished 20 or so minutes later so we came back and took a road outside of the hiking trail, the day was very hot and we got tired very quickly (take food and water with you), after one more hour walking we turned back. We were not asked any money and the people we met on the road, mostly road workers, were very nice and friendly. We wanted to buy some brown rice from the ladies next to the Unesco commemorative plaque but we found it too expensive, so in our way back we stopped in a small town and bought some at a reasonable price.It is a long way to Tegalang Rice Terrace from Ubud but it is worthy.
Magical. Definitely take the time out to jump on the back of a moped and travel to this place. Worth the trip! Beautiful, very green and absolutely massive! Astonishing place.

Greaaaat. Greaaaat view
You can enjoy the very green view
Have little drink
Take awesome pictures
You can even go down there and take a closer look

Interesting and incredible view.. Such a beautiful sight.You can walk down along the terrace however you need to be super careful as its very narrow and muddy.If you walk a ways down you need to pay the farmers a donation as you have walked on their grass from the rice fields and its no longer considered as good. Best to stay at the top and take in tbe view from there.
Really pleasant. A must see in and around Ubud. Take the time to do a proper trek in the area and take a little loose change for the local vendors
Rice Field Irrigation. The process of gravity irrigation was created many, many years ago and still serves well today as long and they can get enough rain and also rotate their crops regularly.

Beautiful. It was not easy to walk up to the field but it was amazing to walk through the field. There are few restaurants there and you can have some bites whilst enjoying the view of the paddy field. It is a pierce of art!!

Very pretty worth seeing. Tegalalang Rice Terrace was very beautiful, well worth going to. You have to make small donations along the fields, about $1-3 max. Some people got upset about the donations, but these people are so poor, work all day, a small donation here and there is nothing to get too worked about. The views are stunning, so green, very very pretty. They sell water along the way. Lots of shade from the palm trees, water running everywhere, so even though it's hot, it's bearable.
Great views. I didn't like the "donations" required besides the entrance fee that we already paid. They wouldn't let you pass further if you didn't pay the "donation". Very rude.

Not worth it!. Set amidst a street lined with little souvenir stores, this is an eminently missable 'attraction' given the options in Ubud. There are Rice fields everywhere sans the hordes of tourists and nothing special here. There is even an entry fee to make matters worse.You can enjoy much less touristy Rice fields at the Gunung Kawi temple. Skip this - isn't worth the time in Bali.

Just beautiful!!!. Tegalalang Rice Terraces may not be the largest rice terraces in Bali, but they are the most beautiful ones! We were lucky to visit this place when there was no tourist crowds at all and we could enjoy the full beauty of this place...

Just Beautiful. The Tegalalang Rice Terrace is always just beautiful. The drive up to te fields is stunning and then when you stop to take photos you are just taken back with the beauty and serenity of the fields. It's so ard to believe you are in a poor country. The Handy Crafts that you can purchase there are fantastic too. A must see when visiting Bali.

Worth the trip. Went there at about 8.30 am which was a great time to go there, as it wasn't too busy. I used a Local taxi driver I Wayan (082 341 760 304) at a very good price who was really helpful, he was like our guide walking with us through the terraces the easiest way he could. As I only wore flip flops which was a big mistake. Make sure to wear good trainer or walking shoes. When we were finished and had taken loads of picture I Wayan asked what else we wanted too do. So we went to the coffee plantation which was ok but nothing to rush there for.  So thanks to I Wayan for a great morning out.

Worth seeing up close. We came here as part of a bike trip.Worth seeing if you get the chance and probably worth coming here on its own (it was nice and green at the time).Extensive terracing and you are able to walk in among it.

Must See!. If your visiting Ubud you must take some time out to visit this place and understand its history if only for an hour. There is no real need to go into the terraces itself you can fully appreciate them from the road by nipping onto many of the shop terraces. Simply breathtaking !!

Ok. Was a bit underwhelmed with this experience. I expected it to look like the pictures to u see when ya Google rice terraces in bali. Wasn't really like that when I got there. Still worth a visit to see
Beautiful. As part of a full day tour, we stopped at the rice terrace for about an hour. Such a spectacular place! Walking along the fields is amazing and certainly a must if you're in the area.
Impossible to take a bad photo. I didn't stay here for long, just wanted to see the rice fields and take a couple of photos. The views did not disappoint.
Worth viewing. Very over crowded with visitors but great shopping in Tegalalang itself Moroccan lamps so inexpensive

Massive tourist trap!. I was there in Oct 2014, and most of the rice fields were ripe, and ready for pickin, other than this one which was bright green. At the trails are scummy dudes trying to get donations every few yards. I went by them all, but had to push one out of the way. Go get a massage, this was dumb!
Beautiful and Peaceful Experience. What a fabulous place to visit. It is just so beautiful and seems peaceful (even when there are many tourists visiting).A must see when staying in the area.
rice, rice everywhere. This is a lovely rice paddy that is terraced into the mountain and anyone can wander through it. It's quite hilly and not for the tired or faint of heart.
Must do. Great place to visit, but make sure you have a proper shoe to wear, otherwise be prepare to get wet.
Nice view, especially at sunset. It's a nice road to go there and the view is impressive. You can even go through the rice puddles. It worths a 30min drive!
Just pass by. Just pass by to take a photo and have a cup of coffee ....entrance fees 3000..you have to bargain if you're going to buy any souvneir

Absolutely not exaggerated. When I first saw pictures in Internet, the Colours and overall look and feel - felt like some photoshop had been done. But in reality, it's absolutely not. Loved the whole space and walking through the rice fields. It's amazing inspiration for landscape artists. Should be part of your Bali itinerary

Spectacular. Unbelievable to view. Magical. This is the real bali with the workers in the fields. Suggest you spend some time here and just soak it in. Loads of eateries along the edge which all seem to do a good trade. Walk in the fields is recommended.

absolutely breathtaking. amazing views, perched on hillside, stopped at ceking village, great little character eateries and retaurants( went to crispy duck- as amazing outlook and good food and drinks) cool little shops- to check out also.

Beautiful!. Ok, it's a little touristy but if you want to get the perfect rice terrace photo, this is it! You can also walk in the terraces, go all the way down and climb all the way up on the other side. If you go at the end of the afternoon, the light is perfect. Very nice place to see.

Beautiful landscapes .... These rice fields are a must visit in the area as they have history associated with it. These were made 1000 years ago and and it's incredible to see that. The location is picturesque and good to spend some time. If you visit countryside in Ubud you may see many more rice fields which are beautiful.

Get lost in time... I went to Tegelaland on the off-chance and loved it. It is certainly not for the unfit; and for people with mobility challenges, I suggest you can visit and take in the stunning views, atmosphere and sounds from one of the bars that overlook the site.For those stepping into the adventure, please do as I say and not as I did and take a decent pair of of walking shoes with good grip to navigate the uneven terrain. The site attracts all sorts of people and can be quite busy, so watch your step when passing people - the ledges can be thin. At the various stalls with the donation sign, the sign says donation, the expectation is pay-up. I did it once as a gesture of goodwill, but it got a bit frustrated as I passed more of these stalls. Suggestion is: know how much you want to 'donate' upfront and spread it amongst the stalls. There are two or three of these, plus some random photo ops that some of the paddy farmers will create and ask for payment in return. It is good to know what to expect.On my visit, the most functional stall was the first that sold coconuts. If you have not already hydrated, take that opportunity to do so to avoid heat exhaustion during your walk.The site is beautiful and set against a back-drop of luscious greenery. The wind-powered cog instruments fill it with evocative sounds that can transport you into space and time - just close your eyes for a second and take it all in.I loved it as a day-time, better still, early morning excursion when the day is still relatively cool. It's about a 1 hour exercise - two if you include breakfast or lunch after.
Heaven on earth!. Stunning views, you can also enjoy shopping in the market facing the rice terrace, very attractive prices and nice work of art!

Very pretty sight!. We had not planned our trip as well and reached the rice terrace around noon which meant the scorching sun was on our backs. Hence we couldnt explore the rice terraces completely. Even then it was a very pretty sight! If you only end up being there in the afternoon, I'd suggest you look at the view from the shade of a coffee plantation.
Beautiful. Really beautiful rice terraces. Just a short bike ride out of Ubud. Like 9 kilometres. There is rice everywhere in Bali but the view is really stunning.

A Must if in The Area ! . There is not much else to add to the thousands of previous reviews accept for the simple fact that it's a must see if you have the chance. They are wonderfully engineered with a make shift trail to walk/climb/hike through and get to vantage points throughout. As photogenic as they are the best time to go is sun down when the light becomes dull and the richness of the green is at its best. Donations are welcome here however there is no price for entry. Time Spent - 1-2 hrs is sufficient. Footwear - thongs/flip flops are not recommend. Closed walking or hiking shoes ideal.
Nice view. Here you can enjoy the amazing view of the green rice terraces. It is a really nice place to take a break and enjoy the scenery.

Stunning. Beautiful and stunning place. Watch where you step. I fell into one of the paddies and my poor driver went elbow deep into the mud trying to save my flip flop. It was quite hilarious. Stunning views and would recommend this place.

Must see. Very picturesque and well worth the trip. Many markets to go visit while there also with some lovely handicrafts. Go earlier in the day before the heat of the day and before too many tour buses/taxis get there.

Best landscape and workout!. Went today to the rice terrace and was blown away by how beautiful it was! My recommendation is go early, which is what we did. We arrived at about 9:45 and they open at 10, we were the only people in there at first but after about an hour and a half it was getting packed! The walkways are smaller so maneuvering around others was difficult. They do charge for each destination point up the terrace. You pay 10,000 rp to get but then 5,000 more and then another 5,000 luckily our driver told us this because they call them "donations" and one guy tried to take our 1000,000rp and give us no change so be careful! None the less it was a great experience and one of the most beautiful parts of Bali! Don't forget to try the cinnamon iced tea after your walk back up, so refreshing!

Nice view from the top. It would be a good experience for people who don't grow up in country side where people grow vegetables and rice. When you get to the bottom of the field, there is a donation box where you will be forced to pay money to get in. There is no official ticket booth. I have noticed that the definition of donation is not the same as I knew since I visit Indonesia.
Calm and peaceful. This is a must visit in Bali. The view is absolutely stunning. It is worth having lunch at the restaurants on the terrace!

A great stop. This is a beautiful part of Bali. Steps lead down through the terrassed rice paddies, dotted with coconut palms, cocoa trees and banana. The rice farmers are friendly and accommodating and for a donation, will give you a tour. There are a few convenient places to have a drink and look at the view along the road.
Awesome. Marvel at this engineering feat! It's simply amazing how the terraces were constructed in the first place. Even more amazing is its maintenance and upkeep over the centuries.

Worth a vist when passing through, but Ubud better for shopping..... Visited these Rice fields during our "guided tour" around Bali, with a private driver. Well worth the £40 cash it cost us for a whole day sightseeing which took in Tegalalang. We stopped for coffee/drinks in Bar overlooking fields and walked through the many road side market/shops.... Worth a visit.

Nice landscape . We arrived there around 9:30 in the morning, only a few tourists were there so probably more enjoyable than in the afternoon. Entry is free but a donation is asked at some points, we left 20.000 IDR first time, 10.000 the second time and said we already gave two times at the third point (we were 4 of us) so I wouldn't say this is an expensive attraction !The landscape is absolutely wonderful and really worth to come. It's not really physical to walk around but get some walking shoes to be sure to enjoy it at its fullest (forget the flip flops). There's a few spot where you can have a drink after your visit with a beautiful view above the rice fields. It's something you absolutely have to see if you're around !

Fun place to visit and a must see!. This place is touristy, but for a reason. It's a lovely place to visit and very photgenic. There were lots and lots of tourists there the day we went, a weekday and late afternoon. Everyone was in a happy mood though, it was great fun walking around the terraces, tripping over, squeezing past each other etc. A great way to spend an hour or two.
Big rice terrace, good photo op. Nice view from top by the road where you will be let out of the car or bus. Some people walked down to the fields, but the best views are up top.

So green and beautiful landscape, just too many tourist. I like being in the green area is just feel so cozy and relax, we went there on a motor bike from ubud we took a road not the popular one but more from village to village it was an accident though but we got to see a beautiful scenery on our way, we see the village people in the village walking to the temple for some ceremony which is very stunning to see womens with traditional clothes and kind of fruits bucket on their head and walking so confident without holding it. which is very cool.we got to this rice paddy aroun 10.30 am and i must say it was beautiful so green with with rice field, coconut tree, the terraces is just so unique, im glad we did this trip, but like any other tourist place there were many tourist and store but its no ones fault. Then i sat down in the coffee coffee order the local coffee with view to the rice field to coffee taste was second to none probably because of the air the view not just the coffee it self, but i suggest you to sit down for a while enjoy a cup of coffee and enjoy the view, its a wonderful moment :)

Small denomination notes or strong will to ignore beggars required. Certainly worth a visit. Dont donate to the cheeky locals requesting money to pass just keep walking and donate on the way back if you so feel inclined but there are ALOT of them so if you havent got the balls then take lots of small denomination notes or it will cost you the earth
Uau. Great view, very good food, nice people and familiar ambianceThis is a mandatory site to stay, to lunch and to visit

Simply stunnng. Do not leave Bali without seing this place. Absolutely blown away by the sight of these rice terraces. Even my 12-year-old son was mesmerised. Unbelievably stunning. It is worth going down the steep flight of steps to walk along the terraces all the way to the top. Plenty of photo opportunities.The views are sensational. The terraces are a bit uneven in places so sturdy footwear recommended and take some small denominations of rupiah to pay the "donations" to farmers who expect payment at various points along the way.
Stunning scenery. Don't miss - go for a walk. Stunning, restful scenery. We had our regular driver take us and walk us around explaining how they do things. Lacks are very friendly also.

More tourists & souvenir stands than rice terraces. The ultimate tourist trap - a stretch of road lined with souvenir stands, tour buses and tourists taking photos of each other with a view over some very ordinary rice terraces,easy for drivers to get to so usually included as a "surprise" addition to a tour or a place your driver thinks you should see..There are other much better rice terraces higher up in the mountains..
Rice Terrace. well worth a visit, lovely views and nice walk around the Rice Terrace if you are feeling energetic.

Amazing site.. An amazing site that you should see when in Bali.My five star review is based on getting there early. Try to get there at 9am or earlier as by the time we left at half 10 it was getting very busy with tour buses which could ruin itBe prepapred to pay entrance fees for different areas of the terraces but they only expect very small amounts - just carry smaller amounts with you. It is also worth paying to go further as it gets quiter and the views get more impressive.

Nice place to visit. Tegalalang rice fields are a good example of terrace farming, with lush green beauty all around. I have encountered much better terrace farming fields in India, up north, so I was not quite excited by that. However, the handicraft market near this place is a must to hang around. People of Bali are real talented and this is the right place to experience their gift. In handicraft market, you can always buy gifts for your loved ones at a cheaper price, if you can showcase some good skills of bargaining.

Speechless. This site cannot adequately be described by word or photograph. It was a surprise stop on a small tour organised at the last minute off our cruise boat. It took my breath away, a Bali MUST see. Hint, take a cab or hire car and have lunch on the terrace by the road.
Great photo op!. Really just a wide spot in the road although you can hike a trail through the terraces. Stop on the way to the volcano lookout!

A must do for everyone visiting the Lake Batur (it's on the way). Very well maintained with breathtaking views of the rich terrace. There is no entry fee. That said, you can donate whatever you want for the people there to maintain that place. Do wear some comfortable shoes since there is a fair bit of climbing (unstructured steps) at a few places.
The famous one. Great place to visit during Ubud vacation.It is better if you visit it on the morning, like 7 pm. It took 45 mins motor bike ride from the ubud city center.

Beautiful but a tourist trap. Beautiful place but be warned that it's full of tourists and "bridge donation scams"I counted 7 points at which people stopped you passing unless you gave them money.... 3 of which were not bridges.

meet my expectation. rice terrace is quite common in China, but the layout of this rice fields and the overall view is indeed stunning. definitely recommend to have a walk or just chill in a restaurant or cafe in the terrace.
beautiful views. not only can you see the beauty you can walk a trail through the rice fields. There are many restaurants to sit and escape the craziness of Kuta and relax.

Fantastic nature!. A 30 minutes ride away from Ubud city you reach this amazing rice terrace and the nature is mind blowing! We walked around there for a couple of hours just enjoying the view and the nature. Remember to bring cash (preferably small bills) because you are expected to donate money for using the roads or bridges. This place is a must see if you are in Ubud! If you like coffee there is a coffee plantage just 5 minutes away from the terrace where you can try the Luwak Coffee (the poop coffee).
Stunning scenery. These rice terraces are stunningly beautiful. Photographs don't do justice to the size and beauty of these terraces. A must visit for travellers to Bali.

A disappointing view and effort.. I think early morning would be better. We got there around 1pm and it was busy busy very had to get a picture without the Tourists!! Me being one of them. Apparently there is a better Terrace fields further afield ask your drivers. It didnt cover much area either. So a little disappointing really - I got better pictures driving up to the coffee plantations.

Enjoy the view. Nice hike through the rice terraces (no tour required). Just follow one of the many paths to find the perfect photo that will uncountably become your desktop wallpaper. Coming from the west, the vistas were very foreign to me (in a good way). I went into this thinking "it's just like grass, but on steps, is it really any different from a well tended park?", but the hills, the turns, the perches that opened up the entire valley made me were really impressive. It's a completely different environment. TIP: bring some bills in smaller denominations. You're basically walking through the village farm - access is free, but donating something is expected... multiple times. The locals build bridges and paths for themselves to access and tend to the terraces. And tourists stampeding through them inadvertantly cause some damage. There are collection baskets scattered throughout the terraces. I think we encountered 4 during the hour or so that we were exploring.

Wear something comfortable. Try to avoid wearing slippers if you wish to walk up to the rice terrace. It is free walking up to the rice terrace. Don't get con by paying for some "entrance" or "guide" fee. Just reject their help nicely.
Stunning. Stunning place, but a bit overcrowded by people. maybe you should go there early in the morning and not at lunch time as we did.

Beautiful place and wonderful people.. Fantastic views and amazingly perfect for photos. Lots of small street stores where one can buy souvenirs and handcrafted items. A part of a trip to the mountains which should not be missed, nature is amazing.
Refreshingly Green. Only had a quick lunch overlooking the terrace on a rainy day, but what I saw was beautiful--especially considering how close it is to Ubud. Nice escape from the bustle of town.
Best of Bali. Awesome photo opp!! Stopped off for a quick pic...Beautiful green rice paddys. Was seen in the Julia Roberts movie "Eat pray love".

Too many buildings blocking the view of the nice rice terraces. After an hour car trip from Denpasar we reached Tegallalang which is located pass Ubud. Compared to my last visit to Bali 21 years ago I was disappointed. Too many buildings have been build on both side of the road obstructing the view of the rice terraces. 21 one years ago we could see the rice terraces from the road with no obstruction at all.

Ok for a couple of hours. It is a great place to trek around and take a few snaps for a couple of hours, but I would not recommend anything more than that. Of course, if you love soaking in the greenery, then you could extend your sojourn in one of the cafes overlooking the terraces. The constant stops by local villagers demanding donations to let one progress further is a bit of a nuisance to many people.. but I think they deserve the money for keeping the place neat and tidy.. Overall, a good place to pass by..
Great views. The views were very pretty and it's worth getting the camera out for a few shots. The pestering is intense and hard to get away from. Worth a stop to look at it.
Relaxing walk. Is always a pleasure to walk through those rice fields at late afternoon and then catch the sunset overlooking the terraces.

Beautiful but difficult with a toddler. We visited the terraces in Thursday and although the view is beautiful it was really tricky with a toddler, even with 3 adults to juggle him. The track down is very rural and basic, very very slippery and some do the "steps" are quite steep. We only made it about half way down on side as it was just too dangerous. Worth a look but probably not with kids.
Bewilderment!. Amazing views from the café while drinking fresh coconut and eating durian! The ability to carve out the mountainside with hand tools was such an impressive feat of man power!
Great to see. Well worth the visit. Suitable for families and if you have baby carrier. Not suitable for toddlers. Bit of climbing if you wish.

One of the most beautiful sights I've seen. We visited these rice terraces during a full day tour of Ubud and surroundings. I was really blown away by the beauty of these terraces. The color of green was just astounding. We were allowed to walk all around up and down- hundreds of tourists must visit every day, so I didn't mind being asked for a donation to keep up the bridge etc. An elderly woman came walking by and put a hat on my daughter and then posed for a picture and asked for money- perhaps some people would be put off but I thought it was fair. Overall I was completely enchanted and wished I could have stayed longer.

Beautiful Rice Terrace. Beautiful rice terrace!!! and a good workout too :)Don't forget to bring mosquito repellent tho! We were there until around 6 pm and then the mosquitoes seem to appear out of nowhere and bit me... :(

A bit of a tourist trap:(. The rice Terraces are absolutely breathtaking!!!! I would recommend having a half day to experience the whole thing!! However i was upset about paying my way in and then having to stop every ten minutes inside the rice terrace to pay random people to pass through. Kind of irritating. And by the end we only had 2000 rupiah left and when we gave it to the guy who demanded we pay him to move through the terrace he hissed at us( because 2000 rph is only like 20 cents ) and there are children everywhere selling postcards selling sob stories about how they are starving or need money for school. That kind of tainted the experience for us
Must visit. The rice terrace was beautiful. It was nice to get away from the city and all the traffic to see real Bali. You might want to go in the morning when it's not so hot.
nice view. I have been there in the afternoon but it was crowded. the best time is early morning If you have a chance
Serenity. Beautiful scenery, peaceful and calming. Interesting to see how rice is grown and harvested.A must see !
Worth a visit on your way past. Once you're in Bali, hire a driver for a day and knock off a few sites. If you're in the area it's worth swinging by, but I wouldn't make the trip just for this.

View of Rice Terrace. I visited this area on my way back to my hotel after covering many attractions during my full day tour. I learned that Tegalalang Rice Terrace is recognized by UNESCO as a Heritage area in Bali.
Very nice. Worthwhile to visit, but need to hire a driver and quite far away from Bali airport, which around 3 hours to go.
Scenic. Picturesque view. Nice to have lunch overlooking the terrace. Go early before the sun becomes too strong.

Stunning view; beware of locals asking for donations. The GoodThe rice terraces at Tegalalang are truly stunning and every visitor to Bali should see them at least once. The main road has a small selection of overpriced cafés and restaurants. The BadThere is an "official" ticket booth but nobody checks the tickets anyway. They also don't explain where the proceeds of ticket sales go so that official ticket booth could very well be a scam. Along the short terrace trail, at least 3 different checkpoints staffed by older farmers will stop visitors and ask them for donation money. Many people get intimidated and turn around to avoid a confrontation but you can walk through without donating. If they get aggressive and try to physically restrict access, simply stand your ground and threaten to file a complaint until they lose patience and let you pass. This worked for us.

Lovely place for a walk. The rice terraces were a great place to go wander and take lots of pictures! There were several ways to go down and into the terraces and walk around at your leisure. don't be fooled by the parking guys who say you need a ticket to enter, this is a scam! Entrance to walk in the terraces is free. There are a few spots donations welcome but this is at your discretion, not a set entrance fee.

Go early in the morning. I went to see the rice terrace early in the morning, before 10 am, and we were only maybe 5 or less than 10 people visiting which was a great way to really enjoy the view and to take pictures.
Heaven. Great place for sightseeing and taking pictures. We love it! You can also eat at cool restaurants nearby and enjoy the view.

The most beautiful rice terraces. The Tegalalang Rice Terraces are incredible. Because the rice fields are on a terraced land scape, the photo opportunities are incredible. The parking is incredibly crowded, and the street is mayhem unless you get there early but the terraces themselves are beautiful and the photos taken with an amateur camera are stunning. Most drivers like to get out early so take the drivers advice and get to the terraces before the crowds so you can get your perfect photos. There are plenty of places to have a drink and it amazes me that even in little cafes on the side of the hill where there isn't a flushing toilet, there is still free wifi!
Honest review. This was beautiful and we got some fantastic pictures. Well worth visiting and paying the money t go to the top to see everything.

A great photo opportunity. The rice terraces are beautiful ! You do need to choose to visit at the right time of year though, when rice is growing & is lush & green. There are a couple of tea houses there which overlook the terraces. I did find the people working at the souvineir stalls very pushy & a little aggressive unfortunately, which is unusual for the local people of Ubud. For me, seeing the rice terraces was amazing & another thing to cross of my bucket list.

Nice, but not on par with Jatiluwih.... Definitely some impressive landscape here, no doubt. A nice setting to spend a few hours meandering through the paddies and taking some pictures, stopping for a drink and some lunch somewhere, but definitely not on par with the rice terraces at Jatiluwih.

Beautiful . Perfect for a quick stop. This'll just take you an hour. Beautiful rice fields. Was worth it.Located just 15 minutes drive from Ubud centre. No entrance fee just a donation. You can walk around freely so no tour guide needed.

Great Relaxation Stop. A must visit north of Ubud. I'd never been here, only ever driven past on my way to the north of the island... that was until recently. Unless you really need to clamber over the rice terraces, find a nice warung, order a cold drink and relax to enjoy the views of these amazing rice terraces!

Shades of green. We hired a taxi for the day and one of my must sees was a rice terrace.Tegalalang did not disappoint. It is truly beautiful. The shades of green are quite mesmerising. It was a very hot day and there are a lot of steps but if you take your time it is well worth walking around the terraces. There is a very small fee to help with the upkeep.Our driver explained how the rice is sown and harvested. So much work for a small grain of rice. I will never take it for granted again.
Greatt Nature. Human made rice terraces and god made nature well combined in this piece of paradise. Nature and green lovers, when they see there, they will definitely agree with me.

Beautiful place. If you would like to see a magnificent view and understand rice agriculture it's the right place. I never seen in my life a beautiful landscape like the Tegalalang rice terrace. There is tiny bridge every where to let you move between the rice terrace. Nice place to visit :)
