Must see. We were recommended to go here. this place is just great. Even through The riceplants were very low, it was beautiful. A lot of tourists during the day.

worth it. this is a huge, tranquil rice terrace totally worth the visit. you can go for some really nice walks around, have a nice lunch and do a bit of shopping. it is included in most tour days, or you can rent a moped and go alone, and stop at some of the lovely shops on the road up to it.

Banana fritters and luwak coffee. Please stop by the coffee shops along the road one of it is really nice, the one with small cottages. we sat in a cottage overlooking the vast rice terraces having banana fritters and luwak coffee.

No Need to Go Down. The rice terraces is just behind restaurants that offer a view. However, if you go down to the terraces you have to give donations in certain areas. I think different people plant in specific areas that you have to give a different donation if you enter their area. It was cloudy afternoon so the view was not nice. The area is smaller compared to Jatiluwih. I did not like the view from the terraces as you can see the restaurants. Most of the rice has already been harvested so there are some areas that are not green anymore. You can only see the soil.

A Breathtaking Experience. We stop by here on our way up to the volcano place. The view was amazing. Take lots of pictures because the green color of the terrace looks so nice in pictures. You can choose to go down near to where they plant the rice or paddy. A must visit if you go to Bali.

Beautiful View!. A beautiful view of the rice terraces! Great time taking pictures. However, prepared to be harassed by the locals to buy stuff at their stalls. They are not overly rude, but I would definitely describe them as pushy. Look away and keep walking. Don't make eye contact...unless of course you want to buy something. Worth the trip.

Take a Look !!. I've seen the rice terraces in Tegalalang many, many times. I lived close by Tampaksiring and would visit Ubud several times a week - usually passing by the terraces. In the good old days, you could simply stop and enjoy the view without too much hassle. Now- a- days, they need someone to direct traffic and you must pay to park. The terraces are beautiful when green and full - I even like to look after the rice is harvested and golden brown looking. Here's a little secret .... keep driving past the terraces and a little further up the road it splits. Go to the right and you will be in Pakadui, where there's rice terraces, almost no traffic and you don't have to pay to park !!!

gorgeous view, but I was lazy. I rented a scooter and one of the sights I saw were the ricefields. To be quite honest I didn't go down. The best view is from where the viewing points are and form the restaurants on the level below the road. It wasn't lunch time and I was also on my way to other places so I started to go down and then reconsidered. It looks gorgeous form up there and it might be nice to go down there, but probably I have alteady done too much walking, riding bicylces and so forth. Might be nice on a tour when you are getting things explained. Or you can stay on the upper level of the restaurants. Be warned, unless you are a young Australian, it is not an easy path to go down on flipflops.

Average. The place was very busy with tourists and tourist buses filled with even more tourists, who most would not form single lines while walking on the footpaths etc which can make things quiet difficult at times and possibly dangerous for elderly/less mobile/small children etc. The amount the locals want for donations is a bit too much, also saying no to the children being sent out by their parents to constantly ask for money is hard and you end up always having to keep saying "no sorry" as there was too many. We didn't stay for long as it was overcrowded and constantly being hassled for money was tiring. I think we were also charged extra when our driver parked the car, we were stopped to hand over more money, by men in "official vests" who would not let us pass. I would not visit here again

do not make a special trip. my husband & I revisited the Tegalalang Rice Terrace after 10 plus years and were so surprised to find cafes side by side the whole stretch of the road. So the only way to take a photo or two is on private property, that been you must give or buy something.So I picked a elderly couple that had 2 sons both disable .....The fields did not change from the very 1st time I came across them back in 1974, back then there was not a single shop/cafe. only the beauty without people in the photo's.....but if this is your 1st time then make it a quick side trip .....

Forced into 'donating'. A beautiful place aside from it being overcrowded with tourists so it's a big of a hassle getting up and down the terraces with people going both ways. Our driver dropped us near a huge flight of stairs where we had to walk down and past a winding road to get to the terraces. Encountered our first donation drive where we gave some money only to be asked for more which we kindly declined and moved on. After climbing up the terraces there was another donation booth where we had to donate more money in order to pass. There were two ladies in front of us that gave money but were still not allowed to pass as it wasn't enough. This was the last straw so we turned back as we weren't ready to be scammed again and there pretty much wasn't a lot to see past his donation booth. These people pretty much ruined the experience for me although the place was beautiful.
Live rice !. Rice will have a new meaning in your life if you come here...this is so picturesque and beautiful. Workers are a,ways in the fields. Go down the hill a little to be in the rice paddies.

Is okay if going past. Is an okay stop if in the area. Very pretty rice terrace's that provide nice photo's. If going for a walk be prepared to be asked for donations as different families have plots of land. Is not as good as Jatiluwih Green Land but worth a stop if going past

Green paddy fields. This was part of the kintamani tour that we took. You buy tickets for stopping on the roadside and looking at the paddy fields. Very green and pretty, and perhaps worth it if you're from a country where rice is not grown.

My favorite rice terrace place. This is a place whete to go first thing in the morning before it go too busy later on. The view was incredible and you can find also people working there. Nice to go down and around to see very close the rice fields.
I am really glad and lucky because I did not miss this spectacular place.

Meditative tranquility. Wonderful manicured rice fields, that I spent a whole day just wandering around. At night time the fireflies dance, and bring a whole new dimension to these rather magical fields.A true taste of Bali life.

Very nice trip around the rice terraces. You can make a 1-2 hours very nice trip around the rice terraces.
You must count on going up and down.
In the entrance you can taste the different types of Bali coffes.
Great view and trek. Great view and an even better walk through the terraces. Be prepared to donate money every few hundred metres as the land is run by different families

Not an authentic experience. We hired a car and guide for the day to experience Ubud's delights. I wanted to wander through a rice field, but we were brought here to view from the side of the road virtually. A few market stalls set up for tourists naturally. It was a pretty view, photographs well, but not the authentic experience of walking through rice fields I was expecting.

Stay at a hotel here instead of going with a tour. Tagalalang is a village north of central ubud. Although many people feels it as a tourist trap, it is a huge place you can visit on your own or even better enjoy as your view when you sleep at a hotel over there. Locals ask for USD 1 to take pictures and walk through the fields if you go alone. Worth paying.
A must see!. Got here first thing in the morning before it got busy, views were incredible, glad we did not miss this spectacular place.

Rice Terrace Without rice. No rice on the rice terrace, still required to pay a fee to pass. Tons of hustlers and cheap souvenirs, was not even bothered to exit the car. Save your time and do something else.

Amazing views, whether rice is growing or not. As part of a day trip organised by our hotel we stopped here about 1600. The main and only street is bumper to bumper with tour guides and the shops are full of tourist related items including using children to try and sell to you as you walk along. Step off the main road and you are greeted by lush, layered and amazing rice fields. We arrived and the rice had been harvested 3 weeks earlier but I don't think it matters. It's the sheer scale and working conditions you have to admire from the farmers and then there is the natural beauty of the scenery. We wished we had asked the driver for an hour here just to be able to sit and take in the views with a drink or walk more of the fields (well the edges). Well worth a visit.

Very pretty but trampled by tourists. Worth a visit, but one must wait for tourists to move out of frame before taking a photo. The street side sellers are not pushy so that's a plus. You have to pay for parking, 5000rp not hot requested 10,000rp. The terraces are being eroded and I've seen far better in other locations like on the road to Amed.

Eye Therapy. Lovely setting and peaceful ambiance in there! There are plenty of restaurants too which facing these rice terraces. Its always nice to go there when you need some changes from the routine.
Nice view! . The route leading towards the rice terrace is to cherish with. It has plenty of small café nearby which offers the view or path leading towards the rice fields.
Beautiful. Very nice rice terraces, go early so not so many tourists. There are shops there but not the cheapest make sure you barter. Definitely worth a trip and the drive there is stunning.

Amazing place!!. I felt in love with that place, so lush and green!! We had our lunch in the middle of the rice terraces and the view was awsome! Later we walked next to a small river inside the ricefields area and we took amazing photos!!! It is a MUST!!
Picturesque terraced rice fields. Just a short drive from Ubud, this picturesque rice terrace stretches all the way into the hills. We spent some time taking in the view and also took lots of photos.

A nice break from the city chaos. Easy enough to get to, and a nice little easy trek that can end with some fresh coconut water at the terrace restaurant. Get there early to avoid the heat and crowds.
Nice. We stop at the Tegalalang Rice Terrace after our cooking class and it was very beautiful! However we only spent 1 hour there and it was enough!
A pleasant Walk. The rice terraces are unusual beefing on a steep valley side, this makes them a bit special. Well with the climb up the sides.
Beautiful Landscape. Very, very vivid green. A fresh contrast from the hot humid weather and the smouldering roadside fires. Simply stunning
Perfect in sunset. Better visit around just about almost sunset, perfect time walking down to the terrace and set a good angle for photo.

Not the right time for visit. This is our 2nd trip there. Brought our friends there for a look. Think this time round we were there at the wrong time. The crops have been harvested. The image did not create an impact like our last trip Still the area were jam packed. Lots of traffic. Still worth to take a look.

Beautiful area near Ubud. This was my our second visit...this time with my daughters. Our driver took us to a very nice spot for sampling coffee with a spectacular viewing terrace. Got some great photos!
Beautiful Place. It was such Beautiful place to and was there during sunset to it was really lovely to see the sun set from there. It quite crowed with tourist thou.

Very small but very near to ubud. Great for few hrs trip to from ubud. restaurants are available overlooking the rice terrace, walking through it would be a great energetic experience.
Great place for shopping wooden art crafts very negotiable prices, I found this place more cheaper than Ubud and Kuta .

Good place for photography lover. This place is good for get some good picture... and perfect place for relax and peace situaation...
Location is about 10-20 minute from Ubud city centre..

So pretty. We hired a driver to take us up there its about 30 min outside of Ubud. There was a guy that stopped our car and insisted that we pay for the entrance fee. Be cautious with this because this is a money grab, there is no fee to enter the rice terrace. The drive was in on it too but we outsmarted them so we didn't pay. The rice terraces were so pretty just like the pictures you see. It was a tad annoying if you wanted to walk longer or higher through out them as you had to tip the locals to continue on the walkway but oh well. Lots of cafes just above them that you can grab lunch after overlooking the terraces.

Beautiful views, but the ride out there is even better!. It's a beautiful place, as is the rest of Ubud, but the ride out was the best part in my opinion. Go by motorbike or motorbike taxi to really take in the scenery. If you go late afternoon/evening you'll get all the benefits of: less tourists/hawkers, cooler temperatures, and a nice view of the sun setting over the (tons of) other rice fields and local villages you'll see on the way there.

Cooler Tropics!. If you have already spent time near the beaches, and are ready to try something a lot less congested, try staying in the upper island area surrounded by beautiful rice paddies. The elevation is a bit higher, but the lush jungles surrounding Ubud create a cooler place to stay. Get out and take a tour of the Tegalalang Rice Terrace, where you might see the farmers planting or cultivating rice, depending on when you go. Pay attention to your surroundings as there are monkeys in the trees, and some aren't too shy if you leave your bag unattended. We didn't have any encounters with the monkeys, but we could hear them, especially towards the evenings.Enjoy your time in this cooler elevation, and slower, more peaceful area of Bali.
Nice views near Ubud. It took us 20 minutes to drive here from the monkey forest. The rice terraces are a beautiful site. I can imagine how the locals carved out these plots from the mountain.
Go there early. Nice Rice Terrace if you go there early no tourists and no charge have a coffee with view. Nice stopover enroute to tirta empul
Easy to access. Good photo opportunities and easy to access with people working on the terraces.Very picturesque and so like poster photos of Bali.

Nice walk. Nice walk through the terraces, definitely recommend if you are in Ubud, the drive is only about 20 mins from the main centre of Ubud and we spent about and hour walking through. Make sure you take small notes as you will hit a few donation stops along the way from the locals. The plots of land have different owners so if you get asked for money more than once this is why.

Stunning scenery . Really interesting place to have a look at and great photo opportunity. Worth having a look at but as in most places in Bali, be careful of people pestering you the whole way down the street.

Simple and Amazing!. Who doesn't like walking through a bunch of rice terraces??? This is a great contrast to the beaches and super touristy stuff like in Kuta. Although, there are probably going to be a bunch of tourists out there with you and there is a still a significant amount of touristy feel around with all the vendors and stuff along the way.I was stopped twice to give a donation to the terraces. I had already donated at the first stop but they wouldn't let me pass until I donated more money. It wasn't a huge deal but it was kind of annoying.I'm not sure there are any real limits to where you can explore in the terraces, so be prepared for an adventure and be careful of getting lost!I didn't think the hike was challenging at all but you can definitely take it all at your own pace!

Beautiful view. Tegalalang is not far out of Ubud and the views of the rice terraces are quite spectacular, they run down the side of the mountain into a deep valley. The Main Street in Tegalalang is also a great place to shop for crafty items, the street is lined with shop after shop, I got my driver to drop me at the top and pick me up at the bottom after I slowly walked down looking in the shops!

Make sure to go in the right season!. Everyone says how beautiful it is, but it is only so when the rice is growing! We went when the rice was already harvested and the paddies dried up. Disappointing. If we ever come back, we will do research about the growing/harvesting times. Lesson: do your research!
lovely view. it was a lovely view. unfortunately we were too tired to go trekking along the fields. however we enjoyed our drinks at a nearby cafe just admiring the view in front of us.

Always Captivating. Each time I visit Bali I head to the rice fields. They are both beautiful and captivating. You are reminded also of the hard work it takes to grow such a staple for the Balinese people. You will always be greeted with smiles when you see the workers in the field. Such a beautiful place!!

Was partially green but still good view!! Keep time to cycle around is possible!!. From what I know the terrace is actually fully green by Aug but we visited in June end so the terrace was only green in little areas. However, its huge and interesting to see how 200 local families together together maintain this beautiful terrace. We were just doing a stop over and took pics but I say groups of people riding in bicycles in the middle of the terrace. Wish we had time for that. I recommend you keep time to cycle around coz its irresistible (breezy and fresh).

Amazing. Just amazing how this is done and it's all done manually. The Balinese people are such hard workers and to take this sight in is just amazing. A credit to these people and respect to them all

Serene experience!. I would recommend everyone to do a trip to the Tegalalang rice terrace. Although rice terraces are seen all over Ubud, this terrace is one of the largest and a walk, trek, quad bike visit is a must.

Cool agriculture. Wired tourist attraction on side of road. Lots of traffic congestion and fee takers collecting money from you when you stop. Drive through and spend your money at a road side stand or eatery to support the local people, not the police...
beautiful rice terrace. the scenery is very beautiful. could be way way past the beauty of vast rice fields. place a short distance from the town center of ubud

breath-taking scenery. it is just a paddy field but the view it gives is totally stunning!! there is a cafe where you can have a sit, drink and enjoy the view. be careful with street seller and do not ask anything if you do not wish to buy anything. the road to this area is quite small and expect some traffic jam.

Beautiful view. This is a must do! Beautiful view from any and every angle. Not a hard climb to the top of a rice mountain thing but there are a few 'donation' stands that if you don't donate they tell you to turn around. Great experience in all.

Beautiful spot for a photo. Behind the stalls and shops, there is an amazing view of the rice terraces. You can wak down past the shops and through the terraces. I loved the view! We tried walking further down the road to avoid the tourists and to get a better view of the rice terraces. However, only a small section of the terraces are maintained presumably for tourists. It appears what once were terraces are all over grown further down the road. There are a couple of shops that sell nice wooden carvings on the side of the road opposite to the rice terraces. Overall it was a pleasant couple of hours spent wandering around.

OK walk through rice fields. The actual landscape and rice terraces are nice to see, and I imagine 40 years ago when hippies went trekking and found this place it would have been nirvana. But now it is Kuta/Legian/Sanur on a hill. An endless strip of Bintang singlets and stubbie holders in shacks blocking the view of an amazing terraced rice plantation. There are some nice walking tracks through the plantation, take plenty of 5k notes for all the toll stations along the way and an endless barrage of offered services, but enjoy the walk. Quite steep terrain and good balance required in places. Some nice photo locations and terrain along the walks.
Nice view!. Nice view to take a photo. You can climb up to the upper part of the hill to have a better view. Wear proper shoes to prevent injuries. The rice terrace is quite slippery after the rain.
at awe of this place. Really beautiful and great exercise if you choose to go up and down the terraces. Take lots of pictures! Eat lunch at one of the places so you can really take in the views.

Iconic Balinese rice terrace. The Tegalalang rice terrace is one of the must sees in Bali. However, we learnt inadvertently that the best time to go is in the morning. We were there by 9am. By late morning and for the rest of the day it is unpleasantly busy.

chill and relax. very cool place for sitting and just chilling..
you could also find foods or handicrafts there. Many restaurants/ cafes.
Spirit Of Bali. Very nice rice terrace view, take a walk from the step in south side of the terrace walking down to the rice terrace can be more awesome experience..

Great place for a lunch with a view. We stopped for a lunch in a restaurant with a fantastic view on these rice terraces. It is quite beautiful, if not nearly as impressive as Jatiluwih Rice Fields. Still, a lovely place to visit.

Beautiful spot to relax with easy trekking. Beautiful place for easy walk, unreal green color around you, perfect to take background photos and when you think that beautiful terraces are made only by men hands it's really impressive.

Famous terasering in Ubud area. Nice rice field in Ubud area. There was a time when Tegalalang area very good for handcraft business in Bali. Many many shop spread along the street, from candle sticks to statues,most of the product for export, you drive a car to see the stepped rice field scene and it's so nice to watch the shops along the road, but now business seems falling down. Lot of guest search their product from Java, I think a lot of Balinese product came from Java from a long long time....There was a time you're free of charge to see the Terasering (stepped rice field), but now they ask you paid small fees if you stopped by. At least you must pay for the stop or parking your vehicle. It's okay, maybe the fee is for the development of this area, but it seems like you're in Jakarta, where you must pay even for walking in the beach......The view is pretty nice, you can take photos and buy your soda in here. But for me the view is far better Jatiluwih than this Tegalalang....
A Natural Wonder. Such a beautiful place. So much greenery and open space. Can walk along the terraces. Breath-taking photo opportunities. A kind old man lets you take photos holding the rice carrier
Amazing. Absolutely breathtaking and surreal. I can't recommend this enough. It's not everyday you get to see so much beauty in one place... This is what Bali is all about.
very nice Paddy field. it's really very nice paddy field, landscape plantation, best time to see paddy during December - February.
Huge !. Tegalalang is a rice field, it's one of the best landscapes that i have never seen.dont miss it once in bali !

Lunch at the Rice Fields! . Our driver, Hendra, brought us to see the Terraced rice paddies. While walking along the top road we stopped at a lovely Asian Restaurant and could sit and eat and overlook the hillside.
Beautiful!

Loved this!. This is a beautiful area definitely worth a visit. Apart from the gorgeous rice terraces there is also a number of little handcraft stalls and restaurants that look out over the view. You can climb down into the terraces and up the other side if you wish or admire from above. Put it on the must-see list!

A fairly brief but pleasant interlude on a touristic drive. The terraced layers of this valley were exactly what I had seen in photos. I didn't realise that your driver would pull up on a street full of souvenir shops, and point you towards a set of steps for a photo opportunity. We saw others further down, so headed down after them. It looked lush and productive, with the odd tourist picking out a pathway on the lower terraces. There was no farming activity as the rice was growing, not ready for harvesting. It didn't take long, and we felt that the drive to the terraces was just as interesting as we could see more people going about their daily activities..
Nice staggering paddy fields. Nice staggering paddy fields, but very crowded. Many tourist vans along small road. Quite close to Ubud. Come here once is enough.
Fun Trekking. walking on my feet, all along the rice pady. fresh air and natural sound of water and bird, its heaven.Stay a while on the top of the hill, and take some young coconut. Jelaoussy

Spectacular! A Must see!. Do not miss it! Rent a motorbike (scooter) from Ubud and drive up there! You can leave your bike around on the main street, no one will nick it, dont worry! An amazing place to see!!!! it will take you 30 min max to get there another 2-3 hours to walk around depending on your pace and mood.

WOW don't miss the opportunity to see the Tegalalang Rice Terrace. We had the pleasure of visiting the Tegalalang Rice Terraces while on a Tour in Ubud. What a spectacular sight to see how these rice paddies are carved in to the landscape is something that you should not miss if you are in the area. You can even take a walk down from the road to the river then up the other side winding through the paddies looking back across to the main road. It can get very busy so be careful getting in and out of the car or bus, the best time to visit is in the morning around 11am as it is a little quite and the sun is at its best location to view the Terrace plus a bit cooler more comfortable. You can get plenty of refreshments or even have lunch as there are plenty of restaurants to choose from.

Disappointed. We would stop by if it's on the way to somewhere else. It's probably worth a visit packaged with the coffee plantations, monkey forest and other attractions, but definitely not worth an hour and a half trip over there if this is your main interest. It took us 15 minutes for us to look and take some photos, but that was it. The main street was so busy and crowded. Avoid June as there is no rice or any plant growing in the rice fields. It was just some mud, nothing interesting to see. We had a specific restaurant we wanted to have lunch on the way, but our guide said he would have recommended a restaurant by the rice field if we didn't have a plan. May be if we had lunch there, could have had a better experience. But it was just too busy, too crowded, too noisy with so little to see.
Stop and take a look. Worth a stop to have a coffee and enjoy the astonishing views of the terraces! We took a day trip to visit the area and it is really an amazing experience.
Beautiful. Beautiful to see,have to pay to enter the town/areaWARNING: I wasn't too happy to see cages of puppies and dogs,so be warned you may see some being sold for meat

Perfect view!. Perfect view, the rice paddies is highly maintain. Love the idea that that living in Bali you can have this options to go to. I wish the restaurants and shops around the area is also as well maintain as the rice paddies, at least keep it clean and neat.
Nice for pic. When we went there no more paddy, just the terrain..but still picturesque view. All around there were shops selling the handicraft.
beautiful. beautiful terraces, with the brightest green of rice fields. an amazing construction, well kept and preserved.

Very neat to see. This place was pretty cool to see. I believe its one of their biggest rice terraces (if not the biggest). You can walk all over the rice fields and see how it grows. Really fascinating. Backs onto a street where you can also do some shopping.

Beautiful. Very beautiful rice terraces. Hike downstairs and get a delicous coconut to refresh. (20.000 ruphia)
It was a little bit annoying to donate the whole hike down. Bring enough small money with you. It´s not a donation if they are forcing you doing it.
It is nicer to hike in sneakers. ;-)
great. beautifull, worth the trip. go early in the morning when there are no or just a few tourists. take some pocket money with you for some old women who are sitting there.
Beautiful rice fields to explore.... The biggest and best in Ubud? Not sure, but I think so. Well worth visiting - beautiful fields to get lost in. Great photo opportunity!

Relaxing. Relax eating lunch at the restaurant while you look over the rice terraces and listen to calming local music. We could have sat there all day if we didn't have other places to be. Food was delicious.
Beautiful. I went for a day tour with a guide and we stop at the Tegalalang Rice Terrace. We had lunch with a friend in front of the rice terrace. It's really beautiful.
Green in various shades. Good to see the cascading terraces in various shades of green. Excellent foto opportunity, Udesh kumar
calender perfect. This trip is well worthwhile as is the blessing and cleansing at the temple. A well maintained spot - worth doing a walk as well.

Glad We Saw It. Much better than expected. We loved walking through the terraced rice fields. It was just big enough to provide awesome views of the terraces but small enough to quickly walk through the entire property. It only takes 30 minutes from Ubud to get there so it is worth the quick trip to get there.

It was not mindblowing. We came here as a stop on a larger tour, and we were glad it was only a short stop. The terraces were very green and beautiful, and it was certainly nice to see, but honestly it was nothing mindblowing. It was smaller than I expected and there wasn't really much opportunity to walk in them (maybe a product of our short stop or tour company). The best rice terraces we saw were on the drive to Amed, which were huge expanses of green hills. I'd recommend going to see those over the Tegalalang Rice Terraces.

Stock up on smaller denomination rupiah!. These terraces give rise to some lovely photo opportunities as well as a bit of exercise!Be aware though that at several points along the way as well as anytime a photo opportunity with someone going about their work is offered, a "donation" will be expected. Whilst this is par for the course for the privilege of entering these tourist areas and goes toward maintenance of the area, I would recommend being prepared with smaller denomination rupiah, (5000 to 10 000 IDR notes), unless you don't mind going through $100 AUD very quickly.... (same goes with visits to temples in the area too). There are several cafes along the roadside as you exit the terrace to obtain refreshment.

Famed rice terraces, but nothing spectacular. Maybe I expected too much, but I did not feel anything special here. Simple paddy fields. But worth the visit though if you have come up to Ubud. Also, there is no need to buy any tickets here as it is just paddy fields. Ignore if someone asks you to get tickets.
Rice fields on view. Lovely photo spot and being able to walk down in is great. Little coffee shops along the edge are good.

Great views!. We enjoyed great views, no touts and vendors while we overlooked the rice terraces. Canny private drivers know a little café just off the centre of the action that's peaceful and private. So peaceful for us and I'm glad we booked Safe Bali Driver Ketut Suwenda to take us out for the day, he certainly picked a good restaurant that was peaceful with great views.

Dramatic Timeless Views!. Ignore the souvenir shops along the roadside and pesty hawkers and just embrace the vision before you!These rice terraces have a timeless quality. The green vista sprawls gently across the valley. What more can one say that has not already been said hundreds of times?My spouse and I also enjoyed the local farmer who walked across the terraces to sell his hats woven from the greenest coconut leaves imaginable. He completed the experience.

totally worth it!. awesome views! just make sure you wear sneakers because you'll go up and down hills and stairs.. There's no fees to this place, however in the middle of going up the terrace, there are some locals (2 of them) ask for donation to keep the the place running. I gave them Rp. 10000 each.

Be sure to visit. Beautiful and interesting hillside cultivation. Worth time in your schedule. Beware the multiple people collecting "entrance fees" on the trail. Typically, one is legit but you may encounter several.
Spectacular view. This is an artists dream view. Terraced rice fields form the iconic picture of Ubud. A must see for all visitors to Bali.

Not so great. I have seen better ones in Nepal and india, so this was not so fascinating for me rather it was just an average experience, we had a tour of this on our way to Mount Kintamani.
Will i go there again , no went there because it was on our way to another destination.

Rent a motorbike!. Even if your use to motorbike or not, I strongly recommend that you rent a motorbike and visit the climbing roads to the rice terrace. The scenic views are great and the driving smooth. For those of you who don't have a GPS in your head, there are few roads, which diminishes the risk of getting lost.
Great View :). The view over there is breath-taking.. There are some shops around selling souvenirs and some coffee shops.. It is mainly the view that takes you there

Decent Stop-Over if you are headed back from Gunung Batur to Ubud. Paddy fields can be found throughout Bali. The unique thing about this one is the paddy is planted on the slopes of a valley. Good photo opportunity if you go there during the rice harvesting period. However, it gets over crowded with visitors and you need to pay to view the rice terrace. Ok for first timers but something I wouldn't do again. There is another place called Jatiluwih which is a lot bigger and better than this one.

Worth the hike. Visited as part of a full day tour. The view from the roadside is amazing but you really need to take a hike down to the bottom, then up again the other side to really see the best of it. There are lots of photo opportunities and a local man taking donations for you to cross the bamboo bridge at the bottom - IDR 5000 was enough. Well worth a visit but take insect repellant with you - and watch for falling coconuts!!

Good but busy and annoying donation collectors. This is great for a rice field view. Climb to the top. Pretty easy along paths. Need appropiate fixed footwear. If wearingg flip flops,it is easier to do barefoot. Get to carry a tradional rice basket but dont forget to tip. There are huts along the route (200m apx) with men asking for a donation. Agressive, so be prepared to pay, no more than 20k rph though.
Ancient Farming Spectacular View. This is an amazing site, it is beautiful and well worth the visit as an example of sustainable and cooperative agriculture

Amazing views . It's something very special to see how the locals raise the rice they end up selling locally.The views are amazing and there is a trail all throughout the mountain so you can descend to the valley and climb the other side and take great pictures.I definitely recommend shoes that fit comfortable because it's hard to climb up and down.You should separate about 1 hour to do all of it.
Incredible View!. What an amazing and beautiful view of the most famous rice paddies in Bali! Highly worth a photo opportunity.
Simply amazing. Layers on layers of rice terraces, watching it over a sunset gives an amazing view and a feeling of total relaxation. It's a shame places like these are difficult to find.

Worth a look. Maybe I am spoilt as I have been to the amazing Dragon Backbone rice terraces in China, so for me this stop was a little disappointing. But it was indeed a pretty view and no charge to stop and take a photo. Maybe if we had had some time to wander around the terrace it would have been more fun but we only had time for a quick look before moving on.
Gorgeous & great photo opportunities. Easy to get to & access. if your knees hold up it's worth climbing up & down & really getting close to the rice & the amazing Subak water system. Fun for kids

lovely, but...... Little village with beautiful rice terraces but busy and crowded. No need to go here because there are beautiful terraces everwhere where it is easier to park and take pictures. Must pay toll to drive through the village.views everywhere else are free.
Relaxing and peaceful. its simply peaceful, you can take some nice photos there, and their shops are cheaper than ubud center you can pick up some nice stuff.

Like Disneyland. We visited Tegalalang Rice Terrance at around 3-4pm and it was overrun by tourists. There were only two farmers in sight and neither of them could work their fields because there were so many tourists walking up and down the narrow earthen pathways. I'm sure this used to be nice but it wasn't when we visited. It felt like a theme park. Disappointing that farmers can't even work their fields anymore due to tourism.

Picturesque place, but just for the fit ones!!. The place is absolutely amazing! In this small valley the rice paddies are very well kept and you can make great photos and even meet very kind and nice local workers. However, the route is impervious and it is better to wear tennis shoes! Unfortunately there were missing decent toiletes and a nice cafe with an acceptable offer of drinks and foods... There is no entrance fee, but donations are frequently asked along the way!
Beautiful. Amazing, worth the drive. Even my 10 year old son was blown away. Just stunning and wow - got some great photos.

Lovely scenery. Great scenery but not very convenient for family travellers. Those travelling with kids should be content to just take photos but climbing up and down the terraces are tricky and only recommended for older kids (>8yrs).

Realy worth the visit. This Rice Terrace is beautiful and I thoroughly enjoyed the hiking in the terrace. The view from atop is really nice but as you venture in the fields themselves, you start to have a different perspective.

stunning. The rice terraces are just absolutely stunning! I have been so many times. Tegalalang is particularly beautiful with the sheer size, but just walking through Ubud's make you feel like you're in the middle of nowhere and totally at peace

Beautiful location and worth the trip. This was a magnificent location to visit, and well worth the small entry fee to go and see the rice terraces.
Picturesque, beautiful, captivating...you won't regret going.
Picturesque. Great to see. Do visit here as it is worth the day trip. It's a picturesque setting and it's lovely to see something you would only get to see on this part of the world.
Nice views. This is on way to kintamani tour. These rice fields are beautiful. Few restaurants overlooking these rice fields.

Rice Harvesting in Progress. The rice is ripening! Stalks are heavy, workers are gathering the sheaves of rice piece by piece by hand. So much to see beyond the rice terraces themselves. In other parts of Bali in different rice terraces new rice is being planted and the fields are being flooded. Picturesque in so many ways. Be sure to view the different aspects of the terraces.Great photo opportunity! This a World Heritage site but does that mean it will be preserved?

Stunning. Don't forget your camera as this is one of the "best looking" rice fields in Bali. There are also plenty of market stalls nearby to shop around too. Best time to come is to come approximately 2 months into the growing of the rice or just before the rice has been planted according to the locals
Picturesque. Good photo opportunity and great to see the greenery. Its about half an hour away from Ubud, but didn't spend much time there, just took a few photos.

Gorgeous. Just glowing with color. Just wish Bali still had the many, many rice terraces it used to have. There is a little market surrounding the rice terraces and we bought a lovely quilt. There were quite a few tourists also taking photos, but not so many that it took away from the experience.
Picturesque Bali. Fabulous view of iconic rice paddy! Very worth seeing, but avoid the aggressive people selling souvenirs.
amazing view. we had lunch there and it seems like jou are a part of the nature.the road to that place was not anywhere good.

A bit of a rip off. Various "pit stops" where you had to pay to go further. First you pay for parking, you then go down into the rice fields and there is a lady blocking the way asking for a "donation". When I placed a few coins in the pot she made it very known that this was not acceptable. I pointed to the word donation. She spoke no english which didnt help. We walked a bit more and found another pay station. It was ridiculous. If they want you to pay, i'd rather pay upfront so I know what I am in for. It was beautiful but rather stay on the road and just take some pictures.
Beautiful. You could lose yourself in a place like this. Breathtaking breathtaking breathtaking! the trails can be a little rough in some parts but the views are worth it.

Stunning rice terrace!. An absolutely beautiful sight! Be careful that you don't slip as the walkways can be quite muddy and very slippery - might be easier to walk around in proper shoes or barefoot rather than thongs/flip flops! You do need to donate money at the start of the terraces and then to get up a bit higher to the upper terraces I donated more money - here there was a man who I thought was just doing the thing for the tourists - holding the baskets with rice, wearing a rice farmer hat - I gave him the smallest note I had (not a small one!) which was way too much for just a photo but he then led me all around the rice fields and to the most beautiful views of the less tourist trampled rice fields - well worth $10AUD in the end! Take water with you - it can get hot especially in the middle of the day although you can buy fresh coconuts there. One of the most beautiful sights I found in Bali!
Typical rice terraces. Good some lovely pictures of alot of the rice terraces in Bali. nice trip not far from Ubud. Quite alot of people if done in the afternoon.

Post Card View. Stopped off here on the way to a cycling tour down from the volcano. You can see why this type of setting is the stuff of postcards and many tourist photos. Just beautiful to see. One of those things that you can't go to Bali and miss seeing.

Great views. Had a good look around there, getting close to how rice is grown. Really beautiful terraces to walk up and down. Some of the steps were not very good, so there was a fair bit of clambering around, but it was a great place to visit. Quick to get there from Ubud, about 20mins drive each way so there's no need to book a more formal tour to get here. We hired a taxi chap for two hours for the trip for 100k Rph per hour, trip took about and hour and a half all in.

Well worth it, great photo opp. Some things you just have to see! While this is quite touristy, it's still stunning. I rented a motorbike ($50,000IDR) and it took me under 30 minutes to get there. You should wear better shoes if you are there after it rains, I would imagine it gets quite slippery.

Well worth the trip. Once out of the car at the parking bays, I initially looked down and saw a number of rice terraces with tourists all wandering all over them and thought 'is this it'?. But, we found if you want to spend a bit of energy and walk further up the road past the security check post, there is a small street to the right. We walked up that street, very steep, hoping to get a better view. We got talking to a local guy who then took us on a 2 hour guided tour of his family's rice terraces. We met his family and watched as they worked the fields. They even let us work with them for a short time harvesting rice. He then took us to his village on the other side and invited us into his home. He showed us things we never imaged seeing, even a secluded shrine deep in a gully that you wouldn't know existed if you weren't shown it. Yes, we were hot and sweaty by the end but we got more than we ever bargained for on this trip. Absolutely excellent and the photographs we got on the day were sensatational. Spend a bit of time and you won't be disappointed. Yes, we did tip the guy at the end but it was well worth it.

Should be on your bucket list ...... as it's gotta be one of the most amazing views ever! We didn't actually walk the terraces as it was so hot, but I wouldn't have minded trying. Nevertheless we got some good photos & brilliant video footage. Price just 10,000 which is about 50p? We bought ice cream from the shop over the road, & the nearby Crispy Duck very kindly allowed me to use their bathroom facilities.

amazing views on doorstep of Ubud. Yes, there are lots of tourists, buses & people getting you to buy stuff but DESPITE that, I would still go as the view is breathtaking. Try going early when it's quieter, better still DIY.We had lunch at Boni Bali, a restaurant past madness & mayhem. Did a walk from restaurant into valley. Worth while as you get a different perspective of rice paddies
Great view of rice terraces. Not much else though. Recommended if it's on the way, we enjoyed it, but I wouldn't invest too much time in this. Great photo op, though.

A must see place. you can see rice fields every where in Bali but this one is spectacular, you can walk down to the actually fields or like me you can just look down at the fields in awe. there are a lot of Children on the streets asking for money and it can be a bit overwhelming and sad. Very busy when we where there so you might need to find somewhere to find to get good photos.

Nothing much to rave about here. Apart from special rice fields, there's nothing much to rave about for this place. Quite a sight though. It will be good if one can see the field that is ready to be harvested and not empty. Unlucky indeed.On a side note, we're lucky that there were no vendors that approached us or anything the whole time we're there.

Have to see it at least once. Went on recommendations as per tripadvisor. It's a great view, easily the best rice terrace view that I saw in Bali. However, the view is really about it. You can walk down and to the other side, but it's not for the faint hearted and you can easily slip and fall. As well as on what you might call the trail, there are many young children and old women with hand out asking for money, which can pull on your heart strings.For first timers, definitely go have a look. It's not that far from Ubud and across the road is the Luwak Coffee tour which was enjoyable. Do all three and make a day out of it.

Like a dream!. Beautiful fields. All of the rice fields throughout Bali are exquisite. But what sets this one apart is the expansive view points. When the fields are green (unripe rice...rice ripens when it is yellow) they are so incredibly beautiful and worth the trip to see.
Nice landscape. I love this place, drink bintang beer and enjoy rice padi fields. Very peace. We could see beautiful landscape while drink beer or enjoy the food.

beautiful. I loved this place. You have to work for a good photo, which in the heat may be off putting however I suggest going right up to the top. Once you get up the top opposite the road you have great views and great photo opportunities

A wonderful site...well worth a visit.. It is good to get out and about on the island and ask your taxi driver to take you to local villages and markets en route here.The rice terraces are just so beautiful but unfortunately a lot of them are disappearing, but here they are just magnificent.

One of the best views!. My boyfriend and I visited Tegalalang Rice Terrace in May 2015. Although the rice had already been harvested the view was still absolutely beautiful: so green and intricate. We stopped here for lunch which was really relaxing with such an amazing view while you eat. We regretfully didn't have time to walk through the rice terraces, but got some great photos and saw artists painting. Definitely worth visiting!

Stunning Scenery - Have lunch there at a cafe with views. We visited the Tegalalang Rice Terrace on a day exploration with a driver. The views are simply stunning and I would highly recommend it. We walked down into the valley and up through the rice paddies which was great way to burn off energy for the kids - make sure you have sensible shoes on though as the tracks can be a bit slippy & muddy. To walk up through the rice terraces you need to pay a donation at each of the booths. Our driver advised us to pay no more than 5000 rp per donation & we did get asked for more at one (Bali just seems to be like that...just felt like there was always someone with their hand out) but we were more than happy to pay the donation...blows me away how much work has gone into the rice terraces.We stopped for a drink at one of the cafes on the way back up...and really wished we had stayed for lunch here, the views were stunning with little low tables set in 'huts' the side of the hill overlooking the rice terraces.Be warned that there are no public toilets here and I think (understandably) the local cafe is sick of providing toilets for every visitor to the rice terraces so plan to have lunch or at least drinks & snacks at the cafe if you want to use their toilets.

The last Ubud Rice terrace ? Too Much Art shop. Its seems like a place just for pass by and take some photograph from the vehicles. Rather then out from car in the busy road and wasting time pass by art shop just to get a good spot for take some photograph of this last Ubud rice terrace. Need a real management of local villagers and government before its losing legendary name of Tegalalang Rice Terrace and the view blocked by art shop and restaurant.

Nice View and Meal. Spectacular scenery and the restaurant meal was good. Walked down to the observation area which is quite steep and probably not recommended for those who have difficulty with walking or balance

The real Balinese experience . If you really want to feel and live the real Balinese experience, then this is a must visit location! First, the view was phenomenon but not only that, we had the chance to walk through the fields and help the locals with gathering the rice. It was a day to remember and i really recommend give it a visit if you are in Bali. However, you must buy the 'merajut' - knit hat to be part of the whole experience. I did, and i'm taking it back home to keep it as a souvenir.

Iconic View. I suppose this is the most visited rice terrace on the planet, but it's beautiful nonetheless. Best to sit in a cliff-side cafe and take a walk down in the valley. And the street above? Traffic! Wondering how it's made to work is one of those things that makes travelling more interesting than just the view!
Just what you envision of Bali. Took a scooter to the rice terrace. great views, but be careful of when you go, as it can get really hot and humid climbing the terraces.
nice photo ops. We crossed this on while travelling to Ubud, and stopped for a short photo opIt is pretty . May consider going early in the day , as it gets pretty crowded during the day

Great scenery and chillaxing. It's a good place to come up and see what the famous post cards were all about. A pity we went in the after harvest period and the paddy fields were brown instead of green.The scenery is still breathtaking nonetheless and you can still enjoy a cafe and some shopping.
Beautiful. The Rice Terrace just looks amazing! You can just stand there and enjoy the view or take a walk. If you are in Ubud you should definitely go there
Rice terrace in ubud. This was good view of the rice terrace in ubud, there i can fell the nature of bali, because in that place is not so many building like in city,
Your average rice plains. Not very exciting unless you have never seen one before. Although in rainy season, it does have its own charm.
Beautiful. Nice place to visit, not that much to do here but the journey up is great scenery. It's something you need to see but not a as picturesque as the brochures.

Be careful where you step!!. STUNNING panorama!!Must see locale!!Gave a few locals a huge chuckle when I stepped off one of the terraces backwards whilst taking a photo!After being helped up, unhurt - and like a good Aussie, not spilling my Bintang (1st for the day I promise) the bloke asked me where I came from...I just pointed down a step & replied "From down there!!"BAHAHAHA!! :D

Lovely to look at.. The Tegalalang Rice Terrace is a great example of the stepped rice fields. It is beautiful and there are market stalls along the road where you can have a try for a bargain. We chose just to view the terrace rather than walk them.

Picturesque. The Tegalalang Rice Terrace was very picturesque. The pictures we took don't do it justice. All of the shops and along the busy road were a bit distracting and commercialized. Our guide showed us the stairway to go down to the valley and then we could climb up the terraces. Amazingly, the pictures were better from the other side! I'm glad we saw this our first day. After a few days of driving around Bali, we saw so many rice fields and terraces that this would not have been quite as fantastic after that.

Nice view. Got a deal with driver from airport for a Day Tour (9-6pm) at 500K IDR for two exclude meals and entrance fees.Trip include Monkey Forest..(Better to skip this), Rice Terrace, King Palace and Tanah Lot.

Don't have too high the expectation. The terrace rice field is best visited at around 0700hr. This the the time when the sun is not too strong and would make good photo shots. After 0900hr, the sunlight would be too strong and harsh. The drive from Ubud to Tegalalang had better scenery than the rice field itself. You would be able to witness the local livelihood. There are small shelters at the terrace rice field which you could either have a cold drink or just sit in the shade to chill out. This place would be a challenge for wheelchair bound person. Wheelchair bound person could only see the terrace rice field by the roadside. The shelters were built on the slopes of the terrace led by cut steps.

Tourist extreme. I guess that UBUD has developped quickly since the hype about the movie eat,pray and love and now everything is touristy ... I was disappointed with the rice terrace but very nice to walk amoungst it. What you need to know is the rice terrace are everywhere and you are allowed without paying to walk through them, the one at Tegalalang are paying one and all the tourists are there, there is so many more along the way that you can enjoy all alone, the main difference is possibly the upkeep. The trek is not easy for someone that does not have some good footwear and footing, it is narrow and no stairs that are very accomodating but worth it anyhow for the picture perfect.

Not mind blowing but......... ....good enough and a good break on the drive to the volcano. We didn't venture down into the fields themselves but no need if you are just after pics and views. 10k IDR per punter to stop and view.

Stunning terrace rice paddies ... perfect for photos. Tegalalang is a wonderful area with cafes, shops and these beautiful rice terraces. The paddies are the most perfect lush green color and look magical. Whether on a tour and just stopping in for amazing pictures or looking to spend an afternoon enjoying the true beauty of the area, it is worth adding to your itinerary.
Beautiful paddies. Do walk inside the paddies. You don't need a guide or a local. but the experience is not to be missed!

Rice Terrace View. We love Tegalalng and would not miss a visit each trip, quiter than Ubud central, great markets and lovely eateries :) treat yourself to Nasi Goreng with a view that is spectacular!
Stunning terraces. This is the famous picturesque, terraced rice paddies. Definitely worth a stop for some photos, on your way to Kintamani.

Beautiful view of Paddy Terrace. There is admission fee of Rp 10k per person to visit the Tegalalang RiceTerrace~ you may take photos of the scenery and also take a short walk at roadside stalls for little shopping~

Nice, but not Spectacular. Stayed at Puri Gangga Resort, so I was able to ride a bike down to the rice fields at sunrise. As mentioned in other reviews, you can view these fields from the roadside. There were many small cafes here where people can sit and enjoy the views, but these are just the cheap cafes. As the sun rose higher after 8am, it would be facing you and not ideal for photographs. The best time to take pictures would be in the later part of the afternoon. When green, the fields look nice, but the slopes are just a small area and hence, not a magnificent view. You could visit it if you happen to be in the Ubud area, but its not worth making that special trip just to see these fields.
Beautiful landscape. The rice terrace is a first of a kind that I have seen.Walking around the rice plantations gives one a different feeling.A must visit

Not that impressive really.. You stop by the side of the road after paying some blokes for the privilege, then walk down some steps into a shop to get any view worth seeing. The rice terracing is straight in front of you and not that impressive really, if you want to walk along the terracing then you have to make your own way down steep banks, as there is no recognised path. We never made it to Jatiluwih rice fields, but with hindsight wished we had.

Small but spectacular. I heard that this is the only one left over the areas. Yes, its small compare to Jati Luwih but if you has no time to Jati Luwih, get the view from here also excellent. This little rice terrace is incredible, but to many store beside the street that blocking the view and decreasing the taste of nature around.

Rice galore. I rented a bicycle from Ubud and cycled to the Rice Terrace. It takes about 45mins cycling through the countryside seeing the local scene. The rice terrace itself is very nice. Steep steps going down and up the terrace. Watch out for mud. I went there when it was almost harvest time so the rice was almost golden brown. Would have loved to be there when it was during the planting season where the waters in the terrace would make great photographs. Remember to donate a small fee when crossing the bridge. Overall a nice place to visit.

lovely views. take some pictures at the top and take a walk (for a donation fee) amongst the rice terraces (do have proper footwear) if you like. there is a line of little eating places along the top where you can have a meal with a view. there is also a farmer who will pose with you for a small fee. was driven here by my driver, komang who is earnest and honest and charges a very reasonable whole day rental and airport transfer. his number is +62 819 9914 8527 if anyone is interested. he is available on whatsapp for easy communication.
beautiful. did not disappoint - the colors reflected by the sun made for a stunning setting. A photographers dream

okay view. should have visited other rice terrace instead. rice terrace is not magnificent at all. you can capture the entire scene in just one shot (yeah without doing panoramic shot). we only stop here for 5min. since we are already here just snap a few pic. should have visited jatiluwih rice field instead however our driver said it is out of the way from our arranged itinerary. no one collect any fee from us for this stopover. (i've read review saying local collect illegal "entrance fee"). however we were already charged when going uphill to kintamani, Local only charge tourist/foreigner, self-printed ticket with "serial number" LOL. although fee is minimal but their gov should ban this illegal fee collection.

Just Another Amazing View In Bali. Tegallalang Rice Terraces in Ubud is famous for its beautiful scenes of rice paddies involving the subak (traditional Balinese cooperative irrigation system), which according to history, was passed down by a revered holy man named Rsi Markandeya in the eighth century. Tegallalang forms the three most splendid terraced landscapes in Ubud's shared region, with the others being in the villages of Pejeng and Campuhan.Tegallang alone has an outlook that spreads down before you and away to the rice terraces on the slopes across the valley. The high roadside location is cool and breezy and it is a well known spot for tourists to stop and take photos. Painters and nature lovers also enjoy visiting this spot, and there are numerous art kiosks and cafes near the ledge offering their ware.Just Amazing, beautiful view, friendly people .

Rice terraceans river in bongkasa. I could not find this place to view, but I actually visit Rice terraceans river in bongkasa for pre-wedding photos, we just go down the van and takes picture for around 30 mins!View is nice!

Amazing view . Absolutely fabulous view of the rice field, but absolutely ridiculous 10,000IDR so-called "Admission fee" per person. You just parked your car on the side road and someone approached your car and you'll get charged for 10,000IDR. There are some souvenirs shop along the road, but you could get better price at marketplace around Tirta Empul Temple. It's a must place to go!
Dissappointed. I thought I would see sweeping rice terraces but the area was quite small. Nepal & Philippines have better rice terraces. I would give this a miss next time I visit Ubud.
Beautiful but too many tourists!. Really beautiful views of the Rice Terrace but just way to packed with tourists. Didn't like the fact that you had to pay to drive down the street.
Convenient but touristy. Nice if you don't have a lot of time to visit the UNESCO rice fields, since it is close to Ubud. Too many tourists and street vendors.

Stunning view. Beautiful view from the top. It's worth to visit once especially a lot of the rice fields have been developed for commercial purpose. There are some art and craft stalls along the street. There is also a coffee plantation nearby where you can visit.

Worth a short photo call. Beautiful landscape and for once in Bali it is free , well apart from the inevitable parking fee ! A number of small shops line the road and if your purchase does not take too long to negotiate it only means that you have paid too much , but it will still be a bargain .

Wonderful. But with entrance fee and donation.. Especially of you are "white" sorry to say that, they will love you to be at Bali.Anyway, this place is wonderful. Just a gentle reminder, travel light, bring your camera, water, a good pair of shoe to walk into the paddy field. You have to "hike" a little. My gf have a hard time to walk back to the entrance. She doesn't do sports. At all. Anyway for the entrance fee details, you can see it on my photo page here, https://www.snapraw.com/photo/110, I had the she album covered with particularly souvenirs prices, entrance fee charges, ohh us, prepare like 5k - 10k if for donation half way walking into the paddy field. The lady there literally block your walk in until u pay. Enjoy my photo page too :) thank you.

Great Rice Paddy!. In Bali, rice paddies are at everywhere. However, Tegalalang Rice Terrace is one of the best. I can suggest you to climb up rice paddy altough it can be difficult. Some people on rice paddy can try to charge you and if you avoid, they can disturb you too much. Be careful. After climbing, have a sit and watch the view.

Beautiful rice terraces...stop for a coffee break. The rice paddy fields are beautiful but it's difficult to find a peaceful view of them when the street is lined with tourist shops and street kids are chasing you to sell their postcards. We suggest you walk down the restaurants or coffee shops on the rice paddy side of the street (walk down the steep stairs) and splurge for a beverage and seat overlooking the rice fields. You can then take photos without tacky tourist paraphernalia invading your view.

Green, green and some green rice. Definitely a place to go if you are around Ubud. Nice views and a great picture location. Be aware that you will have to donate to maintain the bridge across the river to the terraces (yeah right) and parking might cost a bit, too. Either bring good shoes or know how to walk your flip flops.

Tranquil Beauty - if you skip the tourists... We actually managed to miss the main event by following bad directions from the internet on a moped. However, I'm kinda glad we did.We didn't see anything like the pictures of the UNESCO site, but we did spend an hour or so driving around the much less trodden (from looking at other reviews) smaller rice terraces of the surrounding Tegalalang area.We didn't see a tourist the entire time and passed through numerous tiny villages.Obviously it's best to see the proper site, but maybe on the way back to Ubud take one of of the turn offs from the main road for a bit to see something away from the tourist trap.Also, on our later journeys up to Tulambem, we saw some more spectacular terraces along the same lines, without the throngs of tourists.

nice. The rice paddy is nice but we just went their and look. Took pictures and that's it. you can see God's magnificent work by looking at it. If you like to hike you can book another tour. This is included in our central and bangli tour. It is too short and the area where u take picture is small so if their are many tourist around it will give you a hard time taking a photo. Bring hats, sunscreen

Terrace Farming. This was the first place we visited during our trip to Bali. Breathtaking views, great place for photographs as well. There is also a restaurant when you walk down to the rice terraces, great place to have lunch with an awesome view. Definitely a must go when you're in Ubud, Bali.

Go Early. The rice terraces are stunning. But this has become a tour bus stop with touts & traffic jamming the narrow road. Not far from Ubud, so hire a car or take a motorbike up there early in the day.

Tourist trap. Yes, the UNESCO Heritage Site rice terrace is stunning, jaw-dropping even. But you're constantly bombarded with street vendors the moment you step foot in the vicinity. They even started charging "entrance fee" to drive on the MAIN road. There are plenty of other gorgeous rice terraces in Bali if you're adventurous enough to explore this amazing island.

Beautiful rice terraces seen from a restaurant. Beautiful rice terraces viewed from a good restaurant but you do not spend too much time here. You come, you eat and you go. A really good photo op though.

Beautiful rice terraces. The rice terraces at Tegalalang makes an interesting addition to a visit to Ubud as it is only about 5 km north of Ubud. The views are spectacular. There are shops and cafes along the road where one can stop and enjoy the views. Our driver/guide told us that the rice terraces at Jatiluwih are more beautiful but then again, Jatuluwih is quite a distance from Ubud.

Have a drink at the terrace cafe and take in the view. After a close-up walk in the terrace paddies, enjoy the panoramic view from a distance at the terrace cafe with a drink, or a meal. May is not exactly the best time to go especially if you are into photography. Early spring is better when the farmers are watering and planting in the fields. Do watch out for the people who are manning the "donation" boxes. Actually we were essentially forced to pay up in order to pass through even though we had already paid the admission fees. Isn't "donation" voluntary or discretionary?

Nice view but place is overrun. In the town of Tegalalang there is actually one (mostly crowded) street on which you'll find a lot of cafés, shops, sellers - and tourists. While the view over the rice terraces is quite worth a visit, the overall experiance is not. There's just too many other tourists and people who try to profit from it (we paid a fee when we entered the town by motor bikes). My experience was that when renting a motor bike and driving around Ubud, you'll defenitely find more stunning views with much less stress then this crowded spot.

Nice to see a rice field for the first time.. The steps to walk up and down can be quite challenging for old folks with walking difficulty. But once you are in the paddy field, I would say the beautiful scene is worth all the walk. Ok for a visit if you do not have folks with walking difficulty.

Worth a visit . Went here at around 13:00pm and would definately say this was the best time as it was very quiet. The rice terraces are very impressive however, beware of the additional charges. Paid 20,000 for 2 people to enter then once inside there are a few stops where 'donation' is a must or you can't get through... Eventhough you may have already donated to another person beforehand - this was very annoying and it kinda ruined the experience for me...

Great rice terraces but a tourist trap. From mid morning till mid afternoon this is a busy tourist trap. Shops, restaurants and vendors all over the streets. You or your driver will have to pay to pass through. The view is great but thats about all i can say as this is not a place you want to hang about in. It will be hot, busy, full of people, and vendors selling everything from crochet tablecloths to postcards. An option might be to ask your driver to go through very slowly so you can take a few pictures and keep going a few miles farther on to find some just as spectacular views with no hustlers.

Why those ugly shops?. If you take the road to Tegallalang to see the rice terraces by car and if you are not prepared you can pass them without seeing them at all because there are ugly shops and restaurants blocking the view. But when you there take a one hour walk on the terraces although the path is quite steep.

Beautiful setting but be careful on the steps!. Lots of shops and restaurants around. Your taxi will park far away to make sure you walk through all the shops! :( Also there are no clear signs as to where you could go down the steps. Ask around : )

Rice fields. Really pretty area. Was a little crowded in middle day. Some people were relaxing with a meal overlooking the fields. This would be a good option I think to slowly and fully enjoy the surrounds.
Most gorgeous rice fields ever seen!. These are very beautiful rice fields. Worth a short visit! You will have to pay a small fee to stop here.

Fun and Naturesque!. Beautiful place, fun to go quad biking if you are adventurous and sporty. Good for hiking or trekking too. Very beautiful but visit preferably in the morning or close to sunset as it can be uncomfortably hot during sun peak hours!

Excellent Views. The views of the rice terraces from the road above them is excellent' Set in very lush country side you can walk among the terraces if you desire. But I did get the feeling that it is very commercialised and some what contrived. Many shops and cafes on the road above. I must admit that the rice terraces in the Philippines are more natural and not so commercialised and worked by the local tribes people

Beautiful and special. Beautiful and special rice terraces. They are very thin on this hill and therefore special. I guess this is a must have seen. Tipp: Don't stay near the road, go down and up again on the other side. It's worth it. It's a unusual way of walking through rice fields. I liked it a lot.

Beautiful Bali with a professional driver!. We spent the whole day in Ubud visiting different temples, doing shopping in Ubud central Market and on our way back we went to the Terraces. We were tired, but happy! It was fantastic! Thanks a lot to our driver, who showed us this place and many others on our way. I think, the most important thing in Bali is a good driver. In this case you can trust him, you can leave your stuff in the car and don't worry about it, also you can plan your budget because you always know the price and he never ask any extra money. I love Bali too much! It's already my 3rd time there and not the last one! If you need a driver, call to our Made (almost every driver in Bali is Made!), he has a good new car with aircon and he drive the car very careful what is important for me. So, his phone number is +628123611213. You can find him on Facebook as Made Umariawan. Ah, yes, his prices were USD65 for full day and USD45 for a half day for the whole car! We were 4 people and we shared these prices! Enjoy Bali!!!
not to be missed!!!!. beautiful, lush green rice flields about 30 min bike ride from ubud, not to be missed. You can walk around the rice fileds, sit at a cafe and enjoy the breathtaking views.
impressive. Really amazing view when it's the first time you see a rice terrace, unfortunately full of tourists, buses everywhere, very difficult to take a picture without tourists on it

Beautiful sightseeing spot. The scenery was just breath-taking! You can actually walk on the rice terrace to get up close and personal. Alternatively you can have lunch or drinks at one of the many cafes there and enjoy the view from there. Definitely worth a visit.

Must see. We went to see the rice fields in the morning. Beautiful, lush, green rice fields made the trip worth while. We got incredible pictures and were able to see the rice fields. The climb to the top and over the bridges makes the trip fun, adventurous and perfect for couples, singles, and groups. Loved it.

Beautiful. My expectations were high, but they were met here! It certainly was a divine scenery! Our chauffeur parked along the street and it was just a few meters walk and few steps to the shelf were we could stand and watch.
Amazing views. We just enjoyed the view rather than doing the walk as it was too hot for us. The ride from Ubud is nice, many shops along the way.

Simply said, beautiful!. Beautiful place! Enough said.. If you'd like, you can walk down the path down the terraces, but you need proper shoes. Flip flops are not good as if it has rained, the path may be slippery. The only tip I'd give is Bali Pulina Coffee Plantation and tasting is literally right across from the Tegalalang Rice Terrace and is really worth a visit. Everyone knows about Tegalalang Rice Terraces but not everyone knows about the coffee plantation.
Best ever. Lying on cushions sipping their hot chocolate -is there any thing like it... scenery was just that.....serene, they couldn't do enough for us, all those steps, all day. ?..

Gorgeous view!. If you're staying in Ubud, Tegalalang's Rice Terraces are a must-see. We did a short tour that first took us to taste Luwak Coffee along with a variety of other coffees and teas - with a breaktaking view of the terraces! Then we drove to walk through the rice terraces and a nearby town. We used a guide whose stand we found in the center of Ubud, as his services were much cheaper than the tour my hotel would have set up. Overall a great experience!

Beautiful Nature!. Nice rice terraces - very green and very relaxing to the eyes and so cool to admire.Love this place as we have also rice terraces in the Philippines, but this one is so cute. SO mini compared to our Banaue Rice Terraces.Would recommend to our relatives and friends to visit this.
Perfect tourist photo op.. Sat in a lovely cafe overlooking the beautiful rice paddies. Lovely spot for the perfect tourist photo op
Beautiful!. Tegalalang's terraced rice paddies were simply beautiful, and worth the winding drive. if you have a chance, find one of the restaurants that overlook the area, for a relaxing lunch.

Beautiful, and wonderful restaurant in the paddy. We ate in a lovely little restaurant in the side of the paddy which served up some of the best food we had in Bali. Fresh, tasty curry that was presented beautifully
Beautiful. The pictures don't do it justice. It's such a beautiful place. Definitely walk through the rice fields, don't just drive by.
Fabulous!. Do NOT miss seeing this. This rice terrace is so beautiful. We visited with our guide on a private day tour while staying in Ubud.
super beautiful from Ubud. if are you going to bali and one of the places that you must to go is the rice fields, go down stairs to have the more beautiful pictures.
It's a must see. This is included in one of the private tour I booked in at Alam Puisi Villa. It was an amazing experience to be able to make it at the top of the rice terraces.

Very beautiful! must see in person. The pictures of this ride terrace don't do it justice, they are way better in person! You can get the best overall view from the road or cafes, but if you want to go down into them you will need good footwear and some money. It is a steep climb down and then you start the gentle paths of the terrace. There are stop points where you are told you need to give a donation to get further. Typical donation is 5000 rupiah per person. We spent about 45 minutes here and then we were blistering hot as it is not in the shade, so we made our way out. If your staying in Ubud there is no need to hire a driver to get here, rent a scooter for 45-60,000 ($4-6 US). Take Raya Ubud east all the way to the statue and at the statue turn left (north) then stay on this road all the way to Tegalalang (approx 10-15 mins). There's tons of street parking for your scooter. *I've read on here that Tegalalang is very busy..? We barely saw 20 people in the fields and we were visiting mid day. So we never witnessed crowds. Well worth the visit, so close to Ubud!
Beautiful. Very picturesque rice fields . You can view from the road or climb down into the fields - however the climb is quite steep and involves quite a lot of steps
Nice View. I enjoyed the nice view of beautiful and unique rice fields.
Highly publicised but not fantastic. The tegalalang rice terrace were average and in my view it is worth a visit only if you are visiting the nearby temples and ubud.

Stunning Valley . What a breath taking view , drown through the valley over all of the rice fields . Amazing photos to be had from on the side of the road . Great cafes situated along the road side as well as your standard Bali tourist sellers . Very hot in the sunshine , but beautiful .
Small rice terraces. Small rice terraces on the way from Ubud to Batur volcano. Terrace a small but nice, you can make beautiful pictures and have a romantic breakfast or lunch - lots of cafes.

Beautiful. This is a beautiful rice terrace to look down on, particularly from the little stores that line the road along it. It is VERY crowded though. If you're after something a little more peaceful, head to the other rice terrace: Jatiluwih, in Tabanan. It's the largest rice field in Bali, much more peaceful and you can walk amongst it - it's worth the small fee the village charges to enter.
Beautiful rice fields. I liked the views of the terraced rice fields, very beautiful! Great picture opportunities. Some shopping in the area

Amazing place to see ! Peace and nature. Every people should see this place, is really beautiful, peaceful ! There is a restaurant there, you seat on the floor for the lunch and u can admire this view green !

Rice is Nice. Wherever I went in Bali it seemed I was surrounded by small paddy fields usually tended by a stooped old man or woman who trudges bear-footed through brown turbid water, inspecting each plant and moving slowly on.
