These tiny plots are planted either as a community project or for the needs of a single family. When the rice is growing the paddies look like deep green patchwork quilts undershot with a shimmering muddy silk sheet. The gurgle of running water is not far away and the chirruping of bugs a constant companion to the heat and humidity. Growing between the paddies are banana plants and coconut palms and mature rice plants heavily cropped heads bowed and stooped while small birds dart from one plant to the next oblivious of the flags flapping in the thin breeze.But the Tegalalang terraces are rice farming on a semi-industrial scale. It seems as if the terraces have been carved from the earth itself and formed into a stairway for Balinese giants. The verdant steps seem to tumble down a hill side into the valley below. The effect is of an amphitheatre padded with green velvet and a backdrop of tall lush-canopied palms.For the more energetic and adventurous a climb through the terraces to the top-most point is rewarded by hauntingly beautiful views.These ancient terraces are recognised as a UNESCO World Heritage Site and besides supplying a staple crop the terraces are an ancient form of water management. I stopped at a small café and enjoyed a Java tea while marvelling that these terraces have been continually worked for centuries. The green was occasionally broken by the bright crimson flash of hibiscus flowers that grows on the edges of the terrace. Bali is famed for its paddy fields and the Tegalalang Rice Terraces are a relaxing stop and one of the true marvels of the ancient world.  As more and more rice paddies are being bought for commercial use the protection of the UNESCO is to be valued.

Wow picture postcard view. The view is just off a postcard - we were lucky as it wasn't busy when we stopped to view the rice terraces our driver did a great job of explaining the processes and it's definitely worth a photo visit.
not so fancy anyway. It's just ok, abit too commercialize, nothing so special about it. I've seen the nicest one in Vietnam which is not so commercialize and pretty.

Look at it, don’t walk it!. We were taken to the famous rice terrace by our driver. We payed the entrance fee and started walking down very steep stairs and when reaching the bottom started climbing the steep rice terraces. I am 62. I found it very hard. More so it is overrated. Now and then you come upon a station to give a donation. Climbing up the stairs back to the road was very difficult. Don’t do it! Instead ask your driver to drop you off at the view point and enjoy the site. Pretty incredible.

Beautiful sight. Would recommend going as part of a tour of ubud, sacred monkey forest, etc. It's a beautiful sight. Worth seeing. You can walk throughout the rice field, but we didn't as we had young children, and it would have been a long walk through narrow paths.
amazingly beautiful. This is such an amazingly beautiful spot - either just to admire the green terraces , take photo's or walk leisurely about to see the terraces from different vantage points.

A Must See. This is a fabulous site to check out if you're on your way towards the volcano. Our driver told us that it's actually privately owned, so I would see it in case in a few years it disappears to more development like many other places in Ubud.

Nice view but not worth the price. Terraced rice paddies in a valley. Yawn. Charge for parking if you can find any parking. Lots of tourists and people wanting to sell you souvenirs. To me it was not as scenic as the terraced quinoa fields in Peru.

Intimate spot. Unfortunately we arrived after dark, due to the language barrier at our villa. The meal was lovely & the service good. We were even supplied with mosquito repellent on arrival, although that didn't seem to be too much of an issue (possibly because it was already dark).
Dissapointed. The paddy field is nice but the coconut trees are killing the view! There are lots of restaurants serving local foods and a good shopping spot if are one shopper.

Inside a green picture. Tegalalang Rice Terrace seems to be the nearest one from Ubud, it is also a stop on your way to Kintanmani. From there you may see the rice fields from afar, therefore flood of visitors (always for group tours) lining in queue to take pictures because it is free of charge( except parking fee for vehicles only). Don't go there in the afternoon, you may suffer from sunstroke because of the hot weather.
Nice View & trek. Try to go on early morning or late evening. It will be very hot during the day. Make sure you wear good shoes, it will be very slippery.

nice for Bali. this area is nice to see if passing through to kintamani or other areas north, however just to drive here for this I believe its not worth it.Stopping your car will mean you have to pay a few thousand for parking.2,000. make sure you take the ticket upon paying.Tabanan area boasts better terraces than here and you will be the only person there.

Rice Terraces. Beautiful Rice terraces. Most drivers stop here on the way out in the morning but it puts the sun in a tough spot to take photos. Ask them to stop on the way back instead when the sun is behind you.

Decent but VERY busy. Its a cheap (they ask for donations but at *several* places along the terrace track) but scenic way to spend a hour.The main road itself is lined with tourist shops and cafes to cater for the bus loads of people that turn up.The terraces themselves have tracks along for people to enjoy the views.The MOST scenic place is one people seldom go to though - after reaching the "top" of the valley looking across at the main road continue up the track through some trees and you come out in the next valley over(2 min walk). That is a much much prettier area with no roads, no tourist buildings and pretty much no tourists - just a few friendly farmers. Most people seem to stop at the valley, look across at the road then work their way back down to the exit rather than continuing. Its not sign posted at all so you blunder across it by accident.You wont need to spend more than an hour here but its a worthwhile distraction if you're driver past or near.

Beautiful scenery. We visited the terraces as part of a long day tour with a driver. Although we had to pay to see what could easily have been seen from another vantage point it was a small price to pay as supposedly the money goes to the "Village" ( not to sure about that) Once we paid or the driver paid for us we were take down some steps to vies the terraces which were stunning to say the least and was so so green. Rice plants actually give two crops per year so is a very good food source for those in the village Glad that I saw this.

Nice fields, not as great as pictures in magazines. I loved seeing rice terraces and would certainly recommend seeing them. Was just a little disappointed that they were more commercial than I expected and a bit more worn than I expected (but its Bali!). Some great photo opportunites, esp with workers carrying things about. It would be good to go for a long walk through them but we didn't have time. Very small fee

Amazing. We went to Jatiluwih Rice Fields the previous day and were thinking to skip this one. Thanks God we did not! How lovely it is there. One of the most beautiful places in Bali.If possible, go early about 7-8 a.m., and you will have it all for yourself.

Walking on the rice terrace. If you visit Ubud, you don't want to miss this one. You can walk on the terrace and experience the rural feeling of Bali there. There's also some hut where they sell coconut water, if you speak Indonesian (or even better with Balinese) you can have a better price.

Interesting to see. It was interesting to see these much publicized rice fields however it wasn't the best time to go as it looked like they had not long planted a new crop. Once there was some more growth of lovely bright green padi it would have been much more scenic!

Paddy-fields like nowhere else. Tegalalang is an area on the northern part of, 10 km from Ubud, that is one of the homes to beautiful paddy-fields. I remembered back in elementary school, we were thought that Bali has been the leader among other provinces in the layered paddy-field system which is beneficial for irrigation, which is called 'terasering' or 'sengkedan'.At tegalalang, you can either take beautiful pics with the lush green paddy-fields as background, or have lunch at one of the many restaurants that provides huts facing the fields, or take the guided walking tour across the field.We were approached by a local lady, 60+yrs, and she offered to guide us touring the fields with good english, for idr50k. The terrain is not for everyone, the steps are steep, and sometimes you have to climb quite high. So using a guide might be a good idea.

Fantastic place. It is far, and during the way to get there you pass trough the local villages that they are amazing. When you get there the view is fantastic and you can go and walk among the rice plantation. It worths.
Beautiful and rural. Drove by lots of rice terraces at Tegalalang. We went to Jatiluwih the day before so we didn't stop, but they look almost the same.

Shame about the tourists waling over the rice paddies taking shortcuts. I sugges going either very early or for sunset. Otherwise can be very busy and the road at the top gets congested, lots of tourist shops. Wont need to spemd long here.

Another Iconic place in Ubud. Tengalalang Rice Terrace is the most iconic and known terrace in all Ubud Area. It has been displayed in several films, including BARAKA (1996). Although the principle is the same "another rice terrace you may say", this one has an excellent angle for shots. Totally recommended if you go North (Kintamini / Batur Lake or Mother Earth Temple).

Beautiful scenery. The view is lovely but go early to avoid the crowds as bus loads from the rest of the island start arriving by late morning. There are lots of touristy shops and restaurants around the area.

nice view, ordinary food. located on the valey overlooking the paddy field, this restaurant is merely selling the view only. the food is not special. furthermore, it is very crowded during lunch time.
I would recommend some other place in Ubud.

Excellent View and Fresh Air. We went there from Ubud. The view was excellent. Can sit in a roadside eatery which can give you excellent view, can have light snack & coffee and can imbibe the serenity of the place.

nice view. not much to do apart from sight seeing...
it has a really nice few tho ...i like to see it during sunset time...gives a the feeling of serenity

Rice terrace ubud. If you come to Batur mountain you have past this place,from Ubud central around 15minut to Kintamani you can see this place.nice view with rice terrace,and coconut tree.enjoy with a couple cup coffee,Balinese cake Or just juice.relax with green view front Of you.come enjoy it.!

This is the Picture-Postcard View. We stopped here for about 20 minutes on our way around the island. They sell you a ticket and you park. The valley is really very photogenic. We were there in April when the rice plants have grown in and all is an amazing velvety green. It's a perfect one-frame photo of the best Balinese rice terrace. There are a few restaurants but we did not stay. You can use the rest rooms for about IDR 2,000 (US 0.15) so you don't need to buy anything. By all means plan your drive so you go by Tegalalang -- but I also liked the big wide-open rice terraces at Jatiluwih further north. There, they go on for miles and have walking trails. (You can also hike through Tegalalang but we didn't have time.)

Spectacular and donation based. It was spectacular!!! But make sure to wear good hiking shoes as the steps are steep and slippery. Also, they ask you to donate everyone you go down and back up the terrace. If they offer coconuts, they will also ask for money.
Such an amazing view!. Pictures do not do justice to how beautiful the rice fields are! If you get the chance make sure you go! Well worth it even to just stand at the top and see all the rice.
Nice. Nice view. It's a place I really wanted to see because I have never seen it before and now I have seen it, not planning to re-visit next time.

Amaaazing!. The pictures does not give justice of the real nature of the rice terrace.
Such and amazing view with amazing experience.
U can go up the hill and return.
U need to wear comfortable clothes and shoes.
Its hot and sunny so bring hat and water with u .

Overrated and crowded, just driving through is a nightmare. I must admit, it is one of my least favourite places in Bali. There is nothing wrong with the terraces - the view is nice, although you can see equally nice or even nicer views driving between Ampapura and Chandidasa. It is just they every tour operator in Bali brings their tourists to Ceking, Tegallalang to view the terraces, and as the result there is a constant traffic jam.Road is narrow anyway, so just to drive through can take half an hour. Locals are also desperate to get their share of the action and are following the unfortunate tourists trying to sell them all sorts of goods which are cheaper in villages up and down the road - which makes it all a bit of a nightmare. Every organised tour will take you there, so if you go on one of those you will not manage to avoid it. But my advice would be to hire a car (135000Rs to 150 000Rs - £13 to £15 per day), get a map of Bali and go and look at rice terraces elsewhere. Or get a motorbike if you know how to ride one from before (Bali is the wrong place to LEARN to ride a bike). Or hire a car + driver if you are not happy about driving yourself - about 350 000 Rs per day - still cheaper then tours that charge $50 or $60 per person
Nice trakking place. Beautiful beautiful terraces. I did not like men on every terrace, having short of tent there and asking for donation.

Magnificent view. I was initially planning to have a walk around there but unfortunately time did no allow it. But it was great even just for the view. However would recommend people who enjoy outdoor activities to put it on there to do list when visiting Ubud.

Stunning. Stopped off here for some breathtaking photos on the way to the volcano. Not sure if the pictures really do it justice mind you.Just a magnificent sight and really something you must see when in Bali - toilets are a bit thin on the ground, so you may need to buy a cheeky Bintang to use the facilities at one of the local eateries ;-)
Breathtaking view. The rice terraces are just amazing and are a breathtaking view. Well worth the visit, just beware of street sellers

Beautiful view but little else. The terraces are beautiful. For a western tourist it's so unlike what you've seen before. They're lush and green at the end of the wet season too. We just looked really, as it's a fair climb down and back up again and it was 32degrees. It was busy too. Hoards of tourists, 'terrace view' style cafes and trinket shops line the narrow road. We were there late in the day though, and our guide said an early morning view is just as beautiful, cooler and quieter.

Nice green view. We went in December 2014 and I guess it was a bit off season. Though the view was still great, it was not as good as I had imagined based on all the reviews and pictures that I had seen.
Please check for the correct/best season for this place, I think, before visiting.

Small in scale. It is less than an hour drive from Ubud and is on the way to Kintamani. We wanted to go Jetiluwih instead but our driver said sama sama (same same). However, I find the rice terrace rather small, not as spectacular as Longsheng Rice Terrace I visited in Guilin, China. I also think the rice terraces in Sappa, Vietnam, is much nicer than this. There is an entrance fee of RP20,000. Even though it's cheap, skip this and go for Jetiluwih If you only have time for one rice terrace.
Great pictures. The classic Bali terraced rice files you hope to see. We combined this with a visit to several temples and an art stores all within an hours drive of Ubud

Beautiful scenery. Lovely scenery and location. Cool air. Lots of tourist shops though, so they might start harassing you if you come during the peak hours. No real signage to get around so have a wander and take in the sights.

So green and peaceful. After hearing about people going on about how amazing this place is, we decided that we must give this place a go - and I am so glad we did!Although you don't need to spend too much time here unless you are at one of the restaurants next to the Rice Terrace enjoying the view (there isn't much to do expect to be amazed and take heaps of photos)One thing I must warn you guys is the tiny and old Balinese lady who walks along the rice terrace with a bamboo stick full of plants. When she sees you she'll smile and welcome you to take photos with the Balinese working hat and the bamboo stick. However, after you had you're fun she'll tell you to pay 10,000 rupiah which is around USD$1. Although this isn't much for us it was a bit shocking as it was quite unexpected and mind you, 10,000 rupiah is good amount of money for the local Balinese people.
Stunning views. The views are amazing. The rice paddy terraces are so lush and green. This is a must see while in Bali. Get off the tourist hub and out to the villages.
Amazing. It was raining little when we visited these rice fields. And it made it more memorable. The surroundings is very natural, impressive.

Terraced rice paddies of Tengalang. The terraced rice paddies are quite spectacular, but I think that this area has become too touristy now. There are a very large number of people, cars, buses and bikes all trying to jockey for space. The road is only very narrow , so parking is at a premium. The locals are also starting to try and cash in on the tourist trade (can you blame them ) with people trying to sell you there wares as well as some enterprising entrepeneurs trying to charge for photo opportunities.Maybe try going early in the day before the busses arrive. get better photos in the early morning light as well.

A highlight of our Ubud stay. The spectacular vista of paddy fields stepping down into a ravine makes this a very popular tourist spot. There may be a parking fee, which our driver paid. There are cafes and market stalls set up on the side of the road to take advantage of all the people who stop to take in the sight. There is also the option of a walking tour - you would need to be fit - and photo opportunities with an old farmer who was charging for the privelege.The commercial side couldn't take away from a really amazing visual experience - millions of photos taken there I would guess. Just a little up the road, we stopped at another small viewing area - but this was very unpleasant, with families of hawkers becoming relatively aggressive trying to sell their souvenirs - and demanding parking fees also. Whatever, the experience was well worth any negatives.
Emerald green. This is a must see of unique, luscious emerald green rice patties set up in hillside steps. Just gorgeous!

Only good if you have not seen rice terraces previously. Nothing too fascinating, unless you have not seen rice terraces previously. Actually, you will see better landscape of rice terraces in other parts of Indonesia, particularly the more rural areas.

Well worth a stop. Rice terraces are available throughout the trip toward Mt Batur but its worth stopping here for the experience of a different culture if you come from a country that does not farm rice in the traditional way. The terraces are quite spectacular in places, and working out the farming techniques is an education, as is contemplation of the work ethics and lifelong energy of the paddy field works who endlessly plant, water and harvest rice. They are small and wiry and an inspiration to those of us who think a few hours in the garden on Saturday is hard work. Well recommended as a tourist stop.
Breathtaking. The scenery are superb...just breathtaking ...A nice place to take photograph and not forgetting you can shop along the street as well.....

Tanya Grant Jones. Beautiful landscape. A great place to stop and have a break. To sit and drink a Luwak coffee overlooking the rice paddies is a treat. If you have time take a walk through the fields.

Amazing to see! Lots of great photo opportunities.. A great spot to see the rice terraces! There are many places to stop along the road to take photos. If you look close you can see people working on the terraces which is interesting to see! Don't miss the opportunity to see the terraces.

Breathtaking View. Stand on the terrain, take a deep breath and take in the view. The rice terrace is definitely unlike anything you've seen. The artistic side of Bali has gone from oil painting, wood crafts, to terrain sculpting. The entrance fee is Rp5,000 but if you choose to walk further to the other side of the hill, donation is expected at each booth. The market price is around Rp5,000 - 10,000 for each booth. The best time to visit to avoid the tourist crowd is around 10am or 5pm.

Stunning—and challenging!. Wear good, gripping footwear, a sun hat, and bring plenty of water. A trek here isn't for the faint of heart, but it's so worth it. One of the most beautiful places I've ever seen.
Spectacular view. Gave a spectacular view. When we went, there was a mild drizzle, enjoyed the view a lewak coffee made it more special.

The rice field of Ubud. The view is stunning. We enjoyed the walk around, (donation to farmers at 10,000 IDR per person). There are lesser and lesser rice field in Bali so able to walk around this place is a blessing. Not just seeing the rice plants, there are fish and crab in the water, also the sound of the insects. Not hot cuz the trees' sheds. Rather steep steps so people with knees problem and not physically fit may find it difficult.

Great Place but too commercialised. The narrow road leading to the place is always congested but during my third trip there the congestion was bad but it is due to the preparation for Nyepi Day. I like the place it is so peaceful except for the crowded tourists (including me) . Parking is a huge problem if you self drive like me but the view is spectacular. Since it is situated on the route to Kintamani, thus I'll definitely return to this place.
The view is something different. The view might be interesting especially for non-Asians, who are not used to seeing rice fields.. But the layering of paddy fields is really something worth seeing..

Lushous Green Rice terrace. It was raining when we visited the Tegalalang Rice Terrace and it was an awesome sight watching the rain water flowing down the lush green rice terrace. We had lunch at a restaurant on the hill which gave a great view, a hot soup with chill of rains and beautiful veiw was simply perfect. One of the must see places in Bali.
Fabulous views over the ricefields not far from Ubud. Great views over the ricefields, but you must be prepared for thehard sell from the souvenir vendors who are gradually taking theplace over.
A nice view. Though not the best I have seen but it is nice enough to stop by on the way to Mount Batur.However do go there early as the weather will be cooler and less chance of rain.
MUST. SEE.. Honestly, the quintessential, but most beautiful sight in Bali. You don't need a whole lot of time here, but don't miss it. The photos alone are worth it.

was a seriously beautiful adventure. this was a place we always wanted to visit.. be warned as it is very hot and very humid and you do need a certain amount of fitness but well worth all of it.. the views are beautiful

gorgeous views. we hired a scooter from Ubud for 50K and had a lovely ride out to the tegalalang rice terrace. It took about 30mins from the centre of Ubud on a straight road! Parking was free as we just pulled up on the side of the road. We then walked around the rice terrace for around an hour taking various pics. Try to avoid midday heat as there is no shade!! You are asked for a donation but there is no fixed price/suggested price so it's up to you what you think it's worth. We then went back up onto the road a rode down opposite the "office/toilet" where you can take a gorgeous picture from a lookout point. There are a few cafes and restaurants for a cold drink before heading away. Overall, I wouldn't waste money on paying for a tour to the rice terrace but on the scooter, it was an excellent way to spend the morning!!!!

Journey to Bali, Indonesia. A small version of Rice Terraces from Mountain Province in Philippines thus the look or landscape are more typical that we saw already. Though we don't really expect to see such features in this place considering Bali is not a big place.

View is all that matters. We had a problem to reach out the Tegalalang Rice Terrace because of the too many cars and busses that where in the area, but when we saw the view we were so pleased we went there! There are many tourist shops if you want to buy something and small coffee shops on the hill if you want to drink your coffee seeing the view. Of course it was too crowdie, but everyone should expect that in places like that.There were many people who walked through the rice terraces all the way across the hill and up to the next one. Firstly, if you want to do that you must wear appropriate cloths and shoes. Just think that you should go down and up again from small paths across the terraces. Another thing you should be careful of are the spiders and the snakes…. Yes, you think that with so many people all the creepy things will be hidden somewhere away from you, but no… this is not true! While we took photos with my husband and when I was next to a banana tree I saw next to my face the biggest spider ever. I screamed, my husband took a picture of her in order to keep scaring me with it… not the best experience. When we saw a snake among the rice plants, we decided to leave and that we do not love nature that much.Concussively, everyone should visit Tegalalang Rice Terrace at least for the view from the safe coffee shops and balconies. If you do not want to walk around the terraces, I don’t think that you will miss any great experience. The view is all that matters.

Spectacular views!!. Tegalalang is about 10 Kms north of Ubud, and worth a short stop to view the rice terraces/padi fields (NOT rice paddies.....PLEASE!!!), but the old guys with the pole and baskets hustling to have your pics taken with his baskets over your shoulder are a bit much at times. This is a seriously overcrowded area at times, with a narrow road, and tourist buses as far as the eye can see.The touristy shops, hanging precariously off the side of the road, over a drop of 10+ meters, are selling the same things you'll see in the Ubud market, but mostly more expensive because they're preying on the bus travelers.Tegalalang is between Ubud and Kintamani, so if you're passing through in either direction, stop off, stretch your legs and have a coffee.

stupid payments. I liked the views - just amazing. You can have really nice pictures there made.
I did not like that at certain points some locals want to charge you money to pass (it wasnt understood why we had to pay if we already paid at the parking lot).

Stunning view b. It is worth a visit. Simply beautiful sight. Take a few minutes to walk down to the fields for a close up photo opportunity. Drive about 50 meters further down, unknown to many, is another site for a different view and photo opportunity.Other than the awesome sight of the terrace paid fields there isn't much else to do though you can have coffee or browse around the stalls. Most people drop by Tegalalang on the way to another place of interest.
Beautiful . Amazing view worth the trip. Don't need to stay long as it's a great place to stop & streach your legs. We were on our way to Ubud.

Very beautiful, scenic, and relaxing - A must see!. These are Bali’s most famous elevated rice terraces and they are located just north of Ubud’s city center. Along the road are shops, restaurants, and cafes. You can chill out, have a drink, and watch that rice grow. This area is also very famous for woodworking; local craftsmen sell statues and very unique furniture.You can also climb up and explore the rice terraces. Along the paths local have set up booths that accept “donations.” Some of the booths will not let you pass until you give them any amount of money while others will let you pass. There are only a few booths so it’s not like you’ll be giving away money every few meters.
Absolutely beautiful!. An incredible beautiful tradition. Great platforms to view from. Only worth a short stop though as there is not much else nearby

Stunning pictures! Worth the visit.... One of the best rice fields (paddies) that are found in Ubud. We stayed at The Kayon Resort about 15-min. personal driver ride and it was worth it. Amazing views of the rice terraces, incredible landscapes.
place for tourists. Nice grounds but full of tourists!!! people and shops everywhere , but was ok to take a photo.Actually my girlfriend loved took a lot of selfies.

worth a look. Beautiful view and well worth the trip to see it. You don't need long to be here if you just want a quick photo. You can walk down on onto the paddies if you want. We just got our driver to drop us off took a few snaps the carried on somewhere else.
Nice. Nice rice terrace, beautiful place, but not much to see or do.We ask the taxi driver to wait for us, it was good because we were done quickly.

Incredible. Such an amazing experience being able to see the traditional side of Bali. And the best part about it is it's free! I would definitely recommend getting a driver if you are staying in Kuta or Seminyak as its a bit of a drive. We had an awesome driver (only 400,000IDR for the day) that we used for every major outing we did.

Beautiful scenery and Atmosphere. Beautiful spot to see the rice terraces of Bali at their best. It is so lush, green and peaceful. We were lucky to see a farmer ploughing with his bull. You can get beautiful pictures from the road above the fields.
Only one in bali. It cannot be found anywhere else in Bali i think, but too many people there, it has one good restaurant called Teras Cafe if i'm not wrong.

Breathtaking atmosphere. You can just stand still and feel the atmosphere, very breathtaking. If you want, you can walk there in rice terrace or just sit and enjoy the view and surround. There are many places to drink and eat there. This is a must experience in Bali

Beautiful scenary. Enjoyed the space and air on the hill. Very nice spot for photography. Many shops along the way.
Would recommend anyone to visit.
Nice green like post card picture view. I like The view is nice . Dislike is when you entrance will have local people take a little entrance fees .
fantastic views. Didn't stay for long but it would have been a lovely place to walk around and perhaps meet some locals. We were on a tight schedule.

A must see during your trip in Ubud. The Tegalalang rice fields were definitely one of the destinations I wanted to visit in Bali, and I was quite pleased by it. It's a green heaven I could spend days in. There are however a few things to know:- prepare change, a small donation/fee is required (like RP. 5000). You'll also be able to get a refreshing coconut down there- have good shoes, it's not the easiest terrain to go- I recommend to start the visit a bit downhill (not a the top with the nice view) where you will find a nice, concrete stair that will avoid you to break your legs while falling! Then go up and climb back on the top, were you'll finish with a nice view over the fields.

Nice view, that's it . We stopped by as part of our day trip with a driver. After we paid the entrance fee to get in, we parked, got out, had a look, then got back in and left. All for about 10 mins. It's a beautiful view but it's too hot to be standing around outside, let alone hiking up and down the rice fields to get a closer look. There are the same ol same ol shops that line the street. We're not interested in shopping so there was nothing more for us to do here. We wouldn't go again but maybe we don't appreciate it because we've seen similar before.

Good views. Nice drive not far from the centre of Ubud. Parking on the road is easy if you're riding up. We went in rainy season so it was very green. Many tourists shops trying to sell you the usual gear. Had to pay 5000 for parking then you may have to make a donation to walk around the terraces.

Local Agriculture. i and my friend ride a motor bike to see the sunrise and stop by to visit Tegalalang, one of the famous rice field. Sound like normal culture of local people but concept how to get water all include the area is wonderful.With the height of each step of rice field, how can they harvest all things. Quite interresting!!!
Old Bali rice fields. A reminder of old Bali, full of rice in all stages. Sometimes one can see the people working. Gives a beautiful face to the old world.

A visual treat on the road from Ubud to Batur. This is the third time we visited this site and it as amazing as the first time. A definite treasure to be enjoyed when in the Ubud area of Bali. The wonderful rice terraces and the hospitable people make Bali a favoured destination. It requires some stairs in the hillside to be climbed but is well worth the time and effort. Many souvebirs shops and restaurant are nearby. Make a side trip to see the wood carvers creating the marvelous Garuda / Vishnu statues.Our guide, Adit swarna widya, has shown us many memorable sites as we toured Bali. Her warm character and wealth of knowledge makes her a perfect partner for exploring Bali. She has a Facebook name of Ni Ketut Widiyantari and her mobile numbers are 6281999101407 or +6281338515386Her e-mail is adit1974@gmail.comWe are looking forward to returning to Bali in May 2015. Visited August 2014
Amusing. The view is amusing, go down to the paddys and have a closer look at them. It's very steep and make slowly at the time you go up again.

Great view. there were few cafes overlooking the rice terrace, you can go to the middle of the rice terrace too quite a hike, but there were two huts where the farmer will stop us to donate some money. so prepare small change!

Breathtaking - a must do. When we arrived by scooter we had to park and pay 5,000 rupiah each person to get an entrance ticket. You walk in and it is just beautiful, be careful and watch your step! Once you have entered and walked in a bit you will come to a "stall" like booth and there will be a sign which says to make a donation in order to keep the paths good. The lady will not let you pass until you give a donation (she said we were to pay 5,000 rupiah each however you can just let them know you will be willing to give them a donation) You can keep walking on. The photos do not give this place justice, it is just amazing.

Amazing!!. Whilst staying in Legian we booked a car and driver for the day and this was one stop along the way. There was a small charge by an official to proceed along the road and we were informed that this goes towards the upkeep of this area. Our driver was most knowledgeable about the rice terraces and the view was spectacular. The terraces are situated beside a very busy road and has many tourist hawkers are in the vicinity. Ignoring that, the rice terraces are magnificent and well worth the effort. The steps from the road are uneven, broken and at differing heights. So be very careful. We have marvellous photos of us and the rice terraces as background. We were there mid morning and sun shone brightly. There is a walk through the rice fields but we didn't have time.

Wow!. I wasn't sure what to expect, but was blown away by the view. The downside is that the view is from an extremely busy road full of hawkers and tourist shops - think Brighton when the sun comes out. if you're able to ignore this, then enjoy!

off a busy road, but still beautiful. we stopped here, thinking it was going to be in the middle of a big serene field of lush rice terraces. it is just slightly off a busy road and lots of street vendors. it can get super busy with lots of businesses..we didn't end up hiking through the rice terraces cuz we got there late in the day. they are still beautiful but we enjoyed the terraces in Gunung Kawi for the peacefulness much more.

Pretty, but Jitilawhu much more scenic. Surrounded by vendors and cafes, off a busy road. Basically a stop on the way to Kitamano. We were not bothered by the vendors, but the area is junky along the road. Because Jitalawhu is protected by UNESCO, you can see a larger area of rice fields without the encroaching development.

RICE TERRACE. We do have PODU cultivation in India but Bali Tegalalang Rice Terrace has much scenic beauty, especially if you visit when there is sufficient sunlight. Don't miss to take you photo with the Rice Terrace as Background.
Beauty. Beautiful spectacle of the rice terraces, but great shame about the vendors, scary as some of them are very pushy, and won t go away.

Beautiful and awed. Find a quiet coffee shop and enjoy the serenity.
While I was there a storm with strong winds came about and literally snapped trees in pieces.
Nature wow!

Must visit. Beautiful little area and view. I did not like the tourist shops blocking the view but I guess it's part and parcel of tourism. Too many hawkers selling things though. The traffic was bad. Go when it's more quiet at the end of the day, not in the morning.

Thanks. short but nice car-trip from Ubud
these terraces are as mind blowing as on the pictures
find the steep but practical steps down and join or great the paddy workers amidst this well kept worldwonder
just listen, smell, ... contemplate

Nice to see, but... Paying for the view and gettin "attackt" by shop owners. .. I rather rent a scooter and drive to a diffeent place with better view and less or no tourists (pretty much drive till you can't see tourists anymore)... yeah its a nice picture, but I never understood the point of paying for a view to take a picture...

When I think of Bali, this is what I think of!. I was breathless looking at this view. I could've stayed all day. Being that it was our first time to Bali and our first outing, I didn't think it could get any better. The constant barrage of people asking if we needed a taxi or to buy their wares gets a bit old after the first 2 minutes. And holding a conversation with my family was difficult, but you just need to switch off and enjoy what you see. You can also walk around the terraces, which I didn't realise until we were sitting down to lunch. No walking after lunch for me! So next visit will see me walking around them.

Spectacular Rice Terrace. The Tegalalang Rice Terrace is on a hillside that is too large and beautiful to describe in words. It was built as a tourist destination but I didn't feel like I was being manipulated. There are hilly walking trails if you are fit. The view is truly spectacular and exotic and makes for stunning photos.

Beautiful Terraces. This was an added stop by our driver on our way toThe Elephant Sanctuary so we were very pleased to be able to include it in our day. The terraces are beautiful and it is enough just to stop and take a few pictures. There is a lovely little cafe where you can get a drink or snack. It is well worth the stop if you are in the Ubud area as it is a great viewing point.
well made terraces. we just passed by this area for photo op. this was on the way to kintamani for view of Mt. Batur and Lake Batur

The Best Rice Terraces - a must see, Ubud. The step farming - the 100 shades of green in front of your eyes - the amazing horizon of paddy fields and coconut grooves - yes this is a must see if you are traveling to Ubud.

Very Nice in Early Morning.. WE hired a taxi to take us to these rice fields just before sunrise. As a photographer, typically the 'golden hour' is best for images; that point where the sun is almost up and the colors are very vivid. We were there in early February, and I had not researched where the sun would rise. And, unfortunately, it rose right over the terraces, a bright star aimed right at the camera. Dang. It would have been a much better shot if the sun was rising behind you as you look from the road to the rice fields.My suggestions for images - evenings, for good sunset and low light.However, the best part was that we were the ONLY ones there. Had the terraces all to ourselves. No tourists, no venders, no people at all. It was very peaceful. I really don't think the street shops open until about 9 or 10am, and then, from what I understand, they are very persistent. We would take this short 15 minute drive again, but only at sunset next time. Or, drive further on where there are many more rice fields.
A Slice of Balinese Traditional Way of Life. The rice terrace is giving away slowly to development. So, enjoy this incredible Balinese traditional scenery while you can.

Fabulous views but there are alternatives.. If you only have a few hours to explore the Ubud area the standard quick tourist stop at Tegalalang is well worth the visit but if you have more time and have hired a driver/guide who is usually very reasonably priced, then ask for alternatives. The rice terraces throughout Bali are extensive and there many viewing points, some with excellent semi-remote restaurants where you can view and dine at the same time while feeling a little adventurous. Even around the Tegalalang bus stop there are lovely restaurants off the main road.

Beautiful landscapes. This is just breathtaking scenery, but watch out for all the locals trying to sell you things. It has become such a tourist trap that you've barely gotten off your bike before kids are running up, trying to sell you post cards.

Prepare for some climbing!. The best views of these rice terraces are from the far side, which you can walk to, but it can be tricky. Not recommended for the elderly or disabled, to attempt the climb, or for anyone if it's raining.That said, you don't need to be fit to do it, and it's not that far, but some parts can be steep, narrow and slippery. The views are stunning, and it's well worth a visit. So green and vast! Great for panoramic photography.There are annoying hustlers along the way demanding "donations" (firstly, you don't demand a 'donation'). This isn't real and not necessary. Of course it's up to you, and some offer a free coconut juice in return which might be a welcome refreshment, but know you're being scammed. And there's not just one. There are multiple people asking for these donations along the route to the far side of the rice fields, and some really don't want to let you pass. Even if you say you already made a donation, they say "this is different" and one man even put his arms out to stop me passing until we'd given money. So be prepared. If you're feeling cornered, 10,000rp is more than enough to get them out of the way. Often these people leave once they've made enough easy cash for the day, so I expect there's less of them in the afternoon. Don't let that put you off though. You don't have to climb in the terraces if you don't want to. The view is spectacular from the roadside. And there's plenty of cafés, and souvenir shops there. You can sit and have a drink while admiring the view. Allow an hour or so if you want to explore the terraces. Sensible foot wear might be a good idea, but not necessary - I did it in flip flops. Take bottled water, a hat, and a good camera.

Beautiful. This was one of our last stops on a tour. Its a quick stop. It looked like there were some visitors that were visiting a home on the property. That would be the way to do this if possible. We viewed from the street and is worth the visit since it was on our tour route. May be better if we planned to eat at a restaurant and enjoy the view more.Overall good. Visited south Vietnam after this sight expecting we would see more like this. Not so, this one stood out as our favorite.

Not just rice terraces!. The extra trip past Ubud is worth it! The rice terraces are beautiful and have a guided tour to learn about them. The markets here surpass others in the area as they are mostly run by the artist themselves The prices are good and the quality is better..

Only if you haven't seen rice terraces before. If you've seen rice terraces before this is probably not worth it. It is a nice little place with a lovely view but it's basically just a tourist trap nearby to Ubud. It was soured by the constant stream of fees, firstly we got shaken down by a policeman (we had a guide for the day who stopped for them), then at the terraces there are two donations you need to make to just walk through. You can just make one donation (which is just after the bridge) and turn around before the second one. We did just that and with plenty of stops for photos it's about a 20 minute walk. Remember to bring an umbrella during the rainy season if you're caught out there.
Beautiful View. Very beautiful Rice Terrace. Simply stop for few minutes to take some photos in such an amazing place. Many people do the same. Many things to buy medals, key chains, photos etc.

Worth visiting. This place is a must see place. I enjoyed walking there while our tour guide from the hotel was explaining the process of growing the rice, the type of rice, the farmers routine, and the life in bali

This is the most beautiful rice terrace ever seen. A must visit spot...
This is the closest I've ever been to a rice terrace..
Amazing and refreshing view... What a treat to eyes... Sipping coffee at the site and cool breeze on my face... Ahaaa moment...
Large rice terrace. The time when we visited just sewed. The terrace with water reflecting the sunset, excellent! Not easy to get there.

Nothing special. Nice view is truly depending on season.It is nothing special if you visited paddy field before this.The only thing is it’s terraced. That’s all.One thing to take note i.e., apart from entrance fee, one needs to prepare small note/coin for donation. I don’t know whether it’s compulsory or not. Our tour guide just asked us to donate 5000Rp at each donation points (only two points).Restaurant and souvenirs are just outside the entrance of this place.Enjoy.

Beautiful view and relaxing... A trip to the rice terrace is a must whilst in Bali. Seen various rice fields in my life but not one like this. Make sure you carry your camera as it has stunning views. Have lunch or a drink at the cafes that face the terrace and enjoy!!
Beautiful. worth a visit to see and take pictures. Very beautiful. Won't take you long and should be done on the way somewhere
Lovely place - but hard to find. Its a nice place, fairly quiet of you go around sunset. The climb down is steep(ish) and worth it. Its a nice place to catch some quiet
Rice terraces next to the road .. Worth while going there , very nice terasses , not far from Ubud.Even the road to there is full of woodcarving shops .

Quite nice. Firstly - the location of this place is not where the trip advisor map says it is.Obviously our fault for not double checking, but we rode a motorbike south east of ubud down to the location marked on the trip advisor map where we found next to nothing, besides a nice man who told us we'd gone to the wrong place.After finally getting to the rice terrace it was quite nice, a very direct ride from ubud. Although the rice had been harvested shortly before we arrived, but it was still pleasant and picturesque having lunch overlooking the paddies.

Beautiful terrace but not the best. We had a one-day trip from Kuta to Ubud. Our guide recommend us to go to the terrace. We followed his recommendation. It is a very beautiful terrace and you can take many good shots there. There are also some free-wifi cafes around the terrace where you can have some fresh coconut juice and take a break. But honestly I have seen many other terraces in China which are greater than this one.So my suggestion is: only go there if you have plenty of time to spend in Ubud. (In bad traffic it might take more than 2 hours to go there and come back to Ubud center) Otherwise the local shops and markets are more worth going.
Interesting. The experience is very touristy but still worthwhile. Be prepared to eat at one of the cafes in order to absorb the experience.

Worth the walk down. Probably about 30mins from Ubud. It's an impressive rice field and much cheaper to visit than the others in China and elsewhere in Asia.From the top there are steps leading down, which are pretty central in relation to the rice field. At the bottom there is a bridge and we paid a small charge (a dollar I think), which was well worth it. We were then free to wander about the fields and take a few photos, and a few of our friends took photos of us from the top.Most people were just jumping out of their tour buses for 2mins but it's worth spending 30mins or so on the actual fields.

Green. Raining while visiting this place. Eyes opening for me because I've not seen such thing in my country. It just simply a view. If you are not interested in this you may just skip it and go some where else.
Great view but many shop. one of the tourist attractions in Ubud, approximately 20 minutes from the town of Ubud. very beautiful place but crowded and many shop

Scenic location. One of the beautiful sights in Bali.. Scenic location. One of the beautiful sights in Bali.- Magnificent view of the terraced paddy fields from the roadside- Café and eateries overlooking the scenic view and great for chilling out- Souvenirs shops selling Bali trinkets (bargaining recommended)- For the adventurous, exploring the rice paddy is available for a nominal 'entrance fee'- Trek may be challenging for some. Proper footwear recommended- Have fun! You won’t regret it

Liked it. We had lunch and dinner whenever we are around. it's near where we stayed in Ubud and they cook good meals and reasonable price. The waitresses are attentive, a few speak good English but most don't. View was good so was the atmosphere. Liked it.

Lovely scenery. A must see if you are in the area. I had breakfast at a small cafe directly opposite the terrace with an excellent view. From Ubud it takes you ca. 25-30 minutes to get there with scooter or car. I think it´s worth the trip.
Nice view worth for a stop. Rice terraces do have an awesome view. If you are travelling via Ubud, this place is worth stopping for a photograph.

Beautiful view. Tegalalang Rice Terrace is a beautiful place and you have a really amazing view over them. I would say they are one of the best Rice Terraces. We were there when no shops or cafès had open, so it was quieter than usual i guess. You don´t need much time there, 10-15 mins are enough. I would recommend to rent a bike and drive by yourself.

rice field... Well.. yes, it's rice field on the hills, yes it's special and pretty.. maybe it's fun for people never seen the rice fields..it's not that amazing to me for this place.. i was disappointed by the small section and another small section of rice fields.. I wish I could see something like an acre and acer rice field that kind of view, but not this place.. thanks to those hard working farmers that the tourist can see the view..
beautiful. the rice terraces are very scenic and photographic. Worth a look, green, different stages of growth. Some field had workers with hats bending in the rice, beautiful !!

Stunning and is an absolute must despite the overcrowding. It goes without saying: you simply have to visit these rice fields. Yes, the place is rather touristy but what can one expect on a small island whose poplulation is 90% tourists anyway? The veiws are absolutely stunning, and it is one of those occasions when one needs a good panoramic camera to capture at least a glimps of the views as most of the photos simply can't do this place any justice. It is still very tranquil and you don't see/feel the hords of tourists there at all: the place is so vast that all these people simply dilute and disappear. Have stroll through the fields, enjoy the breathtaking views that have no time-stamp attached to them: they looked exactly the same a hundred, five hundred years ago and even earlier than that. The place looks like an astonishing formal English garden rather than an agricultural facility, especially as all the labour there is still manual owing to the very intricate and complex relief of the landscape with valleys, hills, and even mountains, small brooks, rivers, an occasional flower oasis, and volcanos at the background. The place is easily accessible from the road, and even before you pay a nominal fee to drive into it and park, you can and should enjoy the breathtaking panorama of the place from the top of the hills that embrase the place.There is a cafe, lavatory facilities, some souvenir shops, and a small bar there, so you can enjoy a light meal or a drink while you are there. The place is mostly disabled-friendly, and you won't have too many problems with a buggy or a wheelchair there though you won't be able to have a long stroll over the fields as they have to accessed via steep but very short staircases and the paths through the fields are proper narrow footpaths and field tracks. Tranquility, natural beauty, and serenity of this place has to be experienced personally as words fail to describe it adequately. It is one of the most stunning sights of Bali.

Amazing but very touristic. Beautiful views on the rice terraces, don't forget you camera. We where lucky to be there early around 10 am and it was not crowded. But I can imagine that later on the day and even more in the " high" season it will be very busy
Beautiful views. We pass by on our way back to Ubud, had a coffee, took a few pictures and it was very nice.There are souvenir and batik shops and good coffee places with beautiful views.
Breathtaking. We loved this experience. I wish we were able to actually go down to the rice paddies-but we could not find a way down (it does exist:)
Nice views. Nice views, you spend little time watching the rice fields in Ubud. There is guide tours in the hotels, but you can also go by car and watch for a little time this nice landscapes.

Amazing. The rice paddies were not green when we visited like many of the images we had seen but even at this quite bare stage of rice production the Tegalalang Rice Terrace is a marvel of human endeavour and natural beauty. There are a lot of small shops around to buy souvenirs if you wish and it is quite crowded with tourists. There are several vantage spots in among the shops. Very well worth a visit and you can walk along tracks if you have the energy and appropriate footwear.
Stunning terraces. Great place to visit - also possible to have a trek through the terraces. Sometimes very busy with bus loads of visitors.

Real people. We walked this each day- it is possible to get a scooter taxi to take you one way (not wide enough for cars). A chance to see the locals at work tending their fields. Also come across little cafés, artists at work, gold and silver merchants, home stays and lovely scenery. Reasonably easy to traverse although can get muddy after the rains. Take your water bottle.

Touristy but Worth a visit. Visited many smaller rice terrace in the past, but this one is nicest. I was lucky that I wasn't asked to pay any admission fee/donations nor hassled by vendor as some reviewers described. It rained a lot in the morning, so the pass down/up to paddy was slippery and muddy. So didn't go all the way down but had a coffee at one of the cafe and enjoyed the view instead.If I visit there again I would allow enough time and wear sturdy shoes so I can walk right around the beautiful terrace. Having a relaxing drink/snack at the one of the thatched roof cafe is good idea also.

A great excursion. Nice terrain no matter seeing from near or afar.Make sure to make the effort to walk the paddy field for up-closed experience. However, be warned that walking back up the steps could be tedious especially for those unfit yet it ain't that challenging if compared to trekking a volcano mountain.

Beautiful and Colorful.. We were going to see a volcano and did not expect to see the terraces. We took a break and our driver pointed it out to us. It was gorgeous. We ended up staying there longer and having some snacks. There were a lot of small shops around to buy some souvenirs from.

Lovely rice terraces but very touristy.... You have to pay on the side of the road to enter Tegal Lalang area but then there is an excellent view of the terraces. There is a lot of hassling by locals to buy goods.

Great experience. Those field are well maintain if you are there in the right season. It is a walk to go down and you have people who are asking for money in every corner of the field. Have some some money for donations ready.

Beautiful scenery . It's an amazing view. Not to be missed.
The only thing we didn't like we're the shops spoiling the overall mood and turning it into a commercial/ touristic area.

A Picturesque Panorama of Terraced Rice fields. My wife and I asked our Private Driver to take us on a tour stopping along the way at the Tegalalang Rice Terrace. The price of admission was 5000 each. We only spent 30 mins there, walking along the main road, stopping at each vantage point to see which offered the best view. I'm sure you could spend a few hours there, however as this was just a stop along our bigger tour, so after 30 mins, we had seen enough. It's definitely a great photo opportunity, and if you are interested in Lewak Coffee then there is plenty on offer. Worth a quick look, if nothing else.
beautiful view ... great experience. Must visit if you have never been to a rice terrace .. fascinating to walk along the terrace across levels
Beautiful rice terraces!. We took our motorbikes and drove here- easy to find and nice drive! Great to stop, walk around, have a coffee and enjoy the scenery. Also, nice wood shops around here!

A must see on your trip to Bali!. The view was breath-taking from the top! Such a beautiful thing to see!As mentioned below, there are numerous stalls hounding you to buy things, but once you enter and start climbing there is a sense of freedom.Just note, have some loose change on you as every little bit of climb there are little huts where you need to donate money. Also, we recommend wearing good walking/climbing shoes if you are making the trek to the top!

Timing is everything.... The views at Tegallalang are definitely beautiful, but it's best to see it when the rice is planted one week before. At that point, the paddies have that beautiful reflection on each level of the terrace. However, if you go when the rice is about to be harvested or has just been harvested, it just looks like long grass or mud. It's still a sight to see, but I wasn't in as much awe as people had said I would. I have heard that the much less visited Jatiluwih terraces are better, but they are a bit further away.Also, even if you just go take a look at the terraces from the road, some guy will come around and require that you pay.

Amazing view. Despite of all the locals trying to sell you useless stuff it is still worth those 15 min ride from Ubud. We arrived quite late, arround 6pm , and there might have been maxiamly some other 10 tourists so it didnt even felt that touristy. there is no fee, but there was an old lady collecting "donations". we gave her 5K because we didnt have change, she gave us a bad look and uttered sth about giving at least 10K but she didn't do anything when we went on.

Beautiful views. A bit touristy but still an easily accessible view of the beautiful rice terraces. I took my 88year old mum in 2013. The driver parks on the main road and there are lots of vantage points to be able to take pics.
Just it?!. The place was so crowded with locals. It wasn't really a friendly place to visit unless you came with a tour guide. Also, no activity was held there. Too much shops around.

Shame about all the tourist stuff right next to it. Great rice terraces and you will get some good shots here. Lots of shops and restaurant's selling the usual Bali stuff. Good to visit, can get busy once the buses of tourists start to roll up. Lots of steps to walk up and down to get some good photos so wear sensible shoes! Shame about everyone trying to make a dollar right net to it.
Impressive!!!. Just like the picture we saw in magazine the Rice Terrace is an impressive scene. We walk around and talked to our guide who told us some history about the place......very interesting
good to see. I am happy to visit this area because it has really different landscape. It is also good for taking good landscape photo. Go there with your suitable shoes and walk around

Good fun!. A nice long ride out of Ubud, takes abt 30-45 mins to reach. beautiful rice terraces. Please wear good walking shoes if you want to walk around the terraces. Lovely restaurants to sit and watch life go by

Great view and nice spot for pictures. I have been during a sunny day which helps to walk around the terrace fields. These are really beautiful and with calm you can spend 1 hour walking around and taking plenty of pictures.The annoyance, was you have few places that people are asking money for offer on the field (I counted 3) which maybe is fair to give but felt they were only interests on money. A dollar at each stop or less (10000 rupee) at the end is kind of acceptable but not sure it goes on the right hands.Definitely worth a visit, better early in the morning.

Nice view ! Stopped for photo. Stopped here for photo. Spend 15 mins. Didn't take the effort to walk down. Scenic view and a must go when you are in Ubud.Actually just like any other paddy field in Bali (abundant in Ubud), Tegalalang stands out from crowds because the paddy fields are stacked up in steeper slope. Thus, easier to get stunning photo. If the paddy field at Tegalalang is harvested, it is not difficult to find another one (less slope) in green or yellow. Paddy field in Bali are cultivated in different stages.
So Amaaaaazing . So recommended for nature seekers..Views are magnificent and so lovely..So colourful and makes you feel so excited

Mixed views about visiting here. I had read the reviews on Trip Advisor about the crowds at Tegalalang so decided to go early in the morning. There were less visitors at this time but still hoards of stalls trying to sell you sarongs etc and traffic. I don't think there would ever be a truly peaceful time here. The terraces themselves were interesting to see but it's not a very big area so feels a little contrived. Perhaps one of the other rice terrace areas in Bali would be more authentic and quieter?
Beautiful rice filed. The nature views of the rice field. It was very different from our city view. It gave me a peaceful surrounding. I enjoyed it very much. Wish I could stay there.
Rice Field. really love the village area with the tour in the morning , you could how the villagers live in the area with their friendly and outspoken tips
Worth a visit. We reached here in the evening and the setting sun along with the rice fields was an excellent view.

Go for the view & a quick lunch . If you are wanting to see the terrace I would suggest taking a taxi, only about 15 minutes fromCentral Ubud (should cost about 15-20$) walking around for a bit take some pictures and have lunch at one of the cafés facing the fields. Not much else to do there, if the rice isn't being planted it's a little bare once it's all picked but still nice to see it. I wouldn't spend more than an hour there. Have your driver wait for you.

In Awe of the Rice Terrace. THis place was Amazing view was Spectacular it is exactly what i had envisioned envisioned in my mind since i was a child of what Malasia Should look like!!  There were Fantastic local Market stalls and lovely food and coffee over looking the rice Terrace one note was remember to take enough cash with you as there was only 1 ATM at his location and it failed to wrok for us Happy Travels

Not so bad.... First ever visit and amazed at the sight of terraced Paddy Fields, happily sat for a while had a coffee bemused at the efforts of an old lady trying to convince me to pay to have my picture taken with her. Was all in all quite happy, this was all spoilt a few days later when exploring the northern part of Bali to come across a huge landscape of paddy fields that just astounded me thinking only a couple of days earlier I had seen the real thing. Take a look if you are in Ubud its only a short drive, but you need to travel for a good couple of hours further north to see the real thing and be really amazed...
worth seeing. Take the trip to have a look. Very beautiful. Be sure to include it with other sight seeing activities.

Pretty good. If you haven't seen rice terraces before then it would be pretty good. There are a lot of hawkers and shops around, and it smells pretty bad around the area, but pretty nice views, you can walk around the terraces, but be prepared to pay some "donations" to cross the "bridges". If you want to see impressive terraces try Batad in the Philippines.

Depressing. A trip to these rice paddies it is like a visit to the zoo: nature in a cage. The rice terraces are truly stunning but the locals managed to surround the paddies with cafe and restaurants destroying the poetry and romanticism of the place. When I was there there was also a moron flying a drone overhead.Unfortunately the tourist traps built around the top tourist attractions is a problem that plague Bali. Sadly The island has lost a lot of its charms ....

Slippery Trails in the Rain. You could miss the entrance to this as the parking lot and ticket sales booth are across the street from where you hike into the rice terrace. We would have been lost without our driver/guide. It is gorgeous to behold, but with the rain that had fallen and my flip-flops, I was worried about falling and did not venture up the sloping fields. Worth a visit, 45 minutes is more that enough time. If I had known, I would have planned to have lunch there admiring the view.
picturesque and memorable. Stop here and enjoy the gorgeous view while having a nice lunch. Gado gado is perfect and simple. curry, nasi, etc. all very good but it's really the view that impresses.

great place to have lunch. the area as such is very small and doesnt warrant a day trip but most tour operators will get you here as part of the day trip. Make sure you arrive at lunch time so you can eat at one of the many open air cafes made over-looking the terraces.
Green place. I'm glad too have seen it, but it's nothing you have to do. Take a cab there for some fotos. Nothing more to do there.

Worth the climb down. Make sure you walk down & just not take photos from the road.
We walked as far as possible and crossed a bamboo bridge with a 30foot drop. Great photos
Eat pray love. Beautiful place, something definitely worth seeing whilst in Bali. 💗 It's only 15 min drive from Ubud, we went 8 o'clock in the morning and there was no people. Highly recommend.
Nice Rice Terrace especially sunset & sunrise. Cooling and nice scenery. Road are winding, limited guesthouse. Not much to offer at night. Meals are from the Guesthouse only.

Stunning step terraces but they charge you at every chance. Must see. 5000rupiah (AUD$5) per adult to park in the area, then if you walk down to the actual rice fields you have to pay another unspecified 'donation'. Photo taking from top is free. Steps down are steep and, once down, there is no paved path - it was quite muddy and slippery when I went because it had poured in the morning.

Nice drive - but very crowded. We arrived late morning, and it was quite busy. Hardly could get a picture without any people in it. Recommend to visit early in the morning. Its actually quite a small bit of land - its not a vast expansive field of terraces - but its a decent day out. Quite close to the city - as opposed to the big fields which are about 2 hours away from the centre. We didnt have much time - so we opted for this one. If you have more time - visit the bigger rice paddies.

Worth a look but get there early. Ok, so you've seen it in the movie, then it is worthwhile to have a look at these gorgeous terraces. But get there early in the day while there is some semblance of calm...later on it's hectic with tour buses and tourists all eager to 'get that quintessential shot'.

Good exercise up the rice terrace. We went super early in the morning around 8:30am. No traffic jam, and it's the best time to catch the beauty of the rice terrace with the morning sun shinning over the golden field.A good trek too, but plenty of tourist trap asking for donations etc.
Too Much. Well that´s the main problem of Bali ...Too much of everything ...Too much trafic , too much tourist and everything who go with it ! the Tagalalang rice Terrace is the perfect exemple ...

Gorgeous. It's a little tricky trying to find the staircase the leads to the rice paddy, but when you do find it, you basically have access to walking all over the rice fields and the entrance is free. There are people scatterred throughout the fields begging for money but that did not ruin our experience. The heat and humidity was hard to tolerate and I only lasted about 30 minutes before I wanted to go to a warung and get a cold drink. The fields are gorgeous. Don't forget to spray your insect repellent before going!

If you going to Ubud even with the crowds its worth a picture. its a MEGA tourist trap but I still wanted to see it Taking advice of our drive, going in an out just for a photo, and "rewarding" the store with the location we used with a Bintang or Ice Cream purchase was worth for the view if you dont have time to head into the more agricultural areas of the island

Amazing view !. We went there this morning and we were so stocked about the Rice terrace. The architecture is perfect. Little ways to go inside. We didn't go because it was too muddy.An incontournable attraction to do in ubud

Scenic Greens ! ( break from blue seas). If you love greens this is Highly recommended. Among many rice terrace of Ubud this place seems well maintained. Tegalalang Rice Terrace will sure add some green essence to your stay in Exotic Bali Island. Also highly recommended to have lunch enjoying the beautiful greenery. Very scenic place. Don`t forget to have sunblock cream , shades n hat otherwise you will burnt coal. Also some local handy craft shops lay aside the road dt you can buy some souvenirs. So if you want a break from beautiful marine blue try some Rice Terrace.

Bali as one expects it. What a beautiful view over these amazing terasses. We enjoyed our stay there very much. Sitting in one of the places and sip a coconut while overlooking the workers on the different levels cutting the rice, others preparing for the next planting, such as spinach. Its fantastic how these structures are just held by grass that surrounds each terrasse.A must see in Bali

Nice scenery but don't expect too much and enjoy a cup of coffee or you can be part of scenery by walking into it. We went there a couple of times, it's famous for its scenery, as said don't expect too much. It's a tourist spot, there are many cafe, you can sit back and have a cup of Balinese coffee while enjoying scenery. Or you can walk into the padi field and be part of the scenery:)
Beautiful rice terrace. The view is beautiful ...where the rice terrace flows down the valleyJust don't like the vendors trying to push their items in your face and parking is a bit difficult..

Wonderful rice terraces a bit damaged by excessive concrete constuction buildings and works along the road. Victim of their success, the rice terraces of Tegalalang (north of Ubud) remains however beautiful.Too many concrete terrasses and buildings along the road have turn the place into something far less nice than ten years ago...Parking easy along the main road and well organised.
Beautifull terraces. if you intend to stay many days in Bali you will see beautifull rice terraces everywhere but don't miss Tegalalang Rice Terrace that is located very close to Ubud. It's awesome!

A nice photo opportunity. If you travel in midday, it gets really hot and you might not want to walk down and across the rice terraces. But it's a nice picturesque spot if you want to see how rice is grown.

go in the morning. Best tip I can give you is go in the morning, before it gets insanely busy later in the day. I really enjoyed hiking up/around and between the rice paddies while I still had them to myself. I also found it greatly beneficial to go with a tour guide as he assisted my friends and I in bypassing the locals demanding "donations." It is fascinating to learn about the rice planting/harvesting and how the local farmers work together to irrigate their fields. The view is positively stunning. Be warned, the footpath can be steep, narrow, and even slippery so be sure to wear sturdy shoes and be careful if you are a klutz like me.

Beautiful. We should have spent more time here. We were on a day long trip and we didn't spend too much time here. The view of the rice terrace was just so beautiful. As we went down into the rice terrace the view unraveled and we were blown away by the colors. We stopped from going down to the ground level, but we should have. The small, cozy tea houses there seemed very tempting, and it would have calming to sip a cup of coffee / tea while looking at this beautiful view. Definitely must do if you are visiting Bali / Ubud.
worth the trip up. Although theres not a lot to do its a great photo opportunity. If given the chance id go up again. Lovely view, breathtaking view and free!
Lovely view. Exactly what they show on tour book pictures. But these a few and far in between. It can get pretty crowded because it's free. However, do expect to be hounded by street peddlers.
overwelming view. many tourists in this area, but it is a must to see it. take the car trip with wayan, he tells you something about rice terraces

Rice view. Worth a photo or two.A beautiful view.Green valley with large rice paddies.Touristy stop but it is a beautiful area with many opportunities to see the production of rice and how the local people live

Beautiful. If you have never seen terraced rice fields then go. If you have seen them a plenty then it is not a must. After seeing large rice fields in Nepal that are completely unspoiled (no tourist) this is not as impressive.

Poetry in Motion - Great Experience. We went to rice Terahs and we ended up having the best afternoon at the cafe, the owners was just the best - offering to take pics with and for us. We also had great samosas and chicken fried rice.Just a lovely afternoon and definitely worth a visit

Just about okay!. Terrace cultivation is common across Bali, especially Ubud. If you are visiting Kintamani or around the area - sure, go in and have a look. If not, there is no reason to drive all just to have a view of rice fields. That said, I didn't have a chance to climb down the narrow lane and visit up close. I am not sure if this is the norm - but we were charged an entry fee. Not much, but I didn't think it is worth a paid visit.

Amazing views. We arrived late in the day so they did not charge us for looking out over the terraces.
It was absolutely amazing that they have created these paddy fields in these terraces, Well worth a visit
Landscaped poetry. Make sure you visit on a rain free day, find the narrow winding road that will take you to the fields and not just view them from the top.

Top views. Yes I must say when I was in Bali in September I went there twice, Top views ,It can get a little busy on the road there in front were the shops are , But there is police there controlling things, Also bought some timber goods, post cards, Sat down had a drink and took in the views.
Spectacular. I can only say you must go there in person to really appreciate the view, especially having a beer at the restaurant.
Tegalalang Rice Terrace. Visited the Tegalalang Rice terrace with my family last week and it's as beautiful as the post cards show. Being there in person even more special

Green Rice Paddies!. We stopped here after visiting Kintamani and it was packed with tourists! Seems as if we were seeing the same people from all the other tourist stops. It was great to see the rice paddies as they were lush and vibrant green. It was very scenic and picturesque! We stopped here for a break and enjoyed a drink in one of the cafes that line the rice paddies. Glad we visited!

Lovely place. Lovely people. Lovely culture.. We saw the rice terraces while on our day trip around Bali with ida. The local markets were better here than other touristy places. The view is surreal. A must do.

Best Rice Paddy Excursion. Dewa my driver took me here as a must-see. I trusted him and was right in doing so (each and every time)! I loved the local vendors and farmers I encountered along the way and bought some wood and coconut carvings (that I was not expecting to purchase) just because the people were so darn friendly! The rice paddy walk was a great photo op and the farmers didn't mind posing with their equipment for some Rs. They are catching on! It was worth it..these smiling farmer photos are my favorite souvenirs!
Geography trip. Scenic place. Nothing much there.. Drop and click a few shots.. Approximately about 15mins is enough. Toilet realatively clean.
Beautiful site. I have seen rice paddies round the world and love them all. The building of them is so clever and visually they are so green and beautiful

The rice terraces were impressive but I'd expected more.. Like: these were impressive feats of irrigation and deserving of marvel.Dislikes: - Being charged for doing no more than stopping by the road and having a look at the fields. I actually don't mind paying had there been some facilities to perhaps shelter an inform me of the place.- Visiting Tegalalang appears to be inextricably tied to visiting nearby coffee plantations (where civets are kept in cages) whether or not we liked it.

A great ride up the Mountain. As a 40+ solo female traveller I headed off on my rented scooter with my map to the terraces at the top of the mountain. It did not disappoint. Fantastic photo opportunity and the shopping for wooden homewares on either side of the road all the way up and down is incredible, so cheap and gorgeous stuff. Could definitely have done it multiple times. Recommend!

Beautiful rice paddy, wear tennis shoes!. We visited Tegalalang when our drive recommended it. Not really knowing what to expect we were blown away when we saw how beautiful it was! I never knew rice could be so pretty! We chose to walk all the way down and through the rice paddies. It was great walking around. We arent really sure if we were supposed to walk down and around as far as we did, but no one stopped us so away we went! Definitely recommend for great photo ops in Ubud!
A Good View. This was worth the stop. The rice terrace is interesting in it's design. The little bitty shops are run by sellers who are not too pushy. That in itself was refreshing.

Good but not the best. This place seems to have acquired a great name for itself hence the (small) entrance fee and the hordes of shops and cafes to supply the tourists at peak times. When I visited luckily there were only a handful there but the rice was had a beautiful green sheen and was great for photos. It is good but not brilliant for photos.
