Along the road a few kilometres there are equally good stepped paddies with no distractions - get a local guide. Travelling by motorbike is great as you can see the views as you travel along
nice the most beautiful and with steps.. nice rice field with steps down, and it also the season for planting of rice... with good driver.. after that we when to ubud for babi guling lunch.

Beautiful greens. Take a walk through beautiful rice terraces like you've never done before. Easily done with a river at the bottom and lots of paths to follow. Quite the postcard picture, and you were there.

Looks nice but overcrowded. If you have no problem with horde of tourist camped on a tiny perimeter, than you will find this beautiful. Similar terraces and rice fields can be seen when walking just a few hundred meters further or by roaming on the road around.

How Beautiful are These Rice Terraces Depends on the Time You Visit.. I have seen these fields a number of times, in different parts of Indonesia. Some I saw in Java are more steep and treacherous and large scale, but this is still a really pretty place to appreciate how the irrigation system works. I was hoping to see the terraces during the rice planting time when water would be flooded into the fields and create beautiful pools od water. That's the time when they are most photogenic. Unfortunately I was in Ubud in November and the weather had been quite dry and the rice had matured. I was still lucky because I arrived there around 3 to 4PM, and the sun had just started to cast beautiful shadows on the terraces. And everywhere looked so green and fresh. So when you go visit, pick the best time of day and I guarantee you would be rewarded with many gorgeous photos. Also the area is very touristy as many reviewers suggest.

Sustainable ancient rice paddy fields. The terraces of rice fields that have been cultivated for over 1,000 years are simply one of the most sustainable organic agriculture system around. It is spectacular to look at especially when the rice grains have turned yellow about to be harvested. Plenty of cafes around where you can enjoy a cuppa and taking in the amazing sight. Short walks along the terraces are also possible and well worth a try. It is probably the reason why Indonesia can sustain such a massive population of people despite the corruption and lack of governmental support for the community.

Lovely view!. Unfortunately it was raining when we went there, but I would have loved to walk through the rice terrace. this is probably the only rice terrace where there is defined walking path for visitors and the view is lovely here.

Beautiful close up view from top of the rice terrace. It rained when we reached the place but nonetheless it didn't stop us from admiring the beauty of it. We only stopped for few mins to take some pics and left due to the rain. The view is somehow different fr Jatiluwih although not less beautiful. Jatiluwih spans a bigger area which you can really see much further... Wished we had the weather n time to walk around...

Magnificent. My second visit to these amazing rice fields. The view is breathtaking and well worth coming to see. The first time I came, I was bothered by the sellers but this time they were very quiet which made the trip much more enjoyable.I thoroughly enjoyed the very elderly gentleman with his pole and baskets of rice, complete with 'coolie' hat who posed to have his picture taken with everyone...he smiled and said cheese and then put his hand out to be paid for the privilege. My husband offered him a note and he responded by giving it back and taking one half the value. He was delightful.Like most places of interest, there was a fee to pay to be able to view the terraces but it was only about the value of $1...well worth the price.

Amazing sight. this was my second visit here and I was impressed by the sight of these terraces as I was during my first visit. Nice shops and cafes here but the hawkers are very persistent and annoying.

Excellent Views Of Terrace Rice Fields. Pro :1) Spectacular view of the terrace rice fields.2) We have lunch at the restaurant at the north end of the village. The food was very good and price reasonable. It has 2 levels and spectacular views.3) On the main road from Ubud to Penelokan.Con :1) There is an entrance fee (not sure of the fee). We did not pay because the entrance post was empty.2) Parking may be a problem because the road is narrow. May have to park just outside of the village and walk in.
Scenic. Awesome spot for a great picture. Very serene and peaceful. Magnificent view. Everyone so friendly & kind.

Beautiful views but be prepared for people to demand donations from you at various points!. As we had previously read, you have to pay 5,000 rupiah per person when entering via car - that was fine and we of course paid. We then got to the rice paddies and left our driver so we could walk around for a while. You initially come to a small bamboo bridge which you then have to make a donation when you get to the other side, that's another 5,000 rupiah. Again, we were fine with this. You will see various huts dotted around the rice fields - please be prepared that the people here will demand more donations to allow you to pass. Unfortunately we were met by a very angry man who ended up spitting in our direction when we decided to just walk back on ourselves rather than 'pass' through, with the fear we would just have to pay more! The views are stunning and we were lucky it was quiet and not many tourists but just be wary.

what greeting cards of made from. Beautiful terrace. Usually seen on Bali postcards. and there's one reason its a representation of Bali's beauty.Some nice restaurants as well as you admire the scenery. The ride is about twenty minutes from the main Ubud area. As you drive you pass lots of wood carving shops, plus.

Try to get there early and not late evening.. Most ridges and their valleys run in a north south direction. If you arrive after 4PM you won't get the best light to appreciate the beauty of this place. Try to get there in the morning (not too early) and wander around to get the best photos.

Stunning Scenery. We went on a day tour organised with an awesome driver from the Lokha Ubud Hotel - Made was his name and he comes highly recommended. The views were spectacular - stopped by a cafe for a banana milkshake and mi goreng viewside. Very scenic and friendly locals.

Great view... awesome photo opportunity. Really enjoyed the view, so much greenery. The terrace farming in Ubud is very good. We had to pay 5000 IDR per person. Had to walk down the steep way (no proper steps) and then up on every terrace. Not much of a hassle , can do it. Need to wear proper footwear.
Beautiful.... But, the touts here can bemadde ing. Go with a trusted driver who can get you to the best views with fewer people.
A fantastic View. Like the levels of rice paddies. An amazing view with multi-level of rice plantations. Worth half an hour of sight seeing with pictures taken.

Amazing scenery. If you like photography then you will love this place. The scenery is amazing. You can just spend a couple of hours wandering around and the stalls selling tourist trinkets are well presented and tidy. Make sure you take the walk down through the Terraces it is an easy walk and you do not have to be overly fit to do it. The view back up is as god as looking down.

Nice view but thats it. It is a very beautiful place. Looking great but thats it. Normally tourists can walk down into the rice field. But it just rained before i went there so the track was extremely slippery. Nobody went down. There are too many tourists there. Still a nice place though.

It's a postcard picture. This trip was one of my highlight in Bali the walk to the top. You pay 5000 rp to cross this little bamboo bridge over the stream at the bottom of the rice terrace is amazing!!! Half way up the terrace there is this great bamboo water feature that make a soothing clap noise when it's full you can hear over the walk. This is a must do when in Bali

Worth to go if you come from modern countries. We don't have rice terrace back in Singapore and this place is definitely worth going! Instagram worthy! There are whole stretch of shops here but be careful of rip offs!!
Good for photos. Good buys of carvings around here but you can see rice terraces elsewhere just as good . Can be congested .

Beautiful for photograph but ...,. After a taxi ride there have to pay to get some sort of tax when is just on a road side. Spoilt by all tourists and shops. Lovely views and makes a great photo but is disappointing.
really nice scene. beautiful green scenic place. going there in the early morning is probably best to take nice shots. somehow it does not look real as it is so perfect.

Impressive landscape. I´ve been around Canggu where there are still rice paddies but these were mind blowing. Sometimes it´s hard to believe you are actually visualizing this and it´s not a movie. The engineering is interesting and the green is radiant all over the place.
Really enjoyed walking in the terraces. Great landscape. Being able to walk in the terraces was really cool. This is a must see if your in the area.
Nice view. Great view where we dont get to see back home. Worth the drive to view the scenary while having the lunch. Very relaxing.

Stunning Landscape. I felt like I was walking in a scene from a calendar. This place was absolutely amazing. It's not the biggest terrace in Bali but it's proximity to Ubud makes it easy to get to. It's less than 30 minutes from Ubud and you can get a cab there, have him wait for you, and then drive you back for about $10 (negotiate price before you leae Ubud). Once there it costs 5,000Ru to go across the bamboo bridge and then another 5,000Ru to climb all the way to the top. For roughly $1 per person it's an incredible value and helps maintain the site for the local farmers to make it both a tourist attraction and a working rice paddy so make sure you don't cheap out, the memories (and photos) are worth it.

Clever Concept. The rice terraces are just that: Terraced small areas of rice. If you are looking, as we thought, to get out to actual rice fields, you will be disappointed. This is a series of lovely little cafes set on terraced landings looking over the terraced rice fields. You can have drinks, food, take off your shoes and relax. The service was great. You can, for a small fee, walk amongst the terraces if you wish too.Go for a look but stay for a bite.

Beautifull landscape. Barely reaches the site it is possible to have a general panoramic of the beautiful rice fields.Then if you have time, just go down and walk through the rice fields and enjoy.There are several restaurants near the fields.You must pay a little fee when arriving, but worth the visit.

Nice view. It is not a very big scale of land but the landscape is really nice. There are many resting places where you can have your meals there while looking at the paddy fields. You can also walk down to the paddy field and have a walk. A place not to be missed if you are in Bali.

If Visiting Bali This is a Must. We took a day tour with a private driver and went to the Tegalalang Rice Terrace as one of our stops and it was wonderful. If you've seen rice terraces in other countries perhaps you could skip this but we had not and it was the highlight of our trip.

Relaxing. I went there with friends, we went after lunch to enjoy afternoon coffee & just rest.It's so relaxing to sip coffee while enjoying the greenery in front of you. We shared pisang goreng (banana fritters), it was good. Price is relatively cheap. It's definitely not a fancy place, very humble instead but worth the visit.I recommend this place if you're in Ubud.

Traditional balinese landscape. If you are close to Ubud area you must have a look to this beatiful landscape and admire the green rice terraces. It's a perfect place where to admire the farming of the rice, although it has become just a tourist attraction, but inspite of it,it worht a visit.

Must See!!!. Gorgeous!!!
Must See!!
Don't miss it!!
This was one of my favourite things throughout the entire Island of Bali. It was simply stunning and I can't wait to come back and do it all again. The photos just don't do it justice - you have to see if with your own eyes to believe it.

Lovely. Loved seeing these terraces again. Heaps of people there tho and feel after visiting them in morning and in the evening that evening is the best time to get good photos. Just my thinking mind you
Do have a look if you're in Ubud. the rice terraces are beautiful and do pop by to have a look. if you have time, do take the walk down but be careful as it is quite steep with no proper paths.

Incredible culture. Loved the people, the food, villages, landscapes, bamboo forest, scenery and cultural performances.
Traffic was in insane! Not very conducive to walking (poor sidewalks and traffic required great caution).
Walk around. it is not so big as Jati Luwih rice field. It has bazaar selling souvenirs along the road. Can eat there.

Picturesque. Worth a visit on the way to the Monkey Forest, didn't walk down into it as ran out of time however would have liked to, stood at the top and viewed, need a whole day to sightsee around Ubud.
Great view, mediocre food. Great view especially if you take the front spot. The food is mediocre and overpriced. Nice experience though.

Green every where. When you think of Bali you think of beaches and rice terraces. That is what you see at the Tegalalang terraces. Established years ago, these terraces are still working fields today . Lovely, green and a photographers dream. You do need a car or a driver to get you there.

Beautiful surroundings. Great views that go on for miles! was able to explore the rice fields a bit although we did get hassled along the way for money from some locals. overall great place for breathtaking landscapes.
Beautiful View. Been here twice... 1st time here in 2010 with my family. 2nd time last April with my bf and the view still same beautiful and lovely <3.
Nice views. For 0.75€ of entry fee you can see the rice fields, getting closer if you wish. The landscape view is amazing.

Magnificent!. This place is truly magnificent.. Walking around the rice terraces is definitely one of the best ways to spend an afternoon in Bali. It is really pretty and relaxing.I wore flip-flops the first time I came here, and regret that decision. Some of the paths can be slippery, so make sure to wear sturdy, waterproof footwear. Also, I do not recommend bringing handbags for ladies since in some parts, it is quite hard to balance yourself.. so bring a backpack instead!Highly recommend this place especially for first-time visitors to Bali.
Great view. Beautiful view and nice place to eat lunch. Lots of shops for gifts. A must visit but if you don't want to walk around, you can probably stay for only 20 minutes
Stunning view. Beautiful landscape. Take the time to go through the terrace and have a close look at the irrigation . Have a coffee on the terrace, the view is breathtaking.

Nice view of the rice terraces. Great view of the rice terraces... It would be best to go in the morning or late noon when the sun is not as hot.Along the way of the viewing area lies a whole stretch of shops selling handicrafts and souvenirs! Price wise would be slightly cheaper then elsewhere

Stunning! . So picturesque. Hard to believe it is real. My tip go late afternoon or early morning. We went in the middle of the day and we were wet with sweat by the time we finished. Wear sturdy footwear that you don't mind getting dirty as both my husband and I got our feet bogged in the rice patties. Not fun to clean up. Also make sure you have low denomination notes on you to make a donation to access parts of the terraces.

Good Samaritans . We went here with my friends, was enjoying the view and trying to breathe in the beauty of the place when suddenly we were asked by a lady to give donation to pass so we gave her some money. Then we decided to go down and leave cause we're done taking pictures when her husband came and asked us to go up so we can enjoy and see the view from there. But then i losed balance and slipped, so my right foot was deep in the mud. The wife hurriedly came to my rescue and asked me to remove my rubber shoes so she could wash it. I asked her to let me go down first and sit down as i might slip again. I sat near their hut and she took my shoe and socks and washed it. The husband then got a leaf and asked me to put my feet on the leaf so it wont get dirty. He tried to wash my feet and arm with water ( dont know if its clean though) , and even offered me a fruit to eat. Was really grateful for both of them, thinking that really everything happens for a reason, i got to talk to them and asked them about their family,even took their picture. I really love moments wherein i can talk to the locals and just know about their story and background. But when i was about to leave and said thank you the lady then said "lady, Money" I was shocked that they were asking payment for the help they did. I really thought they did all that out of concern, but then again NOT. Or maybe they really needed the money
Picturesque. Such a beautiful rice terrace! It best for pictre taking and whats great about it is that your able to walk through the rice fields which gives tourists an added advantage :)

Could be better. You get charged to drive in a street, after that you are on your own. It is no worthy treatment of this unesco site! There isn't even a lookout place or a visitors centre! So where is the money going you get charged ??

rice terraces on a steep gradient. the Tegalalang rice terraces are famous, but the rice terraces on the way to the Besakih temple are prettier. the shops at Tegalalang are the usual tourist traps and the stuff they have is average

One of my favorite spots in Bali. The rice terrace here is breathtaking. I went here for lunch at Rice Field Cafe and was blown away by the natural beauty. I didn't venture out for a hike amongst the rice like other tourists since it was 900 degrees and noon but that looked like a nice activity for early morning hours.There were a few shops on the road here that looked interesting but I preferred to stare at the rice.
Simply stunning. A must do. Lots of photo opportunities. Sit in one of the cafes and take in the views for a pleasant hour or two.

Beautiful view. The view was incredibly beautiful, one of the best locations for viewing terraced rice fields. Views like this can be seen elsewhere in Bali, but it is worth going for one look, as the people and shops nearby are also worth a stop.

Must see. When you think of Bali you think of beautiful beaches, amazing cuisine, traditional costumes/dances and of course rice terraces.So many postcards have photos of amazingly beautiful, bright green rice terraces. If you what to witness their true beauty then you must stop at Tegalalang Rice Terraces; they are truly breathtaking.Please note there is a small "entrance" fee to the area and traffic can be quite full on. There are a lot of pushy sales people(just remember this is how they make money; so kindly say no thank you an move on)We did not stop for very long as we had two small children; but still worth the stop and we willvisit longer to explore next time.

Fantastic View, Crazy Traffic!. The view was amazing, but the traffic is really crowded !Along the road, it was little bit difficult to walk as cars and bikes are everywhere. But still,the view was amazed!

Very pretty, would love to have explored more. Sadly we were a bit rushed when we visited these terraces. They are very beautiful (some proper postcard shots up there)... I would have loved to be able to explore more, but I have my suspicions it would have been an exhausting walk - Its pretty steep!
Beautiful. Such a beautiful rice field! Try to get there before it starts to get dark, or your pics won't do the fields justice. Too pretty to miss.
Must-go. Beautiful rice fields absolutely not to miss. Take good shoes if you want to walk along the rice terraces!

Nice walk be careful not to slip :-). I really enjoyed this, walking up and down the very very green terraces. This is something you must see and do.Make sure you have a a couple of ten thousand notes with you as you will be asked to donate (i use the word donate loosely) once at the bottom and once at the top. Allegedly to help keep the fields in good condition. As soon as I put my money in the Jar the lady took it back out. For the sake of a couple of NZ$ it is well worth it.Oh yeah be careful not to slip, i got a boot full....Great lunch at Boni Bali afterwards with some great views, don't follow the crowds for lunch find this place, very close

Beautiful Views!. This is a must see if staying around the Ubud area. Just north of Ubud, it is a picturesque rice terrace, beautifully maintained and manicured to perfection. Definitely a tourist trap, and you would be hard pressed to find a time of day to visit when it's empty. Nonetheless a beautiful view and picture op.
Gorgeous. The view of these rice terraces is absolutely stunning. It's a touristy location, but it's definitely worth visiting.
Rice terrace. Beautiful scenery but we were lucky enough to visit when the rice was lush and green and looking stunning.

Priceless view. A must visit if you go to Bali. Stunning view, clean fresh air, crystal clear water. If you going around with a driver, ask him to recommend the best view among all rice terrace, they sure know where is the best. We took countless of photos and a panorama photo can sum up the whole feel of being there by itself.
Beautiful terraces rice field. Absolutely beautiful rice field terraces near Ubud Bali, Our driver took us to this attraction on our vacation. Best stuning view while

Absolutely stunning view!. The views are incredible; it almost feels as though you're in a postcard. We went right when the sun was at its highest point and walked in/up the fields, which probably wasn't the greatest idea as we became tired very quickly. It's probably best to go earlier in the morning. The surrounding restaurants provide a great space to relax, very cheap food and more amazing views. Definitely worth a visit!

Great view... Stopped by on my way to Kintamani.. My wife and I had a great time posing and taking shots of this scenic view.. You could spend sometime having a drink over there or shop for handicrafts. But please bargain well..

Gorgeous terraced rice fields... Not so gorgeous hawkers & tourists. Great place for some good photo ops of the terraced rice fields. This is the kind of place you would want to spend some time taking in the views but you cannot do so as the place is swarming with tourists and hawkers and this breaks the peace and tranquility of the place. Perhaps it's best you get here early in the morning when it's not so crowded and you have the place to yourself. Thumbs up to the view though.

Quick day tour from rice terraces up to the mountain. Great view, great rice meal, but was misty (rain) and humid. We didn't spend long here. We drove through the area and had our lunch, then took photos.

Very Pretty. We had a private driver who I thought was going to do exactly what we wanted! There was an agenda though and we just pulled up on the side of the road and could walk out for the best pictures. We certainly didn't see the vistas of the tour guides, but they were great to see. It was late afternoon when we got here, so suspect we missed the crowds, but to be fair I don't think we saw the best of them.

Rural insights. This was a fascinating insight into the rural life of the Balinese rice farmers. We walked the terraces which proved quite a challenge for my arthritic eft and legs. You need a reasonable degree of fitness to actually negotiate the ups and downs of the terrain and my legs were sore for god next two days.In spite of this, it was worth the experience.

Not So Charming. The huge"Not For Sale" sign right over the middle of the terraces made the beautiful scenery lose its charm. There were tons of shops along the street too, so we were getting harassed every second by a vendor. I was really disappointed. We only stayed 15 min before we had had enough.
Terraced Rice Fields. It was a very pleasant view. The paths through the fields were enjoyable. We did not expect it to be so very touristy as it was.

Good news, bad news. This is a spot of incredible beauty, but there is a catch. Because of the huge growth of the tourism industry in Bali, this magical spot can become hugely overcrowded. Perhaps a way to beat this is to stop at one of the eating spots overlooking the terraces and take some time to enjoy the moment.

The classic rice paddie view you've been waiting for.. Visited here as part of a private day tour with Bali Sun Tours (reviewed seperately).It's about an hours drive from Kuta/legian/seminyak area depending on traffic so make a trip of it! There's so many things to see around Ubud.Your driver will just park on the side of the road along many MANY tourist shops with hawkers and wait for you there. From there find a vantage point and take it all in. After the photos have been taken just look for stairs to enter the paddies through one of the cafes. Be aware that it can be deceptive because your doing the easy (downhill) first but remember you'll have to walk back up at the end so take plenty of water, a hat and sunscreen. You will need to pay a donation down in the paddies if you want to walk around so take small notes with you. We put 50k IDR in (5USD). The money allegedly goes towards maintaining the walkways and paths for tourists. There are some really nice spots through the paddies and it was worth the effort to walk though. Many reviewers have complained about the area being too touristy and a tourist trap but what do they expect? Nowadays its a challenge to find anywhere in the world thats amazing AND unspoilt. Sometimes you just have to step back onto the tourist trail and enjoy attractions you cannot find at home. Expect to spend around an hour there if you want to walk through the paddies. A bit longer if you want to have lunch (some nice places overlooking the paddies). Or less of you just want a photo and a look from the top.Enjoy!
Beautiful green fields. Is a scenic place....with 2 tones green but the area is not very big. You need to pay a small entrance fee to view the paddy fields.

Breathtaking View. The green colour of the rice growing on the terraces almost blinds you. Wear good sturdy trainers if you plan on exploring further down the terraces. Fascinating to see how they are still being used for rice growing to this day. It is very hard work and yet elderly people could be seen tending the nursery shoots. Very hard on your back I would imagine.
Beautiful. Close to Ubud, we rented motorbikes and got there in 25 minutes quit easily. It's great to walk around, and have a meal overlooking the terraces!

lovely. when you start the sight seeing it comes on the road, you simply walk down a little to the same and can have a long view from the small walk resting place and some huts built along the ridge. some small fee has to paid at the road side toll gate and the view is perfect and better you have time can walk down to the field for much better pictures and close view...

Great attraction!. The Tegalalang rice terrace is a popular attraction that has unique and beautiful scenery, and it’s certainly a great place for taking photos. By just taking a quick work around the rice field, you really can get that feeling of the traditions and the Balinese culture. And make sure to wear walking shoes because there are a lot of up and down elevations in the rice field.

Absolutely Stunning. One of the most beautiful things we saw in Bali was the rice terraces here. If you love nature and beautiful landscapes than stopping here is a must and if you have the time, take a walk down, up and around the terraces. Hiking through the terraces was my favorite part of our trip to Bali. The hike was a little slippery at times and the paths are just wide enough for your feet but it was worth it.Donation/Fee: Consider leaving some Rupiahs in some of the donation boxes scattered around. After all, you are walking through and around people's crops.Food: There are a few restaurants that overlook the terraces.When to Go: Morning or earlier in the day when it's still a little cool and less humid.

Stunning surprise. I was lucky came when the rice field was as green as it gets but I guess sometimes it isn't. I loved the view but would have loved to be able to enjoy so go there early when there is less traffic its a small sightseeing place and a lot of people going there.

nice view. went there at the sunset ..nice view for the rice fields..but i didn't find it like the photos published in the internet , i think there are villages more beautiful than this village like munduk ..
if you will go to mount Batur ..it is in the same road..ask the driver to stop at it to have some photos
very interesting view. we can see padi view everywhere but it is very special impression.

Beautiful. It's so beautiful and it's "free" to get there (some small donations). A must see in Ubud. We were lucky cause there were not a lot of people (october 2014).
You can take a lot of good pictures there!
Amazing Views. Amazing views over the rice fields. Don't forget your camera. Although it is quite a walk in the sun so cover up.
AMAZING. Incredible view and experience - best rice terraces only at 30 minutes by motorbike from Ubud Central. There is also a nice cafe with a great view !

Don't Miss This. What an unexpected pleasure. We made our way down a very steep set of steps, up and around the rice terraces and to the area teaming with little cafes and shops. Perfect for a cool beverage and some phenomenal views.

Lovely view. As you drive into Tagalalang, your driver is stopped, you pay a fee and then you're allowed to pull up at the side of the road, get out, wander along many tourist stalls and take some photos. You can walk down to the bottom of the terraces, but we didn't as it was very hot. Not much else to do there but worth a look anyway.

Go early. My husband and I arrived in the early-ish morning, close to nine. There were not many people around, and we enjoyed walking around the terraces. The area is pretty, small, and worth the motorbike ride. We only stayed forty minutes, and found our trip to be worthwhile. We stopped at quite a few shops along the way back to Ubud--the prices were much more reasonable than the city center.
Great view. Went to Tegaalang on our way to the Volcano. Been to bali many times but the view of the Rice terraces is a must see every time
Beautiful. I like the scenery but the space is to small I think. Tried to circle around the rice terrace by bike, very good, but the road a little bit damaged, we have to be more careful.
Pretty. This was a nice trip and the little stalls and drinking spots as you're walking around the paddies are good for a spot of coconut water or a reasonably priced souvenir
WOW!!!!. This was part of a day tour for us but we had no idea what to expect. The views were stunning everywhere you walk. Entry is very cheap.
Beautiful outlook. Many photo opportunities here! Peaceful and charming experience. The rice paddies are truly Bali. Interesting buildings, water systems and lush colour

Nice Rice Terrace. Beautiful Rice Terrace
Terrace Padi Cafe is located at the best location, in the middle of rice terrace. The restaurant is very famous of its delicious food, and guests can view the stunning scenery. Not only Indonesian food but International menu is also available.
Watch my Bali Video here: https://vimeo.com/108554450
Read my Bali Tips here: https://www.facebook.com/notes/myanv-travel/bali-travel-tips/802546373143349

Worthwhile to have seen. Build between hills, you can enter the rice terraces after buying a parking and entrance ticket. With a deep steep stairs, go to the bottom and then you move along the rice fields back up, via narrow slippery paths. Great views and you feel one with nature.

Tourist trap engulfed in traffic. Would never go back to this built for tourists rice paddy farce. Horrible traffic, crowded and only built for tourists. Much more interesting in the back roads where real working rice fields are situated.

Really unique experience. My wife and I decided to explore after a lunchtime meal at he Kumpung Cafe. There is a path taking you down, across and back up the rice terraces. Its a very unique experience and a must do. yo can get some great pictures up top and is a very satisfying journey. A must do if in Ubud!
A must see if you like nature and landscapes. Beautiful but there's not much to do after you arrive there. Take pictures and that's it. It's not like you are going to walk through the terraces.

Beautiful Views. We found it was best viewed from one of the coffee shops. Didn't want to walk the terraces as in our view the only place you can't take it all in is when you're in them. I may be wrong. We sat down for a Luwak Coffee and a Bintang and just admired them
Lush green vista. This is a wonderful place to visit in order to see the amazing contoured terraces. Fantastic farming process completed by hard physical work, maintained over centuries.

Donations for Days. The view of the rice terrace from the road is magnificent, it was definitely the prettier of the rice terraces in Bali, however the others had different positives as well. The only downfall at this rice terrace was that you were made to pay a "donation" for everything, to cross a pathway, to cross a bridge, to walk up a hill to the next paddy and to take photos of locals. I got a bit annoyed at one stage about this.

Beautiful but very congested. The rice terraces were beautiful but the one in the Philippines was a lot better. In order to view the terraces, you have to go into the shops or restaurants. We viewed the terraces from one of the shops. We only stayed for a few minutes because the owner was already asking me to buy something. We took pictures and left. The place is congested with tourists when we arrived around 4pm so finding a place to park was a struggle.

Tegalalang rice terrace.. The terraced gardens were beautiful and seemed designed for Western tourists unaccustomed to viewing rice paddy fields.It is situated in Tegalalang village a long drive from Ubud city.Coconut trees line the edges of the terrace rice fields and the scenery is straight out of a postcard photo.Purchased a wooden cat carving at the local curio shop

Amazing!. I went there by motorbike that my friend rented, it is a 10 minutes away from the town and it is impressive! Nice bars around where you can eat or drink in a balcony in front of the rice terrace, it is unbelievable, be aware of the people asking for money in many parts of the terrace, try to walk on the other side of the terrace, there is a small temple there as well. Worthseeing

Donations are compulsory if you want to walk along the terrace. Pretty views, I must say. Unfortunately, we didn't have Rupiahs with us. The offer was to give this pretty rude Balinese lady US$50 with a change of 2500 Rupiahs back ... kidding! So we were not allowed to pass. That was a real disappointment. So we walked to a cafe that claimed they served Kopi Luwak. The waiter swore it was the real stuff. It came as water downed bad coffee, nothing Luwak about it. I had and sold Kopi Luwak before, so I know what it's like. Pity Bali has become a tourist trap.

Must Visit Places in Bali but Very Touristy. You can't imagine that this beautiful place is actually surrounded by a lot of shops and restaurants. If you haven't visited this place you would think its surrounded by rice fields but its not. The rice terraces is easily accessible from the airport .It is on the other side of the road surrounded by numerous souvenir stores and restaurants that sometimes its hard to get a parking spot for your car. Bali is really a very touristy place. However the place is worth a visit and you can walk down to take awesome photos of the terraces.
Beautiful rice fields. Excellent rice terraces where you are free to walk wherever you want. Would love to go again. Excellent markets along the road.

Beautiful views but a bit of a tourist trap. I had been to this rice terrace a couple of times before but never had the energy to walk down and back up the other side. I'm glad we did as it wasn't as tiring as I thought and it's a beautiful place to walk around, but you're exposed to the sun so take suncream and water. We were asked for a 'donation' at the beginning so handed over 10,000 but then when we got to the top of the other side, another man wanted a 'donation' and when we decided we'd just head back down instead of continuing past his checkpoint he got quite angry and shouted at us as we walked away.

A real spectacle of human engineering. This place is a marvel of human engineering and design. The rice terraces are amazing and the best place to view them and enjoy them from is on the terrace of one of the restaurants specially built for that purpose! A must see in Bali!

go early. a lovely view and a fun walk the kids loved it, we went at 8.30 as it was near our hotel (check out Alam Sari) and there was only three other people there but i've heard it gets very crowded later on

Great walk through the rice fields. Positive: Shaded walk through rice fields, with great views and photo opportunities. Many cafes along the top offering stunning views while you enjoy your Bintang!Negative: None really - just make sure you have some small notes for the "donations" to the various stalls along the walk.Summary: Well worth the energy to take the steep walk down into the rice fields and would suggest early morning or later afternoon for best light to take photos!

Nice views but There were 3 "exploiters". Bad experience that we had here,I am Indonesian and living in Milan,Italy.we (me&hubby) went here when the terrace was empty,I meant no paddy,so sad...but the most disgusting and embarrassing thing is....there were 3 Balinese men on the top of the field and they offered us to take the pics together with them,after that they asked money and we gave IDR20.000 each...more sad,they asked to some other visitors.i still keep the pics of those guys

Scenic landscape,. As with most attractions in Bali, you will likely spend more time on the road to Tegalalang than there - but it's worth it! There rice terraces are truly scenic due to their height / deepness, but not that large. There are several cafes and restaurants on the upper side, where you can stay and admire the view / take photos - but, of course, you have to order something to stay.

Essential Pit-stop. Spectacular view from the top of a broad sweep of rice terraces. You can walk down, up and around the area and / or spend time in one of the bistros on top gazing. The narrow street is a bottleneck of cars driving in both directions, cars & bikes parked, and shops / visitors along the walkways, so it is not really a quick-stop but it is well-worth the time. I did, cheerfully, feel obliged to do some souvenir / gift shopping there as it is not easy to see to what extent the locals benefit from all the hectic activity on their streets - there is a huge range of patchwork quilts at great prices to choose from, for example.The only negative experience on my last visit was the number and almost-aggressive persistence of young children selling packs of postcards: having a gaggle of kids surround you as you try to navigate the road / path is nerve-wracking.

Worth a peek. We didn't stay long in the area as my partner and I were not prepared (or fit) to actually go to the rice fields (terraces). But what we saw was spectacular enough and recommend this as a must see site in Bali.

Beautiful rice terraces. These rice terraces are beautiful. Great walk and picture taking. The green colors are amazing. Narrow paths so be careful. There are many tourists here. There are shops nearby with low prices.

Great terraces . Amazing rice fields with great view. Rp. 5000 fee to get into region and multiple "donation" points along rice pattie route where people stop you forcing you for a fee (donation) to continue. Rice terraces are great to see though, a lot of walking but worth it.

If you are in Ubud you must go. No surprises here. Terraced rice fields are terraced rice fields. Nonetheless they are beautiful and something you will be happy seeing in Ubud.There isn't much to do in Ubud sightseeing-wise outside of the Monkey Forrest, so I think this is a must visit. If you choose to climb down the steps to the bottom of the fields and then climb up to the other side you will be asked to donate some money to locals that block your path. You only need to give them a few rupiah to pass through. I would wear normal shoes as opposed to flip-flops if you do plan on walking through the fields.When you arrived there you will be on a street that runs along the top of one side. You get great views from there and there are quite a few restaurants where you can sit and enjoy the view while having a bite to eat or drink.If you go by motorbike from downtown Ubud the ride will take about 30 mins. There is some traffic jams along the way. If you go by car I would imagine it takes 45 minutes since you have to sit in the jams.

touristy. Rice teraces itself are okay but nothing overwhelming. In my eyes it was a pity that the whole place was transformed to serve tourists. The road there is plastered with souvenir stores and the road opposite of the teraces is a row of stores, little markets and restaurants (and not the nice kind). There is some places further north which might not be as accesible but offered a more satisfactory experience.

beautiful. This is a beautiful rice terrance! It's very big and there are little cafes where you can eat and enjoy the view. I highly recommend wearing comfortable shoes like sneakers because when you walk do the terrance, the pathways are very bumpy and uneven so you can easily slip. There may be one or two woman collecting donations when you pass through the terrance. It would be nice if you can donate some money as they do own part of the terrance and you'll be passing it by.

Beatiful scenery. Walking through the rice terraces was a wonderful experience. The scenery is breathtaking. Bear in mind that as you progress through the path, there will be checkpoints where the locals collect a "donation". Also be weary of the local farmers who offer to pose for pictures, they expect payment.

Stunning rice terrace. Beautiful example of a terraced rice field not far from the heart of Ubud. It is a picture-postcard view of what you'd expect to see in somewhere such as Bali or VietNam. The only negative is that the streets are lined with tourist paraphernalia and you therefore feel like you're looking at a photo. It's a bit surreal and a bit disappointing, however still very beautiful.

a great way to spend a day. we spent a day travelling from seminyak to UBUD. We did the sensible thing and hired a driver for the day which is better option than driving in Bali unless you have a nerves of steel. We incorporated this in a trip where we tasted Kopi lawak, monkey sanctuary and went to artist retreat. The rice paddies are the good around lunch time as there is plenty of places to stop for a break. Parking seems difficultAlso make sure you have cash as there is occassional official person charging a toll entry on the road (5000 rup pp)
Rice fields, Ubud. It was a nice, long walk away from the crowds at Ubud. There are some simple shops selling crafts along the way, and local people willing to chat with tourists.

Very pretty!. We did a stopover at Tegalalang Rice Terraces and here is where we had some of our prettiest photos. Nearby, too, are small restaurants and souvenir shops where you can do your shopping. :)

Spectacular views. Beautiful views of the rice terraces, great for memorable photos and some good shopping also. The best bit? Travelling through authentic Balinese villages yet untouched by the tourist hype.
Nice experiance. Lovely views of all rice teracce! Photo from this place looks beautiful from all of side! Its must view for Bali travelers

As amazing as only nature can be. "Dgalalang" Rice Terrace is a place where you have to spend at least a couple of hours wondering how amazing nature can be and how great can be the men's work, when is in sinergy with nature. I've never seen such a shade of green in all my life, and can be very nice to drink a coffee or a tea in the nice bar above the rice fields.
Tagelalang Rice Paddies. Stop here on the way to Mt. Batur Lake. Aside from having the rice paddies as your view, there are lots of stores where you can buy paintings and other souvenirs.
Fields of gold. What a view and colours. It's amazing to visit, highly recommend it. Traffic can be a little bit crazy, be careful.
Nice view!!. Very nice viewingpoint on the ricefields!! We still have to go to Jatiluih, so I don't know yet which is more beautifull!
Impressive!!. You should go! Impressive and relaxing! Good place to be, eat, walk and enjoy!! I would so much recommend it!

Picture Postcard. I just knew somewhere like this would still exist in Bali, but I did not know where to find it until I asked our driver for the day. I told him I had seen post cards of steep, terraced rice fields but had not been able to find such a place. He knew! It was beautiful and I commend the Balinese people on their hard work and ingenuity.

Stunning scenery!. We enjoyed our drop-by visit to the rice terrace during our trip to Ubud. I come from a country with beautiful tea terrace but this rice terrace did not disappoint me! The view is absolutely stunning and beautiful. It is not something you can see daily for a city-dweller like myself. We did not have issue with vendors hassling us during our visit maybe because we went there at a off-peak time or we had a local tour guide following us all the time. There is a nice friendly old farmer with rice shoulder pole standing in one of the platforms for photo-taking if you want. Tip him well if you take photo with him or borrowing his rice shoulder pole for photo. He stands there every afternoon after working in the rice terrace in the morning. Drop by and enjoy the beautiful scenery when you visit Ubud, you will not regret for doing it.
Simply Beautiful. That's it, it was simply beautiful. Breathtaking views and an appreciation for the work of the rice farmers.
Unique and must see. Stunning scenery and a must see if you are in Ubud. Very busy, we got our own driver for a cheap price rather than doing a tour

Rice Paddys. Fascinating in the way these people have managed to make a living for themselves and their families in such a small and steep area and you don't need to walk far to get a good perspective of the work done or to get some great photos.

NICE but scale not as big as expected. It was nice as a drop by sight-seeing point. Actually it looks like a human-made sight-seeing point for me….The scale is smaller than I expected and there is no proper facilities around. We went in September, the rice fields were not green or brown enough to surprise us… so basically we got off the bus, took pictures, had a look around for 15 mins, that’s about it. You may wanna go down the stairs for closer look at the fields, but trust me, the views above are much nicer.

The Window Of Earth. Fresh air, green view, the sound of the water just make this place perfect. Sad because of there are so many tourists caused the traffic. Overall it is just great, the thing I cant help to complain is because there are few people ask you for donation. I find out it is kind of annoying.

Beautiful. Pictures cannot do this justice. I rented a scooter and made my way here which was nice as there are many villages and temples off the beaten path that can be visited. A nice way to get out of the shopping center.
Awesome place. Awesome place, if you haven't experienced the rice culture this is a good place to start, yu can just walk around or py for guide and history.

Fascinating!. Quite a spectacle with many small paddies created on the sides of a steep valley. Nice walk around the site if you are in good physical condition. Parking is a little busy but local drivers can cope with it all. Didn't like being hassled all the time by street sellers.

Breathtaking!!!. Just spectacular - like a picture postcard. Lots of people selling stuff and lots of children selling stuff.
On the terraces that lead down to the Rice Terrace there are lots of little nooks where you can sit and eat and just drool over the view...and you can do the BIG walk down into the Rice Terrace..
Beautiful. Lovely place to stop and have a walk. You can wander through the rice terrace which is placed in a valley.

Lovely views - go early to avoid the crowds. I visited the rice terraces at about 9:30am and was the only one there along with my guide. We were able to walk about uninterrupted and none of the shops had opened at that time. Well worth a visit.

rice terrace. great view however very busy narrow main road and lots of people trying to sell nik naks.im not sure if you can walk on the rice terrace ,i did see people walking but not sure if tourist or workers
Wonderful. Worth a stop for sure - but not a destination in itself. Watch the time as gates do not open first thing.

Wow!. Well worth the trip from Ubud, maybe 30min north depending on traffic. This is absolutely beautiful! We also had food and drinks in one on the little Warungs overlooking the terraces. This was a peaceful, beautiful place to relax and enjoy the view.

too much popular. the view is great but it's a mess there are a lot of tourists and bus that drop off groups right on the terraces. the restourants on the fields are nice but my suggestion is to walk over the entrance and have a nice walk in the quite
great views, really enjoyed it. there are great rice field views, i really enjoyd it and took great pictures - definetley recommend it to you!
Worth the drive. The rice terraces were pretty. We just did the drive by and stopped briefly. Definitely worth the trip but not much to do.
Rice Paddies. Very lovely how the terraces were formed. You need to pay a parking fee to stop and take photos. Footpaths have been improved.
Just planted. The rice field were just planted with a tinge of green. Much better when they have the rice padi growing. Quite a few cafes and shops looking at the views. Good and bad :-()
Great place. Awesome place, if you haven't experienced the rice culture this is a good place to start, yu can just walk around or py for guide and history.
Lovely views. Felt like it was a world away from some of the hassle I'd been dealing with .Food great , view peaceful

Astonishing. These wonderful terraces spread along a hillside, overlooked by a number of cafes. You can either sit in one of the cafes and admire the view, or walk down and through the terraces, as we did. They certainly have the wow factor.
Spectacular. I love driving through here. Just spectacular rice fields. I must come to Bali when there are a few tourists. I have t found this to be overly crowded. Worth a look.
Picturesque. A sight to see. Beautiful walking track around rice terrace. Lots of cafes to relax and enjoy the views.
Nice experience. Sadly the rice paddies are being encroached upon by villas and cafés, but still very scenic and well worth seeing/walking, either alone or with a. Guide.
rice terrace. Great scenery very nice use of the hill side there was a lot of people and a lot of traffic we didn't stay long but it was possible to venture out onto the terrace if wished for

Small but very nice. This rice terrace is actually pretty small and touristy but still very enjoyable.
It is well worth the trip to get here.

Beautiful but slight touristy and not as grand as Jatiluwih. Rice fields were beautiful but it was rather touristy with peddlers selling their goods. The rice fields were not as grand as those in Jatiluwih. I would recommend visiting Jatiwulih instead if time and schedule permits.

Beautiful - better photos from climbing terrace. We visited the Tegalalang rice terrace early in the morning two weeks ago. They are a 20 minute or so drive from Ubud, and we booked a taxi for 3 hours so that we could stop and take photos on the way. The terrace itself was smaller than we expected it to be, and unfortunately the terraces were mainly bare as the rice harvest must have just finished. Having said that, the scenery was still really lush and beautiful. We were there from around 8-9am, and at that time the sun is right in your face. The views and quality of photos were much better if you crossed the valley and climbed up to the other side. This took about 10 minutes and was muddy in some areas but well worth it for the views. Afterwards, we visited a nearby place which produces luwak coffee. I cannot remember the name of this place but it was on the opposite side of the road from the main rice terrace. The staff there gave us a tour of grounds, explained how luwak coffee was collected, and let us feed coffee beans to the luwaks. They also showed us trees producing cinnamon bark, cocoa and vanilla pods. We were then taken to a cafe-type area and given samples of teas and coffees. To our surprise there was no charge for these drinks. The views from this place were also beautiful as they looked down over a valley. The 'tour' ends at a shop selling a range of coffee varieties. There was no hard sell. It was a nice place to end our visit to Tegalalang, and quite educational for our children who had never seen where cocoa, vanilla etc came from up close.

Beautiful! But not as grand and sweeping as Jatiluwih. The Tegalalang rice terraces are gorgeous. They're located about 15-20 minutes by car outside of Ubud, so you'll have to hire a taxi there and back. (Pro tip: make sure your driver waits for you as you explore Tegalalang. I didn't do this, and it was very difficult to find a ride back to Ubud.) The area is rather small, so it won't take you more than 45 minutes or an hour to hike around the rice terraces and take a few photos. Admission is "donation-based"; we felt 10000 Rupiah (about 1 USD) for 2 people was an appropriate donation, and the man accepting donations seemed to agree. My only gripe with the rice terraces is that for the trip there and back, which amounts to a total of 30-40 minutes, there's not a whole lot to see in Tegalalang. As I said, it won't take you all that long to hike around the rice paddies, so is it worth the trip? Maybe it'd be better to make this a 30-minute stop on a day trip from Ubud to Kintamani, rather than a stand-alone afternoon trip from Ubud.

Rice fields in Ubud are the most beautiful. Amazing place! I spend in Indonesia a lot of time, I saw many of different rice fields, but this one in Ubud are the most beautiful. Green fields with palm trees inside. Shapes of this rice fields are amazing. You can walk through them and watch people who work on the place. If you are there don’t forget to take lunch or some drink in some of the restaurants on the hill. View from there is stunning.

OK, but not as good as Jati Luwih. Tegalalang Rice Terraces are nice, but relatively small and rather crowded. If you have the Jati Luwih terraces on your itinerary, then Tegalalang will not seem to be that exceptional. Still - if you have enough time to visit, why not to?
Rice paddies. Nice but we saw better ones in other parts of Indonesia and China. Very touristic. You have to arrive early in the morning, otherwise it can be very busy.
Very interesting. Very good to see the rice fields.not really that big. Hawkers everywhere. Glad I visited but would not go back again.amazing workmanship.

Rice and tranquility.. We got here late afternoon so it was quite, you can walk round the rice terraces and then have a drink or a meal in one of the restaurants. Very beautiful area and hopefully it will stay that way.
Red Rice. Stopped here on a little adventure and had lunch at the top of the terrace with an overview of the paddies, nice scenery and glad it has been protected by forward thinking councillors.

Impressive. The views are certainly impressive - the rice fields are irrigated without the use of pumps (that I know of). That's why they have terraces - the river water flows from the top, and slowly makes its way down. All of the rice is hand-planted - imagine how much backbreaking work goes into that.The view depends on the season. Rice is harvested every three months. If you happen to arrive just after harvest, you'll see lots of brown mud instead of the luminous green blades of padi leaves that you expected. Unfortunately, it was also raining when we were there, so there was no chance of walking among the padi.There are also some cafes overlooking the padi fields, so do note that this is an option if you're not in the mood for climbing the terraces.It can get chilly and wet, so bring along a light jacket, and shoes you don't mind getting wet and dirty. Do note that cobras can hang out in padi fields too. They tend to shy away from humans but you should watch your step.

Stunning views. Great to visit to admire the view and hard work it must have taken to make! Good for a short stop not a long activity although there are a few cafés and the usual shops and sellers if you wish to make longer.
Lovely. Great views of stupendous rice terraces which are great for photos. Several nice cafes to have a drink while enjoying the views.
very interesting indeed. this is not a waste of time, not to miss! i would suggest renting a car with a driver and visiting the other spots all together.
Great view. Trek up and down the rice terraces to reach the other side will be rewarded with a 180 degree view of the enveloping rice terraces. Worth the effort!

A beautiful sight. Although busy, the sight of the rice terraces is beautiful. You can walk down onto the terraces for even better views. It's quite touristy, and there are lots of shops and restaurants catering to tourists. I recommend skipping lunch and eating elsewhere, as the restaurants are serving average, overpriced food.

Picturesque but difficult to get to. Worth visiting if you're in Ubud, however, we stopped here on the way back from a drive and found it difficult to get down to enter the rice fields - wear shoes with grip!

Busy, but magnificent views. The views at the rice terraces are quite something. It might be an idea to go early to avoid the buses of Asian (Chinese) tourists that are being dropped off there. Also, watch for the yellow stairs that go down onto the terraces. A very nice walk...and a bit less crowded at the same time.
Serenity & Grace. This place is a photographer's delight and if you enjoy climbing up and sown stairs, you can spend hours here. Lovely place

Beautiful scenery.. I didn't stop by the rice terrace but I looked at the view which was very beautiful. The weather also very nice, acceptable cold and windy. People actually could go down to the rice terrace and get many information and knowledge about the farming. I saw many restaurant/snack bar that located towards the rice field. It must be very enjoyable to have tea there next time.

Not so much rice anymore, but still impressive. You can walk in the steep rice terraces and the views are amazing. I did not see any rice being grown there, but it is still a worthwhile visit. (30min by scooter from Ubud)

Nice rice terraces. Surely they were amazing. We went to these rice terraces as part of a day trip to udud. We had lunch at one of the many restaurants overlooking the terraces which was great. If you want to see rice terraces then make sure you don't miss these ones. It is located about 20mins from the town of ubud.

Nice day trip from Ubud. We were in Ubud for 10 weeks and decided to take a day trip to the Tegalalang Rice Terraces. They were beautiful and although it is kind of weird that there is a fee to get in, it is kind of nice to be able to walk around and take pictures and feel like it is fine with the locals. The rice paddies are beautiful and serene. Honestly though, there are some pretty beautiful rice paddies on the Campuhan Trail in Ubud so if you are pressed for time during your stay in Bali, I would skip Tegalalang because it really takes an entire day to get there and get back.
Lovely destination. We went here during day tour. Recommend walking shoes.Enjoyed a drink overlooking terraces afterwards which was lovely

Breathtakingly beautiful. A must see to gain an insight to indonesian culture. This unique sight is indescribable. Enjoy a drink or meal at one of the cliff top restaurants/cafes while taking in the view.

So worth a visit. I visited in July & unfortunately there wasn't much of the rice to see as it had been harvested; that said it was an amazing place to see especially when you walk down to the bottom & up the other side to get the best of the views. After a busy time in Ubud it was nice to relax in front of this very peaceful place.You pay on entry but as you walk up & down the terraces there is an expected payment as you pass through various sections or if you have a photo taken with a local.I visited late afternoon so it wasn't too busy but you do need to wear decent footwear as flip-flops wasn't my best idea!!!!
Breathtaking!. The serene, peaceful and picturesque scene blew my mind. The long distance from centre Ubud where I stayed costed me an hour or so to get here so it's a minus but worth the while

Nothing special anymore. Too much tourists. Ubud area is loosing it's sawa's because of investments in villa's. That's a pity because Ubud is loosing lot of it's charm! Definitely not a must see. Take a ride to the east, Candi dasa, and you'll see more impressive sawa's
BREATHTAKING VIEW. the view was WOW.....but the parking site ehmmmmm......could have done better.around that area children can enjoyed picking up oranges

Iconic but touristy. It's a must visit for all first-time tourist...like the Great Pyramids of Giza. Be prepared for traffic, crowds and touts. Try to find the way down to the rice terrace, it's worth a walk if you think you're not going to get another chance to do it. Actually, half of Bali is covered in rice terraces and fields so you can do it elsewhere but this is the epitome of it all. Beware of men who act as the farmer of the land inviting you up to the next tier for a photo-op. He'll ask to be paid. Even if you decline, he'll harass you saying that you're trampling all over his crop and ruining it. Just turn a deaf ear and walk away.There is a minimum drive-through fee. If you're just stopping for a photo, 10-15 minutes is sufficient. If you're taking a walk, an hour is good. Stop by the little hut by the bridge for freshly-plucked coconuts.
nice place. quick stop over on my way back from besakih temple, nice view.the weather needs to be perfect for you to enjoy this place.

It's alright. We visit in a wrong time which the fields is not like what you see in the picture. I gave it 4 star because of the other rice field surrounded by it. It's also on the road so hard to stay and have a look. Wear some mosquito repellant before visit.

Mixed feelings. Nice view, and interesting place....but the 'fee' to enter the road, the kids running around trying to sell you stuff by appealing to your soft side (because they are children); and the many stores turned this beautiful place into madness! The road leading it it is crowded w shops selling all sort of crafts. The road is windy, and narrow...Go if you must, but be aware of the above.

Beautiful. Beautiful views but I do worry about where the (small) compulsory donations end up. I sincerely hope they go to the friendly hard working farmers whose land we are trampling over! Everyone was friendly and it really is a beautiful place. The reviewers who complain that the rice fields are dry at certain times of the year are surreal. Next time you should ask the farmers to hand fill the terraces for you with buckets of water...
Tourist attraction. It's a lovely view, but we were a bit disappointed. If you want to see the real rice fields hire a scooter or bike and go to Campuhan. The views here are much better!

Beautiful early Morning (only). Most beautiful rice terraces we've seen in Ubud. Went there twice and the first time (early morning) was gthe place as not to many tourists. During the day it can be very crouded and it looses all its charm.

A highlight of our trip. We visited in early June in the afternoon and almost had the place to ourselves (aside from a group of locals who were harvesting). Yes, you have to pay a donation to get in but it’s not expensive and well worth it for the views. Our guide recommended that we took a walk through the fields, which was lovely. Worth a visit.

To many tourists. The terraces are pretty but you have to be lucky that they are green. Other then that ti's crowded and packed with tourist shops so ti's hard to take pictures without all the people. We saw very pretty ricefields close to the tirtagangga that were much more authentic

Hit the spot. I just wanted to get nice photos of the hilly rice fields. Even though the rice was harvested already, the photos came up great - few locals were still working around the field. The are nice places around to have a drink with an amazing view.
Absolutely beautiful!. Definitely worth your while to make a trip to the rice terraces and it's unparalleled beauty! Plan to eat lunch at one of the overlooking restaurants!
Beautiful !. Really amazing how they managed to make it +the beauty to see it ! Beautiful colours and images. You should be delighted.

ok. I guess there are nicer rice fields in Bali but if you are in Ubud and don't have time to drive much father, I would say just go to Tegalalang. Take some pictures, have a meal or drinks at the terrace restaurants.
Nice view. Rice Terrace with a nice view. We reached in the evening and it was too dark for good photos. So go there early so as not to be disappointed

Rice were already harvested. When we got there, perhaps it wasn't a good time as the rice were already harvested and we didn't manage to see anything much at all. Plus November was the raining season, so we couldn't move around much for photos as well. Would give this place a second chance on a different season next time to be fair.

Nice view. These terraces give you a view of what rice paddies on the hillside are. It is also worthwhile to take a walk through them with a guide who can explain the rice cultivation process. When the rice is grown, the hillside presents a beautiful lush green vista that is quite impressive to behold. Recommended.

Breathing in peace. This area of Bali is both majestic and deeply peaceful. You just sit and absorb the amazing beauty of the so carefully sculpted rice terraces all filled with the fine greenery of the tender blades of growing rice, at the same time as allowing the soft warm breezes to blow across your face from afar... and just take it all in. You come away feeling different without really knowing what has happened, you feel more peaceful and centred, something has drifted into your awareness through such stillness but you don't know what... it's almost beyond words!
One not to miss when in Ubud.. Was in to minds to do a trip to the rice field but visiting Tegalalang was well worth. Amazing views harvesting had just happened but was still worth it.
beautiful but crowded. Have some gelatio on the roof terrace overlooking the rice terrace (hohoho). Absolutely gorgeous if you'd like some quiet.

Fantastic View. We really enjoy the panoramic of Tagalalang Rice Field, using 4WD more better you can cross the rice field and it is safety. You should enjoy lunch in this palace there are some restaurant along the road. Try tea beras merah it is good for diabetes.

Must Do!. I always come to Tegalalang anytime I stay overnight in Ubud. I would wake up 5ish AM and then drive to Tegalalang. The Ceking Rice Terraces is still so fresh, the restos and cafes are still closed. It is like you have the whole terraces for yourself. I also never miss to go down to the rice terraces and experience the fresh natural air. Crossing the river, talking to the farmers. Just enjoying the perfect nature!One of the pictures can be seen in my profile picture!

Rice Patty Scooter Ride. We did not walk, but rented a scooter for $5 CDN per day and headed north a 15-20 minute ride to see these outstanding terraced rice paddies. These are the one you would see on travel advertisements. Along the way are many homes of locals. Very cultural drive to see how people live, and other rice paddies are beautiful as well

really pretty. Tegallalang rice terrace was very special!! Driver led us down some slippery steps to have a better view at the lower terraces but it was totally worth it. So pretty and magnificent! I expected something similar to the tea or paddy plantations i've seen in Malaysia but this was really something. Some parts have already been harvested but it wasn't bare and brown but still very green! Would recommend to come here before paddy harvesting period because that's when its the prettiest! :) Would definitely come here again :)

Unique!. It is somehow unique as so far this is my first time seeing this.I believe we do not have this in Malaysia. I went there right after my visit to Kintamani. Nice capturing some photos with the rice terrace!

Tegalalang worth the visit in Ubud. Rice terrace in Bali is famous for many reasons. It is all about visiting which rice terrace (Pacung, Tegalalang, Jatiluwih, Tampaksiring, etc) that can give you the maximum pleasure to enjoy the scenic views. I rank Jatiluwih ahead of Tegalalang in 2 simple reasons :a) Jatiluwih allows you to trek the entire valley (as huge as kilometers end to end) whereas Tegalalang is just one small valley (football size).b) View of Jaitluwih has a mountain backdrop and this makes Jatiluwih excellent in photo-taking.Tegalalang is worth visiting as it is strategically located in Ubud, hence for visitors taking a tour to Ubud, it is convenient to stop by as part of the attraction.The plus point is after visiting the rice terrace in Tegalalang, visitors can stop by at "jalan raya tegalalang" where you can shop for handicrafts. This is the reason why I return to Tegalalang.I was there at Tegalalang at 3.30pm on 11 July 2014. Not crowded at all. It is worth going. The handicraft shops at Jalanraya Tegalalang is very worth to stop over too.
Gorgeous greenness. Enjoyed seeing the rice terrace view, it is really beautiful however the area is pretty touristy and has lots of shops and traffic.

It is unique in a right time.. If you want to see the rice fields in Ubud, you must ensure that it is not in the harvest or after. It will be perfect when the rice is green. And be careful when it rains, the moor will be slippery and difficult to cross over to the other side of the terrace.

Impressive. If you love nature, you will love this rice terrace, impressive views. Fresh air, feel the breeze. Find a cafe located just in front of this stunning rice terrace, order a cup of bali hot coffee and enjoy the scenery. This rice terrace if the signature of bali, wonder how its look if they had harvested the rice. The down side is the crowds, would be better if plan your trip during the week day to avoid the crowds. Some souvenirs shops, painting shops, etc are there, the price are quite cheap compares to ubud market or sukawati art market. Bought a painting, with 50% discount of the offered price. Great place to see and enjoy.
Scenic view!. A wonderful photo opportunity-when the rice paddies are ripening green, its really beautiful to see how the locals optimise rice cultivation. Lots of souvenir shops too

Wait a bit if you're able. Visited two days ago - beautiful to see and fun to meander around in the experience. Appeared to be quite dry as recently harvested -many locals staging pictures at this time. If you're in Bali for awhile perhaps wait to visit - went around lunchtime on a weekday and wasn't too busy at all :) Had a table with friends to hydrate after, overlooking the terrace, quiet and beautiful. Magnificent local drives to compliment this rice terrace experience.Note: Paid for ticket in/parking and a 'donation' upon entrance to walking in the field.

Boring but unique. I visited three rice terraces in Bali: Jatiluwih, Tegallalang and Pacung.Basically all the three rice terraces looked very similar to each other.All has nothing much to see, nothing much to learn, nothing much to play, just took a few photos and left.However, since rice terraces are one of the uniqueness of Bali, I would recommend people to visit one of the above rice terraces, but not all of them.In Tegallalang, you can borrow some tools (hat, baskets) from the farmers there to take some photos as a memory (but the hat stinks!).There is no fixed price for borrowing the tools, but my driver told me that around Rp. 20,000 is appropriate.

An impressive view, but once the rice is harvested it looses some of its charm. A tourist trap for sure, but it's worth seeing. When we went they had just harvested the bamboo, which while still interesting to see, it lessened the experience somewhat.

Stunning views. The terraced valley is wonderful and intricate. If you look closely you can see the water as it is guided through each of the rice fields on its way down to the valley floor. Go on a week day as to avoid the worst of the crowds.

Terrace Trails. Being from India, rice fields aren't new to me. However, the acres and acres of paddy and the glorious vastness of the green fields surprised me and they was gorgeous to behold. Whether it's a drive through, or view from a strategically located restaurant or a trek through....these rice terraces are worth the visit.
fab. This is amazing to see- however watch the children that are trying to sell you postcards- they can be relentless. We could not figure out how to walk in further to see the terraces.
WORTH TO SEE !!. Stunning view of rice terrace where we can see from the main road.A lot of local paintings that you can choose from.

Beautiful but Crowded. We rented motorbikes for the day and went to visit Tegalalang.Seeing them was beautiful, but the touts and crowds ruined the experience a bit for us. I would still recommend going to see them, but I would make sure to set your expectations accordingly. I wouldn't recommend staying there for an entire day, or even half a day. We skipped the restaurants that were surrounding Tegalalang since most of them were geared to tourists and left to find a more authentic/local place to eat.

Breathtaking scenery but too many people and cars. Upon entering the Rice Terrace, you will have to pay a small fee. I was travellin with my husband and we were charged 5000 Rupiah. As our driver dropped us off, we were mesmerized by the beauty of the rice terraces. The greenery was breathtaking. You can enjoy the view and pictures near some of the local market stalls, where there is a small area for picture taking (you will need to take a small flight of steps down). Surrounding this breathtaking scenery are various market stalls and also cafes. There are some cafes that are high up where you can actually enjoy the lovely view. It will not be too overwhelming for those who do not enjoy scenery.
Beautiful but busy. It's a beautiful sight but the place is so busy. Definitely a place to stop at, but I would suggest going really early before the crowds get out there.

Good view, but over popularised. Visited Tegalalang rice terrace as recommended by our driver. It was good as it was the first rice terrace that I've seen. Crowded with tourists though. Later on, on our way to Ulun Danu temple, we saw much better and scenic ones.. hence if planning to a visit to ulun danu, then skip this place...
Great view. Really nice place to stop by and click some pictures. It was raining when we visited, I think that made it spectacular. Must visit.

Not as nice as Yunnan. These terraces are pretty, but they are mild and small compared to the "real" rice terraces of Yunnan or Guangxi. Those are vast with high mountains; awe inspiring; these are not. These are just cute little "backyard" rice terraces, nothing grand in scale. Surrounded by shops and cars trying to stop for a look clogging the only street. Certainly not worth a trip unless you don't grow rice where you are from and have never seen terraced farming. If you are in the area, you could stop by. Best to adjust your expectations so as not to be disappointed. Some restaurants were available where one could have lunch. Plenty of places to buy souvenirs.

Awesome view. When we were there it was very quiet. So we went down and zipped on a coffee in the bar with view of the terrace. The color green and vista of the terrace is just something unreal. Must see!

Nice scenery. It's a nice rice terrace view. However, fees are collected upon entrance (we paid IDR 25K for 2 of us and driver) just to see the piece of rice terrace. Small area, few souvenirs shops around.

must see in Ubud. lovely rice terraces definitely a must see! nice cafes where you can have lunch or dinner with a fantastic view! best met goring I had so far was at one of the cafes over at tegalalang

Nice enough. A very touristy place to see some pretty curved rice terraces in a valley. You can walk down amongst them. There are cafés overlooking them. A fair amount of hawkers selling stuff. It's on the main road heading north out of Ubud, which is lined with artisan shops for mile after mile. We went on our own on the scooter. It's a nice little outing, but the fields around Ubud are probably just as pretty.

Beautiful. The sight of these rice paddies is quite breathtaking. Make sure you get there early before all the buses, etc take over. We got there around 10am & pretty much had the place to ourselves & it was lovely.
The natural bali. It is great to get out of town and see some of the real bali.We enjoy traveling to various spots and the rice terraces are always on view as you drive thru the various towns.

Pretty, but what's the fuss?. The rice fields were the last stop on my "Bali for Beginners" tour, so I just saw them from the road at dusk. It would have been pleasant if it weren't for a swarm of children and one very persistent old lady trying to sell me Bali postcards for USD10 for their school. I wondered what grade she was in...
Breathtaking view. A nice and breathtaking view of the paddy field. However, some parts of the field has been harvested, therefore, not all green field.

The views are stunning. Great views, try to get some time to walk around on the terrace to get the most from it, tole to be paid on road to viewing point. Busy with nice restaurants, but a tourist trap for sure.
Pretty view!. Went there by scooter. The view was really nice. Is this the place they shot the scene in Eat Pray Love?

Lovely to visit. I really enjoyed this place it was cute and a bit touristy but if you walk through the fields quite nice the locals are always wanting a little picture picture but I got some great ones and they weren't annoying about it like they can be in other countries. I hadn't been to a rice terrace before so for me it was great to see.
