There are some great walks around ubud that perhaps offer a better look at local and village life top we did a great one from the lonely planet guide that took about 20 minutes to an organic restaurant - this was fabulous! A definite highlight if you message I can give you more details.

Just an ordinary small size rice terrace. This is an okay view. There are also several cafe and shops nearby to relax and enjoy the view. I think there are several rice field trekking activities offered at Ubud hotels, but I am not sure if the trekking goes through this location. Aside from them there is nothing special. The weird thing is that a fee is charged for just passing through the road above the area, regardless that it is a public road. The terrace size/view is small compared to the one I passed on my way to Tulamben.

good view. It was on our way back from Kintamani volcano and was worth stopping for sometime.The view of rice terrace is good but nothing amazing.In the midst of market and on a busy road ,one has to be careful to stop.
Beautiful view. The view is beautiful over the rice terraces but the restaurants/coffee shops on the side of the roads are not really good value... A bit too touristy...

Small but amazing view of rice terrace. Went there yesterday during our trip to the volcano , The place quite small with not so much space for parking car . Even small we founded something special of this rice terrace , small and amazing terrace from the top of the hill down to the river . The condition of the terrace make all the job must done by hand . We went trough the terrace down and climb up the hill , it's just amazing experience .

Amazing Rice Terrace - Perfect for photo-taking!. The view is amazing.It will be good if there is some introduction for visitors to see the process of how farmers grow rice and the view of terraces at various periods/ stages of rice growth.

It's lovely. A short drive from Ubud's noise and seemingly endless traffic jams. Yes we've seen lots of rice fields and terraces but there's something sweet about this charming little village and it's extraordinary rice terraces - 600 metres high, built by hand, co operatively watered and just beautiful. The drive out was so quiet which in itself was a breath of fresh air. If you're looking for wooden bits and prices, or lead light lamps, there's lots of good shopping on the way and cheaper than in Ubud. 1590 rupiah per car gets you into the gorgeous little valley and the views are terrific. A couple of cafés and a few young kids practising their tout skills with postcards - shy and not at all pushy so do be polite with them! I hate seeing tourists being rude to the street sellers - we all need to earn a living and a simple "no thank you' surely isn't too exhausting. Take a scenic drive back thru the lush hills and quiet little villages and enjoy the gentler pace for a wee while. Well worth the trip from Ubud.

Great view, cool rice.. If you haven't seen a rice terrace before I think it's a good place I start. Green green green! Amazing teared rice steps, great cheap entrance fee and more bartering oppurtunities if you hadn't done enough of that already

Better elsewhere, in the Ubud area. Other terraces further out are much better. Very tourist like, the whole area around them is shops. Try the red rice growing at
Jatiluwih.

Beautiful view. We travelled to the rice terraces and what lay waiting was the most spectacular view. It was breathtaking to look at and also great photo opportunities.If you choose to walk to to the bottom then wear shoes with a good grip and take plenty of water.There are also markets there if you wish to purchase any local crafts.Well worth the visit

Simple Rice Terrace. we visited on May, It is normal Rice Terrace, in summer time they cutted rice trees, so it look bad and nothing to see.there are nothing to see around the rice field. i was disappointed and feel regret to spend time and money to go there. The steps rice field in Sapa Viet nam is many time better. you should go there instead this rice terrace.
Beautiful. These rice terraces are quite spectacular. The steep hillside, the morning light, the lush green rice plants makes this a paradise. Get here early to avoid the masses.

Beautiful view, but be prepared to be hasseled for money. It can't be denied that this particular rice terrace is stunning. My husband and I attempted to walk through it, but without wearing proper foot ware I had to turn back. When we first arrived a lady offered to take our picture, which of course meant we either had to pay her for it or buy something from her basket. We had drinks at one of the restaurants since the food seemed a bit pricey and not of the best quality. This place is a must-see in my eyes, but definitely has a big touristy feel.
Nice view. Tegalalang is located around 20 minutes driving from Ubud. Its main attraction is the rice terrace view to enjoy while having lunch or coffee.

Too touristy now!. Of course the rice terraces are beautiful but the feeling has been ruined by mass tourism, hundreds of shops now, buses, traffic, etc. And the restaurants and shops are low quality....not attractive at all. They even ask you for donations to visit the rice terraces...Tourism has sort of killed the original beauty of this place... Too bad. I would personally go elsewhere, there are dozens of nice locations to see rice terraces...

Its Ok. I went and did the trekking it was ok because I did it for the first time. This way is broken and slippery so you must have proper shoes (I didn't) and you must take careful steps. Once you get to the bridge after bridge you have to make donation. When you reach the top they ask you for another donation. This is something I found throughout Bali so if you are on a budget then you might want to consider this

The best view in Ubud. 30 minutes riding from Ubud and you will discover one of the best view to see the rice terrasses around Ubud. As a touristic place, you will have plenty of choices to eat or drink something around. Go a little bit further, as the "main touristic places" are quite expensive and not really good quality.

Interesting and nice view. the view is amazing and the fact that they plant rice on terraces is also educational. There is hardly any place to park and both sides of the road are filled with souvenir shops so its pretty good if you are looking for souvenirs. You NEED to bargain as the prices can drop by 50%. Interesting place to visit just to see how rice is planted on terraces as opposed to large fields and for the view of the terraces.
nice to see. Enjoyable to stop and relax for few minutes with such a nice landscape. A little bit annoying having to pay for the right to stop your car just to admire it!

Great views. We arrived around mid-afternoon, car parking was at a premium but we did find a spot, then it was quite difficult to walk back up the hill to view the terraces as the "path" alongside the road was either non existant, broken up badly or simply blocked, however once able to get a sight of the terraces all that was forgotten. We felt it was too warm to go down the hill to get closer, perhaps we will have to revisit another day!

Disappointment.... After the long drive along the narrow roads and villages, we reached the small plot of paddy terrace. Since the paddy was all harvested, there's nothing much to see, but the barren terrace. Anyway, Bali is all covered with paddy fields and terrace, that you don't actually have to visit any specific site to see paddy field or terrace. That long travelling time could very well spent on other interesting activities, like strolling down streets of Seminyak, Kuta and Ubud.
Beautiful Terrace. Loved the view, but found the traffic to be terrible. Also most items were being sold by kids who "need money for school and books".

breathtaking views but require some steep climbing. i guess we're pretty lucky, for when we're at Bali, many other rice fields were actually bare from harvesting but the rice terrace was still green and beautiful. my advice is if you wishes to climb over to the other end for more awesome, picturesque views, do not visit with flip flops. wear proper walking/sports shoes for the day as it will require you some steep climbing. you'll need to pay an entrance fee to enter and at the rice terrace, locals will ask you for donations too. According to the guide, entrance fees goes mostly to the govt and local community. and when the local farmers as you for donations, those money goes directly to them. they're the ones who's truly manning the place as a tourist attraction for tourists like us, so why not give them a small token of appreciation? We donated just RP 10, 000 to each 'donation spot' along the way. Not much of a difference to us, but might be a substantial difference to them. :)for more details with pictures, visit http://molly-mia.blogspot.sg/2014/05/mias-travel-log-bali-day-2.html

Nice place to visit. Nice place close to Ubud and therefore worth a visit, just rent a scooter in Ubud and drive there yourself - easy and saves money. It is a nice view to enjoy, either from one of the restaurants or just walking around and yun only have to pay a little bit (2000-5000rp) to go for a walk through the terraces. Very touristic but you can avoid that if you want and enjoy the view instead, no problemo!

Poorly maintained.. Rice terrace without the rice. Everything is dried up yet we have to pay an entrance fee. If you choose to go down to the terrace, you will have to go down a flight of steep steps, make a donation for the upkeep of the place, before you climb up the terrace. It's a joke.

Beautiful green view. Anyone who comes to Ubud, must visit Tegallalang rice field! Don't ask why. Just go! You will appreciate the green view from any corner! We were lucky that even though it was harvest time, we still get to see all the paddy growing everywhere. Some part of the field were already harvested!
Get here early for the views. Wonderful views well worth the traffic hassles and sellers to get there - best advice try to come early in the morning.

Lost its luster. You may blame it on the dry spell or non-harvest season but the whole place is badly maintained. The whole stretch is also under massive construction and many shops have shut down. We visited our usual Alon cafe and even this place has become so commercialized and rude, perhaps we as tourists have contributed to that? The waitress at the cafe could not wait for us to sit down to take the order - we were intercepted as soon as we walked down the steps. She pushed the menu right into our face and said we had to order first before we are allowed to proceed further. Sigh, what have become of this village and nature? I would suggest you stay away till the whole place is spruce up - probably in 2015?

Great view. Visited early in the morning with very few people here. It was refreshing though slightly challenging to get to the paddy fields. Be careful when going up and down the slopes since it can be slippery. Also, come early if you wish to visit here since the traffic can get congestive and getting a parking is almost impossibble.

Beautiful and worth a visit, in spite of tourist traps. This was the most picturesque rice field we found, and we were able to walk through them to get the best views (not for the faint hearted). It was swarming with begging children, opportunist farmers looking to get in your photos and demand money, and carefully placed donation collectors on the rice field walk, I could liken it to Billy goat gruff. In spite of the hassle it was still completely worth it, also has some good restaurant views although we just stuck to drinks.

Also a must while you stay in Ubud. Rarely will you see such a great variety of green tones :) The rice terrace in Tegalalang was in my view, amazing. While we drove to Ubud, we saw plenty of little rice terraces along the road but Tegalalang if THE one to see if you come close to Ubud.
Lovely and Amazing Rice Field. Really great place and nice view. But beware of the elderly and person that having heart disease, since the road is very steep and high.

Beautiful image. Just like something out of a geography text book! Stunning view, marred only by the presence of fellow tourists. Have a cup of tea (or something exotic) overlooking the wonderful scenery. Definitely recommend a visit. Costs 5000 rupiah per head - peanuts

Paddy Terrace. The famous Tegalalang's Paddy Rice Terrace. Nice scenery and zero Rupiah to be paid here. You can snap a photo with some local farmers here while wearing their hat plus carrying the paddy buckets around the terrace are for 5000 IDR. The locals are very friendly too :)

Popular rural rice view. A convenient place to see the rice terraces and take some photo's, browse the little shops and have refreshments. Parking along the road can be crowded and there is a fee for the vehicle to enter the area.
Kodak moment. Great place to see traditional Balinese rice terraces a little drive north of Ubud. A perfect stop for that kodak moment in Bali

Wooow very good experience. This is most of beautiful landscape in that area. We stopped there in our way to Mount batur. Wife was a bit tired with the journey until she saw that lovely terrace. She said wooooooow......Dont miss a visit to this place.

Neat. This was really neat to see, but it was pouring rain the day we went so unfortunately we didn't really get to see much of it. But it was nice to see it and get a few photographs. I would like to return one day to see it properly. Also you do have to pay a small fee to get through the road to get there.

Great attraction near Ubud! . The view of the rice terrace is amazing!! We went there in the afternoon, it was really very very hot though. It was like the other side of Bali besides beaches and beautiful sunset. We did not enjoy our walk in the terrace, since we were all wearing sandals and flip flop, it was really difficult to walk without a pair of sport shoes! Thus, i recommend you to wear old sport shoes when you pay a visit there, you could be more comfortable while walking and you don't have to worry about your shoes getting dirty! While you follow the path, you will discover several "donation spots", locals would stand there asking for donation, we did pay a small amount when we encounter the first booth, and didnt donate afterwards, some locals would still let you pass through. One more thing to note is that when our driver arrived the "entrance" of the rice terrace, there were (securities?) asking us to pay for rp20000 entrance fee, which was not really expensive, and reasonable for parking! Anyway, it is a good attraction to enjoy another type of beauty of Bali!

Full, but quite cool. A view of the rice field/rice terrace with their irrigation system, which somehow creates an amazing view. Was there on the weekend, so the street was packed with cars & tourist. We only spent 30 - 45 minutes for some pictures.

Great place to relax or get your feet dirty and really enjoy the place. My wife and I were on a private tour and ended up here for lunch, the restaurants were just lovely very laid back literal as you sat on the floor balanise style and had some ok food, with a really serene and beautiful view. Tell you anything would have tasted great with that view. After lunch, we went for a walk in the rice fields and the view just got better and better, worth the hassle and worth the smell of whatever was on that water, it smelt like cow dung and I suspect it was, wear sensible shoes if you are doing this part, not flip flops as my wife did, but well worth the effort

Great View. This was the only touristy thing we did during our six-day visit to Bali. Visit the Tegalalang rice terrace and Kintamani. Mainly because it is the man's first trip to bali, and also because he is a nature buff. So i knew this would be of interest. I have seen countless pictures of the rice terrace while doing my research...and really...you gotta see it in person. AMAZING. We hired a driver for a day, one that came highly rated on tripadvisor, and well lets just say...he must either give caucasians a better service OR we were just unlucky. He wasn't that great...and he definitely took us to places where he gets a commission (which other tripadvisor posters have said he doesn't). But this review isn't about the driver but about the rice terrace and kintamani. We got to the rice terrace at about 9.30am...stunning. It was not flooded with tourist and we did not need to fight for a birds eye view. The place is so peaceful, the view was breathtaking. Tip: Give the restaurants facing the rice padi a miss....very expensive..you are just paying for the view.

Challenging to climb up. Weather during April is terribly hot. We saw someone right opposite (on the rice terrace) so we asked our driver/guide to bring us there! hahahaha wrong move, but it was quite fun thou. Careful of the slippery parts of the small route up & down the terrace.If you happens to see any snake, keep cool. Local says they're harmless. They're there to keep the rats off.

Picturesque view. Nice destination, the padi was green and luscious when i was there, so go grab your camera and go. However, you need to hike up the hills and it is quite dangerous, so do be careful. After the hike, you can enjoy yourself at some of the restaurants there for a meal to cool yourself down, as it's quite hot.

Stunning. The rice terraces are stunning. The best thing I have seen in Bali (although my stay was not too long). It is a short ride from Ubud to Tegallalang and I did not have any problem to park my scooter (it was low season). When you walk the fields (mind your step!) you can get even better views than from the road, especially behind the hill. It is just a little annoying to hand 5000 rupyah to those guys at the checkpoints that claim to be the land owners (who really knows).
it made my day!. trekking through forest, ayung river and rice paddy.... It's healthy and fresh air.. ducks swim and walk around... coffee bean trees..

Gorgeous!. You need to see that, better than Jatiluwih and free! I was on a motorbike with a friend from Ubud, took us 20 minutes to reach and we didn't have to pay anything to admire the terrace, so green and beautiful under the bright sun!

Come early in the morning !! Its AMAZING!!! ♥. After checking reviews from other tourists about tourist traps in Bali we made decision, LETS TRY TO VISIT MUST SEE PLACES IN THE MORNING!! AND ITS WORKED SOOOOO WELL. We came to Tegallalang before 9am. Its just 30min to the North from Ubud. Its was so beautiful and there was no sign of crowds (just one family, was walking around) !!!! The cafes and shops was still close, no one ask for entrance fee or donation, but we donate to one balinese man (5 000rpp each) coz we took some pics with him and his equipment :)) I felt so happy and free at this rice paddies!! It was great experience!!! We took sooo many nice shoots and videos around, and it was only me and my bf on the pics !!!We spent around hour here and its definitely was one of the highlights during our trip to Bali. Its definitely worth visit, and definitely in the morning.

Great view. We stopped here on a day trip to Ubud. My husband wanted to see the terraces and our driver obliged.You need to go through a checkpoint and pay a small amount per person but hopefully this goes into the local economy. There is limited area to park on the side of the road but we were lucky and our driver managed to squeeze into a spot. There are various spots where you can take photos, and a number of shops, cafés and restaurants should you want to stay longer.We only stayed about 15 mins, that was more than enough to take in the view and take a few photos.

Refresh your eves.. Refresh you life... The Best Rice Terrace everr..!! so many great photo spot.. it is all green.. many tourists came here to take the best picture of the terrace.. less parking spot..

Stunning view of rice terraces. One of a must visit when you're in Ubud. My friend and I drove from Sanur with a motornbike. Its quite difficult to find a parking spot (if you're driving with a car) but shouldnt be a problem when you're with a motorbike. Walking down to the bottom part of the rice terraces was a bit deep and slippery. Be careful! You can walk around and can go up on top. Behind the hill, there's a waterfall. I didnt go there but a local guy who sitting on a shack told me. Great view of rice terrace. There are no entrance fees but it seems you're 'force' to do some donation. There are a few 'booth' where local people standing with a sign of donation. Dont forget to bring an umbrella!
Amazing site. The rice terraces are an amazing site - make sure that you visit them. The gifts and food places are expensive though.

Scooter ride to fantastic vistas. loved the scooter ride and hike through the rice fields. You do need to patronize the local farmers with a $1-2 donation for crossing their fields, well worth the endevour.

Narrow Roads. The rice paddies are so lovely to see. The road is very narrow and be patient, traffic and parking maybe a bit of a problem. The area is packed with vendors and cafés. The vendors can be pushy while you are trying to get pictures. This was only slightly distracting from the beautiful views.
Go for the rice terrace at jatiluwih. The rice terrace here is not as impressive as the Jatiluwih rice terrace. And you are unable to walk around the rice terrace unlike the one at Jatiluwih.
Great photos of rice terraces. When I think of Bali, I think of the amazing photos we took at the Rice Terrace. The photos don't show how beautiful the terraces are in person. Amazing views.

Great View!. There are some great viewing points. Driver did have a hard time finding parking place. I was not bothered by vendors while I waited the return of my travel companion. I was not physically able to trek into the rice terrace, but he did. If you wait for someone to make the trek be sure you find a bar/restaurant facing the terrace to wait in. I did not and got too much sun. My travel companion did say their were a few farmers in the field that ask for a donation and we did pay a fee when entering the small village. Well worth the visit. Do not get impatient on your way there. There is not a lot to see on the way, but just be patient.

No parking... Only a glimpse. All i wanted to do on this trip to Bali was see the rice terraces.After a long winding trip in the car on the way to Mt Batur I was really excited to get out of the car and drink in the sights and colour of the rice terraces... Could we get a park? I caught a glimpse of the terraces from our car however there was no parking available for us to pull over and drink in the view. I was so upset.A lesson to us... Don't go in the middle of the day. I assume it would be much quieter first thing in the morning. Parking is extremely limited and does not become available very often. A great disappointment. There's not even anywhere to pull off the road slowly to get a decent look.I will visit again however I will be up and out early to make sure we get a park.

Amazing view and service.. We visited rice terrace during our honeymoon as it wss recommended to us, and it was amazing, breathtaking.
Service was great as 5 star, very special you have to try it.

Beautiful!. If you can't make a trip up to the Jati Luwih UNESCO site, don't feel disappointed, this is a great alternative to seeing the rice paddies in all of their beauty. We stayed around the corner at Villa Sarna, so we were happy to see this view frequently-- but you should definitely make a special trip if you're staying around Ubud. There are a few open air restaurants off the main road that allow you to have a drink or a meal while gazing on the paddies, but just walking off the road down to one of the look out points is also very satisfying. Gorgeous and well worth a visit.

Drink in the colour. The rich green of the terraced rice fields is a sight to be hold. Well worth a visit, but make sure you have a camera. If yours is like mine you will not capture the absolute green of the hills, so sit and drink in the sharpest clean colours you will see in many a day. It is unfortunate that a bar, come hotel (I think), painted in shocking pink, in Tegalalang village disrupts the magnificence of nature.

stunning. I had no plans to see these, as I anticipated something much smaller. However, I had hired a driver for the day to take me to two nearby temples, and he asked if I wanted to see these as well. It would have been a true shame to miss this area - almost as far as the eye can see in any directions is the beauty of green terraces. This has been deemed a UNESCO World Heritage site, and it's clear why. Not only is this area visually beautiful, but it's a crucial part of Bali's culture and economy.

The scope of it is amazing.. Sit at one of the nearby open-air restaurants and take in the view. It's like sitting inside a real life post card. It's super beautiful and it's hard to wrap your mind around the scale. It's giant. Occasionally a worker will appear and you can sort of make out just how small he is on such a wide expanse of green. Just beautiful.
Superb views. I had always wanted to these rice terraces because they are so beautiful. You can stand at the top by the road and look out over them all. Defo worth a trip if you are in Bali.

Beautiful. Amazing views over these rice terraces, landscaped beautifully hard to believe that they are Padi fields. There is a stop point before you enter the location and a small charge is made but you can spend as long there as you wish, great photo opportunities to be had. There are some souvenir shops, but they weren't pushy and even when you went in but didn't buy anything they were pleasant. There are cafes with great views too. Well worth a visit.

Amazing scenery in Bali. I was so looking forward to visit this place, & it didn't disappoint me :) .. The rice terrace is BEAUTIFUL & spread on a vast area .. It's definitely worth a visit, especially in the morning, when it's still quiet & empty .. There are some cafes for a quick drink or so, & other souvenirs shops ..

Excellent view, but not any vendors. The rice terrace its self is beautiful, you'll be able to see the whole field form the top. You choose to go down the rice field and actually "get into" the picture, but roads down can be muddy and slippery so be careful if you do so. However, the vendors (Cafes, restaurants, souvenir shops, random kiosks) are super pricey and can be quite pushy. Whatever you decide to do, unless you're gonna spend lunch there I higly recommend to skip your purchase there.

Gorgeous views of the padi terraces...amazing sceneries. Really gorgeous views of nature in its real form..Amazing sceneriesMorning are best times to visit the tegalalang padi fields..in the evening the crowds are a bit busy..Nice views also further up where they have Argo tourism attractions,the coffee and ginger tea fields..10 minutes further up from tegalalang pdi terraces...
Love the rice terrace but not the shops. The rice terrace very good and picturesque but poor Tegalalang, there is too many shops surrounding makes the sense no natural anymore.

Well worth the trip!. Highly recommended to spend some relaxing time sipping a Bintang beer and having Nasi Goreng with a beautiful backdrop of the green rice fields below. Unfortunately they don't have the restaurant we ate,but was the best Nasi Goreng in the trip, all should be good.

Amazing view!. Had a short visit to the rice terrace, which was truly amazing. Loved the view, the lush green rice terraces. When you get out of your car be careful with children surrounding you trying to sell postcards and stuff. They can be a bit pushy. Highly recommeded.On the way you can stop in the small shops selling wood, ceramic art, mirrors, lamps etc.

Trip to Bali. This was an incredibly beautiful place to go. The views are nothing short of spectacular. There are numerous places to have some refreshment before or after the trek to the bottom. I would recommend making the walk down to there just to see the changing views. It is worth the effort to do that but if you have ANY difficulty in mobility, then I would strongly recommend looking at it from the top. It is nothing more than terraces of rice but it is truly beautiful. I hope to go back again someday if for no other reason than just to sit and look at the scenes before me.

Nice to see. Had a 15 minutes stop to see how Balinese to plant their rice. Worth to paid 5,000 Rp in order see such a good view, but no worth to pay 20,000 Rp to the local to take photo together. Lots of local hawker sells craft and paints.

Third visit and still just as breathtaking as ever. This was my third visit to Tegalalang rice terraces, and quite frankly I don't think you could ever get sick and tired of the vista.When I first visited five years ago, you were mobbed by hawkers the minute you left your vehicle, and the experience was soured by this, however in recent years the local village have put a small entry fee on each person arriving (about $2.00AU) and they have cleared the hawkers out. There are still plenty of opportunities to purchase goods from the local stores and there are a myriad of restaurants with million dollar views to eat your lunch.A recommendation is to head back to Ubud via Tegalalang and Mas villages to see the local crafts and handiwork.Highly recommended if in Bali

Beautiful, dreamy valley.... Hired a car for the day and took us to many places including the rices terraces in Ubud. We came in from Batur in the north down into Ubud. Up to the terraces the roads were lined with small shops specializing in wood sculptures, glass sculptures and hand woven products. On the street above the rice terraces was a small street also lined with restaurants and shops where you can buy souvenirs, hats, shirts, etc. don't be afraid to haggle prices! From the street you can take some great pictures of the green terraces below. We went after harvest so the crops were just planted. Locals said that it looks more beautiful when the rice is matured but seeing all the terracing and the traditional irrigation system that they employ might not be as clearly seen with matured rice. All in all a place definitely worth visiting!

beautiful terraces. Had a short stop for lunch here and took some photos. Was able to see the small cave that was used to hide rice during the Japanese control of Bali. There are some of the typical shops selling the same things you see all over Bali. The terraces themselves are very pretty, our guide said they are even more beautiful just before harvesting.

You have got to get in amongst nature. There is nothing quite like a relaxng walk through cool paddy fields. It is very calming and you feel like you could stay for hours. We enjoyed the experince during a tour with Bali Bliss Tours. The day was amazing and one we will never forget.

Beautiful view of rice terrace!. Nice place to get great view of rice terrace! Just walked along the road and grabbed some pictures! Lots of restaurants nearby where you can enjoy the meal while enjoying the view of the rice terrace!

Touristy Terrace. Although it's scenic unfortunately the rice terrace of ubud is over-run by hawkers. It takes the ambience away when an aged woman selling fruit in traditional baskets across the shoulders then bumps you constantly asking for 'photo, photo'. Alos we were told USD3 for 1 durian!You're better off driving along a rural road back into Ubud township whereby you pass other authentic rice fields in abundance just not of the terrace style.
visit on perfect month. I visit this on January and the paddies has just harvested, it's still green but it's better to see maybe other months before it's harvested

Good to see. We stopped here on our day out, was a fantastic sight to see, not much rice growing at the moment, bet it looks fantastic when there is..Few shops n places to eat there, we were there 20-30 mins, great to stop n see, 5 kRp, entry fee, which is nothing.Afterwards we called to Bali pulina, get yourself a visit, so tranquil with good rice terrace view n good coffee!! Highly recommended !!!

Beautiful. There are so many rice fields in bali and this one is amazing. Great place to take photos. ..there are restaurants on the hill so you can have a drink and look out over the rice fields....the markets there are nice and have a few different things. Worth a look... try to go when the rice is greens as it is sooooo beautiful then

Worth a stop for photos. There are many rice fields around Bali, but this is the go-to spot for photos. The entrance fee as you drive in is minimal & worth it. There are many small shops & cafe's where you could stop, relax & have some coffee & tea. Take some photos & be on your way. All in all, this is a 30-45min stop max.

Rice cultivation. A pretty sight, good photo opportunity, but nothing to cry about if you don't have the time to visit. Ubud is full of rice fields where you can appreciate similar going ons of rice cultivation, albeit not on terraces of such heights. I was charged an entrance fee of 5k rupiah, which my driver tells me does not go to the rice farmers anyway. Perhaps it goes to the maintenance of the little tourist huts that line the facing slope where one can chill and just spend the day watching the farmers go about their business.. May I suggest Bali Pulina instead? You get the same scene, with a nicer hut and coffee to boot.

Rice Paddies. The rice paddies is a attraction that one should visit but personally i didn't find them that fascinating. Our driver took us up high where we could see a vast view of the rice paddies which was a wonderful view but It isnt somewhere where I would spend more than 30 minutes.

Picturesque but predictable. The day we visited, it was drizzling and no sign of ending. It was quite dangerous for one to move around as you might risk falling. The rice terrace was something new to me, compared to tea terrace in Cameron Highland. The way the paddy field was organized was impressive and picturesque. However it was hard to appreciate when it rained.
Beautiful countryside. Loved seeing the locals bathing in the river and working in the rice fields!!! Great to see the real Bali.
Worth visiting. Really interesting. Although it was smaller than I expected. But a great way to see how the locals 'manage' the rice plantations.

Amazing Rice Terace. Amazing mount terraces . Must be visited . It is very close to Ubud
Stop at Aman Resort for a drink on your way back

Serene beauty. This was one of the places on our to-do list in Bali and we were not disappointed. In spite of the slight drizzle that accompanied our visit, we were just mesmerized by the view of the lush and green terraced rice fields. It was a breathtaking sight, so serene and peaceful. The rice terraces are located below the road level but there are steps leading down to the paddy fields for those who want to see the fields up close. Photo opportunities abound and we even had a chance to take pictures with a rice farmer complete with his grass hat and baskets. Do give the locals a small tip if you wish to take photos with them. There are some restaurants with views overlooking the rice terraces but we did not visit them. Plenty of small kids trying to sell you trinkets and postcards but they were not particularly pushy. These kids were just trying to supplement their family's income by selling stuff to tourists. This place is definitely a must-go only to see the magnificent rice fields and the rural beauty of Bali.

Beautiful. This a great place to relax and doing small exercise by getting down,crossing a small river and drinking a coconut water.You may sitting down at coffee shop and enjoy the nice view or having lunch after coming from Ubud sightseeing or on the way to Kintamani (Mt Batur) .

Plan your lunch here. The rice terraces here are just breathtaking. There are some restaurants on the slope that serves lunch, snacks, juices, beers etc. do plan your lunch here and find your self lost gazing and soaking in the beauty of rice terraces of Tegallalang

Amazing people. We went there for a day trip on our own, meet a local friend who showed us the way through the terraces, then drink some coconut water with him in his warung just outside his house and he give us some kopi coffee to taste. People here were the most friendly we met in our Bali trip

The miracle of life at Ubud's rice terrace fields. While staying in Ubud, the incredible town in the Balinese mountains, please do not miss visiting the rice terrace fields. Otherwise, you'll regret forever ... Very scenic, very green and totally peaceful. You'll surely be fascinated by Ubud's rice terrace fields, the opportunity of witnessing the miracle of daily life and the importance of feeding people. Be aware of vendors, they'll do their best to catch your attention. Enjoy!

Small Rice Terrace. Came here for a day trip while in Ubud, a nice place but not really impressive as it is quite small. Good to have a nice lunch or meal there enjoying the sceneries. Be prepared when taking photographs with the locals there as they may demand you to give them some money if you took a picture of them.Jatiluwih rice field are much more impressive and bigger as compared to this.

Worth the drive and take your time. Take your time once you get there. There are plenty of shops to indulge in or take a walk down to the terrraces to experience the vertical rice terrraces and the irrigation system that delivers life to these parts of the land.

Lovely scenery!. Been here just once and as a first timer and a local, i am quite happy to visit this small area. Dont imagine it as a big huge massive rice terraces since this is quite a small area (roughly less than 1km long - if you are planning to walk the road. I hope you could understand what i mean). But this is something different and beautiful. The place is not crowded as the monkey forrest road ubud so you could just sit back, order a cup of bali coffee and enjoy the rice terrace scenery. There are few souvenirs shop and let me tell you that their prices are cheaper than the monkey forrest or kuta (of course).Quite happy to came here and able to take pictures of the scenery. Recommended for first time visitors, family or group of travelers.

Great scenery. We visited this place as one of the stops in our day trip tour. The view was breathtaking as the terraces were lush and green with newly planted paddy. We were lucky as we missed the harvest and planting seasons so timing is important when visiting this place. One can also hike down down some stairs and through the fields.As it is a tourist attraction be prepared to be accosted to buy touristy bits and bobs.

Great view from above!. My friends and I hired a driver during our stay in Bali and Tegallalang Rice Terrace was one of the places we went to. We didn't stay there for very long because we has a hard time climbing down the steep slopes, so we took a number of pictures from the top before leaving. But the view from the top was really good! You'll see greenery all over and layers of fields there.

I've been seen better rice terraces. I was bit disappointed. The terraces are nice, but not as spectacular as we expected. I lived in the countryside when I was little, so rice terraces are not something foreign for me, and I've seen better terraces back my home country. If you need to use the public restroom there, you have to pay 3000 Rupiahs, kinds of rip-off...
Nice rice terrace. Tegalalang one of the best rice terrace in bali, all green view and also you can walk down to rice field to see exactly balinise rice, absolutely awesome

Most spectacular rice terraces. We went to these rice terraces as part of a day trip to udud. WOW they were amazing. We had lunch at one of the many restaurants overlooking the terraces which was great. If you want to see rice terraces then make sure you don't miss these ones and do it at lunch time. Terraces are about 20mins from ubud.

Amazing view. We visited these rice fields on our last daytrip in bali. I liked it much more than Jatiluwih (that we visited on our first daytrip). You can get much closer to the rice fields than Jatiluwih, but therefore the view isn't as panoramic as Jatiluwih. We saw some people walking in the fields with a guide. The rice fields are next to the road and there is a row of little shops between the road and the rice fields. You get a good view of the fields when you step down to the "balcony" of the shops.
Amazing views. The rice terraces are amazing. It's best to leave enough time so that you can sit and have a drink or meal at one of the many cafés on the edge of the terrace - it's beautiful

Absolutely Amazing!. I was expecting a rather average experience but arriving at the Rice Terraces proved a breath-taking view. I was apprehensive that we may have picked the wrong time of year to visit however the terraces were perfectly lush and green. There's also plenty of dining options which overlook the rice terraces. Really a picturesque experience!
Green! Green! Green!. Very scenic. Walk down to the paddy field if you can though the road is a bit steep. Its worth exploring. Anyway, unfavorable for elderly and too young travellers.

Worth the drive. We were staying in Nusa Dua, and hired a driver for the long drive to Tegallalang Rice Terraces. It was very crowded with a lot of tourists, but well worth the drive for the fantastic photo opportunities at some of the most scenic rice terraces I have seen. I have been the Sapa in Vietnam which did not compare to the beauty of Tegallalang.

Too touristy. I think someone from Southeast Asia like me would not enjoy this place very much. Over-expectation. Terrible traffic, very touristy, we could hardly find a place to sit and relax and wind down.
Marvellous. The terraces was indeed awesome. I love the view. I hiked down the stairs dan through the fields.Indeed, it was a good visit. Excellent.

Great views. Advantages;Great views, totally different from Jatiluwih Rice PaddiesDisadvantages; Farmers asking for 'donations' to climb around certain parts of the terraces; although I was more inclined to pay this than the entrance fee as they are likely in more need of it! Touristy; I didn't bother walking around the top road of the terraces as it was lined with tourist shops

Majestic Must Do!. Our driver from Viceroy Bali took us on the short trip to the Tegalalang rice terraces. We went first thing in the morning, 7 a.m., to beat the heat and the crowds. The setting is majestic. Our driver hiked us down the stairs, and through the fields. The walk is not easy, and I fell twice. My spouse took only one tumble. I eventually took off my footwear, and went barefoot, which was much easier! One warning - if you have a fear of heights, there are a couple of fearful places, But I managed, even with some vertigo. Prepare to get a bit dirty, and to trip a few times. That being said, the bruises were so worth it. The Balinese people who work in the fields are so friendly and pleasant. We also hiked up to the Temple within the fields. I cannot express just how beautiful it is. A little slice of real Balinese life. One last reminder, all those stairs and hills that you go down, will be waiting for you on the way back up! Bring water, and a sweat towel! This trip is an absolute must do!

Great photos but hike with care. We were lucky. The drive was fair going but traffic back to our hotel in nusa dua was rough. About 2 hrs on return leg mostly due to traffic in ubud.The walk through the terraces was tricky in some places. Slippery and narrow in some parts. A few times I had to jump over water and land on a narrow wooden plank. I had no problem, but The women in high heels and people with balance and fitness challenges may want to think twice.I was hit up by two 10 yo girls offering a guided tour for 50k. at first I said no, but they were very emphatic that I gave it to them. I don't think I would have hiked the terraces as thoroughly and I know I was overcharged but I got some really good pics that I might not have had otherwise.We did pay a fee to the police as we pulled up 10k.
Beautiful. We didn't actually been here cos we were in the car only pass by but it is so beautiful. I think Oct is a good season to visit there!
Good view. Very good view and we really enjoy the trip to ubud however the traffic was very bad. Dont forget to bring the camera !!!

Stunning Views. Lovely views of rice terrace, but beware, if you are looking for a peaceful walk through the terrace, you've got another thing coming. The path down to the terrace isn't well marked, and when you get to the "bridge" beware of the old man charging an extra 50,000 "entry fee" to walk the terrace. It's a scam. We didn't fall for it, but many did. That said, it's worth a look. Spend a half day in the area and you'll be mesmerized by local life.

A crowded view of nice rice terraces. The view of terraces is really nice, if perhaps not as spectacular as I'd been hoping and expecting. But, wow, is the road traffic congested! Once you finally get up there and get your vehicle parked and you get back to your desired viewpoint somewhere there along the road, it's nice. As expected in Bali, there is no shortage of tourist shops lining the road to meet your needs, but they don't really interfere with the view.
Lovely scenery!. It's good to have this one included in your day tour of the Ubud area. This one offers a nice view of the rice terraces.

Interesting. Terraces are more interesting than most in other countries as they are readily available and follow modern cultivation methods. This country want to be self sustaining as to food and there is a rapidly growing population so they have taken advice and support from the worlds experts. Impressive response to an internal need.
Beautiful. Traffic sucked but it was worth it. It made me think of the ancient Mayan civilization. If you don't check it out while in Ubud you have missed out.

experince. It wiil be gret experince, if you come n do treking in rice terace.
The cost was not realy expensive..you will fell frest wather,with green of ricen pady
Breathtaking!. Lovely place... Would be great if there's a cafe there to chill in with a nice cup of coffee while taking in the beautiful landscape :)...

A Picture Perfect Spot. We stopped here early on our day tour around the surrounding areas if Ubud. Before 10am. The view is spectacular. This early though the sun was on the wrong place for shooting perfect shots. When we were there it was quiet. Howe er can imagine that as the day goes on it gets very very busy as was full of restaurants and tourist shops. Would suggest an early visit.

Nice rice terrace scene. Stopped by for this on our way to another destination. The rice terrace view is marvelous, which its the reason for the crowd here. Souvenir shops were all around the small roadside. We are allowed to walk down the rice terrace but better be cautious for the slippery especially after raining. Overall, its still a worth place to visit.

Absolutely Beautiful. We cycled here from Ubud, and though it was an effort, the result was definitely worth it. The views are amazing, like something out of a dream or a video game. You have to pinch yourself since you can't believe that something could be so beautiful. As to all of the hawkers, this happens everywhere and it didn't really bother us. Truly somewhere to go to just marvel at how beautiful practical things can be.
Amazing views. Of course, they are really touristic, and you can find similar terraces with less tourists in Banaue, Philippines, but these are nevertheless breathtaking....

Beautiful. You can walk down the small paths and marvel at this Beautiful rice terrace! Its in so many shades of green your Eyes start to hurt. its very impressive too. make sure you have good shoes , its slippery. A camera is a must!The farmers take small fees for passing their terrace, may it be a small bridge or something. Bring small amount of cash for this.Truly a nice spot!

Quite disappointed !!!. I had seen rice terraces in Sapa Vietnam before going to Bali and very excited to see Tegalalang terraces. But I was really disappointed with this sight, Rice terrace is tiny and crowded, cannot be compared with the huge and pristine terraces in Northern Vietnam and China. It's ok if you have never seen rice terraces before but if you visited Vietnam or China, it would be a disappointing visit.

Thought it was cool, timing is everything.. The tegalalang rice terraces was quite a unique experience and a photographers dream.PROS:-Our driver (Bali Ari Tour) suggested we should go early in the morning and he was right, not crowded at all.. good temperature.-The rice terraces are serene and beautiful-Lots of photo ops here, with angles everywhere- Not many hawkers inside-Enjoyed a coconut inside for about 1000 rupiahCONS:-Little fees or donations (about 3) (3000-8000rp)-Not enormous like some pictures imply-No history or reading about siteBottomline: Cool place with great unique views for barely any money. Go early in the morning. If you have seen other large rice terraces.. this may be dissapointing as it is not huge.

touristic and crowed place!definitely to be avoided!. We've been brought here by our driver, had to pay a small fee for entering the road(the men asking for money where in the middle of the road, not letting any car passing through without having paid for the fee before). The terrace are on one side of the road, on the other side of the hill. There are heaps of shops, all selling the same souvenirs. he view is nice, but because it's a so touristic place, it's just over crowed! And We are not sure they still use these terraces for growing rice, we had the feeling they just keep them for tourists to go, pay, have a quick look and that's it. It's definitely something to avoid, especially because there are so many and better rice fields all around Bali that it's really stupid going there and paying to see something that it's everywhere else and free. For example, we've been driving from Semyniak to Tulamben and unexpectedly we passed through this amazing and huge rice cultivation, without paying for any fee and without being in the middle of the most crowed part of Bali!We also had amazing rice fields just outside our hotel in Ubud, so have a look on internet and look for the closest rice fields or the one that you can see driving around the island!

Best rice paddies. Although there are plenty of rice terraces in Bali this is really beautiful and different from the rest. On the walk down to the rice terraces you will get children trying to get you to buy postcards however they're just trying to earn some money and if you're polite and say no they will go away. The place is great for photos and worth a stop if you are passing by

nice rice terrace. This place is our 2nd choice after jatiluwih, Tabanan. We can call this the mini version of jatiluwih. But this is something that you don't want to miss while you traveling in Ubud. Easy to reach, not so far from the Ubud city center, maybe only 3 - 5 KM away. There is a lot of art shop to buy some souvenir, and some restaurant with a good view of rice terraces.Suggestion : - If you drive your own car, find a parking spot may be a problem. The road is narrow and crowded with many drivers waiting for the tourist beside the road. But no worries, you can park a little bit far and walk back to this place
Should not be missed. These rice terraces are amazing. The work that must have gone into creating them defies imagination. Nice places to sit, relax and have a cooling drink.
Nice View. Visitors should not miss this place in their travelling agendas as it is really a nice place to sit down have a meal or just coffee and enjoy the splendour of its view!!

Unforgettable View - Simply Stunning!. We never knew what was in store for us on our way there, but it was worth every second of the traffic jam. Ticket vendors would sell tickets through car windows and that somewhat cleared the traffic uphill a bit.As soon as we arrived, we saw that all the action was down the valley. So we went down some steps, found a shop, extricated ourselves away from the persistent shopkeeper, landed on the entrance to an eatery with private verandahs, and finally saw the paddy in all its majesty.Just one word should suffice. WOW!We quickly took all the pictures we wanted and then wound down at that hillside bar. We ate ice-cream and drank coconut juice. For some reason the menu was also in Japanese. We did see a lot of Chinese-looking tourists, just that we couldn't be sure of which country they were from. The menu clued us in. There were toilets and a praying room for Muslims. We could see some visitors actually going down to the paddy fields themselves for a true hands-on, or rather, feet-on experience. Earlier on we actually sat at one of the verandahs on a nice sofa for picture-taking and to tell you the truth there was nowhere better to be at that moment than that very spot. For the first time we weren't bothered about what time it was, what could be selling at the shops and what else was there to see. Honestly, we never wanted to leave.Truly words could not describe what we saw and we shall never forget it. Thank you Bali for giving us one of the best times of our lives!

Gorgeous view. The view here is amazing. Just gorgeous to sit and admire. Although, unless you go into one of the little cafe / coffee shops down the steps off the road, you will get approached by hawkers and shop owners selling their wares. Certainly a lot busier than the last time I visited, but still worth the visit.

Great views. Incredible views. Lots of tourists lots of hawkersThere is a fee to enter area on road. 5,000 per tourist. We went down between shops to see better views - all the shops etc block the views from the road. Traffic is even more chaotic due to narrow road and random parking.There are great views from further up the road and superb views of other less incredible rice terraces nearby. The amount of work to create these is mind boggling.There are rice fields all over the place!
Beautiful Views. Very picturesque views of the rice terraces. Don't forget the camera! We had the best views from inside one of the shops below the road level.
Rice fields. It used to be very nice to visit it but now so many shops are there, so a bit disapointed for me this time
Nice for pictures. Though, it just look likes a miniature form of the Philippines' Banaue Rice Terraces, it still a delight to visit this place.

This was worth the visit. You know how sometimes tour guides and travel experts will tell you that you must visit here or there, and sometimes you are mildly disappointed or perhaps very very disappointed. Well, this is not one of those places! We had such a great time here and were able to get some fantastic shooting opportunities or the photographers in our group. The local people were so sweet and posed for pictures. Some of the local children were selling postcards, which we really didn't want. So instead we sat and had tea at the restaurant overlooking the rice terraces and asked them to dance some of their local dances for us. They were so adorably cute and were happy to dance for us. We of course paid them the same amount we would have bought the cards for, and insisted we really didn't want the postcards, much to their surprise!

Impressive view so nearby. The beauty of rice terraces depends on the stage. Most picturesque (I think) when water is evident. Least when close to or just after harvest. This area was more impressive during my visit than the World Heritage listed terraces at Jatiluwih (although they were larger). Well worth a visit.

Worth visiting. One of the best views of rice terraces I saw during my visit to Bali. Don't go only for this attraction, but if it on the way don't miss it.You can enjoy some drinks and food and watching the terrace.

A sight not to be missed. Tegallalang Rice Terrace is a sight that is not to be missed when in Bali. The paddy are planted in the terrace of a small hill slope. There are also other crops besides paddy. This is my second visit to the Tegallalang Rice Terrace. Plenty of visitors, crowding to take photographs. However. during this trip, I find that the terrace are not so lush as compared to my previous visit.

Astounding rice terraces!. Been here three times and seen the development and progress of this amazing place. There was nothing here five years ago except the stunning rice terraces but nowadays a lot of shops and restaurants available along the 1km - 2km stretch and still the rice terraces remained intact.A must must visit place and take your time enjoying the astounding view!

Beautiful sight. This is a beautiful place if you have time to spend walking through the field and chilling out at one of the many small local cafes along the field. However, if you intend to just touch, shot and go, then this place is a bit too far if you are coming from places like Kuta, Seminyak. Nevertheless, if this is a point along your planned itinerary, do make it a must to stop by for at least an hour. There is a small entrance fee and the place can be really crowded.
Fantastic way to start the day. Had a wonderful morning walk from our hotel (Puri Sunia) around the local rice paddies some very narrow paths and can be a bit slippery but lots of fun

Tegalalang Rice Field. We stopped by this place after the rice harvest so the rice field look bare. My guide said this place is very nice before the harvest and I believe him. There are so many shops selling the usually tourist stuff in this area. There are also a couple of coffee shops where you can get a cup of coffee and sit and look at the rice field. The price at the coffee shops is very reasonable.We only stayed for 20 minutes at Tegalalang. This is quite an interesting place to visit if you are in the Ubud area.

A little disappointing. Firstly, the reason behind the disappointment was that the rice had been harvested so I'd advise going in the growing season. That said, the drive was interesting in that there are no sign posts and without a GPS you see much of the island on the way. All the more enjoyable then when you do arrive. Suggest having lunch at one of the many restaurants overlooking the terraces. Considering it's prime tourist country, lunch was only $20 for two of us. Worth a trip as it's a lovely drive with lots of shopping places on the way and lots of lovely views.
Rice fields. Beautiful view of Bali and Filipino rice fields very serene, very good restaurants near by to eat at.

green everywhere. I have seen tea gardens in layers but these rice terraces were touching the soul. We reached there and was just a sprinkle of rain, added to the beauty of these terraces. the view was heart warming and joyful. We had a lunch there and view was just fabulous. There were many restaurant with perfect view, good food and nice setting. There were also few shops for shopping. The shades of green were cooling the eyes and giving joy.
A must in Bali. The view is spectacular, seems like in the middle of nowhere, although without any warning we were asked to pay for the parking (for a motorbike left next to the souvenir shop).
Hmmmm.. If you've seen one rice paddy, you've seen them all. They are all over Bali. Your missing nothing. But. You should still go if it's a part of your tour.
Somewhere there. A local drivers took us to this spot where one can see an amazing rice paddy. A bit of the tourist trap but when in Rome

A sight to behold. I loved visiting this beautiful section of the world. After passing through streets filled, one after the other, with shops displaying art and giftware we came to the terraced rice paddies. Because at this time (mid May) most of the rice is being harvested I was afraid that we would only see muddy flats where rice had been. We lucked out and even though the workers were bundling the rice stalks there was still plenty of lush greenery. It is picture worthy and breathtaking. I chose to ignore the shopkeepers who were interested in selling their goods but they were nice and not bothersome. On the way back we topped at an Eco-agriculture place that featured tea and coffee as well as spices grown in this region. It was quite interesting and - free! It even included a free sampling of the various teas and coffees. We tipped the guide but it was clearly not mandatory. There is a gift shop there where you can buy the ones you liked.

Fabulous view!. Photographers dream place. Lots of nice angles to take postcard like pictures. The place is very nice. I wish we hiked around but it was raining. If you have time to hike I think it is worth it, bring shoes that can get muddy. The place is not necessarily peaceful, very touristy and tons of people trying to sell you stuff. But if you have a chance to hike to the other side of the terrace you might find lots of peace there. The stop is definitely worth it. We had to pay a few parking/road access fees to get to the site. I think around 20,000 rupiah, so plan ahead and ENJOY!

nice view but very packed. we went in the noon right before lunch. the view was nice, but the area was jammed pack with cars. We spent longer time trying to get into and out from the place compare than time we spent to enjoy the view.

Beautiful. Well worth the 2 hour drive to see these rice terraces - they are beautiful. We enjoyed some Kopi Lewak coffee and sat and enjoyed the views whilst drinking fresh fruit juice - it was a lovely 3/4 hour bit of quiet time in Bali.

Lunch at rice fields. good place to have lunch, but the rice terrace is very commercial place, a bit disappointed as we cant see the true life style of rice field which you may need to go further. need to bArgain 2/3 from original price to get things here. still the price would be high...

Good but contrived. Beautiful terraces lined with strip-mall like stores and restaurants. Not very peaceful or relaxing as there are many stores and people tugging at your purse strings. The image of the farmer walking back and forth with empty work utensils in front of the restaurants asking people to photograph him (for $$ of course) so you could have a real Balinese experience, was priceless. The terraces are beautiful, the rest gimmicky. Beware of the "postcard" girl! She's probably 9 or 10 and could sell Donald Trump real estate. She will charm your money right out of your pocket leaving you to walk away scratching your head as to why you just paid $5 for postcards you neither want or need! Yes, she's that good. And the giggle you get walking away knowing you've just been had is well worth it. Absolutely memorable
Spectacular view!. Loved the tour and spectacular views of the rice fields. Worth going to if you visit Bali.Contrast of colours and atmosphere was just so amazing.
Average food with nice view. nice rice field terrace for view or walking track with our lovely person(s) on cool and calm of Tegalalang - Ubud nature
Gorgeous setting. Yes, this place is not exactly touristy, but the view in itself is worth a million dollars. Have never seen anything as green as the rice terraces. Majestic!

Obligatory stop. Like all can't miss places in Bali (and elsewhere), you know you'll not be alone! And you'll be requested contribution from some farmers: I think they deserve to complement their income, so half dollar isn't too much. If you want to walk through the paddy fields, start from the bottom, and turn right, in the small valley out to the beaten track. The passage is not for tourist, and a bit slippery... but you'll be alone and ... worth the inconvenience. The restaurants with view on the hill are great... but remember that the sunset is the other way! :-)

Beautiful terrace but shame about the touristy set up. I loved the beauty of the rice terraces, but row of many vendors and tour vans made it feel very touristy. If organized better, the vendors could be relocated to a nearby locale while the vans should be given a parking area instead of trying to squeeze alongside the already narrow road at the top of the terrace.

Did one free from the Hotel Uma!. This was a short pre-breakfast walk of about 1 1/2 hours starting from the hotel Uma and visiting the organic gardens of the Pulau Kepala (excellent restaurant) and then on into the rice paddies.Great fun and with a knowledgeable guide very educational. Recommended you do a Paddy walk

terrific. Wowonly use Wow thereamazing , excellent , ... and other words can't use there and if you don't visit there you waste your time and money in Bali i don't know to use what kind of sentence but if you go there because of this writing remind me there
Unforgettable. The unique landscape will stay in my mind forever. Amazing colours. One of the most symbolic images of Bali.

very good for photography. the greens here are spectacular - and especially at low season (when I went), it's great for photography without too many people crowding the landscape. I see now that the fields are artificial - but I think it's alright. You see padi fields on the sides of roads in bali anyway, and it's rather nice to see what they could have been. The souvenir stores by the rice terraces are pretty typical, but aren't too expensive so it might be good to get souvenirs here!photos here: http://andmorefood.wordpress.com/2013/04/01/ubud-rice-fields-bali/
Great view. Great views. You can take a lot of pictures. If you have a tour guide ask him to please take you down into the rice fields...

Great for photos. It's a great rice terrace - it's like a park - they maintain it to look nice, so you'll definitely get some great photos. It is a tourist attraction not a farming field. You have to pay 5000 IDR per person for entry and if you decide to walk the terraces some farmers may ask you for money too, but you don't have to pay them all (use your own judgement). We enjoyed our visit there - the views were amazing!

Small Scenic Rice Terrace but the Greatest I Saw. A small entrance fee is asked to access the terrace. You will have to take some stairs down to get the bast angle view. Deep green terrace, with lots of palm trees, very typical of what you can see on postcards. I found it to be much more beautiful than the Jatiluwih one. A must-see I have to say, very close from Ubud.

When in Bali.... Beautiful scenery, couldn't be any greener!It't definitely one of the to do things when in Bali, and you can tell why as soon as you see it. You can easily get a cab to drive you there and back to where you're staying from anywhere in Bali reasonably cheap (provided you do all the bargaining first, of course).There's not a lot to do once you're there, except taking pictures, but it's definitely worth visiting.

Green, nice, but very touristy. I think a rice terrace is almost always spectacular by definition. These are no exception. Just know that also here the tourist industry knows to find you. That's OK and please do spend your money with the locals, but don't expect to be alone here. Try to go into the fields to get the best out of it, or even better: book yourself a night at Saudara Home (see my review).

Very beautiful. These fields are in a beautiful setting with lots of palm trees. They are not the biggest in Bali, but it would be hard to say any others are prettier. You can walk down from the road in a couple places to get slightly different views. There is a little restaurant right there where you can sit down with a Bintang (good local beer) while you enjoy the view. The 5,000 Rp fee is about 50 cents, so there is technically an entrance fee, but if that is too much, you can see it pretty well from the road and save your money.
Photo stop landmark. It's a landmark for photo stop - amazing paddy view... if you get down to the paddy field, the entrance fee is IDR 5,000/person.
Simple, but pretty rice fields. For someone who lives in South Asia or Southeast Asia rice terraces are not so fascinating but in their own simple way can be quite pretty.

A view that Calm you Down.. I was here yesterday, following my trip to Ubud. Me and my friend decide to go to this place to enjoy its beauty and take a breathtaking picture of the nature. After almost 8 km drive from Ubud (just drive straight , following the main road from ubud to tegal alang (take a left turn from Arjuna statue in Ubud)) we finally saw the sign of 'welcome to Ceking-Tegal Alang rice terrace view, about 1-2 min drive we found some local administrator who collected the fee 1 pax Rp.5000,.We then have to found a place to parked our motorbike, as it was sunday and many visitors, and this place has no special parking lot due to its location (hills). We then found a place to parked our motorbike, take a little walk to the observatory bridge, then take a picture, the observatory bridge is less than 500 metres i guess. Yes, there is many cafes, and art shops, but you can always find a nice spot to view and enjoy the magnificient beauty of nature, or take a picture. From my experiences the sellers is not pushy like you might find in some other places in Bali. The minus so far for me its the parking lot, but then due to its location its quite hard to build decent parking lot.If you happen to be here from your trip to Kintamani or Ubud, spent arround 30 minutes to enjoy the magical scenary, dont forget your Camera, this is the view you will regret to not capture before back to your country.
nice rice terrance view. nice view, you can also take a tour thru the fields. Cheaper just go in Ubud to the rice fields 15 minutes from UBUD palace to get a cheap tour of a local farmer.

Since when looking at rice field requires payment?. We were leaving for Ubud from Kuta, and the taxi driver agreed for 200,000 rupiah. Asked if could stop at rice terrace and he agreed for no cost.A bit shocked at first when asked for 'entrance fee' - i've been to so many places, but was never asked to pay for something that is 5 minutes thing. But not too much, it was only 5,000 rupiah a head.The amount will not make me poor, but overly entreprenurship of Balinese people is shocking and turning every step we are making. They are now willing to do anything, just to make money.Only visit if you want you have 20 mins spare time and word of advice - the best way to avoid getting harrased by the sellers is to be quiet because if you say 'no thank you' then they know theyn can approach you!

Don't let others dissuade your visit!. I'm writing this because someone else wrote a review comparing this to Disneyland. WHAT?! Untrue. Yes, you have to pay an entrance fee but c'mon, it's 5000 rupiah! Only 50 cents! We also noticed that most people stopped at the beginning where all the shops and vendors were, without really seeing the real views much further in. We hiked all the way down and to the far back fields; we were the only ones there, balanced on the edge of tiers of tiers of magnificent, dazzling green! And yes, to go back a little farther they request a donation/fee- but all together it's still less than a dollar. (perspective) If you really want it to yourself, trek it while it's raining. Word of warning though- all the trails become a great series of mudslides. I slipped once and got quite a slide ride. I hauled myself up, covered almost head to toe in mud, not able to stop laughing. It gave me a good excuse to buy a new skirt at one of the shops :-)

one of the best view in bali. watching these rice terraces is one of my favourite activities when i go to bali. always makes me feel so blessed being there. it calms ur mind,emotions, and refreshing all the mood. so peaceful

Don't stand at the edge - Walk it!!. We absolutely loved it here. We were THE ONLY people walking the rice terraces, most tourists stopped at the edge where there were shops and restaurants. Our driver showed us how to get down to the small tracks and we walked down to the small old bridge and up the other side. If we didn't walk it I would still say spectacular views but by walking it we will remember it as one of the best parts of our trip. Its very muddy and trashy beginning the walk but the benefit of the tranquillity and views is so worth it. Not that difficult of a walk but if you are not confident or a bit unsteady maybe just do a small section.

Endearing...to a certain extent. First thing first - there's an entrance fee based on per person basis to pay prior to visit - to see paddy fields that is. The hotel I stayed in Ubud were facing the paddy field the whole 3 days I was there *chuckles*Truth to be told - the Tegalalang rice terraces were a sight to behold. It's like a work of art. Albeit a charging one. Lol.Visit this place if you're visiting the main tourist spots on the island on your daily trips.Personally, there are more cuisine surprise on the island than sightseeing has to offer.

beautiful rice terrace but too small. rice terrace in tegalalang were beautiful but unfortunately it is too small for something you have to pay for if it just for sighseeing. when you pass tegalalang road, some men will ask if you want to stop by and view the rice terrace, if you do;entrance fee of IDR 5000 is a must.good news is tegalalang is perfect for tourist who wants to enjoy a meal with green rice fields as view. Around the site you will find many restaurants offering any kind of food local and international. i recommend for tourist not make tegalalang the primary object to visit, its better to make it optional place to see when we go to kintamani or Ubud. But if you like to see real rice terrace without any industrial involved, you can try Pupuan, Jatiluwih or anywhere around tabanan regency, i can assure no entrance fee for this one

Beautifull. You have to take a car there (small fee to access the road IDR 20,000). You will get to walk along a road which sits on the one side of a small valley. On the other side of the valley, you can see the rice terraces... Really impressive.

Not as good as Jatiluwih. Admittedly you seem very close to the rice terraces but you are constantly hounded by people trying to sell you something. I fell into the trap being on my own of taking up the offer to have my photo taken with the rice terraces as a backdrop with the mention of no need to buy. After getting my photo taken I would have normally looked at the goods and probably purchased something as a goodwill gesture but I was virtually assaulted and abused because I wouldn't buy anything. I had heard that the Balinese were a gentle people and I have travelled all over S.E.Asia but never have I met with such agression and frankly it was quite off putting. That said don't let it spoil a trip here especially if your are in Ubud but I prefer Jatiluwih for its long valleys and magnificent views and agree with previous reviewers that this is a tourist trap.
Beautiful view. Was a good trip, and beautiful view from the restaurants around. whilst visiting ubud definatley put the terraces on your list

too commercial. First of all, you have to pay to get in. Funny thing is, padi fields are all over in bali, why do we have to pay to see this single one? There are shops all around the place, selling sourvenirs and T shirts. This place is too commercial for me. I would rather enjoy the free views all around bali.

Yikes! It's Disney in Tegalalang?. Skip this unless you just have morbid curiosity. The parking is horrible, the street is clogged with tourists, the stall vendors are quite annoying, and the rice terraces look as if they belong in a Disney theme park. If you want to actually see the real rice terraces, have your driver take you to Seririt Menduk. Those are truly spectacular in an actual Bali setting.

Sit, Coffee and Rice Terrace for relaxing time. If you want a relaxing place to sit in front of rice terrace, this place can be an option. Bali Coffee and friend banana with red sugar sauce, fresh air, green view its just will make a day. If you want to shop a bit, try to go to a sign board store, its wash hand made and custom.

Tourist Trap!. Tegallalang does have a nice view of rice paddies but it is small and the shops around attempts to earn a quick dollar from tourists. There is even an entrance fee to view the rice terraces even though it is along a public road.Instead, head over to Jatiluwih for much better and grandeur views of rice terrances! Jatiluwih is NOT an attraction but a settlement about 1.5 hours drive north of Tabanan. No entrance fees or touristy shops around. Jatiluwih is the true countryside of Bali. Drivers that you engage will most likely know where along the road to stop for a photo session.

Awesome view. Nice view of rice paddies while you enjoying your cool drink at one of the food vendors. The price of food there probably little bit dearer (with 16% tax). Parking will be bit tricky as the main street is quite narrow.

There are better terraces on the drive there!. It was packed with people and vendors. The terraces weren't that impressive compared to what we were seeing as we drove there. If you are short on time and just want some photos its fine, but if you take some time to look around you will find better views in Ubud.

Scenic rice terraces. We went in the morning, on the way to temples, and it was not crowded. There is a little cafe where you can sit and have a drink whilst taking in the stunning scenery and watching the rice being harvested by hand on the steep slopes. Our driver led the way, to show the easiest paths up the rice terraces. Very pretty walk, and not too difficult, through lush vegetation to a viewing platform on the other side. These were our first rice terraces, and we thought it was a worthwhile trip.
TOP Location!. Beautiful green area, with stunning view Nice terrace with lunchoptions, setting japanese styleMany shops and postcards sales even close to terrace
good views. good place to have a drink or a meal. Very scenic. Good backround pictures. Also close to coffee plantation

Terraced hills. I wouldn't make a special trip to see these rice terraces - especially if you've seen terraced hills before. You'll get charged a dollar or two to stop and see, and it sort of feels like they're taking your money for nothing - although the small fee is apparantly for fixing the roadway and building a footpath for tourists. I suppose they're trying to get some tourists to the more rural areas. Nice view though, so if you're driving around these areas stop and support some of these locals, but don't get your expectations up.

nice and educational for kids. Very nice and educational for kids. We are allowed to walk on the rice terrace if we want to. However, the soil steps are uneven and steep. We gave up half way as we have 2 young kids with us. Entrance fee is 5000rp for adult and children half price. We have 2 adults and 2 young children. We were given 3 tickets but was charged 20,000rp. So where have my 5000rp go to? Whose pocket?

Terraces are amazing - visit early morning for stunning light. We stopped in at the rice terraces on our way out for a day tour. Early in the morning many of the knick-knack vendors were closed so we didn't get hassled too much. This place is a lovely rice terrace - much smaller than Jatiluwih but these terraces are much steeper and tightly packed. It is a nice contrast to have seen them both.
