These are the ones you will see on most of the postcards from Bali, and in the early morning light they shine stunningly.Well worth stopping if you are passing through, and go for a walk down into the terraces just to help you get a deeper appreciation of the work involved in the rice farming. These farmers must have some amazingly strong leg muscles.

Visit only if you have not seen terrace farming before. There is not much done to make it enjoyable to the visitors. Getting into some of the cafes gives you better views and thats about all. If you have seen terrace farming before, there is not anything spectacular to see and nothing to do!

Worth doing, but manage your expectations. It is very touristy. Wall-to-wall knick-knack shops all selling the same things. You can buy civet-pooped coffee beans for AUD50 a pack, which tastes exactly like regular coffee. The rice terraces are there. It cost us - a family of five - about AUD2 to get in, which is about right. Admire the view, take a photo, or a couple, and get outta there.

An absolute must-see!. They REALLY do look like the postcards! And if you can ignore the incessant knick-knack sales people and find a quiet spot, you may enjoy one the more amazing sights of Planet Earth, partly sponsored by the local food and souvenir shops.

Very Scenic But Touristy. I wish that Bali was like it was 20 years ago, when I first visited. When you went to Ubud, it was magical. Now, it is a huge tourist attraction and the magical rice terraces and those areas where you have a good view have been developed in a vulgar tourist attraction. Hawkers everywhere trying to sell you junk, no peace at all. Maybe our driver did not know where to find a unspiled place to view them (I hope so) or maybe all the scenic lookouts are now gone and replaced by cheap tourist shops.Still, the terraces are worth a visit. Good photo opportunity if you have the right lens to avoid the ugly and concentrate on the beautiful
nice but. not as spectacular as I thought and very touristy. go to the cafe at the entrance (forgot the name) and have something to eat there. Same or better view and less tourists

Beautiful. I love nature and this is what I love to see, greenery all the way till your eyes can see. The beautiful paddy fields and the feel of the village life style surrounds it unlike where heavy machinery or equipment a are used to carry out plantations, this was all done by hand didn't spot any of the machinery around, that was the charm of this place. It also has a few small shacks where one can sit, relax and breathe the fresh n crisp air over some fresh coconut water or snacks, its free of pollution and quiet from the city hustle and bustle.However it would have been better if there would be a walk way or a path where one could walk around the paddy fields. The entrance fee is very nominal.

Breathtaking and spectacular view. Beautiful views! A good place to include in your Bali itinerary. Do be careful if you are travelling with seniors and young children as the steps leading to the rice fields are steep and slippery. There are some souvenir shops outside the rice fields which you could buy beautiful souvenirs at great prices, but please remember to exercise your great bargaining skills (ask for 50% off from what they quote)!

Hm.... We clearly went at the wrong time. It was hot as a mother, and the traffic was obnoxious on the little road. Sidewalks either in terrible disarray or non-existent. We may likely have missed something, because after about 20 minutes, we were done. Don't get me wrong- beautiful, but it was busy and crowded and lots of traffic and HOT. Everyone we talked to suggested Jateluwih, but we never made it there.

A truly beautiful place. Make sure you take the time to look at this Unesco listed attraction. It is truly beautiful and you should take photos from many angles. Its the local romanic spot for young Balinese couples and once you see it you'll understand why. Why pay a fortune to see the Philippine's equivalent. Just see this and enjoy the fact its much coller than in town. A lovely respite.
Nice. So nice views. You can enjoyed this view from on of the coffe terases. Entrance fee 5000 rp/pers. From Ubud to Tegallaland full of litle stores boath side the street.

We only passed by in a bus which could not stop long because of traffic. We only caught a gimpse of these famour rice fields as the bus could not stop long. There is a lot of traffic and the road is very narrow and twists and winds. Still it was interesting and unusual
Gorgeous Views. This was a very special experience of seeing a gorgeous view of what represents one of Bali's most unique settings. A definite must go!

mr bali tour. tegalalang rice terrace located in between ubud and kintamani, take about 30minutes from ubud to tegalalang rice terrace view before we heading to kintamani vulcano and beratan lake view. in these place you can take a photo and feel how is real bali with the culture farming..come to see this place with mr bali tour, gustu
Don't waste your time and money going here. It's an ugly place. There were just 4 or 5 rice terrace and that is all you could see. There are other places worth seeing.
Nice views. Certainly worth a trip to see the wonderful rice terraces - unfortunately a lot of shops block the glorious views.

Breathtaking. Drove up with a driver who we allowed to plan our day. This was the first place he took us, and we were blown away! Sensational views, good viewing platforms with good coffee served. A very good trip, and well worth the small 5000 rup charge.

Simply Amazing. I am so glad we got to see this, amazing! Our driver took us here, I didn't know about it before. The work that must have gone into this, I was in awe. Loved the little Balinese man who posed for pictures with us. I have a greater appreciated of this country and what they can do since seeing this.
Lovely setting. Nice beautiful landscape green paddies with active workers, locals friendly. worth a visit. Can walk around them if you want. Grass hats for sale there.

Beautiful but touristy. This place has the iconic view that many people think of for Bali's rice terraces, and it is beautiful. However, the visiting experience left a lot to be desired. You have to pay just to drive down the street and there are vendors selling junk everywhere. You can walk down into and around the terraces, but there are people at every turn asking for "donation." Worth seeing, just don't expect much more than a tourist trap.
Facinating. Loved the verdant green and watching the Balinese planting the rice. Ingenious layering of fields makes for great photo ops!
So beautiful! Can't miss as they are everywhere. We were fortunate to have a tour through the rice paddies which is definitely a challenge to balance!

If you see one, this is the ONE!. A lovely land of sculpted green beauty! If you came to Ubud for a look at this type of lovely landscape, Tegallalang is a wonderful stop. We spent about 1 hour here walk up and down and all around the beautful green at our feet. This is an amazing look at how the rice terraces are created with their irrigation systems and winding areas. TIP: be sure to wear decent shoes and be ready for a little workout. Keeping your balance and the ups/downs of the terrace can be a bit tricky (and I'm pretty active). Bring some small bills as there is a request for a donation as you are walking through and walking over the new bamboo bridge.
Rice, Nice. This is a paddy field on mountain, looks like a stair case~We had a several photo over there, the weather was around 20c something, quite a nice place when you see the greenly paddy~
Beautifully tranquil. Loved the beautiful green views, have lunch here, there are a few places to choose from. For gifts, avoid buying here as more expensive.

Clogged with traffic and tourist shops. The road is full of trough going traffic which is halted by the many tourist vehicles which are parked here. The view is half blocked by the many tourists shops. If you take either of the paralel roads left and right (look on the map) you hardly meet any tourists, drive through original villages and see the greatest terrace views.

Like from magazines. It as just amazing! I was realy skeptic after few disapointments met in Indonesia and I was expecting anything but this! When you stop on the road and take a break in one of many "coffee bars" you can enjoy amazing view at rice field terraces. You can also go down to the fields and take a wolk there.See it yourself from close. This was realy good trip and you just pay few thousands rupiah for parking.Rest is free or charged only by coffee you drink :)

Worth if visiting Ubud or going through Ubud. The Tegallalang rice terraces are nice nevertheless but this technic of rice cultivation by cutting, shaping and making plain-land strips in the slopes of hills is not unique to Bali! Even the hill people of hilly districts in Bangladesh have similar technic of rice cultivation (locally called Joom cultivation). Anyway, visiting Tegallalang Rice Terraces is worth if someone is visiting Ubud or passing through Ubud! We stopped there for half an hour on our way to Kintamani (Mount Batur) from Jimbaran. We cherished that time and enjoyed the greenery of the rice terraces sloping downhill and having plenty of coconut trees and other trees as well at different layers of the terraces. But again, probably we wouldn't have liked it that much had we put all that effort to see the rice terraces alone!

A must visit rice terraces. i visited it yesterday with my family, it's so green with cool air.. really lovely.. you must visit it in the morning, otherwise too many tourists especially on the weekend during 11 am - 4 pm, it's too crowded and little road gets stuck :( but all in all i love being there, walk in the rice paddy path :)

Tranquility. We enjoyed it from a small cafe that have a view of a green rice terraces (teras siring on local language). Nice place to rejuvenate and feel peacfully looking to the scenery with a breeze of cool wind.Take a deep breath and feels free from a hectic routine.Unique experience.
Interesting. Great to see friendly locals going about their work. Good to see a side of Bali most people dont get out to.
gorgeous!. The view is amazing! There are lots of people trying to sell random things which can be a bit annoying, but it's still worth the trip.

Worth the trip.. No matter what the reviews here say, the moment you see the terraces you will know they were worth the trip and you will keep snapping photos until you get bored. I recommend going early in the morning or in the late afternoon if you can - the lighting is better for capturing the lush green color of the terraces with your camera. Also, be prepared for the sun exposure as there are no shades available.

Great location with a taste of fake. Rice terraces are present all around Bali and despite the flawless appearance, Tegallalang is too much tourist oriented and tastes like a theme park. You pay a cheap entrance ticket, nevertheless, every 50 meters you find some of the local people waiting in strategic spots ready to ask for more tips (e.g. to cross a small bridge).

My best day in Bali. Really superb. Do the walking tour - I will review that as well on TripAdvisor. You don't get the full flavor without doing a morning or afternoon walking tour. Walking through you feel the peace and beauty of the place.
Fantastic view. Really love to see the rice field in Tegallalang, I have visit this place 2 times and still really love the view.
NICE VIEW. really nice view for to make pictures. something different that we don't have in our own city. sitting relax with the luwak cofee.. ehmm.. amazing
Worth seeing. Went early as shops were setting up so not hassled by hawkersVery nice view Had two small children with us so only stopped for 10 mins but that was enough

Worth a look but there are better examples elsewhere. The aspect that distinguishes this attraction from other rice fields is the ability to walk down and see the rice fields close up. The terraces are interesting to look at, but you can't help feel this has been commercialised and the effect somewhat spoilt. On the other side of the road is a long row of shops selling food and souvenirs. You also have to pay for going through this area (Rp 5000 per person). When we went in the afternoon, it was also quite crowded, so I wouldn't recommend going here if you don't like crowds and traffic jams.If you're passing through the area (e.g. on the way back to Ubud from Sebatu), it might be worthwhile dropping in. Otherwise, if you are going to eastern Bali, you can see lots of examples of interesting rice fields on a journey from Tirtagangga to Klungkung via Sibetan and Sidemen (albeit at more of a distance than you can at Tegallalang). The examples on this road seem much more genuine and give a better idea of the "real" Bali. On a smaller scale, drop in to Boni Bali in Sebatu and have lunch overlooking rice terraces.
Amazing View. a place famous for its landscape of rice fields; a very nice view under sunny weather; each tourist needs to pay IDR 5000 though

bike ride and this view is just phenomenal !. Hi ,wouldnt suggest seriously planning it in ur day tour package..this is very easily accessible by bike or cycle..take ur time and do it on ur own ...so just rent one and keep going on the straight road which the locals keep pointing and voila on ur right hand side the beautiful rice terrace !!! our 2 yr old son identified it and screamed wow as he saw this and we really enjoyed the view !!

Nice but.... Nothing to do other than a nice view..nice wheather..if not been here before can come for it.it good for photographs and wont take you more than half and hour unless you wanna stay for drink and enjoy.

Great rice terrace views. The rice terraces at Tegalalang, although not as big as those in Jatiluwih are still a sight if you haven't seen anything like this before (which was my case). We combined this as part of our day trip from Ubud to Batur and visited this on the way back in the evening as it was cooler then.There is a small fee (i think around 10000 IDR) to enter the place (dont know why) but you don't mind since its not a lot in any case. You can walk down all the way into the fields and then cross over onto the other side. Its a nice walk down through the terraces and although it might take a while figuring out the way down, once you get used to it , it can be quite fun. There was a local offering to give his rice basket for a picture at a price but we didn't give it a try :)There are cafes at the top with great views of the terraces and you can sit here and enjoy the views if you dont want to walk down. If you aren't planning Jatiluwih then this is worth a visit.
Worth a visit. if your looking at a great day out just to see the sights you cant go wrong, it is worth getting a driving and visiting the rice terrace,

Amazing view and restaurant!. We took friends with us to see this stunning view which we have visited many times over the years! The terraces here look great whether or not they have new rice planted or fully grown rice! Unfortunately the hawkers can be very pesty along this strip and the pecalang are now charging cars to drive past there..BUT our alternate motive for makintg this a regular stop is the best kept secret on the edge of the terraces which is Kampung Cafe! For years we have worked our way through the menu and tested all the desserts...best in Bali!! The nasi campur and kare lumpia are to die for and wow you can't beat these clean toilets in Bali!! The views from the top deck of this restaurant are sensational and we love to watch the squirrels run up the giant palm trees there!!

just beautiful. The rice terraces are lovely and only 15 minutes away from ubud. They are lush and tropical and you can explore them easily for an hour or so, taking many snaps. As with all tourist attractions, there is a few market stalls that if you are in Bali to shop are most definitely worth a visit as the prices are much more reasonable than in ubud. The villages on the way up to the rice terraces are worth stopping in and taking a few pictures and buying a few trinkets as well. There is a restaurant overlooking the rice terraces also, so it would be an easy half day trip from ubud

Beautiful scenery, nice to stop for lunch or afternoon tea. This is my favorite spot in Bali and I've visited Tegallalang rice terrace twice. I've also been to the Jatiluwih rice terrace and while Tegallalang rice terrace is not as big, the view is beautiful. You can walk from one ridge, down into the valley and up to other ridge and back in about 45 minutes to 1 hour. We got one of the local school kids to take us on a rice paddy treking "tour" and gave him Rp 20,000 afterwards (There is no set rate, he was really happy to earn some pocket money).We usually eat lunch overlooking the paddies at the Rice Terrace cafe - the nasi campur (mixed rice), nasi kuning (yellow rice) and sate (chicken skewers) are delicious! The price is reasonable for a touristy place Rp 40000-Rp 45000. You need to pay Rp 5000 entrance or parking fee. There are many sovenir shops lining the road (and also on the way).

Rice terraces. Good view, nice restaurants all along the way. Good place to take lots of photos. A lot of local paintings which are real good value for money too. However, it's not a place where you can stay very long as theres nothing to do except sight see and take photos. However, its definately worth a visit. After seeing the rice terraces we went to Joni's roast duck which is just next to the rice terraces so you get a great view while having your meal. The roast duck there is a must try too.

spectacular - but then, there are lots of others. This is a nice little stop on the way from Ubud (or further south) on your way to Gunang Batur and Kintamani. I'm not convinced about the readiness of the warungs that have sprung up in the past year or two - but ayam sate and rice is generally reliable as is the Bali kopi. The terraces, yes they're great but there are a lot of others that are as good or better and a little less stressed by the road and tourist volumes. enjoy :)

Snapshot of what terraced rice fields look like.. Our driver explained these terraced rice fields are declared historically significant and can't be destoyed. They are beautiful to look at and yes, there are some hawkers and a local gets some money from our local driver for the priviledge of parking there for all of 5 minutes.
Day tour. The rice paddies make for a magic scenic view. It is good that visitors are able to walk through the paddies.

Nice but not a must visit. It is a nice view but area is too commercialised. Expected a much more expansive rice terraces but turned out to be quite compact. If you do drive around Ubud , you would come across many other such rice terraces but maybe slightly less picture perfect. It is not a must visit but no harm making a short quick detour on the way to / from other major sites in that area.
beautiful views. Rice terraces - views that made Bali famous. Pity there are some hawkers.
nice view~~. a must see in Bali if you have more than 3 days time to spend there

Amazing view. Our driver, Wayan from Bali Sunrise Tours, took us here after our sunrise trek up Mt. Batur. It's just amazing to see how creatively the Balinese have made the most efficient use of the varying levels of land in Bali to cultivate their rice crops. It is also makes for an amazingly beautiful sight.

Perfect terrace view. When you pass Tegalalang on the way to Kintamani to see batur lake and mountain batur, don't forget have a stop at Tegalalang rice terrace. It's good place for you the astoning view sample of rice terrace in Bali before you see the wide terrace if you have time to visit Jatiluwih.

Tegallang / Jatihluwih. I had hoped to go to Jatihluwih but as we were going to Ubud/Lake Bratan at a local's recommendation, we ended up here. Driver said Jatihluwih was out of the way. I was both awed by the lovely greens as well as disappointed that it is actually just a touristy stop. You pay a small fee to stop at the 'lookout' and then you can walk down to it to take pics. There was a man you could pose with but you had to pay him after you've taken a pic with him. Some were unsuspecting and found out after the pic. They probably thought he was a local who just happened to have finished work. :)Some walked further down to the terraces to take pics and if we had done that, I guess it would have been lovelier but we were keen to take our pics and move on as it was so crowded.As I had thought it would be miles and miles of these terraces in a natural setting, rather than a designated spot that tourists (millions of us - I exaggerate but it was hard not to get people in the background when taking pics) were given, I was disappointed. Anyway, maybe next time we will go to Jatihluwih but perhaps that is also similar to Tegallang. The paddy excursion/walk that our hotel had taken us on was a lot more natural and peaceful than this.

The Postcard. Did you remember of how the travel agent in your country explained about Bali? I believe they use the picture of a rice terrace which looks very beautiful. 99% of those beautiful pictures were taken in Tegalalang Rice Terrace. Me as a local people in this area still love to spend some times to see the beautiful nature art created by the farmers. It seems that the farmers have counted very well the proportion of the rice terrace so that will look good from other standing point. If you are a photographer, this is a truly great spot for your journey.

A Few Minutes Is All You Need. Myself, my husband, our 18 month old, and my parents hired a driver for 3 days. On the first day we stopped at the rice terrace after lunch. After a small entry fee, we pulled off to the side of the road and crossed over to take in the lovely scenic rice terrace. Took a couple pictures then pretty much spent 3 times more time haggling with the store we were standing at over a little dress for my daughter. If it's not along the way, probably not worth the trip. But if you're close by, it's worth the stop but it will be a quick stop.
very nice. very nice, to watch, to walk, to have many pictures, and also to eat at their cafes

Beautiful View. We were fortunate when we stopped here to have a look at the rice paddies and have our photo taken, that it was very quiet, so didnt really encounter the busy tourist element.
Certainly well worth a stop and taking some photo's....
Beautiful. A great experience close to Ubud. If you are not staying in the Ubud area, take a day trip with a driver and include this as one of your highlights of the day!
Beautiful views. Great views - almost too picturesque. Prepare to be hassled by vendors.

Picture-postcard perfect... But not much to do except look, take your pictures and leave. After paying an entry fee.. It is definitely an impressive sight to behold, although there isn't much here to warrant staying longer unless you wish to eat with a view, or look in shops that are typical of many places in this part of Bali. It was a bit of a surprise that they charged an entry fee - although it was peanuts - 1000 rupiah per person. On the whole, rice terraces are a typical feature of Balinese landscapes and can be seen at other attractions such as Gunung Kawi. If it will be your first time to see something like this, it can be worth a look. Beware the traffic which is wild and wooly like any major tourist spot in Bali.s

Average View of Rice Terrace. Pretty average to us. Seems that it looked much better on postcard =) Probably it was due to the harvest season just being over. Nevertheless, no regret that we stopped by here for 15mins just to soak in the greeneries and took some photos. We were there around 3pm and didn't experience the local vendors trying to sell us stuff. We saw tourists crossing over the small river and walking all the way to the rice terrace. Could be fun but we were too tired to go the long way.

Worth stopping by and taking a couple of photos. They are definetly worth a couple of panoramic photos. Just be aware that the road is quite narrow, and crowded. Also, I have seen people tripping over the high steps as they were walking going down the hill.

You will have seen a photo of this place. If you have spent any time in Bali then you will have seen a photo of this rice terrace. Great place to get your photo taken but not somewhere I would go out of my way to visit if I was on a limited time frame. If you are staying for more than a week in Ubud then either rent a car or hire a taxi and visit the traditional art and craft shops along this road and stop at this place for that Kodak moment whilst carrying on up the road to the lake/Volcano at the top of the island.
hhmmnnn..... The rice terraces are well worth a look, but you can see more of these if you spend a bit of time looking around outer Ubud without the tourist trap element.
nice. Good view, a must see. Although they do it for tourist spot, however it still produce rice for locals.

Picture postcard. Bring out the camera, take the picture and hop on back on the bus. Overrated? Well, its very pretty and if you're staying in Ubud, it's only 15 or so minutes away. But if from Kuta, make sure that its not the only thing on the agenda. Not much else around other than the trinket shops and small cafes for coffee or tea. Used to be tranquil, more trampled now by hordes of tourists. Choose your time of day well and you may enjoy the scenery as opposed to fighting for that perfect spot for the picture.

SMALL BUT ADORABLE TERRACE RICE FIELDS. We really enjoyed our visit to Tegallalang rice terraces from Ubud. It is a short and pleasant drive, around half an hour, nice landscapes. Then you pay to enter the village around 2 euros.
Stop by Terrace restaurant for a freshly squeezed fruit juice or cold Bintang beer. The VIEWS ARE FANTASTIC and the restaurant is just excellent.
Rice Paradise!. Beautiful scenery, truly something to behold. Makes you appreciate how much work goes in to producing rice when you observe the back breaking, low paid work that the Balinese do.

What a View. Brilliant but literally you can pull over out of the car and take a few photos. There is a small fee to enter the area 10,000 RP per person I think but it is a small price to pay for such a spectacular area of landscape.
One time visit. It's nice to see it but I expected more empty space or a nice walk between the fields...
Beautiful. Take a walk/hike through the terraces - gorgeous! Never seen anything like it.
magical location. The location of this cafe is stunning. Watch the rice paddy workers while you eat and enjoy the serenity of the location. The food is good too. A must do thing in Bali!

True Bali with the tourists. this is one way to see rice terraces. It is very pretty & to see the rice terraces of Bali is something quite special.Unfortunately this area has become a destination for every tour guide in Bali, so it's starting to feel like Kuta Beach with the hawkers etc.The tour guides bring a never ending stream of tourists to gawk at the hillside on the opposite side of the valley for most of the day. there is even a charge by the villiage wardens to drive along the road.The positive side to this is that the proceeds are shared with the farmers who are now working this steep hillside and planting rice simply for the 'tourist dollar'.
Beautiful Bali. We love everything about Bali everyone so friendly and never take offence when trying to bargain, it is all good funWhat I do not like is having to leave and come home

Peaceful. We went in the evening and by that time, most of the vendors and even the toll booth had closed for the day. There were not many tourists and we weren't bothered by the vendors. Beautiful lush scenery and a good opportunity to see the farmers at work in the fields.

Fantastic views. Stunning views, well worth visiting. Would be nice to spend a bit of time there, but people pouncing on you to buy postcards etc can be annoying. Entrance fee is really cheap, but no idea how they control who pays or what this is money is used for! Definitely worth seeing though.
stunning. they are just beautiful and are a treasure of Bali that is in danger of disappearing
glorious terraces. the rice terraces spill down the hill in glorious steps of green! really something to behold! a view of bali that is sadly disappearing
A Terrace of Paradise. The cafe was good, the scenery was excellent, the local saller disappointed

very pretty shopping area.. there are a lot of shops selling tat, so it may be a nice place to pick up a gift for the petsitter. The terraces are beautiful even after they have been harvested. A walk down into the paddy is stunning.

Pupuan although farther away is so much better. I drove by here once again.. mainly because I love to see terraced rice fields..yet I have to say if you can get your driver to take you to Pupuan oh my gosh I tok literally hundred of beautiful rice fields, terraced, flat water, some with duck... with Tegallang you get a distant and beautiful view.. its just there are so many more to see in Bali.

Beautiful!!. If you are staying in Ubud, it is worth the trip out of the town to see the rice patties. We ran into some locals when biking, and they were all friendly! Great experience, and a must see!
Nice but probably not the best. Nice view but viewing location was purely for tourists and there was not much space to wander around.
Iconic Bali. This is the Bali tourists imagine. The best bit of any trip to Bali for me is getting into the countryside. I love these rice terraces.

Rice terrace with a view. There is no doubt the view of the rice terraces were beautiful. However, this place has gotten very touristy and hence lost some of its authenticity in the process. Restaurants here have marked up prices to take advantage of the tourist influx.

The Best Balinese Heritage of Rice Terrace. When you see this rice terrace you should appreciate how hard Balinese people work? How they appreciate a peace of land can be plan rice? to support their life. Now become tourist attraction in Ubud which attract many visitor.
Beautiful Scenic View!. Great to stop and see. We didn't spend much time there. A must do, though a little touristy.
Nice scenery of rice field. It's nice scenery of rice field. And there are a lot of shops at road side selling the souvenirs too

Picturesque landscape. Awesome rice paddy terraces. Some of the best in Bali. Difficult to imagine farming these small pieces of land where every inch is valuable. Great photo opportunity with the palmtrees framing the terraces. Well worth a visit en route to Kintamani or coffee plantations.

Lovely to see as part of Bali. We passed through these magnificent paddy fields as part of our trip touring around Ubud. Lovely to see and spend a bit of time there. If we had more time would be great to trek across as offered be guided by several of the children selling postcards.! Include this sight as part of a tour to the volcanic area to the north is the best way to see these paddy fields.

Postcard view!. What you would imagine Bali look like. Great view. We had lunch at Boni Bali and we had the view for ourselves. You can also go down to the field itself and go up walking on the edge of the terraces. Memorable moment!
nice rice fields. nice for a stopover and some beautiful photos,slightly overrated.
Nice view!. Very nice view with 5,000 rupiah entrance fee! There is a restaurant named Rice Terrence Cafe which the chicken with mushroom cream worth a try!
tipical balinese landscape. nice rice terraces surounded with wild forestsa piece of traditionnal lanscape carving by the joined will of water and farming
so good at all levels. let's go your thoughts and experience the food well done
Beautiful Tegallantang Rice Terrace. Part of our day trip. Short stop to enjoy and absorb the beautiful rice terrace

Beautiful. Being born and bred a city person, the natural beauty of the terraces of green rice fields were awesome. We came at the right time as the rice fields are still green and yet to be harvested. Recommended to visit if you have children so that they can see the real thing instead of reading and seeing pictures from books.We also visited the terraced rice fields in Jati Luweh which also gives a spectacular view.

spectacular view; scary street vendor. A must visit spectacular place in bali.There is a canopy café where you can grab a coffee (recommended Indonesian style LUWAK coffee), have a little chat and enjoy the scenery. However, there will few street vendors that come to you. They will offer tempting and dirt cheap price like USD1 for a ‘batik’, or whatever they are selling to grab your attention. This is not the case as they will change their price (to USD10 or something higher) when you trying to reconfirm the price.ONLY show direct eye contact to the person if you are interesting with the ITEM, please do not interact with them if you are interested with PRICE. If you like the ITEM, the higher chances that you will successfully purchase them at a reasonable price.

Simply Amazing. We went to Tegallalang Rice terraces with our driver so we were lucky enough to have local knowledge and get away from the main viewing area. We got to walk through the fields as our driver explained how and when the rice would be harvested. It is certainly worth seeing!

Simply Beautiful. If you like natural beauty then this is a must see. The flow of the terracing and backdrop for pictures is awesome. Don't lose sight that these are maintained for economic activity and not just a "tourist" site:concurrent form and function
Great view but the hassle. Pity about the hassling hawkers - such a great view.
Nice!. We parked on the side of the road and went down to take pictures of these amazing padi fields.

Terrace Encounter. Being the first sight in our itinerary, travelling 1.5hrs to this place seems like an anti-climax, all enthusiasm was gone due to impatientce. before this site would recommend to instead visit the beautiful temples first.

Beautiful....... Beautiful Rice Terrace 15 minutes drive from Ubud Center with lush green surroundings. Come in the afternoon for better sunlight exposure. I went in May it was all green. In some months when they just start growing rice or just harvest, it may not be so green. A nice spot for a drink and good view. I was there early in the morning though.

Scenic. If you have never seen a rice field or you have never seen one that is as beautiful as this, you really need to head over here. This is one of the top attraction in Bali and after visiting, i totally agree.
A breathtaking view. Never seen such a lovely rice terrace, The air was crisp and fresh and the view was breathtaking.
There are better. We saw better views of rice terraces in the north and west of Bali which were free! We had to pay to get to these
Great View. it just amazing . I wish I could sitting there for a whole trip and back to the hotel in the afternoon . but be still have to complite our journey in Bali
The view was beautiful. The view of the rice terrace was beautiful but we were a little intimidated by the aggressive street sellers. Please becareful. It a place not to be missed
Great Picture Spot. Beautiful view of the terrace but lots of aggresive vendors, we just stayed long enough to get a picture.

nice view, but beware of seller's tricks. the view of rice terrace are nice, and worth for stopping by for less than 30 minutes. But always beware of the seller around the area, only ask the price is you really wish to buy, or else they will push you to buy something even you not wish to. We really annoyed with the seller that kept pushing to buy something from them. (no wonder at first they seem to be so nice help us captured our photo together.)

Great Balinese Landscape. Although you will see miles and miles of rice terraces in Bali the Tegalalang setting is special as it looks out over a valley and you get a very close view of things. Would definately reccommend a adrive by if in Ubud or coming back from a day trip to Kintamani

Skip it if you've seen a rice terrace. Pretty, but the experience of having to view the terrace from overpriced and aggressive souvenir shops after crossing the congested road made the hour car ride not worth it.

Amazing Rice Terraces. While we were visiting Ubud, we viewed the Tegallantang Rice Terraces as part of a mountain biking day trip. They were the most spectacular place we saw while in Bali. It was like viewing a piece of living modern art. It is amazing that they are not only beautiful, but also functional. The Balinese have been farming on these rice terraces for hundreds of years. Please do not miss these terraces if you travel to Bali. They are unforgettable and mesmerizing.

different style of rice field. I walk many many times in Tegallalang, nearly every visit in Bali I always spend some hours to wandering around the terrace rice field there. Just a bit feel annoy with the farmer that asking for money when ever I wanna make photos. For a break I like to enjoy the scenery of Tegal lalang Rice Terrace by stopping by @ Cafe Dewi having fresh milkshake or juice or just simple long black coffee and also spring rolls already make my day there...!!!
Green. It's so darn green!!! Home is very dry so it was great to see so much green.

amazing view. Being in the rice terraces gives you a different feeling, like being in a different world. it has such an amazing view.
just beware of the different tourist traps there.
more on Bali here --> http://paotothelo.wordpress.com/2012/04/06/bali-sights-and-eats-part-2/#more-174

it call "Ceking" Terrace. because the road there tiny men "Ceking", it is wonderful view, i can stay long time there to enjoy the view, but mostly i like it when morning time,.. so quite and less people and the shop is not open yet,..

Lovely peaceful walk. Lovely walk with little art shops along the way and places to stop for a drink. Long walk -about 21/2 km.-along the road to get back into Ubud so avail yourself of the taxi service at the end of it if you don't want a hot, boring bit at the end once you come out of the terraces.
Worth the trip if you are staying in Ubud. Great terraced rice fields with a restaurant in perfect position to enjoy the view and snap some amazing shots.

Spectacularly beautiful place marred by tourist schlock.. On my first trip to Bali this was one of the first places I visited. I was impressed with the beauty, a bit disturbed by all the tourist excesses, and also left with the impression that it was the only "iconic" rice field in Bali. Now that I live here I have seen many more beautiful rice field areas far removed from the tourist circuit. If you have the chance to get out on your own I would encourage you to explore Bali and get away from the tourist areas, otherwise you will be overwhelmed with the excesses of tourist mania that plagues much of the more popular areas of Bali. However, if this is the one chance to see an iconic rice field then I would not want to discourage you from going, it is spectacularly beautiful. However, instead of looking at all the tourist trinkets for sale everywhere on the road, instead look for someone who will be willing to take you on a walk down into the rice field. You would offer him a nominal fee. (Bargain if it seems extreme the amount he asks for, but remember that this is the money he earns to help take care of his family, so don't be stingy either.) You will enjoy taking that memory of your walk home far more than a trinket that will most likely end up in a future garage sale, or even worse on the rubbish heap. This is a great place to bring inquisitive children and they will enjoy their time immensely exploring the intricate environment of a rice field. Enjoy!

Breathtaking. We once again visited the rice terraces just outside of Ubud. They are absolutely amazing to see. It's a great stop for pics. There is a restaurant underneath the viewing point but we didn't stop there. Last time we came we were mobbed by hawkers but this time not one person bothered us. It was a quick photo stop for us. Don't forget to stop and do shopping at the shops lining the road that leads to the rice terraces. There is some amazing shopping there!
Beautiful but a tourist trap. Although a great photo op....beware the hawkers. Get out into the countryside around Besakih and just, if not more, beautiful.

A clip of the ticket. You have to pay just to drive the road here - and then you get hassled! I am all for local people benefitting from tourism - but you walk along the road. Better to go further North to the coffee plantation - where you can sip Kope Luwak in the shade, overlooking much better terraces.

photo taking spot!. a very well organized rice field, was very natural, but now it's become more in special maintenance as it does a very nice spot for photo taking. people just especially stop there for take the pictures. and it's in one way from tegallalang where you can buy all the handycraft and end up in kintamani, the volcano lake, so it is a gud spot to stop n having a break.

Natural beauty at its best... and the locals are friendly contrary to previous reports. I've been to Tegallalang before - back in 2008 when we barely stopped long enough to take a photo before I was hounded by locals to buy something, and the tour guide hurried me back to the safety of the car. IT'S NOTHING LIKE THAT NOW! It's true that it's changed enormously. The rice terraces are still breathtaking, but the locals who have set up their shops have also set up little cafes for us to take refreshments in. If you didn't read trip advisor, you really wouldn't know they were there. The locals are far more friendly now and apart from encouraging you to come closer to look at their wares, they don't accost you anymore. And because of that, I was more than happy to go closer, and i did end up making a purchase. But what was the highlight, was being able to venture down some stairs, and find little open air huts to sit in and order our favourite drink/food. I had my standard watermelon juice, and my husband order Luwak Coffee - a delicacy he said (I'm scoffing - so read up on it before you go). We sat there for ages, taking in the view, marvelling at it's beauty and enjoying the break. We actually did a cafe-crawl, and moved to the next one for lunch (the biggest one) and then the last one for another drink before we left. We got photos from all angles then. Then we got back on our motorbikes and drove back to Ubud. This in itself was a hoot as we had no real idea how to get there, we just kept asking locals, and they kept pointing us in the right direction. The Balinese really are lovely people. If you go by car, you have to pay per person to stop there, but it's some piddly amount which is barely worth worrying about. Hope you enjoy it, and do buy something, these people actually rely on visitors to feed their families. :) Enjoy.

Amazing scenery. You must pay a small fee to be allowed to visit the Rice Terraces at Tegallalang which I felt was a little bit of a rort, but the scenery is amazing. Plenty of eats area selling cheap food and drinks/alcohol and non, heaps of stalls selling Bali souvenirs. Amazing view of the rice fields, you can even walk amongst the fields if you feel like some exercise (at a cost).

Great Views. Was there for the previous two visits. THe restaurants are located facing the rice terrace. Food was OK but the view in front was really good. First time visitors to Ubud should give this a try. There are many wood carving shops along the way to Tegallalang. During our visit there in 2011, we managed to buy inexpensive wood carvings for our newly renovated house. They are significantly cheaper than those you find at Ubud market.
Have to protected by UNESCO. Its amazing view that created by Balinese people.especially when it green and nearly harvest time wow,.. amazing..

The ingenuity of the Balinese on show.. This is a must see. Don't come home from Bali and say you missed this. It is breathtakingly beautiful. It is practical, colourful, popular and, to get to it, you pass through some of the real Bali. The Balinese will make a business anywhere, nowhere is this more evident than at the cafe on the edge of the rice terraces. Clever people.

Good scenery. It is near to town, paddy terrace make the scenery good and photographer stunning. anyway it depends on the season -if you are going after their harvest, than the scenary is just average, anyway, it cannot beat Paddy terrace at Jataluwih.

amazing view!. Bali is unique itself, but this place is incredibly amazing! When we look at this rice terraces, we realize how hard to create them, how hard to grow rice and how hard to harvest it... I've been here many times and I never get borrred to return here every time I have to acompany my relatives and friends, it is still wonderful to me. Usually we have a lunch in one of the cafes down the stairs there, with nice view and fresh air.... awesome!The minus of this place is a lack of parking area ...The fee for this place is only the parking fees, about USD0.20.

Breathtaking. What a fantastic changeup from the beaches. The driver dropped us at an overlook that gave an amazing view of the hillside. Actually there are a number of terraces before and after this location but none as beautiful. There are also a number of nice art and wood shops here with reasonable prices.
Pretty. Was hoping the rice terrace we're more majestic though.. Probably at sideman which we didn't have time to see

Stunning Rice Padi Views. Ubud, located in the cool hilly area of Central Bali, has so much to offer the tourist and traveller. One of the most spectacular rice field terraces in Ubud is Tegallalang area, just about 15 minutes drive outside of Ubud. Surrounding gorge full of rice fields has over the years attracted many photographers who captured its images on film and photos. There are no fees to this adventure, no opening hours just another great thing that you can do while visiting Ubud.

dramatic scenery of rice terrace. On the way back from Mt. Kintamani to Ubud we stopped by at Tegallalang for a while to see the famous dramatic rice terrace. We are glad that we did.We visited Bali in July last year so it was definitely not the best time to see paddy fields as it was post-harvest. Nonetheless we still enjoyed the beauty of Mother Nature and it was a wonderful experience for us.Tips : bear in mind that the appearance of the rice fields will change during the course of each four-month growing season

Sensational views. The views are beautiful, the only thing that spoils it are the vendors selling their goods on the side of the road. They surround the car even before you can get out. The best advice we were given my our driver - "don't touch anything or else its as good as yours"
Stunning. loved it. Better than the other rice fields you pass on your way into the town.

Nice photo opportunity. We stopped here to take some lovely pics of the rice terrace.
Just beautiful.
Also bought some great stuff at the little shops that run along the roadside. Very cheap compared to Legian Kuta etc.
Don't miss. The real rural side of Bali! Its amazing, so green and organise...
Good but small one. Very nice view but small one. Recommend Jati Luwi Rice Terrace!
Good Food. Lovey outlook and good food, nice staff and very peaceful
Exquisite. These rice terraces are fantastic!! They look like a sculpture and are thousands of years old. Well worth visiting. Down side is the markets - but then they are everywhere.

Worth going to have a Great view of the paddy field!. I just stopped by & explored the paddy field.I got some nice photos there.I do think that it's a Great place to chill & have a meal.Sit back & relax.

Rice Terrace. When the rice is growing the terraces are beautiful. Definitely worth a trip up there to see it and stay for lunch.
On the downside, you are mobbed by street vendors and the parking and traffic can be bad.

Mesmerizing. This rice terraces wasn't initially part of our travel plan in Bali, till we heard about it from the local guide who was bringing us around. On our 2nd day in Bali, we had wanted to go to Kuta, however we changed our mind to Ubud since our local guide said that there's more shopping there. He showed us the attractions of Ubud. Tegallantang Rice Terrace was our last stop.When we reached the place, I fell in love with the place immensely. It's so beautiful. We had luwak coffee at a cafe there. It's so nice enjoying the lovely scenery while sipping our coffee.It's a must-visit place in Bali. I would love to go back there, to see the rice fields as well. The place was too far off and we had time constraints.

Worth a visit. Beautiful fields and wonderful scenery. Though one only needs to spend about 30 minutes here to take pictures and a leisure stroll. But overall, this is what Ubud is about, escape from the city.

Rice Terrace. The rice terrace is a really nice sight to see, though I do suggest going early. The viewpoint across from the terraces is full of cafes and restaurants that you need to sit at to get a good view. Though we went at around 8.30/9am and nothing was open yet so we could walk through all the tables and cafe areas to get great views and good angles for photos.
amazing. this has been an amazing subject for our cameras. they are extended for km and it's really amazing loosing yourself there. born2travel.it
So peaceful. make a walk, listen to the birds, we got a village tour from the alam sari resort and we learned a lot how those village people live.

Please urge your driver to go beyond the tourist traps and do your home work. You know how you sometimes just trust your driver / guide to take you to the BEST place ... welll, in Bali that type of lazyness doesn't pay off. You really want to do your homework before engaging a driver to take you around. Yes, I fell for it again ..(. and this in spite of my experience ... ) and decided to let him handle the excusrion of the day. Well, I should really not have done so. Although the views are stunning, we were really put off by the industrial marketing of the place : poor service, poor food and cliché snapshots for the tourist who fall into passive mode on their holidays ...We have a house in Bali, often go on discovery tours planned by ourselves, but with friend and family requesting the ' quick and all inclusive' tour of Bali, this is the very poor extract that they are presented with. I'd advice you to take your time in one of the villages around Ubud. To get out of the car, walk around, breathe the air, hear the sounds of the birds and watch the farmers o about their business. Try to go at the end of the day. The villages of Bali come alive with people living their every day life coming out after the heat. Their gracious presence within the extraordinay beauty of their rice fields will enchant you ....

Stress reliever. 5 busy days in a week and you ran out of option to hangout. Bored of crowded dirty kuta? pricey eateries at Seminyak? then why don't you go ahead to Tegalalang. It's located a little bit further from Ubud (just before Tampak siring) and indulge yourself with green surrounding and cool breeze from the rice field.When you arrived at the tegalalang area, do not go too further. if you start seeing big busses and people bringing souvenirs and shouting at you to buy some of their things, you have gone into the wrong area. turn around and watch for your left side, you will see a small road downhill and you can seethe first small restaurant overlooking the beautiful rice terraces. but sorry, i forgot the name :(Spent 2 hours there, just listen to the voice of birds chirping or rain pouring definitely wash your stress away. totally recommended!
Definitely worth seeing, especially for the shutterbugs out there.. Not a long drive from Ubud with so many photo opps along the way. Definitely recommend doing at least a half day drive to see them.
Fantastic place. It was realy amaising to see the the terraces first hand, the amount of work that has gone into them over the years is huge,It was a great afternoon and well worth the visit
Just nice. Nice view, but a little common in Indonesia.. there's some gift shop and restaurant nearby. And some little boy and girl offered postcard.

stunning rice terraces...but the souvenir sellers are a real pest. absolutely stunning views...unfortunately the place has become a tourist circus, with swarms of souvenir sellers, they are very persistent and don't take no for an answer...also some guy popped up saying that we had to buy a ticket 'for the view'...ever heard of such a thing? we suspected a scam so we just ignored him, he got quite upset though...all this greatly dimished the experience, unfortunately

Wow wow wow. Definitely have a driver take you shopping through Ubud. Got amazing deals and beautiful paintings I watched the guys paint as we had lunch. And then the terrace is a sight not to missed. It should be one of the wonders of the world. It was evening raining and we still got such amazing pictures!! So exited to get home and frame.
You have not been to Bali if you don't go. Of everything I've seen in Bali this is the one I'll try not to forget.

Great views but there are more charming rice terraces elsewhere in Bali. We were staying in Tegallalang so we stopped off here at the end of a day of touring before returning to our villa. The view here is what I'd seen in brochures and it was gorgeous. Shame that it really isn't a charming area at all and yes, you have so many hawkers trying to sell you postcards or batik or some other crap that it's hard to find peace. Very few of the cafes that are on the rice paddy view side are open past 5pm either so we couldn't have an early dinner. We did sit down at a local cafe and had some refreshments before heading back home. It wasn't until later in our trip that there are more charming and better rice terraces near our accommodation down in Canggu that I wished I had known about earlier. If you don't have much time and you're making up trip up to Ubud or to Gunung Kintamani then this is a great stop. It's basically a 15 min stop at most.
I love tegallalang!. Tegalalang became one of my best place in Bali.Please keep such a beautiful view!
Dazzling green. Beautiful views over this area, but be aware of people trying to sell souvenirs, they are rather persistant.

very pretty even in the rain. was looking forward to seeing the rice terraces. Of course when we arrived we had a massive downpoor of rain. We sat at the little cafe waiting for it to clear. still enjoyed it!
Good scenery. It seems like one of symbol of Bali.The amazing rice terrace is so beautiful , so green and like a kind of art.

beautiful views, great for photos. When you park the car you will be hounded by locals selling carvings and sarongs that make the Kuta Markets look tame. Once you get past the hawkers you can step down into any of the many cafes and order a cold drink while you look out over the serene rice fields. Fabulous photo opportunity and it's actually very close to Ubud. There's some fabulously cheap shopping between Ubud and Tegallalang!
Nice views. Some lovely scenery - pity some ugly shops blocking it in some places.
food. Food comfort food and very friendly service love the Bakmie goreng,

Scenic. Scenic place for photo taking. Just got to endure with the 'harassment' from the street seller. USD1 for everything, it seems. If you do not want to buy, don't bother to stop and see. Just take your photographs. If you stop and see what is there to offer, the street seller will follow you all the way to your car, even you're already in your car. Scary. But that's their tactics to make you feel bad and buy things that you do not need. Other than the street seller, love this place! Green green rice terrace and clear blue sky. *thumbs up*

Another *breeaaattthhhtaking* sight. Amazing, amazing rice terraces! The greenery will automatically calm you. You can see some rice farmers working on the paddy field. We were lucky to have a picture taken with one! But be warned, the moment you stepped out of your vehicle, a handful of people will swarm towards you, trying to sell things as souvenirs. We were rather surprised coz they actually shouted the converted the cost of their items to singapore dollars/malaysian ringgit! And when I replied politely we were not keen on any, a seller snapped in his language, "Come on, it's just one dollar! not even enough for your coffee back home!" I just smiled and walked away quickly. There are plenty of shops on the strips of the road. Saunter along and you can find really good stuffs. I bought a hot pink sun hat for only S$2.50! My friends and I managed to sit outdoors and drink bottled Teh Sosro from a tiny shop, overlooking the stunning view, just basking in the ambience. Super relaxing!I'd say, Tegallalang is a MUST to visit when you're in Bali!
Beautiful!. Loved all the rice terraces in Bali. We stopped there briefly for a photo shoot on our way to the woodcarving village.
Amazing. Awesome views of the rice fields while watching the locals go about their day to day life ... Very Beautiful
awesome experience. Must do activity in Bali!! Really feel Bali experience.
Amazing!. Well worth a trip to view these terraces. Stop for lunch and a drink on the mountainside to take in and enjoy the view!

Bali King of Rice Terraces. We only stopped by Tegallalang Rice Terrace quickly after a day full of activities, right before sunset. During the approximate 30 minutes we stayed, we took photos and admired the rice terraces so it was well worth the stop. The rice terraces were lush and green & provided some spectacular opportunities for photography purposes; these provide some perfect computer background wallpapers.

Stunning Views. Well worth a drive here to enjoy the view of the rice terraces. Be prepared for people trying to sell you goods when you arrive and try to leave. Kampung Cafe is a nice place to stop and enjoy lunch with nice views as well. If you like shopping take time to stop at a few of the shops along the way, beautiful mosaics in particular.

just like in the PICS.... the rice terrace view itself is really beautiful!!even if its raining a must to see.if U just stop in Tegallalang for a short break, fine.U might can have a drink or something to bite while you watching the view.when we were visiting there were more seller than tourist wich was a bit disturbing for me.

Ricefield terrace on Culik. Stop here, to picture how is beautiful view. Bright day and so busy everyday, I think. Tips : don't start to bargain to sellers, if you are not interesting to buy. Once you bargain, they rush you until the car. If you want to buy then fine you bargain. Or just say " terima kasih "

beautiful peaceful scenic. great food, great view, great location.
Nice to indulge in food in the traditional way- sitting on a kane floor with good height table for food (which is lovely!) recommend to anyone looking for an authentic balinese experience! bit of a drive out but worth it for the view

a must do trek!!. If you prefer to have a trek instead of going for shopping in Ubud , you will a wonderful walk , worth 2/3 hours , depends of how many stops you'll do for photos!
Definitely a must do ,

Nice outlook but too busy. A lovely vista but too many touts hassling and very busy. Go to little warung called Sari Organik instead and walk through the rice fields for 900 metros and have a drink or light meal instead. Get taxi to drop you at the entry and walk up an old looking road and follow the signs.

Quintessential Bali. One of our favourite things about Bali has been the scenery on our various drives through the countryside. The rice terraces around Ubud are lovely. The trip from Seminyak to Tanah Lot is also great for viewing rice paddies.

great walking trek. now days so many small cafe and seller around the view point but when we make a walk in the rice field its a great trekking place actually and so fresh in the morning time with the fragrance of earth.

Beautiful (But could be better...). I've seen photos of much more spectacular rice terraces but if you're in the Ubud area then Tegallalang is a nice place to go for photos. My guide did say that it is not a good time of year to view them as they are not as lush and green as usual. But I still thought they were stunning!

If ever there was a postcard opportunity in Bali, this is it!. Terraced rice fields are a common sight in Bali but these are some of the most impressive and accessible from the main road. As other reviewers have commented, the vendors here can be quite keen including children selling postcards etc. It can be nice to sit and have a drink or something to eat and there are quite a few places here where you can do this. There are also a few shops selling art and craft that are worth a look if you have time. Tegallalang is on the road between Ubud and Mount Batur so it's definitely worth stopping if you are going this way anyway and is probably worth a trip from Ubud even if you're not planning to go further up the hill.

Guess we missed the rice season... After having read sooo many nice reviews about the Rice Terrace we were very interested to see it. But I guess we missed the rice season because the terraces looked dry and empty instipe of rain the previous night. There lovely restaurants along the hill slope where the viewing point is located so you can enjoy a drink there and try to run away from the hawkers or street sellers! They can be very annoying but politely say, "no thank you".. There are many stores selling home decor items on the way to Tegallalang which can make interesting stops. Many shops sell little souveniers which you will have to bargain for.. Overall the drive to Tegallalang is short from Ubud center and check the season before you go..

Its gotten touristy. When I first went here in the mid 90's the views were breathtaking... now you get bombarded with people selling things and shops blocking the views... Now I prefer to go up north to see the wonderful terraced rice fields than have to put up with the hassle... only advantage is that it is close to UBUD..if you are willing to spend more time in the car go farther...

Breathtaking Green. One cannot see this verdant hillside without holding one's breath. The labor intensity reflected by the narrow terraces, steep hillside, green rice and pooled water, literally take the breath away. We saw it on a tour, and the only detraction is the requisite sarong and postcard vendors vying so hard for the tourist dollar. One cannot blame them but they do detract.
Nice to see. If you have not seen rice terraces before, it is worth to go and have a look. I think it's along the way to Mt. Kintamani. Nice place to take pictures.

2 Minute Stop. It took us 1.5 hours to reach this place from Nusa Dua and 2 minutes to take the obligatory photos, fend of the hawkers, dodge the Japanese tourists drinking beer from the lookout point and make our way to Ubud market for some shopping. We went in December and the heat was unbearable but your mileage may vary.
Not so special since it's common. Not so special as in Asia it's quite common especially in places such as china malaysia Worse still there is many vendors around disturbing you
So beautiful. We stopped here briefly to take photos. It was surreal...so green and beautiful. There are also shops and some slightly pushy vendors. Just say no thanks....

A little disappointing. Perhaps its the wrong time to view as the rice had apparently just been harvested leaving dry and brown terraces. The terraced area is actually quite small to look at. Not worth the trip for us.
Spectacular. Go in the morning or evening and you will be rewarded with pics that are amazing.

A good scenery where you cant find at city. Bright sunshine, small roads (one lane) , no street lightings, vast fields of padi rice, simple infrastructure for people, for spring water drainage ( I heard people drink from the drainage its spring water) and we could capture a mountain and clouds in our photos
rice terrace. small compared to others but is close to ubud has dining facilities and shopping opportunities
Not to be missed. Although touristy this was a great place, we went with our own guide who had "access" to some quiet view points.

a glorious view with the most amazing colur of gree you have ever seen. It is such a beatiful view, seren, and the green colour is unlike anything you may have seen, lovely food in shady restaurant area a perfect afteroon visit.
Beautiful views. We only visited here on a tour. The views are magnicent. There is a restaurant but we did not eat so cannot comment.

a must see. Our driver dropped us off and we were breath-taken with the views. Unfortunately there are many people trying to sell you stuff, ignore them. Have lunch at one of the restaurants a little below street level and enjoy the view, definetely a must see while in Bali!

Good stop for scenery, a drink and chit chat. The rice fields are definitely beautiful, though it seems I would able to capture the whole scenery in one picture. If you choose to, you can just get off the car, take pictures and leave in 5 minutes. But for me, we saw this cafe with porches on the slopes where you can sit down, order some food and drinks and just appreciate the rice field on the other side of the slope. We had our guide who told us interesting stories about the inequality between the two side of the slopes. It's a really good place to sit and chat. So look out for the cafe. The drinks are nth more expensive than a cup of starbuck coffee.

Simply Beautiful!!!. On our recent trip to Bali our driver took us up to the rice fields just outside Ubud. This place is just spectacular & a must see if traveling through Indonesia, you most certainly won't be disappointed......we certainly weren't & would definitely go back if we return!
Beautiful. It is amazign how they have cultivated and set up their rice fields in mountain sides. Very picturesque and beautiful to see in person
What's not to like?. Well, other than some aggressive touts, it's a wonderful view. Probably the best terraced fields we've seen, and we've seen a lot of them!
One of the nicest rice terraces in Bali. We saw it as part of the Bali Eco Cycling Tour. Beautiful!!
The best !. Great view, showing a panoramic picture of the rice fields, looking down from the road.

Amazing view. We stayed at Alam Ubud Villas which is only about 10-15 minutes motorbike ride away from Tegallalang rice fields. We dropped by at the Rice Terrace Cafe and luckly got a little hut with the most amazing view ever. Sitting on the floor in our little hut was just lovely, it made the entire experience even more authentic. The food was very reasonably priced and it was just delicious! After dessert, there was even a Balinese lady who came and sold us durian - yummy (if you like durian that is). Enjoying the food and the view was just half of the adventure though - after a good meal we actually walked down and took a walk through the rice fields - this was the highlight of our afternoon. Coming by for a few minutes to take a picture of the view is simply not enough in my opinion. One would have to try and savour the entire scenery and atmosphere by truely walking through the rice fields - I certainly appreciate rice farmers a lot more now!
Breathtaking. This rice terrace is beautiful, a must see. We hired a driver for the day and went on the way up to Mt. Batur. I would highly recommend

Lush green rice terraces. Tegalalang is a village north of Ubud on the road to Kintamani. There are numerous woodwork shops on the road leading to the terraces. When you get out of your car, persistent hawkers approach you, but they leave you alone when you step down to the terraces. The terraces are carved out of steep hillside and the rice is incredibly green. If you wish to linger and take in the view, there are several cafes. There is no fee.

absolutely beautiful...but beware of locals.............. A long drive from Nua Dua to Tegallalong, but absolutely worthwhile. The terraces are amazing. All is good until you get out of the car...then 'pounce' the hawkers are on top of you, and I mean literally touching at you to buy there wares. You know...the prices were great, but i was just too scared to deal with them. Once you deal with one, you deal with everyone and I mean EVERYONE. I was keen to get back with our driver. I got some awesome pics. Well worth the trek.

Cafe Dewi, exceptional view, excellent restaurant. We enjoyed a late lunch at Cafe Dewi overlooking the Tegallalang rice terrace. The view on 7 September 2011, a very clear day, was breathtaking. The food was excellent; my Nasi Campur was delicious and my wife's Nasi Goreng was equally outstanding. The wait staff was friendly and attentive which made the experience more enjoyable. A gentle cool breeze made the dining experience perfect.

pictures are nice, atmosphere is not. if you expect to find a quiet road with a tiny cafe overlooking the rice terrace, think again. The place is packed with tour buses and cars. Vendors are everywhere and are the most aggressive I've seen in Bali. The view is nice, but if you plan to hire a driver for a day or more, you will see plenty of other rice fields (and even the occasional rice terrace) that are far more secluded, picturesque and quiet. If you really must, stop here for 10 min, take a few pictures and move on.

Most picturesque rice Terrace in Bali. We stopped to view the Tagallalang Rice Terrace on our way to Mt. Batur to start a cycling tour. The view was just amazing. Sorry we had just a short time to take it in. Highly recommend a stop here, but be prepared for agressive street sellers.

Beautiful and peaceful if you go past the rabble to Cafe Dewi. This is a very busy area, with the best vantage points in town spoiled by hawkers and small traders (sarongs and cafes) hassling you to buy as you take your photos - it looks like the best spot for photos is just below road level. BUT, if you go a little bit further north (towards Kintimani, away fro Ubud), you will find a turn off down to the right and Cafe Dewi offers a quiet spot to bide your time. For the reasonable cost of a drink, you can take your photos in peace, from what must be one of the best spots in town, and even take a few steps into the paddies if you wish. We did not sample the food due to the time of day. The kitchen and menu look simple and straightforward with reasonable prices. Others eating there expressed great satisfaction with the food.

Beautiful terraces - worth a visit if you have time. This the famous view that is well known in Bali. It is worth taking the time to stop by if you have the opportunity. It is very beautiful and impressive - you can take photos by the road.There are many vendors, but really, they didn't bother me. As soon as I said 'no thanks' they left me alone. Yes you have to ignore them to a certain degree.I'm glad we visited the area. The drive there is pretty as well, ask your driver to take the back roads where you will see the real compounds and more normal rice paddies.

Impressive area. My husband and I visited the rice terraces after reading how beautiful they were. We were not disappointed with how lovely this area was. These terraces are beautiful and it is well worth the visit. The downside is being harassed by the locals wanting you to buy their stuff. The locals were very pushy, much pushier than other areas we visited in Bali. There were even children selling postcards and one told me he can not go to school unless I buy postcards from him (did not work on me!). Once we got passed the small shops and cafes we were left alone.I think the locals add to it and it is a poor country and these people make their money from us tourists.We had lunch at a small cafe overlooking the terraces, this cafe was called Alon Alon. The food was pretty average but having the view of the terraces from your own little covered 'hut' allowed you to take in the area for a bit longer. They also had clean toilets which was a plus in an area like this. Worth the visit for sure!

Emerald green scenery. The rice field scenery was as beautiful as the pics. There's also an outdoor cafe where you can look at the surrounding views while sipping a cup of coffee or tea. The cafe was packed when I went there and unfortunately it rained, so I didn't get a chance to stay a little longer

Small patch of terrace- Overall waste of time. I am surprised this is being pitched as a major sightseeing attraction. This is ok enough if you are on a day long sightseeing trip and Tegallalang is on the way. Good for a 2 min stop. It overlooks a 300 mt long patch of rice terrace. Hawkers hound you constantly throughout so you cant enjoy the stop in peace. Not worth going out of the way...and rest assured if you driving down to Kintamani etc, you will get to see lots of rice fields n terraces along the way.
Gorgeous rice terraces, 20 minutes from Ubud. Couldn't recommend this more -- although it has rather too many aggressive vendors working the road, it's nevertheless a lovely space.
Really nice views. We have a driver that takes us to the terraces and it worth the visit. It’s a pretty cool sightsee.
Lunch at Cafe Dewi. We enjoyed the views of the Tegallalang Rice Terrace over lunch at this cafe. The food was quite delicious and the decor was simplistic, but enhanced the view very well.
Sit down and relax. Stop have a cold drink enjoy the view and relax clears the mind

One of the best on Bali. These are the rice fields on the picture of the Bali and Ubud Tripadvisor page. Just outside Ubud you find this magnificent rice fields. Rice fields never seems to get borring and after seeing many of them here on Bali I still love to see more. The Tegallalang Rice Fields are definitely one of the best rice fields on Bali. The way these rice fields clime up to the mountain is breathtaking. It is perfect for a quick stop as you can not really walk through the fields and you can only watch them from one spot close to the road. The vendors of course try to sell you all sorts of nonsense, but you can just ignore them. You cannot miss these rice fields when you are in Bali.

WAT a lovely rice terrace. when i look on postcard about bali, i always ask in my heart, where can i find those beautiful rice terrace......... wow Tegalalang is the answerVery beautiful rice terrace... very beatiful... just sit enjoy ur drink or meal on the resto beside...

Nice View but pushy vendors ruin it. It's truly gorgeous. i was disappointed you couldn't walk into the area, but it must be someone's rice field farm and private property which is fine. As soon as we got out of the van we were swarmed by locals to buy post cards and batik sarongs. They would never leave us alone. This has never happened to me in Ubud after 3 visits.

Had a heavy rain but beautiful. It feels just like the good old japanese rural districts.On our way to get there, we had really really heavy rain!!! The road was like a river!!!!The water came out from the drain ditch of the side road like small fountains!!!!!The weather was pretty bad actually but I had an unforgettable moment.

Not impressive enough. On our way up to Mount Batur, we stopped for 15 at the side of Tegalalang (not Tegallalang). The terraced field can be seen just beside the road. However, tall coconut trees planted beside the field flawed the good view. The information we had stating Tegalalang is 500 m above sea level, which cannot be linked to the hot and sweaty weather we experienced there (suppost to be colder, right?). The farmers just finished harvesting, leaving behind brown and muddy field by the time we visit the field. The view would be better one month earlier when the paddy just turned into golden in colour and about to be harvested.Our advice, stop there for a while is ok, but it's not worth to have a lunch or dinner there. Mount Batur is the place that we should stop for a longer time to take a break. For more of our experience in Bali, please visit our blog at http://bettyandlingshing.blogspot.com/2009/12/bali-01.html

Short and sweet visit on a tourist-trodden path but still culturally insightful & beautiful. We, like others, also stopped off here as part of a hired taxi tour. After Mt. Batur volcano, our guide took us to the rice paddy fields which you can always imagine but is far more impressive in real life. To see the countryside carved into terraces is very impressive.Next to the terraces is a pretty waterfall which was quite weak during the time (dry season) and alongside are the houses of the village which are held up on what seem like very feeble sticks. As this is a well-trodden tourist path, we were harassed by many villagers trying to sell us souvenirs and even constant 'No thanks', shaking heads and simply ignoring them weren't enough to put them off so you should be prepared to tolerate them until you get back into your car.Other than that, everything added to the overall experience of the village and it is this that I am recommending people.
